title: Ensemble-Based Methodology for Breast Cancer Detection
authors: Dharmendra Kumar, Mukesh Kumar, Saurabh Arora, Shashank Singh, Shreeya Gautam, Bishakha Pathak, Kritagya Parajuli
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Early and accurate detection of breast cancer is essential for enhancing the results of treatment and patient survival rates. With the advancement of machine learning (ML) techniques, there is growing interest in leveraging computational models to enhance diagnostic accuracy across various medical imaging modalities. This study examines the use of machine learning (ML) algorithms for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), ultrasound, and mammography in the identification of breast cancer. Core ML concepts, including supervised learning algorithms such as logistic regression (LR), decision tree (DT), support vector machines (SVM), random forest (RF), artificial neural networks (ANN), and convolutional neural networks (CNN), are applied and evaluated on publicly available datasets. The classification performance of each model is analyzed based on accuracy. SVM achieved the highest accuracy of 96.50%, followed closely by LR, ANN, and bagging ensemble methods, each with 95.10%. DT and RF classifiers demonstrated accuracies of 93.72% and 93.71%, respectively. In contrast, the CNN model yielded a comparatively lower accuracy of 62.93%, likely due to a lack of spatial structure in the dataset. These findings highlight the suitability of SVM and ensemble methods for breast cancer classification tasks in structured data environments. Beyond performance metrics, the study discusses clinical challenges such as data privacy, algorithmic bias, and model interpretability. Future research directions include integrating multimodal data sources and developing personalized risk prediction models. Additionally, imaging features were extracted from both cancerous and noncancerous samples, resulting in effective classification. This work contributes to advancing ML-based diagnostic tools and supports improved breast cancer screening practices.

title: Design and Implementation of an Intelligent Enhancement System for Fundus Image Quality
authors: Wenxi Li, Xuantao Zhang, Fangyuan Lin, Guangxin Zhao, Boqiang Zhang, Qian Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: The inference accuracy of deep learning models in fundus disease diagnosis is highly dependent on the quality of input images and the effectiveness of features. This study proposes an intelligent fundus image enhancement system based on the RealESRGAN super-resolution algorithm. By integrating multi-scale vessel enhancement, adaptive illumination correction, and a multi-dimensional quality assessment module, a lightweight visual interactive interface is built relying on the Tkinter framework. The system achieves automated full-process optimization of fundus images, covering preprocessing, super-resolution reconstruction, and post-processing enhancement. The core innovation of the system lies in the design of customized algorithms for the anatomical characteristics of fundus images, including green channel directional enhancement and multi-scale Frangi vessel extraction. Through the collaborative integration of traditional image processing and deep learning models, the system improves image resolution while accurately preserving key clinical structures such as blood vessels and the optic disc. Fifty clinical fundus images (including normal fundus, diabetic retinopathy, and glaucoma cases) were selected for testing. Experimental results show that the system can increase image sharpness by an average of 53.9%, contrast by 65.1%, and illumination uniformity by 19.1%. The comprehensive quality score rises from 0.58 to 0.88, providing high-quality image support for subsequent clinical diagnosis.

title: HifiDiff: Two Stream Diffusion Models for High Fidelity Speech Generation of Unseen Languages
authors: Lhuqita Fazry, Kurniawati Azizah, Dipta Tanaya, Ayu Purwarianti, Dessi Lestari, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: Speech generation aims to produce synthetic speech that mimics natural speech's properties. However, pitch inaccuracies exist in voiced and unvoiced sounds when the trained model is conditioned on unseen languages. This paper proposes HifiDiff, a two-stream diffusion model for separately generating voiced and unvoiced sounds. Our approach outperforms the baseline method in most unseen language datasets for the mean opinion score (MOS) metric. This result concludes the effectiveness of our approach to resolving the problem of speech generation in unseen languages.

title: Stage-Wise Acoustic-Linguistic Fine-Tuning for Overlapped Speech Recognition: Does Ordering Matter?
authors: Saddam Annais Shaquille, Dessi Puji Lestari, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: Recognizing speech when multiple individuals speak simultaneously remains a significant challenge for Automatic Speech Recognition systems. While modern architectures integrating audio model and large language model show promise, the best way to fine-tune these models is not fully explored. This study investigates whether fine-tuning the language model first, the audio model first, or both components jointly yields the best results. Our results demonstrate that the fine-tuning order is a critical factor. The strategy of adapting the language model first achieves the highest performance with a Word Error Rate of 8.96 %. This surpasses the 9.62 % WER obtained when the audio model is trained first. This performance advantage is also apparent when using LoRA. These results establish a hierarchy of fine-tuning strategies and highlight a key trade-off between transcription accuracy and computational efficiency for practical applications.

title: Machine Learning based Energy Selective Surface Design Excluding Contradictory Structure
authors: Seung-Heon Oh, Ic-Pyo Hong
abstract: In this paper, a machine-learning based methodology is proposed that automatically excludes point-to-point patterns in energy selective surfaces (ESS), to achieve a manufacturable ESS operating in the 2~4 GHz band. This approach enhances the efficiency of machine learning by detecting and excluding contradictory structures during the data set generation process, also deriving a practically manufacturable ESS structure. The simulation result in Ansys HFSS confirms that the resulting ESS exhibits an insertion loss of 0.14 dB and a shielding effectiveness of 32.8 dB at 3.33 GHz. This work presents a practical approach to expedite the optimization of ESS while ensuring concurrent manufacturability.

title: Tissue-Specific Modelling Reveals Metabolic Shifts in Metformin-Treated T2D Blood Cells
authors: Satyajit Beura, Amit Kumar Das, Amit Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) has emerged as a global pandemic, affecting millions of people worldwide. This is primarily characterized by dysregulated insulin signalling and elevated blood glucose levels. The increased glucose level in the body fluid can damage various tissues and organs in the human body. Metformin is the first-line treatment used to manage high blood glucose levels in patients with T2D. In this study, we performed transcriptomic analysis followed by tissue-specific metabolic modelling to uncover metabolic alterations in the blood cells of metformin-treated T2D patients. To understand the metabolic consequences, we integrated transcriptomic data into the HumanGEM model using the tINIT algorithm. The reconstructed models were subjected to Differential Flux Analysis (DFA) to map the altered metabolism in blood cells. The DFA revealed improved flux through carbohydrate metabolism, including glucose, sucrose and galactose metabolism. This indicated the improved glucose metabolism and insulin signalling in blood cells of metformin-treated T2D patients. In addition, the blood cells also showed an improved amino acid metabolism, which may lead to the synthesis of cellular proteins and enzymes. Further, there is reduced activity in fatty acid oxidation, leukotriene metabolism, and vitamin biosynthesis pathways in treated cells. These alterations suggest reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and overall improved cellular metabolic health. This study demonstrates how integrating transcriptomics with genome-scale metabolic modelling provides insight into metabolic shifts in blood cells under metformin treatment. These key metabolic alterations may serve as potential therapeutic targets or biomarkers for T2D progression.

title: A Trust-Based Blockchain Framework for Mitigating Smartphone Theft Incidents
authors: Erukala Suresh Babu, Banoth Krishna Mohan Naik, Aguru Aswani Devi, Erukala Sudarshan
abstract: In today's digital age, mobile phones are vital for communication, navigation, and productivity, but their growing role as data repositories makes them prime targets for theft, leading to financial loss, privacy breaches, and operational disruptions. Traditional prevention methods often lack robust data protection and are vulnerable to unauthorized access. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a blockchain based mobile theft detection system using Hyper ledger Fabric, a permissioned blockchain platform. The system assigns each mobile device a unique identifier (UID) upon registration and securely stores metadata, such as location and status, on the blockchain. In case of theft, the owner can report the incident, triggering smart contracts to update the device's status and notify network participants in real time. This decentralized approach ensures that stolen devices are flagged and blocked across participating networks. Additionally, the system supports secure ownership transfer, reducing fraud and enhancing trust in the mobile ecosystem.

title: Design of L-band Radar Module Assembly
authors: G. Kim, J. Heo, T. Lee, J. Kim, S. Lee, S. Park
abstract: Recently, advanced radar companies are using technology to develop and scalable radars in module units, and this called a radar module assembly (RMA). Modular scaling of radars allows for greater scalability, allow to be designed to meet various requirements and by maintaining them in modular units also reducing the time required for maintenance and repairs.In this paper, a L-band modular 16-channel direct RF sampling and full-digital T/R module (DTRM) with a high power output and an array antenna module were designed considering the scalability of radar, and evaluated the performance through near-field measurements.

title: Enhancing Thermal Imaging Accuracy for Power System Maintenance
authors: Hasanka Gayan Somaweera, Gethwan Suriyawansa, Rusira Thilakarathna, Charithri Yapa, Nimantha Madhushan, Hasith Liyanage
abstract: Accurate temperature measurement of electrical components is crucial for the health monitoring of electrical components for periodic maintenance. Traditional thermal cameras can apply a single emissivity value across the entire image. This gives an inaccurate reading due to different kinds of materials and factors like elevation from sea level, environmental temperature, and relative humidity. This makes analyzing a large number of thermal images ineffective. This research presents a novel method for machine learning-based object identification by practically applying formulas to increase accuracy considering all the factors. The proposed method can dynamically adjust the emissivity values based on the characteristics on the materials and the environmental conditions. The results show a significant improvement in the temperature of each component. This can improve better monitoring of components health as well as optimize the maintenance schedules. This leads to increase the reliability and efficiency of the electrical systems for periodic maintenance in the electrical industry.

title: CoT-Driven Knowledge Distillation for Fault Diagnosis in Mineral Processing Equipment
authors: Xiaochen Wang, Aziguli Wulamu, Chentian Zhang, Xin Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated exceptional reasoning capabilities in complex fault diagnosis tasks, but their massive parameter requirements hinder deployment in resource-constrained industrial environments. To address this challenge, this study proposes a Chain-of-Thought (CoT)-driven reasoning distillation framework for transferring logical inference capabilities from large teacher models to lightweight student models. By leveraging LLMs as teachers, structured reasoning chains containing multi-step diagnostic logic are elicited through meticulously designed prompts. Alarm signals are then used as inputs, with the reasoning chains encapsulated within ¡reasoning¿ tags serving as critical supervisory signals. The final diagnostic work orders and reasoning chains constitute a comprehensive instruction-tuning dataset. To enhance model generalization, semantic-preserving paraphrasing is employed to augment input signals. Experimental results demonstrate that the distilled student models achieve significant accuracy improvements while maintaining reasoning trace fidelity comparable to teacher models. This research establishes a feasible pathway for deploying interpretable AI diagnostic systems on industrial edge devices with limited computational resources.

title: Automatic Examination of Satellite Collected Environmental Data with Deep Transfer Learning
authors: Vickram A S
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Recently, a number of measures are taken to examine the environmental data using various techniques, like image based approaches and the sensor assisted techniques. The image based techniques are very common in environmental data monitoring particularly with the support of satellite images. This work aims to analyse the forest/ridge satellite images with deep-learning (DL) scheme. This analysis is necessary to plan the bridge and to preserve the forest regions during the construction. This research proposed DL-model based approach to classify the images and this system consist the following sections; data collection and initial processing, features extraction with DL-model and SoftMax based detection, generation of Ensemble-Features (EF), and implementing classification with 3-fold based cross validation. This work considered the VGG, ResNet, and DenseNet models for the analysis and helped to achieve an accuracy of >98% when EF and random-forest classifier is executed.

title: A Dual-Band Dual-Polarized Meta-Lens Antenna for Sub-6-GHz Wireless Communications
authors: Yuehui Cui, Jiaying Du
abstract: A dual-band dual-polarized meta-lens antenna is proposed for Sub-6-GHz wireless communications in this paper. The meta-lens antenna consists of a newly designed wideband meta-lens and a dual-band dual-polarized feed antenna operating at 1.7-2.2 GHz and 3.4-3.8 GHz. The meta element of the meta-lens integrates tightly coupled and real-time distance delay lines to achieve broadband transmission performance, aiming to address the narrow bandwidth limitation in traditional dual-band meta-lenses. To enhance transmission performance for oblique incidence, a copper rod and two layers of Frequency Selective Surfaces (FSS) are introduced to the meta element. The proposed meta-lens antenna demonstrates high-gain performance across the dual operation bands.

title: Deepfake Detection Using ResNet50V2 with Machine Unlearning Integration
authors: Md Serajun Nabi, Dema Yuden, Mohammad Faizal Ahmad Fauzi
abstract: The advent of deepfake content has been an enormous challenge in digital media security that necessitates an effective detection system. This study proposes a deepfake detection model based on ResNet50V2 with an associated machine unlearning (MUL) approach to enable selective forgetting of generated data. The model is trained and evaluated on the FaceForensics- 1600 dataset, which consists of real and deepfake video frames, and then undergoes a retraining phase, excluding the forgetting set. Performance before and after unlearning is quantified in terms of classification reports, confusion matrices, and ROC curves. Experimental results show that the model maintains an accuracy of 96% and ROC-AUC of 97% even after unlearning. These findings suggest that MUL can complement model adaptability in dynamic data environments. It also supports compliance with data privacy laws requiring data deletion. The results demonstrate that practical unlearning can be applied to deepfake detection systems without impacting performance, offering a promising solution for ethically adaptive and privacypreserving AI.

title: Water Quality Prediction Using Ensemble Learning for Sustainable Resource Management
authors: Vakula Rani J, Kiran Kumari Pati, Aishwarya Jakka, Kwatham Srikar Reddy, Haifa Ali Saeed Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Access to clean and safe water is critical for maintaining public health, preserving ecosystems, and supporting sustainable development. Effective water quality monitoring and management are essential for lowering health hazards to people, enhancing water treatment processes, and guaranteeing sustainable resource use. This study presents a data-driven approach that utilizes ensemble learning (EL) to predict water quality and assess safety levels. By leveraging historical water quality data and multiple machine learning models, the system captures complex relationships among key indicators, improving prediction accuracy and adaptability across various environmental settings. A key contribution of this research is the integration of a novel hybrid feature selection technique, which enhances model performance and the interpretability. Through extensive error analysis, the framework demonstrates strong generalizability and robustness. This work offers a practical and reliable approach to modern water quality assessment, contributing to both environmental sustainability and public health protection.

title: ZK-Rollups and State Channels Comparison for Healthcare Data Privacy and Scalability
authors: Jahanzeb Shahid, Stelvio Cimato, Muslim Jameel Syed
abstract: The rapid proliferation of blockchain-based systems frequently necessitates a decision to replace configurable private blockchains with more secure, scalable, and decentralized blockchains. In the case of healthcare data, ensuring privacy is very challenging due to strict data policies and regulations. Private blockchain solutions are emerging due to their transparency, immutability, and customization features. A consortium-based permissioned blockchain is an optimal solution to provide the security of healthcare data. However, ensuring privacy and scalability is important and challenging as well. For scalability, different Layer-2 blockchain approaches have been discussed. In this article, we compare two layer-2 blockchain approaches (ZK-Rollups and zk-state channels) in terms of throughput, latency, complexity, and manageability for a healthcare data sharing model.

title: AI-Powered Cervical Cancer Assistant for Personalized Test Recommendations
authors: Jeyakani P, Sughan M, Kishore Kumar S
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: One of the most curable and preventable, but still a lethal condition affecting the female population around the world and it is considered to be cervical cancer, especially in places where there aren't many resources. A big part of improving survival rates is finding out about diseases early and making sure that medical advice is clear. This paper proposes an enhanced framework that integrates generative AI, language models, and dialoguebased patient interaction, addressing substantial deficiencies in existing systems and advancing current AI-driven diagnostic methodologies. To accurately ascertain the necessity for additional cervical cancer screening in patients, we initially transform structured tabular patient data into natural language prompts for advanced biomedical language models. Second, we teach. However, the models demonstrate how to determine whether additional tests are required. Diagnosis specific recommendations for follow-up tests. patient depending regarding their healthcare background. Our most. Relevant input is multilingual artificial intelligence. A communication system that would facilitate patient comprehension of their tests. The findings suggest the most appropriate clinical interventions in a manner that. is clear and shows empathy. Our method is much more. patients perceive it as a true, readable and fascinating. Expansive and superior to the conventional machine learning approach. Language modeils are applied under the conditions without many or any examples. We describe a scalable and privacy-aware framework that is patient-centric. The diagnosis of cervical cancer will promote the objective. AI-based comprehensive healthcare.

title: Cross-Domain Effects on Syntactic Ambiguity Processing by Chinesemandarin Speaking Children
authors: Yu Jue, Zhang Xiaoxue
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: This study examined the cross-domain transfer from music competence to syntactic ambiguity resolution in Mandarinspeaking children, aiming to elucidate the interactive mechanisms between music and language processing. Altogether, 31 Mandarin-speaking children (aged 6.9 to 13.1) were recruited and 30 adults (aged 18 to 23.6) as a control group. Each participant completed two empirical tasks: syntactic disambiguation test and music test. Accuracy and reaction time in the two tasks were measured and analyzed. The results showed: firstly, most children at this age cannot yet fully obtain adult-like transfer benefits from their music competence to complex linguistic tasks, and such benefits may diminish without constant music training. Secondly, despite the imperfect transfer, a strong relationship between musicianship and the resolution of homophonous sentences was exhibited among the child participants. Finally, from a developmental perspective, children's syntactic processing competence developed with age, with girls processing ambiguous sentences more efficiently than boys.

title: Mobile-Oriented Fusion of Inertial Neural Networks and Visual Localization
authors: Qi Zhang, Lingxiang Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In the context of intelligent Internet of Things (IoT) systems, accurate and continuous mobile localization in complex indoor environments remains a critical challenge. To address this, an AI-enhanced multi-sensor fusion framework is introduced, integrating deep inertial neural networks with ARCore-based visual positioning for edge-aware mobile devices. The architecture leverages a Multi-State Constraint Kalman Filter augmented with bidirectional learning-driven compensation, enabling seamless transition between vision-dominated and inertial-only modes under dynamic environmental conditions. Designed for real-time execution on resource-constrained IoT platforms, the system employs a lightweight fusion engine that balances computational efficiency with estimation fidelity. Experimental results across diverse indoor scenarios—including low-light, texture-deprived, and visually occluded settings—demonstrate significant improvements in positioning accuracy and trajectory continuity, validating its suitability for large-scale deployment in smart building, logistics, and autonomous service robotics applications.

title: Hi-CLIP: Fine-Grained Alignment with Hierarchical Semantic Pyramids
authors: Yuanxin Lin, Haoxi Zhang, Xiaolong Wang, Edward Szczerbicki
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training (CLIP) has emerged as a foundational model in computer vision and multimodal learning, leveraging contrastive techniques to synchronize visual and textual modalities effectively. However, a critical bottleneck for vision-language models lies in understanding local regions, where global image-level perception struggles to respond to specified areas and local representations are easily confounded by background interference. To address this, this paper proposes a novel architecture that integrates negative sample learning with hierarchical semantic alignment. We first design a panoptic negative sample learning mechanism, which constructs highly correlated hard negative pairs by mining semantic relationships between different regions within the same image, thereby effectively enhancing the model's discriminative capability for local details. Concurrently, we introduce a hierarchical semantic pyramid alignment framework, which establishes independent contrastive learning objectives across four semantic levels: global image, scene components, object instances, and attributes/materials, achieving comprehensive semantic alignment from macro to micro perspectives. Experimental validation on benchmark datasets for tasks like image categorization and cross-modal retrieval confirms the superiority of our method over existing solutions, with notable improvements in accuracy and robustness.

title: Splitting strategy based optimization algorithm for solving robots cell cycle scheduling problem
authors: Xiaohui Li, Yuchen Liu, Yuan Dong
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper explores the periodic scheduling problem in robot manufacturing units, considering constraints like multiple handling robots and "no waiting" time window characteristics. The research strives to address a global optimization challenge that integrates production line scheduling design and robot handling scheduling, aiming to minimize processing cycle time. To attain these objectives, a load-carrying initialization encoding, grounded in a splitting strategy, is introduced. To enhance computational efficiency, we incorporate the inter-zone handling processes derived from the splitting strategy into a mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model, solving it with CPLEX. The algorithm framework utilizes an adaptive iterative neighborhood search algorithm (S-AILS) rooted in a splitting strategy, proposing various transformation search strategies both within and across regions. We introduce interval optimal records to store the currently found optimal solution, using this saved solution as the starting point for iterative optimization, thus eliminating redundant searches. The algorithm's efficiency and effectiveness are validated through benchmark problems and dataset experiments.

title: U6G IBFD Antenna with Digital-Assisted Cancellation
authors: Hongji Fan, Yiqiu Liang, Zhiqiang Yu, Jianyi Zhou
abstract: This paper introduces an in-band full-duplex (IBFD) antenna designed for future U6G applications. In the antenna domain, an out of phase power divider is employed to suppress the self-interference signal, effectively achieving 40 dB passive self-interference cancellation. Additionally, in the analog domain, a digital-assisted cancellation scheme is implemented to enhance decoupling effects. To verify the cancellation effect, an IBFD transceiver system is established. The measurement results indicate that the proposed antenna system demonstrates high isolation levels, exceeding 67 dB within the frequency range of 6.4 to 6.8 GHz. The proposed system architecture is expected to be applied in in-band full-duplex systems.

title: ClassiED: Improving Zero-Shot Event Detection by Reducing LLM Hallucination
authors: Yan Yu, Shiyu Fang, Jibing Wu, Mao Wang, Ningchao Ge, Jiaxuan Liu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Event detection (ED) is defined as the process of identifying events through the extraction and annotation of specific trigger words. The hallucination problem of large language models (LLMs) has been shown to lead to suboptimal performance in event detection tasks. To address the issues LLMs encounter when processing specialized domains, this paper proposes an event detection framework called ClassiED, which achieves this by synergistically integrating BERT-based text classification with LLMs reasoning capabilities. The method adopts a two-stage architecture: first, a BERT-based event discriminator filters out non-event sentences to prevent LLMs from producing false positives due to domain knowledge limitations; subsequently, an event detector optimizes prompt engineering to extract text inputs that generate results consistent with the event ontology, enabling zero-shot event type and trigger factor identification using LLMs without domain-specific fine-tuning. Comprehensive evaluations on the MNEE dataset, characterized by a large number of non-event sentences in the military domain, demonstrate that ClassiED achieves an event distinction accuracy (Acc) of 81.83%, an event identification F1 score (EI) of 93.33%, and significant improvements in trigger detection metrics.

title: Forecasting Air Quality Index Using an Enhanced Extreme Learning Machine Based on Genetic Algorithms
authors: D. Sharada Mani, V. Vara Prasad, D. Bujjibabu, V. Anusha
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: For a long time, air quality has been a big problem for the environment. Machine learning AQI prediction systems help look at air quality trends on a larger scale. It is challenging to assess air quality with a single machine learning model when the AQI varies. A genetic algorithm-based enhanced extreme learning machine (GA-KELM) prediction approach fixes this. Kernel approach generates hidden layer output matrix kernel matrix. Kernel limit learning machine hidden nodes and layers are improved using genetic algorithms. This overcomes the problem of the typical limit learning machine's too many hidden nodes and unpredictable thresholds and weights making training difficult. Root mean square error, weights, and thresholds comprise the fitness function. Lastly, least squares is used to figure out the model output weights. Genetic algorithms find the best answer in the search space and improve model performance by optimising it over and over again. The optimised kernel extreme learning machine predicts SO2, NO2, PM10, CO, O3, PM2.5 concentrations, and AQI compared to CMAQ, SVM, and DBN-BP using basic data from a Chinese metropolitan monitoring station's longterm air quality prediction. Results demonstrate the suggested model trains quicker and predicts better. BILSTM extension optimises feature weight both ways.

title: Integrating FDES-DPSIR Framework for Evidence-Based Climate Risk Assessment and Causal Modeling in Indonesia
authors: Muhammad Miftakhul Romadlon, Miya Irawati, Taufiq Asyhari
abstract: Climate change poses complex and interconnected risks that demand structured, data-driven approaches to support effective adaptation and sustainable development. This study introduces a new integrated framework for assessing climate vulnerability in Indonesia by combining the Framework for the Development of Environment Statistics and the Driving Forces-Pressure-State-Impact-Response (DPSIR) model. The framework leverages diverse data from 2014 to 2023, integrating socio-economic statistics and satellite-derived environmental indicators mapped to the DPSIR structure for analysis. To analyze causal relationships among vulnerability components, Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling was applied, revealing significant pathways along the DPSIR sequence. Notably, socio-economic drivers exerted strong direct effects on environmental pressures, while environmental degradation indirectly influenced institutional responses through its link to climate-related risks such as flooding and drought. A composite Integrated Climate Vulnerability Index was developed using the Entropy Weight Method to quantify spatio-temporal vulnerability patterns across Indonesian provinces. Results show a national decline in vulnerability between 2014 and 2020, followed by a modest rebound in the years following the COVID19 pandemic. However, regional disparities persisted; eastern provinces, including Papua and East Nusa Tenggara, consistently exhibited high vulnerability. The evaluation demonstrates that integrating structured frameworks with statistical modeling supports evidence-based, region-specific climate adaptation and sustainable development planning.

title: Advanced Three-Axis Shake Table System for Comprehensive Earthquake Simulation and Structural Dynamics Research
authors: Ashvinda Iddamalgoda, Dulan Sashik, Anuradha Jayakody, Nalin Manchanayake, Pradeep K.W. Abeygunawardhana, Raj Prasanna
abstract: The development of a three-axis shake table is essential for advancing research in sensor validation, earthquake engineering, and structural dynamics. Traditional shake tables that exist provide one or two-dimensional motion where it limits the capability of three-dimensional (3D) movements in experiments conducted by engineers, researchers and users. This paper presents the design and development of a cost-effective 3-axis shake table which has the ability to produce independent motions in the X, Y and Z directions. The shake table consists of three dynamic plates, each axis supported by dual linear guides and driven by separate DC motors with a 12V voltage rating. This independent configuration of the axis allows the users for a precise control and generation of vibrations across all three axes, making it suitable for a wide range of testing applications. The design utilizes motor drivers for varying power to the motors and control the movement of the dynamic plates independently, which omits the requirement of encoders and reduce the production cost. The developed shake table offers a versatile and cost-effective solution for laboratories, earthquake engineering and structural health monitoring, where 3D motion capabilities are essential.

title: Blockchain Hash Pattern Behaviour Analysis for Malicious Detection in Vehicular File Sharing
authors: Kishore Chandra Dev Nakka, Allan Dino J
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Vehicular Networks – VANETs are significant in sharing the information between vehicles on road These types of networks are specifically designed to enhance road safety and to avoid congestion of vehicles. Hence successful and secured transfer of files are essential. The advanced cryptographic techniques in blockchain enhances security of the VANETs. The smart contract mechanism and immutable feature aids in improving the secured transmissions. Conventionally research in VANET is carried out by simulating the environment and the performance is analyzed using its traces. Introduction of blockchain hash and smart contract enhances the security and hence this paper focuses on the behavioural analysis of blockchain hash and smart contract in the detection of Malicious nodes using machine learning algorithms. Regression models are used for training the network and the accuracy achieved is 0.99 for linear regression and 1.0 for gradient boosting and random forest network.

title: Energy-Conscious Edge-Assisted IOT Communication Framework Leveraging 5G and AI Technologies
authors: S Parvathi, Ch. Mastan Chowdry, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, K Srividya Subash Chand, CH Srivardhan Kumar, J. Jebastine
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The intersection of 5G and the Internet of Things (IoT) has also presented fresh opportunities in real-time connectivity and, at the same time, compounded the issue of energy efficiency, latency and intelligent data management. Traditional IoT communication models are mostly based on centralized cloud infrastructure, which leads to significant energy consumption and communication latency, especially in the large-scale implementation. The proposed research project addresses these issues by proposing an Energy-Conscious EdgeAssisted IoT Communication Framework that holistically combines 5G connectivity and Artificial Intelligence (AI)driven optimization mechanisms. In the proposed framework, edge intelligence is used, in which AI models at the network edge do predictive load balancing, adaptive bandwidth allocation, energy-aware task offloading to reduce redundant transmissions and optimize power consumption. A deep reinforcement learning (DRL) module changes resource allocation policies in real time based on traffic and channel circumstances, giving it realtime adaptability. With the help of experimental analysis in different network conditions, it is seen that the proposed system would have saved around 42 percent of energy consumption, 35 percent improved data throughput, and 28 percent reduced communication latency in contrast to conventional cloud-centric IoT structures. These results indicate that AI-powered decision intelligence and edge and 5G networks can create a scalable, sustainable, and high-performance communication model that is appropriate in the future IoT environments in smart cities, health, and industrial automation.

title: LTE Bands for Human Presence Detection Using Software-Defined Radio
authors: Allen Gabriel T. Estorque, Miguel Leo S. Malibiran, Kurt Louis A. Mariano, Krizelle Anne Lou M. Recinto, Alyza Joyce D. Sones, Josyl Mariela R. Reyes, Jehiel D. Santos
abstract: Human presence detection has various applications, with most existing methods relying on fixed-frequency RF signals like Wi-Fi, limiting transmitter-receiver distance. This study investigates the feasibility of using 4G Long Term Evolution (LTE) bands such as bands 28, 3, 1, and 41 for human presence detection in indoor environments. LTE signal data were collected during video call sessions using a Software-Defined Radio (SDR). Support Vector Machine (SVM) models were trained and evaluated on 0 vs. 1 person, 0 vs. 3 person, and 0 vs. 1 vs. 3 or multiple classifications per band. Results show that band 41, which has the highest frequency range, provides better accuracy in detecting human presence for 0 vs. 3 and multi-person classification, while Band 28, which has the lowest frequency range, performs better for detecting no-person scenarios. This highlights the impact of LTE frequency variation on human presence and crowd density detection.

title:
Medium-Power Amplifier for the 17-22 GHz Band Designed for High oIP
                    <sub>3</sub>
authors: Giovanni Di Pietrantonio, Andrea Malignaggi, Corrado Carta
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a 20 GHz medium-power amplifier realized in a 130 nm SiGe BiCMOS technology. To enhance the third-order intercept point (oIP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) of the proposed differential amplifier, an accurate analysis of the bias conditions of the driving stage has been carried out. Experimental measurements confirm high linearity across the frequency band of interest, particularly at the center frequency, where the amplifier achieves an oIP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> of 26.8 dBm and a 1 dB compression point of 13.1 dBm. To the best knowledge of the authors, this amplifier demonstrates the highest oIP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> among reported silicon-based amplifiers operating at comparable frequencies.

title: Wrist-Worn Frequency-Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) Radar for Respiration Monitoring
authors: Iou-Heng Chen, Ting-Chun Wang, Ting-Fang Zheng, Ji-Xun Zhong, Ju-Yin Shih, Fu-Kang Wang
abstract: This study proposes a method for monitoring respiratory activity using a wrist-worn radar-sensing module— one of the first to explore wrist-based respiration sensing with radar. During inhalation and exhalation, the expansion and contraction of the thoracic cavity drive the movements of the pectoralis major muscle, which, in turn, transmit subtle displacements to the skin surface of the upper limbs through fascial connections with various body regions. These displacements can be detected using a commercial millimeter-wave radar module. In this study, respiration-sensing experiments were conducted on the upper arm, wrist, and back of the hand, with a respiration belt used as the reference signal. The results demonstrated that the respiratory rate can be reliably estimated at all three locations, with the wrist and back of the hand showing superior performance and exhibiting potential for integration into wearable devices.

title: Preserving and Disseminating Architectural Knowledge: An Immersive Virtual Learning Hub for Thai Vernacular Houses
authors: Jaturong Chitiyaphol, Kanyarat Kwiecien, Sutthinan Chuenchom, Intira Phrompan, Nawapon Kaewsuwan, Komgrit Rumdon
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: Thai vernacular architecture blends cultural identity, environmental adaptation, and craftsmanship passed down thru generations. The deterioration of traditional Thai dwellings and limited access to physical structures have restricted opportunities for students and scholars to study this unique heritage. This project developed a 3D virtual reality knowledge hub and learning materials for traditional Thai dwellings to preserve and share architectural expertise. The research used the ADDIE instructional design model to analyze the teaching practices of 21 Thai architecture professors and create 3D virtual models based on real dwellings. The virtual environment allows students to explore architectural details and interact with structures thru realistic visualization. Student satisfaction was evaluated by 45 students. The study results show that virtual reality enhances student engagement, understanding, and access to cultural heritage learning materials, as well as helping to preserve local wisdom. This study demonstrates how digital learning innovation can revitalize architectural knowledge and promote sustainable cultural education at the higher education level.

title: Deep Neural Networks-Optimized Risk Forecasting Unit for Dynamic Management Planning
authors: R. Meenakshi, S. Mallikarjunaiah, Nakul Sharma, Parveen Sharma, Sateesh Yalavarthi, V.S. Prasad Kandi
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Risk Forecasting Unit with Deep Neural Networks optimization presented in this paper was used to determine the dynamic management planning, based on Hybrid Deep Neural Network (H-DNN) with Transfer Learning and Reinforcement Learning embedded. The proposed model is a fusion of the Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) model that is used to analyze spatial risk and the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network that is capable of capturing the temporal risk. The proposed model is able to take both the spatial and sequential data into consideration. Transfer Learning makes training faster and provides a better generalization of the model, whereas Reinforcement Learning makes the model fit the real-time data, which allows risk forecasting to keep improving constantly. PyTorch was used to develop the model, and provides a flexible and scalable model to large datasets. The experimental findings have shown that the H-DNN model is more accurate and has a smaller Mean Absolute Error (MAE) when compared with the conventional methods including the Random Forest, Deep Neural Networks (DNN) and Support Vector Machines (SVM). The suggested methodology is prospective in promising the optimization of risk prognostication in variable and intricate management situations.

title: High Flame Retardant and High Mechanical Strength Epoxy Insulation Composites Based on Cross-scale Compounding
authors: Ciyao Wang, Yushun Zhao, Jian Zhao, Hao Shen, Xin Zhou
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: High-voltage electrical equipment operates under elevated temperatures and voltages, subjecting epoxy materials to prolonged exposure to high-pressure, high-heat environments. This poses significant fire safety hazards, threatening both power systems and personnel safety. This study addresses the challenge of synergistically enhancing the flame retardancy and mechanical properties of epoxy composites. By employing a micro-nano scale blending method combining magnesium hydroxide inorganic flame retardant filler and nano-silica, it achieves simultaneous improvement in both the flame retardancy rating and mechanical properties of the epoxy material. The modified epoxy material achieved a V-0 flame retardancy rating, with flexural strength of 49.9 MPa, tensile strength of 48.23 MPa, and impact strength of 8.36 kJ/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, representing improvements of 10.7%, 34.2%, and 18.4% respectively compared to the unmodified epoxy material.

title: PID Control Method for Coal Feed Rate under Variable Load Conditions Based on an Improved Gray Wolf Optimization Algorithm
authors: Taohuang Liu, Lei Wang, Hongliang Guan, He Lin
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: Driven by the strategic goals of “carbon peaking and carbon neutrality,” the energy structure transformation of power systems is deepening. As the primary load-smoothing force, thermal power units' frequent variable-load operation imposes higher demands on the dynamic performance and robustness of coal feed control. Addressing the challenges of parameter tuning and insufficient adaptability in traditional PID controllers when dealing with the nonlinearity, time delays, and complex disturbances inherent in thermal power units, this paper proposes a PID control strategy for variable load coal feed based on an improved gray wolf optimization algorithm. Two typical operating conditions—slow load increase and rapid load change—were designed to comprehensively evaluate the steady-state tracking and dynamic response performance of the control strategy. Simulation results demonstrate that compared to conventional threshold PID control, the proposed IGWO-PID strategy significantly reduces tracking errors and fluctuations in main steam pressure and unit power during steady-state conditions. Under rapid load-change conditions, it effectively suppresses overshoot and accelerates response. This research provides an effective solution for enhancing control quality and operational safety in thermal power units during flexible peak-shaving operations.

title: Air Quality Prediction System in Lima Using Long Short Term Memory
authors: Gonzalo Cadenas, Michell Alvarez, Roberto Montero
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: The city of Lima has a high level of air pollution due to the increase in the number of vehicles using fossil fuels and the lack of natural aspects that can mitigate it. This is detrimental to people’s quality of life. Authorities lack tools that allow them to make decisions on environmental aspects. This research has aimed to create a system that allows measuring air quality in different environments of the city in order to provide quantitative aspects that facilitate taking actions in favor of decontamination. The proposed system is based on LSTM neural networks to model a real-time prediction of air quality that allows the metropolitan municipality of Lima to take action on environmental policies. The results have shown that LSTM outperforms other models such as DTR and SVR by better capturing temporal dependencies, so the validations of the system have been very satisfactory and based on them it has been possible to generate policies on vehicle access in places with a high degree of pollution, which benefits citizens.

title: Robust Quantum-Enhanced Hybrid Approach Design to Accelerate Deep Learning Models Performance and Stability
authors: M.S. S. Sasikumar, D. David Neels Ponkumar, SivaneasanBala Krishnan, Prasun Chakrabarti, M.S.Mohamed Mallick
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Quantum computing and deep learning have been integrated as a revolutionary solution to address the classical limitations of performance, scalability and convergence. This paper has proposed a Robust Quantum-Enhanced Hybrid Approach (QEHA) which integrates quantum feature embedding and classical deep neural networks to increase the learning speed, enhance the stability and improve the model robustness. The architecture uses feature Encoding The architecture uses angle encoding and quantum kernels to project input data into a high-dimensional Hilbert space, in between CNNTransformer layers. Quantum Natural Gradient Descent (QNGD) is used to achieve optimization across hybrid layers so that it is efficient in updating parameters. The experimental results prove that the proposed QEHA has an average accuracy of 97.85, which is higher than the CNN-Transformer baseline (94.12) and PQC-only model (91.54). In addition, the hybrid model demonstrates a convergence time decrease of 32% and energy efficiency increase of 26% with a robustness ratio of more than 0.93 in noisy quantum environments. These findings validate the excellence of the offered hybrid structure in the context of accuracy, speed and reliability. The article also finds that quantum-classical connections are scalable and robust AI systems that can be deployed on edge-based quantum collaborative systems, where data dimensionality and energy limits are still significant issues.

title: A Taxonomy of Electromagnetic Information Leakage Threats Focusing on Emission Process
authors: Yuichi Hayashi, Taiki Kitazawa, Hikaru Nishiyama
abstract: The threats of electromagnetic (EM) information leakage via unintended EM emissions from electronic devices have been increasingly recognized. While conventional research has primarily focused on the identification and reconstruction of secret information from such emissions, recent advances in device complexity and higher operating frequencies have significantly diversified the observable leakage channels available to attackers. This paper classifies the EM information leakage threats by focusing on the emission process of leaked EM signals into three classes, thereby establishing a systematic framework to understand the threats. Based on this taxonomy, this paper presents effective countermeasures and design guidelines tailored to each leakage mode, contributing to develop robust hardware.

title: Millimeter Wave Communication and Sensing for ITS
authors: Hyun Seo Oh
abstract: This paper proposes a roadside millimeter wave sensing model for detecting and classifying vehicles, pedestrians and black ice on roads. The sensing system emits Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) chirps and processes the reflected signals via range and Doppler FFT to generate range-Doppler (RD) maps. These maps are preprocessed and used as inputs to a two-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (2D CNN) classifier. The 2D CNN model is trained on labelled datasets that include RD map characteristics of Doppler frequency, Number of Blob Pixels (NBP) and signal intensity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves about 99% accuracy, confirming its feasibility for classification of vehicles, pedestrians, and black ice on roads.

title: Research on the Application of XGBoost Model Fused with Multiple Features in Load Forecasting of Charging Stations at Highway Service Areas
authors: HaiNing Yu, Qiao Yan, YuanShuo Deng, ZhenXin Wen
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of charging stations in expressway service areas, accurately predicting the charging load of electric vehicles has become the key to optimizing operational efficiency. The charging demand in service areas shows significant spatio-temporal fluctuation characteristics and is influenced by multiple factors such as weather conditions and holidays. To break through the limitations of traditional prediction methods, this study proposes an XGBoost load forecasting model integrating multi-feature engineering, 675 pieces of data from the charging station at Gaoqing Service area along the Jigao Expressway in shandong province are collected from January 2023 to May 2025 with a sampling frequency of one day. The input variables are optimized through three-stage feature engineering, and hyperparameter optimization is achieved by using random search. The experimental results show that the root mean square error (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of this model reaches 0.89, and the root mean square error (RMSE) is 12.36 kilowatts. Compared with the Random Forest Model (ARIMA), its prediction accuracy has increased by 23.5% and 15.2% respectively. During peak electricity consumption periods on holidays, the load forecasting error drops to 8.5%, effectively capturing the load fluctuation patterns in special scenarios. These research achievements provide a scientific basis for power dispatching, equipment maintenance and the expansion planning of charging stations, and have significant engineering value for improving the charging efficiency of new energy vehicles.

title: Multidomain HRV Features for the Smart Diagnosis of ADHD Using ML Models
authors: Shafna V, Madhu Kumar S D
abstract: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a common neurodevelopmental condition that persists into adulthood and is often challenging to diagnose due to the subjectivity of traditional assessment methods. While neuroimaging and EEG-based approaches have gained popularity in ADHD research, they are often resource-intensive and less accessible. In contrast, physiological signals such as Heart Rate Variability (HRV) offer a non-invasive and cost-effective alternative that remains underexplored, particularly in adult populations. This study investigates the potential of HRV-derived features for distinguishing adults with ADHD from healthy controls using Machine Learning (ML) techniques. Time-domain, frequency-domain, and wavelet-domain features were extracted from RR interval data. To identify the most informative features, we employed Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) using a Random Forest Classifier, selecting the top five features contributing most to classification performance. Among various models evaluated, the XGBoost classifier achieved the best performance with 91% recall 83% accuracy and f1-score. The results highlight that HRV-based metrics can provide meaningful insights into autonomic nervous system irregularities associated with ADHD in adults. The proposed approach demonstrates a viable path for scalable and accessible ADHD screening using physiological biomarkers. Future work will focus on expanding the dataset and incorporating advanced feature engineering and deep learning for improved accuracy.

title:
Preliminary Design of a Modified Birdcage Receiver RF Coil for
                    <sup>23</sup>
                    Na Breast MRI at 7T
authors: Sheikh Faisal Ahmad, Sukhoon Oh, Hyun Deok Kim
abstract: This paper presents the preliminary design and electromagnetic simulation of a novel modified receiver birdcage radio frequency coil intended for <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">23</sup>Na nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) imaging of the female breast at 78.8 MHz in 7T magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) system. The proposed design introduces geometric modifications including asymmetric circular end-rings and curved leg conductors, aiming to enhance signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) while preserving magnetic field homogeneity. Simulation results both in the absence and presence of a three-layer breast phantom demonstrate noticeable improvement in the sensitivity and an expended region of homogeneous magnetic field in comparison to the conventional birdcage coil. These findings underscore the potential of the proposed RF coil for improved <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">23</sup>Na breast imaging in ultra-high field (UHF) MRI systems.

title: Vision-Based Quality Assessment Method for Adhesive Application in Screw Installation
authors: BenHua Zhao, YongLi Wang, Jing Yang, HuaXing Ren
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: The traditional aerospace industry uses purely manual inspection during installation, which can lead to safety hazards due to human negligence. Given the remarkable achievements in computer vision, how to apply it to the aerospace industry to solve manual hazards is a problem worth studying. To address the inspection omissions inherent in manual visual inspection of cabin screw installation quality in aerospace manufacturing, this study proposes an automated vision-based detection system. The system architecture integrates binocular cameras, and industrial computing units as hardware core components, coupled with real-time positional detection and adhesive recognition modules to achieve comprehensive process monitoring. Through binocular calibration, intrinsic and extrinsic camera parameters were systematically acquired, enabling depth calculation via triangulation principles. Screw positioning was indirectly achieved through hand key point detection, with geometric modeling subsequently analyzing screw-cabin contact states to trigger photographic verification at critical engagement moments. The adhesive inspection module employs predefined regions of interest (ROI) to narrow processing scope, implementing color feature analysis to quantify adhesive coverage condition while ensuring real-time performance and measurement accuracy.

title: Energy Efficient Routing Protocol Based on Fuzzy Optimized Self Schedule Routing for Lifetime Improvement in WSN
authors: J. Sasi Kiran, Sanjib Kumar Nayak, Voruganti Naresh Kumar, K Srujan Raju, JPrasanna Babu, Swathi Rudra
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: In recent development, the Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) have revolutionized various industries and applications, from environmental monitoring to healthcare and industrial automation. The WSN contains Lot of sensor nodes which is interconnected to the communication medium holds lots of energy due to inappropriate routing. However, the dynamic nature of WSNs, sensor nodes, poses significant energy challenges, traffic, and non-supported feature limits in routing, leading to poor routing. Mobile Ad hoc Networks (MANET) routing protocols have emerged as a promising solution to address these challenges, offering adaptability, self-organization, and energy efficiency. Most of exiting methodologies concerns doesn't make logical dependencies in energy efficient routing. To consider this problems and limitations, to develop an Energy Efficient Routing Protocol based Fuzzy Optimized Self-Schedule Routing (EERP-FOSSR) to improve the lifetime in SN. The Energy-Efficient Routing Protocol (EERP) is used to analyze the sensor node energy consumption in the routing to choose the best consumption rate. To obtain maximum routes, the Fuzzy Optimized Self-Schedule Routing (FOSSR) is applied to choose the optimal features in the route. Based on the routing performance, the Optimal Queuing Energy-Resistant Protocol (OQERP) manages communication routing to schedule the transmission flow to improve the routing. The proposed system improves the performance of the MANET routing by considering lifetime maximization in Qom as well as packet delivery ratio, delay tolerance, latency, time complexity.

title: A 300-GHz Voltage-Controlled Oscillator Using a Coupled-Line Resonator with 177.6-dBc/Hz FoM and 5.6-dBm Peak Output Power
authors: Hyunjoon Kim, Dongkyo Kim, Sanggeun Jeon
abstract: This paper presents a high-output-power 300-GHz voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) implemented in a 250-nm InP HBT technology. The proposed VCO employs a coupled-line resonator with asymmetric end terminations, which eliminates the need for low-Q DC-blocking capacitors between the resonator and isolation buffer, thereby improving both output power and phase noise performance. The coupling factor and electrical length of the resonator are optimized to satisfy the optimum gain conditions of the common-base (CB) core. A transformer-based output matching network combines differential signals at the buffer output to maximize power delivery. The fabricated VCO exhibits a tuning range from 302.7 to 305.4 GHz with measured output power ranging from 4.8 to 5.6 dBm. The measured phase noise is –108.1 dBc/Hz at a 10-MHz offset at 305.4 GHz, resulting in a figure-of-merit (FoM) of 177.6 dBc/Hz while consuming 104 mW of DC power.

title: Handover Strategy Design for CF-MIMO Systems Based on UKF Prediction
authors: Jing-Qi Chen, Hua-Min Chen
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Cell-Free Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (CFMIMO) networks are promising to be a solution capable of meeting the requirements of the 6th Generation (6 G) mobile communication system, providing user equipment (UE)-centric service through a set of densely distributed access points (APs) in space. In high-dynamic scenarios, drastic channel variations lead to frequent handovers. In this study, a systematic analysis of channel estimation and signal transmission in such scenarios is first conducted to obtain more accurate channel state information (CSI) and enhance communication reliability. Next, a predictive handover method based on the Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) is designed to predict the future motion and channel characteristics of UEs, enabling advance AP selection to reduce handover lag. Additionally, a more precise handover evaluation mechanism is proposed to avoid unnecessary handovers and improve system continuity. Finally, by analyzing the system spectral efficiency and handover overhead under the proposed scheme, the effectiveness of the scheme in higher speed dynamic scenarios is verified.

title: SpectralFusionNet: Enhanced Satellite Image Scene Classification Through Hybrid Deep Learning Architecture and Intelligent Data Augmentation
authors: Jixuan Shi, Huazhen Wang, Hao Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: The classification of satellite image scenes has substantial potential for applications in environmental monitoring, urban development, and global security. However, existing deep CNN-based models often encounter difficulties in complex and ambiguous scenes due to their inability to effectively capture context information and the lack of sufficient high-quality real-world data samples. In this study, we present SpectralFusionNet, which boosts discriminative ability via a hybrid architecture and intelligent data augmentation. It incorporates a Hybrid Convolutional-Transformer Model (HCTM) and an Adaptive Augmentation Generator (AAG). While HCTM combines the strengths of CNNs for detailed spatial feature extraction and Transformers for contextual understanding, AAG can dynamically generate synthetic training data to enhance model robustness and generalization. Experiments on public datasets show that SpectralFusionNet surpasses typical advanced deep learning methods in terms of classification accuracy.

title: Model-Free Robust Control of Current-Speed for Marine Propulsion Six-Phase PMSM Based on Composite Virtual Vectors
authors: Xiangjun Wang, Yancheng Liu, Haohao Guo, Fengkui Zhang, Shi You
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To improve the current tracking accuracy and system robustness of traditional Virtual Vector Model Predictive Control (VVMPC) in the fundamental plane of a Six-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (Six-Phase PMSM), this paper proposes a model-free robust current-speed control method based on Composite Virtual Vectors (CVV) for ship propulsion Six-Phase PMSM. First, 12 elementary virtual vectors are extended to synthesize the novel composite virtual vector (CVV), which enhances the current tracking performance in the fundamental plane. Next, to improve the robustness of the drive system, an Extended State Observer-Ultra Local Model (ESO-ULM) is designed in the current loop. Additionally, in the speed loop, an independent ULM sliding mode speed controller is constructed based on Model-Free Control (MFC) theory, replacing the traditional PI regulator. Finally, simulation validation is conducted under a simulated ship propeller characteristic load environment. The results demonstrate that, compared to traditional VVMPC, the proposed method exhibits better robustness to motor parameter variations and step load changes.
