title: Advancing Autism Spectrum Disorder Diagnosis with Multimodal Data: A Survey
authors: K. NAMITHA, S. GIRISH, M. P. ANUVIND, R. S. HARISH KUMAR, HARISHANKAR BINU NAIR, DHANYA CHANDRAN
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a complicated neurodevelopmental condition characterised by a variety of behavioural and communication challenges, marking timely and accurate diagnosis and intervention essential. Despite their widespread occurrence, conventional diagnostic methods like clinical observations and standardised questionnaires are hindered by issues like subjectivity, practitioner variability, and long evaluation durations and existing works using AI for diagnosis falters as they fail to capture range of symptoms, generalizability across cohorts and a lot more challenges. This survey compiles a comprehensive set of ASD datasets, including the limited multimodal collections, and outlines clear modality specific preprocessing steps that ensures data quality. By reviewing prior multimodal fusion surveys and highlighting breakthroughs across individual modalities with the main fusion studies, it establishes a unified view of the diagnostic approach and the fusion techniques used in ASD research. Furthermore, the survey explains the advantages of multimodal fusion, summarises the major limitations reported across existing work, and introduces a simple taxonomy with practical solutions that address these challenges and guide future development.

title: A Real-Time Orbit Correction Method for LEO Satellites using Signals of Opportunity from Multiple Stations
authors: Yue Liu, Ying Xu, Ming Lei, Ming Gao, Zhibo Fang, Jiajia Chen
abstract: The rapid expansion of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite constellations has created new opportunities for global navigation and positioning. Navigation based on LEO Signal of Opportunity (SOP) effectively complements the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) owing to their high received power and wide coverage. However, most LEO satellites suffer from orbital errors of several hundred to a thousand meters, while uncertain signal transmission times further degrade positioning accuracy. Existing orbit determination approaches and differential positioning methods can improve performance but remain limited: the former rely on long-term observations, limiting responsiveness to frequent orbital maneuvers, whereas the latter experience degraded performance over long baselines due to weakened spatial correlation of orbit errors. To address these challenges, this study introduces a real-time orbit correction method based on LEO satellite SOP from multiple stations. By anchoring satellite time references to a network of ground stations, the method imposes a strong constraint on transmission time and decouples onboard spatiotemporal reference errors. Joint processing of time–frequency observations from multiple stations enables real-time orbit error correction without long-term data accumulation. Experimental validation using Iridium NEXT SOPs shows that, within a 953 km² area, the proposed method achieves two-dimensional and three-dimensional positioning accuracies of 13.8 m and 27.5 m, improving by 36% and 21.4%, respectively, compared with existing differential approaches.

title: Microbubble cantilever Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) sensor with ultra-high strain sensitivity under the Vernier effect
authors: Zheng Li, Jianxin Wang, Jingwei Lv, Xili Lu, Lin Yang, Wei Liu, Zao Yi, Qiang Liu, Paul K. Chu, Chao Liu
abstract: A high-sensitivity fiber-optic micro-strain sensor based on a parallel Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) and the optical Vernier effect is designed, fabricated, and demonstrated. The sensor comprises two parallel FPIs. The sensing interferometer (SI) employs a unique cantilever-beam bubble microcavity structure, achieving a high strain sensitivity of 32.89 pm/με, while the reference interferometer (RI) is detached from the experimental environment. By connecting them in parallel, the optical Vernier effect further enhances the strain sensitivity to 555 pm/με, representing an amplification factor of approximately a factor of 17. Meanwhile, the sensor exhibits low temperature cross-sensitivity of approximately 9.73 με/°C. The sensor, with its compact structure, simple fabrication, and low cost, has broad application prospects in fields such as the safety monitoring of oil and gas transportation pipelines.

title: Physics-Guided Posterior Sampling for Diffusion-Based Real-World Dehazing and Image Enhancement_supp1-3662772.pdf
authors: Junkai Fan
abstract: Real-world image dehazing is a challenging task due to the collection of aligned hazy/clear image pairs under unpredictable and complex environments. To address this limitation, we propose a Physical-Guided Posterior Sampling (PGPS) method that designs a dehazing reconstruction posterior to sample an RGB and depth from pre-trained unconditional diffusion generation process. First, we introduce a Hybrid Degradation Atmospheric Scattering Model (HD-ASM) to adapt the diffusion model, enabling the generation of high-fidelity dehazed images from posterior samples without relying on the aligned hazy/clear image pairs. Second, we propose a two-stage sampling strategy with piecewise loss to improve sampling quality and stability, along with a post-processing technique to remove JPEG compression artifacts amplified by dehazing. Extensive experiments show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in image dehazing, and in the RTTS dataset’s complex human-vehicle environment. Additionally, our approach also surpasses other benchmarks in object detection, exhibiting superior generalization performance.

title: An Energy-Efficient and High-Accuracy Dual-ModeECG AI Processor via Deep-Fold and Zero-Free Fine-Grained Quantization
authors: Zuo Zhang, Xuecheng Yang, Shen Ye, Jiahao Wang, Yu Shi, Tianxiang Qu, Zhiliang Hong, Jiawei Xu
abstract: Smart wearable electrocardiography (ECG) devices require classification processors that combine high accuracy, low power dissipation, and real-time operation under stringent energy constraints. Conventional neural network approaches improve accuracy but are limited by high computational and memory costs, restricting on-chip deployment. This work presents an energy-efficient ECG AI processor enabled by algorithm-hardware co-design. Key contributions include: 1) a unified lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) with a shared convolutional backbone and dual task-specific heads for binary and five-class classification; 2) a hardware-oriented deep-fold technique using weight symmetry to reduce parameters and multiplications by 39.1% and 40.1%, respectively; and 3) a zero-free fine-grained (ZFFG) quantization scheme that preserves accuracy at low bit-widths while enabling multiplier-less inference. Fabricated in 65-nm CMOS, the processor achieves 98.70% (binary) and 98.72% (five-class) classification accuracy with an ultra-compact 2.37 KB on-chip SRAM and only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.09~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>J per inference, representing a state-of-the-art, energy-efficient solution for real-time wearable ECG monitoring.

title: A Carrier-Based DPWM Method With Integrated Reactive Power Compensation Capability for Vienna Rectifier
authors: Tong Gao, Hong Cheng, Wei Yuan, Zhijie Wang, Xin Li, Cong Wang
abstract: Vienna rectifiers are widely used in many industrial applications. However, the unidirectional conduction characteristic of the diodes makes it has poor reactive power compensation capability under conventional control. In this article, the reactive power compensation capability of the Vienna rectifier is enhanced by applying a current distortion elimination method, and the corresponding feasible power factor is discussed in detail. By considering the coupling characteristics between impedance angle, modulation index, and power factor angle, the relationship between the reactive power compensation capability and the currently transmitted active current is more accurately described. Besides, a carrier-based discontinuous pulse width modulation (CB-DPWM) strategy with integrated reactive power compensation capability is proposed, the advantage of the proposed CB-DPWM is that the reference voltage has a longer clamping region with maximum absolute current, which is much helpful for reduction of switching losses. Simulation and experiments results verified the correctness of the theoretical analysis on maximum reactive power compensation capability and the superiority of the proposed CB-DPWM strategy.

title: Research on the Frequency Spectrum Fluctuation of Radar Signal Under Plasma Sheath
authors: Lihao Song, Bowen Bai, Ziang Huo, Yifan Li, Bailiang Pu, Hengbo Jing, Xiaoping Li, Yanming Liu
abstract: Radar signal frequency spectrum is a key parameter for radar systems, which decides the upper limit of the performance of a radar system. However, when a radar signal propagates through the plasma sheath, due to the dissipative and dispersive properties of plasma sheath, the radar signal frequency spectrum characteristic will be distorted. Therefore, this article has conducted research on the frequency spectrum fluctuation of linear frequency modulation (LFM) radar signals under a plasma sheath. First, this article proposes a numerical computation method for the frequency spectrum characteristics of a radar signal based on the scatter matrix method. The radar signal frequency spectrum characteristics with and without plasma sheath are computed. By comparing the radar signal frequency spectrum characteristic with and without plasma sheath, the frequency spectrum attenuation characteristic and frequency spectrum fluctuation within the bandwidth are discovered. In order to describe these two phenomena clearer, the two variables called attenuation within bandwidth (attn_band) and fluctuation within bandwidth (inband_fluc) are defined. The influence of electron density, collision frequency, carrier frequency, bandwidth, and incident angle on radar signal frequency spectrum fluctuation characteristics is analyzed. The results demonstrate that when the radar signal carrier frequency is close to the cutoff frequency of electron density, there exists a local peak point of frequency spectrum fluctuation characteristics when collision frequency is low. The radar signal frequency spectrum shows a decreasing trend when the electron density and collision frequency is high and carrier frequency is low.

title: A Millimeter-Wave Two-Way Series-Doherty Power Amplifier With Transformer-Based Second-Order Output Network
authors: Qingxuan Wei, Chao Yang, Xiaoming Liu, Yun Wang, Jing Jin, Jianjun Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a two-way series-Doherty power amplifier (PA) for fifth-generation (5G) millimeter-wave (mm-wave) communications. The design integrates a transformer-based second-order output network, which replaces the quarter-wave transmission line (QTL) with a second-order <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pi $</tex-math> </inline-formula> -network to achieve wideband operation and a compact footprint. To realize wideband quadrature signal generation, the proposed phase-insensitive quadrature hybrid coupler explicitly incorporates the effect of the inductor quality factor (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Q$</tex-math> </inline-formula> factor) based on the ideal coupler model, achieving <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Q$</tex-math> </inline-formula> phase mismatch <0.5° over the 18–38 GHz band. The PA demonstrates measured saturated output power (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P_{\text {sat}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$20.2~\pm ~1$</tex-math> </inline-formula> dBm, output 1 dB compression point (OP<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}_{1{\,}\text {dB}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$19.8~\pm ~1$</tex-math> </inline-formula> dBm, peak PAE (PAE<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}_{\max }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of 24.8%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm ~2.4$</tex-math> </inline-formula>%, and PAE at 6 dB power back-off (PBO) (PAE<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}_{6{\,}\text {dB}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of 16.7% <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm ~2.5$</tex-math> </inline-formula>% from 25 to 30 GHz. Modulation measurements demonstrate average output power (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P_{\text {avg}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of 10.1/9.9 dBm and average efficiency (PAE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">avg</sub>) of 13.3%/13.1% for a 100/400 MHz single-carrier 64-quadrature-amplitude-modulation (QAM) signal with an error vector magnitude (EVM) below −24 dB at 28 GHz.

title: Res-SH: Unbiased Residual Learning for Self-Healing Interface Toughness Prediction with Limited Data
authors: Pei-Sze Tan, Karen Jia-Jun Koh, Sailaja Rajanala, Arghya Pal, Raphaël C.-W. Phan, Nan Ze, Fuad Noman, Chee-Ming Ting, Norfadilah Dolmat, Nik Nur Wahidah Nik Hashim, Afidalina Tumian
abstract: The development of self-healing materials is often hindered by the high costs and material waste associated with traditional characterization methods. Current approaches to toughness prediction, primarily based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs), are limited by their tendency to capture only surface-level features, which can lead to biased predictions. Moreover, working with small datasets, which is common in materials science, further increases the risk of biased training due to overfitting, posing a critical challenge to the reliability and generalizability of predictive models. This study introduces an unbiased residual learning framework designed explicitly for predicting self-healing interface toughness under limiteddata conditions. Our approach, ResNet-inspired approach for predicting self-healing material toughness, named Res-SH, used the power of residual networks to capture deeper, more complex patterns in the data, thereby addressing critical challenges in materials research. Res-SH minimises resource consumption and experimental overhead by focusing on unbiased learning, achieving accurate predictions with fewer training epochs and lower R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score and root mean square prediction errors compared to conventional CNN and lightweight model MobileNetv2. This novel framework provides a cost-effective and resource-efficient alternative to traditional material characterization methods, reducing material waste and accelerating the discovery and optimization of self-healing material systems.

title: A Secure and Efficient LLM-Based System for Natural Language Query-to-SQL Translation in IoT Data Management
authors: Mario San Emeterio de la Parte, Yiting Wang, José-Fernán Martínez-Ortega, Néstor Lucas Martínez
abstract: Structured data embodies vast reservoirs of actionable knowledge, yet non-technical users often lack the tools to effectively access or leverage these resources. This paper presents a novel middleware system architecture that harnesses Large Language Models (LLMs) to translate natural language queries (NLQs) into executable SQL statements, enabling seamless interaction with relational databases without requiring technical expertise. To bridge a critical gap in existing research, the proposed system integrates a robust security framework featuring multi-factor authentication and fine-grained, role-based access control. A comprehensive evaluation was conducted using over 813,000 real spatio-temporal IoT samples from the H2020-AFarCloud international project, comparing both general-purpose LLMs and models fine-tuned for NLQ-to-SQL translation. Two complementary evaluation metrics—Execution Accuracy (EX) and Valid Efficiency Score (VES)—were employed to assess syntactic correctness, semantic fidelity, and runtime efficiency. Experimental results show that GPT-o3 mini-high achieves the highest overall performance in terms of average VES, while DeepSeek R1 exhibits the most consistent behavior across heterogeneous query scenarios, as reflected by lower performance variability. These findings underscore the interplay between model capability and computational efficiency, demonstrating the potential of LLM-driven middleware to democratize structured data access and enhance data-driven decision-making.

title: Dual-Teacher and Dual-Prompt Pool for Few-Shot Dialog State Tracking
authors: Di Wu, Yuheng Li, Zhizhi Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Dialog state tracking (DST) is an essential component of task-oriented dialog (ToD) systems. Existing few-shot DST models face challenges in effectively leveraging semantically related information and exhibit limited adaptability to dialog scenarios. To address these challenges, the dual-teacher and dual-prompt pool model for few-shot DST (DDP-DST) is proposed. Specifically, by enhancing key semantic information and syntactic structure, dual teacher models are constructed to generate pseudolabels from complementary perspectives. Self-training is employed to further improve state value generation. Besides, considering the intrinsic symmetry between slot and state value generation tasks, a dual-prompt fine-tuning strategy is designed. A dynamic prompt pool is constructed to adaptively generate prompts. Reconstruction errors (REs) are fed back into the DDP-DST model, leading to improved accuracy in DST. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset demonstrate that DDP-DST outperforms baseline models such as SM2-3b, DS2, and SVAG with average improvements of 4.3%, 2.4%, and 2.0% in the metric of joint goal accuracy (JGA). Notably, with fewer than 1 billion parameters, DDP-DST achieves competitive performance in few-shot settings, even outperforming models with up to 10 billion parameters.

title: Practical Fixed-Time Control of Switched Neutral Filippov Systems on Networks
authors: Fanchao Kong, Pingping Meng, Shuaibing Zhu, Jinhu Lü
abstract: In this article, the practical fixed-time (FxT) control of switched neutral Filippov systems (SNFSs) on networks is considered. The perturbation functions that can be discontinuous, and the neutral logics expressed by the difference operators, are addressed by new approaches. Several novel Lyapunov inequalities with indefinite functions are proposed, where detailed estimations of the settling-time (ST) are obtained by discussing the different values of the exponents of the Lyapunov functions, which can include the existing results. Considering that the states generally cannot converge to the origin accurately under finite-time control in real applications, practical FxT stability lemmas with indefinite functions are established for the first time, in which the bounded condition imposed on the indefinite function is more practical than the previously unbounded ones. By designing the adaptive control strategies, the FxT and practical FxT synchronization control are investigated based on the Lyapunov–Krasovskii functionals (LKFs), which show the delay characteristic via the adaptive update law containing delay values. Notably, the theoretical deficiency arising from the Lyapunov function when studying the FxT stability of real systems with delays by using the FxT stability lemmas with indefinite function is solved in a successful way. Finally, the validity of the main results is verified by numerical simulations on an electrical device containing an LC transmission line.

title: Mesh Stability of Uncertain Platoon Vehicles with Cornering Maneuver Using Relative Posture Error Information
authors: Junseok Boo, Kangmin Jo, Dongkyoung Chwa
abstract: This paper presents a robust bidirectional platoon control method based on coupled relative posture errors to achieve mesh stability of connected vehicles under kinematic and dynamic disturbances. Platoon control for connected and automated vehicles must guarantee safe intervehicle distances and desired heading angles on a two-dimensional (2D) plane, even in the presence of modeling uncertainties and external disturbances. However, most existing studies focus on string stability in either the longitudinal or lateral direction; consequently, bidirectional error propagation on a plane, combined kinematic and dynamic disturbances, and path departure during curved maneuvers are not sufficiently addressed. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a robust platoon control framework that guarantees mesh stability and asymptotic convergence of relative posture errors to zero using only relative posture information. Coupled relative posture error dynamics are derived to analyze error propagation on a 2D plane, and a novel robust bidirectional platoon controller employing an adaptive integral sliding mode disturbance observer (AISMDOB) is proposed to ensure asymptotic convergence of both relative spacing and heading angle errors to zero while compensating for kinematic and dynamic disturbances. In addition, an extended look-ahead strategy based on relative posture errors is introduced to prevent path departure during curved maneuvers while relying solely on local onboard sensors instead of global positioning information. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method reduces average relative spacing errors by approximately 29% in simulation and 25% in experiments, and heading angle errors by approximately 9% and 29%, respectively, compared with existing methods.

title: A Novel Benchmark for Domain Generalization in Zero-Target-Sample Capsule Detection
authors: Chao Chen, Yongchang Li, Yan Zhang, Feng Ling, Chenyang Li, Jianshe Ye, Shiyuan Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: This study introduces a novel benchmark for domain generalization in zero-target-sample detection of reentry capsules, addressing critical challenges in data scarcity, domain shift, and computational efficiency. We present "CapsuleSet", the first multi-domain dataset for reentry capsules, featuring diverse scenarios and four capsule types. For the problem of domain generalization detection, we propose YOLO-GSA, an advanced detection algorithm built upon the YOLOv11n framework. YOLO-GSA incorporates three innovative modules—GIFM, SGM, and ACDM—to significantly enhance cross-domain feature discrimination and generalization. Through rigorous evaluation, YOLO-GSA demonstrates superior performance, achieving the highest mAP@50 on "CapsuleSet" while maintaining a compact model size, outperforming mainstream YOLO series algorithms. This work not only fills the gap in existing datasets but also provides a robust and efficient solution for real-time reentry capsule detection, suitable for deployment on resource-constrained platforms. Our research provides a standardized benchmark and a practical method for real-world reentry capsule recovery missions, and can also serve as a supplement to the field of domain generalization.

title: Fostering Student Responsibility and Sustainability Literacy Through AI-Based Learning Tools
authors: Nhu Lam Thi Quynh, Linh Nguyen Thi Yen, Giang Tien Thi Nguyen, Luan Huynh Vu, Hiep Dac Nguyen, Luan Trong Nguyen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: This research examines how learning with AI technologies and instructional conditions affect Students’ Sustainability Responsibility (SSR) in higher education settings. Based on quantitative data collected from 249 undergraduate students at FPT University, Can Tho Campus, the study applies multiple regression and moderation testing using PROCESS Model 1 to analyze both direct and interaction impacts of AI Learning Tools (AILT), AI Ethics Awareness (AIEA), Learning Engagement (LE), Educational Environment (EE), and Sustainability Literacy (SL). Results indicate that AILT, LE, and EE significantly enhance SSR, emphasizing the role of active learner involvement, supportive educational settings, and AI-enabled tools in fostering responsible and sustainability-oriented behavior. Conversely, AIEA and SL do not present a significant direct influence on SSR, suggesting that ethical awareness and sustainability knowledge alone may be insufficient to trigger behavioral change without contextual or practical reinforcement. The moderation findings show that SL weakens the effects of both AIEA and LE on SSR. This outcome suggests that students with higher sustainability literacy tend to demonstrate responsibility through internal motivation rather than depending on external encouragement or ethical prompts. Theoretically, this study contributes by integrating AI-enabled learning, ethics, and sustainability literacy into a comprehensive analytical model. From a practical perspective, it recommends that universities develop AI-augmented educational environments that prioritize learner engagement, contextual guidance, and early integration of sustainability training. Such an approach can nurture intrinsic responsibility and equip learners to manage ethical challenges in AI-driven educational contexts, while also supporting broader sustainability objectives.

title: Design of Optimal Reflection Coefficients and Low-Complexity Equalizer for IRS-OTFS System
authors: Rakesh Kumar Yadav, Sai Kumar Dora, Himanshu B. Mishra, Samrat Mukhopadhyay
abstract: For high Doppler scenarios, intelligent reflecting surface (IRS)-aided orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS) systems exhibit enhanced performances in terms of bit-error rate (BER), achievable rate (AR), signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), etc. These performances can be achieved by optimally designing the IRS coefficients through solving proper optimization problems. Note that in the existing literature, for IRS-OTFS systems, the optimal reflection coefficients were designed by minimizing the BER, which may not achieve a highly spectral-efficient system. Therefore, in this work, we design reflection coefficients by developing an AR optimization framework. We propose a root-mean squared propagation (RMS-prop) approach to solve this optimization problem. On the other hand, OTFS system comprises a high dimension delay-Doppler matrix, which can increase the computational complexity of linear equalization techniques. Thus, in this work, we also design low-complexity linear-minimum-mean-squared-error (LMMSE) equalizers, for OTFS system (with and without IRS), which relies on the principle of Cholesky-based decomposition. Our simulation results demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed AR optimization framework and low-complexity equalizers in terms of AR, BER and computational complexity, compared to the existing state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Real-Time Attack Surface Reduction in Cloud Infrastructures Using Reinforcement Learning-Driven Cyber Deception Strategies
authors: John David Raju Pesaramilli, Teja Gudisa
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research lays out a new way of upgrading cloud infrastructure security through the use of reinforcement learning-empowered cyber deception strategies that are designed to minimize the attack surface in real time. The system is not only learning from the environment, but also responds to potential threats by learning the best deception policies that trick the attackers and give infiltration a longer time barrier. The framework that has been suggested is not static, instead, it is designed in such a way that it can incorporate intelligent deception parts that change according to the behavior of the attacker, and therefore it can be a proactive type of defense rather than a reactive one. The reinforcement learning agent is still there and it has the opportunity to observe and learn the behavior of the threats, so it can better allocate the decoys, fake assets, and the misleading paths that it needs. This adaptive mechanism facilitates the system in ensuring a minimum level of exposure of the critical resources and at the same time, it creates a dynamic, unpredictable environment that significantly increases attackers' complexity. This work's contribution lies in the fusion of cyber deception and the learning model, which is self-improving, thus it opens up a strong and scalable option for the cloud security domain. The suggested method is not only capable of improving the security of cloud environments but also can be very efficient in handling and reducing the impact of complicated threat vectors instantaneously.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning and Ensemble Model for Accurate Detection and Classification of Bone Cancer
authors: Puneet Kumar, Nidhi Tyagi, Sindhusaranya Balraj, Sobiyaa P, A. Kaliappan, J. Praveenkumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: For bone cancer to be effectively treated and for patient survival to increase, early identification and precise categorisation are essential. This paper suggests a hybrid deep learning and ensemble model that combines ensemble learning for reliable classification with convolutional neural networks (CNN) for feature extraction. The model handles issues like data imbalance and complicated bone textures when processing medical pictures like MRI scans and X-rays. According to experimental results, the suggested strategy outperforms current methods with an accuracy of 94.7 %, precision of 94.1 %, recall of 93.8 %, F1-score of 93.9 %, and an AUC of 0.97. These results demonstrate how hybrid models can offer accurate, automated bone cancer detection, assisting physicians in making diagnoses and enhancing patient outcomes.

title: Logarithmic Hyperbolic Cosine Adaptive Filter with Variable Center Based Channel Estimation Under Non-Zero-Mean Non-Gaussian Noise
authors: Mahima Chouksey, Sandesh Jain
abstract: The design of robust adaptive filters is critical for applications such as system identification, channel estimation, noise suppression, and channel equalization, especially under nonGaussian/impulsive noise environments. The existing maximum correntropy criterion, hyperbolic cost adaptive filter (HCAF), and logarithmic HCAF (LHCAF) based adaptive algorithms deliver suboptimal performance for non-Gaussian distortions having non-zero mean due to the incorporation of order statistics about the origin. In this paper, we propose a novel adaptive filtering algorithm called LHCAF with variable center (LHCAF-VC), which is robust against impulsive noise with non-zero mean, as it considers central order moments of the error distribution rather than origin-based moments. To further enhance convergence performance and adaptability in dynamic environments, a variable step-size (VSS) mechanism is also integrated into LHCAFVC, resulting in a new VSS-LHCAF-VC algorithm. Simulation results for the channel estimation task under Gaussian-mixture noise conditions demonstrate that the proposed LHCAF-VC and VSSLHCAF- VC algorithms achieve superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Transient waveform recording FDTW decomposition for early insulation fault DTU terminal sensing of distribution lines
authors: Yang Liu, Li Cai, Shengjian Li, Caibo Deng, Le Yuan, Xianda Fan
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Early insulation faults in distribution lines may result in instantaneous abnormalities in voltage and current waveforms or harmonic distortion of discharge pulses. These issues not only affect the operational stability of the power network but may also cause malfunctions in power equipment. Therefore, a DTU terminal sensing method for early insulation faults in distribution lines based on transient waveform recording and FDTW decomposition is proposed. The insulation fault signal is processed using transient waveform recording and FDTW decomposition to improve the DTU terminal triggering mechanism. On this basis, the energy spectrum characteristics of the decomposed signal are matched with the sensing mode of the DTU terminal triggering mechanism, thus completing the design of the DTU terminal sensing method for early insulation faults in distribution lines under transient waveform recording FDTW decomposition. Experimental results show that this method can effectively analyze the instantaneous abnormal performance of voltage and current waveforms and accurately monitor the distorted waveform of discharge pulse harmonics, demonstrating outstanding value in ensuring the operational stability of distribution lines.

title: Adaptive Recommendation Engines for Sparse Interaction Data
authors: Shikha Parekh
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This paper presents an advanced system for generating tailored recommendations, specifically tackling situations with scant user and item interaction data. It introduces a hybrid matrix factorization model that effectively uses metadata to form first and beginning user and item representations. This approach functions as an implied and understood modeling feedback mechanism, permitting the system to learn and adapt even when conventional interaction data are limited. The arising feature embeddings capture rich semantic information, demonstrating valuable for assorted and manifold related assignments and outperforming traditional approaches in cold-start situations. This system shows its relevance in advancing sturdy and resilient and scalable personalization solutions for complicated organization environments, enhancing user experience by offering relevant recommendations from the outset.

title: Charging Load Forecasting based on LSTM Neural Network
authors: Yu Cheng, Zhizhuo He, Xiaonan Liu, Qingyu Cao, Xueting Wang, Xiyu Gu, Tingling Huang, Ying Zhang, Wei Xie, Xinyu Zhou, Deyang Hao, Rongrong Dai, Kaiqi Yang, Wenjun Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In recent years, with the wide application of new energy vehicles, the operation data of charging piles, as a key facility for energy replenishment of electric vehicles, has increased sharply. However, the expansion of data scale has also increased the complexity of charging demand, posing new challenges to power grid dispatching and load balancing. To enhance the accuracy of charging load prediction, this paper addresses the deficiency that traditional methods are difficult to effectively depict temporal correlations and constructs a time series prediction model based on Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTM). This paper selects key indicators such as time, electricity consumption, electricity charges and service fees from the charging dataset, takes the total daily charging volume as the prediction target, and uses the LSTM model to capture the temporal dependence characteristics of charging behavior to model and predict future charging loads. The experimental results show that this model can fit the real load curve well, has a low root mean square error (RMSE), and its prediction performance is superior to traditional methods. The research results can provide reference basis for the capacity planning, power dispatching and operation optimization of the charging network.

title: Consensus Control of Multiagent Systems Based on Event-Triggered Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xuezhi Zhou, Qishui Zhong, Lanfeng Hua, Jiahao Leng, Hanmei Zhou, Shuai Li
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: This paper addresses the issue of achieving optimal consensus control for multi-agent systems (MASs) with uncertain dynamics and proposes a reinforcement learning approach that incorporates an event-triggering mechanism. First, the MASs are modeled as directed graphs, with local and global inconsistency errors defined. Second, a distributed control strategy based on Nash equilibrium is designed to minimize the local performance index function(PIF). To reduce computational overhead and energy consumption, an event-triggering mechanism based on the energy function is introduced. By dynamically adjusting the triggering conditions, the controller is updated only when necessary, significantly reducing the update frequency. Third, the reinforcement learning(RL) algorithm within the Actor-Critic framework is employed, where the actor neural networks(NN) approximates the optimal control policy, and the critic neural networks(NN) estimates the performance index, enabling iterative optimization of the control strategy. Finally, In the theoretical analysis, the Lyapunov method is utilized to prove the convergence of system errors and network parameters, ensuring system consensus and stability. Numerical simulations demonstrate that, compared to the traditional periodic triggering method, the proposed method reduces computational costs while achieving rapid convergence and efficient operation.

title: Millimeter-Wave Miniaturized Antenna and Its Wide-Angle Scanning Array for 5G Mobile Communication
authors: Kai Chen, Jun Xu, Jixin Chen, Zhengbo Jiang, Wei Hong
abstract: A novel millimeter-wave (mmWave) miniaturized antenna and its wide-angle scanning array are proposed in this paper for 5G mobile communication. Utilizing multi-layer PCB process, the proposed antenna achieves miniaturization through the folding of ring resonators along two dimensions. The measured results of the antenna element exhibit an impedance matching bandwidth of 18.7% (24.7-29.8 GHz), encompassing 5G NR bands of n258 and n257. Furthermore, a 1×4 linear phased array is developed. Conducted at 27 GHz, the H-plane beam scanning test indicates that, the array beam is capable of scanning from -57° to 58°, incurring a mere gain loss of 2.53 dB and 2.37 dB, respectively. Owing to the outstanding performance, the proposed mmWave miniaturized antenna and its phased array constitute a highly promising solution for the 5G mobile communication.

title: Electricity Price Forecasting Based on Similarity-Based Date Selection and VMD-CNN-LSTM
authors: Yingying Chen, Dong Li, Wenhao Peng, Yongcan Zhu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the challenges of strong non-stationarity and high prediction difficulty in electricity prices under multi-factor coupling, this paper proposes a short-term electricity price forecasting model integrating hybrid feature selection, similar-day selection, and VMD-CNN-LSTM. First, a two-dimensional analysis using Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients identifies five key features significantly correlated with electricity prices—including renewable energy output and total power generation—to reduce dimensionality and eliminate redundancy. Next, K-means clustering combined with Dynamic Time Warping selects similar days to construct a high-quality training dataset. Subsequently, VMD decomposed the electricity price sequence into 11 stationary eigenmode functions to reduce complexity. Finally, CNN extracted spatial features while LSTM uncovered long-term temporal dependencies, completing prediction and result reconstruction. Experimental results on a northwest China electricity price dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves significantly lower prediction errors and more stable performance compared to baseline models, validating its effectiveness.

title: AI Assisted AR Assembly: Object Recognition and Computer Vision for Augmented Reality Assisted Assembly
authors: Alexander Htet Kyaw, Haotian Ma, Sasa Zivkovic, Jenny Sabin
publish: Adjunct Proceedings of the 10th ACM Symposium on Computational Fabrication
abstract: None

title: Automated Satellite Image Segmentation Using Kapur's Entropy Through Black-Winged Kite Algorithm
authors: N. Sri Krishna Chaitanya, A. Tamilarasan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This study presents an automated satellite image segmentation approach utilizing Kapur's Entropy-based multi-level thresholding optimized through the Black-Winged Kite Algorithm (BWKA). The methodology was evaluated against the Genetic Algorithm (GA) using the Berkeley image dataset comprising 40 satellite image samples with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4024 \times 10$</tex> pixel regions, divided equally between both algorithms (N=20 per group). Statistical analysis was conducted using a significance level of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha=0.05$</tex> and statistical power of 0.8. The BWKA demonstrated superior performance with a mean segmentation accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90.52 \% (\text{SD}=0.63049, \quad \text{SEM}=0.19938), \quad$</tex> significantly outperforming GA which achieved 76.94% accuracy (SD=1.19203, SEM=0.37695). Independent t -test analysis revealed a statistically significant difference between the algorithms <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{p}=0.001, \mathrm{p}<0.005)$</tex>, with a 95% confidence interval confirming the reliability of results. The BWKA exhibited lower variability and higher consistency in segmentation quality across diverse satellite imagery, demonstrating computational efficiency with reduced classification errors and improved boundary detection. These findings establish BWKA combined with Kapur's Entropy as an effective optimization framework for automated satellite image segmentation tasks, offering substantial improvements over conventional genetic algorithm approaches in both accuracy and stability.

title: Smart Voice Commands Control and E-Braking for Safety in Intelligent Transfer Devices
authors: Ilham Saputra, Chin-Yi Cheng, Chen-En Shi
abstract: As smart healthcare develops, the demand for voice recognition in human-machine interaction and safety control of medical assistive devices increases. This study presents a voice-activated safety mechanism for medical bed mobility vehicles, using non-contact voice commands to trigger electronic brakes, improving patient autonomy and reducing healthcare worker workload. The system uses an ESP32S processor, an INMP441 microphone, and a Bluetooth module to transmit voice data to a Raspberry Pi 5 for recognition and display. The voice model, based on Meta Wav2Vec2.0, includes three commands “lock,” “unlock,” and “other” to control braking. A high-power relay activates the electronic brake. To enhance performance in varied environments, the model is fine-tuned using PyTorch with data augmentation and GPU acceleration. Experimental results show a 92.8% recognition accuracy with an average delay of 1.677 seconds, meeting real-time and reliability needs. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using voice recognition for braking control in medical bed vehicles and provides a reference for designing safety mechanisms in smart healthcare.

title: Graph Neural Networks for Mapping Intertextual References and Thematic Networks in Large–Scale English Poetry Collections
authors: A. Elangovan, Suchithra K.P, Godwin Raj S, A. Rajeswari, S. Abirami, M. Vinoth Kumar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The paper is a fresh application of Graph Neural Networks or more precisely a Graph Convolutional Network to mapping the intertextual references and thematic networks among massive collections of English poetry. It uses a preprocessing technique of tokenization, lemmatization, and stop word removal as methodology to improve the quality of data and concentrate on meaningful features. The feature selection procedure is Recursive Feature Elimination, which allows the selection of only the most relevant features, which would maximize the performance of the model. The GCN classifier is used to find out the complex interrelationships among the poems, their themes, and intertextual links. The use of Apache Flink is required to manage large datasets in real-time to achieve scalability and efficient data processing. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is proven by the results of the experiments that are conducted to enhance the detection accuracy and computational efficiency. Such an approach demonstrates much potential in the development of computational literary analysis as a strong instrument of studying large literary collections.

title: Speech Input Interface for Electronic Medical Record Supporting Automatic Soap Generation Using Large Language Models
authors: Rikuto Yamanaka, Tsubasa Saito, Yukoh Wakabayashi, Norihide Kitaoka
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: To increase the efficiency of the time-consuming process of clinical documentation, in this study we propose a speech input interface for Electronic Healthcare Records (EHR) that automatically generates SOAP notes from patient-clinician conversations. Our system employs the large language model (LLM) GPT-4o to carry out a two-stage SOAP note generation process that includes opportunities for human evaluation. A huge amount of EHR data, which has been collected by the hospital we are collaborating with in this research, is used as external knowledge to enhance the accuracy and reliability of the generated output. Based on related research and feedback from nurses, we have also implemented features to improve practical utility, such as a function to input the generated SOAP notes into existing EHR systems via QR code, as well as an automatic save feature. A usability evaluation conducted with nurses suggests the fundamental effectiveness of the system, while also highlighting challenges for practical implementation, including processing speed, speech recognition accuracy, and privacy protection.

title: Precision Watering: Enhancing Crop Yield with IoT-Integrated Irrigation
authors: M. Balasubramani, Sivabalan K, Santhosh A, Sarankumar S, Sivaselvakumar S
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Utilizing IoT for irrigation has been developed into smart irrigation, which remains a novel idea. In modern irrigation, smart irrigation has been a boon. Agriculture has suffered an ecological crisis due to the depletion of water supplies, poor resource management, and environmental adversity. In this always-available, modern world, easily attainable food should also have a minimal ecological footprint. One way to address water scarcity is Systematic Precision Irrigation, which promotes more intelligent irrigation.

title: Research on the surface flashover characteristics and failure mechanism of oil-impregnated pressboard containing thermally induced bubbles under power frequency voltage
authors: Junli Du, Yuxing Chen, Chao Li, Zhaohua Wang, Hua Zhu, Qiaogen Zhang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: An investigation is conducted on the surface flashover characteristics and failure mechanism of oil-impregnated pressboard containing thermally induced bubbles under power frequency voltage. An experimental platform is established for this purpose. Key parameters, including the partial discharge inception voltage and flashover voltage, are measured and compared between conditions with and without bubbles. The entire surface discharge development process is recorded using a high-speed camera. The formation and role of white streaks are identified and analyzed. The results indicate that thermally induced bubbles significantly reduce both the discharge inception voltage and the flashover voltage. These bubbles also promote the initiation and growth of white streaks. The surface discharge development process is divided into four distinct stages. The presence of bubbles is found to guide the discharge channel and accelerate the overall process, while simultaneously making the associated electrical signals more difficult to detect. This study provides a theoretical basis for assessing the threat of bubble defects to transformer insulation.

title: Research on Charging Strategies for Multiple Battery Swapping Stations Considering Demand Response
authors: Yueran Ma, Na Li
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: With the rapid development of Electric Vehicles (EVs), Battery Swapping Stations (BSSs) have become key charging infrastructure. Thanks to their inventory of pre-charged batteries, BSSs possess significant operational flexibility, making them highly suitable for participation in Demand Response (DR) programs. This paper studies the joint optimization problem for multiple BSSs participating in DR, aiming to maximize their integrated operational revenue while satisfying the declared DR targets. A mathematical model is first established to precisely describe this complex optimization problem. Considering the problem's characteristics, an algorithm based on Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) is designed to efficiently solve for the BSS dynamic sequential charging decisions. Numerical experiments demonstrate the superiority and effectiveness of the designed algorithm in solving the research problem under real-world operating conditions.

title: Estimating Obstacle Position for Ensuring Safety of Elderly Powered Wheelchair Users
authors: JeonMin Kang, SuHong Eom, DongKwang Lee, Eung Hyuk Lee
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Conventional safety systems for powered wheelchairs, often relying on distance sensors, merely provide alerts about proximate obstacles. This is insufficient for elderly users, who may struggle with rapid perception and agile response, leading to accidents due to the lack of specific obstacle location information. Therefore, this paper proposes a technology to ensure the safety of elderly powered wheelchair users by detecting hazardous obstacles on pathways and providing their precise location information. The proposed method utilizes an RGB-D camera and machine learning for object detection. It then performs a 3D transformation on the detected object’s location within the image, based on the RGBD depth value. This transformation provides the obstacle’s direction and distance relative to the camera’s position, thereby assisting the user’s cognitive perception of the obstacle. Quantitative verification of the proposed technology demonstrates an average position estimation error of 2%.

title: Research and Implementation of a Flink-Based E-Commerce Order Processing and High-Value User Identification System for Real-Time Data Scenarios
authors: Weifeng Lu, Jing Shen, Long Zhang, Yize Gao, Rui Gu, Cuiling Song
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: With the rapid development of Internet technology and the explosive growth of the e-commerce industry, e-commerce platforms generate massive volumes of order data every day. How to efficiently extract valuable information from such data, especially the real-time identification of high-value users, has become an important means of enhancing enterprise competitiveness. Traditional offline processing methods can no longer meet the dual requirements of real-time performance and accuracy demanded by modern e-commerce applications. To address this challenge, this paper designs and implements a real-time e-commerce order processing and high-value user identification system based on the stream processing engine Apache Flink.The system adopts a loosely coupled and scalable distributed architecture, integrating multiple core big data components such as Flume, Kafka, Flink, Redis, and HDFS to establish a complete processing pipeline from data collection, message transmission, and real-time computation to result storage. In the data collection phase, Flume monitors system logs generated by business servers and transmits data concurrently to Kafka and HDFS via channels, achieving both real-time data transmission and offline backup. In the real-time processing phase, Flink continuously consumes order stream data from Kafka, applies event-time semantics for windowing, and utilizes KeyedProcessFunction together with state management mechanisms to dynamically aggregate user consumption data and identify the top two high-value users in real time. For result storage, the system writes the processed data into Redis, enabling real-time visualization on the front-end interface and supporting subsequent data-driven decision-making.Furthermore, this paper conducts an in-depth study on key technical challenges in Flink’s state fault-tolerance mechanism, window processing strategies, and optimization of integrations with external systems (such as Redis and Kafka). It also proposes corresponding optimization strategies for practical issues such as data skew and state inflation that may occur in real-world scenarios.Through deployment testing and performance evaluation, the system demonstrates high throughput and low latency, while reliably identifying and updating the list of high-value users in real time. The research results provide an effective technical solution for building real-time operational analytics systems in e-commerce platforms and offer valuable insights for other industries requiring real-time data processing, such as financial risk control and intelligent manufacturing.

title: GM (1,1) perception method for intelligent situation of SCADA in distribution network based on multi-source data fusion
authors: Shuo Zhang, Feng Zhao, Heyi Zhang, Jiaqi Chen, Yana Zhu, Jiarong Xie
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: A multi-source data fusion GM (1,1) intelligent situational awareness method based on grey system theory is proposed to address the characteristics of heterogeneous data sources and real-time situational awareness requirements in SCADA systems for distribution networks. The study constructs a comprehensive situation sequence by weighting and normalizing key characteristic quantities such as voltage, current, active power, reactive power, and load rate; Subsequently, utilizing the modeling advantages of the GM (1,1) model in a "small sample, poor information" environment, dynamic prediction of the operation status of the distribution network was achieved.Simulation experiments have shown that the fusion model outperforms traditional models in terms of prediction accuracy and trend consistency. Compared with ARIMA and BP neural networks, the multi-source data fusion GM (1,1) intelligent situational awareness method performs better in indicators such as average absolute percentage error, root mean square error, and grey correlation degree, with an error reduction of over 15% and a trend correlation degree improvement of over 10%. Multi source fusion significantly improves the sensitivity and stability of the model to wave dynamics, while its average single prediction time remains at the millisecond level, meeting the real-time requirements of SCADA. The proposed multi-source data fusion GM (1,1) model can achieve high-precision and low latency intelligent situational awareness in complex power operation environments, providing reliable technical support for the operation monitoring, early warning, and scheduling optimization of distribution networks.

title: Predictive System to Avoid Passenger Saturation on the Lima BRT using Neural Networks
authors: Aguilar Mellarez, Guillermo Teodoro, Roman Antezana, Aymin Cynthya, Montero Flores, Roberto Elías
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: The main cities in the world have a transport service that allows citizens to move around them. Lima has a public service called Bus Rapid Transit (Lima’s BRT), which allows the transportation of citizens. This service presents situations of passenger accumulation in all its stations caused by the poor determination of supply and demand of buses; this results in delays in departures and journeys, overloading of buses and the annoyance of people, so the quality of the service is diminished without fulfilling the objective of rapid transport. In this research, a predictive model has been developed using neural networks that allows estimating the flow of passengers in the stations, providing the competent authority with an important resource for determining the demand and supply of buses with the objective of speeding up the flow of passengers. The model allows a precision of 92% compared to other models and it has been proven that the estimation of the use of buses allows speeding up the flow of passengers, satisfactorily speeding up the service.

title: Miniaturized Millimeter-Wave Co-Linearly Polarized Patch Antenna with Dual Fence-Strip Resonators for In-Band Full-Duplex Applications
authors: Li Qian, Jing Liu, Zhiqiang Yu, Jianyi Zhou
abstract: In this paper, a miniaturized millimeter-wave (mm-Wave) co-linearly polarized microstrip antenna with dual fence-strip resonators (FSR) for in-band full-duplex (IBFD) applications is proposed. The FSRs are modeled as series LC circuits that create a zero-impedance current path at resonance, effectively suppressing current flow from the transmitting port to the receiving port. Two layers of FSR are integrated beneath the patch antenna to achieve high isolation in mm-Wave band between two ports. A prototype was fabricated and measured to validate the proposed co-linearly antenna. The measured results agree well with simulated results, which indicate a maximum in-band isolation of 35.9 dB within the dimension of 0.23 λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> × 0.25 λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>.

title: Balancing Innovation and Regulation: Integrating Blockchain into the European Digital Identity Framework
authors: Jorge Palomares, Marianna Zaccaro, Maryam Basereh, Elham Mohammadzadeh Mianji, Mohammad Fardad, Irina Tal
abstract: This paper investigates the legal implications of integrating the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure (EBSI) into the European Digital Identity (EUDI) framework. The objective is to assess EBSI's potential to support the EU Digital Identity Wallet and cross-border authentication services through a decentralized, service-oriented blockchain architecture. This research is motivated by the fragmented legal and regulatory landscape across EU Member States, which hinders the seamless implementation of EBSI. In particular, challenges related to interoperability, standardization, and compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) present significant obstacles to the adoption of blockchain-based identity solutions. Despite the European Commission's ambitions to promote secure and trusted digital interactions, existing digital identity frameworks lack sufficient provisions for managing these legal complexities in a decentralized environment. Using descriptive legal research and qualitative content analysis, the study examines EU regulatory texts, EBSI white papers, and international standards such as those from W3C. It also compares self-sovereign identity (SSI) models with traditional digital identity systems to identify critical legal and operational distinctions. Findings reveal that, while EBSI and the emerging Europeum-EDIC initiative signal substantial progress toward a digitally unified Europe, issues of legal harmonization, data governance, and technical interoperability persist. Theoretically, these challenges underscore the tension between decentralization and centralized legal frameworks. Practically, they highlight the need for clear regulatory guidance and technical standards to enable cross-border trust and functionality. This paper makes a unique contribution by offering legal recommendations tailored to blockchain-based digital identity systems within the EUDI context.

title: Dynamic Electrocardiogram Encryption for Enhanced Security and Privacy in E-Gate Facial Recognition Technology
authors: Rohan Suresh Vaidya, Purvi Dalal, Maulik Bhardwaj, Jaskaran Ohsan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Facial recognition technology (FRT) is important for quick identity checks at airport e-gates. However, it relies on fixed biometric templates, which can expose travellers to privacy violations and replay attacks. Once a template is hacked, it cannot be cancelled, leading to potential long-term abuse. This work mitigates these risks by combining live electrocardiogram (ECG) signals with FRT to create dynamic, session-specific keys that encrypt facial templates at the time of capture. During face acquisition, a short ECG segment is captured using a wearable or handheld sensor, preprocessed and converted through "R-R(peak-to-peak)" interval quantization and Secure Hash Algorithm 256-bit (SHA-256) hashing into a high-entropy key. This key encrypts the facial feature vector with Advanced Encryption Standard – Galois/Counter Mode (AES-GCM) before secure transmission, ensuring confidentiality, freshness and unlinkability. A formal threat model addresses man-in-the-middle interception, replay and insider compromise, demonstrating that ECG-derived keys render intercepted templates useless beyond their session. This method requires no changes to FRT algorithms, adapts to continuous passenger flow and ensures that post-verification data is invalidated. It balances operational efficiency with strong biometric privacy.

title: AI-Driven Document Intelligence: A Survey on Preprocessing, Detection and Recognition
authors: Tao Cheng, Shaoshuai Feng, Zhenda Yu, Fangsen Liu, Pengyuan Zhang, Peng Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Document parsing is an important research direction in the field of computer science and artificial intelligence. Its core goal is to transform unstructured or semi-structured documents (such as contracts, academic papers, invoices, etc.) into machine-readable structured data through algorithms. The current mainstream method consists of three AI driver modules: preprocessing, detection and recognition. In the preprocessing stage, the document image quality is optimized through tilt correction, denoising, contrast enhancement and binarization, providing standardized input for subsequent AI models. In the detection phase, relying on computer vision technology (such as convolutional neural network and transformer Architecture), the layout analysis and spatial positioning of semantic elements such as text areas, tables and formulas are realized, while preserving the context of the document structure. In the recognition phase, natural language processing (NLP) and deep learning model are combined to complete content extraction, logical relationship modeling and semantic understanding. In recent years, with the continuous breakthroughs in machine learning algorithms and computing frameworks, the robustness of document parsing technology in complex layout processing has been significantly improved, and has played a key role in intelligent document management, automated knowledge extraction and AI driven enterprise solutions. This review systematically summarizes the development of the current technology path, and discusses its frontier applications and challenges in the field of computer and artificial intelligence.

title: Development of Coaxial Differential Dual-Beam Interferometer
authors: Yung-Cheng Wang, Chung-Ping Chang, Mu-Hung Tsai, Cheng-Chieh Kuo, Yang-Rang Fan
abstract: This investigation aims to develop a coaxial dualbeam interferometer by modifying the Fabry-Perot interferometrical structure such that the influence of environmental disturbances and non-orthogonal signal can be minimized. The differential signal processing module for the coaxial dual-beam interferometer have been proposed. Displacement measurement experiments were conducted with this interferometer. The results revealed that the measurement error of the differential coaxial interferometer is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5 \upmu \mathrm{m}$</tex>.

title: AI-Based Fraud Detection System for Online Transactions with Real-Time Alerts
authors: Allada Sankara Rao, Dukka Somesh, Pragada Jagadeesh, Gaipuri Gowthami, Bandaru Annapoorna, Ksnv Someswara Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: In the rapidly evolving digital economy, securing the exponential increase in fraudulent activity has made online financial transactions crucial. This essay introduces an AI-driven fraud detection system tailored for real-time identification of malicious transactions. Using a publicly available imbalanced dataset, the model leverages Random Forest due to its superior interpretability and robustness in handling noisy and skewed data. A lightweight yet efficient Flask-based web interface is developed to ensure real-time interaction with users, delivering immediate fraud alerts. The system not only predicts the probability of fraudulent behavior but also provides useful information. for preventive mechanisms. According to experimental findings, the suggested system maintains minimal latency while achieving excellent accuracy, making it appropriate for deployment in real-world banking environments. This research contributes to enhancing transactional security Using methods for intelligent machine learning embedded within a user-friendly interface.

title: AI-Driven System for Assessing Age-Related Changes in Physical Status of Kyrgyz Women
authors: Kyialbek Sakibaev, Tugolbay Mamaev, Aiperi Alimbekova, Abdyrakman Eshiev, Tatyana Grichanova, Talantbek Narymbetov
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The paper introduces an AI-based system that evaluates physical changes in the age of the Kyrgyz women basing on a multimodal federated learning model with an explainable fusion network and executed on the Flower (FL) framework. Anthropometric, physiological, and functional data is incorporated into the model to predict the patterns of biological aging whilst preserving privacy of the data at the distributed healthcare centers. The results of the experiment indicate a prediction accuracy of 93.6 percent and a mean absolute error of 4.2 years, which is better than the traditional centralized and single-modality models. Use of explainable AI methods, e.g. SHAP contributes to the level of interpretability since it can be used to identify the most important indicators of aging such as grip strength, gait speed, and bone density. The federated system will provide a safe cooperation between regional clinics, and ethical and privacy-ensuring data analysis will be promoted. The system will offer a population-specific, interpretable, and scalable solution to detecting physical aging in early stages to support personalized healthcare plans toward the Kyrgyz women.

title: Focusing System with Multiple Dielectric Lenses for mmWave OAM Waves Generated by Loop Antenna Array
authors: Ryo Ishikawa, Masaaki Kawase, Takumi Aramaki, Akira Saitou, Kazuhiko Honjo
abstract: A focusing system with multiple dielectric lenses has been developed for millimeter-wave orbital angular momentum (OAM) waves generated by loop antennas. Since the OAM waves generated from the loop antenna has a large spread angle, a multiple lens system is applied to obtain sufficient focusing effect. For the design, ray-tracing approximation was applied to estimate the OAM propagation. By using the fabricated multiple dielectric lens system as a transmitter and a parabolic reflector system as a receiver, a 4-channel OAM transmission evaluation was carried out at the 40-GHz band. As a result, a signal-to-interference ratio of more than 17.1 dB was obtained at 39.8 GHz for a transmission distance of 1 m.

title: LSST: Lightweight Spectral–Spatial Transformer Network for Efficient Hyperspectral Image Analysis
authors: Soumya Ranjan Sahu, Sucheta Panda, Sasmita Acharya
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) classification poses unique challenges due to the high dimensionality of spectral information and complex spatial structures. To address these, we propose a novel transformer-based architecture named LSST (Local-Global Spectral-Spatial Transformer), which effectively captures both local spatial relationships and global spectral dependencies. The LSST framework introduces a multi-scale spectral-spatial encoding mechanism using self-attention modules and hierarchical feature aggregation to enhance contextual understanding. By integrating local and global feature learning, LSST improves class discrimination, particularly in spectrally similar and spatially heterogeneous regions. Comprehensive experiments on benchmark HSI datasets, including Pavia University and Botswana, demonstrate the superior performance of LSST over several state-of-the-art models such as HyperES<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>T, MSST, and SSFCT. The proposed method achieves significant improvements in Overall Accuracy (OA), Average Accuracy (AA), and Kappa coefficient across all test cases. Confusion matrix analysis and visual results further validate the robustness and generalization capability of LSST. This study confirms the effectiveness of attention-driven models in hyperspectral analysis and sets a foundation for future research in efficient transformer-based architectures for remote sensing tasks.

title: A 127-GHz High-Efficiency Push-Push Oscillator Using Harmonic-Decoupling Bypass-Stub in 100-nm InP HEMT Technology
authors: Seungwoo Shim, Hyunjoon Kim, Sanggeun Jeon
abstract: A push-push oscillator incorporating a harmonic-decoupling bypass-stub (HDBS) is presented to enhance second-harmonic efficiency by mitigating parasitic-induced gate swing at sub-terahertz frequencies. In conventional push-push topologies, gate-to-drain capacitance introduces a negative-feedback path that causes destructive interference of the second-harmonic signal at the drain node, thereby limiting output power. To address this, HDBS is introduced to reduce signal propagation through the transconductance path, thereby mitigating the destructive interference. The oscillator with HDBS is implemented in a 100-nm InP D-mode HEMT process and operates at 127.2 GHz with 1.35 dBm output power, 7.07% DC-to-RF efficiency, and – 104.1 dBc/Hz phase noise at 10 MHz offset.

title: Experimental Design of Wind Speed Analytics Prediction Methodology Using Modified Deep Learning Principle
authors: Sophia. P, C.R.Rene Robin
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Wind speed forecasting is important in broad areas such as renewable energy management, disaster prediction, aviation safety and agricultural planning. Nevertheless, the prediction of the wind speed is a complicated problem which is highly non-linear, stochastic and chaotic and depends on a variety of environmental factors. The study introduces an enhanced deep learning-based wind speed analytics model based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and multi-head attention models, coupled with residual connections and a specially designed peak-sensitive loss. The model was trained and validated using real-time and historical data collected with meteorological sensors and IoT-based deployments in the different geographical and climatic settings. The model showed significant progressions compared to the conventional approaches like ARIMA and bare LSTM, with a Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.38 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.05 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, having a R2 value of 0.95 and a maximum wind detection accuracy of 94.3%. This performance is owed to the architectural improvements that focus on the short-term changes and peak winds. Also, the hyperparameter tuning was done with Bayesian Optimization, so that optimal configuration is achieved automatically. The suggested architecture is lightweight and can be deployed on edge computing platforms, which would be appropriate to real-time forecasting. This paper has created a predictable, interpretive, and highly accurate method of predicting the wind speed. It provides access points into smart city systems and renewable energy networks, where dynamic wind situations can be anticipating to promote the optimization of efficiency and resilience.

title: AI-Driven Garbage Truck Monitoring & Smart Waste Management System
authors: Khushi Sikarwar, Aditya Dubey, Nookala Venu, Dhananjay Bisen, Md Nizam Ul Haque
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Municipal solid waste management is becoming exponentially complex and the environment is becoming largely challenged due to rapid urbanization and pro-longed population growth. Conventional waste collection modes are woefully in-efficient in terms of routing, pickups, or monitoring, and public participation is denied. This paper proposes an intelligent waste management framework integrating artificial intelligence (AI), the Internet of Things (IoT), and computer vision algorithms to optimize all processes related to waste collection. Noise pollution monitoring alleviates environmental degradation caused by garbage trucks, while an integrated government dashboard offers comprehensive analytical insights. The simulated testing in urban spaces proved that collection times are reduced by 26%, fuel consumption decreased by 31%, and citizen satisfaction increased by 42%, compared with traditional waste management systems. By presenting how integrated technological approaches can reinvent urban waste systems towards a greener and cost-effective operation, this study supports the smart city solutions.

title: Impedance Estimation of Internal Nodes of RF Devices based on Measurement Cable De-Embedding Enabled by Transmission Line Model Fitting
authors: Abdul Basir, Uzman Ali, Toni Björninen
abstract: Fixtures and adapters introduce parasitic effects in radiofrequency (RF) components measurements, which unwantedly transform their impedances. To remove the effects of coaxial measurement cables, this paper presents a de-embedding method based on transmission line (TL) model fitting in 400–3000 MHz range. The method uses numerically fitted TL parameters: characteristic impedance and electrical length to extract the terminal impedance of any device under test (DUT). We have used two different DUTs with the 8 cm long flexible coaxial connector to extract these parameters. As a proof of concept, an experimental validation of a quarter-wave transformer confirms that the de-embedded impedance correlates closely with simulations across the broad frequency range considered.

title: Machine Learning Driven Energy Optimization for Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency IoT Communications in 5G Networks
authors: G Senthil Velan, Mahmoud Odeh, Netranandha Behra, T Chandra Sekhar Rao, N Karthik, Ramya M
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The high rate of Internet of Things (IoT) gadgets development in 5G networks has prompted an immediate demand of ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC) and energy efficiency at the same time. The traditional optimization methods tend to be unable to balance latency, reliability, and power consumption as they are both static and heuristic. In response to these constraints, this study will present an Energy Optimization Framework of URLLC-based IoT communications in 5G networks that will be based on Machine Learning. The model proposed combines the Reinforcement Learning (RL) to adaptively control power, Deep Neural Networks (DNN) to predict the traffic and channel conditions, and Federated Learning (FL) to update the model distributed across the IoT nodes in a privacy-preserving manner. Using the adaptability of learning, the system will dynamically allocate network resources and network transmission power to reduce the energy expenditure without negatively affecting the latency or reliability. It will be trained and validated with the datasets like the IoT network dataset, the ITU-R M.2412 and the 5G NR simulation data created by Network Simulator 3 (NS-3). Performance assessment will be conducted in parameters like energy consumption, end-to-end latency, packet delivery ratio (PDR), throughput, reliability and spectral efficiency. The projected results will be 25-35 percent of energy consumption and 15- 20 percent of latency performance improvement relative to the current 5G energy management schemes.
