In general, the suggested intelligent optimization model will improve scalability, adaptability, and sustainability in the large-scale IoT environments, which will go a long way in the creation of energy-aware and intelligent communication systems of 6G.

title: Real-Time Vision Inspection with AI-Based Edge Processor for Printed Circuit Board Assembly Quality Control
authors: Lai Jun Le, Hudyjaya Siswoyo Jo
abstract: In modern electronic manufacturing, particularly in printed circuit board (PCB) assembly, ensuring product quality through automated inspection is essential. While traditional automated optical inspection (AOI) systems are effective, they often face limitations when dealing with complex assemblies and are typically designed for specific board types, limiting flexibility and scalability. This research presents the development of a universal, real-time inspection system for PCB assembly using artificial intelligence (AI) integrated with edge computing. The system is trained on a diverse dataset containing common PCB assembly defects, such as missing components, solder bridging, and insufficient solder. A lightweight AI model is developed to enable efficient inference on low-power edge processors. The proposed system is evaluated in real-world testing scenarios using different PCB assemblies to validate its adaptability and feasibility for deployment in practical manufacturing environments. Results demonstrate the potential of AI-based edge solutions in enhancing the flexibility and performance of automated quality control processes.

title: Intelligent Flood Sensing (IFS): Real-Time Flood Monitoring and Alert System for Farmers
authors: Aastik Das, Jyoti Saxena, Om Prakash Singh, Ujjwal Biswas
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Floods are among the most devastating natural disasters, posing significant threats to agriculture, rural infrastructure, and the livelihoods of farmers. The Intelligent Flood Sense (IFS) is a comprehensive approach to flood detection, prediction, and alert dissemination tailored specifically for farming communities. Using satellite imagery, weather data, and IoT-based sensors, the proposed system uses machine learning algorithms to analyze environmental parameters and forecast flood events with high precision. A key focus of this study is the development of a low-latency alert mechanism that notifies farmers. The system is designed to be scalable, cost-effective, and easily deployable in rural and semi-urban regions prone to flooding. By integrating predictive analytics with ground-level communication strategies, this work contributes to building resilient agricultural practices and supports sustainable disaster risk reduction. Our proposed model has a training accuracy of 97.8% and validation accuracy stabilized at 96.4%, with the potential to be extended to other climate-related events, offering a foundation for future smart agriculture solutions.

title: Reduction of Sidelobe Level in Reflectarray Antennas Using LCMV Algorithm
authors: Hogun Lee, Jeong-Hae Lee
abstract: This study presents a method for reducing the sidelobe level of reflectarray antennas by integrating LCMV(Linear Constraint Minimum Variance) algorithm with a GA(Genetic Algorithm) optimization framework. The proposed method addresses the problem of high sidelobe level by formulating the beam pattern synthesis as an LCMV optimization. A 12x12 reflectarray antenna operating at 10GHz was used as the test platform. The results demonstrate that the LCMV-GA method significantly improves sidelobe performance, with only minimal degradation in main beam gain across various beam steering angles, thereby validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Boundary-Aware Concept Drift Detection for Automated Industrial Systems with Limited Supervision
authors: Haowen Tan
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In real-world automation systems, factors such as dynamic environmental changes, equipment degradation, and operational mode shifts can induce continuous changes in data distribution—a phenomenon known as concept drift—which leads to progressive deterioration in the performance of deployed models and jeopardizes control accuracy and operational reliability. To enable timely detection and early warning of model performance degradation, this paper proposes a semi-supervised concept drift detection framework based on boundary sample selection. The approach employs contrastive learning to construct a highly discriminative embedding space and utilizes gradient-based response analysis to accurately identify critical samples near the decision boundaries for selective annotation. This allows for early detection of model failure risks under limited labeling resources. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively identifies various types of concept drift without relying on fully labeled data. While maintaining competitive detection accuracy compared to fully supervised approaches, it significantly reduces labeling overhead, offering a practical and efficient solution for sustaining the reliable operation and adaptive maintenance of machine learning models in automation systems.

title: A Comparative Study on Event Extraction from Open-Source Military News
authors: Hao Yang, Yan Yu, Xuan Li, Mao Wang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Event extraction (EE), as a core research direction in natural language processing, serves as a key means to automatically transform textual information into structured data, holding significant application value in areas such as intelligence collection, document synthesis, and intelligent question answering. With the explosive growth of open-source military news data, the efficient and accurate extraction of high-value military intelligence from such content has become a critical challenge that requires urgent solutions. Current research predominantly focuses on sentence-level event extraction in general news or financial domains, while specialized studies on Chinese military news texts remain noticeably insufficient. In light of this, this paper takes open-source Chinese military news as the research subject and systematically evaluates the applicability and effectiveness of mainstream deep learning methods for the task of document-level event extraction, aiming to provide theoretical and methodological support for the automated processing of military textual information.

title: Predicting ADHD Diagnosis Using Anxiety and ASRS Features
authors: Sakthi Priya G, J K Kaviyalakshmi, J R Sri Prishigaa, K S Kamali Sri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a complex condition that often continues into adulthood. It can negatively affect academic, social, and emotional functioning. Traditional methods for diagnosis, such as clinical interviews and behavioral assessments, rely heavily on subjective judgment. This can lead to significant variability and potential misdiagnosis. To close this gap, this work suggests a hybrid diagnostic framework. It combines psychometric data from the Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) and the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI). This way, it integrates both ADHD-related and anxiety-related behavioral markers. The methodology follows a two-stage approach. In the first stage, a lightweight one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) automatically extracts features. This captures hidden behavioral patterns from questionnaire data. In the second stage, the extracted features are classified using common machine learning algorithms, including Support Vector Machine (SVM), Logistic Regression (LR), and Random Forest (RF). The dataset consists of structured responses from standardized self-report questionnaires. It was preprocessed, normalized, and validated using stratified k-fold cross-validation to ensure reliability. The experimental results show that the hybrid approach achieves high accuracy and consistent performance across several classifiers. CNN-based feature extraction significantly improves predictive power. Visual analyses reveal dataset imbalances, such as the low number of ADHD cases compared to non-ADHD cases, and provide insights into patterns of gender distribution. The study concludes that combining anxiety features with ADHD self-report scales creates a cost-effective, scalable, and interpretable method for early ADHD screening. This work not only enhances diagnostic reliability but also highlights the potential of merging deep learning with traditional machine learning in mental health applications.

title: Accurate House Price Prediction using Ensemble Machine Learning Model
authors: Bharti Thakur, Ansh Bisht
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: In today's dynamic real estate industry, accurately predicting home prices is more important than ever. In this study, we developed a machine-learning-based system for estimating home prices using the Ames Housing Dataset. The system is capable of providing predictions from regression models (predicting exact price) and classification models (grouped into price ranges) comprising multiple models from both regression and classification categories, including single regression techniques: linear regression, lasso, and ridge regression, and advanced techniques such as support vector machines (SVM) and random forest. A key contribution of this study is the development of a unified system that leverages Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for efficient dimensionality reduction and simultaneously addresses both the exact price prediction (regression) and price categorization (classification) tasks to provide comprehensive real estate insights. Overall, the random forest provided the best estimates for price across all of the models tested, and SVM was classified into the best price groups. Multiple graphs were employed, including heatmaps, scree plots, and price prediction graphs, to visualize the model's performance and identify key features. There are substantial potential applications for this system because it can provide a buyer, seller, or investor with explicit price estimates. Exploring potential future work and improvements with that system included options such as adding time trends, adding location-based variables, deep learning models (and future versions), and a real-time app that can increase the value of price prediction and be used in multiple cities or markets

title: Low Earth Orbit Satellite Range Scheduling Using Advantage Actor Critic and Large Neighborhood Search
authors: Tianhao Zhou, Yuning Chen, Ming Chen, Hao Wang, Jie Chun, Xiang Lin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The Satellite Range Scheduling Problem (SRSP) involves task types such as Telemetry, Tracking, and Command (TTC) and Data Transmission (DT), which are essential for ensuring satellite operation and mission completion. With the rapid expansion of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) constellations, the demand for TTC and DT, driven by massive mission requirement data, has increased significantly. However, existing methods lack scalability in handling large-scale and complex data and fail to address the integrated scheduling of TTC and DT tasks, rendering them inadequate for meeting the scheduling requirements of an integrated TTC and DT ground station network. To address this issue, this study develops a mixed-integer programming model that captures the scheduling relationship between TTC and DT tasks under shared resources and proposes a big-data-oriented intelligent scheduling method—Advantage Actor-Critic with Large Neighborhood Search (A2C-LNS). The method employs multi-policy networks to learn and optimize the destruction ratio, task selection, and repair strategies, driven by large-scale task and resource data. Experiments conducted on multiple large-scale simulation and data-driven scenarios demonstrate that A2C-LNS achieves superior performance in terms of mission profit and operational efficiency.

title: GNN-Assisted LLMs for Configurable Service Function Chaining Orchestration in IoT Services
authors: Prohim Tam, Dinesh Elango, Seungwoo Kang, Seyha Ros, Riccardo Corrado, Seokhoon Kim
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Large language model (LLM) showcases intelligence and creativity for a wide variety of problem-solving. With state-specific training, LLMs can tailor the core knowledge from generic into detailed and reliable instruction. Researchers have leveraged their capability in understanding context into big data IoT services for giving specific recommendations and turning into actionable configuration as management files. In future IoT networks, intelligent service function chaining (SFC) orchestration framework is significant to handle massive real-time services. Our framework introduces proactive classifiers and request handlers with enabling high-dimensional state learning for optimal action configuration in software-implemented service functions. These mechanisms enable service function forwarders to efficiently distribute IoT network services while ensuring optimal utilization. The actions are configured using a proactive online module to physical and logical network graph components through Sfvo-Nfvo and Sfvo-Sdnc points. Simulations are conducted using an integrated testbed consisting of Mininet, RYU SDN controller, and Mini-NFV. The proposed orchestration guides real-time settings on the policy mechanisms and forwarding rules of the testbed in the experiments.

title: Skin Cancer Classification using Deep Learning and Explainable AI Techniques
authors: Nikita Chorge, Veena Parihar
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Early detection of skin cancer is important, as it facilitates early and effective treatment, thereby being an important international health issue. The proposed work designs a Deep Learning (DL) mechanism which classifies skin lesions into cancerous or non-cancerous categories. Key contributions include (i) merging HAM10000 and ISIC2024 datasets to create a large and diverse training corpus, (ii) applying transfer learning using ResNet50V2 with early stopping and regularization, (iii) integrating Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) for visual interpretability which supports clinical trust and decision making and (iv) developing a user-friendly Gradio interface that enables real-time prediction and visualization.

title: Cooperative Control of Multiple Motor Movers Based on Model Predictive Control
authors: Yize Wang, Zhicheng Wang, Tong Wen, Ya Deng
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Permanent magnet synchronous linear motor (PMSLM) is widely used in modern logistics and manufacturing owing to their long-travel capability and the potential of multi-mover operation on a shared track to reduce cost and improve efficiency. However, in the absence of effective cooperative control, safe inter-mover spacing cannot be guaranteed, making collisions likely. To address this challenge, this article proposes a cooperative control algorithm for multi-motor movers based on model predictive control (MPC), aiming to achieve precise spacing maintenance during high-speed motion. We begin by modeling an individual mover in the PMSLMs system and detailing its speed control strategy. Building upon the above, we construct a longitudinal motion model for multi-motor movers adopting a predecessor–following (PF) topology. Finally, we propose an improved variable time headway (IVTH) strategy and use it to design the MPC-based cooperative control algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves high-precision tracking control of spacing and velocity. Notably, even under sudden conditions such as emergency braking, the system can respond rapidly and maintain safe spacing. This research provides a feasible solution for achieving low-cost, high-efficiency cooperative control of multi-motor movers in long-travel transportation systems.

title: Comparison of Deep Learning and Statistical Methods for EV Charging Demand Forecasting
authors: Maizatul Shafiqah Sharul Anuar, Illani Mohd Nawi, Saeed S. Ba Hashwan
abstract: The growing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) presents challenges for maintaining power grid stability and managing energy resources efficiently. Accurate forecasting of EV charging demand is crucial for optimizing charging infrastructure and ensuring grid reliability. This study evaluates two time series forecasting models: the Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) network and the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model. The LSTM model, based on deep learning, captures complex, time-dependent, and nonlinear patterns in EV charging data, whereas ARIMA, a statistical approach, models linear trends and seasonality. Both models were trained on 90% of the dataset and tested on the remaining 10%, with performance evaluated over 30-, 60-, and 9 0 - d a y forecasting horizons using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE). The results show that the LSTM model achieved significantly higher forecasting accuracy than ARIMA. These findings demonstrate the potential of deep learning approaches to capture complex, nonlinear patterns in EV charging behavior, providing a more reliable framework for demand forecasting in smart grid applications.

title: Compact Ultra-Wideband Antenna for SFCW GPR-Based Concrete Scanning
authors: Gyeongyong Jeong, Seung-Jun Park, Changbin Joh, Joo-Hyung Lee, Moon-Que Lee
abstract: In this paper, we proposes a compact ultra-wideband (UWB) antenna for stepped-frequency continuous wave (SFCW) ground penetrating radar (GPR) used in concrete scanning applications. The proposed antenna integrates a bowtie radiator, a bent tapered balun, and a vertical strip reflector with attached RF absorbers. This configuration achieves a low profile, wideband impedance matching, and a high front-to-back ratio (FBR). The fabricated antenna has compact dimensions of 45 mm × 90 mm × 19.5 mm and exhibits a wide −10 dB reflection bandwidth from 0.85 GHz to beyond 5 GHz, along with an FBR exceeding 10 dB across the entire operating band.

title: Identifying Technology Evolution Pathways Using Patent Citation and Multidimensional Scaling
authors: Duanwu Yan, Zhuona Zhang, Qinrong Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: With the rapid development of science and technology, active innovation has become the basic requirement to keep up with the times and lead the trend. Analyzing technology evolution paths through patent identification enables organizations to identify R&D priorities and understand key technologies' distribution and future trajectories. This study proposes a three-layer analytical framework for identifying domain-specific technology evolution paths using patent citation analysis and multidimensional scaling. The first layer is the data processing layer, including data acquisition and preprocessing; The second layer is the data analysis layer, including patent data citation extraction, patent citation network construction and patent co citation matrix construction; The third layer is the result analysis layer, which mainly analyzes the results of the second layer and improves the main path. Finally, this study selects the photovoltaic inverter technology field for empirical analysis. A key technology evolution path in the field of photovoltaic inverter is obtained: research on DC-AC conversion method of inverter → research on improvement of inverter efficiency and power quality → research on intelligent and scene application of inverter → research on low voltage ride through control of photovoltaic inverter. The empirical results show that the proposed framework effectively identifies critical technology evolution pathways within specialized domains.

title: Wideband Endfire Magnetoelectric Dipole Antenna Array Based on Micro-Metal Additive Manufacturing
authors: Quanda Liu, Fan Wu, Jingxue Wang
abstract: A wideband endfire magnetoelectric (ME) dipole antenna and array using micro-metal additive manufacturing (M-MAM) technology is proposed. The design employs a bended ground as a reflector to significantly enhance gain by improving broadside radiation. For impedance matching, the conventional dipole is reshaped into a L-shaped configuration, which achieves a stable radiation within a broad bandwidth of 78.3%. Subsequently, a compact 1×4 antenna array based on this element design is developed. By removing bended ground between elements and folding the L-shaped dipoles, the miniaturization of the array is achieved, which presents an impedance bandwidth of 78.3% with a peak gain of 11.5 dBi. Due to its wide bandwidth, compact footprint, and stable radiation, the proposed ME dipole array shows strong promise for high data-rate sub-THz wireless systems.

title: Advanced 3D Path Planning for Robotic Calligraphy Based on LLM-Driven Text Prompts
authors: Cheuk Tung Shadow Yiu, Dick Ho Cheung, Haolun Huang, Kam Tim Woo
abstract: Chinese calligraphy is a complicated art form that requires precise control of movement and brush dynamics, making it a challenging task for robotic systems. This paper presents a novel approach to enabling robotic manipulators to perform Chinese calligraphy using 3D path planning algorithms and a large language model (LLM) as input generators. The proposed framework integrates an LLM to generate textual content prompts, which are then transformed into detailed 3D Bézier curve trajectories which represent the strokes of Chinese characters. These trajectories are optimized to ensure smooth and accurate motion of the robotic manipulator, taking into account the brush's pressure, orientation, and speed to emulate traditional calligraphy techniques. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach in producing visually authentic Chinese calligraphy with high precision and artistic quality. This work highlights the potential of combining LLM with advanced robotic path planning to bridge the gap between traditional art and robot world.

title: Unsupervised Brain Abnormality Detection and Segmentation Method Based on Improved Diffusion Model Block
authors: Fan Li, Fozia Anjum, Chao Huang, Musab Sahrim, Zhixiao Wang, Mengfei Kang, Minghua Zhao, Jie Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging is widely applied to diagnosing neurological disorders, offering detailed anatomical information for early detection and treatment. However, the scarcity of labeled abnormal cases, the diversity of lesion patterns, and the inefficiency of current generative models remain major challenges for unsupervised brain abnormality detection and segmentation. Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and standard Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs) often suffer from instability and weak global context modeling. We propose a patch-wise Improved Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (pIDDPM) integrating an enhanced DDPM backbone, a U-ViT network combining Vision Transformer attention with U-Net skip connections, and a patch-based inference strategy for precise anomaly localization. Experiments on BraTS21 and MSLUB datasets show that pIDDPM surpasses state-of-the-art baselines, achieving Dice scores of 49.63% and 10.42%, respectively, confirming its effectiveness for unsupervised medical image analysis.

title: A Novel Missing Data Imputation for Early Chronic Kidney Disease Diagnosis Using ANFIS System and Machine Learning Models
authors: T. Chandra Sekhar Rao, Ibrahim Mohammad Khrais, Millicent Mabel M, P Lakshmi Tejaswi, K Srinija, M Ramya
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: One of the ways to predict and manage the risk of Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) in aged patients with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is to identify the main contributing factors and Electronic Health Records (EHR), we designed the missing data imputation for early CKD Diagnosis using an ANFIS and machine learning (MDECKA) model. The dataset comprises critical demographic and clinical variables from patients aged 60 and above with CKD stages 1 to 4, excluding stage 5 cases for data consistency. A preprocessing pipeline, initially assessing missing data randomness using Little's MCAR test. When data is identified as potentially missing completely at random, KNN imputation is merged with an ANFIS. To enhance the accuracy in the approximation of nonlinear relationships, the ANFIS combines fuzzy logic and neural networks via a carefully designed five-layer network. Model accuracy is measured using the NRMSE, and optimal biomarker patterns connecting kidney function with cardiac health are identified using genetically optimised Fuzzy C-Means clustering. The MDECKA model evaluation metrics include accuracy, precision, recall, F1-Score, MDECKA confusion matrix, MDECKA ROC curve, specificity, and learning curve. By comparing existing models DCKME, DLCKD, and EACKI. MDECKA has an accuracy of 93.75 %, with precision at 90.3 %, sensitivity at 93.3 %, specificity at 94 %, and an F1-score of 91.8 %. It achieved a TPR of around 0.95 and a low FPR of below 0.05, an AUC of 0.98, a DCKME of 0.91, a DLCKD of 0.94, and an EACKI of 0.97. The specificity of 97 % during the BFS phase and 99 % in the AFS phase through a fuzzy clustering-ANFIS method. Validation accuracies for MDECKA range from 0.99 to 1.00 for datasets CKD15 and CKD21.

title: Focus, Attend, Extract: LLM-Guided Prompt Refinement for Event Argument Extraction
authors: Zhenyu Song, Shiyu Fang, Ningchao Ge, Xuan Li, Lihua Liu, Jiaxuan Liu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Event Argument Extraction (EAE) is a fundamental information extraction task, focuses on pinpointing event participants and categorizing their specific roles. While prompt-based methods leveraging Pre-trained Language Models (PLMs) have set high performance standards, their reliance on static, predefined prompts limits their effectiveness in complex scenarios involving long-distance dependencies or semantic ambiguity. To address this, we propose LLM-Enhanced Focus for Prompts (LEFP), a novel framework that enhances prompts with dynamic, contextual focus. LEFP employs the Large Language Model (LLM) to analyze the input document and distill the most salient textual evidence for each argument role, which we term a "focus snippet". This snippet is then encoded and fused with the original role representation at the feature level, creating a context-aware prompt. Extensive evaluation on three challenging datasets indicates that LEFP consistently improves performance. Further ablation studies validate our design, confirming that feature-level fusion is significantly more effective than simple textual concatenation. Our work demonstrates that leveraging LLMs to generate auxiliary focus information is a promising direction for enhancing smaller, specialized models, effectively combining the reasoning power of LLMs with the efficiency of fine-tuned PLMs.

title: Towards Sustainable Smart Cities: IoT and Big Data-Driven Anomaly Detection in Building Management
authors: Irin Laila Parvin, Md. Arif Rahman, Tahsina Farah Sanam
abstract: For the development of sustainable smart cities, the combination of Internet of Things (IoT) and Big Data Analytics plays a vital role while IoT constitutes interconnected sensors to generate a data-rich environment, enabling real-time measurements and contextual information for smart buildings with significant benefits and challenges in security, data acquisition, processing, and storage. To identify anomalous devices in smart buildings, there are various existing statistical and classical Machine Learning models. But they are significantly inefficient to deal with non-linearity with average reported performance. Comprising the LSTM Autoencoder model and implementing advanced data analysis and machine learning techniques, this study represents recent research on anomaly detection with the unique CU-BEMS data set, which offers valuable insights for research applications. This technique includes various dataintensive approaches, along with lightweight methods tailored for edge and in-node computing. The paper highlights state-of-the-art methods for detecting anomalies in sensor systems by addressing challenges such as sensor miniaturization, energy efficiency, security, and data heterogeneity.

title: Multi-View and Multi-Kernel Crack Segmentation Network Based on Visual State Space
authors: Zilong Zhao, Chuanyi Ma, Pei Niu, Wenhao Sun, Feng Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Crack segmentation is crucial for identifying and repairing potential issues in infrastructure, such as roads and bridges. However, existing pixel-level crack segmentation models often struggle to effectively capture the directional diversity and complex structural characteristics of cracks, which limits segmentation accuracy. To address this, this paper proposes a crack segmentation network named MMCSeg, which is based on the Visual State Space and incorporates multi-view and scale alignment. It consists of two key modules. First, an MARC module is designed, incorporating a multi-view processing mechanism along with an adaptive rotated convolution module to enhance the model’s adaptability to cracks of varying orientations. Additionally, a Multi-Kernel scale Alignment Fusion (MKAF) module is implemented, which aligns cross-scale feature spaces through multi-kernel convolution, effectively integrating crack features at different resolutions. Extensive experiments are conducted on three datasets, and the results demonstrate that MMCSeg achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance in crack segmentation, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: BLSQ: AI-Enhanced Performance Framework for Wireless Multihop Networks
authors: Zhihan Cui, Yuto Lim, Yasuo Tan
abstract: Multi-server wireless multihop networks (MWMNs) are critical for modern communication systems, enabling efficient data transmission between devices and servers. However, the complexity of determining optimal server selection and multihop path planning in such networks often results in high interference, high network latency, low network capacity, and reduced network performance. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a two-stage network optimization scheme for MWMNs, using Broad Learning System and Q-learning, called BLSQ. First, the Broad Learning System (BLS) is employed to allocate servers to devices based on their location and computational requirements. Second, a Q-learning algorithm is introduced to optimize multihop path selection, aiming to maximize network capacity while minimizing interference. The proposed approach is evaluated based on different path selection methods in extensive simulations. Results demonstrate that our method significantly reduces network interference, increases network capacity, and achieves lower transmission time, providing a possible approach for optimizing wireless in MWMNs.

title: Real-Time Instance Segmentation for Object Scale Diversity
authors: Yujia Chen, Yaochi Zhao, Jiezhuo Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Achieving an optimal trade-off between inference latency and segmentation accuracy is paramount for safety-critical applications, such as autonomous driving and maritime surveillance. However, current real-time frameworks largely rely on static receptive fields that are ill-equipped to handle significant object scale variations, frequently resulting in performance degradation when detecting diminutive targets. To mitigate this representational bias, we present a novel Scale-Equalization Decoder (SED). Unlike traditional approaches, SED dynamically modulates local feature responses within shallow layers to equilibrate the semantic weight of objects regardless of their size. By effectively amalgamating these rectified features with deep semantic information, our method significantly improves segmentation fidelity without incurring substantial computational costs. Comprehensive experiments on standard benchmarks (MS COCO, Cityscapes) and remote sensing datasets (SSDD, HRSID) demonstrate that our proposed architecture outperforms contemporary real-time baselines, exhibiting superior capability in small-object detection within complex environments.

title: Prediction of Insulating Oil Breakdown Voltage Based on Ultrasonic Characteristics and Generalised Regression Neural Networks
authors: Yuhang Jiao
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Breakdown voltage is a critical electrical parameter characterizing the quality of insulating oil, closely related to the operational safety of transformers. Therefore, this paper proposes a breakdown voltage prediction method for insulating oil based on ultrasonic features and a GRNN neural network. First, 100 sets of insulating oil samples with varying breakdown voltages were collected. Multi-frequency ultrasonic analysis was conducted to investigate the amplitude-frequency response and phase-frequency response between ultrasonic acoustic parameters and breakdown voltage. Then, the original high-dimensional input data underwent feature dimensionality reduction using the LLE algorithm. Finally, a GRNN-based prediction model for insulating oil breakdown voltage was established. The results demonstrate that the combined LLE and GRNN approach enables rapid and effective prediction of insulating oil breakdown voltage, achieving 96% prediction accuracy with a training time of only 1.5 seconds. Its performance significantly outperforms other comparison models in this study.

title: Energy-Efficient Multiply-Accumulate Architecture Using Compressor Logic for FPGA-Based Systems
authors: Sakthi G, Abhishek N Tripathi, Jagana Bihari Padhy, Indrasen Singh, Vivek Rajpoot
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Multiply and Accumulate (MAC) units form the computational backbone of modern digital systems such as digital signal processors, machine learning accelerators, and embedded IoT devices. As performance and efficiency become increasingly critical, conventional MAC architectures face limitations due to sequential accumulation delays, increased area, and underutilized hardware. This work addresses these challenges by proposing a high-speed and area-efficient MAC unit that eliminates loop delays through a compressor-based architecture. The design integrates accumulation directly within the multipliers summation network using 4:2 and 5:2 compressors, supported by Half and Full Adders and a Carry Save Adder (CSA), thus avoiding idle cycles and improving throughput. An 88-bit MAC unit was modeled in Verilog HDL, functionally verified through simulation, and synthesized on the Nexys 4 DDR (Artix-7) FPGA using the Vivado Design Suite. The architecture achieves a reduction in area utilization and an improvement in critical path delay compared to existing designs, with a moderate increase in power due to the parallel compression logic. This trade-off makes it highly suitable for real-time, performance-critical applications. This work also aligns with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 9 (Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure) and 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production), contributing to energy-efficient hardware designs.

title: Enhancing Reinforcement Learning Agent with Multimodal Large Model Perception
authors: Lian Liu, Dongpu Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: With the continuous development of artificial intelligence technology and high-performance computing power, various large models have transitioned from the experimental testing phase to production use, offering more efficient solutions for traditional deep learning research. By annotating a massive amount of data, reinforcement learning algorithms are utilized to inject data features into the model. When the model's parameter scale reaches a certain level, the phenomenon of intelligent emergence occurs. This has been widely applied to a variety of tasks such as text-to-image generation, virtual scene recognition, robotic arm control, and manufacturing. However, reinforcement learning has the challenge of poor generalization ability in agent inference when the environment changes. During the agent's training process, the action rewards are generated based on an environment model. In practical applications, when the environmental factors continuously change, the reward function may also vary. It’s leading to the issues with the agent's action strategy. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning method that integrates large models into the agent's situational awareness loop. The processed information is used as the state for the agent's actions, guiding the agent to generate behaviors in its operational work. Finally, the miniworld experiments are used to verify the correctness of the proposed reinforcement learning agent training method. This work also provides a new approach for agent decision-making methods in practical applications when the agent faced with environmental changes.

title: Surface EMG – Based Quantitative Assessment of Muscle Coordination and Complexity in Post-Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injury Individuals
authors: Arunthathi S, S Saranya
abstract: Surface Electromyogram (sEMG) signals can be used as an inevitable tool to assess muscle coordination and complex activation during walking. The proposed study employed key EMG features indicative of muscle inter-coordination and complex dynamics, such as Co-Activation Index (CAI), Kurtosis, Correlation Dimension (CD), Sample Entropy (SE), and Skewness, to investigate variations between post-ACL reconstruction patients and control subjects. The dataset consists of sEMG signals obtained from Medial Hamstrings (MH), Biceps Femoris (BF), Vastus Lateralis (VL), Gastrocnemius Medialis (GM), Gastrocnemius Lateralis (GL) from Control Groups (CG) and individuals undergoing post-ACL injury Reconstruction (PAIR) between 18 and 30 years of age. While CAI and kurtosis showed no significant differences between PAIR & CG, CD (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P_{G M}=0.04$</tex>), SE (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P_{M H}=0.04$</tex>) and Skewness (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P_{G L}=0.03$</tex>) demonstrated significant difference based on the Mann-Whitney U test at a 95% confidence level. Therefore, the proposed study enhances the understanding of the dynamics of selected EMG features and emphasizes their importance in the objective, quantitative assessment of rehabilitation progress after post-ACL injury reconstruction.

title: Evaluation of Ku-Band Geostationary Satellite Link Latency Under Tropical Rainfall
authors: Yasser Asrul Ahmad, Hazrul Hafiz Abdul Shukur, Yousif Dafa Alla, Anis Hannai Razman, Khairayu Badron
abstract: Satellite communication still faces the challenges of the effect of rainfall on Ku-band link. This study aims to measure and analyse suitable parameters that represent rainfall intensity and latency to evaluate their relationship. Rainfall data was collected using a tipping bucket rain sensor and subsequently processed to determine rainfall rate. Latency data was collected by connecting the received signal of SES 12 from the antenna to a computer via a router and a ‘ping’ operation was performed to obtain the needed latency values. Both sets of data were collected from July to December 2024. Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) were plotted for rainfall rate and latency. The CDF analysis implied that Ku-band affected by rainfall rates higher than 50 mm/h. This study shows rainfall rate significantly affect the latency and network reliability of the Ku-Band satellite link.

title: Semantic Log Aggregation for a Machine Readable Knowledge Base of Incident Response Activities
authors: Haula Sani Galadima, Cormac Doherty, Rob Brennan
abstract: This paper presents an approach to creating a Machine-Readable Knowledge Base (KB) from heterogeneous Incident Response (IR) activities logs, to support automated continuous IR learning. The prototype architecture addresses the challenge of consolidating and analysing diverse IR data from complex IR tool chains, allowing organisations to learn from day-to-day activities in a way that is often overlooked or too costly. The design is informed by a prior evaluation of a Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT), which identified gaps in automation, knowledge management, and learning from everyday IR processes. By synthesizing logs across diverse IR systems into an single knowledge base, this study facilitates automated knowledge management and learning to enhance IR organisational cyber resilience.

title: CDFFCIL: Comprehensive Framework for Data-Free Federated Class-Incremental Learning
authors: Weike Liu, Zhaoyun Ding, Lailong Luo, Qingbao Liu, Cheng Zhu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The purpose of Federated class incremental learning (FCIL) is to enable the federal learning (FL) system to continuously learn new tasks through dynamically evolving classes, while retaining the knowledge of previous classes. However, existing FCIL methods often require access to past task data to consolidate old knowledge and fail to address challenges arising from inter-client data heterogeneity, limiting their generalization capability in real-world applications. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes CDFFCIL: a Comprehensive framework for Data-Free Federated Class-Incremental Learning. We introduce a novel dual correction-based knowledge distillation strategy that enables clients to preserve their initial strong capability for learning new classes throughout continual learning. Furthermore, we develop a federated NCM classifier based on anisotropic Mahalanobis distance, which significantly enhances the global model's predictive performance under non-stationary data distributions. Experimental results demonstrate that CDFFCIL effectively mitigates catastrophic forgetting and heterogeneity impacts while outperforming state-of-the-art FCIL methods.

title: Self Supervised Learning for Structural Integrity Assessment of UAVs in Extended Missions
authors: Pooja Jayprakash Patel, Selvakumaran T, Yagya Dutta Dwivedi, Vipin Sharma, Akash Deep Kushwaha, JoshuvaArockia Dhanraj
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles that operate in long-range operation are constantly subject to structural driving, therefore due to their mission safety and long-term operation, reliable health status monitoring is important. The proposed self-supervised learning framework of structural integrity assessment reduces the reliance on labelled data and still provides adaptability with changing operating conditions. The methodology incorporates a wavelet-based noise removal (DWT with soft-thresholding) on the vibration signals and acoustic signals before selecting the information-rich and non-redundant features mRMR-based feature selection. The features chosen are identified under LightGBM with high accuracy, precision, and recall on the damages and degradation identification. Accelerated training up to multi-GPU, mixed-precision optimization, and on-board deploy ability to resource-constrained UAV systems are some of the advantages of implementation using PyTorch Lightning. Testing the method, experimental data showed the number of key thicknesses to be detected improved dramatically compared to conventional supervised strategies. The suggested method offers a scalable, interpretable, and real-time UAV structural health monitoring system on long-range tasks.

title: Acoustic Differences Between Coronal Nasal /n/ and Lateral /l/ in Standard Chinese
authors: Yijing He, Wai-Sum Lee
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: This study compares the acoustic properties of the Standard Chinese /n/ and /l/ in different prevocalic and tonal contexts The speech data of eight Mandarin speakers show that the distinction between /n/ and /l/ primarily lies in the spectral energy distribution along the frequency scale, regardless of the contexts in which two consonants occur. While /l/ exhibits enhanced high-frequency energy, /n/ displays a more skewed spectral shape with energy concentrated in the lower frequency region. The frequency-related features of /n/ and /l/ play a relatively minor role in distinction. Generally /n/ and /l/ share similar formant patterns, but the formant values of /l/ show more variation in different vowel contexts, presumably due to more coarticulation with the following vowel. There is no apparent tonal context effect on the acoustic properties of the two coronal consonants

title: Silkworm Grasserie Disease Detection Using Electronic Nose Technology
authors: Binson V A, Sania Thomas, Sini Rahuman, Sivakumar K S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Sericulture industry supports rural livelihoods and contributes significantly to the Indian economy. This industry faces severe challenges from silkworm diseases, among which Grasserie, caused by the Bombyx mori nucleopolyhedrovirus (BmNPV), is one of the most devastating. Current diagnostic methods, such as microscopy, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), though reliable, are time-consuming, costly, and require laboratory facilities, making them impractical for field-level disease management. Electronic nose (e-nose) technology has emerged as a promising non-invasive tool for rapid disease detection. In this study, we designed a low-cost e-nose system using four metal oxide gas sensors integrated with an Arduino Uno. A total of 101 samples, comprising 54 healthy and 47 Grasserie-infected silkworms, were collected and analyzed. Data were preprocessed using baseline manipulation, followed by Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for feature extraction. Classification was carried out using Support Vector Machine (SVM) and k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) with three-fold cross-validation. Results showed that the developed e-nose can effectively discriminate healthy silkworms from the infected silkworms, with SVM achieving the highest accuracy of 91.42%. The study demonstrates that e-nose technology is a rapid, cost-effective, and practical tool for early detection of Grasserie disease, offering significant benefits for sustainable sericulture.

title: Application of mmWave FMCW Radar to Measure Thickness of Materials and 3D Imaging
authors: Edrick Baijukya, EunMi Choi
abstract: This paper presents a high resolution 3D imaging framework using Millimeter Wave Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) radar. The system combines ultra wideband (75-110~GHz) radar measurements with a Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) and mechanical scanning to reconstruct volumetric object profiles. Using Delay and Sum (DAS) beamforming, the method captures both surface and internal features with a depth resolution of 5 mm, lateral and vertical resolutions of 2 mm, and sub millimeter accuracy. Unlike prior simulation based or 2D imaging approaches, this work demonstrates an end-to-end experimental implementation, offering a compact and precise alternative to MIMO based systems for high resolution imaging tasks.

title: Blockchain-Driven Evolution of Cloud Service Architectures
authors: Aravind Narayanan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This paper presents BlockCloud, a framework that integrates blockchain primitives into cloud service architectures to strengthen trust, security, and auditability in regulated domains, with a particular emphasis on insurance applications. The framework leverages on-chain verification and smart contract automation while maintaining cloud-native scalability through hybrid on-chain/off-chain storage, permissioned consensus mechanisms, and oracle-mediated data feeds. The paper further outlines a detailed technical specification of the architecture, a formalized threat model, and an evaluation plan encompassing a prototype stack, performance metrics, and experimental validation. While the work is conceptual, these elements clarify the design rationale and establish a clear pathway toward prototype implementation and empirical assessment.

title: Cooperative Target Detection in Dual-Base Station Enabled ISAC Systems
authors: Changyuan Liu, Haitao Zhao, Wenchao Xia, Qin Wang, Yiyang Ni, Hongbo Zhu
abstract: This paper considers an integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system, where two dual-functional base stations (BSs) serve their users and detect multiple targets. To improve detection accuracy while meeting communication quality of service, this paper proposes a two-phase cooperative target detection algorithm that relies on Capon-based adaptive beamforming and maximum likelihood estimation (MLE)-based hypothesis testing. Specifically, based on Capon’s detection results, the two BSs first scan targets with an omnidirectional beam and then track targets with a directional beam. Subsequently, multiple hypotheses regarding the locations of targets are established based on the detection results of the Capon method, and the MLE is employed for hypothesis testing to filter out ghost targets. Finally, simulation results show that the proposed algorithm achieves more precise angles-of-arrival estimation of multiple targets than conventional single-BS sensing, and enables high-precision localization by eliminating ghost targets.

title: Real-Time State-Constrained Power Management Based on Pontryagin’s Minimum Principle: Application to Fuel Cell Vehicles
authors: Théotime Héraud, Paul Malisani, Thomas Leroy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: The contribution of this article is to propose a power management system (PMS) for a hybrid vehicle based on an adaptive Pontryagin’s minimum principle (A-PMP) approach that optimally handles state constraints in an online setting. We show that the resulting algorithm is implementable and can run on a real-time target with performance very close to offline computation. Optimally enforcing state constraints [in this case, the battery state of charge (SoC)] allows the battery to be used more efficiently, enabling a reduction in its capacity without increasing energy consumption. The proposed algorithm, therefore, provides greater flexibility in the design and sizing of the vehicle’s energy architecture.

title: Accurate and Computationally Efficient Aggregated Modelling of Offshore Wind Farms for Grid Compliance
authors: Muhammad Helal Uddin, Junaid Khalid, Michael Smailes, Jun Liang, Sheng Wang
abstract: Detailed electromagnetic transient models of off shore wind farms incorporate the individual wind turbine dynamics and controls of many wind turbines (WTs), resulting in substantial computational burdens. This limits their practicality for large-scale system studies. While aggregation techniques re duce this burden, they often compromise accuracy, particularly in capturing dynamic behaviour during power system disturbances. To overcome this challenge, this paper proposes a gaussian mixture model clustering with information-theoretic averaging to group similar WTs and derive representative aggregated models. A structured eigenvalue sensitivity analysis is conducted to identify the control parameters that have the greatest impact on system dynamics, reducing the dimensionality of the parameter space. Additionally, an improved multi-objective gradient descent optimisation strategy is developed to identify and provide optimal values of system and control parameters under varying wind conditions and fault scenarios to ensure accuracy. The proposed modelling applicability is further demonstrated through assessment on an HVDC connected offshore wind farm under large disturbance and weak grid conditions in the time and frequency domains. Finally, the aggregated model's performance is validated against the detailed benchmark to ensure UK's grid compliance on modelling, confirming its ability to replicate key dynamic and steady-state characteristics with substantially reduced computational effort.

title: Improving Energy Efficiency in Post-Disaster Networks: Multi-agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Enhancing Local Contributions
authors: Yuchao Dang, Xuefen Chi, Hangyu Yan, Tianyue Zhang, Xin Zhang, Zhu Han
abstract: To address the energy efficiency (EE) optimization challenge in post-disaster space-air enhanced integrated access and backhaul networks (SAE-IABN), a multi-agent global trust region local policy optimization (MA-GTRLPO) based resource allocation (RA) strategy is proposed. This strategy adopts a hybrid hierarchical architecture, decoupling global RA into centralized authorization and decentralized allocation to manage the multi-layer structured SAE-IABN's resources efficiently. MA GTRLPOenhances local contributions through a sequential local policy update rule, which helps stabilize convergence and avoids joint policy degradation risk. The general global performance difference bound theorem provides theoretical convergence guarantees for MA-GTRLPO. This theorem also offers a coordination mechanism for the Kullback-Leibler (KL) regularization coefficient and learning rate, improving global rewards by 6.9% compared to a heuristic hyperparameter baseline. Next, the global reward with the dynamic feedback framework and triple normalization is proposed to optimize EE further. The feedback framework with quality of service (QoS) constraints is introduced to prevent over-allocation. Then, the triple normalization helps agents clarify the contribution of EE, QoS guarantee, and energy constraint to the global reward. Simulations demonstrate that MA-GTRLPO outperforms the baselines in all metrics. It shows good scalability, robustness, and timeliness under varying network densities and topologies, guaranteeing QoS for user equipment (UE) and ensuring the endurance of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) remains above the minimum endurance bound.

title: Evaluating the Accuracy of Fabric Mechanical Digitization Methods_supp1-3665029.pdf
authors: Gabriel Cirio
abstract: The apparel industry has witnessed a significant shift toward 3D virtual design, driven by advances in simulation and digitization technologies. Central to this transformation are digital twins, which allow designers to test and refine garment designs virtually, reducing reliance on physical prototyping. A critical aspect of this process is accurately capturing the drape behavior of fabrics, as it impacts both the aesthetic and functional properties of garments. Traditional fabric digitization methods involve mechanical testing of fabric samples, but they are labor-intensive, costly, and require specialized equipment. Recently, AI-based digitization techniques have emerged, offering potential advantages in terms of cost and logistics, though their accuracy remains uncertain. This study addresses the gap in knowledge regarding the accuracy of AI-based fabric digitization by utilizing the Cusick drape test—a standardized method for assessing fabric drape behavior. We introduce a reference digitization pipeline based on traditional mechanical testing and perform a comprehensive comparative study of six commercially available digitization methods, including both traditional and AI-based approaches. Using a diverse set of fabrics, we evaluate the accuracy of the digitized fabrics against real-world measurements. Our results demonstrate that AI-based methods can achieve competitive accuracy, while also highlighting areas for further improvement. We present a publicly available dataset containing real fabric properties, their digitized versions, as well as their corresponding real and digital drape metrics, which can serve as a valuable resource for further research and development in fabric digitization.

title: A Momentum‑GS‑ Based Large-Scale 3D Reconstruction Algorithm for Bridge Piers Using a Climbing Robotic Platform
authors: Hao Du, Huifeng Wang, Zefeng Pan, Yunmei Jiao
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: High precision 3D reconstruction of bridge piers plays a vital role in bridge digital inspection and digital twin creation. To address the limitations of existing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAVs) and wall‑climbing robots during bridge visual inspections, a novel annular vision acquisition system based on a climbing robot is proposed. To overcome the limitations of the conventional 3D gaussian splatting (3DGS) algorithm—namely its inability to train in parallel and its low efficiency when handling large scale bridge pier scenes—this paper introduces a novel Momentum-GS based reconstruction method, Momentum-Octree-GS. The proposed algorithm achieves efficient parallel training and markedly improves rendering performance by integrating an octree data structure and a level of detail (LOD) hierarchy into the Momentum-GS framework. Experiments on bridge pier datasets demonstrate that Momentum-Octree-GS attains state-of-the-art (SOTA) results, and the reconstructed models faithfully reproduce the pier surfaces' geometric shapes and defect distributions. This work offers an efficient technical solution for bridge digital inspection and the generation of digital twin bases.

title: Towards Intelligent Agriculture: ML Algorithm Analysis in IoT-Based Smart Irrigation Systems
authors: Tummala Adithya Reddy, Gopalam Rahul Malik, Maddu Sriharsha Naidu, Jayasree K R
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Smart irrigation systems have emerged as a vital innovation in modern agriculture, addressing the challenges of water scarcity, energy efficiency, and crop yield optimization. This study presents a comparative analysis of multiple smart irrigation system projects, focusing on their technological frameworks, performance metrics, and cost effectiveness. This research focuses on systems including IoT devices, automation, machine learning, and sensor-based technologies to enhance water management. Particular emphasis is placed on soil moisture monitoring, energy consumption control, scalability, and adaptability to diverse climatic conditions. This analysis also considers the practical implications of cleansing methods in agriculture, evaluating the advantages and disadvantages of the approaches. Overall, the findings aim to support economic considerations of these systems for small and large-scale farms. This analysis is intended to aid decision making on smart sustainable irrigation for different types of farming, across different farming contexts.

title: A Comprehensive Node Threat Assessment Algorithm for Combat System Network
authors: Boliang Sun, Shengquan Liao
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In modern warfare, the complex dynamics of combat systems demand sophisticated decision-making processes to accurately identify critical targets and maximize damage to enemy capabilities. This study introduces a novel algorithm specifically designed to evaluate target threats within a unified coordinate framework. The algorithm systematically quantifies the threat levels of firepower nodes while assessing the significance of auxiliary nodes within the broader combat network. The analysis begins by identifying a simple circle from the combat network, characterized by the largest chord length, calculated as the circumference divided by the total number of nodes. A reference node is then selected within this circle, assigned a weight of zero. Nodes connected to this reference are granted weights based on the length of the longest path leading to it in the network. Subsequently, a diffusion model is employed to allocate weights to previously unweighted operational units, utilizing the established weights of firepower nodes across the local network. This approach ensures that all combat units receive comparable weights. To further validate the utility of our approach in combat scenarios, we developed an assessment prototype that simulates commanders’ strategies based on our weight assessments. This tool effectively demonstrates the algorithm’s capability to prioritize targets. The results highlight its potential to enhance decision-making in fast-paced combat scenarios, enabling commanders to maximize their operational impact.

title: Optimizing Restaurant Billing through Intelligent Systems for Enhanced Customer Satisfaction using Machine Learning
authors: Mamata Rath, Lucky Harichandan, Satyabrata Lenka
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The invoicing system in modern restaurants has changed a lot to meet the needs of a fast-paced, tech-driven world. This paper examines the essential elements, characteristics, and advantages of modern billing systems that utilize cutting-edge technology, including cloud computing, mobile integration, and point-of-sale (POS) systems. These new ideas all make the billing process easier, make operations more efficient, and make the customer experience better by allowing speedier transactions, real-time inventory management, and detailed reporting. This study incorporates machine learning (ML) methodologies for anomaly detection and predictive analytics to enhance reliability and intelligence. We used a Random Forest Regressor to anticipate billing because it can handle complicated, non-linear data well. We also used an Isolation Forest model to find strange patterns in transactional data. We also used advanced ensemble and neural models like XGBoost, LightGBM, and LSTM to see how well they worked with different metrics. We used 5-fold cross-validation to check the results using R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, RMSE, MAE, MAPE, Precision, Recall, and PR-AUC. The results show that the XGBoost model had the best overall performance, with a R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.884 and an RMSE of 0.307, which was better than other baselines. The suggested edge-aware framework is good for real-time POS billing situations since it has a low latency of 0.02 seconds (20 ms). The addition of an integrated anomaly detection module makes sure that fraud is stopped and operations are open. The study shows that there is a single, smart billing system that can give accurate, low-latency, and reliable results in restaurants with limited resources.

title: RainGAN-Kathmandu: A Generative Adversarial Framework for Synthetic Rainfall Augmentation in Urban Road Scene Datasets
authors: Nitesh Kumar Shah, Gadde Jahnavi, Navjot Singh, Chandra Prakash Maurya, Satish Kumar Singh
abstract: Urban roads face major challenges during rainfall, impacting visibility and road texture. Rain degrades the performance of vision-based systems in traffic safety and monitoring. Real-world rainy road datasets are scarce and often lack diversity. This limits the training of models for image translation under rainy conditions. Effective rainy image synthesis is essential for advancing robust autonomous driving systems. This paper introduces a novel methodology to bridge this gap by generating synthetic datasets simulating adverse weather conditions, particularly rainfall, using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). We introduce a newly curated dataset of Kathmandu road scenes to provide diverse, real-world clear-weather imagery. Leveraging these datasets, we employ advanced deep learning techniques to synthesize high-quality rainy road scenes. In experiments, RFDETR achieved a mean Average Precision of 0.405 (averaged over IoU <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.50-0.95$</tex>) on the RainGAN-augmented dataset 0.605 at IoU 0.50 and 0.416 at IoU 0.75 demonstrating that our augmentation preserves detection performance under simulated rainfall. Proposed GAN also outperforms existing GAN variants, achieving an FID of 8.34 and LPIPS of 0.12 (versus DCGAN 18.45/0.29, Pix2Pix 15.32/0.24, and StyleGAN 10.57/0.18), indicating realism in the generated imagery Generated outputs are evaluated using Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity (LPIPS) metrics to ensure realism and perceptual fidelity. The paper outlines the data creation pipeline, model implementation, evaluation strategy, and broader implications, offering a robust framework for weatheraffected scene synthesis and road safety research.

title: An Ensemble Clustering Approach to Recognize Flight State in Pilot Training
authors: Anam Iqbal, Graham Wild
abstract: The aviation industry has been growing rapidly, and the success of the sector depends heavily on pilots receiving rigorous training, which guarantees the safety of air travel. During various flight states of an aircraft, pilots encounter different situations; to anticipate and manage potential hazards, pilots must possess detailed knowledge of these flight regimes and maintain appropriate control. This study employs an ensemble clustering approach on flight data simulated through Monte Carlo Simulations to determine and recognize crucial flight states of an aircraft, providing the basis for assessing pilot performance within each state. The clustering performance of various individual algorithms and their combinations is evaluated. Among single clustering models, Shared Nearest Neighbor (SNN) achieved the highest performance with ACC of 0.83, ARI of 0.69, NMI of 0.69, and FMI of 0.83. While ensemble clustering models further enhanced clustering performance, the combination of SNN and Fuzzy C-means performing particularly well with ACC of 0.97, ARI of 0.89, NMI of 0.84, and FMI of 0.95. When comparing individual and ensemble approaches, it is observed that ensemble methods detect and distinguish flight states more accurately than any single clustering algorithm. This research marks a significant advancement in the use of ensemble approaches to improve the diagnosis of pilot performance during specific flight states, thereby enhancing training and flying safety.

title: Zero Trust Architecture for Secure Smart City Infrastructure Using AI-Powered Authentication
authors: N.V.A. Ravi Kumar, Tentu Papi Naidu, Balajee Maram, Aakula Swathi, Vasupalli Manoj, Potnuru Jyothika
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Smart cities use sophisticated information and communications technologies (ICTs) in an interconnected way across sectors, including transportation, energy, healthcare, and public safety, to create a more efficient community and improve people's quality of life. However, integrating technologies and data from different sectors increases the attack surface and creates additional vulnerabilities in connected systems, exposing them to threats that grow in sophistication. Furthermore, the traditional boundaries that define our security perimeters cannot satisfactorily restrict movement in this complex environment. This paper introduces a comprehensive Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA) specifically for smart city infrastructures, utilizing Artificial Intelligence (AI) to authenticate identities and devices continuously through risk-based analysis. Our design continuously enforces the principle of "never trust, always verify," and accesses controls are modified based on contextual risk changes. We propose a layered methodology, which shows potential, including secure micro segmentation architecture, behavior analytics in real-time, and federated identity management. Our proof-of-concept implementation showed that machine learning classifiers can detect anomalies during authentication attempts, resulting in a reduction of 35% in false positives and preventing two simulated attacks in an IoT network of municipalities. We analysed performance overhead, scalability, and resiliency concerning interacting with attacking systems. As a result, our AI-enabled ZTA had a significantly higher threat detection rate and still maintained a reasonable latency for smart city operations. This research presents a foundation for municipalities seeking to strengthen their city’s connected infrastructure against risk.

title: AI for Sustainable Learning Student-Centered Approaches to Eco-Digital Education
authors: Hiep Dac Nguyen, Luan Huynh Vu, Nhu Lam Thi Quynh, Linh Nguyen Thi Yen, Giang Tien Thi Nguyen, Luan Trong Nguyen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and eco-digital education tools is transforming higher education and promoting sustainable life-long learning. This study investigates the influence of AI ability, eco-digital education, sustainable orientation, and environmental awareness on students' sustainable learning capacity. Utilizing a structured questionnaire distributed to university students and analyzed through quantitative methods (regression models), the findings reveal several key relationships. Students with higher AI skills and a stronger commitment to sustainability tend to engage more actively in sustainable learning behaviors. Eco-digital education was identified as a key mediator, significantly shaping students' values and attitudes toward sustainability. Furthermore, environmental awareness emerged as a critical factor driving motivation for long-term learning outside formal education settings. These results underscore the necessity of incorporating digital literacy and sustainability awareness into curricula to foster resilient and responsible learners. This study advocates for a balanced, student-centered approach that integrates AI technologies and environmental consciousness into educational practices, ensuring students are equipped with both the technical capabilities and ecological values required to navigate and succeed in a rapidly evolving, sustainability-focused world.

title: Learning Disentangled Representation for Multi-Modal Fusion in Resume-Job Matching
authors: Dayong Shen, Xiang Jiang, Chenfeng Hu, Shiyi Xu, Zhongshan Zhang, Feng Yao, Tao Wang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Structured and unstructured data are two common data types in the online recruitment process. Traditional resume-job matching algorithms tend to focus on only one of these data types. Effectively integrating both and fully exploiting the hidden information they contain is of great importance. To address this challenge, we propose a novel Hypergraph-based shared Representation Fusion recommendation model, named HrFuse.Specifically, we first learn the representation of structured data through hypergraphs, while leveraging a pre-trained language model to vectorize the unstructured data. Subsequently, we introduce a HrFuse module to disentangle cross-modal shared features from modality-specific features.Finally, we evaluate our model on a real-world global dataset collected from one of the largest job recruitment platforms in China. Experimental results demonstrate that HrFuse outperforms all baseline models across all evaluation metrics. This study highlights the benefits of integrating structured and unstructured data through shared representation fusion.

title: A Corpus-Based Investigation of Acoustic Features Influencing Intelligibility of Super-Elderly Japanese Speech
authors: Meiko Fukuda, Ryota Nishimura, Norihide Kitaoka
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: We conducted comprehensive acoustic analyses to identify features influencing speech intelligibility using read-aloud speech from the Japanese super-elderly corpus EARS, including measurements of Fo, vocal quality, formant frequencies, vowel articulation metrics, F2 slope, voice onset time of plosives and following vowel duration, speech and articulation rates, and the frequency of non-speech intervals. Comparisons were made among cognitively healthy speakers with intelligible speech (CH I) or with slightly unintelligible speech (CH SU), and speakers with dementia and slightly unintelligible speech (DM SU). Both CH SU and DM SU exhibited significantly increased frequency of non-speech intervals and reduced speaking rates relative to CH I speakers. Additionally, DM SU speakers demonstrated greater standard deviation in two vowel formants compared to CH I, which could suggest increased articulatory instability associated with dementia. For the plosive-containing syllable, CH I speakers showed longer vowel duration and higher consonant-to-vowel duration ratio than both of SU groups, indicating a potential acoustic correlation of reduced intelligibility.

title: Design of a Wideband SIW Bandpass Filter Using Resonator Spacing for Improved Coupling
authors: Geun-Young Bae, Kwang-Sik Park, Jong-Gwan Yook, Chan-Sei Yoo
abstract: This paper proposes a 10th-order substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) bandpass filter (BPF) operating in the D-band (110–170 GHz) for ultra-high-speed wireless communication systems. The conventional window width control method was limited in precise control due to its large variation in coupling strength. Therefore, this study introduces resonator spacing as an additional parameter. By simultaneously adjusting the window width and resonator spacing, more precise control of coupling becomes possible within the same process. The fabricated SIW BPF on a MEGTRON8 substrate achieved an insertion loss of 5.5 dB, a return loss better than 13.8 dB, and a bandwidth over 18 GHz (141–159 GHz). These results show that the proposed method enables flexible and practical wideband filter design without complex processes, making it suitable for next-generation high-frequency applications.

title: AI-Powered Sentiment Analysis for Early Detection of Mental Health Disorders in Social Media Communications
authors: Sneha Patnaik, Khemraj Sharma, Itishree Mohanty, Himanshu Sekhar Pradhan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The investigation of novel, scalable, and non-intrusive methods for early identification and intervention has been spurred by the rising incidence of mental health issues. Real-time psychological evaluation is made possible by social media platforms, where people often share their ideas, feelings, and actions. This study compares the effectiveness of the CNN, XGBoost, BRDT, and NB models and uses sentiment analysis on Reddit data to try and identify mental illness. The CNN model was found to have the best overall performance with an F1 Score, accuracy, recall, and precision of 95.7%, making it highly effective in detecting depression based on text post data from both the pre- and post-pandemic periods. Despite having a somewhat lower accuracy of 95.6%, the XGBoost model actually has the lowest error rate, at 0.052734. The BRDT and NB model had the highest error rate and the lowest accuracy. These results demonstrate the potential of machine learning and sentiment analysis in detecting mental health problems on social media, and they imply that improved models can enhance early detection and intervention initiatives.

title: AI-Enhanced Learning for Engineering Community of Practice
authors: Phuwadon Yaiyindee, Panita Wannapiroon, Prachyanun Nilsook
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: This research aims to develop an integrated conceptual framework for enhancing engineering education through artificial intelligence (AI) support via the Communities of Practice (CoP) mechanism. The study proposes a two-phase research methodology in which both phases complement each other. Phase 1 employs bibliographic analysis using VOSviewer to map keyword co-occurrence networks. The mapping results reveal three main clusters: (1) AI teaching and learning practice clusters (e.g., chatbots and generative AI); (2) learning approaches, including active learning, cooperative learning, and individual learning; and (3) cross-dimensional issues related to information security and AI ethics, which are essential for ensuring credibility in educational contexts. Phase 2 synthesizes relevant literature to define the components of three main dimensions: AI-enhanced learning, engineering communities of practice, and engineering education. The proposed framework integrates bibliographic analysis and literature synthesis and highlights how AI-powered personalization, intelligent tutoring systems, and adaptive analytics can be leveraged to create more sustainable learning experiences. CoP facilitates knowledge exchange and mutual learning among learners, while the CDIO (Conceive–Design–Implement–Operate) approach strengthens problem-solving skills and engineering innovation. In addition, the integration of emerging technologies supports active learning, real-time assessment, and scalable infrastructure for engineering education. The findings indicate that the implementation of the Engineering CoP framework can enhance learner engagement and improve the efficiency of knowledge sharing.

title: Enhancing Power Quality in Distribution Systems: Marine Gravitational Search Optimization for UPQC Sizing and Placement
authors: Sangeeta Patil, Haripriya R, Swaroop Mallick, K C Kavitha, Sanjay Srivastava, Mohammad Shabeeh
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper addresses the enhancement of power quality of a distribution system by using the Marine Gravitational Search Optimization (MGSO) algorithm to optimize the sizing and the location of Unified Power Quality Conditioners (UPQC).
