The main goal is to alleviate typical problems of power quality which include sagging, swelling of voltages, harmonic distortions as well as load imbalances. Based on natural acting of marine lives, which is influenced by gravitational forces, MGSO is implemented to compute the most effective structure of the UPQC units in a distribution network. The formulation of the optimization process is to minimize the overall cost of installation and operation and maximise the correction of the disturbances in the power quality. The findings of the simulation, which is executed with the help of MATLAB, prove that MGSO is effective to determine the optimal size and location of the UPQC devices, as well as to promote considerable power quality improvements at minimum costs of the systems. The approach is a strong solution to the improvement of the power quality of contemporary electric grids.

title: HumidiTech: An Autonomous IoT-Enabled Dehumidification Robot for Smart Indoor Climate Control
authors: Kassem Yahya, Jalal Shamas, Malak Salloum, Gaby Abou Haidar, Chafic Saide
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Maintaining optimal indoor humidity is essential for human comfort, health, and the preservation of materials. Excessive moisture promotes microbial growth and structural deterioration, while dry air can cause respiratory discomfort. This paper presents HumidiTech, an autonomous and IoT-enabled dehumidification robot designed to provide adaptive multi-room humidity regulation. The system integrates Peltier thermoelectric cooling modules for condensation-based dehumidification, distributed DHT22 sensors for real-time feedback, and LiDAR-based SLAM for autonomous navigation and mapping. Cloud connectivity enables continuous environmental logging and remote supervision via a mobile application. Experimental validation across three indoor environments (totalling $70 \mathrm{~m}^{2}$) demonstrated a mean water extraction rate of $1.35 \mathrm{~L} /$ day, maintaining humidity within $\pm 4.6 \%$ of the setpoint over 48 -hour trials. Comparative testing revealed a $\mathbf{2 1 \%}$ lower energy consumption than a standard $\mathbf{6 5}$ W stationary dehumidifier under equivalent conditions. The prototype’s average power draw of 56 W and energy efficiency ratio (EER) of 1.28 confirm its practical viability. Owing to its modular design, cloud-based control, and scalable architecture, HumidiTech represents an energy-efficient, user-centric solution for smart indoor climate regulation.

title: J-Double DQN: Jolt Discount meets Double Estimation for Stable and Fast Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Peiyan Gong, Yuqi Jin, Jinwei Zhao, Jun Ren, Libin Pei, Guirong Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Value-based deep reinforcement learning algorithms—exemplified by Deep Q-Network (DQN) and its successors—have demonstrated substantial empirical achievements. Nonetheless, training instability and sample inefficiency remain unresolved challenges, especially when reward signals are sparse or the state space is high-dimensional. These difficulties are exacerbated by the discount factor, conventionally treated as a fixed hyperparameter, which propagates bootstrap targets that may be overly optimistic and adapt slowly once the learning policy settles into local optima. Motivated by human cognition, wherein exploratory planning gradually gives way to exploitative decision-making, we introduce a dynamic-discount mechanism that anneals the effective planning horizon as a function of both training progress and episodic return. By embedding this schedule within Double DQN, we obtain J-Double DQN, an off-policy algorithm that (i) mitigates Q-value overestimation, (ii) accelerates convergence, and (iii) markedly reduces variance across random seeds. Comprehensive experiments on CartPole-v1 show that J-Double DQN surpasses both DQN and Double DQN in convergence speed and stability. Due to its model-agnostic design, the proposed method can be easily integrated into existing value-based reinforcement learning frameworks with minimal modification.

title: Nonzero-Sum Game-Based Approximate Optimal Control of Reconfigurable Manipulator System Identified by RNN
authors: Bo Dong, Chen Li, Tianjiao An, Rui Sun, Hongbo Dong, Bing Ma
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: This paper explores the issue of an approximate optimal control problem within a nonzero-sum differential game context for reconfigurable manipulator systems. Utilizing the input-output data from these systems, we introduce an effective identifier via recurrent neural network (RNN) to recognize dynamics of the system. We consider all joints as players and establish an n-player nonzero-sum differential game optimal control problem. We utilize adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) in conjunction with a critic neural network to approximate the optimal control policy. This approach effectively circumvents the curse of dimensionality typically encountered when dealing the Hamilton-Jacobi (HJ) equation. We then establish the convergence properties of ADP and the identifier, demonstrating that the system state, along with the weights of the RNN and critic neural network, will converge to a finite neighborhood of equilibrium. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness of the ADP methods.

title: Physics-Informed BiLSTM for Predicting Battery Remaining Useful Life: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework
authors: Pavithra R, Gurupandian M, Guru Prasad C, Viknesh S R, Sundaresh M, Sanjai S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Predicting how long a lithium-ion battery can continue operating is now a make-or-break capability for electric mobility, distributed solar, and any product that depends on dependable energy storage. We introduce Physics-Informed Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (PI-BiLSTM), a hybrid framework that blends neural sequence modeling with the first principles that govern electrochemical aging. Convolutional layers distill localized information from charge-discharge cycles, bidirectional LSTMs describe long-range temporal behavior, and physicsinformed heads keep the network's predictions aligned with Arrhenius temperature sensitivity and Peukert's rate-capacity law. Evaluations on the NASA PCoE dataset and auxiliary synthetic profiles report an overall accuracy of 87.5 % with balanced precision and recall above 0.93 for both healthy and degraded cells. Beyond the scores, PI-BiLSTM is packaged for deployment: the loss term is transparent, the model ports cleanly to cloud or edge targets, and the output can be interpreted by battery engineers. The study demonstrates that lightweight physics regularization provides a practical path to humantrustworthy RUL estimation.

title: Four-Port Probe Stations and SOLR Calibration Standard Design up to 125 GHz on 28 nm CMOS
authors: Dipankar Shakya, Theodore S. Rappaport, Ethan Shieh, Michael E. Knox, Hamed Rahmani, Davood Shahrjerdi, Mingjun Ying, Kimberley Fan, Matt Lu, Andrej Rumiantsev, Vince Mallette, Gavin Fisher, Giancarlo De Chirico, Pratik Ghate, Shean McMahon
abstract: This paper presents two innovative four-port probe stations developed by FormFactor Incorporated (FFI) and MPI Corporation (MPI), and a four-port calibration standard design up to 125 GHz for the probe stations. True four-port probing at mmWave and beyond does not yet exist, but is anticipated for future multi-band wireless devices using several antennas and RF chains. The four-port probe stations are housed in the THz measurement facility at NYU and allow simultaneous probing from East, West, North, and South orientations, which presents challenges for calibration. An on-chip Short-Open-Load-Reciprocal (SOLR) calibration (cal) standard is designed leveraging UMC’s 28 nm CMOS process. S/O/L standard S-parameters are extracted using a virtual multiline Thru-Reflect-Line (mTRL) cal and used to validate SOLR cal performance via simulations up to 125 GHz. The novel probing solutions from MPI and FFI, along with the SOLR cal, open up considerable opportunities for precise RF characterization across wide frequency ranges.

title: Structure-Aware GNN-Transformer for Content Prediction and Caching in Vehicular Networks
authors: Xuefang Nie, Chen Zhang, Chen Wang, Qiangqiang Zhou, Xuesheng Zhu, Jiliang Zhang
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Vehicular edge caching is crucial for reducing content delivery latency, yet high mobility and dynamic topologies severely limit the effectiveness of traditional caching and prediction schemes. Most existing methods rely on local correlations and ignore global structural dependencies, resulting in suboptimal caching decisions. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a structure-aware predictive caching framework that jointly captures spatial-temporal features in vehicular networks. A Graph Neural Network (GNN) models the vehicle-RSUMBS communication topology to extract global representations, which are integrated as attention biases into a Transformerbased predictor for accurate content popularity forecasting. A joint caching mechanism further optimizes content placement to maximize cache hit ratio and minimize access latency. Simulation results verify that the proposed GNN-Transformer framework significantly enhances cache hit ratio and reduces latency compared with state-of-the-art baselines.

title: High-gain conical beam coverage realized by using switchable tilted patch array elements for satellite broadcasting reception
authors: Yuta Ishihara, Takuto Oyama, Nobuhiro Kuga
abstract: This paper presents a circularly polarized patch array antenna with beam-switching capability for satellite broadcast reception. By arranging multiple subarrays in a circular configuration and electronically switching beams, the antenna achieves stable performance over a wide elevation and full azimuth range. Simulation results confirm its suitability for reliable satellite broadcast reception across Japan.

title: Enhanced Parkinson’s Disease Diagnosis via Ensemble Learning on the NewHandPD Dataset
authors: Ashwin Kumar Mathura, Om Prakash Singh, Sharbani Purkayastha, Gopal Krishna, Rahul Priyadarshi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects the central nervous system, leading to progressive deterioration of the nervous system resulting in loss of motor control, balance, and cognition. Early detection is crucial for slowing down the progression of this disease and for management. To address this problem, we introduce an ensemble learning approach that predicts Parkinson’s disease at an early stage. Firstly, we perform the preprocessing steps on the NewHandPD dataset, and then the EfficientNet-B3 model is applied to extract the optimal feature, which ensures better classification accuracy. After that, the ensemble learning concept that integrates the embodied extraction procedure is utilized. This study focuses on the prediction of Parkinson’s disease using various machine learning algorithms and techniques.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Predictive Diagnostics Framework for Fault Detection in Industrial IoT Systems
authors: K Arthishwari, Y Murali Krishna, CH Priyanka, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, Sravanthi, C Geetha
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The fast development of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) systems made it possible to monitor and control the work of the industry in real-time; nevertheless, the traditional ways of fault detection, which rely on thresholding and rule-based approaches, do not usually allow working with the massive heterogeneous sensor data and changing operating conditions. Current models, like Support Vector Machines (SVM), Decision Trees, and simpler and simpler Neural Networks, do not have an adaptive learning quality and are not very competent in holding their own in non-stationary settings. In overcoming these shortcomings, the current study presents a Machine Learning-based predictive diagnostics framework (ML-PDF) to IIoT systems to detect faults early and predict them. The suggested architecture incorporates combined feature extraction with Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Autoencoders based dimensionality reduction, and a stacked ensemble architecture comprising of the Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (GBM), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to recognize temporal fault patterns. Moreover, an adaptive anomaly scoring system proposed on the principles of Bayesian inference reflects the fault probabilities dynamically so that the system could be reliable and resilient. The model is trained and tested on real-time IIoT data of industrial machines (e.g. rotating motors, pumps, compressors) and benchmark datasets of NASA turbofan engine degradation dataset. The experimental findings prove that the suggested MLPDF allows achieving a fault detection rate of 98.6 %, a 35 % decrease in the false alarm rate, and a 42 % increase in predictive maintenance scheduling efficiency in contrast to traditional ML methods. The importance of the work is that it allows conducting proactive diagnostics and practical decision-making, reducing downtime, minimizing maintenance expenses, and providing continuity of operations in smart industry settings. The proposed framework can also be used as a scalable and smart base of the next-generation self-healing IIoT infrastructures.

title: Affordable Non-Contact Respiration Monitoring Using Wi-Fi CSI and Doppler Radar: A Performance-Cost Trade-Off for Resource-Limited Settings
authors: Abrar Zarif, Hasin Rayhan, Sourav Kumar Pramanik, Shekh Md Mahmudul Islam
abstract: Non-contact vital sign monitoring has gained significant attention for enabling continuous in-home health surveillance without user discomfort or privacy intrusion. This study compares the performance and economic feasibility of two promising technologies— Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI) and Doppler radar phase measurement—for non-contact respiration monitoring. We developed and evaluated a system integrating a commodity 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi module and a 24 GHz continuous-wave (CW) Doppler radar, collecting respiration data from ten participants. The systems achieved a mean breathing rate accuracy of 92.01% (Wi-Fi) and 93.95% (radar), validated against a medical-grade chest belt. A cost-performance analysis indicates that Wi-Fi sensing offers a highly cost-effective solution, providing comparable accuracy to radar at a fraction of the hardware cost, making it suitable for scalable deployment in low-income regions, such as Bangladesh.

title: Solar Global Tilted Irradiance Prediction for PV-Optimized Microgrids: A Machine Learning Perspective
authors: Kanaka Raju Kalla, D.Ravi Kishore, D.Vijaya Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Solar irradiance prediction is important in order to optimize photovoltaic (PV) systems in microgrids. Although Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI) is used because it is simple to measure, Global Tilted Irradiance (GTI) is more physically appropriate when tilted PV panels are used but has not been extensively used in data-driven modeling. This paper compares and contrasts the GHI and GTI prediction with three machine learning regression algorithms: Linear Regression, Decision Tree and Rand-Forest. The models were trained and evaluated using real-world solar and meteorological data sourced from Solcast. Performance was assessed using standard metrics (RMSE, MAE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) on both validation and test sets. Results show that GTI prediction, while slightly more challenging due to its geometric and diffuse complexity, achieves high accuracy with Random Forest (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.998). In contrast, GHI prediction achieves scores (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> =0.9995). This work highlights the need for greater adoption of GTI in predictive pipelines and suggests further exploration using advanced models to improve GTI prediction and forecasting accuracy in operational microgrid environments.

title: A Q-Band -4 dBm Output Power Passive Frequency Tripler Using Stacked APDNP
authors: Ryunosuke Saito, Ryosei Miyagawa, Yuki Fujiya, Tomoyuki Furuichi, Noriharu Suematsu
abstract: This paper describes a high output power passive frequency tripler using stacked anti-parallel diode-connected nMOS transistor pair (APDNP) in 45nm RF SOI CMOS. By stacking diode-connected nMOS transistors, the threshold voltage is improved and output increase. The Q-band stacked APDNP tripler and conventional single APDNP has been designed and fabricated. Stacked APDNP was measured the output power of - 4dBm at 40GHz which is 4.4 dB higher than the single APDNP. Stacked APDNP shows the highest 3<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rd</sup> harmonic output among CMOS APDP.

title: KKL Observer-Based Control for Piezoelectric Actuators with Bouc-Wen Hysteresis Compensation
authors: Xinlian Wang, Zicheng Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Piezoelectric actuators have inherent hysteresis nonlinearity, which severely limits their positioning accuracy. This article proposes a new observer based control scheme that combines an improved Bouc Wen model with the Kazantzis Kravaris/Luenberger (KKL) observer. By rigorously verifying the reversibility and Lipschitz characteristics of the system, the accuracy of state estimation was ensured. Finally, a closed-loop control system was constructed by combining state feedback control law. The experimental results show that for high- frequency sine wave signals at 10 Hz and triangular wave signals at 10 Hz, the root mean square errors are 0.004, 2008 μ m, and 0.00277 μ m. Compared with existing methods, this method effectively compensates for hysteresis nonlinearity, achieves stable control with nanometer level accuracy, and greatly reduces errors.

title: EEG based Motor Imagery of Hands Classification using Modified Sub-Band Common Spatial Pattern
authors: Yash Kashyap, Eashita Chowdhury, Cheruvu Siva Kumar, Manjunatha Mahadevappa
abstract: Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) leveraging motor imagery (MI) create intuitive systems that translate brain activity into direct control of computer applications. Motor imagery is a technique that provides simulated solutions during training for motor problems. For this study, Electroencephalography(EEG) data is collected from fourteen healthy subjects with 11 channels for two tasks with 40 repetitions each; the data were sourced from a publicly available database, 'OpenVibe'. The present work proposes a modified Subband Common Spatial Pattern (mSBCSP) with Linear Discriminant Analysis as a method to classify right and left hand motor imagery movements, which provides a significant accuracy of 91.79% compared to other methods. The mSBCSP features are extracted from six EEG sub-bands after band pass filtering to enhance the discriminatory features. The results suggest that the proposed method offers a reliable and efficient framework for MI classification, which can serve as a foundation for future development of BCI-controlled applications for motor rehabilitation and the multimedia industry.

title: Edible Oil Purity Check with a Sensor Based on Microwave Metasurface
authors: Rajarshi Paul, Shiven Sisodia, Srijani Hati, Ahana Manna, Niten Kumar Panda
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Abstract—In this article, a metasurface absorber based on split-ring resonators (SRRs) is developed for detecting adulteration in edible oils. A cavity is designed above the metasur-face sensor to hold the oil sample. For pure edible oils, the sensor exhibits near-unity absorptivity at a specific resonance frequency, which is first calculated for the empty cavity. In the case of adulterated oils, the resonance frequency shifts and the absorptivity changes due to variations in their refractive indices. This sensor is a four element structure having dimensions 78 × 78 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and each unit cell consist of two concentric metallic split rings carved over FR4 substrate having thickness 0.8 mm (with dielectric constant 4.4 and loss tangent 0.02). This portable low cost sensor has very high sensitivity having Q factor 76.97%.The simulation to find the absorptivity of the oil sample is performed using Floquet mode analysis in CST Microwave Studio. A prototype has been fabricated and tested using microwave test bench setup in laboratory by observing the VSWR variation. Their affordable price and small size make them suitable for real-time tracking in healthcare, the agriculture industry, and manufacturing industries, especially when it comes to food safety.

title: Data-driven profits prediction and its application mechanism for intelligent satellites task planning
authors: Yongming He, Hao Zhou, Yonghao Du, Jian Wu, Junwei Ou, Ming Chen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In the domain of imaging satellite task planning, profit prediction aims to scientifically forecast the total profit of task planning schemes based on the attributes of tasks within the planning scenario and the parameters of relevant resources, states, and environment, for supporting decision-making. This problem involves numerous input information and complex calculation during the intermediate process. To address these challenges, this paper designs a data-driven task planning mechanism that organically integrates the profit prediction module with other intelligent computation modules of the satellite. Building upon this foundation, a profit prediction model and algorithm based on a multilayer perceptron is proposed, enabling rapid and precise predictions across various real-time task planning scenarios. Through the design of simulation experiments in two aspects, the accuracy and universality of the profit prediction method are validated, while the contribution of the profit prediction module to intelligent satellite task planning is demonstrated.

title: A Single-stage Interpretable Vision Transformer Model Via Granular-ball Computing
authors: Huan Gou, Fenglin Yu, Guolai Jiang, Chengfang Zhang, Shuyin Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Deep learning models have been widely used in image recognition tasks due to their superior feature learning capabilities. The Vision Transformer (ViT), a mainstream deep learning architecture, uses a self-attention mechanism that effectively captures global feature dependencies compared to traditional convolutional neural networks. However, existing ViT models, because of their single-scale nature, suffer from poor interpretability when target features vary in location and size. This paper proposes a purity-based multi-granularity single-stage transformer model designed to precisely locate key regions that influence classification decisions. This approach first uses a convolutional network to decompose the input image into multiple subimage patches of varying granularity, which are then fed into the ViT module for feature extraction and classification. Using the output of the attention weight matrix from the attention layer, this paper constructs an undirected graph structure with high-attention image patches as nodes. A single-stage random walk algorithm is then used to generate interpretable analysis results. Compared to traditional multi-stage random walk methods, this single-stage strategy significantly reduces computational complexity while effectively maintaining the advantages of multi-granularity feature importance analysis and enabling the quantification of the importance of feature combinations.

title: FilterNet: A Filtered Gait Motion Fusion Network for Classifying Adult Spinal Deformity
authors: Kaixu Chen, Tomoyuki Asada, Kousei Miura, Hideki Kadone, Kotaro Sakashita, Takahiro Sunami, Masashi Yamazaki, Itaru Kitahara, Yoshihiro Kuroda
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Analyzing periodic human motion from videos is vital for applications such as action recognition and healthcare. In gait analysis, models must capture subtle phase-specific motion patterns. However, processing entire sequences often introduces noise and reduces accuracy. We propose FilterNet, a frameselection framework that identifies phase-relevant frames to improve temporal modeling and enhance discriminative representation. On a clinical gait video dataset, FilterNet achieves 74.5% accuracy, 75.2% precision, and 74.3% F1-score, outperforming baseline methods. Though demonstrated in a medical context, the framework is broadly applicable to other periodic motion analysis tasks. Code is available at: https://github.com/ChenKaiXuSan/ FilterNet_ASD_PyTorch.

title: Design of an Intelligent LED Plant Lighting System Based on Greedy Algorithm
authors: He Wang, Jiping Wang, Qikai Liu, Meijian Wang, Dachong Deng, Wentao Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Traditional agricultural lighting systems suffer from multiple challenges including low light efficiency, excessive energy consumption, fixed spectral composition, and insufficient environmental control precision. To address these issues, This paper develops an intelligent LED lighting system based on greedy algorithm optimization. Using blueberry tissue culture seedlings as research subjects, the system integrates three innovative technologies: customized light formula development, cloud-based remote monitoring platform, and data-driven decision-making algorithms. By applying greedy algorithm optimization for spectral ratios, it achieves dynamic adjustment of light conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that this system significantly enhances both growth efficiency and fruit quality of blueberries, proving the practical value of intelligent control technology in modern agriculture.

title: MQTT Protocol-Based Detection and Classification in UAV-Assisted Smart Farming for IoT Intrusion Detection System
authors: T Sunitha, K Surendra Reddy, Ola Khresat, Chintala Muralikrishna, Rakesh Chandrashekar, Maranan Ramya
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) presents challenges in energy efficiency, communication reliability, and network security in applications like precision agriculture and smart cities. To address these challenges, we propose a MQTT Protocol-Based Detection and Classification in UAV-Assisted Smart Farming for IoT Intrusion Detection System (MDCUSI). An advanced energy framework optimized for UAV energy consumption of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) combined with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for enhanced intrusion detection, and an FT-Transformer-based Intrusion Detection System for heterogeneous IoT data analysis. The Transformer component improves accuracy by leveraging attention mechanisms to identify correlations in data features. The evaluation analysis we used to calculate accuracy, CNN model loss, CNN model accuracy, remaining energy, communication delay, and energy consumption of the MDCUSI model.

title: 1.75-43.75 GHz N-Path Harmonic Mixer with Folded Noise Cancellation
authors: Yuki Tsukui, Yoshiaki Morino, Kazutomi Mori, Takuma Torii, Akihito Hirai, Koji Yamanaka, Tomoyuki Furuichi, Noriharu Suematsu
abstract: A 1.75-43.75 GHz N-path harmonic mixer with folded noise cancellation is proposed using 45 nm CMOS-SOI. In an N-path harmonic mixer with N number of paths, the noise figure (NF) can be improved by canceling the folded noise due to harmonics of the LO signals of orders other than multiples of the number of paths N. To verify the NF improvement, an N-path mixer was fabricated using a 45 nm SOI-CMOS process with the number of paths switchable from 1 to 4. By achieving wideband input matching, the mixer demonstrated operation with the widest relative bandwidth in the 1.75-43.75 GHz band, corresponding to the 1st to the 12th harmonics of the LO signal in 1-path mode. Additionally, an NF improvement of 5.1 dB was achieved by switching the number of paths from 1 to 4. This is the first time in the world that NF improvement has been confirmed in the N-path mixer without digital processing, which is used as a 12th-order harmonic mixer.

title: Direct Wideband Matching Technique for Nonlinear Multistage Power Amplifiers
authors: Alexander Deublein, Michael Loose, David Riess, Christian Musolff, Robert Weigel, Georg Fischer, Christof Pfannenmüller, Norman Franchi
abstract: Key metrics of multistage power amplifiers – such as efficiency, linearity, and bandwidth – are strongly influenced by both interstage matching networks (ISMNs) and, in some cases, the nonlinear input impedances of transistors. This work presents a wideband direct matching technique that derives linear RC networks from nonlinear load-pull simulations, providing an intuitive framework to accelerate ISMN design and analysis, while accounting for nonlinear input behavior. A dual-stage Infineon GaN-on-Si demonstrator operating at 6.8GHz was designed and measured, showing good agreement with simulation and demonstrating the technique’s value in guiding the design process.

title: Self-Calibration Algorithm for Amplitude-Phase Errors in UHF Radar Arrays Based on Enhanced Channel Optimization Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Zhicheng Qian, Qing Zhou, Linxun Jiang, Xiaohua Zhu, Hong Hong
abstract: This paper proposes an enhanced channel optimization particle swarm optimization algorithm (ECHOPSO) to enhance the amplitude and phase consistency of the ultra-high frequency (UHF) radar array system. The algorithm introduces a multi-strategy improvement mechanism based on the traditional PSO framework. It uses the Latin hypercube sampling method to generate the initial population, enhancing the coverage of the search space. Additionally, it proposes an adaptive classification coefficient based on norms to divide the particle population levels and guide the elite particles to accelerate convergence. The algorithm also incorporates the Gaussian perturbation strategy into velocity update process to effectively avoid falling into local optima, aiming to more accurately estimate the amplitude and phase errors of the array antenna. Simulation experiments indicated that ECHO-PSO holds a stronger global search ability and convergence stability. The field experiments further demonstrated that the method significantly improves the performance of spatial spectrum estimation and enhances direction-finding performance.

title: AI-Based Decision Support for Energy Management in High-Penetration Renewable Grids
authors: Ch. Mani Teja, V N S R Murthy, O.Ranjit Kumar, K.Vijaya Prasad, T. Venkateswara Rao, P. Lakshman Naik
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: As electrical systems increasingly rely on solar and wind power, managing their inherent variability becomes critical. This paper introduces an AI-powered decision support framework tailored for grids with substantial renewable integration. By leveraging machine learning techniques, the proposed system forecasts generation and load, schedules battery operations, and optimizes grid imports/exports to maintain balance. Evaluated using open-source datasets, our approach demonstrates significant improvements in forecasting accuracy, cost reduction, and grid stability compared to conventional methods.

title: Recent Developments in Millimeter-Wave Receiver Technology for Radio Astronomy in South Korea
authors: Jung-Won Lee, Do-Heung Je, Jihoon Choi, Bangwon Lee, Junhan Kim, Seungrae Kim, Jiman Kang, MinSu Ko, Wooseok Kang
abstract: A millimeter-wave receiver for radio astronomy typically houses a superconducting mixer or a low-noise HEMT MMIC amplifier inside a cryogenic chamber as the primary detection element. Positioned in front of this element are receiver optics that couple the incoming signal from the antenna system, along with components such as polarizers and orthomode transducers for polarization analysis. This paper outlines recent technical developments in such millimeter-wave receiver systems for radio astronomy in South Korea. Key advancements are presented in the areas of receiver optics, waveguide components, local oscillators, and superconducting mixers. In addition, upcoming receiver projects are introduced, highlighting the direction of future efforts in this field.

title: Transfer Learning–Driven Convolutional Framework for Early Detection of Pulmonary Abnormalities in CT Imaging
authors: Krishnaraj Rao N S, Sanjeev Kulkarni
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Computed tomography (CT) imaging is important in early identification of pulmonary abnormalities that can help in diagnosing and treating respiratory diseases including COVID-19, pulmonary fibrosis, and lung tumors in time. The traditional computer-aided diagnosis systems tend to use handcrafted features and shallow learning models which restrict their ability to process the complex spatial structure of CT images. In the present investigation, we suggest a Transfer Learning-Based Convolutional Framework, which is a convolutional structure, which is pre-trained on ImageNet, to extract the deep features representations of the lung CT slices automatically. The model utilizes fine-tuning and sophisticated methods of data augmentation based on domain-specificity to improve robustness and generalization. Prediction of the abnormality classes is achieved by passing the preprocessed CT images through a frozen CNN backbone which is ended by a global average pooling layer and a fully connected softmax classifier. The model was tested on a five-fold cross-validation scheme on an annotated dataset based on LIDC-IDRI. The model with a classification accuracy of 94.62, an average F1-Score of 92.8, and an AUC-ROC of over 97% had a higher classification accuracy than the baseline models, such as ResNet50, VGG16, and CNNs trained by themselves. Grad-CAM visualizations are added, which makes it interpretable and highlights the important pathological areas. Our findings reveal that domain adaptation transfer learning is very effective in CT based diagnostics of the lungs. This framework provides a scalable and precise instrument of early identification in clinical environments eliminating the use of manual radiological evaluation and enhancing diagnostic rates.

title: Development and Research of Modular Integrated Testing Device for Vapor Recovery Systems at Gas Station
authors: Liwei Zhang, Wenwen Wang, Bo Zou, Hua Zhu, Peng Lei
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the increasingly stringent global environmental protection standards, the effective operation and accurate detection of vapor recovery systems at gas stations have become a critical component of air pollution prevention and control. Addressing the technical bottlenecks of traditional detection methods, including dispersed equipment, low efficiency, and poor data consistency, this study developed a modular integrated testing device. The device innovatively integrates multiple functions including liquid resistance testing, tightness testing, air-to-liquid ratio testing, and leakage detection on a unified platform, utilizing standardized interfaces to achieve rapid switching and combination of detection modules. The multi-parameter synchronous acquisition technology employs a cascaded sampling architecture with adaptive Kalman filtering (Q=0.001I, R=0.01I) achieving 100Hz data acquisition. The multi-parameter coupling compensation model implements cross-sensitivity correction through polynomial regression (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.9973) reducing measurement uncertainty by 40%. Standardized interfaces follow ISO 12207 specifications with mechanical tolerance ±0.05mm and electrical contacts rated IP67, supporting hot-swapping with automatic module recognition. Experimental validation demonstrates that in practical applications at 30 gas stations, the device achieved liquid resistance detection accuracy of ±1.8 Pa, tightness test repeatability of 4.2±1.0 Pa, air-to-liquid ratio measurement relative error controlled within 0.65%, and detection time reduced by 51.3%. Field testing across 450 measurement cycles showed module switching reliability of 99.8% with mean switching time of 3.2±0.4 seconds. All performance indicators significantly exceed those of traditional single detection equipment, providing a new technical solution for standardized and efficient detection of vapor recovery systems at gas stations.

title: Smart Campus Evolution Via Iot: Technical Constraints, Stakeholder Analysis, and Future Opportunities
authors: Bishwajit Banik Pathik, Abir Tirtha Das, Md. Kothan Miad
abstract: This article aims to address the technical challenges and potentials associated with implementing smart campuses in conventional university frameworks. Integration of cost effective IoT sensors, improved wireless communication, different machine learning algorithms for data analysis, sustainable energy infrastructure are valuable tools for facilitating smart campus architecture. To gain insight into the feasibility and future prospects of smart campus adoption, a comprehensive survey was conducted among various campus stakeholders including students, faculty, and administrative staff. A total of 138 responses were received from the survey which had eighteen questions inquiring various aspects of any smart campus. The survey responses not only highlighted diverse opinions and priorities on the implementation of advanced technologies in smart university campuses but also indicated future aspects of the same in terms of educational and administrative growth. This study provides valuable recommendations for universities seeking to transition toward smart campus architectures while addressing the technical challenges inherent in such initiatives.

title: Explainable AI-Powered Risk Assessment System for Strategic Business Planning
authors: S Mamatha, G. Pandi Selvi, N N Murthy, Srichandana Abbineni, Pramod Kumar, Ganeshkumar D. Rede
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The paper focuses on an Explainable AIPowered Risk Assessment System as a part of strategic business planning with the SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) method to provide transparency and interpretability of the models. When dealing with the complex decision environment, it is important that the stakeholders understand the basis of the assessment of risks. The SHAP values give a single measure of the importance of features, decomposing the contribution of each variable to the prediction done by the model. With SHAP applied to a machine learning system of risk assessment, companies will be in a better position to learn more about the impact of each risk factor on the overall strategic choices made. This method does not only make decision-making more predictive because it offers a more accurate picture of the world but also makes sure that the behavior of the model does not go against the business priorities and regulations. The system will be structured to enable real time risk analysis, which will encourage better and more informed strategic planning. On balance, this research highlights the significance of explainability in AI systems, which is necessary to make the risk assessment process transparent, responsible, and capable of changing in response to changing business demands.

title: Coordinated Dual-ARM Manipulation Using Reinforcement Learning: A Soft Actor-Critic Approach on the Poppy Humanoid
authors: Allen Jacob George, Abhishek Sarkar, Joyjit Mukherjee
abstract: In this work, we present a reinforcement learningbased framework for dual-arm object manipulation using the Poppy humanoid robot platform. Our approach addresses the challenges of coordinated grasping and object transport by decomposing the task into two sequential stages. In the first stage, a single policy is trained using the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm to simultaneously control both arms and the torso to perform object grasping. In the second stage, a separate SAC policy is trained to move the grasped object to a specified target location. To improve learning efficiency, we incorporate human demonstration data during training. This integration of expert guidance with sample efficient deep reinforcement learning enables the system to achieve robust, coordinated manipulation behavior. Further validation of the simulation results were tested by putting the Poppy robot joint trajectories generated from the simulation results. Both simulation and experimental results are shown to demonstrate that our method can successfully perform dual-arm object grasping and relocation with stable and synchronized motion.

title: Decadal Land Cover Change Analysis and Forecasting in the Mahiga River Watershed Using GIS and CA-ANN Modeling
authors: Leo Nhel D. Abao, Ricardo L. Fornis, Jonah Lee I. Bas
abstract: Rapid urbanization in the Philippines, particularly in highly urbanized cities such as Cebu City, has altered land cover patterns and intensified development pressure on natural landscapes. The Mahiga River watershed, located within Cebu City, has seen urban expansion encroach on natural waterways and disrupt terrain, contributing to frequent flooding in several key areas during heavy rainfall. This study analyzes and projects decadal land cover changes in the watershed using remote sensing and GIS. Land cover data for 2000, 2010, and 2020 were mapped and processed, with a 2030 projection generated using the MOLUSCE plugin in QGIS, which integrates cellular automata and artificial neural networks. Results show built-up areas expanding from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.33 ~\text{km}^{2}$</tex> in 2000 to a projected <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13.19 ~\text{km}^{2}$</tex> in 2030, while wooded (5.34 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.98 ~\text{km}^{2}$</tex>), covered (3.51 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.16 ~\text{km}^{2}$</tex>), and bare (0.17 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.02 ~\text{km}^{2}$</tex>) lands declined. These trends highlight the rapid urban growth within the watershed and demonstrate the utility of geospatial modeling for monitoring land cover transformation in floodprone urban environments.

title: A DMA-Based High-Precision Control Method for Attitude Control Flywheels
authors: Zhibo Jia, Guangzhi Cui, Xinqi Li, Maodong Shen, Xudong Liu, Shuo Dong, Fang He
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Utilizing a Digital Signal Processor (DSP) as the core control chip can effectively ensure the closed-loop control performance of the attitude control flywheel. The acquisition speed of analog quantities, such as current, is a critical factor influencing this performance. Employing a polling transmission mechanism for data transfer between memory and the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) presents issues of low transmission efficiency and extended control cycles. Utilizing an interrupt-based transmission mechanism introduces problems like interrupt response latency and jitter; furthermore, frequent interrupt responses increase system uncertainty. To address these issues, a high-performance data transmission method based on Direct Memory Access (DMA) is proposed. This method configures the Multi-channel Buffered Serial Port (McBSP) as an SPI peripheral and utilizes DMA to facilitate data transfer, enabling ADC-acquired data to be transmitted directly to system memory without CPU intervention. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to polling and interrupt-based data transmission methods, the attitude control flywheel employing the proposed method achieves an improvement in speed control precision (3σ) of no less than 18.41% and 18.42%, respectively, and an improvement in torque control precision (3σ) of no less than 20.18% and 51.18%, across its entire operational envelope.

title: Wiper Motor Control for Oscillation Suppression of Windshield Wiper Arms Using H-Infinity Synthesis
authors: Tsutomu Tashiro, Sodai Kato
abstract: In this paper, a windshield wiper control and its design method to achieve both basic function of wiper control and oscillation suppression of wiper arms. A wiper model is described as a three-inertia resonance system to realize second mode oscillation characteristics. The control is designed based on H-infinity control theory to track the target motor angle and suppress the oscillation of the angular speeds of the driver's side arm and passenger's side arm. Verification is carried out with a wiper test rig using five types of rubber blades with different deterioration levels under a wide range of rainfall conditions. The effectiveness of the proposed control is demonstrated by comparing with the results of the conventional control designed based on optimal regulator theory. The experimental results are investigated from the viewpoints of suppressing the second mode oscillation and the accuracy of the reversal motor angle which determines the wiping range of the arms.

title: DK-CBLOF: A Novel Method for High-Temperature Anomaly Detection in Cloud Resource Pools
authors: Yue Shen, Xiao Yang, Wei Dong, Xuhui Cai, Xunchao Li, Xi Chen, Zhongxu Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: With the expansion of cloud computing scale and the increase in computing density, high-temperature anomaly issues in cloud resource pools have become increasingly prominent. However, traditional static threshold-based detection methods suffer from delayed responses, inefficient fault isolation, and poor adaptability.This study develops the DK-CBLOF hybrid anomaly detection algorithm.The algorithm integrates the Cluster-Based Local Outlier Factor (CBLOF) to realize clustering and anomaly identification of multi-dimensional operational indicators, and introduces reinforcement learning to optimize dynamic K-Sigma threshold adjustment—solving the problem of missed detections and false detections caused by fixed K values in traditional algorithms when dealing with fluctuating data. Experiments based on real-network data from four resource pools of Shandong Mobile’s network cloud show that the DK-CBLOF algorithm achieves an average accuracy of approximately 90%, outperforming traditional algorithms such as CBLOF, LOF, and KNN by nearly 15 percentage points. The proposed system has been deployed in China Mobile’s data centers across 16 provinces, covering about 200,000 network devices. It can issue early warnings 10-15 minutes before high-temperature alarms are triggered, effectively resolving the impact of cross-regional differences and scattered anomalies on algorithm accuracy, and demonstrating strong practicality for real-network deployment.

title: Assessing Migraine Severity in University Students Using Low-Channel Wearable EEG
authors: Lee Fan Tan, Huei Qhi Teoh, Hou Kit Mun, Kiruthika Selvakumar
abstract: Migraine is a common neurological disorder that substantially affects quality of life (QoL) and is associated with altered cortical activity. While advanced neuroimaging has enhanced understanding of migraine-related brain changes, such methods are often costly and not widely accessible. This study investigates the feasibility of using a low-channel, wearable electroencephalography (EEG) device to assess migraine severity in a non-clinical population of university students. Fifty-three participants were stratified into four groups based on the Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) questionnaire. Resting-state EEG data were recorded with the Muse 2 headband and processed via EEGLAB in MATLAB. Power spectral density (PSD) analysis focused on alpha (α, 8–12 Hz) and beta (β, 13–30 Hz) activity in frontal and temporal regions. Although statistical analysis using one-way ANOVA did not yield significant differences, a decreasing trend in α and β power was observed with increasing migraine severity. Participants also completed the Migraine-Specific Quality of Life Questionnaire (MSQv2.1), which showed no significant differences among the groups. The findings support the feasibility of using consumer-grade EEG systems for non-invasive assessment of migraine severity and provide a foundation for future studies involving larger cohorts and advanced signal analysis.

title: YOLO-RSNet: A Lightweight Multi-Scale Object Detection Framework for Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Jianguo Ma, LiangYu Dong, Hanfeng Xie, Guanyu Chen, Anzhu Yu, Chunping Qiu
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: The substantial scale variation of objects in remote sensing imagery presents a persistent challenge to high-precision detection. While existing deep learning methods have advanced, they remain constrained by the static receptive fields of convolutional neural networks, struggling to preserve fine-grained details for small objects while maintaining extensive contextual information. To address this limitation, this paper proposes YOLO-RSNet. The backbone incorporates a Lightweight Feature Enhancement Block (LFEB) module that employs lightweight high-order feature interactions to enhance representation of complex objects. The neck network is redesigned with an MultiScale Fusion Assembly (MSFA) as its core, which actively reinforces edge and high-frequency texture information to effectively mitigate detail degradation during multi-scale fusion. On the DOTA 2.0 dataset, it achieves a $\mathbf{m A P}_{50: 95}$ of $\mathbf{6 4. 5 \%}$, surpassing the baseline model by 6.0 percentage points; on the NWPU VHR-10 dataset, it attains a mAP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">50</inf> of $85.9 \%$, representing an improvement of 3.1 percentage points. The model reduces parameters from $\mathbf{2. 5 8 M}$ to $\mathbf{2. 4 4 M}$, a reduction of approximately $\mathbf{5. 4 \%}$, achieving a superior balance between accuracy and efficiency with a more lightweight architecture, making it suitable for resource-constrained remote sensing applications.

title:
A Sub-400 mm
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    24-GHz FMCW Radar With 2×2 Antenna Array Configuration
authors: Goo-Han Ko, Si Keuk Ryu, Minki Kang, Donghyun Baek
abstract: A sub-400mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> 24-GHz FMCW radar with a 2×2 circularly-polarized (CP) patch-antenna array is proposed. The design focuses on minimizing the overall module size and allowing for high integration flexibility. The proposed radar consists of quadrature coupler (QC) based four-channel CP single antenna and highly integrated frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) integrated chip (IC) with four transmitters (TXs) and four receivers (RXs). In the TX configuration, the four antenna elements are combined to operate as a single left-handed CP (LHCP), while in the RX configuration, each antenna element operates independently with right-handed CP (RHCP). The overall size is 18.75×18.75 (mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) with multilayered printed-circuit board (PCB) consisting of 6-layers. Lastly, the proposed radar successfully demonstrated FMCW radar functionality by estimating the target’s range and angle.

title: Dual-Stage Feature Refinement and Wavelet Denoising for Enhanced VIX Prediction Using Residual BiLSTM
authors: Akanksha Sharma, Priya Singh, Chandan Kumar Verma
abstract: Derivative pricing and financial risk management rely heavily on volatility predictions. Given the dynamic and nonlinear nature of financial markets, accurately predicting volatility remains a persistent challenge. Traditional econometric models often struggle to capture the complex patterns and time-dependent behaviors present in market data. This research presents a Residual Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (ResBiLSTM) model-based deep learning framework for VIX price prediction. By integrating residual connections and bidirectional temporal processing, the model is able to successfully capture intricate patterns found in financial time series data. A complete array of 64 designed features, comprising technical indicators and wavelet-denoised inputs, was employed to train and assess the model. The suggested ResBiLSTM surpasses conventional models, including LSTM, GRU, CNN, BiLSTM, and Residual LSTM, across multiple criteria. The performance was additionally confirmed using 5-fold cross-validation and statistical significance assessment via paired t-tests across many experimental iterations. The findings illustrate the model's resilience, precision, and applicability for implementation in practical volatility forecasting scenarios.

title: Real-Time-Phishing- URL Detection with a Deep Learning-Based Browser Extension
authors: L. Arulmozhiselvan, Krishna Sudthan B, Gowtham V
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Phishing has been one of the most long and harmful cyber security attacks, usually taking the vulnerability of users exploited by malicious URLs. In this paper presents a live window plug-in that will identify phishing web sites utilising deep neural networks to perform URL feature-based detection instead of the more common blacklists. The contributions made are to extract a series of structured features, e.g., age of domain, the existence of SSL certificates, and patterns in special characters, lexical structure of the URL, pass them to a lightweight neural network model built on TensorFlow and Keras. Its backend is made possible using Flask such that there is effective API interaction model business park entre le browser extension and the backend. Our model can be dynamic, very accurate also less latent than the static blacklist method of identifying phishing URLs, which will facilitate new phishing URL that will be created. Experiments on the standard datasets of PhishTank, UCI and Kaggle show that the results are good and show a lot of indicators of classification, including accuracies, precision, recall and F1-score. The proposed solution to the problem is rather possible to implement in the real-time usage in modern webbrowsers.

title: Research on voltage support control strategy based on ESO terminal sliding mode
authors: Shengbo Gao, Zhongjian Kang, Dongshun Li, Shuaihua Liu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In grid-connected PV power generation systems, PV grid-connection affects the stability of the power system due to the fluctuating and intermittent nature of PV output characteristics. To address this problem, PV inverter control strategies need to be studied to improve the stability of grid operation. In this paper, by comparing the grid-following type PQ control with the grid-constructing type VSG control, it is verified that the stability of the grid-constructing type VSG control is better than that of the grid-following type PQ control, based on which, according to the virtual synchronous generator control technology and nonlinear robust control technology, the voltage controller of the virtual synchronous generator is redesigned, and terminal sliding mode control based on the expansion state observer is introduced. Through simulation analysis, when the PV output fluctuates, the ESO terminal sliding mode control can improve the system transient voltage stability compared with the VSG control.

title: A High-Accuracy Deep Learning Model for Early Prediction of Chronic Kidney Disease using Optimized Clinical Features
authors: Nageswari Sankar, Pandiselvam Pandiyarajan, Baskaran Maheswaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily an escalating global health problem, because it progresses insidiously and remains undetected for long periods. Avoiding death-causing diseases like end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requires early detection. The primary risk factors for renal failure are high blood pressure, diabetes, heart disease, and a family history of renal illnesses. Predictive diagnosis might develop with the use of machine learning in the healthcare industry. This work aims to identify sequential patterns from patients' clinical history by proposing a deep learning-based CKD classification algorithm. Several methods, including correlation-based, info gain, gain ratio, and relief score algorithms, are used to carry out feature selection. Proposed method begins with 25 attributes, along with the target, and it ends with the 10 most significant attributes to identify CKD. Different activation functions (ReLU, Tanh, Sigmoid, and LReLU) are also explored. When evaluated using several validation procedures, including data splits of 80:20 and K-Fold set to 20 and 25, respectively, the accuracy rate of the proposed model is 98.75%. The models' efficacy is evaluated for the diagnosis of positive instances by assessing their accuracy, examining confusion matrix statistics, and computing recall, F1-Score, precision, cross-entropy loss function. Experimental results are useful for healthcare practitioners in making timely decisions towards the prediction of CKD disease.

title: Performance Evaluation of Tab Net and MLP Algorithms in Credit Card Fraud Detection
authors: Madeti Sumanjali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Detecting fraudulent credit card transactions remains a major challenge in financial analytics due to the highly imbalanced nature of real-world datasets. Effective fraud detection requires models that can recognize rare fraudulent patterns without being biased toward the majority class. In this research, a comparative study between two deep learning models Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) and Tab Net is conducted using a real credit card transaction dataset. To handle class imbalance, the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) is employed to enhance the representation of minority (fraudulent) cases. The models are evaluated based on classification metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score, along with computational efficiency. Experimental findings reveal that both models achieved high recall (0.78) for fraudulent transactions, indicating strong sensitivity in identifying frauds. However, precision values were comparatively low (MLP: 0.07, Tab Net: 0.08), suggesting the presence of false positives. Tab Net slightly outperformed MLP in terms of F1-score (0.14 vs. 0.12), reflecting a marginally better balance between recall and precision. Although both models reached an overall accuracy of about 96%, this metric was less reliable due to the inherent data imbalance. The outcomes highlight the importance of recall in fraud detection and demonstrate Tab Net advantage in structured data modeling when compared to conventional neural architectures such as MLP.

title: Modelling and Control of a 4-DOF Moving Base Manipulator
authors: Aksa Santhosh, Lal Priya P S, Sneha Gajbhiye
abstract: Moving-base robotic manipulators are increasingly utilized in various industries due to their flexibility and adaptability in diverse dynamic environments. This work focuses on the modeling and control of a 4-DOF robotic manipulator composed of a planar two-link manipulator mounted on a mobile base capable of translating along the dual axes. The dynamic behavior of the manipulator is derived using the Euler-Lagrange equation, which effectively captures the dynamic coupling between the manipulator and the base. Additionally, kinematic analysis is conducted to accurately determine the end-effector's position during operation. One of the main challenges in this setup lies in dealing with the system's nonlinear characteristics, external disturbances, and the need to manage the dynamic interactions between the base and the manipulator components. To address these challenges, a Sliding Mode Control (SMC) strategy is adopted, chosen for its well-known resilience to system uncertainties and external perturbations. The proposed control framework is implemented within the MATLAB Simulink and Simscape environments, where the entire 4-DOF system is modeled to reflect realistic dynamics and base-manipulator interactions. Through simulation, the effectiveness of the controller in achieving robust and precise motion control is demonstrated.

title: Development of Chatbot Module in an Intelligent Tutoring System for English Language Learning Using Large Language Model
authors: Ziyad Dhia Rafi, Ayu Purwarianti, Samsu Sempena
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: This project develops a chatbot module for an Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) in English language learning, powered by a large language model (LLM). The chatbot provides personalized practice, real-time grammar correction, vocabulary support, and question answering, adapting to each student's proficiency. Integrated with student and tutor modules, it tracks progress and tailors feedback dynamically. Leveraging LLM capabilities, the system understands natural language inputs and generates contextually relevant responses, enhancing engagement and learning outcomes. Evaluation focuses on accuracy, informativeness, and user satisfaction, offering a scalable AI-driven solution to improve English proficiency efficiently.

title: Low-Power VLSI Accelerator Architecture for AI-Enhanced Real-Time Audio and Video Processing at the Network Edge
authors: D Shaiksha Vali, Ala'a Al-Shaikh, Venkata Ramaiah Kavuri, SkGouse John, Sravanthi, R Suresh Kumar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Multiple multimedia analytics functions that utilize edge-based Artificial Intelligence (AI) require efficient and low-power machines that can support real-time audio and video streams. The current accelerator architectures (GPUs and FPGAs) are powerful but have high energy consumption, high data movement latency, and a high level of scalability, which does not allow simultaneous processing of many modalities. In order to overcome these shortcomings, this study adopts a Low-Power VLSI Accelerator Architecture that has been tuned to run AI-based real-time audio and video processing in the network edge. The proposed model integrates the hierarchical dataflow, adaptive clock gating, and multi-core neural processing unit (NPU) that is tuned to systolic array-based computing with the dynamic voltage-frequency scaling (DVFS) that ensures the efficiency of the workload balancing with lesser energy leakage. Moreover, the architecture uses on-chip memory compression and shared buffer reuse techniques that reduce redundancy in accessing memory; this improves the throughput besides bandwidth use. The experimental analysis shown that the proposed model performs well with the improvement in reduction of power consumption, reduction of latency and improved energy consumption of a GPU. The results of this study should play a significant role in the implementation of intelligent, scalable, and sustainable edge computing systems to next-generation IoT and multimedia applications that would allow real-time decision-making with a low latency and power consumption.

title: Research on Real-Time Localization and Mapping Algorithms for Police Quadruped Robots
authors: Tan Yao, Chen Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: To address the application requirements for precise localization and reliable mapping of police quadruped robots during high-maneuver motion conditions, this paper proposes a tightly coupled LiDAR-IMU odometry framework named HMA-LIO (High Maneuverability-Adapted LiDAR-Inertial Odometry). HMA-LIO innovatively designs an online IMU data quality evaluation mechanism and establishes an adaptive optimization strategy based on IMU quality factors, which can dynamically select point cloud motion compensation schemes and optimize sensor fusion weights in the error-state Kalman filter. Experimental results on the publicly available SubT-MRS dataset demonstrate that HMA-LIO achieves significantly higher trajectory estimation accuracy than mainstream comparison algorithms in complex maneuvering scenarios. Further verification through quadruped robot simulation experiments confirms that HMA-LIO can provide real-time, robust, and high-precision localization outputs and 3D map construction capabilities. This research provides a comprehensive solution to the challenge state estimation for high-maneuver platforms in complex environments, and offers a reliable technical approach for police quadruped robots to perform critical tasks such as counter-terrorism, emergency response, and disaster rescue.

title: Sentiment Analysis on Product Reviews using Hybrid Deep Learning Models
authors: Vidyashree K, Arati Chabukswar, Dhanusha S, Niharika D S, Swimpy Pahuja
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: As social media and e-commerce sites become more popular, more people are sharing their thoughts on products. We can learn about customers' feelings from these reviews by applying natural language processing techniques. In this study, we look at how sentiment analysis can automatically sort reviews into neutral, negative, or positive categories. We test LSTM, CNN, and two hybrid versions of deep learning architectures, implemented with embedding layers and trained on tokenized product review datasets. Sequence learning and convolution-based feature extraction work together so the models can capture contextual patterns in the text and make accurate sentiment predictions. Through the direct learning of meaningful representations from the input, deep learning (DL) techniques have significantly improved the processing of raw textual data. This study evaluates four architectures developed in our project: a CNN that uses word embeddings to extract spatial features, an LSTM network that captures sequential dependencies, a CNN–LSTM hybrid model that combines convolutional feature extraction with temporal context learning, and a CNN–Bidirectional LSTM (CNN–BiLSTM) that learns dependencies from both past and future word sequences. These models are trained on pre-processed and tokenized product review datasets to perform sentiment classification. All models were implemented using the TensorFlow Kera's framework and trained on a labelled dataset using GloVe embeddings for word representation. These findings indicate that CNN–BiLSTM achieved the highest accuracy (97%), outperforming CNN–LSTM (92%), LSTM (91%), and CNN (88%).

title: A Compact Ultrawideband Common-Mode Filter Based on Comb-Shaped Defected Ground Structure
authors: Zhiyuan Niu, Cheng Zhou, Peng Zhou, Xiaoxing Yin
abstract: This paper proposes a compact ultrawideband common-mode filter utilizing a comb-shaped defected ground structure (DGS). The incorporation of the comb-shaped DGS significantly increases the equivalent characteristic impedance of the slotline resonator, enabling a substantial enhancement in common-mode (CM) suppression bandwidth. The equivalent circuit models based on even- and odd-mode analysis are developed to elucidate the operating principles. The proposed CMF is validated through experimental measurements of a fabricated prototype. Measured results demonstrate an ultrawide CM suppression fractional bandwidth of 95.53% (S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">cc21</inf> < -10 dB), alongside a differential-mode (DM) passband with insertion loss (S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">dd21</inf> > -3 dB) below 3 dB exceeding 10 GHz. Excellent mode-conversion suppression (S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">cd21</inf>, S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">dc21</inf> < -25 dB) is also achieved, confirming the effectiveness in high-speed differential signaling applications.

title: Hybrid CNN-LSTM Model for Healthcare Service Efficiency Prediction and Optimization
authors: F. V. Jayasudha, B. R. Supreeth, Ragini Mishra, D. Sugumaran, V P Rameshkumaar, Mohit Tiwari
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The growing complexity of medical processes requires smart models that can forecast and streamline the efficiency of the service with the help of different patient and hospital statistics. A Hybrid CNNLSTM framework to improve healthcare performance in terms of temporalspatial feature learning. The model combines Convolutional Neural Networks to extract the spatial features and Long Short-Term Memory layers to identify the sequential patterns, which would provide the correct prediction of patient flow, diagnostic load, and resource utilization. The proposed system also outperforms the existing deep learning architectures by achieving an accuracy of 97.86%, precision of 97.42%, recall of 96.95%, F1-score of 97.09%, and a lower RMSE of 0.081 on a real-world MIMIC-IV dataset. The hybrid model exhibits better adaptability, effective calculation, and strong generalization during real-time healthcare settings. Itconcludes that the offered CNNLSTM combination is a valid solution to streamline the work of hospitals, enhance clinical performance, and provide opportunities to manage healthcare based on data.

title: Development of a Strap-Based Active Back-Support Exoskeleton for Static Postural Sway Correction
authors: Jun Han Lee, Yu Zheng Chong, Siow Cheng Chan
abstract: Postural sway control has traditionally been targeted through lower-limb or ankle-based interventions, especially critical for individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP), older adults, and those with neurological disorders. This paper introduces a strap-based soft active back-support exoskeleton that applies corrective torque directly across the trunk and shoulders using pneumatic actuation. Trunk sway is detected via an inertial measurement unit (IMU) mounted on the sternum via nylon straps, with corrective action triggered through a lightweight ESP32-based threshold control algorithm. Fifteen healthy adults were evaluated across four static stance conditions, with the Tandem Stance Eyes Closed (TSEC) posture representing the greatest challenge to balance. When the exosuit was active, the centre of pressure (CoP) pathlength decreased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1. 5 \%}$</tex>, while RMS sEMG activity was reduced by 51.2 % in the rectus abdominis, 38.3 % in the external oblique, and 41.8 % in the erector spinae. These results highlight the feasibility of a trunk-focused active exosuit for improving static balance control, offering a complementary alternative to conventional ankle or limb-based corrective strategies. These findings suggest the exosuit's potential as a practical tool for assisting static balance.

title: An Overcurrent Protection Circuit for High-Voltage Half-Bridge Drivers
authors: Ziting Zhu, Jingchao Zhou, Chengyu Ma, Haijin Chen
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: A 0.35-μm BCD (Bipolar-CMOS-DMOS) process-based overcurrent protection circuit suitable for high-voltage half-bridge driver applications is proposed. The circuit mainly consists of a control logic block, a current detection circuit, and a comparator. By introducing a sampling delay based current detection method into the driver, the conduction current of the low-side power MOSFET can be monitored in real time, effectively preventing false triggering caused by transient current spikes during turn on. When the detected voltage signal exceeds a predefined threshold, the control logic circuit immediately turns off the power transistor, and the driver automatically resumes operation after 15 clock cycles. Simulation results show that under a supply voltage of 600 V and an operating frequency of 50 kHz, when the load current exceeds 10 A, the proposed overcurrent protection circuit promptly activates the protection mechanism and rapidly shuts down the power transistor, demonstrating fast response and high reliability.

title:
A Coupler-Based Single-Stage Broadband Ka-Band Power Amplifier with Dual-Driven Gain-Boosting Technique Achieving 21.9 dB/36.4% Gain/PAE
                    <sub>max</sub>
authors: Lei Zhang, Weitao Yang, Xiaoxian Liu, Zhangming Zhu
abstract: This paper proposes a gain-boosted, fully integrated coupler-based single-stage broadband Ka-band power amplifier. The coupled line is introduced in the middle of the common source (CS) and common gate (CG), which facilitates broadband gain enhancement. Meanwhile, distinguishing from the ideal matching analysis of the coupled line, the analysis of the performance enhancement by introducing the coupled line takes into account the effects of the different port impedances of the CG transistor. Additionally, coupled lines are also applied for output matching achieving low loss matching of 0.8 dB over a wide bandwidth from 25 GHz to 40 GHz. The proposed power amplifier is fabricated in 65nm bulk CMOS process. Measurement results demonstrate a small signal gain of 21.9 dB with 45.6% 3-dB fractional bandwidth (BW) from 22 to 35 GHz, and saturated output power (P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf>) of 18 dBm with full-band 1-dB Psat coverage, and peak power-added efficiency (PAE) of 36.4%.

title: Performance Validation in Large-Scale Computing: Iterative Workflow Refinement through Orchestrated Execution
authors: Shikha Parekh
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This paper examines systematic approaches to executing computational experiments within high-performance environments. We present strategies for managing complex workflows that support community-driven benchmarking and reproducibility. By orchestrating robust execution frameworks, our work highlights how performance insights derived from executed workflows serve as a crucial feedback mechanism, enabling continuous optimization and validation of computational processes. This allows for the iterative enhancement of system configurations and application benchmarks, fostering a more adaptive and reliable computational science ecosystem.

title: Late Binding ROM: Flexible, In-Field Updateable Post Quantum Cryptography in Hardware
authors: John Barry, Marek Zmuda, Nikola Radovanovic, Yarden Hareven, Paul Stanley Sundar, Christine Severns-Williams
abstract: The threat which quantum computers pose to the security of the asymmetric cryptographic algorithms underpinning digital infrastructure has been widely recognized and is actively being mitigated across the industry. Post quantum cryptographic algorithms have been developed and standardized which are resistant to attacks using quantum computing techniques. However, new algorithms are under development and the implementations of the new standards are, relative to established algorithms such as RSA or ECDSA, immature and untested in the field. For this reason, hardware manufacturers must be prepared for the fact that the definition of these algorithms may change in the near future. This paper proposes a field-upgradeable mechanism which enables post quantum algorithm implementations within a hardware Root of Trust for Detection. The proposed mechanism ensures a secure boot flow while allowing for new algorithms to be deployed or vulnerabilities which emerge in existing algorithms or their implementations to be rectified in the field.

title: Battery-Aware UAV Path Planning for Maximum Value Collection: A Spatial-Correction and DRL-Based Optimization Approach
authors: Xunkang Zhao, Pan Wang, Jiaming Tan, Zhihan Shou, Xiaopeng Cui
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: This paper tackles the problem of planning paths for battery-limited drones by offering a real-time method that blends spatial sense with deep reinforcement learning. We build a simple model that adjusts the value of each target point by adding the worth of nearby points and their distances, guiding the drone to visit high-value clusters first. On top of this, we join the POMO algorithm with beam search in an end-to-end framework: POMO creates strong route options, and beam search quickly refines them, lifting path quality while keeping response fast. Tests on tasks ranging from 20 to 100 nodes show that our POMO-CM method clearly beats classic optimizers like ACO, PSO and ALNS, and also tops the deep baseline AM+POMO. It raises solution quality by more than 8.59 % on average and cuts computing time by over twenty-fold. Adding beam search lets the method move even closer to the global best. This approach gives a solid basis and ready-to-use tool for real-time decisions in power-limited drones working in logistics, reconnaissance and monitoring.
