title: A Trench SiC MOSFET With Depletion-Mode pMOS for Improved Performance and Reliability
authors: Weizhong Chen, Zhijie Deng, Zesheng Chen, Yufan Xiao, Hongsheng Zhang, Zhengsheng Han
abstract: A trench SiC MOSFET (TMOS) integrated with dual depletion-mode pMOS (D-pMOS) without extra gate signal is proposed. The P-shield, P-ch, and P+ act as the source, substrate, and drain of the D-pMOS, respectively. Additionally, the gates of the D-pMOS are shorted to the main gates. At <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state with gate–source voltage (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {gs}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of 15 V, the holes in the P-ch are completely depleted, and then the P-ch is pinched off. Consequently, the D-pMOS is turned off to achieve the P-shield with floating state, which effectively suppresses the JFET effect and decreases the JFET resistance (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${R}_{\text {JFET}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>). At <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</small>-state with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {gs}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> of 0 V, the D-pMOS is activated to turn on, and the P-ch maintains sufficient hole concentration. Thus, a direct conductive path is established between the P-shield and the source, thereby the P-shield is grounded. Consequently, it effectively suppresses dynamic performance degradation. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SiC MOSFET with adjustable P-shield-TMOS (AP-TMOS) shows significant performance advantages over conventional grounded P-shield-TMOS (GP-TMOS) and floating P-shield-TMOS (FP-TMOS): 1) compared to GP-TMOS, it achieves 20.69% lower <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${R}_{\text {JFET}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and 2) compared to FP-TMOS, it achieves 80.52% lower turn-off loss (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${E}_{\text {off}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) and 46.57% lower turn-on loss (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${E}_{\text {on}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>).

title: Analytical Surface Potential-Based Compact Model for Vertical Cylindrical Independent Dual Gate a-InGaZnO FETs
authors: Yue Zhao, Fuxi Liao, Ke Hu, Jingrui Guo, Lihua Xu, Guanhua Yang, Lingfei Wang, Ling Li
abstract: This article presents a surface potential-based compact model for vertical cylindrical independent dual gate (V-CIDG) amorphous In-Ga-Zn-O field-effect transistor (V-CIDG a-IGZO FET), considering intrinsic structural asymmetries to meet an increased demand of monolithic 3-D (M3D) integration. Continuous analytical inner and outer surface potentials are derived in a cylindrical coordinate system under various inner-gate (IG) bias conditions, including depletion and accumulation operation modes, with self-adaptive algorithm selection based on physical behavior. The analytical solutions of surface potentials demonstrate excellent agreement with numerical results and ensure the model’s efficiency and convergence by avoiding complicated functional forms. Besides, the procedure is examined for capturing the geometric dependence of surface potentials, e.g., critical diameter (CD) and material thickness, indicating the awareness of intrinsic asymmetries. Furthermore, the complete model is developed and validated with experimental data by incorporating transport theories. Finally, this model is implemented in Verilog-A and successfully enables simulations of logic circuits and a multibit 2T0C DRAM cell, indicating the potential for future M3D circuit design applications.

title: Noncommunicative Output Regulation and Efficiency Maximization for Multiple-to-One WPT System With Unknown Receiver
authors: Junhui Yang, C. Q. Jiang, Xiaosheng Wang, Zhaozheng Zhu, Ben Zhang, Yijie Wang
abstract: The control and optimization of wireless power transfer (WPT) systems with multiple transmitters face substantial challenges in practical applications due to varying coupling network and load. This article discusses the efficiency optimization of a multiple-to-one WPT system with phase-shift modulation. Then, a novel online parameter identification method for multiple-to-one WPT systems based on the concept of voltage transient detection is proposed. By inserting a sensor inductor into the primary resonant tank and monitoring its voltage response to the rising and falling edges of the square voltage inputs, both mutual inductance and output voltage can be accurately identified without a communication link. The identification principle and sensitivity are analyzed to demonstrate robustness, and the extendibility to different primary compensation structures is discussed. Afterward, constant voltage output and efficiency optimization can be achieved via the identified results. Experiment results show an identification accuracy exceeding 97% and a combined identification and closed-loop control response time of approximately 2.2 ms. Moreover, the efficiency fluctuation is limited to within 1% over a wide range of misalignments, compared with over 15% without control.

title: BAG: Body-Aligned 3D Wearable Asset Generation_supp1-3665510.pdf
authors: Xiaoguang Han
abstract: While recent advancements have demonstrated remarkable progress in general 3D shape generation, the challenge of automatically generating wearable 3D assets remains largely unexplored. To address this gap, we present BAG — a Body aligned Asset Generation method that produces 3D wearable assets which can be automatically fitted onto given 3D human bodies. This is achieved by controlling the 3D generation process using human body shape and pose information. Specifically, we first construct a general single-image-to-consistent-multi-view diffusion model, and train it on the large-scale Objaverse dataset to ensure diversity and generalizability. We then train a body conditioned multi-view ControlNet to guide the generator toward producing body-aligned multi-view images. The control signal leverages multi-view 2D projections of the target human body, where pixel values represent the XYZ coordinates of the body surface in a canonical space. The resulting body-conditioned multi-view diffusion outputs body-aligned images, which are subsequently fed into a native 3D diffusion model to reconstruct the 3D shape of the asset. Finally, we recover the similarity trans formation using multi-view silhouette supervision and mitigate asset-body penetration using physics-based simulation, ensuring accurate asset fitting onto the target body. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing approaches in terms of prompt adherence, shape diversity, and shape quality.

title: Same Data, Different Audiences: Using Personas to Scope a Supercomputing Job Queue Visualization
authors: Connor Scully-Allison, Kevin Menear, Kristin Potter, Andrew McNutt, Katherine E. Isaacs, Dmitry Duplyakin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Domain-specific visualizations sometimes focus on narrow, albeit important, tasks for one group of users. This focus limits the utility of a visualization to other groups working with the same data. While tasks elicited from other groups can present a design pitfall if not disambiguated, they also present a design opportunity—namely, the development of visualizations that support multiple groups. This development choice presents a trade-off of broadening the scope but limiting support for the more narrow tasks of any one group, which in some cases can enhance the overall utility of the visualization. We investigate this scenario through a design study where we develop Guidepost, a notebook-embedded visualization of data that helps scientists assess compute wait times, machine learning researchers understand prediction accuracy, and system maintainers analyze usage trends. We adapt the use of personas for visualization design from existing literature in the HCI and design domains, applying them to categorize tasks based on their uniqueness across stakeholder personas. Under this model, tasks shared between all groups should be supported by interactive visualizations and tasks unique to each group can be deferred to scripting with notebook-embedded visualization design. We evaluate our visualization through real-world case studies and a task-focused evaluation with nine participants. We observe that together, Guidepost's visual encodings, interactions, and export capabilities support the tasks of our differing personas.

title: PhysiXDeform: Real-Time Vision-Guided Soft-Tissue Deformation Prediction With Physical Priors_supp1-3665063.mp4
authors: Jiyuan Wei
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue deformation from endoscopic video is critical for robot-assisted, image-guided interventions. However, it remains challenging due to occlusions, complex dynamics, and the absence of direct physical measurements. Existing vision-based approaches often impose rigid or simplified motion priors, limiting their generalisability and physical interpretability. In this paper, we introduce a vision-guided, physics-informed framework that predicts multi-step 3D deformation by integrating stereo disparity, optical flow, and tracked keypoints into a spatio-temporal graph. Motion features, including velocity, acceleration, and directional strain, are encoded as node and edge attributes and processed via a graph network. The model is trained end-to-end with self-supervised objectives promoting geometric alignment, temporal coherence, and motion consistency. Across synthetic and real surgical datasets, our method achieves up to 28.8% reduction in Chamfer Distance (CD) at short prediction horizons, and an average 43.9% reduction over extended-horizon forecasts. In cross-scene adaptation, our model achieves average CD reductions of 12.9% with light tuning and 12.2% with heavy tuning, where the latter shows slight overfitting but still outperforms mesh-based baselines and supports real-time operation.

title: Finite-blocklength Fluid Antenna Systems With Spatial Block-Correlation Channel Model
authors: Zhentian Zhang, Kai-Kit Wong, David Morales-Jimenez, Hao Jiang, Pablo Ramírez-Espinosa, Chan-Byoung Chae, Christos Masouros
abstract: Finite blocklength (FBL) effects are often overlooked in analyses based on outage probability, where the assumption of vanishing decoding error can lead to overly optimistic performance predictions. Although fluid antenna systems (FASs) have been shown to deliver substantial spatial diversity for various system designs, their behavior under FBL constraints has not been adequately studied. Leveraging the simplicity, tractability, and accuracy of the spatial block-correlation channel model for FAS, this work investigates the random coding performance limits of FBL-coded systems equipped with fluid antennas. We analytically characterize how FAS contributes to performance enhancement under the FBL assumption and validate the findings through numerical evaluations. Both analytical and simulation results reveal that FAS offers pronounced advantages over conventional systems employing multiple fixed antennas in FBL-coded communication scenarios.

title: Wind Power Forecasting for Independent System Operators: Modeling Approaches, Practical Applications, and Operational Challenges in the Brazilian Context
authors: Paulo Sérgio C. Nascimento, Lucas M. Pires Deotti, André Luís M. Marcato, William Cossich M. Farias
abstract: The increasing share of renewable sources in power systems has heightened operational complexity due to their inherent variability and intermittency. These characteristics challenge supply–demand forecasting, which must achieve high accuracy given the dependence on meteorological conditions and the non-dispatchable nature of renewable generation. In Brazil, where the energy matrix is strongly linked to natural resource availability, reliable forecasts are essential to ensure supply security and optimize system dispatch. Improved forecasting reduces reserve requirements and thermal plant activation, yielding both economic and environmental benefits. This study proposes an original methodological framework for short-term wind power forecasting at an hourly temporal resolution, with horizons of up to one month ahead, with emphasis on operational application by Independent System Operators (ISOs), particularly in Brazil. The framework considers the regulatory environment, international best practices, and sector-specific challenges. It employs a deterministic approach that integrates global numerical weather prediction models with historical wind farm data, enabling accurate representation of wind generation variability. The methodology is scalable and can be adopted by the Brazilian Independent System Operator (ISO) as well as other ISOs worldwide. The results demonstrate robust forecasting performance, achieving an average systematic error of approximately 4.5% for hourly forecasts one day ahead. For weekly aggregations, errors remain close to 3.4% in the first forecast week and gradually increase to 6.3% by the fifth week. These outcomes highlight the effectiveness of the proposed framework in supporting short-term operational planning and enhancing system reliability, efficiency, and sustainability in contexts with high penetration of wind power.

title: Low-Voltage Assisted SiC-Si Hybrid Bridge for High-Efficiency Hard-Switched Operation
authors: Xuhao Zhu, Wu Chen, Yubo Yuan
abstract: In this paper, a novel SiC–Si hybrid half-bridge topology is proposed, in which an auxiliary low-voltage (LV) half bridge is integrated at the midpoint of a conventional SiC MOSFET–Si IGBT direct-parallel configuration. The control strategy introduces a pre-switching low-voltage step to accelerate residual carrier recombination in the IGBT during turn-off and to softly turn off the Si fast recovery diode (FRD) before turn-on, thereby mitigating dominant loss mechanisms in conventional direct-parallel schemes. Experimental evaluation with a 600V/50A hybrid bridge test platform showed total-switching-loss reduction of 32% at 50A-load and 45% at 25A-load compared with traditional approaches. The auxiliary capacitor is charged at turn-off transition and discharged at turn-on transition, and charge balancing is achieved by pulse duration control, eliminating the need for an external power supply. The proposed scheme is suitable for inductive load with bidirectional current involving both hard turn-on and hard turn-off, and can also provide benefits in cases requiring only hard turn-on.

title: Reinforcing CBDC Integrity: A Novel Anti Money Laundering Solution by Integrating Blockchain, Machine Learning, and Taint Analysis
authors: Shamama Tul Amber, Huma Ghafoor, Pham Duy Thanh, Chih-Hsien Hsia
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: As the central bank digital currency (CBDC) is rapidly becoming operational, there are both opportunities for financial inclusion and efficiency, as well as problems of security threats and anti money laundering (AML), particularly due to concerns about user anonymity. In order to address the risks associated with anonymous transactions, this research proposes a multi-layered security framework for CBDC that makes use of smart contracts built on the Ethereum platform, taint analysis, and machine learning (ML) models. The solution makes use of programmable smart contracts to automate policy enforcement and transaction validation within the CBDC ecosystem. Taint analysis techniques are incorporated to track the movement of illicit funds and identify questionable transaction patterns across the blockchain network. This is further enhanced by ML models that are optimized to learn from transaction data in order to reliably identify anomalous or illicit actions before they occur. We have generated two synthetic datasets that include two case scenarios and trained six ML models to evaluate them comparatively. Of them, random forest had the highest level of accuracy, 91.11%, in the cross-border case, whereas the support vector machine had a accuracy of 93.12% in the case of real estate transactions. In addition, we conducted a performance comparison of five environments; traditional banking, CBDC with baseline blockchain, CBDC with blockchain, CBDC with ML, and CBDC with blockchain, taint analysis and ML. Weused different metrics to test the performance of our proposed scheme and found that our AML tracking algorithm took an average of 0.55 s inference time, which is faster than the underlying reference method. According to our results, the proposed combined framework ensures high-level protection that improved risk detection in digital currencies, with a significantly reduced risk of money laundering and related hazards when using CBDC systems.

title: Coordination for Dual-channel Remanufacturing Rupply Chains with Dual Reference Effects under Market Segmentation
authors: Jie Chen, Lili Dai, Weijuan Zhou, Jiawu Peng
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Consumer purchase decisions are influenced by reference price and quality, which are directly related to product pricing and demand. The study uses game theory models to analyze the effects of reference price and quality on the dual-channel remanufacturing supply chain involving the manufacturer and retailer. Under the framework of Stackelberg game, the centralized and decentralized models of traditional and dual-channel systems are discussed, and the revenue sharing (RS) and two-part tariff (TPT) contracts are designed. Market consumers are divided into new product consumers and remanufactured product consumers. The results show that: 1) Dual-channel system is more beneficial to the manufacturer under specific remanufacturing costs; 2) Reference price has a positive impact on supply chain members; 3) The reference quality may adversely affect the manufacturer’s profit; 4) The manufacturer may choose different coordination contracts according to different channels. This study sheds light on the rule of reference effects in dual-channel supply chain decision making, which provides some guidance for firms’ decision making and practices.

title: Load Pull Driven Insights for GaN on Si Technology Optimisation at FR3/FR2
authors: Rana ElKashlan, Daanish Smellie, Alfredo Sanchez Ramos, Babak Kazemi Esfeh, Aarti Rathi, Hao Yu, Sachin Yadav, AliReza Alian, Dominique Schreurs, Uthayasankaran Peralagu, Bertrand Parvais
abstract: We present a calibrated source- and load-pull (LP) methodology for stress-aware benchmarking of GaN-on-Si (MIS/MOS) HEMTs in FR3/FR2 power amplifier applications. A 13 GHz passive LP setup, validated against on-wafer standards, achieves ±0.4 dB output power accuracy and ≤20° phase error across the Smith chart. Power budgeting guided by pulsed-IV provides realistic P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf> estimates under device stress, avoiding the overestimation inherent to DC analysis. Harmonic tuning at 2f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> and 3f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> delivers ~6% efficiency enhancement, with I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf>–V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">g</inf> monitoring confirming the absence of V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> shift or current degradation. Gate leakage is shown to impose a hard ceiling on input drive, beyond which efficiency collapses and irreversible V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> shifts occur. While demonstrated on GaN-on-Si, the methodology, linking calibration fidelity, harmonic control, and stress-aware diagnostics, generalises to other GaN variants and emerging device platforms, offering a reproducible framework for fair and reliable benchmarking under large-signal operation.

title: Proactive Energy Management Through Demand-Side Forecasting: A Future Load Profile Nomination Approach
authors: Abdul Aziz G. Mabaning
abstract: The Future Load Profile Nomination (FLPN) framework is introduced as a novel approach to enhance power system load forecasting by enabling proactive participation from the demand side. As a specific application of the broader concept of Future Behavior Nomination (FBN) within power systems, FLPN addresses a key limitation of traditional forecasting methods, which depend primarily on historical and real-time data and often fail to anticipate deviations driven by future-oriented consumer behavior. FLPN empowers consumers to voluntarily nominate their anticipated electricity consumption in advance, effectively shifting the demand side from reactive to proactive. Mathematical models are developed at both the individual and system-aggregated levels, incorporating dynamic parameters such as participation rates, forecast blending, and time-varying accuracy. A simulation of a non-historical load anomaly validates the framework, demonstrating a significant reduction in forecast error even with imperfect user input. FLPN contributes to the broader objective of Proactive Energy Management (PEM) and directly supports the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) by promoting efficient grid operations that reduce reliance on carbon-intensive spinning reserves (SDG 13), increase the hosting capacity for renewables (SDG 7), and empower consumers for responsible consumption (SDG 12).

title: Real-Time Control of a Lab-Based Flexible Rotary Servo System Using Linear Matrix Inequalities
authors: Surya Narayan Santra, Mousumi Mukherjee
abstract: We consider the problem of designing a linear quadratic regulator (LQR) for a lab scale flexible link rotary servo system using linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). First, data from the open loop system is collected in real-time. In particular, data corresponding to the two measured outputs are recorded in response to an input. This input-output data is used for identifying a model of the system. The identified model is compared with the given model for correctness. Once verified, the identified model is used to synthesize a linear quadratic regulator by solving linear matrix inequalities. It is known that the weighting matrices play a crucial role in the LQR design. The effect of the choice of the weighting matrices in the LQR design is examined, and accordingly a suitable pair of weighting matrices are chosen for the design. Thus, a state-feedback controller, based on measured input-output data is obtained. The design is experimentally validated by implementing the controller in real-time.

title: An Improved Power Management Solutions for DC Microgrids Featuring Electric Vehicle Fast Charging Stations
authors: Sujith M, M. Ganesh Kumar, Shaik Rabbani Basha, S. Padma, KavinPrasath TS, Dhilip Kumar P
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) and the emergence of distributed renewable energy resources are driving the need for efficient power management solutions in DC microgrids. Conventional microgrid architectures often struggle with voltage instability, inefficient energy utilization, and high dependency on the central grid when subjected to the highly dynamic demand of EV fast-charging stations. This study presents a better power management system that incorporates renewable energy systems, hybrid energy storage system and sophisticated control systems to improve reliability and efficiency. The architecture uses the strategies of bidirectional DC/DC converters, model predictive control (MPC) and demand response to optimize real time power flow between distributed resources, storage and charging loads. The outcomes of the simulations indicate that the proposed system can provide an improvement in the voltage stability of 50.6, a reduction in charging time by 24.6, and an improvement of system efficiency to the tune of 4.4 % over traditional models. There was growth in the use of renewable energy by 14.5 and a decrease of 23.7 in grid dependency and an overall operational efficiency in fulfilling the dynamic load requirement of 96.2 %. The findings demonstrate that the system can support peak charging conditions without degrading performance. In this research paper, it can be concluded that the combination of hybrid storage and predictive optimization has allowed sustainable, resilient, and cost-effective EV fast-charging in DC microgrids. The framework offers a scaled route of future smart transportation ecosystems through minimized carbon emission, better grid resilience, and grid stability.

title: Indoor Motion Trajectory Prediction Based on CPO-LSTM-Self-Attention
authors: Yu Wang, Honbin Chang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: With the widespread use of mobile devices and the development of indoor positioning technology, predicting user movement trajectories within indoor settings have emerged as a research focus over the past few years. Although most prediction methods based on kinematic or statistical models demonstrate satisfactory performance in outdoor scenarios, their effectiveness is notably diminished in indoor settings. In response to this challenge, the paper presents a hybrid approach integrating crested porcupine optimization (CPO) and long short-term memory (LSTM), and self-attention mechanism. The process begins with the model optimizing the LSTM network’s hyperparameters through CPO, ensuring that the LSTM processes the input data with the optimal configuration. The LSTM network is then leveraged to extract temporal features from the input data, identifying dependencies across short and long timeframes. Subsequently, the self-attention mechanism is introduced, which adaptively assigns different weights to different time steps, enhancing the model’s focus on key time points and effectively capturing important information in the time series. Finally, the predicted results of the indoor trajectory are output through the fully connected layer. Comparative experiments and ablation studies are conducted on a real indoor dataset to evaluate the predictive performance of the model. The experimental results show that the prediction performance and evaluation indicators of the model are better than those of the benchmark model and other optimization algorithm combination models, which verifies that the combined model has good prediction performance and generalization ability and can be applied in practical scenarios.

title: A Method for High Power Microwave Array Antenna Pointing Calibration and Power Combining Based on Drone
authors: Xinhong Cui, Chenxiang An, Ning Zhou, Youyou Gui, Yanchao Shi
abstract: Distributed coherent synthesis of high-power microwaves (HPM) serves as an effective approach for achieving HPM power synthesis. To obtain high efficiency of power combining at multiple positions in space, a new method based on drone was verified to realize antenna electrical axis alignment, servo platform pointing calibration and phase compensation under high-power conditions. A set of HPM radiation field measurement system is loaded on a drone. The optical imaging of drone hovering at arbitrary spatial positions is used to calibrate the pointing of array antenna, the power accepted by the measurement system is used to compensate inter-element phase difference in the antenna array. Experimental results show that the average efficiency of power combining is not less than 97% at multiple spatial positions.

title: Frequency-Modulated Continuous Waves Generation Based on Space-Time-Coding Leaky-wave Antenna
authors: Zi Han Ma, Han Qing Yang, Rui Bi, Shao Nan Chen, Hui Dong Li, Jun Yan Dai, Qiang Cheng
abstract: A Space-time-coding leaky-wave antenna (STC-LWA) that can generate linear frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) in the millimeter-wave frequency band is proposed. By loading PIN diodes on the LWA leakage slots, the slot unit can switch between radiation and non-radiation states, thereby obtaining the 1-bit amplitude reconfigurable characteristic. To realize the harmonic generation, the 1-bit STC matrix is delivered to the PIN diodes of the LWA. A prototype of STC-LWA comprising 86 units was fabricated and measured. The proposed STC-LWA can effectively excite target harmonic frequencies at 27 GHz and steer their radiation beams by the unique STC matrixes. Finally, the STC matrix for generating FMCW is developed. And the experiment results verified that, with help of the manipulation of radiated waves across spatial and frequency domains, the proposed design can generate linear FMCW with controllable bandwidth.

title: SMV-Sketch: A Sketch for Simultaneous Detection of DDoS and Heavy Flows
authors: Jingfu Yan, Huachun Zhou
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: DDoS attacks and Heavy Flows have become significant threats in the Internet. However, most existing defence systems require detection software to centrally collect traffic and various detection models for analysis. This paper proposes the SMV-Sketch and conducts a theoretical analysis thereof. SMVSketch identifies attack types by detecting when the cardinality of connections to a target IP exceeds a threshold and when traffic data surpasses a threshold. Experimental results demonstrate that SMV-Sketch can simultaneously detect distributed denial-ofservice attacks and traffic-replication attacks. While maintaining over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> detection capability, its false positive rate is one order of magnitude lower than that of the baseline method.

title: Extrapolation of the Avalanche Frequency in Noise-Source Diodes from Conventional 130 nm SiGe HBT Test Structures
authors: Luca Menicucci Salamanca, Giacomo Schiavolini, Seyyid Dilek, Giulia Orecchini, Gunter Fischer, Federico Alimenti, Corrado Carta
abstract: This paper presents a methodology for the extrapolation of the noise diode characteristics with bipolar test structures. To empirically validate the proposed approach, three different avalanche noise diodes, each with different dimensions, were characterized. All the devices are fabricated in a 130 nm SiGe BiCMOS bipolar technology, featuring HBTs with f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</inf>/f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> of 350/450 GHz. By using the correction factor proposed in this paper on the retrieved avalanche frequency, good accordance between bipolar test structures and test structures designed specifically for noise generation were achieved. This demonstrates the viability of employing typical bipolar test structures to extrapolate the technology noise generation performances.

title: A Power-Efficient mm-Wave Divide-by-16 Frequency Divider in SiGe BiCMOS Technology
authors: Matthias Möck, Benedict Baschang, Ahmet Çağrı Ulusoy
abstract: We present the design and characterization of a power-efficient divide-by-16 frequency divider used as prescaler in a D-band radar system. The divider consists of two high-speed emitter-coupled logic (ECL) divide-by-2 stages with split-load for speed enhancement, as well as two static ECL divide-by-2 stages. All divider stages are optimized individually for low power and matched sensitivity. An analysis of the employed split-load, current-scaling, and layout optimization techniques is included in this paper. As proof of concept, the divider was fabricated in a 130-nm SiGe BiCMOS technology. Measurements demonstrate a locking range from 14-106 GHz. The divide-by-16 frequency divider achieves a self-oscillation frequency (SOF) of 86.9 GHz at a remarkably low power consumption of 90 mW including buffers. The first divide-by-2 stage dissipates only 25 mW.

title: COA-MLP: Training Neural Networks Using the Coyote Optimization Algorithm for Medical Data Classification
authors: Maher Talal Al-Asaady, Teh Noranis Mohd Aris, Nurfadhlina Mohd Sharef, Hazlina Hamdan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Interdisciplinary Computer Science and Engineering (ICICSE)
abstract: Artificial neural networks (ANNs) have been widely applied in complex domains such as medical data classification, where uncertainty and nonlinearity pose significant challenges. However, traditional gradient-based methods, such as backpropagation, have drawbacks, including early convergence, high dependence on initial parameters, and a leaning to quickly become stuck in local optima. To address these limitations, this study proposes COA-MLP, a novel hybrid model that employs the coyote optimization algorithm (COA) to optimize the weights and biases of multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural networks. COA is a population-based meta-heuristic inspired by the social behavior of coyotes, offering a balanced trade-off between exploration and exploitation. This research presents the first implementation of COA for MLP training. The proposed model is evaluated on five benchmark datasets from the UCI repository and compared against eight state-of-the-art meta-heuristic algorithms. Results demonstrate that COA-MLP achieved the highest classification accuracy on three out of five datasets in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. These outcomes confirm the superior generalization capability and optimization efficiency of the COAMLP model. The findings underscore the value of meta-heuristic approaches in enhancing ANN performance for medical informatics applications.

title: Customer-Centric Power Reliability Assessment of Selected Cebu Distribution Utilities via Real-Time Localized Intelligent Power Monitoring System
authors: Wilen Melsedec O. Narvios, Jayson C. Jueco, Rafran P. de Villa, Ferdinand F. Batayola, Gilbert M. Silagpo, Maria Gemel B. Palconit
abstract: There is restricted access to reliable data from distribution utilities due to privacy concerns, and inadequate infrastructure results in frequent outages and hinders analysis of power reliability issues in regional areas in the Philippines. The paper evaluated power distribution reliability by calculating the Customer Average Interruption Duration Index (CAIDI) using data from a real-time intelligent monitoring system across multiple sites served by local utilities. The intelligent monitoring system utilized an ETL model to collect and manage data via cloud infrastructure and integrate AI models to detect anomalies in the system. VECO and CEBECO I exceeded DOE CAIDI limits with values of 185 and 140 minutes, respectively, while CEBECO II, III, and MECO demonstrated strong reliability with zero interruptions in key areas. To address these gaps, the paper recommends deploying reclosers, advanced outage management systems, and integrating distributed energy resources to reduce outage durations by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 0} \boldsymbol{\backslash} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> and enhance grid resilience.

title: Compact n77/n79 Diplexer Using Dual BAW Filters and Glass IPD Based Matching Networks
authors: Daehee Park, Minsoo Park, Jongsu Ha, Dongsu Kim
abstract: This paper presents a compact diplexer for sub-6 GHz 5G applications, supporting both n77 (3.3–4.2 GHz) and n79 (4.4–5.0 GHz) bands. The diplexer incorporates high-performance bulk acoustic wave (BAW) filters based on AlSc30%N thin films, which offer enhanced electromechanical coupling and wide passband characteristics. Glass-based integrated passive device (IPD) technology is employed to implement impedance matching inductors with low loss and high integration. Two diplexer architectures—full-rejection and skirt-reuse—were investigated, with the latter selected to reduce circuit complexity and footprint. The device was fabricated using glass interposer processes and flip-chip bonding, resulting in excellent performance with low insertion loss, strong out-of-band attenuation, and high inter-band isolation. The proposed design demonstrates suitability for compact, high-density RF front-end modules in next-generation mobile platforms.

title: A Cost-Effective Prosthetic Hand Design through sEMG Feature Extraction and Grasp Security Model with Optimised Support Vector Machines
authors: W. Abitha Memala, D Venkaiah, Shaik Shaphiya, Khaled Tawfiq Al-Assaf, Bhukya Balakrishna, K. Srinivasan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: A mixed-actuation prosthetic hand system has been developed that integrates Surface electromyography (sEMG)-based gesture recognition with a real-time graspsecurity predictor for improved user feedback and control. So, we developed the CPHFGO model for a cost-effective prosthetic hand via sEMG features and optimised Support Vector Machine (SVM)-based grasp security. The prosthetic, made from a 3D scan of a human hand, includes a rotary thumb MCP and silicone-coated fingertips for enhanced grip, supplemented by lightweight 3D-printed components. It utilises three DC motors for intricate hand movements. Tactile sensing at the fingertips is achieved through normal and torque channels, as well as shear sensors, to provide real-time shear magnitude data. Multiple classifiers' outputs are combined by an inference mechanism through majority voting, whereas a support vector machine (SVM) regressor that considers, among other things, torque and shear sensor responses is used for security estimation. The metrics of the performance to measure accuracy, precision, and F1-score were put in comparison with the existing models such as BCIEH, MLULM, GMPRF, and the proposed CPHFGO model. The high error rate is less than that of the existing models, CPHFGO with 20 % error rate. After we perform the speed calculation, we get 0.61 ms which is relatively higher, F1-Score at 86 %, the validation accuracy from 95 % to 96 % and the linear SVM got 75 % accuracy that was increased by RBF kernel to 85 % accuracy.

title: Active Disturbance Rejection Control for Predictive Current Control Based on Self-Tuning Incremental Model
authors: Mingdi Wang, Haiyan Zhang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To enhance the robustness and transient performance under model parameter mismatch, this paper presents an improved strategy based on the predictive current control with a self-tuning incremental model (STIM-PCC). Specifically, an active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) system is incorporated into the speed loop to strengthen the anti-disturbance capability of the original strategy. In the presence of inductance mismatch, the current tracking performance can still satisfy the requirement of following the reference current without overshoot within 2 control cycles, thereby further improving the model's robustness. Additionally, the current ripple is reduced and the settling time is shortened, which leads to a significant improvement in transient performance. The effectiveness of the proposed scheme is validated through simulations.

title: Diffusion Model Driven Inverse Design of Microstrip Patch Antenna Enabling Extendable FOM Modeling
authors: Minje Kim, Euiho Shin, Hooyoung Kim, Taeyeong Yoon, Jungsuek Oh
abstract: This paper introduces Multi-Response-to-Patch (MR2P) diffusion models, the first framework that directly converts the diverse electromagnetic (EM) figure of merit (FOM) of an antenna (broadband reflection coefficients |S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf>|, frequency-wise X-polarized beam patterns, and frequency-wise Y-polarized beam patterns) into a 1-bit microstrip patch layout in a single generative pass without any thresholding. Trained and tested on 7.2 k datasets simulated by HFSS, MR2P achieves mean-absolute errors of 0.72 dB for |S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf>| and 1.15 dB / 6.53 dB for X/Y -polarized beams on generated layouts. Moreover, MR2P can be easily and seamlessly scaled to richer EM FOM—such as full 3-D beam patterns—without any change to the network topology.

title: Biomedical Radar Sensor for Non-Contact Simplified Pulmonary Function Testing
authors: Li Wen, Yijing Guo, Changzhan Gu
abstract: This study presents an optimized biomedical radar scheme for simplified pulmonary function assessment, featuring a highly sensitive system and respiratory feature processing methods. Through spirometric comparison, novel radar-derived parameters (ΔDisp1s/ΔDisp ratios and Disp.-Vel. loop morphology) were validated for detecting airway obstructions. Experimental results demonstrate strong agreement between radar-measured and reference values (Pearson’s r = 0.98, p<0.01). The radar system successfully identifies expiratory patterns in simulated normal, restrictive, and obstructive breathing conditions. This non-contact approach shows potential for decentralized respiratory screening applications.

title: VisuBench: A Flexible Web Platform for Script-Free Model Evaluation
authors: Ya Miao, Xu Guo, Hao Wang, Jianpeng Guo, Chengwu Yang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: This paper presents VisuBench, a flexible and deployable web-based platform for script-free model evaluation. Users can perform end-to-end machine learning experiments through a browser interface without submitting any custom code. The system integrates classical models (SVM, Random Forest) and deep learning models (RNN, CNN, Transformer) via scikit-learn and PyTorch, supporting both image and time-series data applications. By uploading datasets and configuring model parameters through interactive forms, users can initiate training and testing with simple clicks. Upon completion, the platform generates comprehensive performance reports, including multi-dimensional visualizations of training efficiency (e.g., resource utilization, execution time) and testing performance (e.g., accuracy, F1-score, model complexity), saved as PNG images for easy access and reporting. VisuBench requires no database or container technology—users launch the service by running a Python script, and the modular design allows developers to extend it with new models or data types. Applied in teaching and prototype validation, VisuBench demonstrates its effectiveness in enabling intuitive model comparison. The source code is openly shared to support customization and adoption.

title: Building Height Estimation and 3D Reconstruction Using Shadow Detection and Semantic Segmentation from Satellite Imagery
authors: Ruben D. EspejoJr, GyuJin Shim, Joongrock Kim
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Automatic building height estimation and 3D reconstruction plays crucial role in urban planning and disaster preparedness. Using remote sensing technology and segmentation algorithm can improve the traditional way of visualizing and crafting 3D buildings without manually obtaining data from the real-world scenario. Current techniques involve obtaining metadata from satellite imagery and obtaining community-based driven OpenStreetMap (OSM) data which are often missing or incomplete sources of data. The proposed method integrates deep learning-based semantic segmentation for building footprint extraction and shadow detection that will be used to measure geometric data including shadow length and sun angle estimation. This research aims to develop an automated pipeline that enables us to perform automatic 3D reconstruction of building model based on remote sensing data and segmentation algorithms.

title: Segment-Side Window-Based Aggregation for Local Disparity with Edge and Texture Preservation
authors: Ahmad Fauzan Kadmin, Rostam Affendi Hamzah, Nadzrie Mohamood, Ken Prameswari Caesarella Aryaputri, Karmarul Hawari Ghazali, Nabil Jazli
abstract: Accurate disparity map estimation is critical for computer vision applications such as 3D reconstruction, autonomous navigation, medical imaging, and immersive entertainment systems. Traditional local window-based methods often suffer from edge fattening and texture inconsistency, leading to inaccurate depth estimation. This paper proposes a Segment-Side Window-Based (SWB) algorithm that integrates segment-based cost aggregation to address these challenges. The SWB method combines Truncated Absolute Difference (TAD), Gradient Magnitude (GM), and Census Transform (CT) for robust matching cost computation, followed by Superpixel Linear Iterative Clustering (SLIC) segmentation and Side Window Filtering (SWF) for edgepreserving aggregation. The final stage involves postprocessing and disparity refinement to enhance the accuracy of the disparity map with left-right consistency checking (L-R Check) and median filter. Experimental results on the Middlebury dataset demonstrate that SWB achieves superior performance, reducing the average bad pixel error to 24.7 % (All) and 14.6 % (Nonocc), outperforming state-of-the-art methods like Bilateral Filter (BF), Guided Filter (GF), and Median Filter (MF).

title: Evaluation System and Application Research for Cost-Effective Measures to Enhance Power Supply Reliability
authors: Hongliang Chang, Shenli Lin, Yongli Liu, Zian Zhong, Zibin Yu, Jinming Hu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Enhancing power grid reliability requires substantial capital investment. How to maximize power supply reliability improvements within limited financial resources has become a critical issue in the field of reliability. This study constructs a comprehensive evaluation system integrating reliability benefits and economic costs across three dimensions: grid structure, technology, and management. Through case analysis, it provides theoretical foundations and practical references for prioritizing decisions on measures to enhance power grid reliability.

title: Electro-Magnetic Wave Scattering by a Dielectric Wedge
authors: Jung-Woong R A
abstract: An analytic solution for the electromagnetic field scattered by a dielectric wedge excited by a line source is obtained as an infinite sum of the symmetric and the anti-symmetric mode eigen-functions. Its eigenvalues may be shown to satisfy the same transcendental equations for static fields. Derived solution satisfies Helmholtz equations, the continuity of tangential electromagnetic fields at the boundaries and the static edge conditions.

title: A Study of Wireless Signal Connection Between Microstrip Lines with Open Ends
authors: Atsushi Oyama, Teruo Tobana, Kohei Akimoto
abstract: In recent years, with the realization of 5G communications, the amount of information that must be processed by electronic devices is expected to increase significantly, and devices that can operate in high-frequency bands are required. Since wired connections in high frequency have problems such as difficulty in matching, wireless signal connections are required. The purpose of this study is to investigate a wireless signal connection between two printed circuit boards in proximity using electromagnetic coupling between microstrip lines with an open end and a U-shaped ground slot. Numerical simulation using the Finite Difference Time Domain (FDTD) Method are used to determine the parameters that can achieve efficient transmission characteristics. We also confirm the validity of the simulation results by fabricating and measuring printed circuits and show the possibility of wireless signal connection between microstrip lines with open ends.

title: Modified Viterbi Algorithm for Religious Text: A Part-of-Speech Tagging for Waray-Waray
authors: Jeneffer A. Sabonsolin, Robert R. Roxas, Ace C. Lagman
abstract: Part-of-speech tagging (POS) is a vital process in natural language processing, enabling the identification of grammatical categories within sentences. This research emphasizes the lack of attention given to POS tagging for Asian languages, particularly Waray-waray. Limited studies on Waraywaray religious texts have hindered linguistic documentation and the deeper understanding of its grammar and vocabulary. To address this gap, the study introduces a POS tagging system for Waray-waray utilizing a Modified Viterbi Algorithm, which also incorporates a strategy for handling unfamiliar words. Evaluated on a corpus of 50,000 religious text datasets, the algorithm demonstrates outstanding performance-achieving an accuracy of 93%, precision of 90%, recall of 90.52%, and an F 1 score of 92%. These results underscore the algorithm's effectiveness in navigating linguistic challenges across specialized genres. Beyond technical contributions, the study promotes linguistic diversity and fosters inclusive language technologies, advancing the goals of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Specifically, it enhances language learning and literacy among Waray-waray speakers, supports inclusive education through computational tools for minority languages, and aligns with SDG 4 by providing foundational resources for mother-tongue instruction and educational content development. Additionally, it offers new insights into Waray-waray's grammatical structures, laying a robust groundwork for future linguistic and computational research. Beyond technical contributions, the study promotes linguistic diversity and fosters inclusive language technologies, advancing the goals of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Specifically, it enhances language learning and literacy among Waray-waray speakers, supports inclusive education through computational tools for minority languages, and aligns with SDG 4 by providing foundational resources for mother-tongue instruction and educational content development. Additionally, it offers new insights into Waray-waray's grammatical structures, laying a robust groundwork for future linguistic and computational research.

title: HGNN-NCF: A Hybrid Neural Framework for Child-Friendly TikTok Video Recommendation
authors: Lucky Harichandan, Sasmita Kumari Nayak, Satyabrata Lenka, Debasish Pradhan, Jayant Kumar Mishra, Rasmita Badatya
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Video recommendation system suggests video content to the user prefers. If the user is a child, recommending age-appropriate videos makes sense. We propose a novel deep learning method to recommend TikTok-style short videos that are child-safe. Our proposed hybrid model, HGNN-NCF, combines high-level visual features extracted with ResNet18 with a Neural Collaborative Filtering (NCF) architecture. Both visible semantics and latent user preferences are gathered by the system to provide safe and personalized recommendations. Standard metrics such as Recall, Precision, and NDCG are used to simulate user interactions and track performance to evaluate effectiveness with 0.6571, 0.7687, and 0.8696, Furthermore, the recommended method provides visual explanations and is scalable to larger video datasets. This paper presents a model for child-safe video recommendations based on TikTok videos. Experimental results show that while our model achieves strong recommendation quality, it preserves interpretability and guarantees content safety for children.

title: Frequency-Domain Equalization Detection Based on Orthogonal Time Sequence Multiplexing
authors: Ziqi Wang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: This paper introduces Orthogonal Time Sequence Multiplexing (OTSM), an innovative modulation scheme that integrates the Walsh-Hadamard Transform (WHT) with rowcolumn interleaving and incorporates zero-padding between data blocks. As a single-carrier architecture, OTSM achieves efficient information symbol multiplexing in the delay-sequence domain through a cascaded structure combining time division multiplexing and Walsh-Hadamard sequence multiplexing. By applying the WHT to convert symbols from the delay-sequence domain to the delay-time domain for transmission, the modulation and demodulation processes involve only simple addition and subtraction operations, without requiring any complex multiplication or division, owing to the properties of the Walsh-Hadamard matrix. Furthermore, a frequency-domain equalization algorithm is proposed and compared with the commonly used zero force algorithm. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed frequency-domain equalization algorithm achieves a higher performance gain.

title: Dragonfly Algorithm-Based Cooperative Spectrum Sensing for Enhanced Spectrum Hole Detection in Cognitive VANETs
authors: G D Vignesh, J D Wilson Arul Raj, M Silambarasan, A M Balamurugan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs) are systems that belong to dynamic and spectral-limited conditions, which require smart methods to detect vacant spectral bands, referred to as spectrum holes. Traditional spectrum sensing methods in cognitive radio-based VANETs have low detection and high false alarm rates, especially during high mobility and dynamic signal-tonoise ratios (SNR). To deal with these issues, this paper suggests a Cooperative Spectrum Sensing (DA-CSS) framework based on the Dragonfly Algorithm which intelligently adjusts sensing thresholds and fusion weights to enhance spectrum opportunities detection. The algorithm is implemented in a multidimensional space of sensing parameters by emulating the swarming motion of dragonflies as a way of global optimization. The suggested solution utilizes a hybrid signal detection technique that integrates energy and cyclostationary signals and allows mobile vehicles to make mutually beneficial decisions through a Roadside Unit (RSU) which will serve as a fusion center. Experiments with simulations indicate that DA-CSS can have a detection probability as high as 95.2 with a false alarm as low as 6.5 and an average improvement in throughput 23.4 times that of conventional CSS. Moreover, up to 2.5 ms reduction in sensing delay is provided and faster spectrum access decisions can be made in latency-sensitive vehicular networks. Such developments make DA-CSS an effective, scalable, and low-complexity platform to update the next-generation cognitive vehicular communication systems. The described framework has a potential to manage spectrum in real-time within a dense traffic environment, increasing the level of safety, infotainment, and autonomous functions.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Thermal Management in Electric Vehicle Battery Packs
authors: N. Manonmani, P. Suresh Kumar, Shailendra Kumar Bohidar, L. Karthick, M Pandikumar, JoshuvaArockia Dhanraj
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Thermal management of EVs is becoming increasingly important due to the increasing adoption of EVs; hence, batteries must be safely and longingly heated and cooled. The first part of this research is a comparative analysis of Embedded Heat Pipes and Loop Heat Pipes for effective battery cooling in cell, module and pack levels. To increase model reliability, preprocessing techniques like, thermal data normalization and removing of outlier as per sensor readings, were used to the model. The performance was assessed with key thermal features taken off-Heat flux, temperature gradients, material thermal conductivity and system level resistance. Adecision tree and random forest classifiers were used to predict the optimal thermal management configuration(EHP or LHP) using machine learning method based on the EV classification, power requirements and thermal load conditions. Exemplary results demonstrate the ability of EHPs to conduct efficient heat acquisition at the integration level and that LHPs are more suitable for conducting heat flow at the system level. These findings show a hybrid two phase cooling strategy that tremendously improves thermal reliability, lowers the risk of overheating and lengthens battery cycle life.

title: Securing IJTAG with Dynamic Priority Control and Path-Integrated Validation
authors: Hewei Cui, Ying Zhang, Jie Deng, Yuan Chen, Hai Yang, Donglai Zhou, Xin Chen
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: The reconfigurability of IEEE 1687 (IJTAG) enhances test flexibility but also exposes scan paths to security threats such as data sniffing, tampering, and unauthorized access. To mitigate these risks, this paper presents a two-tier secure IJTAG architecture that combines dynamic priority arbitration with a parallel CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check)-protected scan core. The arbitration module restricts scan participation to instruments with valid configuration bits and priority tokens, providing fine-grained access control. However, while effective against unauthorized access and path manipulation, it cannot detect data tampering. To address this, lightweight checksums are appended at scan-in and verified at scan-out to detect data modifications. Together, these mechanisms block a wider range of attacks and ensure end-to-end scan data integrity. Simulations show that the architecture effectively prevents attacks such as data sniffing and tampering, even when malicious instruments are embedded within the scan path. When implemented in 65 nm CMOS technology, the design incurs less than 35% area overhead, offering robust security with minimal impact on IJTAG compatibility and performance.

title: Adaptive Deep Learning-Based Intrusion Detection and Prevention System for Encrypted Network Traffic
authors: Shanthabhushan B M, Chidananda T, Arun Kumar S, Supriya H S, Ravi G H, Rakesh V S, Santhosh M, Bhavana P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: With the rise of encrypted communication protocols like TLS and HTTPS, established IDS solutions that rely on inspecting payloads are becoming less effective. This work introduces a deep learning-based security mechanism for detecting and blocking intrusions that relies only on flow-level metadata, allowing it to function effectively in encrypted environments. The model integrates a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a long short-term memory (LSTM) layer to capture both structural patterns and temporal dynamics within network traffic. One of its defining features is an adaptive module that updates the model in response to performance drops or noticeable shifts in traffic behavior. When evaluated on the CICIDS2018 dataset, the approach achieved 98.2% accuracy and 97.1 % F1-score on the test set. Although its performance aligns closely with that of other modern methods, what sets this system apart is its ability to adapt in real time to evolving traffic conditions, making it particularly effective in real-world scenarios where encrypted communications and data privacy are key concerns.

title: Pavement Crack Detection via Transformer and CNN-Based Semantic Segmentation
authors: Zheng Chen, Ao Deng, ZhenHu Zhang, GuiHong Guo, ZhiHao Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: To address the limitations of conventional pavement crack segmentation methods in terms of precision and completeness, this study proposes a semantic segmentation network named TCU-Net, which integrates Transformer and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures. The model employs FastViT, a Transformer-based backbone, to capture long-range contextual dependencies and extract high-dimensional global representations. In parallel, an EVC Block is incorporated to enhance local feature perception by explicitly modeling spatial details around crack edges. Furthermore, a CAFusion module is introduced to merge global and local features through a coordinate-attention mechanism, enabling adaptive feature weighting and improving fine-grained feature fusion. The study applies the Focal Dice Loss function to mitigate class imbalance and improve the delineation of object boundaries within segmentation results.Experiments conducted on the Shandong Highway Crack Dataset demonstrate that TCU-Net outperforms conventional architectures including U-Net and DeepLabV3+. The model achieves mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), mean Pixel Accuracy (mPA), and F1-score values of 77.28%, 85.97%, and 85.57%, respectively, highlighting its strong representational capacity and generalization ability for pavement crack detection. Overall, TCU-Net effectively combines the global awareness of Transformers with the local sensitivity of CNNs, providing a high-accuracy solution for crack segmentation and decision support in pavement maintenance.

title: AVR-ADF: An Adaptive Visual Retrieval-Augmented Diagnostic Framework for Confusable Skin Diseases
authors: Yuwei Chen, Haoxi Zhang, Edward Szczerbicki
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have demonstrated significant potential in medical diagnostics, yet their accuracy is severely constrained when diagnosing visually confusable skin diseases. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) offers a promising paradigm to address this issue without fine-tuning. However, applying this paradigm to fine-grained diagnostic tasks through the standard Visual RAG framework reveals two critical bottlenecks: poor retrieval quality from general-purpose models lacking domain specificity, and ineffective context presentation stemming from rigid context lengths and uncertainty over optimal prompt design. To overcome these challenges, we propose the Adaptive Visual Retrieval-Augmented Diagnostic Framework (AVR-ADF). The crux of our framework lies in a novel retriever fine-tuning strategy, which combines Supervised Contrastive (SupCon) learning with domain-specific data augmentation and is optimized using our proposed Clinical Confusion Rate (CCR) metric. This is complemented by SN-EA-k, a hyperparameter-free adaptive context selection algorithm that dynamically determines the optimal number of examples, alongside the finding that a simple In-Context Learning (ICL) prompt is more effective than complex Chain-of-Thought (CoT) counterparts for this task. Experiments on the public PAD dataset show that AVR-ADF substantially boosts the diagnostic accuracy of the baseline model from 53.75% to 83.75% for pigmented lesions and from 55.64% to 76.32% for keratotic lesions. The framework's superiority and generalizability are further validated against state-of-the-art specialized vision-language models, such as PanDerm, and on the public ISIC 2019 benchmark, confirming its effectiveness.

title: A 280-GHz Signal Source for FMCW Radar Systems Based on 28-nm CMOS Technology
authors: Myeongjae Kim, Jaewon Jang, Wooyong Keum, Giyeong Nam, Jae-Sung Rieh
abstract: In this work, a 280-GHz signal source for FMCW radar systems is developed based on a 28-nm CMOS technology. The proposed 280-GHz signal source consists of a 17.5-GHz voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO), a divide-by-4 frequency divider chain, and a × 16 amplifier-multiplier-chain (AMC). Combined with an external loop filter and frequency-control board, the 17.5-GHz VCO demonstrated a chirp range from 16.5 to 21.0 GHz with 27 mW of DC power dissipation, while the 280-GHz signal source achieved a chirp range from 266 to 321 GHz and a 3-dB bandwidth of 266 to 294 GHz with a DC power consumption of 152 mW.

title: Analysis of Ice Melting Characteristics and Ice Shape Recognition for Transmission Conductors Under Different Warming Pathways
authors: Keji Chen, Zidi Zhu, Mingfeng Huang, Wei Zhu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Ice accretion on transmission lines poses severe risks to power grid safety, especially during natural melting processes induced by temperature rises. This study conducted conductor deicing experiments under three distinct warming pathways: rapid rise, gradual rise, and gradual rise traversing a sub-zero transition zone. A multi-angle visual monitoring system was employed to capture the dynamic ice-melting process, while an enhanced Canny algorithm combined with image binarization was developed for real-time ice shape identification. Key time points—ice slide and ice shedding—were defined and analyzed. Results indicate that the temperature rise rate significantly influences the timing of ice sliding and shedding, with faster warming accelerating initial melting but slower warming leading to higher post-sliding melting rates. Ice thickness distribution and melting rates were quantitatively assessed, revealing that thicker ice layers melt faster.

title: Realistic AI Based Mental Health Detection and Analysis Model Using AR Agentic AI & Conv-BiLSTM Architecture
authors: Premanand Ghadekar, Ajinkya Matre, Piyush Pise, Harshada Sawai, Manoj Mule, Sanika Shedbale
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition and Interaction System is presented that blends deep-learning and Generative AI with an Augmented Reality avatar to foster truly empathetic, human-like conversations. By processing text, speech intonation, and facial micro-expressions in parallel, our pipeline achieves robust emotion detection across diverse contexts. We fine-tune transformer-based models on open-source emotion corpora (GoEmotions, EmpatheticDialogues) and leverage a custom "Counsel-Chat" dataset to enable continuous, personalized learning. The AR avatar then mirrors the user’s mood through nuanced gestures and tone, creating an immersive feedback loop that feels more engaging than traditional interfaces. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that our model achieves 94.8% accuracy, 93.5% precision, 92.7% recall, and a 93.1% F1-score, significantly outperforming baseline CNN, RNN, and standard LSTM approaches.

title: Switch-Based Complex Termination Impedance Reconfigurable Filters for RF Receiver Front-Ends
authors: Chengfei Yi, Shangsong Ye, Zhuoyuan Liu, Chao Yuan, Pei-Ling Chi, Tao Yang
abstract: In this article, a switch-based reconfigurable bandpass filter (BPF) capable of accommodating complex termination impedances (Z<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</inf> and Z<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">L</inf> ≠ 50 Ω) is proposed. By integrating the impedance matching network (IMN) and the tunable BPF into a single structure, the proposed BPF allows direct connection to a low-noise amplifier (LNA), eliminating the need for additional IMN. The filter employs multiple PIN-diode-switched capacitor banks to achieve independent tuning of both the termination impedance and the center frequency under high-power conditions. To validate the concept, a reconfigurable filter with complex termination impedance (50-to-(40+15j) Ω) along with an LNA without input IMN is manufactured and measured. The passband frequency of the BPF can be tuned from 100 MHz to 180 MHz (57.15%) with the insertion loss variation from 1.81 dB to 2.52 dB. When directly connected to the LNA, the system results in a gain of 28.5–30 dB and a noise figure (NF) consistently below 5 dB, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing the overall performance of the RF front-end.

title: Chromatic Intelligence in Complete Graphs Through Polynomial Decomposition and Stability Optimization
authors: Umadevi. G, Yamini. S, Sivakami Sundari. M, Senthil Kumar. K
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Graph coloring is a basic idea of graph theory, which consists of the process of assigning colors to the vertices in such a manner that there is no color overlap on the adjacent vertices. The chromatic properties of complete graphs are analysed through the development of mathematical models and equations to explain how color is allocated, redundant, and behaves about stability. The model makes use of the chromatic polynomial <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P(\text{kn}, \mathrm{k})$</tex>,the redundancy coefficient of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R \mathrm{c}(\mathrm{G})$</tex>, and the stability factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sigma \mathrm{c}(\mathrm{G})$</tex>. Python and MATLAB simulations were done on complete graphs with 5 to 500 vertices. The model that was proposed had a 100% chromatic quality, zero instability of color assignment, and a reduction of redundancy was 17.3% in the case of weighted optimization. The findings confirm the mathematical coherence of the framework proposed and prove the model to be efficient in analyzing large-scale colorability. It provides a good base to generalize chromatic modeling to the incomplete and dynamically evolving graphs.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Intrusion Detection in IoT Networks
authors: Manjot Kaur Sidhu, Pradeep Reddy Ch., Gaurav Gulati, Fareesa Firdouse, Shalini Agarwal
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has heightened cybersecurity threats, necessitating advanced intrusion detection systems (IDSs). Traditional IDSs struggle with the dynamic nature of IoT networks and novel attack vectors. This paper introduces a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework employing Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) for autonomous intrusion detection in IoT environments. Leveraging the EdgeIIoTset dataset, we model intrusion detection as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), enabling adaptive threat identification. Our approach achieves 98.7% accuracy, surpassing conventional machine learning methods by 5– 10% in precision and recall. Extensive experiments validate its effectiveness against diverse attacks, including DDoS and injection, with minimal computational over-head. This work enhances IoT security by providing a scalable, adaptive IDS, addressing critical gaps in real-time threat mitigation.

title: Object Detection for Intelligent Vehicles
authors: G. Sai Prakash, Rituparna Choudhury
abstract: Intelligent Vehicle System (IVS) is a very lucrative application of artificial intelligence or AI. These intelligent vehicles need to identify or classify objects present in a captured image. The detection latency is a very important factor for these high-speed applications. In realtime scenarios, this object classification or labeling latency should be minimal. In these applications, the accuracy of detection also plays a vital role. So, this paper proposes a hybrid algorithm to reduce detection latency while improving the accuracy of detection. The proposed approach uses a hybrid of feature selection, clustering, and classifiers to achieve the highest accuracy and lowest latency. The results show that the proposed method achieves better performance as compared to other algorithms. It can complete the classification in 2 msec while the detection latency of other deep learning or machine learning techniques is in the range of seconds. This algorithm also has the highest accuracy among all the existing classification models.

title: Biometric Parameter Selection Towards Human Identity Recognition Using Wi-Fi CSI Sensing
authors: Antoinette R. Anastacio, Joshua Jake M. Benitez, Ryan Carlo D.J. Enriquez, Miguel Albert P. Icuspit, Ken Wesley O. Lampa, Azel Monique O. Pangan, Josyl Mariela R. Reyes
abstract: Traditional human activity recognition (HAR) systems utilize vision and wearable sensors to sense and identify human movements. When applied for security and surveillance, these HAR systems can also be utilized for human identity recognition (HIR), where the sensing technologies authenticate users. Recently, Wi-Fi sensing using channel state information (CSI) has emerged as a promising alternative technology for HIR applications, wherein the users are typically identified by their gaits as the primary biometric parameter. As there are other possible biometric parameters, this study explores Wi-Fi CSI sensing in HIR where the subjects perform three physical (static) and two behavioral (dynamic) biometric parameters. A CSI dataset involving samples collected from six subjects in a controlled indoor environment was preprocessed using discrete wavelet transform (DWT) and principal component analysis (PCA). Different parameter-specific HIR models were trained and tested and the HIR model based on the ‘draw triangle’ behavioral parameter achieved the highest HIR accuracy of 98.61 %. Results show that the five investigated gestures are viable biometric parameters alternative to gait.

title: A Hybrid-Integrated Dual-Circularly Polarized Horn Antenna with Microstrip-to-Waveguide Transition for Ku-Band Receiver Applications
authors: Hao-Chun Chen, Tzung-Wern Chiou, Jian-Yu Li
abstract: A hybrid-integrated dual-circularly polarized horn antenna is proposed for Ku-band receiver applications. The horn antenna employs a planar microstrip-to-rectangular waveguide transition for integration with PCB circuitry, and utilizes a stepped septum embedded within the waveguide to realize circular polarization. Measured results exhibit good impedance matching from 10.3 to 11.7 GHz, with port isolation better than 17 dB across the entire band. The antenna achieves a 3-dB axial ratio bandwidth fully covering the target Ku-band and demonstrates a peak realized gain of 8.2 dBic. Owing to its high radiation efficiency and integration capability, the proposed design is suitable for use as a standalone element or as a unit cell in scalable beam-steerable array architectures.

title: Leveraging Artificial Intelligence for Real-Time Language Translation and Interpretation
authors: Virat Vasantrao Giri, Vishnu Vandana Devi V, Bhavani Sankar Telaprolu, Vijay Karthic R, Prashanthi Matam, Nisher Ahmed
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Real-time language translation and interpretation have been transformed by the quick development of artificial intelligence (AI), which has created previously unheard-of possibilities for smooth cross-cultural communication. Modern translation systems can now analyse and analyse spoken or written language with amazing speed and accuracy thanks to the use of potent AI models, such as machine learning and neural networks. In contrast to conventional techniques, these systems enable more nuanced and contextually relevant translations by using Natural Language Processing (NLP) to comprehend context, syntax, and semantics. Real-time translation systems are being incorporated more and more into industries including international business, education, healthcare, and travel. Examples of these techniques include wearable technology, AI-powered mobile apps, and speech recognition software. Additionally, even for low-resource languages, advances in multilingual modelling and DL have greatly enhanced translation quality. Despite significant progress, there are still issues to be resolved, such as managing colloquial language, cultural quirks, and protecting privacy and data security. This study examines the state of AI-driven translation and interpretation today, emphasising important tools, uses, and potential paths forward. It highlights the possibility of AI to remove language barriers and promote global connectedness in real-time communication contexts by analysing the strengths and weaknesses of these tools.

title: AI-Driven Multimodal Big Data Framework for Early Screening of Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorders
authors: Syed Azeem Inam, Muhammad Afan Arif, Sumaira Hussain, Inam Ullah
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: The global burden of bipolar and schizophrenia spectrum disorders demands innovative diagnostic tools, as traditional methods of the Mini-Mental State Examination overlook critical emotional biomarkers. This study introduces a multimodal AI system that enhances MMSE screenings by integrating real-time emotion recognition across facial expressions, ocular micro-expressions, vocal prosody, textual sentiment, and body language. Trained on specialized datasets of FER-2013, DIU Eye, RAVDESS, GoEmotions, and BOLD, the system employs cross-attention fusion and a 4-bit quantified phi-3-mini LLM with QLoRA adapters for efficient clinical inference. Results demonstrate 89% sensitivity for early dementia detection, an F1 score of 0.86 for emotion recognition, and 92% accuracy in identifying cognitive gaps, consequently reducing assessment time through emotion-adaptive questioning. The results are also validated against neurologist scoring, i.e., κ=0.91, which bridges cognitive and affective diagnostics, offering a scalable solution for resource-constrained settings.

title: A Design of Enhanced Dyna-Q Algorithm with Emotional Learning and Thread Mapping in Brain-Inspired Robot Navigation System
authors: C. Bhuvaneswari, K Navya Sree, Ola Khresat, Puchakayala Priyanka, M Ashok Babu, ATA Kishore Kumar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: An emotion-enhanced Dyna-Q approach with thread mapping techniques modeled on brain function, is presented the Emotion-Driven Dyna-Q for Brain-Inspired Robot Navigation (EDETBR) model. This model incorporates a 1D ring attractor network for spatial mapping and transitions from phase-model to rate-coded neuronal signals, allowing reward signals to inform adaptive decisions and target-specific actions.
