The framework includes a Brain Emotional Learning (BEL) controller that augments decision processes and reward assessment in an adaptive manner, with rapid learning via the amygdala and emotional modulation of decisions through the orbitofrontal cortex. The EDETBR model performs multiple optimization functions with enhanced speed and accuracy in navigation tasks when compared to standard Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control algorithms. The result was improved energetic efficiency and accuracy with significantly reduced position decay and accumulated error, all of which make this hybrid model a meaningful advance in neurobiologically based and inspired autonomous systems.

title: Torque Ripple Reduction in IPMSM Based on Non-Uniform Air Gap Design
authors: Jiaxing Xing, Dong Li, Junci Cao, Feiao Wu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To achieve smoother torque output and further improve permanent magnet synchronous motor(PMSM) performance, this paper proposes a non-uniform air gap structure for torque ripple suppression. Specifically, the rotor profile is optimized to realize a sinusoidal air gap magnetic field distribution, which in turn suppresses torque ripple. Two non-uniform air gap configurations—direct circular arc cutting and segmented arc eccentricity—are comparatively analyzed. Based on the segmented arc eccentricity configuration, a parametric study of the eccentricity of rotor segmented arcs is carried out to clarify the effect of different eccentricities on the motor's electromagnetic performance. Subsequently, the optimal eccentric design is obtained by adjusting the eccentricity value and eccentric angle. The finite element method (FEM) is utilized to simulate and compare the air gap flux density, back electromotive force (Back-EMF), and torque ripple. Simulation results indicate that the torque ripple of the optimized motor is reduced by 72.2%. Finally, a prototype is fabricated, and experimental measurements are in good agreement with simulation data, confirming the correctness and feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Bi-directional Gain-Enhanced D-Band FMCW Radar with Transmitarray and Packaging-Conscious AoP Integration
authors: Dongyeon Seo, Kwangseok Choi, SeongEun Yoon, Jungsuek Oh
abstract: This paper presents the design, fabrication, and measurement of a compact D-band meta-radar system that integrates an Antenna-on-Package (AoP) transceiver module with a high-gain planar transmitarray. To address the high propagation loss inherent to D-band frequencies, a link budget analysis is conducted, targeting a 50-meter detection range for objects with moderate radar cross-section. The proposed AoP module is optimized through packaging design considerations, such as wire bonding height and antenna-chip alignment. A single-channel series patch antenna is designed to interface with a 40×40-element transmitarray, which enables directional beam shaping. Measurement results show that the antenna achieves a gain of 10.5 dB and 10.1 GHz bandwidth, while the transmitarray achieves 10.8 dB gain with a 5.5° beamwidth. The integrated system successfully detects a target at 35.4 meters, verifying the feasibility of the proposed approach for high-resolution, long-range D-band radar applications.

title: Study on temperature uniformity of lithium battery based on gradient porous metal composite phase change material
authors: Yinxiang Wu, Wenhao Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the issue of temperature non-uniformity in lithium-ion batteries under high-rate discharge conditions (5C and 7C), this study proposes and investigates a composite cooling strategy based on gradient porous metal foam combined with phase change material (PCM) to enhance both temperature uniformity and thermal stability of the battery system. The results demonstrate that, compared to pure PCM, the gradient porous metal foam-supported composite PCM not only reduces the maximum temperature difference but also shortens the phase change duration, thereby enabling a faster thermal response. Specifically, under 5C and 7C discharge rates, the reverse gradient design (with a gradient index of n = 2) reduces the maximum temperature difference by an average of 36.1% and 52.9%, respectively, compared to the pure PCM cooling scheme, indicating its strong capability to suppress temperature differences and significantly improve temperature uniformity under high-rate discharge conditions. Further analysis reveals that the flow rate of the liquid cooling plate also plays a crucial role in the thermal management performance. An appropriate flow rate can minimize the maximum temperature difference while ensuring the latent heat absorption capacity of the PCM, thus achieving optimal temperature uniformity for the lithium-ion battery.

title: Frequency Aware Restormer for Impulse Noise Image Restoration
authors: Chaeyeon Lim, Changhoon Yim
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Image restoration is a crucial task in computer vision, and Transformer-based models like Restormer have demonstrated state-of-the-art performance, particularly in removing continuous noise such as Gaussian noise. Although their performance remains reasonably robust, Restormer are not fully optimized for non-continuous, high-frequency distortions such as impulse noise. This is attributed to their architectural characteristics, which focus on learning global context and are vulnerable to the extreme pixel value variance introduced by impulse noise. In this paper, we propose the Frequency Aware Restormer (FA-Restormer), a novel dualpath architecture designed to enhance robustness against impulse noise. While preserving the original Restormer’s spatial domain processing path, we introduce a parallel, memoryefficient frequency domain processing path that transforms the image into frequency domain to effectively filter noise patterns using a convolution block. The outputs from both paths are then intelligently integrated using an attention-based fusion module. Experimental results on standard denoising benchmarks (Set12, BSD68, Urban100) show that the proposed FA-Restormer consistently outperforms the baseline Restormer for impulse noise image restoration, validating the effectiveness of our hybrid spatial and frequency domain approach.

title: Change Point Detection based on Unsupervised Adversarial Autoencoders with Time-Frequency Domain Analysis
authors: Wenxin Hu, Caidan Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Change point detection is the task of specifying sudden changes in the distribution of bit timing data. Real-life timing data acquisition is susceptible to noise and other interference in the environment, resulting in a decrease in the detection accuracy of the change-point detection algorithm. If the original timing data is smoothed and filtered, it is easy to lose effective data features. In addition, algorithms that only model the time domain information of the timing data also have a certain impact on the detection accuracy of change points due to the lack of effective information that can be extracted. To alleviate these problems, this paper proposes a change-point detection algorithm based on unsupervised adversarial autoencoders with time-frequency analysis. A time-frequency analysis framework is introduced based on dual autoencoders, which combines time and frequency domain features to extract potential feature representations of the original timing data, and information such as potential periodicity and frequency components of the data can be obtained while enriching the data features. Unsupervised adversarial training is then utilized to improve the robustness of the model against interference, such as noise in the real environment, and reduce the false alarm rate. Experimental results show that the algorithm achieves excellent detection accuracy on the public datasets USC-HAD and HASC.

title: Vision-Based Detection and Fuzzy-PID Control for Autonomous Floating Waste Collection
authors: Jyh-Cheng Yu, Chih-Chia Chang, Yi-Cheng Lin
abstract: Floating waste in lakes and harbors poses serious threats to aquatic ecosystems and local economies, while conventional manual cleaning remains inefficient and labor-intensive. This study develops an unmanned surface vehicle (USV) that integrates vision-based detection, a fuzzy logic-based PID controller, and multi-sensor fusion to enhance autonomous waste collection in calm waters. A prototype vessel was designed and tested in an indoor pool environment, where ultra-wideband (UWB) localization was used to emulate GPS positioning, a YOLO-based model performed real-time waste recognition, and landmark detection for docking assistance. The control system applied a Fuzzy-PID algorithm to regulate thrusters, using feedback from UWB, IMU, 2D LiDAR, and a depth camera for dynamic heading and speed adjustments. Experimental results demonstrate that the USV achieved stable autonomous navigation, obstacle avoidance, effective waste collection, and automatic docking. These findings validate the feasibility of the proposed approach and highlight its potential for practical applications in inland water waste management.

title: A 66-GHz/121-GHz Dual-Mode Distributed VCO in 250-nm InP HBT
authors: Satoshi Kawahara, Teruo Jyo, Tsutomu Takeya, Hitoshi Wakita, Munehiko Nagatani, Miwa Mutoh, Yuta Shiratori, Hiroyuki Takahashi
abstract: We propose a dual-mode distributed voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) that enables an octave frequency span by switching feedback loop paths and output power enhancement by a forward-propagation power synthesis technique for broad-bandwidth communications and permittivity imaging. The VCO was fabricated using in-house 250-nm indium phosphide (InP) heterojunction bipolar transistor (HBT) technology and achieved the nearly octave dual-mode frequency switching of 66 GHz/121 GHz and high output power of over 2 dBm.

title: Research on Fault Prediction of Electronic Current Transformers Based on the Slope Analysis Method of Linear Regression
authors: Kunpeng Wang, Xin Kong, Guohui Rao, Yupeng Yin, Xin Liu, Jie Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Aiming at the issue where existing station-side monitoring methods find it difficult to achieve early fault warning due to limited computational resources, this paper proposes a lightweight prediction method based on trend analysis of laser drive current. The method constructs a fixed-length sliding window mechanism to conduct linear regression analysis on the real-time acquired drive current sequence. It uses the slope value as a quantitative indicator of fault progression and establishes a multi-level early warning mechanism. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average early warning lead time of 20.23 minutes in 31 real fault cases, with the false alarm rate controlled at 0.51%, significantly outperforming traditional threshold-based alarm methods. Moreover, this method has low storage requirements, low computational complexity, and is easy to deploy in engineering, providing an effective technical solution for the predictive maintenance of electronic current transformers.

title: Performance Improvement Scheme for Distance Protection of Offshore Wind Power VSC-HVDC Grid-Connected Lines Based on Control-Protection Coordination
authors: Fei Kong, Xiao Ma, Jie Li, Chi Zhang, Yibo Sheng, Chen Yang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the advancement of flexible HVDC transmission technology, the characteristics of VSC-HVDC systems—such as low damping, rapid DC fault current rise, and high overcurrent peaks—have become increasingly prominent. While these systems promote the global utilization and development of renewable energy, they also impose higher demands on relay protection. This study focuses on offshore wind power systems integrated with VSC-HVDC grids. It investigates the performance of phase-comparison distance protection based on positive-sequence voltage polarization and proposes an MMC control-protection coordination strategy optimized via *q*-axis current injection. The proposed method significantly enhances the reliability of distance protection and its ability to withstand fault resistance. The effectiveness of this performance improvement is validated through simulations on the PSCAD/EMTDC platform, demonstrating its notable advantages.

title: A Dual-Pipeline UAV Framework for 2D AI-Based Pavement Distress Detection and 3D Quantification
authors: Yaohan Liu, Wei Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Timely identification of pavement distress is essential for maintaining road safety and serviceability. Existing ground-based inspection systems are restricted by limited viewpoints and coverage, making it difficult to achieve both semantic detection and quantitative measurement. This study establishes a Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-based dual-pipeline framework that integrates 2D defect detection using an improved KCA-YOLO network and 3D geometric reconstruction through close-range photogrammetry for metric quantification. The proposed method utilizes multi-angle UAV imagery under controlled flight conditions. The 2D detection achieves a mean Average Precision of 0.585, while the 3D reconstruction attains an RMS reprojection error of 1.02 px and a georeferencing RMSE of 0.015 m. Quantitative comparison with laboratory-cut specimens shows that the mean deviations in depth are within 9 mm. The results indicate that UAV-based photogrammetry can provide consistent millimetre-level accuracy for pavement deformation assessment, offering an efficient and scalable approach for automated road condition monitoring and maintenance planning.

title: From Code to Combat: Introducing the Role of AI in Cyber and Kinetic Warfare in 2024
authors: Adam Edward D'Arcy
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has become rapidly integral to modern warfare, transforming both cyber operations and conventional military tactics in 2024. This review surveys AI deployment in offensive and defensive roles across kinetic battlefields and digital domains, examines shifting geopolitical dynamics and ethical debates, evaluates security risks and vulnerabilities, and extrapolates emerging trends. AI-enabled targeting systems, autonomous drones, and cyber defense platforms saw practical use in disputes (Ukraine, Middle East), offering unprecedented speed and efficiency while introducing vulnerabilities including adversarial attacks, algorithmic bias, and eroded accountability. Major powers accelerated AI integration, driving a global arms race. Simultaneously, urgent ethical and legal questions arose about autonomous lethal decision-making. AI tools unveiled capabilities for strengthening defenses and enabling new offensive tactics like automated malware generation, enhancing the AI attacker-defender duel. Looking ahead, generative AI, multidomain hybrid warfare, and fully autonomous systems will transform warfare while policymakers grapple with ensuring meaningful human control and international law compliance.

title: A Dynamic Scheduling Optimization Method for PCB Workshops Based on LSTM-Differential Evolution Algorithm Fusion
authors: Chenlei Sun, Zhengchao Liu, Chunrong Pan, Junjie Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Addressing the hybrid flow shop scheduling problem (HFSP) of printed circuit boards, this paper presents an adaptive variable neighborhood differential evolution algorithm based on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM). The approach employs integer coding and plug-in greedy decoding strategies to simplify the problem's complexity; By incorporating a variable neighborhood search mechanism, it enhances the convergence speed and solution quality; LSTM is utilized to dynamically adjust mutation and crossover factors, it further balances the algorithm's global exploration and local exploitation capabilities. The experimental results demonstrate that Adaptive variable neighborhood search differential evolution (AVNSDE) algorithm outperforms the traditional variable neighborhood search differential evolution (VNSDE) algorithm in PCB scheduling, effectively reducing completion time, cost, and premature convergence. This solution offers both theoretical value and practical application for the multi-objective optimization of HFSP.

title: Optimizing Venture Capital Allocation with Deep Learning-Based Sentiment Analysis and Financial Data Fusion Techniques
authors: MohdShahid Ali, Piyush Mehta, S. Umamaheswari, Claudio Paya Santos, K S Srinivas, Saif Siddiqui
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research offers a new idea of optimizing the allocation of venture capital by a Hybrid Deep Learning Model which incorporates Sentiment Analysis and Financial Data Fusion Techniques. This approach enhances the accuracy of predictions and efficiency of decision-making when investing in venture capital by integrating the use of the sentiment analysis using LSTM with the use of traditional financial models. The advanced functionality of the AWS SageMaker has been utilized in the model to provide the means of processing real-time data, scalable training, and scalable deployment to ensure high performance in large-scale datasets. Moreover, the explainable AI methods bring transparency and interpretability, so that the predictions of the model can be trusted by the investor. The suggested system addresses the drawbacks of the conventional approaches, namely, the lack of data and overfitting, perfectly integrating the financial data and the sentiment-based insight. The findings prove that this hybrid model has the potential to improve the allocation of venture capital, which has provided a solid and data-driven solution to make informed investment decisions in moving markets.

title: InfraRedSeg: Multimodal Point Prompting and Multi-Round Refinement for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-Based Infrared Target Segmentation
authors: Yingbin Feng, Yukai Ding, Keshuai Wang, Le Yang, Binglu Wang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Infrared segmentation of small objects from UAV imagery is crucial for disaster response. However, the lack of pixel-level labels and the difficulty of accurately detecting object boundaries in thermal scenes limit the performance of traditional supervised methods. We present InfraRedSeg, a point-guided segmentation framework that combines a vision-language model with a zero-shot segmentation module. Qwen2.5-VL is used to generate semantic point prompts, which are passed to SAM2 for initial mask prediction. To improve point selection, we apply a reinforcement learning strategy (Group Relative Policy Optimization, GRPO) that iteratively refines Qwen’s behavior through multi-round feedback. We further introduce a dual-point prompting mechanism (positive + negative) to improve foreground-background discrimination and mask quality. To address annotation scarcity, we construct a large-scale pseudo-segmentation dataset from the WIT-UAS benchmark using our proposed framework. This pipeline enables high-quality mask generation from bounding-box annotations with minimal human intervention. Extensive experimentation with our dataset supports the superior performance of our method. Our results show that integrating multimodal prompting with reinforcement learning offers an effective solution for infrared segmentation under zero-shot or low-data conditions.

title: Wideband Beam Scanning Leaky Wave Antenna Using CRLH T-Shaped Unit Cells
authors: Mahalingam Durga Lakshmi, Nasimuddin, Arokiaswami Alphones
abstract: A wideband leaky-wave antenna (LWA) is designed using composite right/left-handed(CRLH) T-shaped slotted unit cells integrated with a substrate integrated waveguide (SIW). The antenna features a multilayered structure, with a parasitic rectangular patch layer sandwiched between two substrate layers. The proposed antenna consists of twenty-one T-shaped slotted CRLH unit cells, enabling continuous beam steering through frequency sweeping. The antenna beam can be steered across a range of angles such as -53° to 64°, within a frequency range of 5.48 GHz to 8.215 GHz and antenna design achieves a peak gain of 9.0 dBi.

title: A New Modeling Method for Universal Kriging with Qualitative and Quantitative Factors
authors: Zhijun Cheng, Dahao Chen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In terms of high dimensionality, mixed qualitative and quantitative factors and limited sample size, this paper proposes a penalized blind likelihood universal Kriging modeling approach to obtain more accurate model parameters and improve prediction accuracy. First, the trend and correlation functions are constructed to incorporate both qualitative and quantitative factors. Regularized terms on regression coefficients and correlation parameters are introduced as penalties to simultaneously screen significant qualitative and quantitative factors. Subsequently, an iterative algorithm is presented to solve for the maximum likelihood estimation of the model parameters. In this process, a cross-validated grid search algorithm is employed to compute the regularization parameters of the penalty function. While a nested optimization algorithm is used to determine the regression coefficients and correlation parameters of the Kriging model. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed model and algorithm is validated on five commonly used benchmark numerical functions. The results demonstrate that the proposed method addresses the problem of surrogate modeling with mixed qualitative and quantitative factors and significantly improves model accuracy compared to other types of Kriging models.

title: BitRelation: Exploring Bit-Level Dependencies in Neural Cryptanalysis
authors: Yue-Tian Goi, Shu-Min Leong, Raphaël C.-W. Phan, Ana Sălăgean, Shangqi Lai, Wei-Chuen Yau
abstract: This paper applies Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) to improve the interpretability of neural differential cryptanalysis on the SPECK cipher. We use Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) to analyse and visualise feature importance in neural distinguishers, giving signed contributions and absolute rankings. Signed contributions show whether, and how strongly, specific bit positions influence the model's decision, while absolute rankings reflect their importance regardless of sign. To study interactions beyond single bits, we introduce a Systematic Masking Approach to reveal relations among bits by testing if chosen combinations of masked bits alter classification accuracy. On Gohr's 8-round SPECK32/64 distinguisher, masking up to four-bit combinations shows that decisions involve multi-bit interactions rather than isolated single-bit effects. Although LIME highlights strong single-bit signals, masking reveals interaction patterns consistent with differential cryptanalysis. These findings clarify model behaviour in neural cryptanalysis and show XAI's value for exposing and visualising interaction structure in ciphertext features and decisions.

title: Investigation and Enhancement of Spatial Light Uniformity of Laser-Driven PiGF for High-Brightness Lighting
authors: Jiuzhou Zhao, Wei Cheng, Tao Lu, Hongjin Zhang, Bo Sun, Yang Peng
abstract: Phosphor-converted laser lighting is a new generation of high-brightness solid-state light source, and its spatial light uniformity is of crucial importance for actual applications. Herein, the spatial light distribution of a laser-driven phosphor-in-glass film (PiGF) with a transmissive type was systematically studied for the first time, and its spatial light uniformity was enhanced by integrating an aluminum reflective cup. The YAG:Ce PiGFs with various thicknesses were printed and sintered on sapphire substrates. The PiGF was tightly bonded on the sapphire and maintains a high quantum yield (QY) of 91.9%. With the increase in PiGF thickness, the luminous flux of laser-driven PiGFs initially increases and then decreases, while the correlated color temperature (CCT) gradually decreases. The spatial irradiance and CCT of common laser-driven PiGFs show a strong central peak and rapid radial attenuation. By integrating the aluminum reflective cup, the laser-driven PiGFs emit white laser light with uniform irradiance. The related CCT increases from 6164 K at 0° to 9493 K at 25°, corresponding to a balanced warm-to-cold white emission. The work provides valuable guidance for testing and optimizing of spatial light distribution in high-brightness laser-driven lighting.

title: Automated High-Precision Parameter Extraction for Thin-Film Transistors via a GRU-Based Neural Network
authors: Xiao Zhang, Yao Zhang, Lishi Lin, Zhongwu Wang, Tao Jing, Wenxing Huo, Xian Huang
abstract: Accurate and efficient extraction of thin-film transistor (TFT) parameters is critical for large-scale device characterization. However, manual methods are time-consuming, and existing machine learning approaches often generalize poorly across different TFT types. To address this, we propose a deep learning (DL) model that casts the TFT transfer curve as a time series for automated parameter extraction in both linear and saturation regimes. Trained on a diverse dataset encompassing indium gallium zinc oxide (IGZO) and both p- and n-type organic TFTs, the model demonstrates strong generalizability across these distinct semiconductor technologies. The model employs a recurrent sequence network to extract sequential features from the TFT transfer curve, followed by fully connected layers for parameter prediction. After benchmarking various architectures, a gated recurrent unit (GRU)-based network is selected as the optimal backbone. The model achieves superior performance on linear-regime TFTs, with average relative errors of 0.72% in threshold voltage, 6.81% in subthreshold swing (SS), and 4.27% in mobility; for saturation-regime TFTs, the corresponding errors are 1.38%, 10.74%, and 9.79%, respectively, outperforming other data-driven baselines. Furthermore, we integrate instrument control, device classification, and parameter extraction into a unified software interface to enable fully automated measurement. This work offers a scalable solution for industrial TFT array characterization, effectively bridging the gap between physics-based modeling and data-driven automation.

title: SCImputation: Mitigating Feature Confounding From a Structural Causal Perspective for Data Imputation_supp1-3665199.pdf
authors: Jiaoyun Yang
abstract: Missing data remain a critical challenge in data analysis, often leading to biased estimates and reduced reliability. Many imputation methods, operating under the assumption that similar instances share similar feature values, overlook the pivotal role of the feature associated with the missing value. Consequently, they apply uniform strategies to all missing values within an instance, often resulting in suboptimal neighbor sets and less accurate predictions. In this paper, we adopt a structural causal perspective to examine data imputation, revealing that once the target feature guides neighbor selection, it acts as a confounder and biases subsequent missing-value estimations. Building on this insight, we propose Structural Causal Imputation (SCImputation), a strategy that leverages both instance-level and feature-level information to refine neighbor selection, and applies a back-door adjustment formula that reweights local estimates with the global distribution, thereby mitigating the confounding introduced by the target feature. We integrate SCImputation with KNNimpute and LLSimpute, and evaluate the resulting variants on five datasets (NACC, three NCBI microarrays, and the Turkiye Student Evaluation) with ablation studies. In comparative evaluations against 12 baselines, SCImputation achieves 3.0%–4.6% gains in accuracy and 0.009–0.059 reductions in RMSE over the established approaches, and demonstrates competitive performance against leading deep learning baselines across diverse missingness mechanisms. These results suggest that SCImputation provides a causally grounded strategy for data imputation in both biomedical and general applications.

title: Improving the Accuracy of GNSS-IR-Based Soil Moisture Retrieval by Mitigating Phase Biases from Non-Environmental Factors
authors: Jianmin Lai, Changsheng Cai, Zhizhao Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The phase derived from the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is a critical parameter for soil moisture (SM) monitoring with the Global Navigation Satellite System Interferometric Reflectometry (GNSS-IR) technique. While most existing studies have focused on the impact of environmental factors on phase estimation, little attention has been paid to non-environmental phase biases. For the first time, this study provides a detailed analysis of two non-environmental phase bias sources: one arising from the nonlinear least squares (NLS) estimation method and the other from satellite revisit trajectory variations. To mitigate the two phase biases, we propose a reparameterized phase estimation (RPE) method and an adjacent-day SNR correlation-based phase bias correction (ASC-PBC) method. Their performance is evaluated using nearly one year of in situ observations from four GNSS stations with varying topography and vegetation cover. Experimental results demonstrate that the RPE method provides more stable and accurate phase estimates than the conventional NLS method, thereby enhancing SM retrieval accuracy. Specifically, the NLS method only yields 12 satellite trajectories with phase–SM correlation coefficients above 0.5, while the RPE method produces 34, a nearly twofold increase. Accordingly, the root mean square error (RMSE) of SM retrieved by each trajectory decreases from 0.068 cm3/cm3 to 0.058 cm3/cm3, with the mean absolute error (MAE) declining from 0.056 cm3/cm3 to 0.046 cm3/cm3. Meanwhile, the ASC-PBC method reduces the RMSE of SM retrieved from the trajectories affected by satellite revisit trajectory variations by 4.3%–10.9% and the MAE by 4.0%–13.2%. Overall, after mitigating the non-environmental phase biases, the average RMSE and MAE of SM retrieved from all trajectories at four stations decrease by 25.6% and 23.5%, respectively. This confirms that the performance of GNSS-IR-based SM retrieval can be significantly improved by mitigating non-environmental phase biases, even in a complex observation environment.

title: FSG-Net: Frequency-Spatial Synergistic Gated Network for High-Resolution Remote Sensing Change Detection
authors: Zhongxiang Xie, Shuangxi Miao, Yuhan Jiang, Zhewei Zhang, Jing Yao, Xuecao Li, Jianxi Huang, Pedram Ghamisi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Change detection from high-resolution remote sensing images lies as a cornerstone of Earth observation applications, yet its efficacy is often compromised by two critical challenges. First, false alarms are prevalent as models misinterpret radiometric variations from temporal shifts (e.g., illumination, season) as genuine changes. Second, a non-negligible semantic gap between deep abstract features and shallow detail-rich features tends to obstruct their effective fusion, culminating in poorly delineated boundaries. To step further in addressing these issues, we propose the Frequency-Spatial Synergistic Gated Network (FSG-Net), a novel paradigm that aims to systematically disentangle semantic changes from nuisance variations. Specifically, FSG-Net first operates in the frequency domain, where a Discrepancy-Aware Wavelet Interaction Module (DAWIM) adaptively mitigates pseudo-changes by discerningly processing different frequency components. Subsequently, the refined features are enhanced in the spatial domain by a Synergistic Temporal-Spatial Attention Module (STSAM), which amplifies the saliency of genuine change regions. To finally bridge the semantic gap, a Lightweight Gated Fusion Unit (LGFU) leverages high-level semantics to selectively gate and integrate crucial details from shallow layers. Comprehensive experiments on the CDD, GZ-CD, and LEVIR-CD benchmarks validate the superiority of FSG-Net, establishing a new state-of-the-art with F1-scores of 94.16%, 89.51%, and 91.27%, respectively. The code will be made available at https://github.com/zxXie-Air/FSG-Net after a possible publication.

title: Cascaded Metasurfaces with Polarization Multiplexing for Channel-Separated Terahertz Beam Steering_supp1-3665773.docx
authors: Jianquan Yao
abstract: Conventional adaptive dynamic beam steering schemes suffer from excessive complexity, large volume, and high power consumption. Meanwhile, dynamically tunable metasurfaces lack mature material systems optimized for high frequency terahertz (THz) operation, restricting their practical application. To solve these limitations, we propose a polarization multiplexed cascaded metasurface (PMCM) for adaptive THz beam steering. The joint phase distribution of this design strategy is realized via the linear superposition of the phase distributions of the two cascaded layers, which obviates the need for complex local phase adjustment using active components. One with rectangular pillars enable spin-decoupled phase modulation, allowing lens phases, gradient phases, and vortex phases to be embedded in orthogonal circular polarization (CP) channels; the other type is cylindrical dielectric pillars, which are used to maintain polarization-insensitive propagation phase control. By controlling the rotation angle between layers, not only can dynamically beam steering within each independent polarization channel be achieved, but the movement trajectory of the focused spot on the focal plane can also be further regulated. The experimental results obtained based on the probe-type near-field imaging system are in good agreement with the simulation results, with a measured maximum displacement difference of up to 4.23λ within the target rotation range and an average focal length of 8.8 mm. This low cost, multi-dimensional solution paves the way for compact integrated THz systems for high-precision applications such as real-time reconfigurable imaging.

title: A Calibration Method for Star Sensors Based on the Zernike Wavefront Aberration Model
authors: Tianyu Hu, Yan Ma, Jie Jiang, Lingfeng Tian, Yaoke Xue, Jianqiao Zhang, Yi Xu
abstract: Star sensor calibration is essential for obtaining accurate intrinsic parameter values and reconstructing star vectors, thereby ensuring high-precision attitude determination. Traditional calibration methods employ different mathematical models to correct intrinsic parameter errors. However, these methods rely on fitting the observations and are constrained by ambiguous physical interpretations, failing to satisfy the requirements of high-precision applications. To address this problem, a novel star sensor calibration method is proposed in this paper. Based on the wavefront properties, a new physical model is developed to characterize the imaging coordinates of star spots as affected by intrinsic parameters. Subsequently, a corresponding parameter model is derived using Zernike polynomials to relate wavefront aberrations to intrinsic parameter errors, providing a clear physical interpretation for their sources. In addition, a multi-order sequential optimization strategy is designed for parameter calibration to obtain better calibration results. Experimental results confirmed the effectiveness and adaptability of the proposed method for different star sensors. Compared with traditional calibration methods, the proposed method achieves better calibration accuracy with fewer parameters and lower parameter orders.

title: Soft Auxetic Fingertip (SAF) for Shape-Adaptive and Stable Grasping_supp3-3665077.mp4
authors: Peiyu Ma
abstract: This letter presents a soft auxetic fingertip (SAF) that decouples shape adaptability from payload ability by separating rigid support from compliant conformity. A stiff outer frame carries loads while auxetic array provides passive conformity and enlarges the contact area, distal tips improve grasping of flat and thin objects. The fingertip is fabricated by 3D printing conductive thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU). Based on its piezoresistive effect, the soft auxetic layer is used as a mechanical filter to enable contact and slip detection and to drive a grip-force compensation strategy. Under identical input torques, SAF achieves a 10.66%–151.72% payload improvement over the FinRay baseline across eight objects. Combined with slip detection based on resistance signal and grip-force compensation, it achieves a 89.29% success rate in pick-and-place tests on 28 tools and food items.

title: MEDS-Net: Meta-Evidential Dual-Stream Network for Multimodal Few-Shot Driver Fatigue Detection
authors: Yuankang Fu, Xinrong Gong, Kaixiang Yang, Song Sun, Tong Zhang, C. L. Philip Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Fatigued driving is a major societal risk factor in the road safety system, affecting the efficiency of the entire transportation network and public safety. Fatigue detection methods based on multimodal physiological signals can objectively reflect a driver’s neurocognitive state, offering higher monitoring reliability. However, existing methods face two main challenges: 1) the high cost of annotating high-quality physiological signals leads to challenges in learning with limited data; and 2) the signal-to-noise ratio of multimodal physiological signals is variable, leading to imbalances in the confidence in the decision between modalities. To address these issues, this article proposes the meta-evidential dual-stream network (MEDS-Net), which integrates a meta-learning framework with evidential deep learning to establish a solution for driver fatigue detection for the first time. Specifically, MEDS-Net employs a dual-stream evidence generation network to extract heterogeneous features from multimodal physiological signals and uses a Dirichlet distribution to quantify cognitive uncertainty for each modality. Additionally, MEDS-Net introduces a meta-learning framework to enhance the model’s ability to handle data scarcity through the design of task simulation mechanisms and a two-layer optimization strategy. Extensive experiments on the SEED-VIG dataset demonstrate that MEDS-Net outperforms current state-of-the-art methods in terms of effectiveness and generalizability. Furthermore, MEDS-Net can precisely quantify the importance of global features in explaining modal contributions and average activation patterns.

title: Multi-Stage Survivable Network Slicing with Load Balancing for LEO Mega-Constellation
authors: Ning Chen, Ailing Xiao, Sheng Wu, Zhe Ji, Haoge Jia, Linling Kuang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: In the low earth orbit (LEO) mega-constellation, dynamically reconstructing resources to enhance the on-orbit efficiency and flexibility of payloads remains a critical challenge. Network slicing (NS), a core concept in 5G communications, offers a promising solution by deploying end-to-end customized and logically isolated virtual networks over shared infrastructures. However, existing methods overlook the survivability of satellite nodes and the impact of load balancing of satellites and inter-satellite links (ISLs) on subsequent slicing processes. Therefore, this paper proposes a multi-stage survivable NS (MS-SNS) method based on load balancing for LEO mega-constellations. The method adopts a hybrid heuristic-reinforcement learning (RL) framework, decomposing the problem into multiple stages. First, a multi-constraint “load coefficient” indicator is proposed for constellation target area planning and selection using a greedy algorithm. Second, a soft actor-critic (SAC)-based algorithm is proposed for slice mapping within the selected target region. Finally, a survivable NS remapping algorithm is proposed, where a multi-constraint “remapping cost” indicator is proposed to guide the selection of remappable LEO satellite nodes, ensuring service continuity during node failures. Extensive simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of MS-SNS.

title: DiffLSTM-MTE: A Hybrid LSTM-Diffusion Framework for Virtual iEEG Reconstruction from MEG
authors: Xiangyu Xue, Liankun Ren, Hongyu Zhou, Anqi Dai, Huaqiang Zhang, Di Wang
abstract: Accurate non-invasive characterization of complex brain dynamics, especially aberrant network activity in epilepsy, is crucial yet challenging due to the invasiveness of iEEG and limitations of noninvasive MEG. We introduce DiffLSTM-MTE, a novel deep learning framework that reconstructs virtual iEEG (ViEEG) from MEG recordings. This framework synergistically integrates an LSTM for temporal modeling of MEG with a conditional Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM) for synthesizing realistic iEEG. Our physiologically-informed training objective incorporates losses for noise prediction, spectral fidelity, and Interictal Epileptiform Discharges (IEDs) preservation. Evaluated on data from five epilepsy patients, DiffLSTM-MTE demonstrates high temporal fidelity (mean Pearson R = 0.71 ± 0.08), preserves spectral characteristics (The mean PSD RMSE is < 0.071), reconstructs spatial coherence (mean correlation 0.92 ± 0.04), and accurately characterizes IEDs (76% ± 7% alignment). These results highlight DiffLSTM-MTE’s potential as a non-invasive tool to enhance epilepsy diagnostics and pre-surgical assessment by providing richer, patient-specific neurophysiological insights.

title: An Energy Compensation Method With Dropout Technique Based on Data-Driven Approach for SOE Estimation of Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Linhui Zhao, Kai Jia, Pengliang Qin
abstract: Accurate state of energy (SOE) estimation of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is critical for providing feedback on the remaining range of electric vehicles, which is one of the most concerning metrics for drivers. The power integration (PI) method is a simple approach for SOE estimation and serves as the foundation for other modeling techniques. The performance of the PI method, however, is limited by its cumulative error. To tackle this issue, this article proposes an SOE estimation method with energy compensation, and the method employs a data-driven approach to reduce the cumulative error of the PI method. The causes of the cumulative error are first analyzed, and a variable maximum energy metric is presented to improve the accuracy of the cumulative discharge energy calculation. The parameters characterizing the energy errors between the maximum energy and the reference energy are extracted via data-driven methods. To use data-driven parameters for reducing cumulative error, an energy-compensated SOE estimation method is proposed by designing the scaling mechanism that considers multiple discharge factors. In addition, a dropout technique is introduced into the compensation method to prevent overcorrection under unknown working conditions. The experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed method under complex working conditions, with satisfactory estimation results.

title: Efficient Heat Generation Systems Through Transformer and Recurrent Neural Forecasting Combined With Mixed-Integer Predictive Control
authors: Diyar Altinses, Marlon Löppenberg, Andreas Schwung
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: Accurate heat demand forecasting and control are critical for optimizing the operational efficiency of thermal energy systems, including power plants and district heating networks. This work presents a receding horizon control framework for optimizing heat production in district energy systems under real-world operational conditions. The proposed controller minimizes production costs while considering electricity market prices, which significantly affect the economic performance of heat generation units. The system coordinates multiple heterogeneous generation assets under mixed-integer programming constraints. To support the controller, we develop a forecasting framework that combines transformer and gated recurrent unit (GRU) architectures to improve prediction accuracy. This hybrid model utilizes multivariate input features, including ambient temperature and historical thermal output, to generate robust and probabilistic forecasts. The Transformer captures long-range dependencies in the data, while the GRU models temporal sequences and cyclical behavior. Experimental results on real-world data demonstrate that this method can reduce total operational costs by 16.3% and enhance resource efficiency in thermal energy production, providing a scalable solution for smart energy management.

title: A Coupled Oscillator Arrays for D-Band Scalable Phased Arrays
authors: Xiangao Meng, Yinian Feng, Jun Yuan, Bingli Dai, Bo Zhang, Cheng Wang
abstract: This paper presents a novel LO distribution array for D-Band scalable phased arrays. Each D-band phased array tile is configured with two 15.6 GHz VCOs, achieving coupled synchronization by means of wire bonding, while frequency locking is performed by an independent integer-N SSPLL. Fabricated in a 65-nm CMOS process, the phase noise of single-core and 5-core VCOs, as well as the SSPLL jitter, were measured respectively. 5-core VCO exhibits phase noise of -138.2 dBc/Hz at 10 MHz offset from the carrier. Within the integration range from 1 kHz to 100 MHz, the rms jitter reached 107.7 fs and 63.6 fs respectively, with a spur level of -70.3dBc.

title: A Reconfigurable Dual-Band Asymmetrical Doherty Power Amplifier Using PIN Diodes
authors: Gongxu He, Cuiping Yu, Yuanan Liu
abstract: A reconfigurable dual-band asymmetrical Doherty power amplifier (DPA) employing a reconfigurable input matching network (Re-IMN) composed of a T-shaped network and a shunt line controlled by switch in the carrier amplifier (CA) branch is proposed in this paper. By controlling the state of the PIN diode-based switch, the Re-IMN can achieve impedance matching in two separate frequency bands, thus enabling frequency reconfiguration. In addition, the second harmonic control technology is adopted to improve the performance. For validation, a reconfigurable asymmetrical DPA operates in 1.6–1.85 GHz and 2.4–2.7 GHz was designed and implemented using two GaN transistors with different powers. The measurement results demonstrate that the implemented DPA achieves drain efficiencies of 56.4%–71.4% at saturation level and 43.6%–58.9% at 9-dB output back-off (OBO) power level.

title: Assessing Tidal Energy Potential in the Visayas: Viability of the San Bernardino, San Juanico, and Cebu Straits
authors: Justin Kyle O. Ricafort, King Harold A. Recto
abstract: By laying the groundwork for sustainable tidal energy infrastructure, this study contributes to advancing the Philippines' renewable energy portfolio and supports the global transition to clean energy solutions. With the country's extensive coastline and rising energy demands, tidal energy presents a largely underutilized yet promising resource that can address both local and global energy challenges. Tidal energy is highly predictable, stable, and environmentally friendly, offering a reliable alternative to conventional energy sources like coal and natural gas, which are often subject to price volatility and environmental concerns. The study focuses on the Visayas region, a prime candidate for tidal energy development due to its dense population centers, major seaports, and high energy consumption. Integrating tidal energy into the national grid could reduce the Philippines' reliance on fossil fuels and lower carbon emissions. This research explores tidal stream turbines' potential, addressing challenges like maritime traffic and environmental considerations, while suggesting strategies for overcoming these obstacles. Ultimately, this study supports the transition to a cleaner, sustainable energy future.

title: Hardware Software Co-Design of 2D Modulation Schemes Otfs and Otsm on System-on-Chip
authors: Sai Kumar Dora, Rakesh Kumar Yadav, Himanshu B. Mishra, Amitav Panda
abstract: In this paper, we design low-complexity hardware architectures for the basic modules of the two-dimensional (2D) modulation scheme, orthogonal time sequency multiplexing (OTSM). OTSM scheme works in the delay-sequence domain by using the basic modules inverse Walsh-Hadamard transform (IWHT) and Walsh-Hadamard transform (WHT) at the transmitter and receiver, respectively. We next compare the performance of the proposed architectures of the abovementioned basic modules with that of its counterpart modules of the another 2D modulation technique Zak based orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS). Note that Zak-OTFS operates in the delay-Doppler domain, requiring the primary modules as 2D inverse Zak (IZak) and Zak transforms at the transmitter and receiver, respectively. This comprehensive comparative analysis is conducted on the computational complexity, timing performance, and power consumption of both schemes, evaluated on the ZCU706 Zynq SoC board. The results indicate that OTSM outperforms the Zak-OTFS in terms of area, power consumption, and latency. Zak-OTFS requires more programmable logic (PL) resources, utilizing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 8, 8 7 9}$</tex> LUTs and 26,124 FFs, while OTSM uses significantly fewer resources, with 5,440 LUTs and 6,216 FFs.

title: Educating Students for Sustainable Futures: Integrating AI and Environmental Awareness
authors: Luan Huynh Vu, Linh Nguyen Thi Yen, Nhu Lam Thi Quynh, Giang Tien Thi Nguyen, Hiep Dac Nguyen, Luan Trong Nguyen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: In the era of digital transformation, integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) into Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) is becoming increasingly crucial for shaping students’ sustainable mindsets and future orientations. This study proceeds to survey the impact of the three pillars of sustainable education (including economic, social, and environmental sustainability) on students' Sustainable Futures Orientation, while analyzing the moderating role of Artificial Intelligence Application (AIA). Using a quantitative survey design, data were collected from 251 university students in Can Tho, Vietnam, and analyzed using SPSS through Cronbach’s Alpha reliability tests, Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA), multiple linear regression, and moderation techniques. The results reveal that all three sustainability pillars positively and significantly affect Sustainable Futures, with Environmental and Social Sustainability showing the strongest influences. However, the moderating effect of AI is negative and statistically significant, suggesting that excessive or unstructured AI use may weaken the positive impact of sustainability education. The study extends the theoretical framework of Education for Sustainable Development by introducing AI as a moderating variable, highlighting the need for ethical and reflective AI integration in higher education. It provides practical implications for educators and policymakers to design curricula that balance technological efficiency with humanistic and ethical values, fostering interdisciplinary learning for sustainable development.

title: An End-to-End High-Resolution Model for TFT Chip Pattern Segmentation: Leveraging an Enhanced DeepLabV3+ Architecture
authors: Alin Hou, Junpeng Zhang, Hai Gong, Junxiu Chen, Jiayu Sun, Minjun Xu, Mengxue Yan, Wen Cao
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive study on the application and optimization of the DeepLabV3+ model for pixel-level semantic segmentation in ultra-high resolution Thin-Film Transistor (TFT) Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) images. The research addresses two critical challenges: the inability of conventional models to directly process ultra-high-resolution TFT images and the excessive memory and GPU resource consumption associated with such images. The goal is to demonstrate the feasibility and efficiency of the DeepLabV3+ model in accurately segmenting large-scale TFT images, thereby improving the automated optical inspection process in TFT manufacturing and ensuring product quality. The proposed model enables direct training and inference on ultra-high-resolution images, seamlessly integrating into the automated optical inspection (AOI) of TFT panels. This optimization significantly reduces inspection time, improves efficiency, and ultimately enhances production throughput.

title: HFS-VAE: A Hierarchical Feature-Splitting Variational Autoencoder for Interpretable and Robust Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Munnangi Suresh, Shaik Mohammad Thaheer, Derangula Durga Rao, Shaik Mannepalli Mastanvali, Panduri Bharathi, Vavilala Divya Raj, Sireesha Moturi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The complexity of modern networked environments has increased the risk of advanced cyber threats, making effective Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) essential. Deep learning has improved anomaly detection, but many models still lack robustness and interpretability. We propose the Hierarchical Feature-Splitting Variational Autoencoder (HFS-VAE), a novel architecture that partitions network features into semantic groups and encodes them through parallel branches, followed by classifier fusion. This design enhances transparency in the latent space and improves anomaly localization compared to conventional VAEs. Experiments on CICIDS2017 demonstrate an Average Precision of 0.8412 and an F1-score of 0.7463, while tests on NSL-KDD confirm adaptability with an AP of 0.9234 and an F1 of 0.7371. Robustness is validated through PCA-based latent visualizations, Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE), and boundary complexity analysis. Although recall remains lower than precision in some cases and evaluation is limited to CICIDS2017 and NSL-KDD, HFS-VAE provides a practical balance of interpretability and accuracy. Compared with prior approaches, it achieves competitive detection performance and superior anomaly separation, offering a structured and interpretable solution for enterprise-scale cybersecurity.

title: Cryptographically Secure Random Number Generator Utilizing Environmental Radiation
authors: Tee Hui Teo, Maoyang Xiang, Qianrui Lin, Yi Kai Zhang, Pan Ziyue, Ng Au Hern Wesley, Kaung Khant Htet, Chua Kevin Subong, Shum Hei Lam
abstract: This paper proposes a cost-effective Cryptographically Secure Random Number Generator (CSRNG) utilizing a Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) integrated with a Geiger counter. The front end of this system is designed to capture ambient radioactivity through a Geiger counter system that emits pulses in response to such environmental stimuli. To complement this setup, a neoTRNG-based ring oscillator RNG is incorporated to enhance the randomness of the generated numbers. By combining these elements, the CSRNG can achieve a high level of unpredictability crucial for cryptographic applications. Moving to the system's backend, utilizing the BLAKE2s hash function is pivotal in counteracting any potential biases introduced by the frontend components. This hashing function ensures that the output random numbers remain robust and secure, free from discernible patterns or vulnerabilities. In essence, the methodology outlined in this paper offers a comprehensive guide to conceptualizing and implementing a cost-effective CSRNG. The challenges inherent in generating cryptographically secure random numbers can be effectively navigated through a meticulous integration of hardware components and cryptographic techniques. This approach sheds light on the intricate processes in creating a reliable source of randomness, essential for safeguarding sensitive information in various digital systems.

title: Deep Learning-Based Resident Change Detection Using Electricity Metering Data
authors: Jongin Kim, Dayeon Lee, Dong Sik Kim, Beom Jin Chung, Young Mo Chung
abstract: As smart meter technology advances, the advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) enables real-time monitoring of electricity usage at 15-minute intervals. Since prior studies mainly focused on industrial infrastructures, anomaly detection in residential electricity usage remains underexplored. In this paper, we propose a gated recurrent unit (GRU)-based deep learning model to detect resident changes in residential households using the electricity metering data through AMI. Monthly consumption patterns and energy consumption are predicted using actual electric energy metering data collected from 846 apartment households in Seoul, Korea. To detect the resident changes, combined losses are computed by integrating the consumption pattern and consumption energy prediction errors. The experimental results show an accuracy of 82.55%, specificity of 100%, and recall of 65.11% when allowing a +-1-month error margin. The proposed deep leaning model demonstrates the practical feasibility of detecting resident changes in residential households and is expected to contribute to the development of smart grid services.

title: Domain Knowledge Leveraged Inductive Transfer Learning on Solving a Regression Task
authors: Pallabi Saikia
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are widely used for classification tasks due to their ability to learn complex features. However, their effectiveness is constrained in datascarce scenarios. Transfer learning (TL) has proven useful in handling such limitations by leveraging knowledge from related tasks. While TL is extensively applied in classification, its use in regression remains relatively unexplored. This paper presents a TL-based approach for regression when labeled data is limited. The study focuses on predicting petrophysical properties in reservoir characterization, a real-world regression problem. A ResNet model, pre-trained on a related classification task within the domain, is adapted to regression by transferring learned parameters. This imposes an inductive bias that enhances model generalization. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves regression performance compared to conventional approaches, particularly in lowdata conditions. The findings highlight the potential of TL in improving regression models when data availability is a major constraint.

title: 1D-CNN-Based Denoising of PPG Signals for Preserving Heart Rate Variability Information
authors: Swandip Singha, Aditta Chowdhury, Ray C.C. Cheung, Mehdi Hasan Chowdhury
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Photoplethysmogram (PPG) signals are highly susceptible to motion artifacts, baseline wander, and powerline interference, which severely degrade the accuracy of physiological and heart rate variability (HRV) analysis. Conventional filtering techniques such as Butterworth, Savitzky-Golay, Moving Average, and Wavelet filters often fail to remove complex noise components and preserve the fine morphological features of PPG waveforms. To address this limitation, this paper proposes an attentionenhanced one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1DCNN) for robust PPG signal denoising. Synthetic PPG data were generated using a MATLAB-based double Gaussian model that emulates systolic, diastolic, and dicrotic peaks, with controlled noise sources added to simulate real-world conditions. The proposed encoder-decoder CNN incorporates attention mechanisms and an HRV-preserving loss to maintain both temporal and spectral fidelity. The model outperforms classical filters, as demonstrated by performance evaluation on synthetic, public, and locally collected datasets. On synthetic data, it achieves an average SNR of 27.88 dB, RMSE of 0.012, PRD of $4.58 \%$, and correlation of 0.998, while maintaining high fidelity on real-world datasets with SNR up to 48.93 dB. Additionally, frequency-domain analysis revealed moderate retention in the powerline and high-frequency bands and strong preservation in the low-frequency band. The model’s capacity to suppress noise without altering cardiovascular dynamics was validated by HRV parameter analysis, which also confirmed that SDNN had minimal preservation errors. These findings validate the suggested CNN as a successful denoising framework for precise and trustworthy physiological monitoring based on PPG.

title: Research on Energy Efficient Edge Computing Strategy Based on Federated Reinforcement Learning
authors: Hao Chen, Xiaohong Zhao, Qiang Zhang, Tianyu Zhang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: In the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle(UAV) assisted edge computing system, in addition to ground equipment energy consumption, UAV flight energy consumption is also a part of the total energy consumption of the system, and flight energy consumption modeling needs to consider the moving direction and speed of UAV. Therefore, in order to achieve accurate modeling of drone flight energy consumption, discrete drone movement variables are difficult to apply. This article considers the movement variables of unmanned aerial vehicles as continuous variables (flight direction and speed), and designs trajectory planning and unloading strategies for unmanned aerial vehicles to optimize the overall energy efficiency of the system. This article models the weighted sum of total energy consumption of drones and equipment as the optimization objective. In order to achieve flexible and accurate movement control of drones and model their energy consumption, the movement variables are relaxed into continuous variables. This problem is a long-term stochastic optimization problem and belongs to mixed integer nonlinear programming. As the action space increases, centralized learning algorithms require an increase in network complexity, making it difficult for the algorithm to converge. Therefore, a distributed federated learning architecture is adopted for network training, and model parameter sharing is used to promote network convergence. After distributed training, the network model at each drone can make independent real-time decisions. Finally, the proposed algorithm is validated through simulation experiments.

title: Cybersecurity in AR/VR Environments: Threats, AI/ML Defenses, and Future Network Enhancements
authors: Akhil Patha, Mani Sathwik Reddy Elkapally, Abhiram Reddy Challaram, Chaitanya Chukka
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The world is evolving in a virtual environment, as we have seen that the rapid expansion of augmented reality and virtual reality has become so popular in many fields such as medical treatment, remote work, and even gaming and learning. As these devices make it very easy for us to use them, they also increase our threats as well. Hackers can try to access personal data, and they can control our virtual environment or connected devices. In this paper, we discuss the main security problems for the AR/VR platforms, their impacts, and mitigation techniques like using artificial intelligence and machine learning, which can help to detect and stop these attacks. Finally, the paper talks about how fast and strong networks can improve security, and the purpose of this paper is to understand the current threats and solutions for making the AR/VR platforms more secure in the future.

title: Preserving Identity in Portrait Video Generation via Facial Structure Injection
authors: Zhenchun Liao, Dawei Dai, Le Yang, Chengfang Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Although existing diffusion Transformer-based video generation models can synthesize high-quality dynamic portraits, they still face significant challenges in maintaining identity consistency across long sequences. We identify that the root cause lies in the model’s difficulty in decoupling stable identity features (such as facial structure) from transient appearance details (such as lighting and expressions) in reference images. To address this issue, we propose a lightweight Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) module based on Facial Structure Injection, which can be seamlessly integrated into pre-trained video generation models in a plug-and-play manner. Specifically, we first construct a portrait video-text dataset containing one million samples. Subsequently, we extract and render a "structure map" from the reference image that contains only the core facial topology, thereby eliminating the interference of appearance information. Finally, this structure map is utilized to guide the LoRA module, providing explicit and stable geometric priors to the base model at each step of the denoising process. Without any modifications to the large foundation model, our approach achieves significant improvements in identity preservation metrics by training only our compact LoRA module. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method enhances identity consistency while maintaining the original model’s robust video fidelity and text controllability, providing a practical, efficient, and scalable solution for addressing identity drift issues in controllable portrait generation.

title: FlowMamba-FSCIL: A Few-Shot Class-Incremental Learning Framework for Adaptive Encrypted Traffic Identification
authors: Yao Liu, Lanyi Zhang, Rui Hou, Weiyi Zhou, Mengyao Lu, Yubo Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: The rapid evolution of network applications necessitates that models for identifying encrypted traffic continuously adapt to new categories with limited labeled samples while mitigating the risk of catastrophic forgetting. To address this challenge, this paper introduces FlowMamba-FSCIL, an adaptive framework for encrypted traffic identification based on Few-Shot Class-Incremental Learning (FSCIL). The framework initially constructs dual-byte traffic graphs and grayscale images of traffic flows, utilizing Graph Neural Networks and Bi-LSTM to extract spatiotemporal identity features. Furthermore, a dual-branch selective state space model (Mamba) is designed to separately preserve knowledge from base classes and acquire knowledge from new classes. This is achieved through suppression and separation loss functions that effectively balance stability and plasticity. Experiments conducted on the CSTNET-TLS 1.3 datasets demonstrate that our method surpasses existing mainstream techniques in both average accuracy and resistance to forgetting, thereby providing an effective solution for continuous identification of encrypted traffic in dynamic network environments.

title: Skill-A-Thon Action Learning Framework
authors: Wanrak Srisung, Pallop Piriyasurawong, Prachyanun Nilsook
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: This study has two main objectives: to analyze the Skill-A-Thon Action Learning Framework and to synthesize the Skill-A-Thon Action Learning Framework. The analysis used the keyword "Digital Twin" to search the Scopus database for publications from 2020 to 2025, which yielded a total of 38,637 articles. Subsequently, related keywords such as action learning, engineer, and digital fabrication laboratory associated with learning were used for further searches. As a result, a total of 1,028 relevant articles were identified. The frequently used keywords numbered 18 and were grouped into three main categories: Skill-A-Thon Action Learning, Digital Fabrication Laboratory, and Industrial Engineering Competency. The synthesis was conducted using data from the Skill-A-Thon learning design, which comprises six key components: (1) problem, (2) action learning team, (3) action learning process, (4) actions taken, (5) continuous learning, and (6) action learning coach.

title: Research on Web-Based Image Classification Methods for Professional Domains
authors: Xinrui Xu, Xin Liang, Songyi Wang, Haolin Wen, Xing Luo, Zongjia Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: To address challenges in professional-domain image classification tasks, such as labeled data scarcity, limited computing resources, and high deployment thresholds, this paper proposes a lightweight image classification method based on the TensorFlow.js framework. By integrating data augmentation, transfer learning, and model compression techniques, the method establishes a complete technical workflow. This workflow includes intelligent image preprocessing, configurable convolutional neural network (CNN) model training, real-time classification inference, and cross-platform model migration. The core innovation lies in the implementation of end-to-end model training and deployment within a web browser environment, thereby effectively reducing the technical and resource thresholds for AI applications in professional domains. Application validation in typical scenarios — including geographic information recognition and preliminary medical image screening — demonstrates that the method not only ensures classification accuracy but also significantly enhances system convenience and scalability. It thus provides a feasible lightweight solution for the intelligent upgrading of professional domains.

title: Comparative PEEC Modeling of Magnetic Materials Under Different Equivalent Sources
authors: Qiwen Yan, Xiaoping Li, Xu Wang, Yin Sun, Jun Fan, Jingkun Mao
abstract: This paper presents a systematic review of modeling approaches for magnetic materials using the Partial Element Equivalent Circuit (PEEC) formulation, with particular emphasis on comparing equivalent physical models, system equations, and numerical characteristics. Based on the Coulombian-PEEC (C-PEEC) formulation, we conduct a comprehensive comparative analysis of the system matrix's convergence behavior across three discretized magnetic source representations: magnetization current density, magnetic flux density, and magnetic field. The comparison of numerical results shows that among these three discrete strategies, using magnetization current density as the equivalent source can significantly improve the condition number of the system matrix and enhance the numerical stability of the solution.

title: Causal Intervention via Visual–Linguistic Filtering for Multimodal Fake News Detection
authors: Siqi Hao, Rongxin Lin, Jun Zhang, Xianghan Wang, Shuohao Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Multimodal fake news detection has gained significant traction as deceptive content proliferates across diverse online platforms. Strategies that naively fuse visual and textual embeddings often fall prey to spurious correlations introduced by superficial image–text matching, resulting in erroneous predictions when semantics between modalities diverge. To address this, we introduce VLCF (Visual–Linguistic Causal Filtering), a novel framework that harnesses causal inference to deconfound each modality and enhance detection accuracy. VLCF comprises two bias correction modules: a visual bias correction module that disentangles confounding visual patterns through a combination of local patch sampling and global attention, and a textual bias correction module that mitigates contextual distortions using vocabulary calibration and cross-modal attention. During training, these modules implement front-door interventions to learn purified representations; at inference, the deconfounded visual and textual embeddings are integrated via a multimodal fusion layer for robust classification, effectively breaking the spurious link between surface image–text alignment and news veracity. We evaluate VLCF on two public benchmarks, demonstrating significant gains over state-of-the-art approaches in terms of accuracy, F1-score, and AUC. Ablation studies and robustness tests confirm the individual and joint impact of each bias correction component.

title: Screen-printed Via Integrated with 4D-printed Multimaterial for Microwave Circuit Applications
authors: Seyeon Park, Junghyeon Kim, Taehwan Jang, Hyeonji Song, Sungjoon Lim
abstract: 3D printing technology is being actively explored in RF electronics, with 4D printing offering significant potential for creating reconfigurable RF circuits through shape deformation. In these RF circuits, smart materials are used to modulate RF characteristics based on shape changes, enabling applications such as tunable antennas, filters, and metasurfaces. While the via process, a critical component for improving RF circuit performance, has been limited in 3D-printed substrates, this study investigates the RF characteristics of circuits with vias, fabricated on 4D-printed substrates using screen printing. Experimental results demonstrate that via characteristics are stable even after repeated shape deformations, suggesting that 4D printing provides a practical and reliable solution for fabricating RF electronics.

title: IoT-Enabled Logistics Optimization Framework for Real-Time Supply Chain Management
authors: Charu Bisaria, Venkata Prasanna Kumar Pathipati, Chaya Devi H B, P. Venkateswarlu, Akanksha Kathuria, Nidal Al Nidal Al Said
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper introduces IoT-Enabled Logistics Optimization Framework, which is aimed at optimizing the supply chain management in the context of modern supply chain management. The suggested system combines Adaptive Kalman filtering to perform sensor-fusion smoothing of sensor readings, ReliefF feature selection to select the most significant logistics parameters and a Graph Attention Network classifier, which is realized within the FedML framework to perform federated and privacy-preserving learning. The combination of these technologies, the framework allows optimizing the paths dynamically, preventive maintenance, and resource use with lower latency and communication costs. The results of the experiment show that there is a dramatic increase in accuracy, reliability, and scalability, with a prediction accuracy of more than 94 percent and a significant decrease in latency and energy use. The offered solution contains a powerful and smart infrastructure of supply chain optimization in real-time, which allows to deal with the main challenges of data heterogeneity, system scalability and safe distributed learning of IoT-powered logistic ecosystems.

title: Review on Implementation Strategies and Challenges of the Internet of Things (IoT)
authors: Nithin S. K, Prashant Kakkamari, Rayappa Shrinivas Mahale, S K Ramalinge Gowda
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Referred to as the Internet of Everything (IoE). People and objects may be able to connect with one another through a worldwide network known as the Internet of Things. It's an embedded data transfer network made up of physically linked devices. Projects incorporating fans, the lighting, and various other electrical products can be marketed through the Internet of Things. This article's main goal is to give a thorough introduction of the Internet of Things by identifying technologies, describing how they are being implemented, analyzing existing literature, and discussing IoT problems. Among the sectors utilizing the Internet of Things are the building, medical, healthcare, industrial, residential, communication, agricultural, and educational sectors. Connecting devices and enabling smart environments across a variety of industries, including healthcare, transportation sector, agriculture, and urban development, the Internet of Things (IoT) has become a game-changing technology. There are several obstacles in the way of the successful deployment and broad acceptance of IoT. This paper explores the critical aspects of IoT implementation, including network architecture, data management, security concerns, and the integration of legacy systems. The paper examines potential solutions and strategies to address these obstacles, ensuring the seamless deployment of IoT technologies in diverse applications. Through an in-depth analysis, this work seeks to offer a thorough comprehension of the intricacies connected to IoT implementation and offer insights into overcoming these barriers to achieve a fully connected, smart future.

title: A K-Band CMOS Power Amplifier with Transformer-Based Matching for High Gain and Low Distortion
authors: Min-Seok Kwon, Jong-Ryul Yang
abstract: A high-gain, low-distortion K-band power amplifier (PA) is designed using a 65-nm bulk CMOS process. The PA employs a two-stage differential architecture, combining a common-source first stage with a cascode second stage to simultaneously enhance gain, linearity, and stability. Transformer-based matching networks at the input, inter-stage, and output nodes enable broadband impedance matching and compact chip integration. Capacitive neutralization is applied to mitigate inter-stage parasitic coupling, improving gain linearity without additional power consumption. The fabricated PA occupies a chip area of 0.38 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and operates over the 21–25 GHz frequency band. Measured results show a peak gain of 25.6 dB, a saturated output power of 15.5 dBm, and a peak power-added efficiency (PAE) of 11%, These performance metrics demonstrate the suitability of the proposed design for fully integrated K-band transmitters in compact, low-cost millimeter-wave systems.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Spectrum Sensing for Cognitive Radio Networks: AHybrid CNN-GRU Approach
authors: M. Aarthirani, Noel Jeygar Robert. V
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Spectrum Sensing (SS)is a significant part of Cognitive Radio Networks (CRN), as it enablesthe detection of spectrum holes andensures reliable coexistence between the Primary Users (PUs) and Secondary Users (SUs). Conventional SSmethod often failslow Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) conditions, whereas existing hybrid Deep Learning (DL) model such a CNNLSTM, DLSenseNet, and CNN-RNN, show limited detection accuracy. Hence, this study attempts to develop a hybrid DL based SS model using Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN).
