The simulation results indicate a high detection probability of 96.3% and 96.2% with low false alarm rate of 0.45% and 0.21% for QPSK and 16-QAM, which is significantly better than the existing models. The proposed model guarantees a reliabledetection, effective spectrum utilization and the feasibility of practical implementation.

title: Coronary Artery Disease Diagnostics by Applying CNN and Segmentation Techniques
authors: S.Vanitha
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a condition that affects the coronary arteries. In this disease, the arteries become narrowed or blocked, reducing the blood supply to the heart. This can lead to serious complications such as heart attacks (myocardial infarctions), heart failure, and other cardiovascular issues. One of the major challenges in identifying CAD is that many patients may not exhibit explicit symptoms like chest pain. Instead, they may experience non-specific symptoms or silent ischemia, making early detection difficult. Moreover, diagnosing CAD using X-ray coronary angiography images poses additional challenges due to the complexity of the visual data.In this paper, we propose a solution using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for the diagnosis and prediction of region-based coronary artery disease. We also apply segmentation techniques and morphological operations to highlight the affected arteries in X-ray coronary angiography images. By utilizing CNNs, along with morphological operations such as dilation and segmentation techniques like thresholding, we aim to effectively process the angiographic image dataset. This approach enhances the accuracy of CAD detection and clearly highlights the affected regions in the images.

title: Cross-Temporal Transfer Learning for Online Question Answering via Dynamic Knowledge Distillation
authors: Sheng Zhang, Shanshan Liu, Fengcai Qiao, Dayong Shen, Zhaoyun Ding
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Online question answering (QA) systems typically handle streaming data that evolves over time. The distribution of this data may vary, resulting in cross-temporal transfer and a decline in performance of online neural networks. Therefore, online QA models are typically designed to be smaller in scale to ensure quick response time. However, they are required to have better out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization when dealing with changing streaming data. On the contrary, large language models exhibit strong OOD generalization, but their response speed may slow down when faced with high-concurrency requests. A dynamic knowledge distillation framework is proposed in this paper to enhance the OOD generalization of small models under cross-temporal transfer, which dynamically extracts knowledge from a large pre-trained language model to provide guidance for training a much smaller model that is better suited for online deployment and rapid response. To showcase the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing the OOD generalization of small models in cross-temporal transfer scenarios, we collect a medical QA dataset named cMed2022. The distribution of its test sets differs from the dataset used to train the models. Experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in OOD generalization of models through our method. Furthermore, by employing ensemble learning, the student models can match the teacher model on the extreme shifted dataset, with minimal increase in inference time.

title: Study on Adopting Machine Learning to Predict the Health Condition of the Inhibiting Film in DLP-Type High-Speed 3D Printing with Inhibiting Film to Reduce Separation Force
authors: Yih-Lin Cheng, Ching-Jung Hsieh
abstract: Digital Light Processing (DLP)-type 3D printing, a vat photopolymerization process, can be enhanced by using an inhibiting film to create a dead zone, reducing separation forces and enabling high-speed fabrication. However, prolonged operation with repeated exposures in localized regions leads to progressive film wear, which may compromise print quality. In this study, machine learning was applied to monitor and predict the health condition of the inhibiting film. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model was adopted due to its suitability for image-based analysis. Images of the inhibiting film were captured and corrected prior to training. Initial training on the full dataset yielded limited accuracy due to illumination effects and the overrepresentation of healthy-film images. To mitigate these issues, data selection strategies were explored, including varying image acquisition locations and excluding early-layer images. Model performance, evaluated by MAE, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{\mathrm{2}}$</tex>, and accuracy, improved notably when early-layer images (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<400$</tex> layers) were excluded. Moreover, data collected farther from the light source provided more stable predictions. These findings suggest that accuracy can be improved by focusing on data acquisition beyond 400 layers, prioritizing stable imaging regions, and optimizing illumination conditions or correction methods.

title: Computer Vision-Driven Inventory Inspection System for E-Commerce Quality Assurance
authors: Mahavir K. Beldar, Chetna Sinha, Anil Kumar Kukkamalla, SelvaMalar N, P. Bharath Kumar, Banitamani Mallik
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research reports an automated architecture for the inspection of inventory based on Vision Transformers (ViT) and EfficientNet-V2 model for quality control of e-commerce warehouses in real-time. To ensure the high precision of defect detection and product verification, the system combines YOLOv8 for defect detection and CLIP for multi-modal product verification, and got the detection performance of 96.3 %, identified defects of packaging damages, labeling errors and product inconsistencies. We build our network using a hybrid edge-cloud architecture and NVIDIA Triton Inference server, to ensure that we can help our network to 45 ms per item through the network. The pipeline utilizes a sophisticated algorithm known as Segment Anything Model (SAM) that accurately localized the defects and the concept of contrastive learning method to detect the abnormality using very little data for training. The system was put into place at three plants and it reduced the amount of time spent inspecting the products manually by 78 percent and eliminated 84 percent of shipping errors. Integration with existing WMS gives scalability with interpretability using GradCAM visualization techniques to give throughput of 10,000 objects per hour.

title: Improved Monarch Butterfly Algorithm-Optimized Particle Filter for Ultra-Wideband Positioning
authors: Hai Lin, Gang Ming, Biao Wang, Gang Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the challenges of Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) errors degrading positioning accuracy in Ultra-Wideband (UWB) systems, this paper proposes an improved Monarch Butterfly Algorithm optimized Particle Filter (IMBO-PF) for UWB positioning. Firstly, the migration rate is modified to enhance the algorithm's global exploration and local exploitation capabilities. Secondly, a nonlinear inertia weight is applied to improve the adjustment operator of the Monarch Butterfly Algorithm, preventing the algorithm from being trapped in local optima. Finally, a repulsion mechanism is adopted to disperse particles around the optimal particle, adjusting the particle distribution of the Particle Filter more accurately. Simulation and hardware experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves significant improvements in positioning accuracy compared to conventional Particle Filter (PF), Firefly Algorithm optimized Particle Filter (FA-PF), and standard Monarch Butterfly Optimization Particle Filter (MBO-PF), confirming its effectiveness in achieving precise positioning.

title: A D-band CMOS Low-Noise Amplifier Using Complementary Feedback Techniques
authors: Ha-Neul Lee, Jong-Ryul Yang
abstract: A 4-stage D-band CMOS low-noise amplifier (LNA) is presented that employs complementary feedback techniques for enhanced stability and performance. The proposed LNA adopts a single-ended structure in the first stage, which is converted to a differential topology via a transformer balun. In the differential second stages, both source degeneration and charge neutralization techniques are simultaneously applied to improve stability while maintaining low noise and sufficient gain. The combination of these feedback methods effectively mitigates potential oscillations and ensures robust operation at D-band frequencies. It is implemented in a 65-nm CMOS process with a compact core area of 0.15 × 0.45 mm2. EM-circuit co-simulation results, including layout parasitics, demonstrate a peak gain of 13.8 dB and a minimum noise figure of 7.1 dB at 140 GHz. The stability factor exceeds 8 across the entire D-band, verifying stable broadband operation.

title: Application of Combined GWO-HHO Techniques for Minimization of Energy Consumption Cost in Home Energy Management System
authors: Avni Bagga, Shreya Ranjan, Prabhakar Karthikeyan Shanmugam
abstract: An increase in global energy requirements, coupled with growing environmental concerns, has led to a heightened focus on efficient energy management systems, specifically in residential settings. Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS) have emerged as a promising solution to optimize energy consumption, reduce costs, and minimize environmental impact. These systems utilize advanced technologies and algorithms to monitor, control, and manage energy usage within households. Recent advancements in optimization techniques have introduced novel approaches to enhance the performance of HEMS. This paper explores the application of two powerful metaheuristic algorithms, the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) and the Harris Hawks Optimization (HHO) algorithm. The objective of this paper is to minimize the energy consumption cost and simultaneously satisfy the operational constraints of residential appliances, which include demand limits, minimum usage frequency, and energy requirements. To meet the constraints, penalty functions are inculcated. The GWO, inspired by the social hierarchy and hunting behavior of grey wolves, and the HHO, which mimics the cooperative hunting strategy of Harris hawks, have shown promising results in optimizing the energy consumption cost by scheduling the loads effectively.

title: Optimizing Microgrid Profits Through Automated P2P Energy Trading Using Blockchain and BESS
authors: Sajarupan Tharumaraja, Madura Prabhani Pitigala Liyanage, Akila Wijethunge, Janaka Ekanayake
abstract: The integration of Distributed Energy Resources (DERs), such as rooftop photovoltaic (PV) systems and Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), enables peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading in microgrids, enhancing grid flexibility and optimizing operational management. This study presents an automated, blockchain-enabled framework for very short-term (VST) P2P trading, tested using Sri Lanka's tariff data to harness the economic and operational potential of decentralized energy systems. The Intelligent Prosumer Energy Node (IPEN) facilitates autonomous energy trading through real-time monitoring, VST demand forecasting, recommendations from the OpenDSS Demand-Side Management (O-DSM), and userguided decisions. Similarly, the Intelligent Consumer Energy Node (ICEN) autonomously executes trading based on power demand monitoring, forecasting, and O-DSM guidance. The blockchain network, built on Hyperledger Fabric, secures and transparently manages transactions across five organizations, supported by multiple channels and smart contracts. Three trading models, Feed-in Tariff (FiT), P2P without storage, and P2P with BESS, were evaluated across prosumer-to-consumer ratios of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25:75,50:50$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$75:25$</tex>. Results show that automated P2P trading outperforms FiT, with BESS providing the highest economic gains. Prosumers achieved up to 35.1% higher profits, while consumers reduced costs by up to 15.2%, demonstrating the system's potential for scalable microgrid deployment.

title: The Impact of Different Starting Methods on The Starting Performance of Squirrel-cage Three-phase Asynchronous Motor
authors: Duanyue Gu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Squirrel-cage Three-phase Asynchronous Motors are widely used, and frequent starting is often required in industrial production. Therefore, it is necessary to select the most suitable starting method based on specific industrial scenarios. This paper employs an empirical research method. Two typical starting methods for squirrel-cage three-phase asynchronous motors—direct starting and autotransformer reduced-voltage starting—were selected for comparison. Using MATLAB simulation software, motor starting control systems for direct starting and autotransformer reduced-voltage starting were separately established. Through the simulation platform, the curve characteristics of starting current, starting torque, and rotational speed during the two starting processes (direct starting and autotransformer reduced-voltage starting) were obtained. By comparing the starting performance of direct starting and autotransformer reduced-voltage starting, it was concluded that the starting current and torque of the autotransformer reduced-voltage starting are both lower than those of direct starting, while the rotational speed rises more slowly. Due to their distinct characteristics, direct starting and autotransformer reduced-voltage starting are suited for different application scenarios: the former, with its high starting current, is only suitable for low-capacity, light-load starts; the latter is applicable for high-load, infrequent starting operations.

title: Next-Gen Distributed Power Framework with Intelligent Load Dynamics
authors: R. Mythili, M. Deepak, T.A Naveen, N. Sakthivel, A. Sam Prakash
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: This project addresses the critical challenge of maintaining stable power management in islanded microgrids powered by highly variable renewable sources like solar and wind. Conventional droop control methods often fail to ensure accurate power sharing and voltage stability under these dynamic conditions. To overcome this, we propose an intelligent hybrid microgrid integrated with a novel control strategy. The methodology employs an Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) to dynamically regulate the virtual impedance of inverter interfaces, thereby enhancing conventional droop control. This allows for communication-free, real-time coordination between solar photovoltaic and wind energy systems. Major findings from simulations confirm that the ANFIS-based controller delivers superior transient response, enhanced voltage stability, and more accurate reactive power sharing compared to conventional and fuzzy-based methods, while simultaneously ensuring MPPT and power quality. The significance of this study lies in validating a robust, intelligent control framework that is particularly suitable for off-grid and remote applications, providing a resilient and efficient solution for leveraging high-penetration renewable energy in dynamically varying environments.

title: Extracting Insights From Medical Text Corpus Using Knowledge Graphs and Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Gowri Sriya R V S, M. Farida Begam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: In the field of healthcare, it is essential to extract and integrate information efficiently from huge, intricate medical texts. Traditional techniques often fall short in managing the long-windedness, technical jargon and other variable formats associated with the medical documents which causes incomplete or erroneous data extraction. In this paper we explore how knowledge graphs and deep learning can be used for automated or enhanced knowledge extraction as well as entity and relation identification in medicine while also allowing the visualization of results. The system aims at precise linking of entities, advanced graph-based data analysis in addition to a user-friendly querying environment aimed at promoting knowledge discovery and decision-making processes. We assessed five approaches for extracting information from small PDF documents. Each method entails data cleansing, entity extraction and relation identification that results into a knowledge graph whose entities are nodes while the edges are relationships that connect those nodes together. Different techniques help visualize these networks clearly. Users may query the knowledge base using languages such as NetworkX and Cypher which allows them to pose natural language questions thereby improving health-related text mining through enhanced search and analysis.

title: Voice Controlled Event Scheduler Using Cyclone IV FPGA
authors: Parthipan V, Ishwarya Niranjana M, Yugesh G, Vishnu Karthick G, Tamizh Iniyan M, Thinakar Subramanian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Being somewhat natural and hands-free, voicecontrolled systems are gaining high importance in humancomputer interaction. This paper discusses the design and implementation of a voice-activated scheduling system on an Intel Cyclone-IV Field Programmable Gate Array hardware platform. Setting alarms or reminders by voice commands is converted into text by a custom-created Python speech-to-text framework and is sent to the FPGA board for further processing using serial communication over UART. The Cyclone-IV FPGA receives the times of setting, decodes them, stores them momentarily, and compares them continuously with its internal system clock; when a match occurs, it signals an alarm. Intuitive voice commands fused with deterministic parallel processing power of FPGA hardware gives rise to a dependable scheduling system capable of real-time operations. Simulation was done to verify the system, and then the implementation was carried out on a Cyclone-IV board to prove that the design is sound, accurate, and efficient during operation.

title: Research on a CNN-BLSTM-GRU Workload Prediction Model for Software Performance Testing
authors: Zixin Wang, Zhenyu Li, Shuo Wang, Yong Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: As software systems scale, accurate runtime workload prediction becomes vital. It helps optimize resource allocation and software performance. Traditional threshold-based or ensemble methods often lack accuracy and transferability. Single neural network or simple hybrid models show some effectiveness but have limited prediction accuracy. To address these challenges, we propose a hybrid model that combines a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Bi-directional Long Short-Term Memory (BLSTM), and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU). In our model, CNN extracts local features. BLSTM learns bidirectional dependencies. GRU further improves temporal feature learning for better accuracy. Evaluations on public Bit-brain and Alibaba datasets show our model outperforms several baselines. Compared to single models Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and GRU, and the CNN-LSTM hybrid, our approach reduces four key error metrics by 3.3% to 10.8% and improves the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score by 0.3%.

title: Enhanced Bad Data Detection in Power System State Estimation Using Modified CUSUM with Future Load Profile Nomination (FLPN)
authors: Franclein L. Francisco, Abdul Aziz G. Mabaning
abstract: Power system state estimation is highly sensitive to the quality of input data, particularly in distribution grids where consumer-driven load variability can introduce significant discrepancies between expected and actual power usage. Traditional residual-based detection methods, including classical cumulative sum (CUSUM), often misclassify these natural fluctuations as anomalies due to their reliance on static baselines and lack of normalization. This study proposes an enhanced anomaly detection framework that integrates Future Load Profile Nominations (FLPNs) into a modified two-sided CUSUM structure. The method evaluates normalized residuals relative to time-aware, user-declared load expectations, and incorporates drift compensation to suppress the accumulation of small benign deviations. Simulation results on the IEEE 14-bus system across 100 trials revealed that the Modified CUSUM with FLPN achieved up to 82% reduction in false alarm rate and up to 69% reduction in missed detection rate compared to traditional CUSUM (without FLPN) approach. This underscores the efficacy of integrating FLPNs and normalization in enhancing anomaly detection performance under dynamic consumer load behavior.

title: AI-Driven Predictive Analytics for Sustainable Restaurant Operations and Waste Minimization
authors: Padmavathy M, Dharmendra H, K. Thilagavathi, Burri Naresh, P. Praba Devi, Mohit Tiwari
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: There is mounting pressure in the restaurant business to minimize the waste of their operations and use of resources, and still be able to make a profit. Unreasonable forecasting, over-procurement, and poor management of resources are the key causes of environmental and financial waste. As a potential solution to the issue, it presents an AI-based Predictive Analytics Framework (AID-PAF), which combines both a Temporal-Fusion Neural Architecture (TFNA), which is an asset demand prediction framework, and a waste-conscious linear programming model used to solve an inventory and resources allocation problem. Real restaurant operational datasets were used to test the system in a hybrid AnyLogic-MATLAB simulator. Experimental findings show that the proposed framework achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \%, 18 \%, 15 \%$</tex>, and 21% reductions in the food waste, energy use, water use, and costs, respectively, and in addition enhanced the accuracy of the forecast, MAPE of 6.5%, the customer fill-rate 96.2%, and the Sustainability Score 78.7. The results prove that predictive analytics based on AI can greatly contribute to the sustainability, efficiency, and profitability of restaurant operations by making intelligent decisions with the assistance of data.

title: AI-Driven Predictive Analytics for Employee Sustainability in the Automotive Manufacturing Sector
authors: J. Niruba Rani, P Sibarose, K S Varshini, M Venkatesh, P Lavanya, T Ragul Anand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Legacy HR dashboards and delayed surveys fail to address retention risk and safety concerns as these arise, resulting in plant damage. The downsides of reactive, segregated systems include lagging signals, a lack of multimodal context, and the inability to foresee burnout or attrition. A framework integrates wearables, an MES/ERP, an HRIS, shop-floor text, and environmental sensors under strict governance; normalizes streams; and applies TCNs for physiology, LightGBM for structured data, RoBERTa for text, DeepSurv for attrition, and late fusion with calibrated, fair, privacy-preserving outputs into a decision engine for proactive interventions. The results enhanced stress AUROC to 0.89 (vs 0.80/0.71) and rare-event AUPRC to 0.54 (vs 0.36/0.23), while decreasing ECE to 0.03 and improving Macro-F1 to 0.78 across many plants. It increased early-warning quality (C-index = 0.82; 18-hour lead; fewer false alarms) without sacrificing latency (45 ms) or throughput (2200 events/s) and achieved the lowest fairness gap and calibration drift in real deployments.

title: RF-DNA Recognition Based on Domain Adversarial Neural Network in Wireless Channe
authors: Tianjia Li, Jiyu Wang, Zhou Hang, Zhenhao Zhu, Tao Ma, Jingwen Hua
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: RF-DNA, just like human fingerprints, is a unique signal feature with a certain degree of temporal stability inherent in each individual RF radiation source. It can serve as an identity marker for RF devices and boasts the advantage of being difficult to forge, thus holding broad application prospects in fields such as national defense security and civil communications. However, in practical applications, RF fingerprints are highly susceptible to the influence of factors like wireless fading channels, which leads to a decline in recognition accuracy. To address the aforementioned issue, this paper proposes an RF fingerprint recognition method based on a Domain Adversarial Neural Network (DANN) in wireless channels. This method adds a domain discriminator branch to the traditional IQ-GRU model. By constructing a DANN deep learning model, it directly extracts RF fingerprints from IQ signals and performs automatic 13features and time-domain features contained therein to improve recognition accuracy. Additionally, a gradient reversal layer is employed to confuse source domain samples and target domain samples, enabling the mapping of both types of samples to the same feature space. This approach can enhance the performance of RF fingerprint recognition in wireless fading channels without the need for prior knowledge of the signals. Experimental results demonstrate that this method can achieve an RF fingerprint recognition accuracy of 91.75% in wireless fading channels.

title: Design of a narrow-wall slotted waveguide array antenna with corporate feed in the 150 GHz band
authors: Ryosuke Sakurai, Jiro Hirokawa, Takashi Tomura, Minoru Inomata, Wataru Yamada
abstract: We design a hollow-waveguide slot array antenna for a channel sounder in 150GHz. The antenna is composed of the feeding part of cascaded junctions, and the radiating part of four waveguides. In simulations, the realized gain of the main polarization at 158 GHz is 24.6 dBi, and the 3-dB beamwidth in the E-plane is 4.6°. The reflection is less than -10 dB from 153.2 GHz to 161.1 GHz.

title: A Topology Optimization Technology for Distribution Networks Based on Graph Theory and Graph Search
authors: Guaiqiang Wang, Feng Zhao, Heyi Zhang, Shuo Zhang, Yana Zhu, Xuhong Qin
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the issues of insufficient self-healing capability, high computational complexity, and poor engineering applicability in traditional distribution network topology optimization, this paper proposes a modular topology optimization technology for distribution networks based on graph theory and graph search. The technology decomposes the optimization process into four core modules: spanning tree genetic optimization, BFS-based path combination, XML/SVG standardized modeling, and GIS spatial fusion, realizing full-process optimization from algorithm design to engineering visualization. Specifically, the spanning tree genetic optimization module uses Kruskal algorithm for valid tree screening and multi-objective genetic algorithm for optimization, maximizing load recovery while ensuring N-1 security; the BFS-based path combination module simplifies the topology by merging electrical zones and generates a limited reconstruction structure set to reduce the solution space; the XML/SVG modeling module extends core tags to uniformly describe equipment parameters, spanning tree status, and path combination information; the GIS fusion module achieves "geography-logic" integrated display through bidirectional data synchronization. Experiments on IEEE-33 node and 64-node actual distribution network systems show that compared with traditional methods (BPSO, heuristic algorithm), the proposed technology reduces active power loss by over 31.2%, increases node voltage by 7.73%, shortens solution time by more than 80%, and compresses the topology decision space from 215 to 26 feasible structures. It effectively balances optimization performance and engineering applicability, providing a reliable technical solution for the digital transformation of distribution networks in highdensity power supply areas.

title: An Improved Image Encryption and Fusion Framework with Multi-Task Loss Analysis for Embedded UAV Communication
authors: Muthuramya C, T Tirumala, Mohammad Musa Al-Momani, Chintala Muralikrishna, Swathi B, Maranan Ramya
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The multi-functional monitoring and synchronized operations using Micro Aerial Vehicles (MAVs) and a base station (BS), we introduced the proposed IIFMEU model, by enhancing UAV image encryption and fusion with multi-task loss optimization. It combines MAVs equipped with cameras and sensors for real-time area monitoring and facilitates communication between the MAVs and the BS through a hybrid network utilizing 5G and Wi-Fi. By integrating a multi-task learning framework that optimizes classification and segmentation tasks concurrently via a dynamic loss function. Hyperparameter optimization is achieved using the Penguin Search Optimization (PESO) algorithm, which seeks global optimal solutions. The fusion mechanism with time accuracy challenges in UAVs by implementing a Real Time Clock (RTC) and a Kalman filter-based protocol to correct kernel clock offsets and skew without reliance on external synchronization. The experimental analysis covered the accuracy, loss, precision, PSNR, and MSE, and the ROC curve was calculated.

title: Machine Learning-Based Blood Group Detection Using Fingerprints
authors: Allada Sankara Rao, Doppa Amrutha, Sirasapalli Prasanthi, Kona Pavan, KSNV Someswara Rao, Jyothi Angireddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Biometric identification has long relied on the distinctive patterns found in human fingerprints. There may be a relationship between blood types and dermatoglyphic features, according to recent research. This paper proposes a unique approach to blood type prediction from fingerprint patterns using state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms. Image pre processing, feature extraction, and classification are all combined in the pipeline using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Random Forests, and Support Vector Machines (SVM). With an accuracy of more than 90%, the CNN-based model performs better than traditional classifiers, according to experimental results. This quick, non-invasive technique has potential uses in emergency medical care, forensic analysis, and blood donor matching. Its usefulness is proven by its implementation in an easy-to-use web application.

title: Implementing Zero Trust Micro Segmentation Using Open Source Tools for Robust Security in Cloud Environments
authors: Olanrewaju Tope Onifade, James Egan
abstract: In the face of evolving cyber threats and the limitations of traditional perimeter-based security models like weak containment of insider threats, lateral movement and privileged escalation post breach, this research explores the implementation of a Zero Trust Microsegmentation architecture within a cloud-native environment. Leveraging Microsoft Azure as the hosting platform, the study integrates open-source tools-Tailscale, Open Policy Agent (OPA), alongside Azure Network Security Groups (NSGs)-to enforce identity-aware access control, encrypted peer-to-peer communication, and dynamic policy enforcement. The research follows a Design Science Research (DSR) methodology. Empirical results showed a substantial reduction in unauthorized lateral movement attempts and complete enforcement of identity-based access rules across all virtual machines. Compared with baseline NSG controls, the integrated Tailscale + OPA framework achieved measurable improvement in contextual access precision and policy adaptability. The study answers three research questions by confirming that (1) open-source tools can effectively implement Zero Trust microsegmentation, (2) they significantly reduce lateral movement risk, and (3) they provide stronger fine-grained control than traditional NSGs.

title: Research on the Improvement of the Signal Detection System for Small Basket Positioning
authors: Xinyao Liu, Fengna Tang, Haili Li, Yu Liu, Huigang Shen, Shuwan Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: The accurate seating of key components, such as the small basket, in a reactor is vital for nuclear safety at reprocessing plants. This study addresses operational failures in the bubbler detection system used to monitor the seating status. Focusing on the small basket, we detail technical improvements derived from theoretical and experimental analysis. A threefold approach was implemented: optimizing system parameters, optimizing the detection criteria, and installing an anti-crystallization device. The enhanced system ensures reliable detection and significantly improves the safety stability of the nuclear fuel dissolution process.

title: Optimized Sizing and Impact of BESS and PV on Grid Frequency Under Varying Droop Coefficients with Partial Load Shedding Mechanism
authors: Irfan Ahmed, Ahmed Zubair
abstract: Along with the increasing adoption of renewable energy sources, maintaining grid continuity has become a growing concern. As solar photovoltaic (PV) systems and battery storage systems (BESS) proliferate, their contribution toward increasing system resilience and offering frequency response is becoming critical. This research focuses on frequency regulation and assesses how BESS increases stability by modifying the droop coefficient in primary frequency control. We present a simulation-based analysis for different droop settings and construct a BESS sizing algorithm to mitigate a 0.5 Hz frequency dip and advocate a partial load-shedding approach with BESS aid. In addition, the integration of PV systems contributed to a significant reduction in the required size of the BESS, as the PV systems were able to directly supply a portion of the energy demand. The findings demonstrate that adaptive droop improves frequency response, optimal BESS size enhances energy efficiency, and load-shedding with BESS support reduces the burden of excessive load shedding to increase reliability and balance in the system.

title: Extraction of Wildfire Regions from UAV Imagery Using Boundary Priors and Advanced Semantics Derived from the Visual Foundation Model
authors: Shiyong Huang, Tianzeng Liang, Chengwen Lu, Zhonghua Tong, Zhou Zhang, Kejun Yao, Qi Li, Xiaoming Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Accurate extraction of wildfire regions is crucial for emergency response, disaster damage assessment, and ecological restoration. However, deep learning-based wildfire extraction typically depends on large quantities of training samples to achieve good performance. Existing methods face challenges in fully learning deep semantic features of parcels when training samples are limited or in complex scenarios. This leads to poor extraction results in scenarios with blurred fire boundaries, smoke obscurity, and abundant terrain features. To address this challenge, we propose a multi-task dual-branch network (DBNet) based on the visual foundation model Fast-SAM, capable of extracting precise wildfire boundaries from complex mountain imagery. DBNet utilizes Fast-SAM to extract rich deep semantic features of wildfires. These features are then used as inputs to the mask prediction branch and boundary prediction branch. We developed a Boundary Prior-Guided Module (BPM) to refine wildfire contours. We also developed a Multi-Scale Feature Enhancement Module (MFEM) to enhance wildfire recognition across varying shapes and sizes. We evaluated our approach on the Fire-Segmentation-Dataset. Results show that DBNet exhibits the highest attribute accuracy and lowest geometric error. Our method effectively extracts wildfires of varying sizes, shapes, and spectral characteristics, even under conditions of limited sample.

title: Smart Farming: Harnessing Robotics and Automation for Sustainable Agricultural Practices
authors: Gajanan Shankarrao Patange, Arvind M, Debabrata Baral, Akruti Bose, Namrata Shrivastava, L. Subha
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Innovations in robots, artificial intelligence (AI), and the internet of things (IoT) are transforming precision agriculture and soil resource conservation. The system enables resource optimisation, data-driven decision-making, and environmentally sustainable farming. Because AI enables advanced predictive analysis, farmers may anticipate crop outcomes, identify diseases beforehand, and optimise planting schedules. Real-time crop development, patterns of weather and health of soil monitoring are made measurable by IoT-based sensor networks, which facilitate quicker and more effective farm operations. By introducing autonomous platforms for soil testing, harvesting, and seeding, robotics revolutionizes traditional farm labour while reducing labour costs and increasing operational efficiency. This investigation primary objective is to use robotics, machine learning (ML), and the IoT to forecast yields of crop depends on soil and climate data. The investigation makes use of a Kaggle dataset that has data on 12 different crops. The collection includes vital soil parameters required for the best crop growth as well as important climate variables like temperature, humidity, and rainfall. The goal is to create precise models that can forecast crop production by using sophisticated ML methods and Robotics on this dataset. As a result, this helps farmers maximise their agricultural earnings and make decisions which is informed about management of crop. The findings of this study have important ramifications for the agriculture sector since they support the adoption of sustainable farming methods and offer insightful information about crop yield estimation.

title: Weighted Binary Search Tree to NDN Name Lookup
authors: Gyubin Kim, Hyesook Lim
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: The current Internet architecture based on IP addresses to identify routers and hosts is inefficient for large-scale content delivery. Named Data Networking (NDN), proposed as a future Internet architecture, enables efficient data dissemination through name-based data forwarding and in-network caching. A key challenge in realizing NDN lies in the fast processing of Longest Name Prefix Match (LNPM) operation for Forwarding Information Base (FIB), given variable-length hierarchical names. A Name Prefix Trie (NPT) conventionally used for name lookup results in increased trie depth and empty nodes as the number of name components increases, leading to inefficiencies in both memory usage and lookup latency. A Binary Search Tree (BST), which eliminates empty nodes by comparing the magnitudes of variable-length prefixes, encounters degraded lookup performance due to the structural imbalance of the tree. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Weighted Binary Search Tree (WBST), which selects a pivot based on the cumulative weights of prefixes, where the weight of each prefix is derived from prefix nesting relationships. This enables balanced tree construction, and hence the average depth of the tree and lookup cost are reduced. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed scheme outperforms both NPT and BST in terms of memory efficiency and lookup performance.

title: Experimental Validation of Finite Element Models Using Digital Image Correlation Strain Data
authors: S.Agnes Shifani
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: With the aid of numerous computer algorithms, digital image processing applies image processing to digital images. Any measurement of entire field displacement involves strain. It is quite difficult to measure strain in any 2D or 3D image. Digital Image Correlation (DIC), a contactless technique, has been proposed in this work to study an accurate strain measurement. Aluminum alloy was used as a specimen for this study, and Ncorr software was used to analyze the strain. The coordinates before and after deformation are measured in order to determine the complete field displacement. The outcome demonstrates that the displacement field calculation error is smaller than 0.5 mm.

title: Measuring Emotion Preservation in Expressive Speech-to-Speech Translation
authors: Bagus Tris Atmaja, Toru Shirai, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: Measuring how well emotions are preserved in speech-to-speech translation is a difficult task. Previous research focused on measuring the similarity between speech embeddings related to emotion or prosody, which may not accurately capture the emotional contents. This study proposes more direct approaches by evaluating emotion preservation using metrics derived from speech emotion recognition (SER), including balanced accuracy ratio, emotion preservation rate, and Cohen's Kappa. The results show that about half of the original emotion is preserved in the translation process in the MELD-ST dataset, with metrics such as balanced accuracy ratio, valence-arousal similarity, and pause rate serving as reliable indicators of emotion preservation. We also found that high similarities between emotion embeddings do not necessarily mean emotion preservation, since the same acoustic embeddings used for SER lead to distinct performance. The analysis highlights the challenges of maintaining emotional consistency during speech-to-speech translation.

title: A Study on the Noise Source Analysis of Capacitance Differences Between Single IGBT and Module for Automotive Power Systems
authors: Jaewon Rhee, Sanguk Lee, Seungmin Ha, Hongseok Kim, Jiseong Kim, Dongil Shin, Semin Woo, Seokhyeon Son, Seungyoung Ahn
abstract: The demand for automotive power systems has led to a growing focus on power modules designed for miniaturization and weight reduction. Traditionally, insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs), which are commonly used in power systems, consist of separate switches and diodes, and are integrated into power systems such as inverters, where the IGBT, diode, and module package are combined. Manufacturers typically use commercial switches and diodes to create modules suitable for specific vehicles. In other words, while capacitance-voltage characteristics for single IGBT devices are provided by manufacturers, module-level capacitance characteristics need to be separately verified and analyzed during the module manufacturing. This study compares the capacitance differences between single IGBT devices and modules based on measurements, and analyzes how these differences in capacitance affect electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) and contribute to noise sources that cause electromagnetic interference (EMI) in switching systems. This highlights the importance of measuring capacitance at the module level.

title: DR-VQA: Large Language Model Based Vision Question Answering System on Diabetic Retinopathy
authors: Saleh Musleh, Hamada R. H. Al-Absi, Md Rizwan Parvez, Anant Pai, Ghassan Mohamedsalih, Tanvir Alam
abstract: Medical Visual Question Answering (VQA) presents challenges due to the complexity of imaging data and the need for precise, context-aware responses. Traditional VQA models often struggle in clinical settings, limiting their utility in decision-making. This study proposes DR-VQA, a fine-tuned BLIP (Bootstrapped Language-Image Pretraining) model for medical VQA specifically designed for diabetic retinopathy (DR) based on fundus imaging, leveraging both visual and textual data to generate accurate diagnostic answers. To enhance semantic relevance, BERT-based similarity evaluation is integrated. Using a diabetic retinopathy dataset, the model achieves a validation BERT similarity (BERTsim) score of 0.94 and a test score of 0.95 on 450 samples, demonstrating strong alignment with expert annotations. These results highlight the model's potential to assist clinicians by improving diagnostic accuracy and efficiency. The proposed approach can streamline medical workflows, reduce clinician workload, and enhance patient outcomes. Future work will focus on expanding datasets and refining the model for broader medical applications. We believe our approach will support to enhance the patient care as well democratization on AI technology for community.

title: Enhancing Histology Image Segmentation Using Improved Retrieval Augmented Generation Technique
authors: Animesh Hazra, Ashutosh Bajpayee, Nibaran Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Precise segmentation of histopathology images is a vital part of automated tissue analysis. It is important for diagnosing diseases, planning treatments, and advancing medical research. Recently, Deep learning has shown remarkable success as a method for facilitating advancements in medical applications, often yielding better results than traditional techniques. Recently, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) has been used to improve segmentation tasks by providing additional contextual knowledge. However, its usefulness is limited due to shallow features, noisy retrieval, and weak spatial alignment in complex medical images. This work introduces an improved RAG model focused on boosting semantic segmentation performance in histology images. We demonstrate its effectiveness through a detailed comparison with four traditional segmentation models: U-Net, U-Net++, Attention U-Net, and classical RAG. These models are tested on two benchmark datasets: GlaS and PanNuke. The improved RAG model tackles significant issues found in the classical RAG model by adding dynamic memory indexing, support-based retrieval, and attention-driven feature fusion. The proposed approach delivers improved performance across both datasets. Compared with the standard U-Net model, it achieves higher IoU, Dice coefficient, and accuracy by 24%, 13%, and 12% on the GlaS dataset, and by 19%, 10%, and 4% on the PanNuke dataset. This shows its strong generalization for various tissue types. Finally, this paper reviews modern deep learning-based segmentation methods and showcases the potential of retrieval-augmented techniques for building more reliable and accurate AI systems in digital pathology.

title: Investigation of Nano Refrigerant Lubrication System in Vapor Compression Refrigeration System Using Environmental Friendly Refrigerant
authors: Yamini S, Divya S, Sivakami Sundari. M, Senthil Kumar. K
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Compression of vaporized refrigerant is the essential process of the refrigeration cycle which is performed by using a compressor. The amount of power consumed by a refrigeration system is governed by the work input given to its compressor, which also determines the COP of the system. By reducing the work input given to the compressor, the power consumption of refrigerator is reduced along with the improvement in its COP. Nowadays, nanoparticles have emerged as the new generation additives in various working fluids because of their remarkable ability to improve the heat transfer, tribological and other thermo-physical properties of the base fluid. In such a vein, we propose a compressor oil-based nanofluid prepared by dispersing nanoparticles into the conventional compressor oil. In the present study, four mixtures of nanoadditive compressor oil were prepared by dispersing the nanoparticles like <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Al} 2 \mathrm{O} 3, \text{TiO} 2$</tex> and ZnO into the conventional mineral oil as a lubricant. The thermophysical and tribological properties of these four mixtures were studied, out of which Mixture 4 was chosen because of its better lubrication and heat transfer properties which are considered as one of the key parameters for reducing work input to the compressor. This can result in reduced power consumption, with enhancement of COP. These results are analysed experimentally by carrying out performance and exergy analysis in a Vapour Compression Refrigeration System (VCRS), using R600a as a refrigerant. The experimental results show that there is an improvement of COP by 14.6% and exergy efficiency by 7.51%. Also, the efficiency defect in the major components of VCRS has been reduced effectively. The results of the performance tests done as per BIS show an improvement in the energy conservation by 27.5%.

title: Real-Time ML-Based Fraud Detection in Insurance Claims Using Kafka and Snowpipe
authors: Harsh Parnerkar, Parth Joshi, Shreekant Malviya
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: In this work, the researchers elaborate on the application of Apache Kafka and machine learning in detecting fraud in real-time during the insurance claims. The insurance claims are fed into the system and processed in low latency by utilizing the real-time streaming data features of Kafka. The claims information is subsequently loaded into a Snowflake data warehouse via Snowpipe which makes the data loading seamless and serverless. To detect fraud, a machine learning model, e.g., an XGBoost, is trained on past claims data to detect the trends of fraud in terms of features such as claim amounts, claimant behavior, and frequency of claims. Upon deployment, the model does real-time inference and marks suspicious claims when it processes them. This system will enable an automated scalable solution to fraud detection that will save insurers losses and enhance operational efficiency. Kafka streaming architecture, Snowpipe to store information in real-time and XGBoost to predict the presence of frauds will guarantee that the process of fraud claims to the insurance company is real-time and would streamline the process of insurance claim.

title: Fixed-Time ESO-based Longitudinal Speed Tracking Control for the Four-Wheel Distributed Electric Drive Vehicle
authors: Baochen Li, Kaikun Wang, Jicheng Chen, Miao Liu, Yan Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel control strategy with lumped resistance compensation for speed tracking of four-wheel distributed electric drive vehicles. The proposed approach integrates a fixed-time extended state observer (FTESO), a resistance-compensated integral controller, and an energy-optimal torque distribution strategy. First, the FTESO is developed to estimate system states and lumped resistances within a settled time. Based on the observer outputs, a resistance-compensated integral controller is designed to track the reference velocity. The tracking error is uniformly ultimately bounded, with the bound adjustable via observer gain parameters. To enhance energy efficiency, a torque distribution strategy is formulated to allocate optimal torque to each wheel by minimizing overall energy consumption. MATLAB simulations confirm the validity of the proposed method in achieving accurate velocity tracking and reliable state estimation.

title: A Cost-Effective Approach to PCB Structure and Process for Enhanced High-Speed Signal Integrity
authors: Jeonghyeon Choi, Youbean Kim
abstract: As the use of high-speed signals continues to grow, precisely controlling signal loss has become an increasingly challenging task in the electronics industry. This paper focuses on dielectric loss that occurs in transmission channels during high-speed signaling and proposes a novel printed circuit board (PCB) structure to effectively mitigate such loss. To evaluate the feasibility of the proposed structure, electromagnetic simulations were conducted to analyze the electrical characteristics of the PCB. Furthermore, in order to reduce additional manufacturing costs, a practical PCB fabrication method that does not require high-end equipment was developed, and a prototype was manufactured. Finally, using a vector network analyzer (VNA), the electrical performance and signal quality improvement of the prototype were thoroughly evaluated. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed structure can effectively reduce dielectric loss in the transmission channel while minimizing the need for expensive low-loss dielectric materials, making it a cost-efficient solution for high-speed PCB applications.

title: Performance Analysis of TabNet for Autism Spectrum Disorder Classification in Children
authors: Mrutyunjaya Sathua, Bijnan Biswal, Ashutosh Soni, Jayanti Rout, Surendra Kumar Nanda
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Children are the most promising segment of society, but birth disorders can significantly impact a child’s growth and societal presence. Among these, Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a prominent neurodevelopmental condition characterized by difficulties in social interaction, communication, and repetitive behaviors. Its early detection and proper support can greatly improve the mental conditions of children. There are various detection methods, including eye movement analysis, facial features, questionnaires, etc. Among these, Q-Chat-10 and AQ-10 are widely used for effective screening and assessment. Manual detection of ASD is prone to human-biasness, delayed results, and subject to error based on the stress level of the doctor. As a result, Machine Learning (ML) came into play, but was limited due to manual feature engineering techniques and the inability to deduce hidden relationships. To address it, a Tabular Network (TabNet)-based ASD detection model for children has been proposed that is trained on the autism screening dataset. The model was equipped with Adam optimizer, LRScheduler, early stopping, etc., to ensure proper training. Various experiments were also conducted to gain insight into the dataset and the performance of the classifier that were found to be missing in various studies. An ideal accuracy for multiple split ratios was achieved that demonstrates suitable performance across both balanced and imbalanced datasets. It demonstrated faster training times, enhanced interpretability, efficient feature selection through sparse attention and the ability to handle mixed data types seamlessly.

title: Federated Learning for Collaborative Dental Diagnosis Across Hospitals Without Compromising Privacy
authors: Niladri Maiti, Riddhi Chawla, Babacar Toure, Pratik Agrawal, Syed Hauider Abba
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper examines how Federated Learning (FL) can be used to conduct dental diagnosis in many hospitals without threatening the privacy of patients. The approach is based on a Cross-Silo FL design where involved hospitals receive training on a common deep learning framework locally on their individual dental images (e.g., panoramic X-rays, CBCT). The model does not transfer raw data, but instead the update of the data is consolidated at a central server and sensitive data about the patient is kept confidential. In order to solve the problem of data heterogeneity and unbalances among hospitals, the research uses Federated Proximal (FedProx) a technique that becomes used to stabilize learning and enhances the convergence of the models when the data distributions are uneven. The experiment is conducted with the help of the TensorFlow Federated (TFF) framework of the model creation and coordination, which promotes efficient distributed learning and safe aggregation. The findings indicate that FL as implemented in dental diagnostics could facilitate cross-hospital training and keep privacy intact and the accuracy of diagnosis increased.

title: Efficient Integral Equation Modeling of Arbitrary Rectangular Waveguide Bends and T-Junctions with Conducting Inclusions
authors: Antonio Manuel Huéscar De La Cruz, Antonio Oliva Aparicio, Fernando D. Quesada Pereira, Alejandro Álvarez Melcón, Vicente E. Boria Esbert
abstract: This contribution presents an efficient and versatile Integral Equation (IE) formulation for the analysis of discontinuities in rectangular waveguides, with particular emphasis on T-junctions and bend-junctions as use example cases. The proposed methodology enables the modeling of zero-thickness discontinuities with arbitrary geometry, as well as the inclusion of arbitrarily shaped conducting elements within the rectangular waveguides. The original problem is decomposed into a set of equivalent subproblems, coupled through an equivalent surface magnetic current density $\left( {{{{{\vec M}}}_{ap}}} \right)$ defined at the discontinuity. By employing Lorenz-Gauge Green’s functions of rectangular waveguides, a significant reduction in the number of unknowns is achieved. Furthermore, to enhance computational efficiency, the Ewald method is used for the evaluation of the Green’s functions and their spatial derivatives. The accuracy and computational performance of the proposed approach are validated through comparison with results obtained from the widely used commercial full-wave Ansys HFSS software, demonstrating good agreement and better numerical efficiency.

title: Green Hydrogen Generation Using AI-Based Predictive Control of Electrolyzers
authors: Vasupalli Manoj, Rebba Sasidhar, Aakula Swathi, Balajee Maram, N.V.A. Ravi Kumar, Nagalla Pradeep
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Green hydrogen, produced through water electrolysis using energy from renewable sources, represents a sustainable pathway to decarbonization of numerous sectors. However, there are challenges associated with efficiency, durability and cost of operation, arising from the inherent variability in renewable power and operational behavior of electrolyzers. This study presents a predictive control framework for proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzers, employing an Artificial Intelligence methodology, incorporating machine learning models and model predictive control (MPC) to optimize hydrogen yield, losses, energy input and equipment health. First, a surrogate model encapsulating the biological and non-linear dynamics of the electrolyzer stack was developed using the available data from the stack, which accounts for a range of temperature, pressure and current conditions experienced. Next, the MPC algorithm was calculated in the short term for the renewable generation forecast, leveraging the surrogate model, finding the setpoint of the current, optimizing the setpoint of the current against the production target and degradation of the system. Simulations of this adaptive predictive controller were rendered using realistic solar and wind profiles, demonstrating up to +12% energy efficiency and up to -20% degradation of the system due to cycling (renewable use) than that provided by traditional PID control. In addition, we performed a sensitivity analysis on forecast errors and associated parameter uncertainties, and showed sufficient robustness. The proposed methodology opens up a future of more intelligent operation of the electrolyzer and combining renewable energy, beyond that of more historical controls, enhancing utilization of green energy, improving operational lifetime of the equipment, and lower levelized cost of hydrogen, etc.

title: A Fractal-FSS Based Antenna Architecture for Enhanced DSRC Communication in Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Sunil Kumar Dubey, Ashok Kumar Shankhwar, Nand Kishore
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This research looks into a small fractal antenna that works at 5.9 GHz and has a frequency selective surface (FSS). Smart transportation systems (ITS) might work better after this radio is put in. The project’s goal is to use Dedicated Short-Range Communication (DSRC). The FSS layer’s two most important jobs are to increase the antenna’s gain and stop radiation from going in other directions. The fractal design, on the other hand, encourages radiation, which makes things work better and makes them smaller. The low-profile design is easy to adapt to and works with both vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) technologies. The simulation showed that the DSRC spectrum for V2I communication has the right impedance matching, a higher gain, and stable radiation characteristics. You can see many of these events in the spectrum. The design shown here strikes a satisfactory balance between size, functionality, and usability, which makes it a great choice for use in modern ITS settings. This is what makes them perfect to use.

title: Simulation and Performance Analysis of the Communication Link Between Earth and Moon
authors: Lijuan Gao, Jiong Li, Long Chen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: The communication link between Earth and Moon is a bridge connecting the Earth station and the lunar probe, which is crucial for conducting lunar exploration. It analyzes the tasks, operating frequencies, modulation methods of the communication link between the Earth and the Moon, and further analyzes the physical factors, space environment factors, equipment factors, orbit factors, which affect the performance of the communication link between the Earth and the Moon. Combined with simulation software, it simulates and analyzes the link performance parameters corresponding to these factors, including signal loss, duration, Doppler frequency shift, etc. Then it analyzes the C/n0 and information transmission rate of the communication link between the Earth and the Moon, in order to provide the high-speed data transmission in subsequent lunar exploration.

title: LLM-Augmented Causal Discovery: A Framework of Integrating Non-Causal Priors for High-Dimensional Noise Scenarios
authors: Ting Huang, Yinghui Wang, Xinnian Wang, Yun Zhou
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: As data dimensionality increases, the adverse effects of data noise become substantially amplified, leading to significant degradation in the learning accuracy of conventional causal discovery algorithms. This degradation primarily manifests through the introduction of spurious dependencies and the confounding of genuine causal pathways. While large language models (LLMs) offer the potential to mitigate these issues through implicit knowledge extraction, existing approaches predominantly concentrate on causal directionality, neglecting the critical role of non-causal priors. To address this limitation, we propose LLM-Augmented Causal Discovery (LACD) in this work, a model-agnostic framework that integrates LLM-derived non-causal priors into continuous optimization to suppress error edges. Our framework formalizes non-causal relationships via a structured prompting mechanism, thereby penalizing spurious dependencies in the adjacency matrices of causal graphs. Empirical results on synthetic and real-world data sets demonstrate that LACD achieves (1) a significant reduction in false discovery rates (FDR), (2) improved structural Hamming distance (SHD) metrics for causal discovery in high-dimensional settings, and (3) enhanced algorithmic robustness through its model-agnostic architecture.

title: Comparison of Omni PDP and Synthesized Directional PDP at 415 GHz
authors: Jinhyung Oh, Jong Ho Kim
abstract: This study investigates the similarity between addition based synthesized directional power delay profile (PDP) and max-hold synthesized directional PDP at 415 GHz, targeting indoor short-range terahertz applications. The directional PDP was generated by rotating a horn antenna with a 60° beamwidth in 60° increments, with the strongest received signals retained. Through experimental comparative results, we compared the delay characteristics and signal strength between max-hold based PDP and addition-based PDP, and prepared for comparison with the characteristics of the omni-directional antenna PDP to be studied in future research. These results substantiate the utility of directional synthesis in modelling terahertz channel characteristics for indoor use cases.

title: A Compact High-Isolation Wilkinson Power Divider Combiner for W- and D-Band with Series and Coupled Inductors
authors: Jong-Seong Park, Joon-Hyung Kim, Jae-Hyeok Song, Jae-Eun Lee, Jeong-Taek Son, Min-Seok Baek, Byeong-Chan Lee, Ilhun Kim, Eun-Gyu Lee, Choul-Young Kim
abstract: This paper proposes a compact 2-way Wilkinson power divider/combiner suitable for millimeter-wave applications such as next-generation high-speed wireless communication systems and phased-array transceivers. The proposed circuit is designed with an optimized topology to simultaneously achieve high integration and excellent electrical performance. To validate its performance, the circuit was fabricated using a 65 nm CMOS process, and the chip area was implemented as 0.007 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Measurement results show that the circuit achieves a return loss greater than 10.8 dB, an insertion loss of 0.863–1.2 dB, and an isolation higher than 20 dB over the 104.1–123.8 GHz frequency range. This work demonstrates that high integration and performance requirements in millimeter-wave integrated circuits can be effectively realized.

title: Atmospheric Correction for HY-3A CZI: A Deep Learning Method Applied Across Open Ocean, Coastal, and Turbid Inland Waters_supp1-3665003.docx
authors: liqiao tian
abstract: Atmospheric correction (AC) is a critical step for retrieving accurate remote sensing reflectance (Rrs). However, in highly turbid inland and coastal waters, traditional AC algorithms typically require shortwave infrared (SWIR) or ultraviolet (UV) bands, thereby limiting their applicability to sensors that lack such bands (e.g., HY-3A CZI). To address these limitations, we introduce ACTransNet, an end-to-end deep learning model based on the Transformer architecture. This model directly retrieves Rrs from satellite digital numbers (DNs), bypassing the explicit radiometric calibration (RC) process. The model is trained on synthetic datasets derived from Sentinel-2 MSI, with reference Rrs generated using a combined strategy that involves the POLYMER and ACOLITE-DSF algorithms. The training data span 40 distinct regions, covering diverse water environments ranging from clear open ocean to turbid coastal and inland waters. These data undergo a strict quality control process to ensure their representativeness and reliability. Application results using CZI data demonstrate that ACTransNet performs robustly across seven spectral bands, with R2 values ranging from 0.61 to 0.97. In the visible bands, ACTransNet substantially reduces the mean absolute percentage difference (MAPD), with an average reduction of ∼ 82% relative to ACOLITE-DSF and ∼ 74% relative to NIR-bio. Comparisons with quasi-synchronized Sentinel-2 MSI imagery further confirm that the model maintains strong spatial consistency (R2 > 0.96) across two contrasting water environments (the eastern coast of the Bay of Bengal and Lake Hulun). In a separate evaluation, the model also outperforms traditional multi-step AC algorithms, such as DSF and NIR-bio. Overall, ACTransNet integrates the strengths of both POLYMER and DSF, offering enhanced accuracy and robustness across diverse water environments. This model provides a practical and generalizable solution for AC tasks, particularly for sensors with limited spectral bands, and offers valuable references for remote sensing applications on other similar satellite platforms.

title: Efficient Transient Electromagnetic Inversion with Automatic Differentiation
authors: Jun Lin, Yuqi Zhao, Feng Liu, Jian Chen, Junlun Li, Yang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The transient electromagnetic (TEM) method is recognized as a highly efficient geophysical prospecting technique for rapid acquisition of subsurface resistivity distribution. Conventional gradient-based iterative inversion for TEM usually adopts finite-difference (FD) to compute the Jacobian matrix to minimize the loss function and update the model parameters. However, when inverting large datasets for complex geological models, FD-based Jacobian computations not only could compromise gradient accuracy, but also incur substantial computational costs. To address the demand for rapid inversion of field TEM data, we propose ADABFM—a novel TEM inversion method that integrates automatic differentiation (AD) with adaptive Born forward mapping. Leveraging the gradient-calculation capability of AD, ADABFM can use essentially error-free gradients to update model parameters, and obtain highly accurate resistivity models. Furthermore, ADABFM embeds system response characteristics directly into the forward modeling kernel functions. This design eliminates the complexities associated with explicit system response modeling, and enhances the robustness of inversion. To validate the new method, we first conduct systematic tests with synthetic datasets. Then, we apply ADABFM to two distinct field datasets: 1) the open-source tTEM20AAR dataset collected in Aare Valley, Switzerland, and 2) an dataset acquired by our proprietary TEM system for the Quaternary overburden in Urumqi, China. For the tTEM20AAR dataset, the results obtained by ADABFM are essentially consistent with the those obtained by the conventional FD-based iterative method with spatial constraints, while revealing more detailed subsurface features. For the Urumqi dataset, the inversion results also demonstrate satisfactory consistency with the direct borehole measurements. Benefiting from the improvement in computational efficiency, ADABFM enables rapid inversion from multiple initial models, which can effectively alleviate the local minima issue inherent in iterative inversion. The ADABFM method proposed in this study should provide an accurate, efficient and robust solution for rapid TEM inversion.

title: SCAN: Visual Explanations with Self-Confidence and Analysis Networks
authors: Gwanghee Lee, Sungyoon Jeong, Kyoungson Jhang
abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has become essential in computer vision to make the decision-making processes of deep learning models transparent. However, current visual explanation (XAI) methods face a critical trade-off between the high fidelity of architecture-specific methods and the broad applicability of universal ones. This often results in abstract or fragmented explanations and makes it difficult to compare explanatory power across diverse model families, such as CNNs and Transformers. This paper introduces the Self-Confidence and Analysis Networks (SCAN), a novel universal framework that overcomes these limitations for both convolutional neural network and transformer architectures. SCAN utilizes an AutoEncoder-based approach to reconstruct features from a model’s intermediate layers. Guided by the Information Bottleneck principle, it generates a highresolution Self-Confidence Map that identifies information-rich regions. Extensive experiments on diverse architectures and datasets demonstrate that SCAN consistently achieves outstanding performance on various quantitative metrics such as AUC-D, Negative AUC, Drop%, and Win%. Qualitatively, it produces significantly clearer, object-focused explanations than existing methods. By providing a unified framework that is both architecturally universal and highly faithful, SCAN enhances model transparency and offers a more reliable tool for understanding the decision-making processes of complex neural networks.

title: Personalized Federated Learning for Session-based Affective Interaction Modeling
authors: Rajesh Titung, Cecilia O. Alm
abstract: Multimodal human conversational interactions are characterized by individual differences, ambiguity, and complex socio-cultural and situational dynamics. Modeling session structured affective interactions, including emotion expression during communicative exchanges presents challenges for centralized machine learning approaches. Traditional machine learning pipelines for identifying these behaviors typically rely on learning a single generalizable model across all individuals in the dataset. However, data heterogeneity suggests that a single centralized model cannot capture individuals' respective nuances. To confirm this, we analyze multimodal behavioral datasets of expressive emotive interactions and demonstrate the statistical heterogeneity in individuals' data distributions. This serves as motivation for our focus on personalization. To achieve that, we turn to federated learning (FL). FL offers a compelling framework that enables integrating a centralized model (for shared behavioral trends) and client models (for individualized behavioral expressions), while additionally offering privacy preservation. However, so far, FL research has often focused on image benchmarks with non-IID partitioned data among the clients, ignoring the heterogeneity of naturalistic interactions. To address this gap, we propose FedSession, a novel personalized federated learning (PFL) strategy that accommodates heterogeneous data distributions by explicitly modeling sessions as structured interaction units, where each client corresponds to a real individual participating in a conversation-based affective interaction. FedSession incorporates an additional tier to capture how interlocutors align their behaviors to one another in interactions. Experiments on affect recognition tasks involving dyadic sessions demonstrate that FedSession outperforms existing PFL strategies. Unlike prior PFL strategies, which often struggle to outperform even localized training performance, FedSession effectively addresses the challenges of personalization in heterogeneous, interactive emotion recognition settings.

title: Prescribed-Time Tracking Control for Nonlinear Systems: A Nonvanishing Disturbance Observer-Based Approach
authors: Yulong Ji, Xiucai Huang, Ben Niu, Yafeng Li, Xudong Zhao, Guangjing Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article investigates the problem of observer-based prescribed-time tracking control (OPTC) for a class of nonlinear systems with uncertain nonvanishing disturbances. First, a prescribed-time observer (PTO) with a well-designed time-varying high gain is constructed to achieve zero-error observation of the uncertain nonvanishing disturbances within the prescribed observation time. Subsequently, a two-stage controller design framework is proposed to construct the desired control input, which consists of two distinct components: the first-stage controller and the second-stage controller. The first-stage controller is established to compensate for the effects of the system’s nonlinear dynamics, thereby providing a relatively satisfactory tracking performance. The second-stage controller, on the other hand, is constructed based on a sophisticated switching mechanism of the control gains, which not only ensures that the tracking error converges to zero within the prescribed tracking time but also guarantees a smooth transition between the two-stage controllers. Finally, the simulation example involving a disturbed single-link flexible-joint robotic manipulator is presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy.

title: Decentralized Constrained Optimization Over Time-Varying Directed Networks via Subgradient Rescaling
authors: Qingguo Lü, Huaqing Li, Chaoxu Wu, Hao Zhou, Tingwen Huang, Ponnuthurai Nagaratnam Suganthan
abstract: In this article, we investigate a decentralized constrained optimization problem over time-varying directed networks. The nodes in the network aim to collaboratively minimize the aggregate of all locally known convex cost functions, subject to local nonidentical and multiple constraint sets, inequality constraints, and equality constraints. Problems of this nature arise in a number of applications in real networks, such as facility location in wireless sensor networks and image deblurring in machine learning. To address these types of problems, we propose an efficient subgradient-rescaling-based decentralized fixed-random projection (SR-DFRP) algorithm, named the SR-DFRP algorithm. In particular, the SR-DFRP algorithm employs Polyak’s random projection to handle nonidentical and multiple constraints, which reduces computational load by avoiding the formulation of complex subproblems. Furthermore, by utilizing dynamically constructed row-stochastic matrices, the algorithm employs a subgradient rescaling strategy to mitigate the imbalance induced by the time-varying directed networks. Rigorous theoretical analyses are provided to establish that the SR-DFRP algorithm converges almost surely to the optimal solution. Extensive simulations on facility location and image deblurring problems are presented to validate the efficacy of the algorithm and the validity of the theoretical results.

title: A Knowledge-Enhanced Evolutionary Multitasking Memetic Algorithm for Multimodal Multiobjective Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Considering Speed
authors: Cong Luo, Xinyu Li, Liang Gao, Qihao Liu, Qingsong Fan
abstract: Most research on flexible job shop scheduling assumes constant processing speeds. However, in real production, machines need to operate at variable speeds to achieve energy-efficient scheduling, which requires balancing multiobjective between production efficiency and green development. Such tradeoffs thus trigger the phenomenon in which massive solutions converge to identical objective values (i.e., the multimodal property), which is often neglected in scheduling problems. To address the above challenges, this work introduces a knowledge-enhanced evolutionary multitasking memetic algorithm (KEMMA) to solve the multimodal multiobjective flexible job shop scheduling problem considering speed (MMFJSP-S).
