First, self-paced learning motivated us to construct a simple auxiliary task and employ an evolutionary multitasking (EMT) framework to tackle the complex MMFJSP-S. Moreover, a knowledge enhancement and explicit transfer strategy is designed to reduce the effects of negative transfer by reinforcing and sharing beneficial knowledge across tasks. Finally, a mapping transformation mechanism is proposed to handle the multimodal property of the MMFJSP-S in the decision space. By comparing with ten advanced algorithms, the experimental results verify the remarkable superiority ofthe proposed KEMMA in solving MMFJSP-S and reveal the significance of studying the multimodal property.

title: Learning Multi-view Anomaly Detection with Efficient Adaptive Selection_supp1-3660076.pdf
authors: Lei Xie
abstract: This study explores the recently proposed and challenging multi-view Anomaly Detection (AD) task. Single-view tasks will encounter blind spots from other perspectives, resulting in inaccuracies in sample-level prediction. Therefore, we introduce the Multi-View Anomaly Detection (MVAD) approach, which learns and integrates features from multi-views. Specifically, we propose a Multi-View Adaptive Selection (MVAS) algorithm for feature learning and fusion across multiple views. The feature maps are divided into neighbourhood attention windows to calculate a semantic correlation matrix between single-view windows and all other views, which is an attention mechanism conducted for each single-view window and the top-$k$ most correlated multi-view windows. Adjusting the window sizes and top-$k$ can minimise the complexity to $O((hw)^\frac{4}{3})$. Extensive experiments on the Real-IAD dataset under the multi-class setting validate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance with an average improvement of +2.5$\uparrow$ across 10 metrics at the sample/image/pixel levels, using only 18M parameters and requiring fewer FLOPs and training time. The codes are available at https://github.com/lewandofskee/MVAD.

title: Aging Aware Test Generation Procedure for Multicycle Scan-Based Tests
authors: Irith Pomeranz
abstract: Storage of a compressed deterministic scan-based test set in an on-chip memory allows compact test sets with complete fault coverage of target faults to be applied in-field.With in-field test periods varying in duration, short in-field test periods should detect the faults that are the most likely to occur as a chip ages. This can be addressed by a procedure that generates a test set such that subsets with increasing numbers of tests detect subsets of increasing numbers of the faults that are the most likely to occur with aging. Such a procedure was described for a two-cycle scan-based transition fault test set. This article suggests for the first time the use of multicycle scan-based tests for this purpose. A multicycle test has several functional capture cycles between scan operations. A larger number of functional capture cycles allows a multicycle test to detect more faults. In the context of this article, more of the faults that are the most susceptible to aging are detected with each additional test. The test data compression logic used in this article allows both scan-in states and primary input sequences of multicycle tests to be compressed together. However, it also requires compressed tests to be generated directly, and the aging aware test generation procedure must continue increasing the fault coverage as it addresses aging. The procedure was implemented in an academic simulation environment and applied to transition faults in benchmark circuits to demonstrate its effectiveness.

title: Visual Based Fixed Wing UAV Trajectory Tracking with Optimal Control Methods
authors: Sevinc Gunsel, Seref Naci Engin, Mustafa Dogan
abstract: This paper describes a study on developing a novel, vision-based autonomous landing system for fixed-wing UAVs, primarily optimized for GPS-denied environments, using visual data and optimal control approaches. First, the algorithm uses vSLAM to determine the UAV’s exact location and build a map. A key innovation to enhance this process is the use of an SVD-aided Kalman filter within vSLAM, which significantly improves map point update accuracy and efficiency by reducing noise. The system precisely defines the landing area using image segmentation andWatershed Transform for real-time vSLAM data, and find important landmarks. This visual data feed the linearized MPC, which computes the optimal control inputs-longitudinal acceleration, yaw rate, and vertical velocity to guide the UAV along the landing trajectory. While both MPC and Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) were tested and showed successful guidance capabilities, simulation results confirm the effective performance of our integrated vSLAM-MPC architecture in precisely guiding the UAV to the landing zone.

title: Adaptive Feature Aggregation Enhanced by Using DenseNet for Robust Breast Cancer Histopathology Image Classification
authors: Zaka Ur Rehman, Mohammad Faizal Ahmad Fauzi, Wan-Noorshahida Mohd-Isa, Meriem Touhami, Arbab Sufyan Wadood, Muhammad Kashif Jabbar
abstract: Accurate classification of breast cancer from histopathology images is critical for early diagnosis and effective treatment planning. While deep learning techniques-particularly convolutional neural networks (CNNs)-have achieved substantial success in medical image analysis, existing models often struggle with issues such as overfitting, channel redundancy, and insufficient focus on clinically salient features. To address these limitations, this paper introduces a deep learning framework that integrates an Adaptive Feature Aggregation (AFA) block into the DenseNet121 architecture. The proposed AFA module learns to emphasize important feature channels by modeling inter-channel dependencies through a lightweight attention mechanism, thereby improving the network's ability to distinguish between benign and malignant tissue patterns. Extensive experiments were conducted on the BreakHis <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$400 x$</tex> histopathology dataset. The proposed model achieved 98 % accuracy, 98 % F1-score, and an AUC of 0.99, outperforming the baseline DenseNet model. Evaluation metrics such as precision, recall, ROC-AUC, and confusion matrix analysis confirm the robustness and effectiveness of the proposed method for breast cancer classification.

title: An AI-Driven Fuzzy-Statistical Model for Alzheimer’s Disease Risk Assessment Based on Coenzyme Q10 and 25-Hydroxyvitamin D Levels
authors: Jianli Cui, Hongkun Liu, Sirui Li, Kok Wai Wong, Xi Huang, Yujie Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) using fuzzy system offers powerful alternative for modeling complex, nonlinear biomedical relationships, especially under small-sample conditions common in clinical research. This study establishes an fuzzy-driven hybrid framework that combines traditional statistical modeling with fuzzy logic reasoning to predict Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk employing two serum compounds-25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) and coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10). Serum samples from 32 AD patients and 32 cognitively healthy controls were analyzed by liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS). Both levels of the two substances were significantly lower in AD patients compared with controls (p < 0.001). Logistic regression identified 25(OH)D (OR = 0.51) and CoQ10 (OR = 0.45) as independent protective factors, yielding an AUC of 0.86. The fuzzy logic model, based on the Mamdani inference system with nine IF–THEN rules, achieved an accuracy of 81.3% and an AUC of 0.785, indicating stable and explainable performance on a small-scale data. The proposed fuzzy framework effectively bridges quantitative biostatistics and qualitative reasoning, offering a transparent and data-efficient method for biomarker-based AD risk estimation. This explainable AI strategy may provide a good alternative for future applications in accuracy medicine and biomarker-driven disease screening in situations where available are small.

title: Skyline Cardinality Estimation Model of Skyline Queries over Incomplete Data
authors: Zhang Xiaowei, Hamidah Ibrahim, Fatimah Sidi, Siti Nurulain Mohd Rum, Mudathir Ahmed Mohamud
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Interdisciplinary Computer Science and Engineering (ICICSE)
abstract: Skyline queries over incomplete data have been extensively explored in the database community over the years. Moreover, they have been integrated into various real-world database applications. Given the substantial computational cost of executing skyline queries on incomplete data, accurately estimating skyline cardinality is essential for the query optimizer to derive optimal execution plans. In this paper, we propose a Skyline Cardinality Estimation Model (SCEM) that aims at estimating the skyline cardinality of skyline queries over incomplete data. Also, the Spearman correlation coefficient (SCC) is integrated into the SCEM model to identify the data distribution type of an incomplete database. Extensive experiments are conducted on both synthetic and real incomplete datasets demonstrate that the SCEM model, built upon an ensemble learning algorithm, achieves the most effective and efficient performance in estimating skyline cardinality, while the SCC can identify the type of data distribution with high accuracy.

title: Text Neck Syndrome: Electromyographic Analysis of Forward Head Posture Induced Cervical Strain
authors: S Saranya, R Rakshana, Shravan Kumar Subbaraman, Sharadha Gopal
abstract: Detrimental neck postures are unconsciously adopted during prolonged usage of handheld mobile devices (HHMDs). The strain on the neck muscles and spine from this posture can lead to chronic discomfort and, over time, severe musculoskeletal complications. This condition, commonly referred to as Text Neck Syndrome, has become an increasingly prevalent occupational disorder in today's digital world. The main purpose of this study is to develop a wearable custom-made device that actively monitors neck posture to help prevent and mitigate the effects of Text Neck. This device integrates an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) to detect head positioning and acts as monitor to remind users if their bad posture remains unchanged for a fixed period of time. These time and position thresholds are validated using an Electromyography (EMG)-based data acquisition system. Detailed EMG analysis has been performed on the acquired data to track the onset of fatigue and decide the corresponding time threshold. This provides users with real-time feedback on posture, encouraging prompt correction and inculcation of pristine ergonomics.

title: Redefining Disease Detection: Innovative Machine Learning and Wearable Sensor Integration
authors: Pankaj Mehta, Amruta Desai, Shuvo Dutta, P.R. Sanjaya M.D. S, Asha M. S, Aravindan M
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Wearable sensor technology is considered to be one of the fastest growing fields of information and communication technologies and it has revolutionized the healthcare delivery by enabling continuous and real-time physiological monitoring. This research presents a novel approach that allows an early onset disease detection instigated with the prowess of advanced Graph Neural Network (GNNs) matched with the body streams gathered from wearable machines using its implementation technology - Pythonline of programming named Awesome Geometric libraries referred to as Aztec PyTorch. Graph neural networks (GNNs) are especially suitable within the scope of modeling complex relationships among multivariate inputs of the sensors for modeling the temporal and spatial subjacent dependence of the physiological signs with regards to reality. The proposed system analyzes the data acquired from the various wearable sensors such as heart rate, accelerometers and bio sensors, which help in anomaly detection and hence the detection of the patient having cardiovascular, metabolic and neurological diseases. The synergy between innovative deep learning models and sensors as ubiquitous technologies offers great promise to transform the provision of personalised healthcare services and dealing with disease in its early stages.

title: Antenna factor calibration of optical electric field sensor using GTEM cell
authors: Yuma Otomo, Shinobu Ishigami, Ken Kawamata
abstract: A calibration of antennas or field sensors used in EMC measurements is usually performed in an anechoic chamber. On the other hand, a GTEM cell is a type of TEM waveguide, and is a device designed to perform radiated immunity tests and radiated emission measurements even in the microwave frequency band. In this report, focusing on the broadband property of a GTEM cell, calibration result of the antenna factor of an optical electric-field sensor using LiNbO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> optical crystal up to 9.25 GHz was shown. The calibration was conducted using the standard field generated by a GTEM cell inside.

title: ProFS: Pareto-based Resource-aware Optimized Fog head Selection in Healthcare IoT Systems
authors: Alibha Patel, Rupalin Nanda, Rama Krushna Rath
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Nowadays, with the advancement in healthcare systems, there exist challenges such as huge volume of healthcare data management and optimal resource utilization. In a Internet of Healthcare Things (IoHT) network, the real-time data are generated from healthcare devices need faster and efficient local processing. Therefore, the paradigm is shifted from the cloud computing to the fog computing, where multiple fog devices are able to handle the data volume. In this aspect, it is necessary to select an optimal fog device considering heterogeneity, that is responsible for task management in the fog layer. In this work, we propose a Pareto-based resource-aware optimized fog head selection technique, termed as ProFS, for IoHT network. We consider multiple key parameters such as cost, network latency, throughput energy, and memory utilization for selection of fog head. In simulation result over 100 iterations, we find that our work reduces latency 56 − 80% and overall energy consumption of 80% with increasing number of tasks and fog devices.

title: A Lightweight Temporal Convolutional Identifier for Dynamic Modeling of Substation Inspection Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
authors: Dukang Li, Fenglin Deng, Wen Wang, Qihang Jin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Autonomous inspection technology of substation utilizing unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) is pivotal for ensuring the reliability of the power grid. An accurate UAV dynamic model constitutes the key to implementing this technology. Although existing data-driven modeling methods have achieved significant progress, their high computational costs render them difficult to deploy directly on inspection UAVs. Furthermore, these methods neglect the impact of accumulated errors over extended prediction horizons, which can easily result in the failure of long-term predictions. To this end, we propose a dynamic modeling method based on lightweight temporal convolutional identifier. Specifically, to reduce the computational cost of the dynamic model, we introduce a context-aware downsampling-based temporal convolution strategy that maintains model accuracy while enhancing its lightweight property. A decoupled dynamics learning framework is presented to simplify the learning process and improve the modularity. In addition, to explicitly mitigate the issue of compounding prediction errors in long-term prediction, a multi-step prediction loss is incorporated into the training objective. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated on real flight datasets, and the results demonstrate that it exhibits the characteristics of low computational cost, fast inference speed, and high modeling accuracy.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Machine Learning and Ensemble Models for Medical Diagnosis from Patient Profiles
authors: Arvind R, Saba Tahseen, Abhilash R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of categorical outcomes remains a fundamental challenge in machine learning. This work provides a comparison analysis of different supervised learning techniques, ranging from classical logistic regression to advanced ensemble-based models. To provide reliable data representation, using a Medical Diagnosis dataset constructed from patient profiles, the dataset is pre-processed utilising imputation techniques, one-hot encoding for categorical features, and conventional scaling for numerical features. Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) is applied to iteratively select the most relevant predictors, enhancing interpretability and reducing redundancy. Classifier performance including stochastic gradient descent (SGD), random forest, gradient boosting, logistic regression and support vector machines (SVM) which is evaluated on stratified train-test splits using accuracy, confusion matrix, classification report, and ROC-AUC metrics. Results reveal the relative strengths and drawbacks of these models when addressing mixed-type data and imbalanced outcomes. This comparative study highlights the value of ensemble approaches in enhancing classification performance and offers insights into feature relevance and model selection for prediction tasks in structured datasets.

title: Design and Development of an Integrated Water Spray and Brush System for Solar Panel Cleaning
authors: Maaizatul Zolkapli, Muhammad Mustaqim Mohamed Muhizam, Azween Hadiera Hishamuddin, Shahril Irwan Sulaiman, Ahmad Sabirin Zoolfakar, Rozina Abdul Rani, Marianah Masrie
abstract: Solar energy facilitates the global transition to renewables; however, dirt accumulation can reduce efficiency by 30 percent, and existing cleaning technologies remain ineffective, expensive, and water-intensive. This project aims to develop an innovative solar panel cleaning system that integrates a water spray mechanism and a mechanical brush, all controlled by an Arduino-based system, to overcome these restrictions. The objective was to create an environmentally sustainable, cost-effective, and energy-efficient solution that consumes minimal water while assuring adequate cleaning. The system could autonomously traverse the panel, directed by limit switches that regulate the directional trajectory. The device maneuvered the cleaning brush along the panel via two motors, while a third motor regulated the rotation. The system's performance was assessed by comprehensive testing, emphasizing cleaning efficiency, water usage, and adaptation to various environmental circumstances. The system improves solar panel energy efficiency by decreasing soiling, while conserving water and reducing maintenance expenses, hence providing dependable performance under diverse environmental conditions. This project aims to enhance the efficacy, sustainability, and scalability of solar panel cleaning, thereby significantly benefiting the solar energy sector and promoting the broader adoption of renewable energy technologies.

title: Broadband Modeling and Stability Analysis of DFIG Grid-Side Converters for Offshore Wind Farm Clusters
authors: Beini Cheng, Qihui Liu, Shuqian Meng, Xinyi Chen, Xipeng Cai, Yihua Zhu, Chao Luo
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the increasing integration of wind power into the grid, wide-frequency oscillations caused by power electronic converters have become a critical stability issue. This paper presents a wide-frequency modeling approach for the grid-side converter (GSC) of a doubly-fed induction generator (DFIG) under grid voltage disturbances. The proposed model comprehensively considers the phase-locked loop (PLL) angle disturbance induced by grid voltage perturbations and establishes the relationship between AC-side disturbances and power/DC voltage variations. A small-signal model is derived to relate power disturbances and DC voltage fluctuations to grid voltage amplitude and phase perturbations. Simulations in Simulink validate the derived model, showing the frequency-dependent behavior of key matrix elements under wide-frequency disturbances. The impact of control parameters such as PLL and DC voltage regulator gains on system stability is analyzed, and suggestions for mitigating wide-frequency oscillations are provided.

title: A hybrid wireless tracking method based on electromagnetic tracking and IMU
authors: Yuming Fu, Xiaoyang Wu, Yong-Xin Guo
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid 6-DoF wireless tracking method that fuses a 6-axis inertial measurement unit (IMU) with electromagnetic tracking (EMT). The IMU resolves orientation ambiguities caused by the lack of phase reference in wireless EMT, while the EMT compensates for long-term IMU drift, effectively replacing the role of the magnetometer. The experiment validates the effectiveness of the proposed method. The system achieves a position error of 2.38 ± 1.36 mm and an orientation error of 3.4± 1.6 °. A tunable update rate of 1-50 Hz enables a trade-off between accuracy and power consumption, ranging from 8.1 mW to 109.7 mW.

title: Bio-Inspired Neuro-Swarm Communication Protocol with Dynamic Spectrum Intelligence for IoT and UAV Networks
authors: Thillaiyarasi S, Lincy Golda Careline S, S L Priyenga, Nansy K
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: With the rapid proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices and the increasing use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) in dynamic environments, the need for adaptive, reliable, and energy-efficient communication protocols has become paramount. Conventional routing and spectrum assignment algorithms find it difficult to address the non-stationary and decentralization of such networks. In order to address them, this paper suggests the Bio-Inspired Neuro-Swarm Communication Protocol (BNSCP) in combination with Dynamic Spectrum Intelligence to optimize communication in the UAV-assisted IoT networks. The protocol models neuro-swarm agent nodes with spiking neural network logic of forwarding packets and ant colony optimization and energy-wise mobility and relative positioning. Multi-Armed Bandit learning is used to improve spectrum sensing to allow real-time selection of channels and the neuro-immune anomaly detection layer guarantees security and reliability in adversarial environments. It has been shown in experiments that the proposed model is much more effective than the traditional protocols such as AODV, LEACH, and even the newest learning-based models. In particular, BNSCP delivers packets with a Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) of 94.7, end-to-end delay per packet is reduced to 139 ms, spectrum is used more efficiently up to 86% and energy consumption is reduced by 20% over current baselines. Further, the neuroimmune model has an accuracy of 96.5% in intrusion detection with a false alarm rate of 4.8% false alarm rate. BNSCP is a powerful and scalable solution to the next-generation IoT-UAV ecosystems as a combination of the bio-inspired intelligence with the dynamic spectrum learning. This is a prospective implementation base of adaptive mission-critical systems of smart agriculture, disaster response, and real-time surveillance.

title: High-Precision Control Method for Visual Composite Robots Using Continuous PID Sliding Mode Tracking with Extended High-Gain Observer
authors: Lu Chen, Shiyuan Wei, Xinyu Zhang, Qilong Miao, Chenfei Xie, Yuhang Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Composite robots are high-performance systems that integrate various cutting-edge intelligent technologies. They have been widely applied in multiple fields, driving the deep development and innovation of intelligent applications. With the continuous advancement of technologies like deep learning, machine vision, and pattern recognition, composite robots are now capable of efficiently perceiving complex environments. This capability opens up more possibilities for autonomous decision-making and the execution of advanced tasks. The control precision of the end-effector is particularly critical, as it directly influences the range of complex tasks it can perform. To address this, this paper proposes a high-precision tracking control method for a six-degree-of-freedom robotic arm that integrates PID (Proportional–Integral–Derivative) control with sliding mode control. The aim is to enhance the accuracy of intelligent robotic systems in dynamic environments. The system’s uncertainties are modeled and compensated, and the Extended High-Gain Observer (EHGO) is used to estimate system disturbances in real time. This ensures the asymptotic convergence of the closed-loop system error, enabling high-precision synchronous tracking control. Experimental results confirm that the proposed control algorithm achieves outstanding performance on both simulation and practical validation platforms. It proves capable of effectively addressing complex dynamic environments and multi-task scenarios.

title: Research on Bearing Fault Diagnosis Based on Synchronous Compressed Wavelet Transform and Multi-scale Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Mengzhao Ge, Yuhang Chen, Haifeng Liu, Kai Chen
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that existing rolling bearing fault diagnosis methods based on CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) struggle to effectively mine and utilize multi-scale information in data, a rolling bearing fault diagnosis method with multi-scale convolution feature fusion is proposed. A convolutional neural network MCNN (Multi-Scale Convolution Neural Network) structure with multi-scale feature extraction and fusion capabilities is recursively established to enhance the model's understanding of input signals. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified using the Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) database. Synchrosqueezing wavelet transform is applied for spectral analysis of rolling bearing signals, and spectral samples are input into the MCNN network. Data analysis shows the method achieves high fault diagnosis accuracy, providing an efficient and reliable new scheme for bearing fault diagnosis.

title: Trends in Beam WPT Technology and Its Applications of the 920 MHz WPT System
authors: J. Tsumochi, N. Kodate, Y. Tanabe
abstract: In recent years, research on Wireless Power Transmission (WPT) technology using microwaves and millimeter waves has been gaining momentum. Beam WPT is expected to become an essential technology in the future Internet of Everything (IoE) society, with some products already released. Aeterlink Corp. also commercially released AirPlug™ in 2024, and more than 700 AirPlug™ transmitters are currently in operation in Japan, primarily in commercial buildings. An analysis of the implementation of AirPlug™, aimed at improving air-conditioning temperature control, confirmed not only its effect in stabilizing room temperature but also its effectiveness in reducing energy consumption.

title: Vehicle-UAV Cooperative Reconnaissance Path Optimization Based on Improved Variable Neighborhood Search
authors: YiDan Wang, Zhihao Luo, Danni Xie, Haibo Liu, Jianmai Shi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In response to the large-scale and high real-time requirements in the field of vehicle–Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) cooperative reconnaissance, this paper proposes a one-vehicle–multi-UAV Team Orienteering Problem (TOP) reconnaissance model. To address this problem, this study designs a clustering- and greedy-based initial solution generation algorithm, develops fifteen path optimization operators, and propose a hybrid algorithm that combines Variable Neighborhood Search (VNS) with Simulated Annealing (SA). Extensive experiments on large-scale instances demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves improvements of 2.3%, 2.1%, and 0.2% in solution quality over the hybrid Adaptive Variable Neighborhood Search with Simulated Annealing, the Adaptive Variable Neighborhood Search, and the Variable Neighborhood Search algorithms, respectively, showing a significant advantage.

title: High-Performance X-Band Semi-Transparent Metamaterial Absorber Utilizing Flexible PDMS and Resistive Elements
authors: Wahaj Abbas Awan, Domin Choi, Jaemin Lee, Niamat Hussain, Seong Gyoon Park, Dongkyu Sim, Nam Kim
abstract: This work presents design and analysis of a metamaterial absorber designed for X-band applications. Unlike conventional rigid or semi-flexible material, this works is made up using highly flexible material polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) to target conformal surfaces and flexible devices. The ground and upper structure is made up of conductive fabric that results in visibly transparent devices along with achieving high absorptivity of > 90%. The unit cell comprises of a compact size of 6.25 mm × 6.25 mm that correspond to electrical length of 0.16 λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> × 0.16 λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>. The structure is made up using a squared loop design which is then loaded with two tilted stubs forming an X-shape structure. Moreover, 8 resistors are inserted to enhance the performance of the absorber. The Design and analysis of the absorber is conducted using commercial EM software CST. Furthermore, a comparison table is also provided to highlight the key contribution of the proposed study.

title: Deep Learning Models for Predicting Service Innovation Outcomes in Telecom Networks
authors: Syed Mohammed Ghouse, Anil PS, Naveen C Sankannanavar, Skanda N R, Jacinth Paul G, Mohd Ajaz Khan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: There is a requirement for an accurate forecast of the effectiveness of service innovation so that strategic choices can be made in telecommunication networks. The intricate and non-linear coupling of operational limitations, end-user behavior, and network efficiency needs to be addressed in the forecast. Classical models are made inadequate by the time-varying and high degree of interdependence of telecom data. The network topology of this research consists of the Transformer-Bi-LSTM-Attention Network (TBLA-Net) for multi-dimensional feature embedding, a bidirectional long short-term memory (LSTM) for temporal sequence modeling, and an attention layer for dynamic feature relevance weighting. An extensive dataset is used for model training and evaluation, including operational KPIs, consumer metrics, and innovation of services indicators. After normalization, the target variable is assigned to the Service Innovation Outcome (SIO). The Transformer-only, GRU-Attention, and CNN-LSTM baselines are better than TBLA-Net in prediction accuracy, which is proven by experiments. The approach can notably reduce the value of RMSE and MAPE while keeping the accuracy rate at 98.64% and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> value at 0.976. Data-driven practices can be implemented more conveniently in constantly evolving telecom networks by leveraging the interpretable and scalable innovation outcome prediction of this technology.

title: High-Output-Power Sub-Harmonic Injection-Locked Colpitts Oscillator
authors: Nicola Pelagalli, Andrea Malignaggi, Corrado Carta
abstract: This paper introduces a Colpitts oscillator with sub-harmonic injection locking, designed for high output power and even-order frequency conversion. A topology improvement is proposed with a common-base stage directly connected to the oscillator push-push node in order to reduce excess saturation induced by undesired odd-order harmonics. Simulations show that this solution brings a minimum 2 dB excess output power when compared to conventional topologies. Based on the proposed approach, a fourth-harmonic injection-locked oscillator was designed and fabricated in a 130-nm SiGe BiCMOS technology. The fabricated chip occupies an active core area of only 0.33 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and achieves a measured peak output power of 4.3 dBm; a DC-to-RF efficiency of 2.6%, and a 99–111 GHz tuning range.

title: A Ku-band CMOS Variable-Gain Phase Shifter for Upper Mid-Band 6G Communication
authors: Eunchae Jo, Mingyu Lee, Haram Park, Hyeonwon Song, Eunsu Mo, Seunghun Wang, Huidong Lee, Bonghyuk Park, Seungchan Lee, Jinseok Park
abstract: This paper presents a 13.8–20.7 GHz variable-gain phase shifter (VGPS) for upper mid-Band 6G communication, fabricated in a 65-nm RF CMOS process. The proposed VGPS incorporates a loading effect-resilient I/Q signal generator, an impedance-invariant vector summer, an interstage matching network, a digital-to-analog converter (DAC), and a quadrant selection DPDT switch. The interconnection between the I/Q generator and the vector summer is impedance-matched to minimize reflection and improve the gain of the VGPS. The VGPS supports 6-bit phase and 7-bit gain control. Measurement results demonstrate a maximum insertion loss of –4.5 dB, with RMS phase and gain errors of 1.87° and 0.5 dB, respectively, across the operating frequency range.

title: Integration of RF MEMS and CMOS RFIC for Infrared Sensing
authors: Pei-Hsiang Wang, Zhixing Lin, Yuen-Sum Ng, Melisa Gulseren, Mattew Benson, Yun-Shan Wang, Jun-Han Lin, Chun-Wei Hsu, Sheng-Fu Zhuang, Xin-Hao Huang, Sheng-Chun Chen, Sheng-Wei Shih, Qun Jane Gu, J. Sebastián Gómez-Díaz, Huei Wang
abstract: This paper develops an innovative chip-level infrared (IR) spectroscopy system, based on the heterogeneous integration of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) and 90-nm process Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) technology. The system relies on merging radiofrequency (RF)-MEMS loaded with ultra-thin metasurfaces that provide spectrally-selective IR absorption and a cost-effective, highly integrated CMOS technology. The CMOS chip incorporates advanced noise suppression techniques to minimize signal interference. Specifically, the circuit is designed to capture signals reflected from the MEMS and uses a chopping clock to alternately select the reference path and the sensing path, thus suppressing common-mode noise (such as environmental coupling) and low-frequency receiver noise (such as flicker noise) while enhancing system performance. This first-of-its-kind IR sensors exhibit a responsivity of ~ 0.036 V/W at wavelength of 6 , a metric very competitive with IR photodetectors, and operates at room temperature without relying on expensive cooling facilities. We envision that this technology will greatly outperform IR photodetectors in the near future and will pave its way into fields like biosensing, spectroscopy, and, environmental monitoring, among others.

title: Simulation and Experimental Verification of a Four-Phase Interleaved Step-Up Converter for Ripple Suppression
authors: R.Seyezhai, V.Arulmozhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Power conversion systems for electric vehicles (EVs) must be reliable as well as efficient in order to improve performance, increase driving distance, and safeguard battery health. High thermal stress and ripple are common problems for traditional boost converters, which can reduce battery longevity and compromise reliability. This paper introduces a four-phase interleaved step-up converter (FPISC) intended to reduce ripple and increase efficiency in EV applications in order to address these issues. The suggested design balances the load, lowers thermal stress, and guarantees smoother power delivery by coordinating switching across several phases. A more stable power supply results from the efficient cancellation of input and output current ripple through the application of phase shift control. Through simulations under various load scenarios, the converter's performance is assessed, and important factors including ripple reduction, voltage gain, and overall efficiency are examined. Power MOSFETs are used to construct a hardware prototype, and real-world testing is used to verify the simulation results.

title:
A Flexible Millimeter-Wave Array Antenna with Ultralow-Loss BaTiO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    /MXene/PET Composite Substrate
authors: Luyang Sun, Hao Chen, Tong-Shuai Sun, Ze-Hui Chen, Jianing Li, Wenzhe Song, Weibing Lu
abstract: The escalating demand for high-performance millimeter-wave antennas in next-generation flexible communication systems urgently requires substrate materials that simultaneously deliver mechanical flexibility and exceptional dielectric properties. Conventional flexible substrates such as polyethylene terephthalate (PET) suffer from prohibitively high dielectric loss at millimeter-wave frequencies, severely limiting radiation efficiency. To address this limitation, we develop a novel flexible composite by embedding electrospun barium titanate (BaTiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) and MXene nanofibers into PET films, achieving marked dielectric loss reduction while retaining flexibility. A millimeter-wave array antenna fabricated with this composite substrate demonstrates enhanced radiation gain and mechanical flexibility, showing significant potential in millimeter-wave 5G wireless communication.

title: Fine-Grained Damage Diagnosis of Robot Cables Using a Transformer Encoder
authors: Seungju Moon, Jaepil Ban
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Industrial robot cables experience mechanical stress that leads to degradation and unexpected failures, making early fault detection essential. Existing diagnostic methods, including partial discharge analysis and reflectometry, are limited by voltage requirements, complex modeling, or insufficient ability to distinguish detailed damage levels. Artificial intelligence-based approaches have been explored, but most rely on simulated or simplified fault data and therefore cannot capture real degradation behavior. This study proposes a voltage-reflectionbased framework for fine-grained damage diagnosis of physically degraded robot cables. Ten mechanical damage levels ($\mathbf{0 - 1 0 0 \%}$) were implemented, and reflection signals were acquired using a Gaussian-enveloped linear chirp. A Transformer encoder was employed to learn local and global temporal patterns. The proposed model achieved high prediction accuracy and strong generalization to unseen damage intervals, demonstrating the practicality of reflection-signal learning for robot-cable health assessment.

title: A robust fault diagnosis method based on cross feature grouping and belief rule base with reliability
authors: Chunchao Zhang, Chao Chen, Lingling Fang, You Cao, Hongbin Shu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: A robust fault diagnosis method based on cross feature grouping (CFG) and belief rule base with reliability (BRBr) is designed. More specifically, how to measure sensor dependability is proposed to assess the reliability of acquired data, which is integrated into the BRB-r-based diagnosis process to evaluate the reliability of output results. Therefore, a distributed fault diagnosis model structure according to CFG is designed to enhance the robustness of the diagnosis method. The experiments show that the proposed CFG-BRB-r model can provide more accuracy and robustness than several existing methods.

title: Design of an Automotive Radar Antenna Based on a Novel Magnetoelectric Dipole
authors: Jianshuang Shao, Xiaodi Song
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper innovatively integrates a substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) feeding network with magnetoelectric dipole antenna elements, proposing a series-fed planar array antenna for 77GHz automotive collision avoidance radar systems. By matching cross-via modified magnetoelectric dipoles with SIW broadside inclined slots, the SIW inclined slots couple and excite the modified magnetoelectric dipoles to radiate electromagnetic waves. The antenna array achieves an operational bandwidth of 76.5-78 GHz, with a measured gain of 15.7 dBi at 77 GHz. The SIW feeding network configuration demonstrates excellent compatibility with output interfaces of front-end RF chips, enabling high-density integration for automotive radar systems.

title: Damping Method for High-Frequency Common-Mode Leakage Current in Electric Drive Systems Using High-bandwidth Current Sensing
authors: Jiguang Zhao, Zhenheng Xu, Yaqian Zhao, Yuehuan Lin
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the common-mode leakage current generated during motor drive system operation, this paper designs a non-contact toroidal inductive coil and proposes a novel damping structure based on it. The structure leverages the excellent common-mode current response characteristics of the non-contact coil by introducing a damping network into its secondary circuit, enabling passive absorption and suppression of leakage current. Compared with traditional common-mode chokes, the proposed design offers higher adaptability to high-frequency components and improved engineering flexibility. Moreover, it requires no external power supply, maintaining structural simplicity and reliability. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed passive damping structure achieves a suppression of 9 dB at the resonance point.

title: High-Speed ATE-Based Test Method for DRAM Read Eye Margin Failure Detection
authors: Jung Min Bak, Yoo-Chang Sung, Young-Ryeol Choi, Byung-Suk Woo, Si-Hyeong Cho, Kang-Yoon Lee
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Conventional read eye margin evaluation in DRAM relies on comparator-based shmoo measurements, which significantly increase test time in mass production. This paper presents a high-speed ATE-based test method that utilizes the Voltage Source Current Measure (VSIM) function in the parametric measurement unit (PMU) to detect read eye margin failures. By measuring the net current during DQ data toggling, the proposed method can capture both eye-height and eye-width defects without exhaustive shmoo scanning. Experimental validation on 40 LPDDR5 devices at 8.5 Gbps demonstrates that defective chips exhibit distinct positive or negative net-current offsets due to driver imbalance or duty-cycle distortion, whereas normal devices converge to nearly zero net current. Compared with conventional margin tests, the proposed method reduces test time by approximately 74% while maintaining comparable failure coverage. These results confirm that current-based margin detection is both efficient and production-practical, enabling reliable and cost-effective testing of high-speed, lowpower DRAM products in mass production.

title: TCAD Study of SEE-Induced Reliability Analysis of PDSOI FinFET Based Capacitorless 1T-DRAM
authors: Mitali Rathi, Guru Prasad Mishra
abstract: A comprehensive TCAD study of Single event effect on Capacitorless 1T-DRAM based on Partially depleted silicon on insulator (PDSOI) FinFET is demonstrated in this work. The device is well calibrated through 3D simulations using SILVACO ATLAS TCAD tool. First the memory operation and device characteristics is studied. The program operation is done by using Impact Ionization (II) method. Further the impact of high energy particle (HEP) strike on the Capacitorless 1T- DRAM operations such as Write-Hold-Read is carried out. The effect of various single event upset parameter such as HEP strike time, linear energy transfer (LET) value, HEP strike position are also evaluated. It is observed that as the device is scaled, it is highly susceptible to Single Event Effects (SEEs), even the drain and source regions are highly sensitive to SEEs. Hence, there is bit flip occurring in the device, and the read operation is corrupted, leading to malfunction of the DRAM memory.

title: A 22.6-28.3-GHz LNA with 22.1-dB Gain and 1.94-dB Noise Figure Using 90-nm CMOS Technology
authors: Yi-Chi Li, Yunshan Wang, Yu-Hsiang Cheng
abstract: A K/Ka-band low-noise amplifier (LNA) is designed and implemented in 90-nm CMOS technology for 5G new radio applications. The proposed LNA is designed using a current-reused technique to reduce power consumption while providing gain. Body-floating technique is employed to reduce the noise figure and power consumption. From the measurement results, the proposed LNA achieves a small-signal gain of 22.1 dB at 25.2 GHz, a 3-dB bandwidth of 5.7 GHz ranging from 22.6 to 28.3 GHz, a minimum noise figure of 1.94 dB at 28.1 GHz, and an average noise figure of 2.18 dB for 22.6 to 28.3 GHz with 6.7-mW power consumption. The measured IP1dB is -26 dBm and IIP3 is - 12.3 dBm. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this LNA demonstrates the lowest noise figure among published K/Ka-band LNAs.

title: Indoor Localization Using CNNs with Integrated Wi-Fi Fingerprints and Directional Information
authors: Taiga Arata, Satoru Aikawa, Shinichiro Yamamoto
abstract: This paper presents a method for indoor localization using Wi-Fi fingerprinting combined with directional features. We confirmed the effectiveness of using the received signal strength indicator and sensor-based direction information, and developed a multi-input convolutional neural network model that integrates both data types. By incorporating directional information into both the training and testing data, the consistency between them is enhanced, leading to improved positioning accuracy. The performance of our method was evaluated under various parameter settings, and its effectiveness was verified through experiments.

title: Multi-Timescale Hierarchical Coordination of Market-Based Day-Ahead Dispatch: Practical Applications and Prospects in CSG
authors: Xin Yin, Haoyong Chen, Yiping Chen, He Huang, Yuefeng Lu, Xin Zeng
abstract: A high proportion of grid-connected renewable energy in power systems represents an economically viable and reliable pathway toward achieving clean and low-carbon power systems. However, the safe and efficient integration of unstable and uncontrollable renewable energy sources remains a significant challenge for power grid operators. Moreover, indiscriminate investment in flexible resources may result in suboptimal resource utilization. Drawing on operational experiences from the power dispatching and controlling center of China Southern Grid (PDCC-CSG), this paper demonstrates how PDCC-CSG mobilizes flexible resources through dispatch mechanisms such as hierarchical coordination, multi-timescale coordination, and “power market plus dispatch” coordination approaches to enable the efficient utilization and consumption of renewable energy in scenarios where new energy accounts for more than 20 % of the total power generation. Furthermore, in order to cope with the scenarios with an even higher share of renewable energy, the future application of advanced cooperative and intelligent dispatch technologies is envisioned.

title: Dynamic Prototype Adaptation for Deep Multi-View Clustering
authors: Miao Jia, Zijian Chen, Qing Cheng, Xingchen Hu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Multi-view clustering (MVC) has garnered significant attention as a prominent unsupervised learning paradigm dedicated to multi-source data analysis. However, conventional clustering methods often exhibit limited capability in capturing expressive features from complex and large-scale datasets. To address this limitation, deep clustering frameworks have risen to prominence recently, attributed largely to their potent feature extraction mechanisms. Despite the progress, existing deep MVC methods still struggle to effectively handle the heterogeneity across views and often fail to produce prototypes that are adaptable to diverse data distributions. Therefore, we propose a novel framework named Dynamic Prototype Adaptation Deep Multi-view Clustering (DPAMVC), which jointly performs representation learning and clustering by dynamically aligning and adapting prototypes across multiple views. Specifically, compact latent representations are first extracted using view-specific encoders, followed by a prototype generation module and a high-level feature extraction layer. Through contrastive learning guided by adaptive fusion weights, view-specific prototypes are dynamically aligned to enhance consistency across views. A prototype shrinkage mechanism is introduced to improve intraclass compactness and inter-class separability, while view-specific decoders are employed to reconstruct latent features and preserve view characteristics. The model is optimized end-to-end by jointly minimizing contrastive, shrinkage, and reconstruction losses. Comprehensive empirical evaluations on standard benchmarks validate that DPAMVC significantly outperforms current leading algorithms.

title: Photovoltaic Power Generation Forecasting Algorithm Based on Improved GWO and CNN-BiLSTM-Attention
authors: Fuyi Liu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the rapid development of new energy and the improvement of economic dispatch standards in power systems, accurately forecasting photovoltaic (PV) power generation data is crucial for power system scheduling and planning. To address the challenges of low prediction accuracy caused by the uncertainty and nonlinearity of PV power output, this paper proposes a PV data forecasting algorithm that combines an improved Gray Wolf Optimization (IGWO) algorithm with a CNN-BiLSTM-Attention model. First, the BiLSTM captures the bidirectional dependencies in the PV data time series, combined with CNN to extract local spatial features, and an attention mechanism is introduced to dynamically allocate parameter weights, enhancing the response coefficients of key parameters. Meanwhile, to overcome the conventional GWO algorithm’s tendency toward local convergence and low optimization efficiency, new individuals with information memory are introduced, and the convergence factor is non-linearly modified based on integrating the attention mechanism into the information transmission process. Finally, the IGWO algorithm is used to optimize the hyperparameters of the CNN-BiLSTM-Attention model to improve prediction accuracy and stability. Ablation experiments are conducted using classic PV power generation data and compared with six mainstream existing forecasting algorithms. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms others across five prediction metrics, achieving higher accuracy in PV power forecasting and providing a solid foundation for optimizing power dispatch and ensuring stable operation of power systems

title: Edge-Optimized Machine Learning Model for Real-Time Prediction of Feed and Water Intake Using Multimodal Sensor Data
authors: Lalith Reddy Tekulapalli, Anshika Verma, Aditya Ray Baruah, Varshith Srinivasa Peddada, Diptanshu Malviya, Likhita Paul Indupalli, Anakhi Hazarika
abstract: The growing integration of digital technologies in agriculture is reshaping livestock farming by enabling automation, data-driven decision-making, and real-time monitoring. Among critical tasks, the timely and accurate prediction of feed and water intake is essential for ensuring animal health, early disease detection, and sustainable resource management. Traditional manual methods are labor-intensive, error-prone, and lack responsiveness to dynamic conditions, while existing smart solutions often rely heavily on cloud infrastructure that introduces latency, increasing operational costs, and limiting usability in rural or resource-constrained areas. This paper presents a lightweight, edge-compatible machine learning (ML) model for real-time prediction of livestock feed and water intake using multimodal sensor data. The proposed approach emphasizes optimizing the model size to minimize dependence on cloud infrastructure to make it suitable for deployment in connectivity-limited farm environments. The use of systematic feature selection and correlation-based modeling enhances the interpretability and accuracy of the ML models, including Random Forest, CatBoost, XGBoost, and Neural Networks. Experimental results validate the performance of the proposed solution for feed and water intake prediction that enables timely and autonomous interventions and promotes operational efficiency, sustainability, and scalability in modern farming practices.

title: A Study on Supply Voltage Control for VOH Drift Reduction in TSV I/O Interfaces
authors: Hyeeun Cho, Won-Young Lee
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: In this paper, various NN driver architectures are compared and analyzed to address the VOH-drift problem occurring in TSV (Through-Silicon Via)-based HBM (High Bandwidth Memory) interfaces. To mitigate the slew rate degradation and power increase caused by the large parasitic capacitance of TSVs, three structures are compared: conventional NN driver, NN driver with a leaker NMOS, and the NN driver with a VOH drift controlled pre-driver. Simulation results show that the conventional NN driver exhibits significant VOH-drift, while the leaker NMOS structure can eliminate the drift but causes a considerable increase in static power consumption. The VOH drift controlled pre-driver improves power efficiency. However, it introduces an undershoot phenomenon. Moreover, reducing the main driver voltage effectively suppresses VOH drift, but a trade-off relationship exists in which the drift increases as the pre-driver voltage decreases. This study provides a design direction for simultaneously improving power efficiency and signal integrity in HBM interfaces.

title: G-SwinTextSpotter: A Guidance-Initialized Framework for Synergistic Scene Text Spotting
authors: Junyan Zhao, Shimin Li, Rui Zhu, Tianqi Zhou, Tianxiang He
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: As a core task of Optical Character Recognition (OCR), end-to-end scene text spotting aims to detect and recognize text instances from natural images in a unified framework. It has significant applications in many fields such as autonomous driving and industrial automation. Recent methods based on query-based iterative refinement have achieved remarkable success, yet they often suffer from slow convergence and potential inaccuracy stemming from randomly initialized queries. Concurrently, the synergy between detection and recognition, crucial for handling arbitrarily-shaped text, has been paid much attention. G-SwinTextSpotter, a novel framework that enhances a synergistic text spotter with a guidance-initialized mechanism is proposed in this paper. The proposed approach addresses the "cold start" problem of the iterative detector by introducing a lightweight, coarse-grained guidance generator which can provide high-quality initial proposals. These proposals can provide a rather good initialization for a multi-stage refinement process, which is deeply coupled with the recognition task via a synergistic conversion module. This design allows the proposed model to benefit from both robust initialization and profound synergy between localization and recognition. Extensive experiments on public benchmarks, including Total-Text and CTW1500, demonstrate that G-SwinTextSpotter significantly outperforms benchmark methods, showcasing superior performance and faster convergence.

title: Analysis and Simulation of Temperature Control in an Indirect Combustion Furnace Using an Auxiliary Fan
authors: Ke-Han Su, Yi-Chia Liu, Yu-Heng Chen, Po-Ch Chen, Kun-Cheng Huang, Yin-Syuan Chen
abstract: In industrial furnace heat treatment, temperature critically affects the grain structure, phase transformation, and resulting properties of metallic materials, making precise control essential. Indirect combustion furnaces typically employ radiant tubes for indirect heating, but prolonged operation under fixed flame conditions can cause localized heat concentration, tube fatigue, or rupture. Auxiliary fans are often used for thermal mixing; however, fixed-speed operation may still result in uneven heat distribution and reduced combustion stability. This study develops subsystem and control models of the furnace and proposes a uniform temperature control strategy that integrates pulse combustion with variable-speed fan regulation. Flame size and duty cycle adjustments equalize heat distribution within the radiant tube, mitigating local flame effects and extending tube service life, while adaptive fan speed control improves temperature uniformity and enhances workpiece quality. Simulation results show that the proposed strategy maintains furnace temperature within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> of the setpoint and limits radiant tube variation to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, demonstrating both effectiveness and practical industrial applicability.

title: Powerlist-Based High-Level Programming Model for Parallelism
authors: Jeya Ganesh M R, Anshu S Anand
abstract: Designing efficient parallel programs is a nontrivial task that requires one to have an in-depth knowledge of the underlying parallel architecture, memory hierarchy and programming model besides other aspects. This may require considerable efforts, time, and cost. To improve the programmers' productivity, there is a need for parallel abstractions that can simplify the programmers job of first specifying the computation and then optimizing it for performance. Powerlist [1] is one such potential parallel abstraction that is able to exploit both parallelism and recursion at the same time, resulting in succinct representations of computations. In this work, we propose the use of Powerlist as a Domain Specific Language (DSL) and implement it as a Source-to-Source compiler that translates the high-level powerlist specification into sequential and parallel C++ programs. Several new powerlist specifications were also devised for computations and in this process, the powerlist notation was also enriched. The proposed framework considerably improves the programmers' productivity by providing a high-level abstraction resulting in succinct and intuitive specification of computations, absolving them of the task of exploiting parallelism and tuning for performance, which is taken care of by the implementation.

title: Real Time Sign Language Recognition Using MediaPipe and Random Forest Classifier
authors: Ajay Kumar Naik G, Imon Kumar Biswas, Ch. V. Rama Rao
abstract: Deaf individuals typically use Sign Language (SL), which involves the use of hand and finger motions, to engage in communication with others. However, when interacting with hearing individuals who may not be familiar with SL, there is often a notable challenge in translating these gestures. To address this communication barrier, various research efforts have focused on employing computer vision techniques and sensor data for recognizing hand movements. This paper presents the development of a Sign Language Recognition (SLR) system utilizing a computer vision-based approach. Here, the data is represented in the form of coordinates extracted using Google MediaPipe from individual frames of video. The extracted features through this representation are fed to the Classifier. Here, the random forest machine learning algorithm is used as a classifier. The experimental results reveal that the Sign Language Recognition (SLR) system using Random Forest Classifier (RFC) achieved an accuracy of 99.777%. This performance is superior to that of other considered machine learning algorithms.

title: Design and Implementation of Library Role-Playing System Based on Hybrid Recommendation Algorithm
authors: Yajun Liu, Yongliang Wang, Aimin Li, Rong Fei
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Against the backdrop of digital technology driving the transformation of libraries towards digitalization and intelligence, users' demands for immersive experiences and personalized services are increasing. Traditional libraries face challenges such as insufficient user stickiness and low levels of personalized services. This paper, based on the concept of gamified library services, and combining current popular technologies in the field of artificial intelligence and Android development, designs and implements a Library Role-Playing System based on a hybrid recommendation algorithm.This system enhances user engagement with role-playing games as its core format. It innovatively proposes a hybrid recommendation algorithm based on deep learning, organically integrating collaborative filtering and content-based recommendation strategies. This approach not only uncovers common user preferences but also accurately matches individual needs, overcoming the limitations of single strategies and achieving complementary advantages. Furthermore, a bidirectional feedback mechanism allows for real-time capture of users' dynamic interests during role-playing games to match current needs before recommendations are made, and for optimization of recommendations based on user feedback afterward, ensuring continuous improvement in book recommendation effectiveness with each interaction.Comparative experiments demonstrate that the hybrid recommendation model has excellent comprehensive recommendation performance, avoids the shortcomings of a single recommendation model, and can help traditional libraries achieve AI empowerment and improve the level of personalized services.

title: A 26-GHz Down-Conversion Receiver for 5G Scalable Multi-Mode Application
authors: Min Lu, Zhilin Chen, Zhoutao Lu, Yong Wang, Songsong Cao, Liyang Li, Wenbo Tian, Sheng Huang, Siyu Lin, Xiaoning Zhang, Runyu Liu, Zekun Li, Jie Hu, Keqing Ouyang, Zhijun Long
abstract: This paper presents a down-conversion receiver featuring architecture supporting 5G scalable and multi-mode phased arrays. The receiver adopts a distributed gain control architecture to trade-off the linearity and NF performances, enabling support for scalable and multi-mode applications. Additionally, a switched-capacitor array is used in the IF-domain block to extend the application of the IF interface. Integrating an LNA, an RFVGA, a Mixer, and an IFVGA, the receiver is fabricated by a 65-nm SOI process. It realizes a maximal conversion gain of 25.5 dB at 25.4 GHz with 3-dB RF bandwidth for 21.8-28.1 GHz. The measured minimum NF is 4.6 dB and 3-dB IF bandwidth is from 3.4-6.8 GHz. An input 1-dB compression point (IP1dB) at maximal gain state is achieved-13.3 dBm at 26 GHz. The receiver enables a 22-dB gain control range with a 1-dB step. Measurement results demonstrate the receiver characters high linearity or low NF performance mode by adjusting the gain control state of RFVGA and IFVGA.

title: Multi-State Encoding for Robust Optimization of Pixelated Planar Bandpass Filters with Manufacturability
authors: Woojun Lee, Jungmin Lee, Jeffrey S. Walling
abstract: A novel design methodology is proposed to enhance the performance of planar pixelated bandpass filters by introducing multi-state pixels beyond the conventional binary ("0"/"1") paradigm. A custom designed triangular meshing scheme is employed to balance the accuracy and simulation speed of the optimization engine based on method-of-moments (MoM), while maintaining manufacturability of the inversely designed filters. The effectiveness of this approach is demonstrated through the design of a bandpass filter achieving a -1-dB S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</inf> bandwidth for spanning 8.8–10.5 GHz, while achieving excellent stop-band rejection under -30 dB from 3-7.4 GHz and 11.5-15 GHz, which is validated by a full-wave solver.

title: Compact 5.8–15.8-GHz Marchand Balun with Narrow Notched Band Based on Three-Line Coupled Scheme for 6G Communication
authors: Zihuan Chen, Jie Zhou, Xun Luo
abstract: In this paper, a broadband Marchand balun with narrow notched band and wide stopband is presented. The wideband differential characteristic is achieved by the Marchand balun topology with broadside tight-coupling. Besides, a compensation line is introduced into the tight-coupled line for balance improvement. Then, to cancel the interference within the operation band, the three-line coupled scheme is adopted to replace the coupled line in the Marchand balun. Finally, the stopband rejection is enhanced by three low-pass units (LPUs) embedded in the input and output ports. To verify the mechanisms mentioned above, a wideband Marchand balun operating from 5.8 to 15.8 GHz with a 3-dB fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 92.6% is designed and fabricated. The measured minimum in-band insertion loss is 0.75 dB, excluding 3-dB power splitting loss. Besides, the in-band phase- and amplitude-imbalances are less than 3<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">◦</sup> and 1.2 dB, respectively. The measurement exhibits a notched band with center frequency of 8.9 GHz, which has merits of 10-dB notched FBW of 4.5%.

title: Multi-Task Frequency Attentive Network for Lightweight Small Aerial Target Classification
authors: Yan Gong, Hanjun Zhao, Hui Chu
abstract: Accurate classification of low-altitude, slow-moving, small radar cross-section aerial targets, such as drones and birds, is essential for radar surveillance. Among existing studies, traditional machine learning methods often struggle with performance, while popular deep learning models, such as ResNet and YOLO, tend to be overly complex and computationally intensive. To achieve a balance between model performance and complexity, this paper proposes a lightweight multi-task frequency attentive network that leverages 128-point fast Fourier transform spectral features derived from radar echoes. The proposed network architecture integrates a convolutional encoder-decoder with a lightweight classification head, where input features are first extracted by the encoder with adaptive frequency attention using multi-scale depthwise convolutions. Latent features are then jointly optimized within a collaborative multi-task framework involving both the decoder and the classifier, enabling compact and efficient end-to-end learning. Experiments show that the proposed model achieves promising results with a mere 0.23M parameters and 4.53M FLOPs.

title: Development of a High-Snr, Feature-Based Machine Learning Model for Accurate Multiclass Lung Sound Classification
authors: Jose Antonio J. Loren, Andre Joaquin D. Adiz, Al Fred C. Picana, Arvy C. Santos, J.R. S. Templanza, Seigfred V. Prado, Wally Enrico M. Ingco
abstract: Lung diseases are one of the leading causes of global morbidity and mortality, accounting for more than four million deaths annually according to the World Health Organization. Although machine learning has shown promise in automating lung sound classification, most existing models are either focused on binary lung sound classification or have a narrow subset of abnormal sounds, hindering their diagnostic utility. This study addresses these limitations by developing a high-SNR, multiclass, and accurate classification model capable of identifying normal lung sounds and five abnormal types: wheezes, crackles, stridor, rhonchi, and pleural rubs. Various feature extraction techniques were compared, including the standard Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) model, an enhanced-MFCC (eMFCC) model, and a hybrid Discrete Wavelet Transform-Short-Time Fourier Transform (DWT-STFT). The input-output Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) analysis confirmed a significant improvement in signal quality, with median SNR increasing from 16 dB (MFCC) to 35 dB (eMFCC), validating the effectiveness of the enhancement techniques. Classification was performed using Support Vector Machine (SVM) and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), with the highest accuracy of 97.69 % and 98.34 %, respectively, achieved using eMFCC mean features. The results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed high-SNR feature-based model for accurate multiclass lung sound classification.

title: Influence of Thermal Fluctuations on the Inverse Piezoelectric Effect in AlGaN/GaN HEMTs
authors: Junya Takeda, Soichi Sano, Hirohisa Taguchi
abstract: With the growing demand for high-performance, high-frequency electronic devices, the development of devices based on gallium nitride (GaN) has garnered increasing interest. In this study, we examined the current-voltage characteristics of AlGaN/GaN high-electron-mobility transistors subjected to electrical stress. Stress application induced a kink effect, which became more pronounced with increasing gate reverse-bias stress and stress application duration. This observation indicated that local lattice strain, caused by the inverse piezoelectric effect, degraded the device performance. When combined with lattice vibrations owing to heat, this strain led to further degradation. However, the combined effect eventually reached saturation. Moreover, lattice vibrations likely suppressed electron trapping and strain during stress application, resulting in a nonlinear performance degradation trend. The inverse piezoelectric effect was sensitive to thermal fluctuations, resulting in instability. Furthermore, transient response measurements of the drain current revealed a long-term current recovery process, indicating a variation in the interaction between polarization and thermal fluctuations.

title: Compact Self-Matching Microwave Plasma Source with a Wide Impedance Bandwidth
authors: Jeong-Hun Park, Seung-Jun Park, Moon-Que Lee
abstract: This paper introduces a compact self-matching microwave plasma source adopting a λ/2-probe, TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</inf> and TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</inf> mode cavities, and a coaxial antenna. TM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</inf> mode is realized by the λ/2-probe and λ/2 perimeter slot. Both cavities are coupled via the probe. The antenna consisting of a blunted cone and a metal coaxial rod plays a role in an impedance transformer. As a result, the designed microwave plasma source exhibits a wide impedance bandwidth. A return loss is greater than 25 dB in the frequency range of 2.37 to 2.52 GHz under plasma conditions modeled with a real permittivity of 0.3 and a dielectric loss of 2.

title: A Scenario-Driven Efficient Federated Unlearning Method for Multi-Granularity Data Removal
authors: Lei Cen, Guohao Li, Li Yang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: With the emergence of the "right to be forgotten" and increasing privacy awareness, efficient data unlearning in federated learning (FL) has become a key research issue. Although FL avoids centralized storage of raw data, the global model may still retain sensitive local information, posing privacy risks. Federated unlearning (FU) aims to remove the influence of specific data from an existing model, but current methods are often inefficient and lack comprehensive unlearning capabilities. This paper proposes MGFU, a scenario-driven multi-granularity federated unlearning method. In sample-level and client-level unlearning scenarios where only a minority of clients require unlearning, the unlearning clients adopt a dual-head model. We design an adaptive interpolation strategy for this model to achieve rapid forgetting and optimal unlearning performance without disrupting normal training. In class-level unlearning scenarios, as well as sample-level and client-level unlearning scenarios where a majority of clients require unlearning, the unlearning clients retain only the unlearning head. To further reduce communication overhead and unlearning training time, we introduce the LoRA strategy and a data compression algorithm. Extensive experiments on MNIST and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that MGFU achieves effective unlearning while maintaining model accuracy.

title: Sentiment Analysis for Detection and Categorization of Extremist Affiliations on Social Media
authors: Anil K. S. Chauhan, Santosh Belagalla, Prashanth G. K, Vijo V. Vincent, Sunil Vakayil, Anshul Saxena
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The proposed study is dedicated to the application of the sentiment analysis to identify and label extremist affiliations on social media. The suggested solution uses spaCy to normalize and tokenize the text and provide a high quality of data input. We use Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) using scikit-learn to select only the most relevant features eliminating duplication and improving model efficiency. The main part of the model is an optimized BERT classifier, which is implemented using the library Hugging Face Transformers, and it enables the proper sentiment analysis and detection of extremist content. The model development, training, and deployment are done with the help of TensorFlow, it has scalability and is capable of processing in real-time. The model is very accurate, precise, recalls and the F1 scores are high indicating that the model is very successful in detecting extremist content on the social media platforms. This paper will aid in the enhancement of the online content regulation as well as improving the security using the automated detection algorithms.

title: Occupancy Driven Optimization for Comfort and Energy Management in Smart Building
authors: Ghulam Fizza, Kushsairy Kadir, Haidawati Nasir, Mohammad Rashid
abstract: Achieving an optimal trade off between comfort and energy consumption in smart buildings remains a complex challenge, especially under dynamic occupancy conditions. Traditional optimization frameworks often neglect occupancy variation, resulting in energy inefficiencies or compromised occupant comfort. This study presents an occupancy aware optimization framework in which the objective weight between Comfort Index (CI) and Energy Gain (EG) remains fixed, while environmental constraints are dynamically adjusted based on occupancy. The approach is tested using three metaheuristic algorithms: Harris Hawks Optimization (HHO), Slime Mould Algorithm (SMA), and Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm (AOA), on a real world smart office dataset comprising 528 hourly observations. Results show that HHO achieved the highest average CI during occupancy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.9341)$</tex> with comparatively low energy consumption <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1327 \text{kWh})$</tex>, whereas SMA delivered the highest CI during non occupied periods (0.7195) with an average energy consumption of 1311 kWh. These findings validate the effectiveness of incorporating occupancy signals into smart building control, improving comfort satisfaction and energy efficiency without adjusting the objective weight.

title: Transcutaneous Auricular Vagus Nerve Stimulation for Cognitive Enhancement
authors: Yena Lee, Suh Yeon Moon, Junyoung Shin, Shinhee Noh, Jee Eun Sung, Sang Beom Jun
abstract: The vagus nerve, a cranial nerve extending from the brainstem to the abdomen, is well known to play crucial roles in parasympathetic regulation and communication between brain and the organs. Due to its extensive connections, the vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) have been explored for treatment of various neurological conditions such as epilepsy, depression, and so forth. This study investigated the effects of transcutaneous auricular vagus nerve stimulation (taVNS) on cognitive enhancement in both human and animal subjects. In rat animal behaviour study, taVNS enhanced cognitive function in a novel object recognition test. In human studies, older adults with hearing loss demonstrated significant cognitive improvements during taVNS.

title: Inductive/Capacitive Coupling Hybrid WPT for Implantable Medical Device: Basic Analysis of Coupler Structure
authors: Miyu Kodama, Dairoku Muramatsu
abstract: Wireless power transfer (WPT) is rapidly expanding beyond consumer and industrial applications and is now being investigated for wirelessly powering implantable medical devices. Efficiency losses caused by coil misalignment in inductive links and electrode spacing in capacitive links motivate a millimetre-scale inductive/capacitive hybrid coupler (ICCH-WPT). Electromagnetic field simulations of a realistically constructed layered abdominal model show a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.5\ \text{mm} \times 7\ \text{mm}$</tex> coupler delivering 5.85 mW at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \text{MHz}-66 \%$</tex> higher than a capacitive-only design-while meeting stringent international human-safety limits. The energy is effectively confined near the coupler, indicating negligible deep-tissue exposure in surrounding biological tissues with minimal unintended radiation. ICCH-WPT therefore satisfies the 3–5 mW power budget of modern neurostimulators and offers an alignment-tolerant, regulation-compliant link for next-generation implants.

title: Toward Ethical Cybersecurity: AI-Chatbot Integration with SIEM Technology for User Consent Management
authors: Stuart Daly, Teerath Kumar Menghwar, Mamoona Naveed Asghar
abstract: Cloud-based Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools play a crucial role in mitigating online threats by collecting data about users' internet usage. However, informed consent for the processing of this data is not always obtained, raising ethical concerns about data protection, privacy, user trust, and even regulatory compliance with General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
