An Artificial Intelligence (AI) chatbot can address the gap between online security and informed consent, by acting as an intermediary between users and their web browser. A sentiment analysis chatbot using machine learning (ML) was developed to classify user input as positive, negative, or neutral, employing Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques. Testing on public datasets helped select the best model based on classification accuracy. The sentiment analysis concept serves as the baseline for the SIEM Consent chatbot, where a deep learning (DL) model expands on the idea of classifying user input sentiments to include classifying user inputs associated with topics related to the consent process, e.g., SIEM, data usage, and consent itself. User authentication is mandatory, with their authentication timestamped and recorded in a SQLite database, providing an audit trail. The chatbot integrates with Wazuh Cloud SIEM for log collection via Wazuh agents and the Wazuh RESTful API. Built-in web browsers (Chrome/Edge) are locked through their Access Control Lists; browser access is only allowed by providing consent through the Chatbot.

title: Dual-Polarized, Lightweight, and Conformal L-band Antenna Array with RFSoC for UAV Platforms
authors: Xunlei Wang, Mohammad Ameen, Peizhuo Yang, Gong Chen, Koen Mouthaan
abstract: A dual-polarized, conformal, and lightweight 4×4 L-band antenna array tailored for unmanned aerial vehicle applications is proposed. The array is fabricated using stacked copper-cladded polyimide films and PF-4 foam layers, making it well-suited for weight-constrained airborne platforms. In the flat configuration, the antenna has a bandwidth of 1.17–1.32 GHz, cross-polarization levels better than 24 dB, a gain of approximately 19.9 dBi at 1.25 GHz, and stable radiation patterns across the operating band. RFSoC integration allows real-time phase control of each element, enabling beamforming and directional radiation in both flat and conformal configurations.

title: Speckle-Assisted Super-Resolution Microscopy for Enhanced Axial Imaging
authors: Hajun Yoo, Kwanhwi Ko, Sukhyeon Ka, Gwiyeong Moon, Hyunwoong Lee, Seongmin Im, Peng Xi, Donghyun Kim
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: We introduce axial interference speckle-assisted microscopy, achieving near-isotropic 3D super-resolution with a single objective lens. Mirror-generated speckle patterns and fluctuation analysis enhance axial resolution, enabling costeffective, multi-color live-cell imaging and dynamic tracking of subcellular processes.

title: Fuzzy Logic Empowered SAPF: A Smart Approach to Power Quality Enrichment
authors: Soundarrajan A, Balachander K, Nagamani Prabu A, Jayanthi G, Venkatesan M, Channu Lal
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Power quality (PQ) has become a significant concern in modern electrical networks due to the increasing use of nonlinear loads and renewable energy systems, which introduce current and voltage harmonics. To address these issues, this study presents a Shunt Active Power Filter (SAPF) controlled by a Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC) for effective PQ improvement. The system integrates both conventional PI and FLC schemes to regulate the DC-link voltage of the Voltage Source Inverter (VSI). Using instantaneous reactive power (p–q) theory, reference currents are generated, and a hysteresis current controller provides fast and accurate switching for the VSI. The MATLAB/Simulink-based model is tested under varying load and harmonic conditions. Results show that the FLC-based SAPF achieves better transient performance, reduced Total Harmonic Distortion (THD), and improved voltage stability compared to the PI-controlled system. Additionally, power quality analysis of a single-phase AC–DC converter feeding a DC motor demonstrates the controller’s capability to maintain stable operation under different load and firing conditions.

title: Improved YOLOv5 Network with GhostConv and CBAM for Ceramic Classification
authors: Chen Huang, Qihui Huang, Chengfu Yang, Zhan Tang, Xiaoli Peng, Jian Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Ceramic classification and detection is a key requirement for cultural heritage preservation and industrial quality inspection. Traditional methods face challenges such as insufficient texture feature extraction and the difficulty in balancing accuracy and deployment efficiency. This paper proposes an improved model (YOLOv5-GCB) based on YOLOv5 that integrates GhostConv convolution and Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) to simultaneously develop detection accuracy and model lightweight performance. The combination of these two modules helps maintain feature representation capability while reducing the computational burden during high-resolution image processing and minimizing background interference. To verify the effectiveness of YOLOv5-GCB, we construct a dataset containing 41 ceramic-related categories and compared it with the original YOLOv5, YOLOv5-GhostConv, and YOLOv5-CBAM models under the same conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that our model achieves a mAP@0.5 of 87.2%, a 5.1% improvement over the original YOLOv5s. The parameter count is reduced to 3.6M, a decrease of approximately 48.6% compared to the original YOLOv5s. The inference speed is 7.0 ms per image, enabling optimized and efficient deployment. YOLOv5-GCB offers a effective and dependable technical solution for the digital recording of ceramic artifacts and quality inspection in ceramic production.

title: Based on Improved Sparse Convolutional Feature Extraction and Loss-Based Data Analysis in Animal Movement Detection Using Drones
authors: A Vennela, B Sonia, Safeyah Tawil, V Josephine Sutha, Kambham Pratap Joshi, Ramya Maranan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: As a Deep Learning approach for detecting and tracking Tapanuli orangutan individuals from thermal infrared footage captured through the use of drones, we developed the improved sparse convolutional and loss-based analysis for drone-based animal movement detection (ISCFLA) model. The detection algorithm analyzes portions of video to affirm the species identification with a 90.25% accuracy upon confirmation by three specialized coders. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) approach was used for detection efficiency using annotated orthomosaics as inputs to the computational method. The CNN approach integrated an F1 score classification. A Linear Mixed Model (LMM) approach was used to test differences in the accuracy measures amongst temperature variation. A compound loss metric, sparse convolutional enhanced feature extraction module was developed to improve classification and localization. The revised loss metric function emphasizes difficult samples (Focal Loss (FL)) while the Complete Intersection over Union (CIoU) loss metric improved spatial accuracy of the tracked or detected objects. A Sparse Convolution Enhanced Feature Extraction Module improved effective portions of images, and reduced unnecessary computations and memory usage. The tracker algorithm used in this model ranked detections to ensure consistent tracking despite uncertain detections through the use of a Visual Particle Filter (VPF) utilizing FN on previous locations of particles initialized with bounding boxing center locations. The system computed features Local Binary Pattern (LBP) features within the Region of Interest (ROI) at 4 scales to return a 36-dimensional feature vector for effective target threat identification.

title: Automated Lung Lesion Segmentation with Minimal Number of Labeled CT Images
authors: Ishita Maiti, Namrata Kadasi, Nihar Domala, Aman Soni, Manjunatha Mahadevappa, Nirmalya Ghosh
abstract: An arduous task in medical image analysis is the automated segmentation of infected regions in a organ (for example, in lungs, segmentation of lung lesion), which is crucial for assessing the volumetric severity of infections and evaluating the effectiveness of subsequent treatments. The affected regions in diseased lung cases, called lung lesions, vary widely in their intensity, texture, contrast, location, and size. The similarity of intensities between the lesion and the healthy surrounding tissue bordering the lung makes lung as well as lesion segmentation more challenging, especially by classical image processing techniques. One solution is machine learning (ML) or deep learning (DL)-based methods, that learn segmentation models from datasets with lung lesion labeled by experts. Unfortunately, acquiring any labeled data in the healthcare sector for ML/DL algorithms is prohibitively costly due to the participation of skilled clinicians. Hence, the current study proposes a Random Forest (RF) based ML-method that utilizes a significantly reduced number of expert-labeled data for lung lesion segmentation. Eight different experiments with varying amounts of labeled data from two challenging benchmark datasets demonstrated encouraging results, comparable to state-of-the-art methods, reaching the highest precision values of 86.4 %, recall value of 78.1 %, and F1 score of 82.0 %.

title: Improving Dynamic Time Warping in Gesture Recognition for Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Yu Wu, Pin-Yu Lin, Yu-Chiu Lin, Min-Te Sun
abstract: Gesture recognition is a key component in developing intuitive and efficient human-computer interaction systems, enabling machines to interpret human intentions through body movement analysis. A common approach employs the Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) algorithm to compute similarity between keypoint sequences extracted via pose estimation from both reference and live video streams. While effective and flexible, DTW has limitations, including high space complexity and sensitivity to keypoint misidentification often seen in pose estimation. To address these issues, we propose two enhancements to the DTWbased gesture recognition pipeline. First, we apply a space compression technique to reduce memory usage without sacrificing performance. Second, we introduce a frame-skip mechanism to mitigate the impact of incorrectly detected keypoints on recognition results. To evaluate our method, we construct a dataset of traffic gestures commonly used in Taiwan. Experimental results show that the proposed enhancements improve the efficiency, scalability, and accuracy of gesture recognition, making the approach more suitable for real-time use in constrained environments.

title: Research on Distributed Technology of Spatiotemporal Big Data in Large and Medium-Sized Smart Cities Driven by Full-Space Information
authors: Lin Lu, Hui Zhao, Hanxiao Zhou, Yu Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In the process of intelligent construction of large and medium-sized cities, the multi-source nature and complexity of spatiotemporal data lead to limitations of traditional GIS in 3D expression and real-time processing. To address the challenges such as inconsistent multi-source data benchmarks and low storage efficiency, this study conducts in-depth research on full-space information-driven distributed management technology for spatiotemporal big data. A "Three-Layer and Four-Dimension" technical framework is constructed: the Data Layer adopts "Three-Domain Identification" for multi-source data encoding, and realizes storage optimization by combining LOD technology with HBase; the Engine Layer is based on the Flink framework and achieves parallel processing of 100-million-level features through custom spatiotemporal grids; the Service Layer adopts a microservice architecture and provides open services in compliance with OGC standards. Key technologies, including hybrid indexing, multi-source data collaborative processing, and dynamic data processing, are being developed. Experiments are conducted based on public datasets such as OpenStreetMap. The results show that: the hybrid index increases 3D query speed by 217% and trajectory retrieval speed by 150%; the multi-source data processing accuracy reaches 86.3% with a speed increase of 243%; the distributed architecture improves throughput by 38% and achieves a concurrent success rate of 97.2%. This study realizes the integrated management of spatiotemporal data, verifies the application value of full-space information-driven technology in the intelligent development of large and medium-sized cities, and will focus on model dimension expansion, performance optimization, and standardization construction in the future.

title: Spatial Distribution and Mobility Trends of High-Level Scientific and Technological Innovation Talents
authors: Zhen Jia, Zheng Wu, Yidan Liu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: As outstanding representatives of China's high-level scientific and technological innovation talents, academicians of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) and the Chinese Academy of Engineering (CAE) play a significant role in pioneering cutting-edge technologies, leading major research missions, and nurturing young scientific talents. High-level talents with military research backgrounds are particularly pivotal as the mainstay in national defense and military modernization. Taking 406 CAS/CAE academicians with military research backgrounds as an example, this study employs spatial analysis methods including Kernel Density Analysis and Mobility Indices to systematically analyze the spatial distribution characteristics of China's high-level scientific and technological innovation talents and their spatial mobility patterns across three dimensions: educational migration, employment mobility, and workplace relocation. Considering the distinctiveness of military research, it analyzes the growth pathways and patterns of high-level scientific and technological innovation talents with military backgrounds in China and proposes strategic recommendations.

title: Cardiac Care IoT and ML: Portable Home-Based Cardiovascular Monitoring for Early Risk Assessment
authors: Khondoker Ahmed Zubaier, Fatiha Tultul, Intesar Hassan Bhuiyan, Fariah Mahzabeen, Riasat Khan
abstract: Sudden cardiac arrest is a significant global health concern; however, triage of cardiac events typically occurs only in clinical settings, often when the patient is already experiencing a cardiac episode. Effective and efficient at-home cardiovascular virtual health monitoring is essential for early intervention, potentially preventing sudden fatalities. A highly accurate machine learning model combined with a Veroboardintegrated cardiac care kit has been developed in this work, which addresses the high mortality rate of sudden cardiac arrest through home-based monitoring. This device integrates three critical parameters-ECG, blood pressure, and heart rate-into a machine-learning model to analyze real-time cardiovascular health data. A combined dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1, 6 9 0}$</tex> cardiac patients from the UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository is used for model training and testing, encompassing 11 health features, including critical cardiovascular indicators such as fasting blood sugar, ECG results, exercise-induced angina, and ST slope. While the dataset includes individuals across different age groups, it primarily focuses on individuals aged 40 to 60. Min-max scaling for continuous features and one-hot encoding for categorical features have been applied in the dataset preprocessing stage. A Stacking classifier is implemented, using Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Gradient Boost classifiers as base estimators, with KNN as the final meta estimator. The applied Stacking ensemble model achieves an accuracy of 95.6% and an F1 score of 95.9%. This proposed device ensures a user-friendly interface and high accuracy, making it suitable as a household monitoring tool to reduce fatalities from unanticipated cardiac events.

title: An Intelligent Scheduling Method Based on Muti-Element Models for Communication Satellite software
authors: Xiaohu Lv, Jianglei Gong, Xin Wang, Xiang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: The communication satellite software system is complex, which contains such as telemetry function, telecontrol function, energy management function, pay load autonomous management function, time management, bus management etc. How to make reasonable scheduling and efficient use of satellite resources despite of the hardware limitation, and meanwhile to restore the running state of software function modules in real-time when the hardware is cut off or reset which can ensure the software functions running orderly and stably, is difficult and important. This paper proposes a method for optimizing the use of software resources based on a multi-factor model which is constructed for function and sub-function. The adaptive intelligent scheduling method is realized according to the actual running state of software system, and the reasonable utilization of satellite software is realized.

title: X-band GaN Front-end MMIC using 0.2 um GaN HEMT Technology
authors: YounSub Noh, JongWon Lim, Sung-Bum Bae, ByoungChul Jun, JiHun Kwon
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: In this paper, we designed and manufactured an X-band front-end MMIC with a power amplifier, low-noise amplifier, and switch integrated into one chip using $0.2 \mu \mathrm{mGaN}$ HEMT technology. The front-end MMIC with a chip size of $4.66 \mathrm{~mm} \times 3 \mathrm{~mm}$, shows receiver characteristics of 25 dB gain and 2 dB noise figure and transmitter characteristics of 23.5 dB gain, 43.5 dBm output power, and $37 \%$ PAE (power added efficiency) in the frequency range of $9 \sim 10 \mathrm{GHz}$.

title: Human-Robot Interaction-Enabled Training Assistant System for Employee Skill Development
authors: Petikam Sailaja, DivyaDharshan S, Prema Sagar, Lingesh. S, Fredsalin. R, Hemavarshini. R
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research introduces a system of training assistant based on Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) that is designed to interactively improve skills of employees by using technically-advanced procedures. The system based on the Learning-by-Demonstration (LbD) method enables the employees to learn practical skills by watching the demonstration of work done with the help of robots. The leading interactive platform is the Pepper robot created by SoftBank Robotics that includes speech recognition, ability to detect gestures, and provide real-time feedback to facilitate an attentive approach to training. The two-way channel of communication advanced using the robot also allows employees to correlate naturally and redo tasks performed in accordance with the demonstrations given by the robot. This approach allows minimizing the learning curve of complicated tasks, invites active participation and promotes individual training experience. The coupled model vis-a-visLbD and a humanoid robot such as Pepper not only helps to make learning a lot easier but also increases their confidence and thus ability to deliver on tasks. The proposed system shows great potential of scalable adaptable training solutions within corporation and industrial environments.

title: Role of Machine Learning in Crop Disease Prediction: A Bibliometric Perspective
authors: Upasana Rana, Sonal Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Crop diseases detection is a critical concern that must be addressed to ensure agriculture sustainability and strengthen the economy. The lot of research has been published on crop disease prediction and detection using machine learning techniques however there is no systematic review in this field. The present systematic review conducted using VOSviewer highlights the extent work carried out so far and identifies area that remain unexplored for future research. We searched the publication in Scopus database from year 2010 to 2024 using "crop diseases" and "machine learning", "crop diseases" and "artificial intelligence" keywords. The result indicate that majority of the research publication have appeared after the year 2020, reflecting a surge in studies focused on crop disease prediction using machine learning. This study retrieved information on subject keywords, countries, journals, organization, and authors actively contributing in this area. Furthermore, the study revealed scarcity of publication on wheat disease prediction through machine learning methods, as compared to studies on other crop diseases in India.

title: Design of Reconfigurable Transmitarray Antenna Element with High-Pass Filtering Characteristics
authors: Qian Song, Ziyang Wang, Dongling Su
abstract: A reconfigurable transmitarray antenna (RTA) element with high-pass filtering capability is proposed. The filtering RTA element is composed of the driving phase-shifting element(DPSE) and the high-pass filter element(HPFE). The DPSE based on the current-reversal method provides 1 bit phase difference. By increasing the order of the HPFE, the out-of-band suppression can be enhanced while simultaneously extending the passband bandwidth. A high-pass filtering RTA element with the third-order HPFE is developed and simulated, and the simulation results of the element show that the out-of-band rejection level is over 13 dB within 14–15.1 GHz frequency band. And the frequency selectivity parameters of the element is F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">L</inf> = 120.

title: Optimal Estimation of Adjacent Waves Based on Observed Wave Data Using a Kalman Filter
authors: Seung Jun Kim, Ju Su Jang, You Seok Yeoh, Min Cheol Paek, Seong Been Jang, Kyeong Sik Min
abstract: This paper presents an optimal estimation of adjacent waves based on observed wave data using a Kalman filter for wave monitoring system. The proposed method is implemented using a Kalman filter based on the two-dimensional shallow water equation(SWE). A grid-based state-space model is implemented using the SWE, and the state vector is dynamically estimated using observable variables such as the significant wave height and surface current velocity. At unobserved grid points, wave states are predicted via a state propagation model incorporating diffusion terms. The validity and accuracy of the method are demonstrated through simulations based on marine wave radar measurements.

title: Research and Application of Geological Hazard Monitoring and Early Warning Management System - A Case Study of a Town's Landslide
authors: Dan Xie, Peng Yang, Chenyu Li, Dong Li, Jun Liang, Tao Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Geological disasters pose a serious threat to people's personal safety and property security, and there is an increasing demand for strengthening early warning of geological disasters. This paper selects landslides in a certain town as the research object and aims to improve the accuracy and timeliness of early warning and support disaster prevention and mitigation work by constructing a multi-model fusion early warning system. Firstly, it studies the multi-threshold early warning model by optimizing the indicator system based on disaster characteristics; secondly, it formulates specific early warning thresholds and response strategies; finally, it verifies the effect of this method through actual cases. The results of the case show that this method can effectively identify disaster risks and issue early warnings in advance, thereby significantly improving the scientific accuracy and timeliness of geological disaster early warning and providing reliable technical support for disaster prevention and mitigation decisions.

title: Improving Multi-Speaker Transcription for Live News Broadcasts With Canary 1B and Pyannote Diarization
authors: Muhammad Rifqi Adli Gumay, Rahmat Bryan Naufal, Alvin Xavier Rakha Wardhana, Kurniawati Azizah
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: Live news programs are especially challenging for Automatic Transcription (AT) systems as they contain numerous and intricate interactions between presenters, reporters, voiceovers and off-site clips. In this paper, we investigate whether Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), and instrumental time-aligned labels from ASR decoding paths, can be used to improve speaker diarization in domain-specific data. We utilize NVIDIA's Canary 1B ASR model within the WhisperX framework in order to improve AT performance, word level alignment and speaker segmentation. Canary 1B has generally shown stronger performance based on average WER and RTFx in the previous evaluation. Using experimental dataset from an English broadcast with several speakers, our proposed model achieves 0% Diarization Error Rate (DER), 2.2% Word Error Rate (WER), and 0.04% Character Error Rate (CER). These results demonstrate that by integrating Canary 1 B transcription model with our search-based decoder can provide a more effective and efficient transcription system for live news applications.

title: A1-step ZQ Calibration for High-Speed Single-Ended NRZ Memory Interfaces
authors: Junmin Lee, Yong-Un Jeong
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: In this paper, a single-ended non-return-to-zero (NRZ) transmitter (TX) with a 1-step ZQ calibration is proposed for high-speed memory interfaces. This ZQ calibration technique reduces the overall calibration time and number of replica drivers from three to one by using the transmitter output voltage determined by the ratio between the transmitter driver impedance and the channel impedance after data are transmitted through a transmission line. The proposed ZQ calibration is designed using a $\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$ CMOS process and achieves a maximum error rate of $6.69 \%$ and an average error rate of $\mathbf{4. 4 9 \%}$.

title: Design and Implementation of High-Speed Interfaces with TGV for 2.5D/3D Glass Interposer
authors: Suin Chae, Jaemyung Lim, Jein Yu
abstract: With the rapid growth of ultra-large AI systems, 2.5D/3D packaging technologies have gained attention to overcome traditional integration limitations. Among interposer materials, glass is a strong candidate due to low signal loss, dimensional stability, and process compatibility. This paper presents the design and signal integrity (SI) analysis of high-speed interconnects in 2.5D/3D glass interposer-based packages. Transmission line structures with multiple signal-to-ground configurations are explored to support 32 Gbps data rates. We analyzed insertion loss (IL), eye diagram characteristics, and crosstalk through 3D electromagnetic (EM) simulation across routing schemes. The frequency-domain Voltage Transfer Function (VTF) is used as the primary SI metric to reflect unterminated signaling typically seen in advanced packaging. Results confirm that the proposed multi-ground guiding structure achieves low IL, reduced crosstalk, clear eye openings. All configurations meet the transmission specifications presented in the UCIe standard for VTF and high-speed channel SI performance.

title: Improved Genetic Algorithm Based on Fractals for Packet Scheduling in MANETs
authors: Mercy Sharon Devadas, W. Nancy, Jessy Sujana G., G. Sowmiya, Niranjana
abstract: Mobile Ad-hoc Networks (MANETs) have become an integral component of modern wireless communication systems, especially in scenarios where infrastructure-based networks are either unavailable or impractical. These self-configuring, decentralized networks are used in various applications, such as disaster recovery, military operations, and mobile conferencing, where efficient data transmission is critical. Ensuring the effective operation of MANETs is therefore essential, particularly in terms of Quality of Service (QoS), which encompasses factors like delay, packet loss, and throughput. This study presents an innovative technique aimed at enhancing QoS in MANETs by combining the mathematical concept of fractals with the optimization power of genetic algorithms. Specifically, the research focuses on developing an improved packet scheduling algorithm-a core element in achieving better QoS. The proposed system classifies packets into service classes based on their priority levels and acceptable delay thresholds. Following classification, a modified genetic algorithm is applied to schedule packets efficiently. To assess the effectiveness of this approach, simulations were performed using the NS3 network simulator, and the results were thoroughly analyzed.

title: MDLA: Multi-Head Latent Linear Attention for Low-Complexity and Memory-Efficient KV Cache
authors: Nahun Kim, Junseok Lee, Sangyong Lee
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable progress with Transformer-based architectures. However, the quadratic complexity of the multi-head attention (MHA) mechanism imposes significant computational and memory bottlenecks, limiting scalability for long-context reasoning. To address these challenges, we propose Multi-Head Latent Linear Attention (MDLA), a unified attention architecture that integrates low-rank joint compression, linear attention, and a state space model (SSM)-based reconstruction mechanism. MDLA inherits the memory-efficient design of multi-head latent attention (MLA) while introducing a linearized attention formulation to achieve computational scalability and an SSMbased reconstruction module to restore sequential dependencies lost during compression. This hybrid design effectively balances efficiency and expressiveness, reducing both FLOPs and memory usage without compromising representational quality. Experimental results demonstrate that MDLA achieves up to 63.6% reduction in total computation compared with MLA at a 16 K -token sequence length, while maintaining competitive performance across language understanding benchmarks such as MMLU, HellaSwag, ARC, and TruthfulQA. These results confirm that MDLA provides an efficient and scalable foundation for next-generation large language models requiring long-context processing.

title: Sequential Three-way-based Method for Hybrid Concept Drift Detection
authors: Ruihua Wang, Jianqiang Du, Jianfeng Xu, Jiguang Deng
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Concept drift refers to the phenomenon in streaming data where the distribution of data changes over time, causing a model’s performance to degrade. Most relevant studies are aimed at a particular type of concept drift, but there is little literature on the phenomenon of hybrid concept drift that exist simultaneously. This paper examines concept drift types from the perspective of model accuracy and defines hybrid concept drift. It also introduces a novel method to detect drift from hybrid concepts. This method determines the occurrence of concept drift according to the change in the accuracy of the model and the type of drift according to the degree of recovery of the accuracy of the new model. Experimental analysis shows that the proposed method can accurately judge the drift type with hybrid concept drift.

title: Analysis of the Impact of Generator Leading Power Factor Operation in Pumped Storage Power Stations on Grid Security and Stability
authors: Xingwei Chen, Chunsun Tian, Ze Gao, Guangjie Zhu, Xueqing Pan, Zhou Fang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Taking the Wuyue Pumped Storage Power Station as an example, this paper conducts an in-depth study on the impact of synchronous condenser operation of units on the steady-state and transient voltage levels of the provincial power grid. First, the feasibility and necessity of long-term synchronous condenser operation of pumped storage power stations are elaborated. Subsequently, from the two dimensions of simulation calculation and on-site testing, the synchronous condenser limit of Unit #4 of the Wuyue Pumped Storage Power Station is analyzed in detail. In terms of steady-state, the voltage regulation effect of synchronous condenser operation on the power grid is discussed. In terms of transient state, the impact of synchronous condenser operation on power grid voltage stability issues is analyzed from the perspectives of low voltage and voltage stability.

title: Brain-Inspired Learning and the Dynamic Interplay Between Neuroscience and Computer Science
authors: Nikolaos Dikaios, George A. Kastis, Nicholas E. Protonotarios
abstract: The year 1958 marked the beginning of a new era, as Rosenblatt introduced the Perceptron, a computational model for supervised learning through error-driven weight adaptation inspired by biological neurons. The backpropagation algorithm, introduced by Rumelhart et al. in 1986, transformed multilayer networks by allowing for weight updates. In 1997, Maass proposed spiking neural networks to emulate the temporal and sequential learning of biological neurons, while Schultz et al. proposed reinforcement learning by integrating brain-like reward mechanisms for decision making. The 2000s witnessed significant advancements, with the development of convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks inspired by brain’s hierarchical and recurrent mechanisms, respectively. More recently, in 2020, Feinman and Lake presented hybrid neurosymbolic models to capture the brain’s ability to learn from sensory data and perform structured reasoning. This work explores the remarkable progression of breakthroughs toward brain-inspired learning, aiming to offer a new perspective in the dynamic interplay between neuroscience and computer science.

title: AI-Driven Online Proctoring: Balancing Integrity, Privacy, and Learner Experience in Distance Education
authors: Raziana Che Aziz, Murad Mohd Zain, Chiam Chooi Chea, Mohd Tajudin Md Ninggal
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: Ensuring academic integrity in large-scale online examinations is a critical challenge for distance education institutions. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an AI-driven proctoring system integrating facial recognition, eye-tracking, and behavioral analytics to monitor misconduct during online examinations. The system was deployed across more than 100 subjects with 2,700 (AI = 2,000; Ruled-based automated proctoring = 700) candidates in an open and distance learning (ODL) university. Data sources included system-generated logs, institutional exam records, and post-exam student surveys. Results indicate that the system reduced suspected incidents of misconduct by 20–25% compared to Ruled-based automated proctoring, while enabling scalability across multiple disciplines. Despite these improvements, student feedback highlighted concerns regarding privacy, continuous surveillance, and algorithmic fairness. To address these issues, the study introduces a responsible proctoring framework emphasizing transparency, data protection, bias mitigation, and accountability. The study highlights the need for responsible AI adoption in digital examinations, offering empirical evidence and a practical framework to guide institutions towards fair, scalable, and ethically grounded assessment models.

title: A Study on Hidden Conformal Antennas for Smart Mobility Vehicles
authors: Jun Choi, Sangpil Kang, Wonwhi Jin, Inho Jeon, Jeok Park, Hyunggeun Lee, Taeil Kim, Jinkyu Hwang
abstract: Vehicle communications require multiple wireless communications due to the advancement of infotainment, navigation, and V2X-based autonomous driving features. Consequently, multifunctional, multi-frequency integrated vehicle antenna technology is gaining significant attention. This study proposes a hidden conformal antenna system suitable for smart mobility vehicles and designs and fabricates a multi-band antenna structure integrating various wireless communications such as 5G, GNSS, UWB, BLE, and Wi-Fi. Specifically, a hidden structure that does not compromise vehicle exterior design or aerodynamic performance was adopted, and a multilayer board-based integrated antenna was implemented inside the vehicle roof. Antenna performance was verified through VSWR, Gain, OTA measurements, and 3D radiation pattern analysis. The results confirmed excellent radiation efficiency and stable frequency characteristics across each band. This paper demonstrates the feasibility of implementing an in-vehicle antenna system optimized for future connected car and autonomous vehicle platforms.

title: Toward a Miniaturized Hybrid-Driven Swimming Robot for Water–Air Cross-Domain Locomotion
authors: Zhanhua Xin, Kaiwei Zhu, Di Chen, Ru Tong, Shihan Kong, Shengkai Pan, Junzhi Yu
abstract: The flyingfish has long inspired the design of bioinspired robots capable of traversing both aquatic and aerial environments. This study introduces an untethered, miniaturized hybrid-driven robotic platform designed for multimodal motion across aquatic and aerial environments. Compared to previous designs, the proposed robot features a substantially reduced form factor while employing a synergistic propulsion strategy—combining high-frequency fish-like undulation with propeller-based thrust—to enable agile maneuvering on the water surface, underwater, and during aerial phases. Experimental results demonstrate that the swimming robot can attain a peak speed of 6.88 body lengths per second on the surface, which significantly outperforms single-mode counterparts while maintaining robust attitude control during rapid transitions. To enable high-speed pitch regulation and seamless water-to-air transitions, we derive a comprehensive dynamic model and develop a reverse-dynamics-based sliding-mode control scheme, integrated with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$z$</tex-math></inline-formula>–<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta$</tex-math></inline-formula> plane line-of-sight guidance and a state observer. The robot's full cross-domain mobility is experimentally verified, including the complete transition sequence from submerged standby to attitude adjustment and aerial acceleration. In a safe indoor laboratory environment, the highest recorded aerial flying height exceeds approximately 5.5 times the body length. This work provides critical insights into the design and control paradigms for next-generation miniaturized aquatic robots, highlighting the promise of bioinspired hybrid propulsion and adaptive control strategies for cross-domain applications.

title: A Fully Integrated Doppler-Assisted FMCW Radar With Low Hertz-Range Noise Figure and High Chirp Linearity for Vital Signs Sensing and Indoor Localization
authors: Yuqin Zhang, Yuri Lu, Zitong Zhang, Kangjie Zhao, Zhiluo Zhang, Zhenyu Zhang, Yue Zhu, Ruilai Xu, Ying Liu, Shixiang Ding, Jikun Wang, Kaige Wang, Dalin Li, Peng Wang, Hao Deng, Guangsheng Chen, Leilei Huang, Chunqi Shi, Jinghong Chen, Runxi Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a Doppler-assisted frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar that combines precise range resolution capability of FMCW with high sensitivity of Doppler radar, enabling versatile performance for indoor applications. A comprehensive analysis of low-frequency noise contributions from key receiver (RX) blocks including low-noise amplifier (LNA), mixer, local oscillator (LO) buffer, and analog baseband (ABB) circuits is conducted. An “RF+LO+BB” joint noise figure (NF) improvement method is proposed to effectively suppress the low-frequency noise. To minimize frequency modulation (FM) error in charge-pump-based fractional-N phase-locked loops (PLLs), a nested-PLL architecture with an optimized loop parameter selection method is employed, significantly enhancing chirp linearity. Fabricated in a 55-nm CMOS technology, the proposed Doppler-assisted FMCW radar achieves NFs of 32.13 and 12.94 dB at 10 Hz and 1 kHz, respectively, and a chirp linearity of 0.0039% over a 3.52 GHz chirp bandwidth (BW), resulting in a maximum detection range of 19.41 m and a range resolution of 4.7 cm. The radar occupies a die area of 12.7 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and consumes 594 mW in FMCW mode and 432 mW in Doppler mode under a 3.3 V supply.

title: Design of a Low-noise Instrumentation Amplifier with Triple-MOS Pseudo-resistor for Bio-signal Acquisition in Consumer Electronics
authors: Feng Yan, Jingjing Liu, Kangkang Sun, Bingjun Xiong, Wenji Mo, Jian Guan, Zhipeng Li
abstract: Low input-referred noise (IRN) and low-power instrumentation amplifier (IA) with small size are crucial for consumer bio-electronic applications. This paper presents a compact, noise-efficient capacitive-coupled IA designed for bio-signal acquisition. The proposed Triple-MOSFET pseudo-resistor (PR) provides ultra-high resistance, a wide operating voltage range, and high linearity. The IA, enhanced by chopper-stabilized technology, effectively reduces noise while minimizing current consumption. An area-efficient DC servo loop with Triple-MOS devices is employed to suppress electrode DC offset. Addi-tionally, parasitic effects are minimized based on layout design, maximizing the advantages of the positive feedback loop. The proposed IA is fabricated using a standard 180 nm CMOS process with an area of 0.49 mm², and operates at a supply of 0.8 V with a current consumption of 1.29 μA. The IRN of this IA is 0.97 μV<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rms</sub> within the 0.5–200 Hz and 2.31 μV<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rms</sub> within the 0.2–5 kHz, achieving competitive noise efficiency factor (1.4) and power efficiency factor (1.56). Furthermore, for a 2 mVpp sine wave input, total harmonic distortion is below -60.2 dB. The precise value of the positive feedback capacitor ensures that the input impedance reaches 628 MΩ at 50 Hz. A prototype test system based on the IA successfully acquired high-quality ECG and EEG signals from subjects. This efficient, low-noise, low-power acquisition chip has broad applications in portable cardiac monitors, brain-machine interfaces, and other biosensors, playing a significant role in enhancing the performance and reliability of these electronic devices.

title: Exploring and Tailoring the Test-Time Augmentation for Sequential Recommendation_supp1-3663633.pdf
authors: Yizhou Dang
abstract: Data augmentation is an effective technique for tackling data sparsity in sequential recommendation (SR). Existing methods generate new data during the model training to improve the performance. However, deploying them on a backbone model requires retraining, architecture modification, or introducing additional modules and learnable parameters. These processes are time-consuming and costly for well-trained models, especially when the model and data scales become large. In this work, we explore the test-time augmentation (TTA) for SR, which augments the input sequences during the inference phase and then fuses the model's predictions to improve final accuracy. It avoids the significant overhead associated with training-time augmentation. We first experimentally examine the potential of existing augmentation operators for TTA and find that the Substitute and Mask consistently achieve better performance. Further analysis reveals that these two operators retain the original sequential pattern while adding appropriate perturbations. Moreover, the random selection of augmentation positions creates suitable augmented samples from both semantic and temporal perspectives. Meanwhile, we find that the fixed operation ratio limits the diversity of augmented data, and the TTA may impair the model's performance on long sequences. In addition, the two operators still face time-consuming similarity-based item selection or interference from mask tokens. Based on the analysis and limitations, we present TNoise and TMask. The former injects uniform noise into the representation, avoiding the computational overhead of item selection. The latter blocks mask tokens from participating in model calculations (TMask-B) or directly removes interactions that should have been replaced with mask tokens (TMask-R). Further, we sample the augmentation ratio from a uniform distribution to improve the data diversity. For short sequences, we introduce a sequence smoothing and lengthening method based on inter-item interpolation. For long sequences, we set a threshold to avoid the negative effects of TTA. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness, efficiency, and generalizability of our method.

title: Contradiction Diagrams in Design: A Practical Tool for Innovation
authors: Daniel E. Sniezek
abstract: Engineering and quality professionals routinely use flowcharts and dataflow diagrams to model processes and information movement. However, these tools do not explicitly expose design tradeoffs created by competing functional requirements. Many real-world systems must simultaneously satisfy conflicting objectives such as cost versus usability, sustainability versus manufacturability, and reliability versus convenience. This article introduces contradiction diagrams as a practical visual method for identifying, structuring, and resolving such conflicts during early design stages. Contradiction diagrams map helpful and harmful functions and represent their interactions through producing and counteracting relationships, enabling teams to explicitly define the sources of performance tension within a system. By making tradeoffs visible, the method supports systems thinking and complements TRIZ-based inventive problem solving and Express Situation Assessment and Management (ESAM) software. A consumer packaging case study involving the design of a smaller, environmentally responsible bottle cap illustrates the approach. Multiple contradictions are modeled, including reduced material usage versus ease of opening and leak prevention. The diagrams guide structured questioning that expands the solution space and encourages separation of coupled variables through geometry, material selection, sealing strategies, and ergonomic features. Results demonstrate that contradiction diagrams improve cross-functional communication, accelerate ideation, and help teams generate innovative concepts prior to formal trade studies. The method provides a lightweight, scalable complement to traditional process tools and offers a systematic pathway to more balanced, sustainable, and user-centered engineering solutions.

title: A Two-Stage Machine Learning Framework for Predicting and Validating the Structural and Beam Characteristics of a Wideband Switched-Beam Antenna
authors: Pichaya Chaipanya, Worakan Noimi, Saraichat Wintachai, Supakpawee Wisetlertmongkol, Nuchanart Santalunai, Samran Santalunai
abstract: This paper presents a two-phase machine-learning (ML)-based approach for the design and performance forecasting of a wideband circular microstrip switched-beam antenna operating at the 2.6 GHz mid-band for 5G communication. In Phase 1, five supervised learning algorithms Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Support Vector Regression (SVR) are employed to model the relationship between the antenna’s geometric parameters (inner radius, outer radius, and slot gaps) and its resonant characteristics. The DT model achieves the highest prediction accuracy when benchmarked against CST full-wave simulation results, enabling reliable estimation of center frequency and impedance bandwidth without repeated electromagnetic simulations. In Phase 2, three machine learning models DT, RF, and KNN are trained using CST-generated datasets to predict the main-beam direction and bandwidth of the switched-beam structure based on the number, location, and distribution of short-circuited holes. The DT model again outperforms the others, achieving 94.56% accuracy in beam-direction prediction and 99.03% accuracy in bandwidth prediction. A prototype antenna fabricated on an FR-4 substrate demonstrates four-direction beam switching (0°, 90°, 180°, and 270°) with a measured impedance bandwidth of 380 MHz (2.48–2.86 GHz), closely matching both simulation and ML predictions. Compared with conventional trial-and-error simulation-based design workflows, the proposed framework significantly reduces antenna design time while maintaining high prediction accuracy, demonstrating the practical effectiveness of ML-assisted design for compact, cost-effective, and energy-efficient 5G antennas.

title: Overview of Stream-Aware Scheduling for QUIC-Based Proxying Using Multiple Paths
authors: Jan-Lukas Menne, Mirja Kühlewind
abstract: In 3GPP networks, Access Traffic Steering, Switching, and Splitting (ATSSS) is specified to enable network-assisted use of multiple paths based on a multipath-enabled QUIC tunnel. Using multiple paths can introduce packet reordering because of path asymmetry, loss, and differing delays. Packet reordering may be mistaken for congestion and thus lead to unnecessary reductions in throughput. While various packet-based schedulers have been proposed to address these issues, stream-aware concepts have not been widely explored when multiple end-to-end flows use the same tunnel. In this paper, we present our scheduling framework that supports stream-aware scheduling and compare state-of-the-art packet-based schedulers to stream-aware approaches in the multipath tunnel scenario, with particular focus on the Bandwidth-Limited Application Demand Estimating (BLADE) scheduler. Our results show that stream-aware scheduling concepts mitigate reordering and improve throughput in this scenario. This paper provides an overview of the current state of stream-aware scheduling for proxy scenarios. Future work is necessary and should investigate stream-aware techniques, adapt packet-based schedulers to be stream-aware, and propose novel stream-aware schedulers.

title: Mechanical Antenna Bandwidth Improvements via Alternate Poling Multimode Resonance
authors: Jesse Rivera, John Blaske, Zhi Yao, Yuanxun Ethan Wang, Gregory P. Carman
publish: IEEE Journal on Multiscale and Multiphysics Computational Techniques
abstract: Electrically small antennas face a seemingly insoluble dilemma. As engineers make headway in efficiency by boosting the device quality factor (Q), the bandwidth necessarily drops. Any wins in bandwidth conversely deteriorate the already low efficiency. The result is that cutting edge designs that boast of high efficiencies also have notoriously low bandwidths. This is untenable for commercial and military applications. One future platform that exemplifies this is the mechanical resonance based piezoelectric antenna array. The high Q piezoelectric material allows even a single 1D bar element to be four orders of magnitude more efficient than an optimized 3D metallic antenna at the same form factor but at a bandwidth roughly 1/1000th of the operating frequency. This work presents a method of partially overcoming these bandwidth deficiencies by utilizing a mechanical tuning method unique to piezoelectric antenna arrays. In such devices, the array spacing alters the stiffness of the piezoelectric elements which thus alters the resonance frequency without significantly diminishing the efficiency. Thus, a frequency band may be scanned by mechanically altering the array spacing. This frequency band is referred to as the mechanically tuned half-power bandwidth (MT-HPBW), which is roughly two orders of magnitude larger than the traditional HPBW. Additional improvements in bandwidth are realized by utilizing multiple resonance modes. An algorithm capable of performing full-wave simulations on such piezoelectric antenna arrays is presented with modifications with respect to previous work. Computational and design guidance is also provided based on the authors' own experiences.

title: Information-based Supervised Learning of In-proximity Effects for 3D Distance Estimation and Collision Avoidance_supp1-3665068.mp4
authors: Kam K. Leang
abstract: In-proximity effects (IPE) in 3D, specifically in-ground, in-ceiling, and in-wall effects, experienced by a rotary-wing aerial robot as it flies near obstacles are leveraged for obstacle distance estimation and collision-free motion control. Onboard motor commands and inertial measurement unit (IMU) signals are processed to enable the robot to essentially “feel” the presence of nearby obstacles through aerodynamic interactions. The physics of IPE, along with Shannon information, are used to tailor the input space and train a deep neural network (DNN) to estimate the distance to ground, ceiling, and wall features. Simulation and physical experimental results demonstrate reliable and robust obstacle detection and collision avoidance with a median distance estimation accuracy of 93.35%, 89.22%, and 90.67% for ground, ceiling, and wall, respectively. This new form of “sensing” is useful in environments with fog, smoke, dust, rain, or snow, where traditional proximity sensors and vision-based systems struggle to detect obstacles and determine distance.

title: Data-Driven Optimization of Wind-Solar Tower Performance a Machine Learning Approach to Thermal Updraft Prediction
authors: Md. Minhajul Islam, Ahmed Intekhab Rohan, Hasanur Zaman Anonto, Md Ismail Hossain, Md Mukter Hossain Emon, Md Akteruzzaman, Abu Shufian, Md Siddikur Rahman
abstract: This paper aims at examining how machine-learning can be applied to achieve optimal wind-solar hybrid towers performance in relation to predicting thermal updraft. Wind-solar towers use solar irradiance and wind speed to generate energy but due to the complex nature of interaction between the various environment variables, wind-solar towers are relatively hard to predict the thermal updraft due to the interaction between the solar irradiance, air temperature, and wind velocity. A complete dataset that covers 90 days is used, and various machine-learning models, such as linear regression, support vector machines, and neural networks, are tested to make a prediction of thermal updraft. The findings show that among all the alternative models, linear regression had a much superior predictability and efficiency in computation. The obtained result showed a close-toperfect fit, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> being equal to 0.98 and indicating the extremely high ability of the regression model to make predictions of the updraft velocity under heterogeneous environmental conditions. Sensitivity analysis had demonstrated that solar irradiance and wind speed are the best predictors of thermal updraft thereby offering insights that would be adopted to streamline the hybrid renewable energy system, and energy forecasting with potential to boost power generation especially during days with low solar irradiance.
