title: Research on Current Ripple Suppression Technology of Current Source Rectifier in New Energy Hydrogen Production System
authors: Lin Li, Xiaohe Wang, Zhaohui Shi, Bin Lin, Xiaofei Chang, Hongyu Wang, Xijin Yan
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Due to the characteristics of step-down output, low switching dv/dt and short-circuit protection of the three-phase current source rectifier, it has become the preferred power supply for water electrolysis hydrogen production and electrolytic cells. However, the three-phase current source rectifier has an inherent current ripple problem, which seriously affects the current quality on the output side. This paper reveals that the root cause of the current ripple of the DC bus inductor of the three-phase current source rectifier lies in the high-frequency ripple generated by the switching of the spatial vector sequence. An improved current source rectifier current ripple suppression scheme is proposed. By constructing a current compensation circuit through transformers, capacitors and inductors, the current ripple on the output side is effectively reduced, and the current quality is improved without changing the switching frequency. By further analyzing the working principle, the conditions for suppressing current ripple were derived, and the parameters of the circuit devices were designed in detail. Simulation verification was carried out on the Matlab/Simulink simulation software.

title: ScholarGenie: A Multi-Agentic System for Automated Literature Summarization and Presentation Generation
authors: Aadhityan S, Gnanamoorthi P V, J Gold Beulah Patturose, R Priscilla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: ScholarGenie is a multi-agent framework designed to automate the academic literature review process by integrating paper retrieval, semantic summarization, and slide deck generation into a unified system. Based on modular agent based orchestration using CrewAI and LangChain, ScholarGenie deploys specialized agents that collectively manage document search, context-aware summarization, and automated content formatting. This architecture reduces the dependency on manual effort and accelerates research workflows, particularly in educational and time constrained environments. Using large language models for understanding and synthesis, the system produces structured summaries and concise presentations tailored to user intent. ScholarGenie is evaluated on multiple research topics, demonstrating up to a 80% reduction in the processing time of the literature with output quality comparable to expert-curated summaries. This study highlights the role of agentic AI systems in redefining early-stage research productivity through scalable and autonomous academic content generation.

title: A Coverage-Reconfigurable Patch Antenna Using Switchable Parasitic Elements
authors: Maodudul Hasan, Eisuke Nishiyama, Masaya Tamura, Ichihiko Toyoda
abstract: This paper presents a coverage-reconfigurable patch antenna featuring a multilayer structure. The proposed antenna consists of a square patch and four switchable parasitic lines. Two of the parasitic lines are designed to control the half-power beamwidth (HPBW) in the E-plane, whereas the other two control the H-plane. The coverage reconfigurability is achieved by activating or deactivating the PIN diodes of the parasitic lines. By turning OFF the PIN diodes of the parasitic lines, the influence of the parasitic lines can be minimized, resulting in a narrower beam. In contrast, turning the diodes ON broadens the radiation pattern. The measured results confirm the coverage adaptability, demonstrating HPBW switching from 102° to 155° in the E-plane and from 95° to 142° in the H-plane.

title: BC-DMKDE: Bayesian Classifier Based on Distance-Corrected Multivariate Kernel Density Estimation
authors: Guangzhou Chen, Xinyang Wu, Zituo Li, Ruirui Zhao, Jiang Jiang, Kewei Yang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In practical classification problems, imbalanced class distribution is very common. Traditional classification methods usually aim at optimizing the overall accuracy, which leads to classification decisions biased towards categories with a large number of samples. Similar to most traditional classifiers, Naive Bayes (NB) is sensitive to the class prior distribution and has poor recognition performance for minority class samples, which restricts its application in imbalanced classification. Therefore, we propose a Bayesian classifier based on distance-corrected multivariate kernel density estimation (BC-DMKDE). BC-DMKDE relaxes the assumptions regarding conditional independence and the normality of continuous variables in NB classifiers, by incorporating the multivariate kernel density estimation (MKDE). We also incorporate a distance-correction mechanism utilizing kernel density estimation, specifically to alleviate the impact of class imbalance and overlapping data samples. Across 18 real-world benchmarks, BC-DMKDE exhibits superior classification performance and robustness, outperforming existing methods at both the algorithm and data levels.

title: Neural Histories: Tracing Genre Evolution in English Literature with Deep Learning
authors: M. Prakash, R. Sivasankari, N. Bhuvaneshwari, D. Nivetha, B. Poorani, R. Kanagaselvam
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The evolution of literary genres over time encapsulates deep cultural, linguistic, and philosophical shifts within human expression. The current work presents a new deep learning model, Neural Histories, which is intended to capture and track the diachronic development of English literary genres between the 18th and the 21stcentury. An annotated corpus of canonical and non-canonical texts was built, annotated in time, augmented by metadata of genre and divided into literary periods. Stylmetric features and semantic embeddings that used ELMo were obtained in order to represent surface-level and contextual regularities. Our models were Bi-LSTM and Transformer, with Time-Aware Neural Attention (TANA) being added to learn historical shifts in genre. They were tracked with the help of the Neural Dynamic Topic Modeling (NDTM), and the genre development was represented through Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) and PCA. The given Bi-LSTM + TANA model reached the average classification accuracy of 89.1, which exceeded those of standard Bi-LSTM (83.7) and Transformer-only models (86.3). Also, semantic drift indications have shown obvious changes, including how the genre of Gothic shifted to become the psychological horror and how Modernism shifted to fragmentation of identity. SHAP analysis was used to gain interpretability and the impact of narrative features, temporal markers and topic centroids was highlighted. This is not just a better way to perform genre classification, but it also provides a computational spectacle through which literary scholars can understand genre mutation, hybridity, and decline. This approach of reconciling computational linguistics and literary theory opens novel vistas of critical inquiry into the history of the genre in English literature: Neural Histories.

title: Biometric Encryption Using Randomised RR-Interval-Driven ECG Signals for Secure Remote Patient Monitoring in Telemedicine
authors: Rohan Suresh Vaidya, Trisha Mukherjee, Suvrat Jain, Dev Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Remote patient monitoring in telemedicine requires robust security mechanisms to protect sensitive health data from unauthorised access and cyberattacks. This paper proposes an electrocardiogram (ECG)-based biometric encryption framework that derives cryptographic keys from the unique, time-varying R wave to R wave intervals of a patient’s ECG signal. These person-specific keys enhance confidentiality, ensure authenticity and resist spoofing, thereby mitigating risks such as identity theft and data breaches. The research used the Massachusetts Institute of Technology-Beth Israel Hospital Arrythmia Database and achieved 89.74% accuracy, a false acceptance rate of 0.00%, a false rejection rate (FRR) of 21.05%, a true positive rate of 78.95%, a true negative rate of 100% and an equal error rate of 1.5%. Although the FRR indicates scope for optimisation, the results demonstrate the feasibility of integrating proposed biometric-driven encryption into telemedicine platforms. By bridging biomedical signal processing with advanced cryptography, the system provides a scalable, privacy-compliant solution for the secure exchange of healthcare data in remote clinical environments.

title: Radiation hardening for better SEU in 12T SRAM using 45nm CMOS Technology
authors: Radha Subramanyam, Niranjan Raj, Avusula Vaishnavi, Ramavath Keerthi, Madishetty Tejasri, P Nagabushanam
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: SRAM with carbon nanotube or FinFET find role in low power smart device applications which empower high speed and stability in reading, writing capacities. Complementary designs, writing latency and impact of using different organic materials in the SRAM design are the key motivations of this work. Nano scaling faces the challenges like short channel and their effects, less gate control, leakages in currents, power dissipations and processing variability in which a few are concentrated in our work. Radiation hardening technique used in our work helps in writing assistance and thereby stability in the operations, thereby overcoming few challenges faced by SRAM. Objective is to design 12T SRAM in Cadence 45nm CMOS technology for addressing the single event upsets by looping the feedback and thereby achieve better noise margin, delay and power dissipations. This work supports commercial feasibility, memory devices which are made up of organic materials and high speed with less area by reducing the sensing time, power consumptions.

title: Carbonization detection of underground pipe gallery cable based on machine vision
authors: Runhao Zhang, Lingzhi Zhou, Qingyun Zhao
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of urbanization, underground high-voltage cables have become the primary carriers of urban power transmission owing to their intrinsic advantages. However, during operation, these cables are subjected to coupled mechanical and thermal stresses, leading to heat accumulation and subsequent thermal degradation and carbonization of the insulation layer, which often precedes open-flame ignition. To enable early-stage fire warning and rapid suppression in underground utility tunnels, it proposes a novel carbonized-layer recognition model, YOLO-CC. The model facilitates real-time identification of carbonization evolution stages and prediction of future degradation trends based on detection results. Nine groups of heat accumulation experiments under various operating conditions were conducted, followed by quantitative analysis and predictive modeling using experimental data. Experimental results indicate that the YOLO-CC model achieves superior detection accuracy in carbonized-layer monitoring. Furthermore, the proposed time-series-based quantification and information prediction algorithms successfully delineate distinct carbonization evolution stages and precisely identify ignition points. Overall, the YOLO-CC framework establishes a new technical paradigm for early warning of high-voltage cable fires and provides a solid theoretical foundation for the development of intelligent early warning systems.

title: Smart Waste Segregation System with Arduino Integration for Enhanced Recycling Efficiency
authors: Juvalika Gudela, Saritha Vanka, Veera Ganesh Kumar Reddy Vuppada, Madhu Gayathri Muthyalapalli
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The increasing volume of waste generated daily has made efficient waste management a critical environmental concern. This project presents an automated waste segregation system designed to classify and separate waste into three primary categories: wet,dry, and metal. Using an Arduino microcontroller as the core processor, the system utilizes moisture sensors, metal detectors, and IR sensors to accurately identify the type of waste. Once classified, waste is directed into the appropriate bin through the controlled movement of servo motors, ensuring effective segregation. A moisture sensor identifies wet waste, a metal detector differentiates metal from non-metal items, and an IR sensor detects the presence of waste at the input point. The system features an LCD display to show real-time classification feedback, enhancing user interaction and operational transparency. Powered by a 5V power supply, this compact and eco-friendly design aims to streamline waste management processes, reduce manual sorting efforts, and promote sustainability by enabling the effective recycling of segregated waste.Unlike many similar Arduino-based systems, this work demonstrates 95% classification accuracy, a low-cost implementation (under 2000rs), and modular scalability, making it practical for household, urban, and industrial waste management.

title: AI-Driven Adaptive Cryptography and Multi-Factor Authentication for Robust Cloud Security
authors: Muhammed Adeem Shaik, S. Venkata Krishnan, S Archana
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The sudden growth of cloud computing has pushed the requirements for strong security models to safeguard confidential information and user authentication procedures. An intelligent model of cloud security that combines multi-factor authentication (MFA) and adaptive cryptography using machine learning (ML) for dynamic threat prevention is proposed in this paper. The system under consideration utilizes a three-layered authentication scheme using passwords, conditional attributes, and facial recognition with facial biometric data being utilized to generate cryptographic keys. A Hybrid CNN-Transformer model acts as an intrusion detection system (IDS), classifying attacks in real-time dynamically and toggling between hybrid encryption pairs-AES + HMAC SHA-256, ECC + HMAC SHA512, HMAC-MD5 + PBKDF2, Twofish + Argon2, and Blowfish + HMAC SHA3-256-accordingly. This twolayer cryptographic strategy provides better data confidentiality, integrity, and access control in cloud computing. Experimental results illustrate a stunning 96.8 % attack prediction accuracy and proof against bruteforce, phishing, spoofing, and impersonation attacks. The convergence of the system with AWS cloud services also enhances scalability and flexibility. Overall, the research framework presents a future-ready, AI-based solution for intelligent and adaptive cloud security.

title: Data-Driven Controllers for Nonlinear Discrete-Time Systems
authors: Koshy George
abstract: The emphasis on data-driven control has increased in recent years, even though the concept is over 100 years old. In one class of such controllers, the objective is to identify a model of the controlled plant and then control using any model-based control technique. Alternatively, methods have been introduced to tune the controller's parameters using the available data directly. Apart from these two, methods have evolved recently based on using a simplified mathematical representation of the plant, typically called model-free control (MFC). MFC is attractive as the objective is to control a plant without explicitly using a mathematical model. It is advantageous if the complex process can be controlled using a simpler model that may not wholly represent the entire process. Many successful applications have been reported. In contrast, model-based control based on the mathematical description of the behaviour has been studied and extensively used. This paper addresses the question of which data-driven controller to use in the context of a class of nonlinear discrete-time systems. It compares a method based on partial linearisation with a technique based on feedforward neural networks. The former is a model-free control and requires no prior information about the plant's dynamics. The latter, a modelbased control technique with minimal prior information, can provide significantly better tracking performance.

title: AI-Driven Detection of Fraudulent UPI Transactions Using Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Anaswara Venunadh, Shreya, Shreyash Agrawal, Abdurrehman Qaisar Mallick
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: The widespread use of Unified Payments Interface (UPI) for digital transactions has led to a significant rise in fraudulent activities, posing challenges for both users and financial institutions. This paper presents a deep learning-based framework that employs Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to effectively detect and prevent fraudulent UPI transactions. The proposed model is trained on typical user transaction behavior, enabling it to identify abnormal patterns with high accuracy and flag them as potentially fraudulent. Emphasis is placed on reducing false positives to ensure genuine transactions remain unaffected, thereby maintaining user trust and transaction security. Experimental results demonstrate that the CNN model outperforms traditional machine learning classifiers, including Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine (SVM), achieving 95.0% accuracy, 93.2% precision, 92.5% recall, 92.8% F1-score, and 0.98 AUC. These results highlight the model's robustness and superior capability in addressing modern digital payment fraud.

title: Residual Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Personalized Insulin Dose Estimation
authors: Hruthik Krishna Pavarala, Kalyani Gadupudi, Sudhamsh Maganti
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Accurate prediction of insulin dosage is essential to effective diabetes management as mis-dosing has the potential to lead to serious healthcare complications. In this paper, a Residual Sequence learning model is proposed that leverages the strength of both LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) and GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit) design in forecasting short-acting insulin dosing from actual clinical data. The model is intended to detect both long-term patterns and short-term fluctuations in the glucose-insulin dynamics of patients.Intensive preprocessing methods were employed, including time-series transformation of glucose events, cyclical encoding of temporal features, and creating advanced lag-based and interaction features to learn historical and contextual physiological patterns.The Residual Sequence Learning Model model was compared with baseline hybrid LSTM-GRU, LSTM-Transformer, and GRU-Transformer architectures. The experimental insights demonstrate that the Residual sequence learning model performs noticeably better in prediction accuracy than the baseline hybrid LSTM-GRU model, with an improvement in R2 score from 0.62 to 0.805, a decrease in MAE from 1.43 to 1.29, and a decrease in MSE from 8.29 to 3.27. The outcomes show that the model has the potential to be a useful and customized decision-support tool for diabetes insulin treatment.

title: Exploring Russian Formalism with Intelligent Systems for Advancing Cinematic Literariness
authors: Bharathi V.J, R. Rajakumari
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The integration of Russian Formalist principles into cinematic analysis presents a novel opportunity to explore literariness through intelligent systems. In this work, the author suggests a computational model, which uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Computer Vision (CV) to address the topics of narrative structure, defamiliarization and repetition of motifs in movie texts and images. Basic Russian Formalist ideas like ostranenie (defamiliarization), fabula and syuzhet are formalized into Bi-GRU sequence modeling networks, YOLO vision systems to detect visual disruption and attention systems to mine motifs. Multi-modal embedding strategy is a strategy that combines both textual and visual attributes to derive a Cinematic Literariness Score (CLS). Assessment on 10 movies (Mirror, Persona, Rashomon, and The Color of Pomegranates) shows a high agreement in the case of expert critics, giving an average of 90.3, F1-score of 0.902, and Cohen kappa values of over 0.84. Scene-level defamiliarization detection represented consistent performance at the level of DII scores over 0.75 on highly formalist films. The human-AI consensus on identifying motifs was 91.4% and inter-rater reliability i.e. 0.85. The findings confirm the interpretive strength of the model, and its correspondence to the Russian Formalist theory. Combining narrative, linguistic, and visual, this framework provides explainable and quantitative research of cinematic literariness. New areas of research, such as cross-cultural adaptation to the narrative and intermediality, as well as AI-assisted film criticism, are also opened by the system. The work provides a fundamental connection between humanities and intelligent computation, both to narrative theory and media analytics.

title: MSA-Net: A Lightweight Multi-Scale Feature Refinement Network for Optic Cup and Optic Disc Segmentation
authors: Weiwei Song, Ming Xu, Haixing Li, Xiaosheng Yu, Hongyu Wang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: Optic disc and optic cup segmentation plays a key role in early diagnosis of glaucoma which is a serious eye disease that can cause damage to the optic nerve, retina, and may cause permanent blindness. To make the segmentation model more applicable to actual medical scenarios. We propose a multi-scale adaptive spatial attention network, which balances the high performance and computational efficiency of the model. A lightweight adaptive multi-branch convolution block is designed to balance accuracy and complexity, and the feature extraction ability of the network is enhanced without excessively increasing network parameters and ensuring lightweight. A spatial attention module that can dynamically adjust the obtained structural feature weights is designed, which not only improves the accuracy of the cup-disc segmentation task, but also significantly reduces the amount of parameters and reduces the computational burden. The Dice coefficients on the test set are 0.9676, 0.8563 for the optic cup region and 0.9632, 0.8871 for the optic disc region, respectively. The proposed method achieves competitive results compared to other state-of-the-art methods.

title: Monitoring of Paddy Plant from Digital Images using Deep Learning with Features Fusion
authors: A S Vickram
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Computerised monitoring of agricultural data is commonly adopted globally to ensure a better yield and profit. Plant disease due to the insects will cause heavy damage and reason for the major decrease in the outcome. Hence, a number of measures are suggested and one of the procedures is the drone-based monitoring of the plant health and implementing necessary action to overcome the issue. This research considered paddy-plat disease for the study and the outcome obtained for healthy/disease class is detected and analysed. This work considered the lightweight deep-learning (LD) based technique for analysing the plant disease using the conventional and fused-features. The different phases of this tool includes; labelled data collection and resizing it to required level, image features extraction with LD-scheme, executing SoftMax classification and analysing the outcome, developing the fused-features-vector (FFV) using best two model features after 50% reduction, and classification and confirming the outcome. This research considered 1400 images for the examination in which the outcome attained with 10 % data (140 images) are then verified to confirm the merit of the developed scheme. This work achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>97 \%$</tex> detection accuracy.

title: Classification of Mangosteen Fruit Quality Based on Microwave Signal Measurement and Machine Learning
authors: Suthami Ariessaputra, Catur Apriono, Fitri Yuli Zulkifli
abstract: This study investigates the classification of mangosteen fruit quality using non-destructive microwave measurements combined with machine learning techniques. The frequency range was set from 800 MHz to 10 GHz in a free-space transmission measurement setup, and the S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</inf> parameter was collected and analyzed. The Daubechies-4 wavelet collects the extraction features, resulting in 28 statistical features per sample. This research considers K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Random Forest (RF), and Naïve Bayes (NB) for the classification. The results show the highest classification accuracy and robustness, especially with Random Forest and Naïve Bayes, reaching up to 100% accuracy within the 4–8 GHz range. In contrast, SVM and KNN displayed performance degradation at the smaller frequency ranges. Combining a wide frequency range and ensemble-based classifiers improves fruit quality assessment using microwave signal analysis.

title: Investigation of the Radiation Characteristics of Bent Circular Polymer Microwave Fibers for Distributed Antenna System Applications
authors: Stefan Wögerbauer, Helmut Paulitsch, Michael E. Gadringer
abstract: Polymer microwave fibers experience a rise in applications due to their advantageous characteristics. Their high immunity against electromagnetic interference and flexibility make them suitable for many applications like communication and mm-wave radar. This work focuses on the electromagnetic radiation behavior at the bends of polymer microwave fibers and their possible usage in antenna system applications. Therefore, we theoretically discuss the radiation of bent fibers and verify this by laboratory measurements in the frequency range from 60GHz up to 90GHz. The observed behavior is discussed, and conclusions are drawn.

title: U-Net Based Near-to-Far-Field Transformation Under Limited Near-Field Measurement Area
authors: Eugene Lee, Seung Hee Jang, Won Hyo Kim, Yeon Jae Kim, Youngwook Kim
abstract: Accurate far-field radiation pattern prediction is essential for evaluating large antennas used in satellite communication, radar systems, and mobile networks, where performance verification under realistic deployment conditions is critical. However, direct far-field measurement is often impractical due to the large required distances and spatial constraints of measurement environments. Conventional NF2FF transformations demand dense and extensive near-field sampling, significantly increasing both cost and measurement time. In this study, we propose a Residual U-Net-based deep learning model that directly predicts the 2D far-field pattern from complex-valued near-field measurements. The proposed model demonstrates robust and consistent performance even under limited measurement areas, offering a computationally efficient and practical alternative to traditional physics-based NF2FF methods.

title: Classical, Quantum, and Hybrid Quantum-Classical SVMs for Binary Medical Classification
authors: Divyanshu Ranjan, Devendra Joshi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This paper presents an empirical comparison of pure quantum, hybrid quantum-classical, and classical support vector machines (SVMs) for binary medical classification on the Breast Cancer Wisconsin dataset. Taking advantage of uniform data preprocessing and feature selection, our hybrid QSVM with quantum kernel mapping coupled with classical optimization achieves accuracy of 98.25% compared with the classical SVM (94.74%) and pure quantum SVM (93.86%). In-depth benchmarking incorporates accuracy, recall, F1-score, and training time, exposing accuracy/computational cost trade-offs. We discuss how dimensionality of features and kernel selection influence model scalability and performance. Albeit constrained to a single dataset and simulation, this work enhances knowledge about hybrid quantum SVM benefits and real-world implications. Future efforts will seek to expand benchmarking to other datasets, include real quantum hardware assessment, and create explanation methods to improve interpretability and clinical usability.

title: Improved Three-Vector Model Predictive Current Control for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors
authors: Touseeq Zaman, Xiwei Zhou, Jiaxiong Zhang, Shifang Huang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In recent years, model predictive control methods have gained widespread application in permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) control due to their rapid response and suitability for multi-variable constraints. The traditional three-vector MPCC strategy has attracted scholarly attention for its potential to further enhance control accuracy by increasing the number of voltage vectors. Nevertheless, conventional three-vector MPCC still suffers from computational complexity, large torque ripple, and substantial fluctuations in the q-axis current. To further optimize control performance and reduce computational complexity, this paper proposes an enhanced three-vector MPCC strategy. This approach introduces a virtual voltage vector to mitigate steady-state error and dynamic fluctuations, while employing a space vector ratio method for precise calculation of vector action time. Concurrently, a binary search method is employed to determine the sub-sector where the reference voltage vector resides rapidly. Finally, simulation analysis under sudden load conditions for built-in permanent magnet synchronous motors validates the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: Millimeter Wave (MMW) Three-Dimensional (3-D) Reconstruction Algorithm Based on the Fusion of Time-Domain and Frequency-Domain
authors: Letian Zeng, Sheng Zhang, Qi Mao, Yuanyuan Huai, Yunhuai Zou, Jingzhao Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In scenarios involving non-contact millimeter wave (MMW) imaging, the information acquired through two-dimensional (2-D) imaging is inherently constrained, necessitating three-dimensional (3-D) reconstruction to achieve comprehensive analysis. However, it is challenging to simultaneously fulfill the criteria of both accuracy and efficiency by employing solely time-domain or frequency-domain algorithms. In order to address this challenge, this paper proposes an efficient 3-D reconstruction algorithm based on the fusion of time-domain and frequency-domain for MMW radar. Firstly, the Flatiron Institute nonuniform fast Fourier transform (FiNUFFT) is employed to mitigate the effects of range cell migration in the range-height domain with a high computing efficiency. Subsequently, the accelerated fast factorized back projection (AFFBP) algorithm is applied in the range-azimuth domain. The fast Fourier transform (FFT) and spectrum shifting are adopted to implement the fusion of 2-D spectrums of each subaperture range-azimuth data, which circumvent the time-consuming 2-D interpolation used in the recursive fusion process of the FFBP algorithm and substantially improve both the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed algorithm. The validity of the proposed algorithm is confirmed through simulation experiments and real data processing.

title: Blockchain-Assisted Federated Learning for Classification of Neurodegenerative Disorders Using Zero-Knowledge Proof
authors: Parikshith Nayaka S K, Dayanand Lal N
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Blockchain and Federated Learning (FL) provide a strong framework for distributed, privacypreserving machine learning in the medical field. In order to provide safe and effective model training, this framework assists in handling sensitive patient data from lung disease diagnosis, such as CT scans, X-rays, and clinical records. The proposed approach improves distributed machine learning security, privacy, and integrity, particularly in delicate fields like healthcare. Contributions from other datasets help the model get better, but patient data is kept private and blockchain guarantees the integrity of the updates to the model. ZeroKnowledge Proofs (ZKP) guarantee that customers can demonstrate the accuracy of their model upgrades without disclosing any personal information. FLBC- ZKP uses cryptographic proofs to remove this requirement for confidence. FLBC-ZKP models exhibit competitive accuracy rates in healthcare applications, guaranteeing confidentiality and privacy without compromising predictive performance. Contri- butions from other datasets improve the model, but patient information is kept confidential and the blockchain ensures the accuracy of model updates. Compared to regular FL, FLBC-ZKP delivers superior privacy and security through blockchain and ZKP, making it particularly suitable for sensitive healthcare data, while maintaining high accuracy. The accuracy data throughout federated learning rounds for a different approach, FLBC-ZKP slightly surpasses the other methods as the number of rounds increases.

title: Behavior Tree-Guided Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Decision-Making in Sea-Air Collaborative
authors: Yueshan Zhang, Mei Yang, Yan Zeng, Hao Chen, Lun Zhang, Jian Huang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Addressing the challenges in heterogeneous multi-agent decision-making for complex sea-air cooperative search and rescue (SAR) missions, such as dimensionality explosion, poor policy interpretability, and the cold-start problem, this paper proposes a hybrid intelligent decision-making framework that integrates Behavior Trees (BT) with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning (HRL). This framework combines the strengths of knowledge-driven and data-driven approaches: the high-level strategy employs Behavior Trees for modular and interpretable task decision-making (e.g., active search, focused monitoring), providing the system with a reliable tactical baseline and rapid response capability. The low-level control utilizes an Actor-Critic based HRL architecture to manage heterogeneous Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and Unmanned Surface Vessels (USVs) for continuous action execution. To enhance training efficiency and policy stability, a curriculum learning mechanism and a progressive opponent modeling strategy are designed, alongside dedicated reward functions tailored for search and monitoring tasks. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively mitigates the cold-start problem in reinforcement learning, accelerates the training process, and ultimately converges to high-performance and stable cooperative policies. This research provides a structured, scalable, and interpretable solution for multi-agent cooperative decision-making in complex dynamic environments.

title: Corrections to “Beyond L2: Leveraging Sinkhorn Distance for Improved Resistivity Recovery in 3-D Magnetotelluric Inversion”
authors: Fuying Yang, Yunhe Liu, Changchun Yin, Xiuyan Ren, Yang Su, Zhihao Rong, Xinpeng Ma, Zhiyuan Ke

title: Transformer-Based Natural Language Processing for Fake News Detection in Social Media Platforms
authors: V. Priyavarshini, Tamilarasan R, Vanitha D, Poovarasan P, Sai Pratab R. B
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The increasing growth of misinformation via social media platforms requires the development of effective detection methods for noisy, terse, and multimodal data. Existing techniques relied on learned features (shallow classifiers trained with hand-crafted features) or static embeddings that failed to describe context and did not understand text-image interaction. Deep learning for natural language processing allows for contextualized embeddings via transformer-based models, although unimodal models continue to minimize multimodal signals. The proposed system, CrossAlign, uses task-adapted transformer encoders (BERT and RoBERTa) for text, a vision transformer backbone for images, cross-modal attention with contrastive learning, and parameter-efficient adapters for scalability. The results of the proposed system outperform the existing systems, with 93% and 92.5% accuracy, respectively, and F1 ratings of 0.935 and 0.923 on Weibo and Twitter. The results indicate that learning using multimodal transformers significantly improves the performance of fake news detection.

title: Design and Measurements of a 10-12 GHz four-way Transformer-Based Power Divider in 22 nm FDSOI
authors: Evgenii Fedorov, Liubov Bakhchova, Vadim Issakov
abstract: This paper presents a transformer-based 1-to-4 power divider for 6G cell-free MIMO backhaul applications. It is comprised of four impedance inverters and implemented in GlobalFoundries 22 nm FDSOI CMOS process. For the desired frequency range of 10–12 GHz, full 5-port VNA measured results demonstrate an insertion loss of 2.7 dB, an amplitude imbalance between output ports of up to 0.6 dB, phase imbalance of 6.3°, an isolation better than >14.4 dB between all output ports, and return loss better than 15 dB. The device occupies 360 µm × 400 µm.

title: Deep Learning Based Phase Calibration for Enhanced Beam Control Accuracy
authors: Nam Jik Kim, Gilsu Jeong, Han Lim Lee
abstract: Phased array antennas are a cornerstone of next-generation communication and radar systems, where precise beam steering is essential. In practical applications, the use of 6-bit Beamforming Integrated Circuits (BFICs) imposes discrete phase control, while mutual coupling between antenna elements introduces significant errors, making conventional beam steering calculations based on Array Factor (AF) theory inaccurate. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework to overcome these limitations. We designed and compared three deep learning architectures—Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), 1D Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)—to predict the optimal phase correction values for a 4x4 microstrip patch array. The models are trained on a dataset generated via full-wave electromagnetic simulations to learn the complex, non-linear relationship between the target beam angle and the required phase compensation. The results demonstrate that the proposed models, particularly the 1D-CNN, can effectively learn to compensate for mutual coupling and quantization effects, predicting the precise phase configurations required to steer the beam to the target angle with high accuracy. This approach enables real-time, high-precision phase calibration without the need for complex iterative simulations, paving the way for intelligent antenna systems.

title: Comparison of Harmonics in Different Topologies of 11-Level Multilevel Inverter Using Different Loads in Matlab-Simulink
authors: Ashutosh Behera, Umesh Chandra Prusty, Debashish Mishra, Ramesh Chandra Prusty
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: A power electronic device that is becoming more common in medium-voltage and high-power electric systems is the multilayer inverter. Because of their special construction, multilevel inverters can achieve high voltages with lower harmonic content and electromagnetic interference (EMI). By employing several semiconductor switches with the insertion of the lowest voltages in DC, the multi-level inverter produces alternating voltage that is higher power, smoother, and less distorted than the traditional two-level inverter. Multilevel inverter architectures offer the unique benefit of operating at high dc-bus voltages for greater power applications. Switching devices are connected in series to achieve this. As the number of output voltages grows the output voltage waveform's harmonic content decreases. Furthermore, alternating between different voltage levels reduces output voltage harmonics. These days, there are three distinct topologies that may be used: flying capacitor, diode clamped, and cascaded H-bridge. In this project, we will evaluate the THD of these multi-level inverters and examine the various multi-inverter topologies in MATLAB Simulink at a fixed level (i.e., at 11 levels) using various loads, such as a motor load and a series RLC load.

title: QMADM-W: A Hybrid MADM Framework for Cloud Service Selection with Unavailable Data
authors: P Navya, Sanjaya Kumar Panda, Rashmi Ranjan Rout
abstract: The rapid expansion of cloud computing has made it increasingly difficult for users to determine the most appropriate cloud service provider (CSP). The provider offers diverse services, typically assessed based on quality of service (QoS) attributes, including throughput, reliability, availability, latency, and response time. Researchers often present these QoS attributes in a decision matrix and apply multi-attribute decision-making (MADM) algorithms to evaluate and rank the CSPs. However, in practical scenarios, not all CSPs satisfy every QoS attribute, leading to unavailable performance measure values in a decision matrix. To address this challenge, we develop a hybrid MADM framework for CSP selection that handles an incomplete decision matrix. The framework integrates QoS-aware MADM (QMADM) algorithms, QTOPSIS-W and QVIKOR-W with attribute weights (QMADM-W). It employs three imputation techniques to determine unavailable performance values: minimum (min), maximum (max), and mean. The weights are derived using the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) and the analytic network process (ANP). Simulation results using the QoS for web services (QWS) dataset demonstrate the framework's effectiveness in QTPOSIS-W, with consistent and robust performance observed under the mean imputation technique through sensitivity analysis. The proposed algorithms offer a reliable solution for selecting an optimal CSP, even for an incomplete decision matrix.

title: An Ontology-Driven Approach to Constructing a Spatiotemporal Knowledge Graph of Cultivated Land
authors: Jie Tang, Jingjin Huang, Tao Yue, Xinying Zhong, Zijun Ling, Yunhe Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In the natural resource domain, large volumes of spatiotemporal data remain weakly linked and under-utilized. Using eleven operational datasets on cultivated land as a case study, this paper systematizes business relationships and extracts spatiotemporal features. We adopt a combined top-down and bottom-up approach to construct a spatiotemporal ontology for cultivated land, and employ an ontology fusion method based on semantic and structural similarity to unify heterogeneous business ontologies, thereby addressing issues of cross-workflow information disconnection and inconsistent standards. For semi-structured data, we perform ontology-driven knowledge extraction to transform business data into a graph. We then integrate spatial relationships via URI matching and rule-based mapping to build a spatiotemporal knowledge graph of cultivated land, effectively coupling operational information with spatiotemporal information. The resulting graph supports rapid querying and underpins the construction of foundational knowledge bases for large models in the natural resources field.

title: Action-Aligned Video Pairing for Video Augmentation
authors: Randy Cahya Wihandika, Israel Mendonça, Masayoshi Aritsugi
abstract: Video augmentation is an effective strategy for improving the performance of action recognition models. A recent video augmentation strategy addresses scene bias by mixing human regions from one video with the background from another. However, this often produces artifacts due to limitations in the video mixing process, which degrade training quality. This study proposes a video augmentation strategy that produces compatible action-scene video pairs rather than choosing them randomly, to improve the quality of mixed videos. To achieve this, two compatibility metrics are introduced to guide this selection to significantly reduce the occurrence of visual artifacts and generate higher-quality augmented videos. Our method improves alignment between actions which leads to more effective augmentation. The performances are further enhanced by applying a temporal morphological operation to improve object detection consistency. Experimental results on the UCF101, HMDB51, and Kinetics-100 datasets show that our approach improves classification performance. Code is available at https://github.com/rendicahya/video-action-alignment.

title: Optimal Scale Combination Selection Based on Cost-Sensitivity and Sequential Three-Way Decision
authors: Yanjiao Ding, Qiong Mou, Peinuo Lv, Wang Yu, Yunlong Cheng, Yabin Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Optimal scale combination (OSC) selection is a crucial issue in the research of multi-scale decision system (MDS). However, most of the existing information processing procedures for finding the OSC adopt the fine-to-coarse pattern, which contradicts the coarse-to-fine pattern of human cognition. Moreover, most of the existing methods for finding the OSC do not take cost into consideration. To address the issues, the method of OSC selection based on cost-sensitivity and sequential three-way decision (S3WD) is proposed, which minimizes the total cost while preserving the classification ability. Firstly, a new strategy of optimal granularity selection that adopts attribute reduction followed by scale selection for MDS is proposed to remove the redundant attributes. Secondly, a new measurement of scale significance is defined and a forward heuristic optimal scale selection strategy is proposed. Finally, the OSC selection model based on cost-sensitivity and S3WD is proposed to determine the OSC with the minimum total cost while preserving the classification ability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can significantly reduce the cost of finding the OSC.

title: Accented Speech Recognition Featuring Convolutional Adapter with Token Bias for Non-native Chinese Speakers
authors: Hao Zhou, Chao Dai, Luping Wu, Jianguo Chen, Huazhen Wang, Yifei Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In response to the challenge of non-native Chinese speech recognition under low-resource conditions, this paper proposes a LLM-based adaptive fine-tuning model featuring token bias adapter and convolutional adapter for accented Chinese speech recognition. The token bias adapter module is inserted between the self-attention layer and the feed-forward layer of the pre-trained large speech model to obtain the speech token deviation vector matching the target accent. A convolutional adaptation module is inserted after the feed-forward layer to capture local receptive field encoding and refine the feature representations. Experimental results on the open-source and self-built datasets encompassing eight nations demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms the state-of-the-art methods, achieving a character error rate of 0.2088, with a parameter size approximately 2.65% of fully fine-tuned models.

title: EMG-based Continuous Trajectory Prediction using CNN-LSTM Networks
authors: Jihwan Won, Hyeonjung Kim, Cheolsoo Park
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Current camera-based hand tracking is limited by occlusion and environmental factors, hindering practical applications in robotics and digital interaction. Although electromyography-based tracking offers a robust alternative, a fine movement regression, such as pen trajectory prediction, remains challenging. This study addresses the problem of predicting 2 dimensional axes’ velocities of a pen using 8-channel forearm electromyography signals. We propose a novel deep learning approach based on the decomposed electromyography methodology, which transforms complex raw signals into latent and independent muscle activation patterns for effective movement command learning. Furthermore, we integrate a signal reconstruction mechanism during the training process. By minimizing the reconstruction loss, the model is jointly optimized for both velocity decoding accuracy and physiological fidelity of the signal representation. This approach allows for the experimental validation of a model that utilizes the muscle signals alone to predict the continuous pen input, demonstrating the feasibility and potential for advancing camera-free digital handwriting and human-computer interaction.

title: Functional Connectivity-Driven Diagnosis of ADHD and ASD via Transfer Learning on rs-fMRI Data
authors: Khushi Jain, Akanksha Upadhyay, Vaishali Chawla, Navjot Singh, Bharti Rana
abstract: Neurodevelopmental conditions such as Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) alter functional connectivity (FC) among the brain regions. ADHD and ASD affect <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 - 6 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 - 2 \%}$</tex> of the population, respectively and hence need immediate attention to develop automated differential diagnosis. This work proposes an automated diagnostic system for ADHD and ASD by investigating FC among brain regions. We used publicly available restingstate functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (rs-fMRI) data for ADHD, ASD and age-matched healthy (HC) subjects. The rsfMRI data helps to analyse the temporal activity in the brain, and computing FC using time-series data helps to capture the temporal correlation among regions. We used five diverse FC measures and performed three classification tasks: ASD vs. ADHD, ASD vs. HC and ADHD vs. HC. Further, we finetuned the pre-trained VGG19 model to develop a decision model. The best accuracy of 99.09% for ASD vs. ADHD, 78.18% for ADHD vs. HC and 65.46% for ASD vs. HC demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed method. The disrupted regions are also identified using SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), an explainable artificial intelligence method, that are in accordance with the literature. The work demonstrates the capability of deep learning in analysing neuroimaging data for clinical and research applications.

title: An Interpretable Deep Learning Framework for Diabetic Retinopathy Grading Using Ben Graham Enhancement and Grad-CAM++
authors: D. Ramalakshmi, M. Maheswari
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is a progressive retinal disease and a primary contributor to preventable blindness globally. Early detection through automated systems can significantly improve clinical outcomes, but such systems must be both accurate and interpretable to gain trust in medical settings. This research introduces an interpretable deep learning framework that integrates Ben Graham image enhancement with Grad-CAM++ visualization for robust DR grading. A modified MobileNetV3-Large architecture is employed, fine-tuned with a custom classifier and trained on a balanced dataset using weighted random sampling to address severe class imbalance across five DR stages. The pre-processing pipeline incorporates circular cropping and Gaussian unsharp masking, enhancing critical retinal structures such as microaneurysms, haemorrhages, and exudates, while preserving diagnostic integrity. Grad-CAM++ is used to generate pixel-level attention maps that provide insight into the model's decision process, making the predictions more explainable to clinicians. The model achieves a validation accuracy of 93.2 % reflecting high consistency across classes. Class-wise precision, recall, and F1 scores further confirm balanced learning and generalization. Visualizations consistently highlight clinically relevant regions, supporting the interpretability of the predictions. This combination of enhancement and explain ability techniques offers a practical and trustworthy approach to DR screening. The framework bridges the gap between deep learning performance and medical transparency, offering a deployable solution for real-world ophthalmic diagnosis and decision support.

title: A Multi-dimensional XGBoost-based Prediction Framework for Intelligent Collaborative Governance
authors: Weikai Yan, Weiwei He, Wei Qin, Ershun Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Accurate collaborative entity performance prediction is pivotal to realizing high-efficiency intelligent collaborative governance in complex industrial ecosystems. Nevertheless, the heterogeneity of data modalities used to characterize collaborative entity profiles, along with the intricate nonlinear correlations embedded within such multi-source data, substantially elevates the challenge of precise entity performance forecasting. To tackle these obstacles and achieve reliable entity performance prediction, this paper proposes a multi-dimensional XGBoost-based entity profiling and prediction framework, encompassing three core modules: systematic data acquisition, multi-modal data preprocessing, and the construction of a customized multi-dimensional XGBoost model for entity profile inference. Moreover, to strengthen model interpretability—a critical requirement for governance decision-making—targeted feature importance analysis is implemented across distinct entity profiling labels, thereby revealing the quantitative and qualitative impacts of various factors on entity operational performance. Experimental validation is conducted using real-world industrial datasets from a Shanghai-based automotive manufacturer, and the results demonstrate that the proposed framework can not only conduct in-depth entity profile data analytics and achieve high-precision entity profile prediction, but also generate interpretable inference outcomes to underpin data-driven intelligent collaborative governance decisions..

title: Knowledge-Guided Parameter Identification Neural Network for Time-Varying Systems
authors: Siyou Tao, Kaikun Wang, Miao Liu, Jicheng Chen, Yan Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of modeling dynamic systems with time-varying parameters. A novel learning-based framework is proposed that integrates a parameter identification network with an underlying mathematical system model. The neural network learns to predict time-varying parameters under the guidance of prior physical knowledge, while the mathematical model provides structural constraints by evaluating the consistency of the predicted outputs. This tight coupling enables the model to leverage both data-driven flexibility and domain-specific knowledge, improving estimation accuracy and robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance in parameter identification and exhibits enhanced generalization capability, particularly in scenarios involving extrapolation and limited training data.

title: Enhanced Load Frequency Control in Interconnected Power Systems Using Shuffled Shepherd Optimization Algorithm (SSOA) for PIDn Tuning
authors: Jonathan David G. Quiling, Rovick P. Tarife
abstract: This study presents an improved Load Frequency Control (LFC) strategy for a two-area thermal power system by employing a PID controller with derivative filtering (PIDn) optimized using the Shuffled Shepherd Optimization Algorithm (SSOA). The SSOA algorithm leverages a combination of adaptive step-size adjustment and multi-community guidance to achieve a balance between global exploration and local exploitation in the search space. The main objective is to reduce frequency fluctuations and tie-line power deviations arising from sudden load variations, particularly under nonlinear conditions such as Generator Rate Constraints (GRC). The effectiveness of the proposed SSOA-PIDn controller is validated through simulation studies under two different operational scenarios. Comparative analysis reveals that the SSOA-based tuning achieves superior performance over classical and several well-known metaheuristic optimization methods in terms of Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE) and system settling time. Furthermore, sensitivity analysis under parameter uncertainties confirms the robustness and reliability of the proposed method for practical deployment in modern interconnected power systems.

title: Leveraging AI and Gamification to Enhance Vietnamese University Students' Motivation and Engagement: An SDT Approach
authors: Tam Tran Luu, Luan Trong Nguyen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: In today's digital education, universities are applying many learning methods and ways of learning for students, aiming to create many learning conditions for students to have many opportunities to develop multi-faceted aspects in learning. Seeing the great potential of the gamification model, organizations and educators have incorporated this model into mainstream lessons and methods for students to be exposed to regularly. Gamification has impacted the motivation and engagement of university students, combining discovery and learning through Self-Determination Theory (SDT). The application of digital learning platforms especially at a university in Vietnam, factors such as motivation to promote learning and regular participation, through the research results not only see the impact of the model on students and their feelings about the model but also find out the limitations and difficulties when applying this model to students, thereby having an overview from many aspects of students when they experience and bring to the final results. This is necessary to develop and improve the gamification model in the future in parallel to be able to address the gaps in evaluating the performance of gamification in higher education, explore the opportunities and challenges surrounding the gamification model, the insights will give results to help educators and organizations have the right direction in applying the gamification model in the modern educational context.

title: Task Data Clustering Method Based On Quantum Genetic Algorithm
authors: Xun Wang, Quan Wen, Qinghui Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The geospatial distribution characteristics are an important factor affecting the execution of various operational operations, emergency rescue and other tasks. Reasonable grouping of tasks is an important link in the effective execution of large-scale tasks. The task grouping is essentially a data clustering problem based on geographical location. A mathematical optimization model for minimizing the distance between tasks in a group is constructed. On the basis of the quantum genetic algorithm, the quantum bit encoding and quantum rotation gate population update mechanism for the clustering problem are studied, and the flow of the quantum genetic algorithm is given. Finally, the superiority of the quantum genetic algorithm is verified by comparing with the genetic algorithm through simulation.

title: SGGC-Net: A High-Resolution Network with Lightened Residual Modules for Human Keypoints Detection
authors: Jing Li, Tingting Guo, Yingchao Yang, Lingchen Gu, Wenbo Wan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Human keypoint detection plays a crucial role in understanding human actions in images and videos. Although research on high-resolution networks has achieved remarkable performance, their heavy reliance on standard convolutions results in a high parameter count and considerable computational burden. In response to this limitation, we introduce the Simplified Group Coordinate Attention Convolutional Network (SGGC-Net)—a redesigned lightweight high-resolution model that integrates two novel modules: the SGneck bottleneck module and the GCblock residual module. By effectively combining depthwise separable convolutions with linear operations and embedding a coordinate attention mechanism, our model significantly reduces complexity while preserving rich spatial information. Additionally, we incorporate an Unbiased Data Processing (UDP) to mitigate alignment errors and improve detection accuracy. Our method is evaluated on the MS COCO and MPII datasets, where it improves detection accuracy and outperforms heavier networks like HRNet. SGGC-Net reduces parameters and computational complexity by over 40% compared to HRNet, achieving a favorable trade-off between performance and resource efficiency for practical deployment in human keypoint detection.

title: An Advanced Hybrid Strategy for Detecting Fraud in Mobile Money Services
authors: Kaung Wai Thar, Thinn Thinn Wai
abstract: Mobile payment systems are growing in popularity as more people use smartphones, which also attracts fraudsters. As a result, mobile money fraud is increasing, especially in developing countries. However, security concerns in mobile money services have gained attention because weak security has kept many customers away. Fraud is not a new problem, but it still costs the global economy billions of dollars each year. Financial transaction data, including mobile money transactions, are mostly labeled as legitimate, making fraud detection difficult. Researchers have developed various fraud detection methods using various machine learning techniques like LGBM, random forests, SVM, deep learning, neural networks, XGBoost, and logistic regression have been tested to identify fraudulent transactions through data preparation, feature engineering, and model building. However, machine learning models trained on imbalanced data tend to be biased toward legitimate transactions, making them unreliable. This study aims to use machine learning classifiers to detect fraud in mobile money transfers. The data comes from real-time transactions that mimic common fraud schemes. This research explores the development and evaluation of ML models for fraud detection and proposes a solution using a hybrid ML approach with effective hyperparameter tuning, and the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE). The results show that the proposed approach improves accuracy by addressing data imbalance. The findings contribute to the development of better fraud detection systems for mobile money services.

title: Design and Implementation of a Spring Boot-Based Web Platform for Interactive Fundus Image Analysis
authors: Haozhe Zhang, Fangyuan Lin, Ruofei Wang, Bowen Li, Bingkun Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: There are pain points for doctors to manually interpret fundus images to diagnose diseases, such as low work efficiency, early microscopic lesions that are easily missed due to inconspicuous characteristics, and diagnostic results that are greatly affected by the doctor’s experience level and subjective judgment. This paper designs and implements a set of interactive analysis web platforms for fundus images based on the SpringBoot framework to provide an integrated solution for the full-process intelligent diagnosis of fundus diseases. The platform completes the remote deployment and efficient scheduling of deep learning-assisted diagnosis models. At the same time, it focuses on front-end usability development and builds key modules such as user rights management, image secure upload, model online reasoning, dynamic visualization of analysis results, and historical record tracing. It supports users in the entire closed-loop process from image upload, intelligent analysis to report generation. Experimental results show that the platform is fully functional, and the average adaptation time for medical staff does not exceed 15 minutes. Regarding diagnostic performance, the integrated deep learning models achieved an average diagnostic accuracy of 96.5% and a Dice coefficient of 0.89 for choroid segmentation on the test dataset, verifying their clinical utility. In the performance test, under the pressure of 100 concurrent users, the average response time of the core model inference interface was less than 1 second, the throughput was stable at more than 41 req/s, and the system ran robustly. This platform has significantly improved the efficiency and accuracy of fundus disease diagnosis, provided reliable software framework support for AI technology to empower clinical research, and has strong engineering application value and clinical promotion prospects.

title: OpenVPN with Hybrid Post-Quantum Cryptography on Constrained Devices
authors: Murad Ragab, Bahareh Pahlevanzade
abstract: Nowadays, Quantum computing presents a greater threat to classical cryptography, pushing towards the need for post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) solutions. This study assesses the performance of hybrid (classical and PQC) and pure PQC algorithms-specifically ML-KEM (Kyber) and MLDSA (Dilithium)-in VPN deployments on resource-constrained devices. Benchmarks across NIST security levels 1, 3, and 5 assess per-phase cryptographic runtime (key generation, encapsulation/decapsulation, signing/verification), connectionestablishment latency under network impairments, and bandwidth during sustained transfer. Results show pure PQC algorithms offer superior computational runtime, while hybrid approaches provide dual-algorithm assurance and comparable steady-state bandwidth once tunnels are established. We report wall-clock runtime on the stated platform and refrain from energy or peak-memory claims; platform-specific energy/memory profiling is deferred to future work. We provide artifacts and methodology to enable reproduction.

title: Proton Irradiation Enhanced and Degraded Performance of GaN Power Amplifier Circuits
authors: Shao-Chun Huang, Yi-Lun Huang, Yuan-Hung Huang, Chao-Hsin Wu
abstract: In this work, we investigate the effects of proton-induced total ionizing dose (TID) on a Ka-band GaN power amplifier (PA) fabricated using a 0.12 um process. The results show that at low (200 krad) and medium (1000 krad) dose levels, key performance metrics including small-signal and large-signal performance exhibit slight improvements. At a higher dose of 1500 krad, however, cumulative radiation damage leads to performance degradation. The underlying physical mechanisms are further analyzed to provide insight into circuit-level radiation-hardening strategies that mitigate TID-induced degradation in satellite communication systems, particularly suited for space-qualified communication payloads and other radiation-intensive, high-reliability platforms and applications.

title: Evolution of Oral Cancer Detection Techniques with VELscope and AI Integration
authors: Ravi Kumar A, Nanditha B R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Early detection of oral cancer is critical for improving survival outcomes, yet conventional screening methods remain limited by subjectivity and delayed recognition of early-stage lesions. This paper presents a structured review and conceptual framework centered on the VELscope device, a non-invasive autofluorescence imaging system that employs blue light (400–460 nm) to excite intrinsic fluorophores. Healthy mucosa typically exhibits green fluorescence, whereas dysplastic or malignant tissues demonstrate loss of fluorescence (LOF), appearing darker under examination. No new experiments were conducted; instead, this work synthesizes current evidence on VELscope's working principles, diagnostic performance, and clinical relevance, while highlighting advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) and spectroscopy. AI-based models, including machine learning and deep learning approaches, have shown promise in improving classification accuracy, while spectroscopy provides complementary biochemical confirmation. However, challenges persist, including high false-positive rates, inter-operator variability, and limited availability of large annotated datasets. The primary contributions of this work are twofold: (i) a systematic synthesis of existing VELscope-based literature and its integration with AI and spectroscopy, and (ii) the proposal of a conceptual AI-spectroscopy workflow to guide future research. This positions VELscope as a potential pathway toward intelligent, cost-effective, and community-deployable screening solutions for oral cancer.

title: QHCL-AOC-IDS: An Uncertainty-aware Online Intrusion Detection System with Quadruplet-Hard Contrastive Learning
authors: Zishu Liu, Jingfeng Xue, Wenjie Guo, Wenbiao Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) must cope with concept drift and zero-day attacks under evolving, partially labeled traffic. While AOC-IDS enables self-adaptive detection via autoencoders and online pseudo-labeling, its pairwise objective yields insufficient abnormal separation, noisy label propagation, and weak open-set ability. We present QHCL-AOC-IDS, an uncertainty-aware online IDS that couples Quadruplet-Hard Contrastive Learning (QHCL) with confidence-based adaptation and open-set rejection. QHCL enforces (i) anchor–hard-negative margins and (ii) negative–negative diversity, producing discriminative embeddings. An uncertainty-aware pseudolabeler filters low- confidence samples to curb error accumulation. A lightweight open-set module models normal embeddings and rejects out-of-distribution traffic. On NSL-KDD and UNSW-NB15, QHCL-AOC-IDS improves overall F1 and zero-day detection rate over strong baselines (AOC-IDS, AE, supervised CNN/MLP). It also exhibits faster and more stable online adaptation. Code, configs, and scripts for reproducibility are provided.

title: MySecureMap: A Geolocation-Based Recommender System for Safety and Healthy Environment
authors: Preecha Tangworakitthaworn, Poramet Kaewpradub, Patcharapon Hathaichot, Waritthorn Mahasiripanya
abstract: This research presents the MySecureMap system, a geolocation-based recommender system designed for real-time air quality visualization and safetyfocused navigation. The system leverages the Air Quality Index (AQI) data provided by both government and private sources. The proposed mechanism has integrated the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network's machine learning technique which is capable of predicting the AQI levels and providing the route recommendations. The ultimate goal of the proposed system aims to protect users from the hazardous air pollutants by automatically identifying the risk zones and suggesting the safe routes which are visualized on the map. This paper discusses the proposed approach and the system architecture, the design and the development of the proposed MySecureMap system, and the performance evaluation, highlighting its usability and effectiveness in enhancing the environmental awareness and public health. The performance evaluation results shown that the proposed system met the acceptable accuracy with Mean absolute percent error (MAPE) of 2.39% when comparing the predicted forecast value with the real AQI data observed for the next 12 hours.

title: A Flexible and Efficient Framework for Multigoal Path Planning in Connected Grid Environments
authors: Wei-Dian Lai
abstract: Multigoal path planning aims to identify the shortest feasible path through a series of objective points, and this represents a fundamental challenge in robot and autonomous vehicle systems. Although optimal solutions can be identified for small-scale problems, the presence of a large number of objective combinations makes precise algorithms impractical for handling large-scale problems. This paper presents a comprehensive framework that combines the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{A}^{*}$</tex> algorithm with a strategic path optimization layer to address the problem of multigoal path planning. Two main strategies are compared: brute-force search for small-scale problems (eight objectives or fewer) and nearest neighbor for large-scale problems. A connectivity-preserving grid generation algorithm is proposed to ensure both path feasibility and a robust evaluation platform.

title: Future Load Profile Nomination (FLPN) in PV-BESS-EV Microgrids: A Philippine Use Case
authors: Jeric Cesar A. Enriquez, Abdul Aziz G. Mabaning
abstract: Modern power systems face challenges amidst the increased integration of distributed energy resources such as photovoltaic (PV) systems, battery energy storage systems (BESS), and electric vehicles (EVs), which introduce complexity and uncertainty of demand profiles. Hence, this study proposes an optimization framework incorporating Future Load Profile Nominations (FLPN) as proactive, consumer-declared forecasts for energy dispatch planning, enabling a Proactive Energy Management (PEM) approach to grid operations. The IEEE 14-bus system is used as a testbed, with PV, BESS, and EV assets scaled proportionally to static loads at each bus. Dispatch optimization is performed under Philippine time-of-use pricing using a Monte Carlo approach to model FLPN uncertainty. Three scenarios are evaluated: (i) baseline dispatch without FLPN, (ii) FLPN-assisted dispatch with flexible EV charging, and (iii) FLPN-assisted dispatch with bidirectional Vehicle-to-Grid participation. Results show that while FLPN visibility alone yields limited operational benefits, its integration with flexible and controllable EVs achieves substantial improvements, reducing dispatch costs by up to 6.8% and lowering grid dependency up to 3%. This approach aims to contribute to achieving United Nation Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy) and 13 (Climate Action) by promoting proactive, more resilient, and consumer-integrated energy management strategies.

title: Leveraging Learning Analytics and Cloud-Based Platforms for Data-Driven Educational Management and Policy Decision-Making
authors: Sri Devi Banu S, Preethi Sheshadri
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research describes an intelligent scholastic analytics ecology using Transformer models and federated learning to predict Student performance using AWS SageMaker to maintain biometric privacy and other student this confident information. The framework is responsible for the prediction of deep sentiment by taking advantage of the 2.4 million set of student feedback records by exploiting BERT-based sentiment prediction in context and TabTransformer architectures for multidimensional learning outcome prediction with 91.7% prediction accuracy. We model the complex relationships between learner, content and instructor, using GraphNeural Networks, GNN and reveal some non-obvious patterns of curriculum effectiveness. Implemented in 450 education institutions is Apache Kafka, a cloud-native application for data streaming in real-time allowing the use of MLflow, the open-source cloud platform designed to monitor ML experiments. Automated Policy Recommendation engine based on reinforcement learning is used to optimize the resource allocation and attention mechanism provides an interpretable insight on critical intervention points The system had 15TB of educational data every month and allowed administrators to identify at-risk students 8 weeks ahead of time as opposed to traditional models and increase student retention rates by 23%..

title: Causal LIME: Enhancing Local Explanations with Causal Perturbations for Military Sensor Data
authors: Trupthi Rao, Navjot Singh, Sonali Agarwal
abstract: Interpretability is vital in safety-critical domains such as defense, where understanding model behavior is crucial for building trust, ensuring accountability, and supporting decision-making. Traditional local explanation techniques, such as Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations (LIME), often neglect the causal relationships among input features. This oversight can result in misleading or spurious interpretations, particularly in complex, high-stakes environments. To address this limitation, we propose Causal LIME, an extension of LIME that incorporates causal graphs to guide the generation of perturbations in a manner consistent with the underlying data-generating mechanisms. This ensures that explanations respect the causal structure of the domain, leading to more trustworthy insights. We evaluate Causal LIME along three dimensions: (i) comparative analysis with traditional LIME, (ii) validation against permutation-based feature importance, and (iii) application to real-world military sensor data for vehicle classification. Experimental results demonstrate that Causal LIME produces more stable, causally grounded explanations, reinforcing its value in mission-critical AI applications where interpretability, reliability, and trust are paramount.

title: VoCare AI: A Multi-Agent LLM Workflow for Improved Clinic Operational Efficiency
authors: Derrick Lim Jo Han, Pai Chet Ng, Malcolm Yoke Hean Low
abstract: In Singapore's polyclinics, touch-based self-service kiosks are widely used for administrative functions such as appointment scheduling and billing. However, these systems pose accessibility challenges for elderly patients, often resulting in increased staff workload and longer wait times. This paper presents VoCare AI, a voice-first conversational assistant designed to streamline healthcare administrative tasks through multiagent workflows powered by Large Language Models (LLMs). The system integrates a graph-based orchestration framework (LangGraph) with specialized agents that manage NRIC-based identity verification, appointment handling, billing queries, and general FAQ responses. It features a fine-tuned Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) model adapted for Singapore-accented English (Singlish), trained on the IMDA National Speech Corpus to handle accent variability, code-switching, and elderly speech patterns.
