Evaluation results show that the best-performing ASR model achieved a Word Error Rate (WER) of 22.22%, while the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) module demonstrated strong performance with 1.00 groundedness and 0.92 retrieval relevance. By focusing on Singapore's linguistic diversity and incorporating localized authentication mechanisms, this work demonstrates how AI-driven conversational agents can enhance accessibility and operational efficiency in public healthcare environments. The complete source code for this work is publicly available at: https://github.com/DerrickLJH2000/langgraph-voice-assistant.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Fish Species Identification and Disease Detection: A VGG16-MobileNetV2 Framework
authors: Rajesh Kumar T, Sharu Deshini A, Nandhitha K P, Ranjith T
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The study aims to develop a deep learning model that focuses on fish species identification and disease detection by using VGG16 and MobileNetV2. The approach uses a modified VGG architecture for analyzing the fish images which involves the incorporation of frozen base layer along with enhanced pooling and dense layer for disease identification. A MobileNetV2 architecture is used for species identification which involves features like rescaling, dense connections, and dropout that minimizes over fitting. The dataset includes both healthy and diseased fishes which are used for training and evaluating the model. Adam optimizer and early stopping methods are used for performance enhancement. The research emphasizes the ability of deep learning model to improve the efficiency and accuracy in fish species identification and disease detection by handling challenges like availability of high-quality dataset and challenges related to species diversity. The fish disease detection is very crucial which helps in reducing the economic losses in aquaculture and in maintaining fish population. This research contributes to the development of fisheries management and efficient in use of marine resources by identifying the fish species and detecting the diseases early.

title: Graph Neural Network with Physics-Informed Attention for Robust Fault Localization in Power Grids
authors: Diddi Mani Kumar, Mohini Mohan Sawarkar, Arun Kumar Arigela, Saziya Tabbassum, Abira. A, Girish M Dhote T
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Dynamic load variations, distributed generation, and environment contribute to the inherent complexity of power grids, which are highly susceptible to various faults. Proper and prompt fault localization is essential in supporting and ensuring stability of the system as well as reducing downtime. The proposed architecture PIA-GNN is a hybrid of graph neural networks and physics-informed attention created to learn topological and physical power grid laws. The framework treats buses as nodes and transmission line as edges and introduces electrical measures, and line parameters in the learning process and applies the laws of Kirchhoff in guiding attention weight. It is experimentally tested on real fault dataset that PIA-GNN achieves an accuracy of 98.99% in fault localization and is sufficiently robust in noisy, incomplete and dynamic working conditions. The attention mechanism has the capability of providing interpretable facts that they extract the role that important buses and lines are involved in the determination of a fault. Such results indicate that the framework is an exceptionally efficient, stable, and explainable model that offers practical help to grid operators to recognize, isolate as well as overcome faults using multi-faceted power systems.

title: Design of Wind Direction and Speed Data Acquisition System Based on STM32
authors: Weiqian Kong, Yilin Zhang, Mingju Gong, Wei Xu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To meet the high-precision data requirements for wind power prediction and provide data support for the scientific site selection of wind farms, a wind direction and speed data acquisition system based on STM32 has been designed. This system uses the STM32L151C8T6 ultra-low power chip as the microcontroller and combines the wind direction sensor, wind speed sensor and A7680C module. It wakes up the microcontroller from the stop mode at regular intervals to collect data and GPS information. After data encapsulation and processing, the data is stored and uploaded to the cloud server. The cloud server receives data via the TCP protocol and then parses and displays it. To further optimize the system's energy efficiency, dynamic power management is implemented in the circuit. The system adopts a low-power working mechanism and dynamically schedules tasks to reduce power consumption. The experimental results show that the system operates stably, with complete and accurate data. Moreover, the average daily power consumption is 350.75 mAh and the effective data upload rate is 100%.

title: Dynamic Deployment Strategy of Decoy Nodes in High-Risk Network Segments Based on Cyber Threat Intelligence
authors: Ruixiang Fan, Zhibin Zheng, Zhiyuan Luo, Rixuan Qiu, Tong Zhang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the growing informatization of power systems, critical networks face increasing cybersecurity risks. Traditional honeypot deployments lack intelligence guidance and adaptability, making them ineffective against stealthy APT and lateral movement attacks. This paper proposes a Threat Intelligence-driven Dynamic Node Deployment Policy (TI-DNDP) that fuses multi-source threat intelligence with real-time traffic data using deep learning for anomaly detection and attack analysis. By integrating game theory and reinforcement learning, the method dynamically infers attacker behavior and deploys Moving Target Defense (MTD) strategies to optimize honeypot placement and deception. Experiments show that TI-DNDP improves active defense and resilience in cyber-physical power systems.

title: Demonstration of MorphoChrome: Real-time, Handheld Fabrication of Programmable Structural Color
authors: Paris G Myers, Yunyi Zhu, Ben Miller, Stefanie Mueller
publish: Adjunct Proceedings of the 10th ACM Symposium on Computational Fabrication
abstract: None

title: A Comprehensive Comparative Study on Text-to-Image Generative Large Models
authors: Jia Wei, Chen Li, Xinyu Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Text-to-image generation is a cornerstone of digital creation, yet mainstream models diverge in semantic grasp and scene versatility. This study evaluate the gaps in existing benchmarks by introducing a test suite of 24 prompts across 6 scene categories, evaluating Doubao, ERNIE Bot, Qwen, and Runway Gen-4 via CLIP scores, NIQE metrics, and human ratings. Results show Doubao's supremacy in photorealistic contexts (CLIP 0.315, NIQE 45.6); ERNIE Bot's stylistic flair with unstable quality; Qwen's strength in imaginative synthesis; and Runway Gen-4's precision in high-resolution close-ups. It provides a quantitative guide for model selection.

title: MPVLT: An efficient lightweight multi-modal prompted vision-language tracker for target tracking
authors: Jianyu Xie, Xin Li, Bo Lyu, Yan Fu, Junlin Zhou, Duanbing Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: The target tracking that fuses visual and language data has high tracking accuracy and robustness. However, traditional tracking methods suffer from weak semantic indication, low transfer efficiency, and weak modelling of vision-language association. To address these issues, an efficient lightweight fine-tuning model named Multi-modal Prompted Vision-Languange Tracker (MPVLT) is proposed to track target. Three key modules are proposed detailly, language indication enhancement, vision-language input enhancement, and dynamic prompt fusion. The performance of the proposed model is evaluated on three datasets: TNL2K, LaSOT, and OTB99-Lang. Compared with baseline models, tracking success rate of MPVLT is increased by 3.2%, 4.4%, and 2.3%, respectively, and its precision is increased by 1.8%, 2.1%, and 0.7%, respectively. Meanwhile, the model proposed just uses less than 3% of learning parameters for fine-tuning, saving 52.0% of training time and 35.3% of video memory. The proposed model achieves rather good transfer property comparing with traditional models.

title: Deep Learning for Turbid Waters: A Noise-Robust Faster R-CNN with Res2Net101 and Data Augmentation
authors: K. Dora Babu, T. Aditya Sai Srinivas, R. Varaprasad, M. Ramu, A. Sai Rekha, K. Swathi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Detecting objects underwater poses significant challenges due to factors like light diffusion, turbidity, and occlusion, which degrade image quality and hinder traditional detection methods. To tackle these issues, this paper introduces an advanced Faster R-CNN framework tailored for real-time underwater object detection. Key innovations include: (1) Enhancing multi-scale feature extraction with Res2Net101 instead of the default VGG16 backbone, (2) Implementing Generalized Intersection over Union (GIoU) loss for precise bounding box regression, (3) Integrating Soft Non-Maximum Suppression (Soft-NMS) to maintain accurate detections in cluttered environments, and (4) Utilizing Online Hard Example Mining (OHEM) and mosaic data augmentation to handle class imbalance and enhance generalization.Experiments conducted on a carefully curated dataset of 1,863 underwater images demonstrate that our model achieves an mAP@0.5 of 80.3%, surpassing the baseline Faster R-CNN by 2.1%. Significant enhancements are observed in detecting small and occluded objects. The framework also delivers practical inference speeds, achieving 10 frames per second (FPS) on an NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPU. These capabilities make it well-suited for applications such as marine biodiversity monitoring and underwater resource management.

title: LIO-Based Navigation and Local Path Adjustment for Substation Drone Inspection
authors: Weiwei Kang, Dukang Li, Xing Zhang, Jiajia Song
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In recent years, autonomous inspection using unmanned devices has become increasingly vital in substations, with drones emerging as a preferred choice due to their maneuverability and ability to navigate complex, multi-level environments. Traditional real-time localization relies heavily on GPS; however, strong electromagnetic interference in substations severely limits GPS signal reliability, compromising positioning accuracy. Additionally, dynamic changes in the local environment, such as the appearance or disappearance of obstacles, render static prior maps insufficient, potentially leading to collisions. To address these challenges, we propose a navigation system for substation drones based on Lidar-Inertial Odometry (LIO), enabling robust localization while dynamically updating local prior maps and replanning local paths in response to real-time obstacle detection. Furthermore, considering the indoor-outdoor transitions typical of substations, we introduce a scene transition detection algorithm using local point cloud density, adaptively adjusting key parameters of the SLAM upon detecting environmental shifts. Field deployments confirm that our method delivers reliable navigation and robust obstacle handling, meeting the stringent demands of substation inspection.

title: Knowledge Graph Enhanced Bidirectional Intent-Aware Person-Job Recommendation Approach
authors: Anqi Ye, Renqi Zhu, Mingyu Liu, Lin Pan, Bo Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In the context of intelligent recruitment, traditional person-job recommendation approaches struggle to effectively capture the complex interaction intents between users and job positions. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Knowledge Graph Enhanced Bidirectional Intent-Aware Person-Job Recommendation Approach(KG-BIAM). The proposed method first constructs a domain-specific Knowledge Graph to enable multidimensional representation of user and job intents. Second, a cross-intent attention mechanism is designed to model the interaction between user intent and job intent, thereby enhancing matching accuracy. Finally, a multilayer graph convolutional network(GCN) is employed to aggregate semantic information from the Knowledge Graph and further refine the intent representations. Experimental evaluations are conducted on a real-world data set obtained from "ZhaoPin.com". The results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing baseline models in key performance metrics such as AUC, F1-score and Balanced Accuracy, thereby validating its effectiveness.

title: ContractIQ : A Multimodal RAG-Based Agentic System for Intelligent Contract Understanding
authors: Abhay A Rao, Abhay Raghavendra Revankar, Nikita Nair, Shreya Mittal, Uma D, Ujjwal Mohan Kumar
abstract: When organizations in industries like finance, health-care, real estate, and technology deal with intricate, high-risk contracts, legal contract analysis cannot be avoided. Accurate and proper analysis assists in the interpretation of minute details, evaluation of risks, and adherence in contracts. Smart contractual automation is needed since manual checking is cumbersome and susceptible to errors. By applying Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), an agentic eleven-coordinated agent, and Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting to interpret legal analysis, the study proposes a legal contract analysis system based on Google's Gemini large language model (LLM). The system includes Clause extraction, definition detection, risk analysis, compliance checks, QnA and summarization. Gemini can be finely adapted to be used in the legal field through LoRA finetuning. Testing achieves strong performance: ROUGE-1 of 0.42, ROUGE-2 of 0.38, ROUGEL of 0.40, F1 score of 0.70, and BLEU of 0.45, indicating high-quality legal text generation. This solution significantly reduces manual labor but with enhanced legal precision and compliance.

title: Effective Emulation of PSS Systems via Retrieval Augmented Generation
authors: Xiangwei Zhou, Guan Wang, Ningning Zhang, Aziguli Wulamu, Ao He
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: We present a training-free retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) framework that emulates the behavioral interface of legacy Unisys mainframes used in airline Passenger Service Systems (PSS). By dynamically injecting domain-specific command syntax, transaction workflows and error codes into a frozen 32 B-code-specialised LLM, our system produces syntactically valid and semantically accurate responses to mainframe commands without gradient updates or live system access. Experiments on four core PNR segment types show that RAG raises exact-match accuracy from 0% to 68–87 % on a held-out expert-labelled test set, while providing isolated, on-demand environments that eliminate MIPS-licence costs and shared-hardware contention. To our knowledge, this is the first demonstration that parametric-free RAG can serve as a drop-in substitute for physical mainframes in safety-critical, data-scarce settings.

title: Transfer Learning–Based Spatiotemporal Urban Mobility Forecasting under Abnormal Situations
authors: Yunshan Li, Qianqian Wang, Wenwu Gong, Xuanzhe Xu, Lili Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: We address short-to medium-term spatiotemporal urban mobility forecasting under abnormal situations, where many models trained on normal conditions degrade due to distribution shift and the scarcity of abnormal samples. We adopt a functional–statistical and transfer-learning framework: daily speeds are represented as smooth functional curves and summarized via Functional PCA to flag deviations from typical behavior, after which an hourly FANOVA predictor with a five-hour horizon encodes time-of-day indicators and current speed. Coefficient functions are estimated in a B-spline basis, and accuracy is evaluated by MAPE. To cope with limited abnormal data, we combine instance- and parameter-based transfer: an abnormal-trend coefficient learned from a source link is used to synthesize target abnormal samples around the target historical mean, and the predictor is retrained to adapt. Experiments on a Shenzhen link benchmark FANOVA against historical mean, LSTM, and SARIMA, indicating that the transferred model improves forecasting under abnormal congestion while maintaining strong performance in normal regimes.

title: An Explainable AI—Driven Ensemble Model for Improved Heart Disease Diagnosis
authors: Vijaya Alukapelly, Mikkilineni Vasudevarao, R Janagi, Iftikhar Aslam Tayubi, U.S.B.K. Mahalaxmi, Pundru Chandra Shaker Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Among the top causes of death worldwide, heart attacks can be prevented if people at risk are identified as soon as possible. Predicting the existence of a heart attack using clinical and laboratory markers has been made possible with the help of advanced machine learning(ML) and deeplearning(DL) strategies. Nevertheless, ML models need to be robust, generalizable, and transparent in order to be used in therapeutic settings. This study presents a method that combines the interpretability of Shapley additive explanations (SHAP) with the hyperparameter tuning precision of Bayesian optimization and the robustness of ensemble learning algorithms. Some of the ensemble classifiers that are being examined are XGBoost, adaptive boosting (AdaBoost), and random forest. With a recall (R) of 97.68% and a precision (P) of 98.5% on the Framingham dataset, and a recall (P) of 98.9% on the Cleveland dataset, the optimized XGBoost model had the best performance in the experiments conducted on both datasets.

title: Adaptive Frequency-Reconfigurable Antenna for Emerging 5G and IoT Applications
authors: Domin Choi, Jaemin Lee, Wahaj Abbas Awan, Sangmin Lee, Nam Kim
abstract: This paper proposes a compact, frequency-reconfigurable antenna tailored for 5G and IoT multi-band wireless applications. The antenna is coplanar waveguide-fed and features a semicircular radiator with dual vertical stubs. Four PIN diodes embedded at key junctions create six switching modes, each reconfiguring the effective electrical length to generate resonances across multiple wireless standards such as ISM, V2X, Wi-Fi 6E, and sub-6 GHz 5G. A five-step geometric optimization enhances impedance matching, mode selectivity, and radiation behavior. Simulations confirm stable operation from 2.0 GHz to 6.6 GHz with |S₁₁| < –10 dB and consistent radiation patterns. The design enables transitions between quasi-omnidirectional and directional radiation, offering spatial flexibility for diverse communication scenarios. The proposed solution balances reconfigurability, compactness, and efficiency, making it suitable for dynamic multi-standard wireless environments.

title: Vision-Based Posture Recognition Using Angle Features for Rehabilitation Exercise Systems
authors: Meiqing Wang, Tomoyuki Yamaguchi
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This study proposes a vision-based rehabilitation exercise posture recognition method using angle-based features derived from MediaPipe skeletal landmarks. Unlike existing applications that require manual exercise selection, the proposed method automatically identifies exercise types from visual input. Five rehabilitation exercises including plank, squat, leg raise, shoulder press, and lateral raise were analyzed. Several machine learning and deep learning models, including SVM, MLP, Random Forest, and LSTM, were trained on the extracted angle features. Experiments showed that the angle based representation improves classification accuracy, with the LSTM model achieving $96.28 \%$. The results indicate that the proposed method supports automated motion assessment and provides a basis for future rehabilitation exercise systems.

title: Hybrid AI Model for Predicting Transformer Failure Types and Diagnosing Anomalies Using Duval Characteristics
authors: SeungCheol An, DaeHan Ahn
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This study proposes a learning-based diagnostic model to quantitatively predict failure types based on transformer insulating oil gas analysis (Dissolved Gas Analysis, DGA). While the existing Duval analysis technique can visually classify PD, D1, D2, and T1, T2, T3 faults using gas ratios, its fixed decision boundaries limit its precision for data-driven diagnostics. To address this, the Duval Triangle and Duval Pentagon ratio characteristics were expanded as input features for the learning model, and the classification performance of RandomForest and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) models was compared. Performance was validated using 5-fold cross-validation with five input feature sets. The MLP model achieved the highest performance when combined with absolute gas concentration and Duval Pentagon ratio characteristics, recording approximately 0.812 on the macro F1 metric. The results demonstrate that combining Duval-based domain knowledge with data-driven learning can enhance the accuracy of transformer fault diagnosis.

title: A Design Science Approach to Automated Classification and Preservation of Networked Blockchain Artworks
authors: Daniel Filipe Farinha, Gerald Estadieu
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This paper presents a Design Science Research (DSR) approach to the problem of preserving networked, codebased artworks hosted on blockchain infrastructures. The study introduces ARKIVO, a system that automates the detection and classification of networked digital artworks minted within the Tezos-based HEN and Teia ecosystems. The artefact was developed iteratively under a DSR framework to ensure both technical rigour and practical relevance. Quantitative and qualitative evaluations demonstrate that ARKIVO achieves high classification accuracy while addressing long-term sustainability and preservation challenges in blockchain-based cultural artefacts. The findings contribute to the fields of information systems, digital preservation, and emerging blockchain applications.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Cybersecurity in International Relations: AI-Powered Legal Frameworks Against Cyber Threats
authors: Annapurna Pattnaik, Amrita Mishra, Rubi Talukdar, Akash Trikha
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Strong, flexible security measures are urgently needed to safeguard sensitive data, diplomatic communications, and vital infrastructure as cyber threats have a greater influence on international relations. This study investigates deep learning techniques as gamechanging instruments for improving cybersecurity in the intricate world of international politics. Governments and international organisations can more quickly and accurately detect, forecast, and prevent cyberattacks by utilising AI-driven models like transformer structures, recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and convolutional neural networks (CNNs). These algorithms provide realtime reaction capabilities, automated threat classification, and anomaly detection that outperform conventional cybersecurity techniques. Additionally, this research explores the development of AI-powered legal frameworks that facilitate global collaboration in cyber defence, guaranteeing that new technologies comply with transnational laws, ethical norms, and digital sovereignty. A proactive approach against ransomware, cyber espionage, and state-sponsored attacks is promoted by the incorporation of deep learning into the creation of cyber policies. This paper illustrates how AI-enhanced systems might increase international trust and resilience through case studies and simulated scenarios. In the end, this multidisciplinary approach offers a way to balance legal governance with technical innovation, strengthening global cybersecurity while upholding nation-state sovereignty.

title: Development of an IMU-sEMG System for Hamstring Analysis in Static Movement Protocols
authors: Michael John M. Espino, Ken Marco C. Mercado, John Jacen D. Del Mundo, Carlos Miguel S. Estrada, Aaron Sam A. Gilla, Jan-Tyrone C. Cabrera, Reil Vinard S. Espino, Maria Belinda Cristina C. Fidel, Timothy Nicolo C. Nazareno, Jazzmine Gale S. Flores, Warren Denzel F. Cheng, Sophia Nicole R. De Leon, Jairo C. Estopace, Renell Arthur A. Kalalang, Augie Louis A. Pador, Ma. Madecheen S. Pangaliman, Consuelo B. Gonzalez-Suarez, Jehiel D. Santos
abstract: Existing data acquisition systems for lower-limb assessment typically rely on single-sensor modalities and devicespecific protocols, which limit accurate measurement of both knee angles and peak muscle activations during exercises like standing leg curls. To address these limitations, we developed a wireless device integrating IMU and sEMG sensors, synchronizing data via timestamps and dynamic time warping. The Kalman filter is used to obtain the IMU signals, while an adaptive filter is used to denoise the sEMG signals. From the combined IMU and sEMG recordings, clear trends emerge in peak leg curl power as a function of knee flexion angle; to visualize these patterns, we applied K-means clustering (k <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=3)$</tex> to knee flexion angle <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(40^{\circ}-115^{\circ}\right)$</tex> versus peak leg curl power (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2-1.0 ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>) across all repetitions, which revealed three regimes, low (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 60^{\circ}-80^{\circ}, 0.5-0.8 ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>), medium (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 80^{\circ}-95^{\circ}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.7-0.9 ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>), and high (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 95^{\circ}-115^{\circ}, 0.7-1.0 ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>), highlighting typical performance zones. Analysis of the resulting scatter plot showed peak muscle activation during concentric phases at flexion angles of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{1 1 3}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>. Prototype knee-angle measurements achieved RMSE 7.37°, MAE 4.76 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{\circ}$</tex>, ICC 0.98, and Spearman's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho=0.9765$</tex> against ground truth, confirming the system's reliability in data acquisition. Overall, the integrated system provided reliable measurements of muscle activation and knee angles with acceptable error margins and consistency.

title: Improved DeepLabv3+-Based Algorithm for the Diamond Wire Mesh of Polysilicon Cutting Machines
authors: Ruilin Quan, Xu Zhu, Runsong Xue
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To enable real-time bow-deflection detection in the diamond wire mesh of polysilicon cutting machines operating under harsh industrial environments, this paper proposes a lightweight algorithm based on an improved DeepLabv3+ framework. The network employs MobileNetv4 as the backbone to substantially reduce computational complexity, integrates a coordinate attention mechanism to enhance spatial localization, and incorporates a squeeze-and-excitation-enhanced atrous spatial pyramid pooling (SE-ASPP) module for robust multi-scale feature extraction. Furthermore, a geometry-aware correction method is introduced to compensate for image misalignment and lens distortion by using the mortar pipe as a fixed geometric reference for accurate bow measurement. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high segmentation accuracy and low measurement error, while maintaining a lightweight structure suitable for real-time deployment on industrial edge devices. This work offers an intelligent and reliable quality control solution for polysilicon cutting production lines.

title: Towards Interpretable and Attentive Deep Visual Perception Through Iterative Refinement in Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Mohamed Nawas Paralath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: This paper introduces an innovative deep neural network architecture that integrates biologically-inspired, topdown processing to enhance visual attention and improve model interpretability within artificial intelligence systems. Moving beyond conventional feedforward paradigms, this work demonstrates how an iterative loop, guided by high-level semantic objectives, can dynamically refine hidden layer activations. This approach facilitates superior object localization and classification, particularly in complex, multi-object scenes, by enabling the network to focus on salient regions and effectively suppress irrelevant background noise. The presented method offers a novel pathway for creating more cognitively aligned and transparent deep learning models for computer vision tasks.

title: A Dynamic Adaptive Framework for Intrusion Detection based on Class Frequency and Sample Difficulty
authors: Chuanlong Yin, Xinglin Li, Zhenhong Li, Yingbo Zhao, Ruijie Zhuang, Cuiping Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Network intrusion detection systems face significant challenges due to the extreme class imbalance in network traffic, where rare attack instances are vastly outnumbered by normal connections, as well as the inherent issue of varying sample difficulty. This paper proposes a dynamic adaptive framework for intrusion detection that incorporates both class frequency and sample difficulty. The framework employs a novel loss function that dynamically adjusts sample weights by integrating global class frequency information with real-time loss feedback. This approach simultaneously mitigates global class imbalance through inverse frequency weighting and prioritizes difficult-to-classify samples via a loss-adaptive mechanism. Comprehensive experiments on the NSL-KDD dataset demonstrate that our framework significantly enhances detection performance across multiple models. The MLP, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM models integrated with our framework achieved substantial improvements in macro-averaged metrics and notably increased recall rates for critical minority attacks. Specifically, the enhanced CNN-LSTM model improved the recall rate for R2L attacks by 27.11% and for U2R attacks by 11.50%. The proposed method provides an effective algorithm-level solution for addressing class imbalance in cybersecurity applications.

title: Characterization of Physiological, Psychological, and Physical Stress Responses from Wearable Technology
authors: Joyce Anne A. Bernardino, Danna Francheska F. De Regla, Florenz TJ D.G. Galvez, Sean Archie D. Gregorio, Anne Margarita C. Yu Ekey, Wally Enrico M. Ingco, Seigfred V. Prado
abstract: Stress affects health and well-being, with heart rate (HR) and heart rate variability (HRV) recognized as the key indicators of the autonomic nervous system (ANS), which are parameters controlling stress responses. While most studies focused on only one to two parameters, this study explored the interplay of three, namely, physiological, psychological, and physical stress responses from wearable technology data. The employment of the Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM), Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) Manifold Learning, and statistical analysis allowed the research to uncover hidden patterns of stress responses, assessing stress severity and binary classifications. Significant overlaps in moderate stress levels were observed between the mild and severe levels, confirming challenges in distinguishing stress levels. This led to the adoption of binary classifications, enhancing robustness and simplifying the outputs. Through statistical validation, it confirmed strong correlations between UMAP components and stress severity. Physiological markers, including HR, electrodermal activity (EDA), and accelerometer data (ACC), consistently exhibited high correlations with severe stress levels. While skin temperature (TEMP) and interbeat intervals (IBI) contributed to moderate stress differentiation. Finally, mild stress has a notable connection to blood volume pulse (BVP), IBI, and HR.

title: Blockchain-Enhanced Speech Recognition: A Secure and Scalable AI-Driven Framework
authors: Naga Gopi Chappidi, Nizampatnam Yashwanth, Puthi Reddy Tharun Srinivas Reddy, Karri Snehalatha Reddy, Gudapati Snohitha Sai Sri, Dubba Naga Malleswari
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Speech recognition technology is used in numerous industries and traditional systems suffer from being subject to security vulnerabilities, being privacy issues, and scalability. The presented work proposes a Blockchain Enhanced Speech Recognition Framework combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Recurrent Neural Network (RNN), Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), and a blockchain technology to guarantee performance in terms of accuracy, tamper prevention and privacy of speech processing. AES encryption is used by the secure the sensitive voice data, and the speech features are extracted from the voice data using CNNs for spatial analysis and RNNs for temporal pattern recognition u sing the AI driven model. A lightweight PoS consensus mechanism along with a private blockchain with smart contracts, provides authentication, access control, as well as decentralized validation. Experimental results show that a 91.9% recognition accuracy, better data integrity and more secure than in the traditional cloud-based SaaS. Rectifying this, this framework is highly suitable for secure and efficient speech-based applications such as authentication and analysis.

title: Rethinking Self-labeling in Parametric Classification for Generalized Category Discovery
authors: Chaofan Dai, Huahua Ding, Wubin Ma, Yahui Wu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Generalized Category Discovery (GCD) aims to leverage labeled old categories data and abundant unlabeled data to discover novel categories unseen during training. However, prior studies have revealed significant limitations in parametric classifiers for novel class recognition. This paper rethinks the role of self-labeling in parametric classification for GCD and identifies that while self-labeling introduces training biases, it holds untapped potential for boosting model performance. We conduct an in-depth analysis of the reason why self-labeling fails in parametric classification and propose a Decoupled Self-labeling (DSL) approach that separates pseudo-labels generation from the predictive classification head. This design minimizes the learning bias introduced by unreliable pseudo-labels while preserving their utility for feature learning. Additionally, we introduce a label encoding risk minimization strategy that provides supervised guidance for unlabeled further extract valuable information from pseudo-labels. Comprehensive evaluations on GCD benchmarks demonstrate that DSL achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming parametric and non-parametric baselines, especially in the novel categories.

title: General Time Series Forecasting of Cloud Monitoring Based on Patchified Embedding for Temporal Sequence Encoding and Cross-Var BiSA
authors: Wei Dong, Yanhui Ren, Yao Zhao, Yue Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Monitoring prediction is a key technology for cloud platforms to warn about risks and reduce business losses. Traditional monitoring prediction methods rely on large amounts of labelled data. These methods have high prediction errors and cannot easily lower data labelling costs or achieve accurate predictions. This paper focuses on two main limits of traditional methods: weak zero-shot inference (making predictions without prior examples) and poor capture of complex time-series features. This paper proposes an improved approach with three parts. First, a time-series feature encoder called PE-TSE is built (Piecewise Embedding-based Time-Series Encoder). It balances local features and maps them into a shared semantic space across different data types. Second, this paper adds a new attention mechanism called Cross-Var BiSA and a prediction head named CTPH (Convolutional Time-series Perception Head). This helps better capture dynamic relationships in time-series data with multiple variables and scales. Together, these form a general time-series forecasting model called PCC-GTF. It can adapt to new data and work well on unseen cases. This paper compares PCC-GTF with several mainstream forecasting algorithms. Our model performs significantly better on two key metrics: Mean Absolute Scaled Error (MASE) and Mean Scaled Interval Score (MSIS). This work provides a low-cost, high-accuracy solution for general time-series prediction in cloud monitoring.

title: Design of an X-Band Transceiver Front-End
authors: Libo Zheng, Yan Jiang, Haowei Xie, Yufeng Guo
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper presents a multifunctional transceiver front-end (T/RFE) for Active Electronically Scanned Array (AESA), implemented in a 0.25 µm GaAs pHEMT process and operating in the X-band. The chip integrates an asymmetric single-pole double-throw (SPDT) switch based on the traveling-wave concept, a broadband low-noise amplifier (LNA) utilizing current-reuse and virtual-ground capacitance techniques, and a combined power amplifier (PA) with watt-level output power. Full-chip electromagnetic (EM) simulation results demonstrate that in receive mode, the chip achieves a noise figure (NF) of 1.99- 2.43 dB and a small-signal gain of 23.5-24.3 dB, exhibiting excellent gain flatness. In transmit mode, the chip delivers an output power of 29.6-30.7 dBm with a power-added efficiency (PAE) of 20%-26%. Moreover, across the 9-13 GHz band, the input and output return losses (RLs) remain better than 10 dB in both transmit and receive modes.

title: Machine Learning Models for Automated Grading and Evaluations in Smart Classrooms
authors: Venkata Ashok Kumar Boyina, Thiyagarajan Mani Chettier, Omar Isam AL Mrayat, Mohan Awasthy, Gaurav Gupta, Naim Shaikh
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The rapid change towards a digital education has facilitated the high pursuit of intelligent classroom ecosystems where automation has a large role in increasing the efficiency of assessment. In this paper, SVM, Random Forest, Neural Network and Gradient Boosting models are tested for their ability to automatically grade the responses of students. A corpus of response scripts from 10,000 responses to objective and descriptive test items were preprocessed with two different types of embedding: TF-IDF based and BERT based. The results were generalized using 10 -fold crossvalidation normalization of a training and testing set. The best results were achieved by the Neural Network model which had an accuracy of 93 % followed by the Random Forest with 91 %. Moreover, the Bagging model has achieved better performance than those of Gradient Boosting and SVM models in identifying sports with 89% and 88%, respectively. Our experimental results demonstrate that neural models are more able to generalize the answer semantics variation. This research pressurizes the fact that automated machine-learningbased grading system can efficiently reduce the labor of manual corpus evaluation and give uniform assessment.

title: Chrominance based Skin Color Identification and Segmentation using YCbCr Color Model and Threshold Approach
authors: Ganesan P, A. Aranganathan, Merlin Sheeba G, L.M.I.Leo Joseph, S.T. Gopukumar, G.Sajiv, V.Elamaran, Santhosh G
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: In most image analysis applications, the recognition of skin hue is vital process for the exact identification of face or gesture recognition. It is also crucial for simple social applications to control crimes. However the major issue in the skin color recognition is the huge variation of tone with respect to race, region etc. Most of the methods and algorithms utilize the conventional RGB model for skin color recognition. However, this device dependent model has many limitations than advantages. So it is necessary to devise a unique color model for this skin color identification. The proposed method employed the derived YCbCr color space wherein the intensity (details) information is easily segregated from hue (color) information. The strong demarcation between the pixels identified by means of an appropriate and optimal threshold values of hue (chrominance) information i.e., chrominance red and green (Cb and Cr). The suggested method presents a simple but efficient way of solution to recognize human skin hue without complicated mathematical computation. This method is compared with RGB skin color segmentation to explore its supremacy. It is obvious that the planned scheme for the skin segmentation using threshold based YCbCr model offers a needy and valuable answer to many real time skin hue recognition applications wherein accuracy and computational cost is utmost important.

title: Defect Degree-Aware Learning through Metric Learning
authors: Hyunki Cho, Hyungmin Kim, Daehwan Kim, Dongjin Park, Hansang Cho
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: The quality control in manufacturing environment is crucial for maintaining credibility with customers and ensuring sustained business operations. From this perspective, the vision inspection process detects surface defects in products before they are transferred to the client, making it a critical step in quality control. In this process, we focus not only on detecting defects to ensure credibility but also on removing false alarms, where nondefects are classified as defects, to improve company’s profits. However, most images in manufacturing datasets are assigned a single label, encoded as one-hot, to represent their class. This approach is not effective in alleviating false alarms, as all data points are assigned equal weight without reflecting the degree of defect. In this paper, we introduce defect degree-aware learning, which leverages defect degrees to rescale the weights, thereby enhancing product confidence and yield. Manually grading the degree is time-consuming and prone to human error. Therefore, we adopt both a metric learning scheme to automatically measure the degree and a learning-with-noisy-labels scheme to enhance robustness against noisy labels. In this manner, the proposed method improves performance compared to a vanilla supervised classification task, thus enhancing credibility with clients and contributing to profit growth.

title: 2D Beam-Steerable 300-GHz CMOS Phased-Array Transmitter and Receiver
authors: Takeshi Yoshida, Shunsuke Hara, Kyoya Takano, Satoshi Tanaka, Mohamed H. Mubarak, Akifumi Kasamatsu, Yoshiki Sugimoto, Kunio Sakakibara, Shuhei Amakawa, Minoru Fujishima
abstract: This paper presents a 300-GHz-band CMOS phased-array transmitter and receiver capable of two-dimensional beam steering. An interpolated feeding scheme enables a λ/2 antenna pitch while relaxing circuit spacing, improving scalability. The proposed transmitter achieved a maximum data rate of 40 Gb/s, while the receiver demonstrated a data rate of 36 Gb/s.

title: Dual-Wideband Metasurface for Polarization Conversion Targetting Integrated 5G and 6G MIMO Communication
authors: Muhammad Awais Khan Bangash, Muhammad Ikram, Syed S. Jehangir
abstract: This paper presents the concept of polarization conversion for an integrated 5G and 6G Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) antenna system. The design consists of a compact high-gain shared-aperture Vivaldi antenna with a meta-surface for linear-to-circular polarization (LP-to-CP) conversion, enabling operation at 40 GHz (5G) and 105 GHz (6G) bands. The metasurface supports both left-hand circular polarization (LHCP) and right-hand circular polarization (RHCP), achieving AR < 3 dB in the ranges of 38.8-44 (GHz) and 93-107 (GHz), respectively. The proposed configuration provides both dual wideband polarization conversion and spatial diversity (30° incidence angle) in a compact form factor. The initial results show satisfactory performance, making it a strong candidate for future integrated mm-Wave (5G) and sub-THz (6G) communication systems.

title: Project Akshara: A Comparative Study of Deep Learning Architectures for Robust Kannada Handwritten Digit Classification
authors: Hemanth T, H A Charvi, Vaibhavi Shastri, Achyutha B Jagadeesh, Bhagyashree Ambore, Prashanth Kannadaguli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Handwritten digit recognition remains a critical problem in computer vision, with extensive progress achieved for English numerals through benchmarks like MNIST. However, Indic scripts such as Kannada remain underexplored despite their widespread usage and cultural significance. Kannada digits pose unique challenges due to their curved structures, stroke variations, and frequent inter-class similarities (e.g., vs vs ), making them difficult to classify with conventional models. This paper presents Project Akshara: A Deep Learning Microser vice for Low-Latency Indic Script Recognition, an end-to-end framework for accurate and efficient Kannada digit recognition. The Kannada-MNIST dataset, augmented with manually curated samples, was employed to train and evaluate three state-of theart deep learning architectures: EfficientNet-B0, GoogleNet, and SqueezeNetV2. Models were trained with a standardized 90-10 split and evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, ROC-AUC, and confusion matrices. Results demonstrate that EfficientNet-B0 achieved the highest accuracy (98.8 %), while GoogleNet reached 96.8% and SqueezeNet 95%. EfficientNet B0 also provided the best accuracy-efficiency trade-off, making it highly suitable for real-world applications. Building on these findings, the system is extended through model fine-tuning and deployment as a microservice, ensuring practical applicability in domains such as education, digital governance, and accessibility.

title: Online Prize-Collecting TSP with Costs for UAV Search and Rescue Missions
authors: Bowen Wang, Ziwen Cheng, Yaling Zheng
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: In the era of big data, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have become indispensable tools in wilderness search and rescue operations. Unlike traditional scenarios where the costs and rewards of all candidate search locations are known in advance, real-world missions require UAVs to make sequential decisions under strict energy constraints, with the reward and energy consumption at each location revealed only upon arrival. In this paper, we formulate the problem as an online Prize-Collecting Traveling Salesman Problem (PC-TSP) with costs, capturing the inherent uncertainty and dynamic nature of search and rescue tasks. We propose an innovative approach that integrates the nearest-neighbor principle with an online linear programming strategy to guide UAVs in maximizing rescue success or the total value of discovered clues. Extensive experiments on both simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our method over conventional offline planning techniques, highlighting its practical potential for real-time UAV decision-making in complex environments.

title: Optimal Active/Passive Beamforming and Positioning of RIS for Ship-Shore Communications
authors: Deepthi M, Poornima S, Deepak S
abstract: RIS offers a cost-effective solution to overcome the coverage issues of using next-generation communication systems. UAVs with mounted RIS can flexibly provide reliable connectivity to remote areas. In this paper, an RIS-mounted UAV is employed to improve the reliability of ship-to-shore communication. The proposed work aims to jointly optimize the beamforming vector of the transmit antenna (active beamforming), the phase shifts of RIS unit elements (passive beamforming) and the placement of an RIS-mounted UAV to maximize the receiver's capacity. The exact joint optimization for active/passive beamforming and positioning of RIS-mounted UAV is obtained by using Maximum Ratio Transmission (MRT) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). An approximate joint optimization, which maximizes an upper bound of the SNR, is also solved using MRT, semi-definite programming (SDP) with a closed-form solution for optimum position. It is found that when the distance between BS and user is equal to twice the height of UAV (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D=2 h$</tex>), RIS should be placed vertically at the mid-point; for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D \gg 2 h$</tex> the RIS may be placed directly above the BS or the user. For lower distances, RIS placed vertically at the mid-point, at a fixed UAV-safe height, is best. The two distance optimized joint optimizations show superior performance compared to a benchmark scheme [3] and the case of random beamforming.

title: Sub-THz Graphene-Based Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface Assisted 2D Beam Steering for 6G Applications
authors: Abhishek Chauhan, Amit K. Singh, Rahul Mondal, Akhilesh Kumar, Mohd Farman Ali
abstract: This paper presents a graphene-based reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS), comprised of a reflective type of meta-atoms. The proposed meta-atom consists of a split-ring resonator (SRR) with an engraved graphene strip at the top and a polyimide substrate backed by a gold reflector. The meta-atom is designed to obtain maximum reflection with 180°±10° phase difference. To achieve two discrete states, chemical potentials of 1 eV and 0.01 eV are considered across the graphene strip for the ON and OFF states, respectively. The proposed RIS provides a 60 GHz bandwidth in the 0.26-0.32 THz range, corresponding to a fractional bandwidth of 21%. The RIS with 30×30 meta-atoms is analyzed for 2D beam steering. The RIS can steer the electromagnetic waves up to ± 30° with low scan loss of 1.1 dB at 0.27 THz. The proposed RIS facilitates electromagnetic wave manipulation, resulting in improved signal coverage and dynamic beam steering for 6G applications.

title: Comparing Deep Learning Approaches for Low Resolution Face Recognition Challenges in Security and Surveillance Applications
authors: Ramakant Soni, Pawan K. Ajmera
abstract: Facial recognition in the low-resolution environments remains as a critical challenge for security and surveillance systems. This paper comprehensively evaluates two advanced deep learning models: MobileNetV2 and EfficientNetB0 across four facial datasets: LFW, LFW Funneled, TinyFace and a locally collected low-resolution dataset (Local LR). Using PyTorch with extensive data augmentation, model's performance was assessed on metrics: Accuracy, Loss, F1-score and ROC AUC. The experimental results shows that EfficientNet-B0 achieves higher accuracy on challenging lowresolution datasets like TinyFace (69.64%) compared to MobileNetV2's 61.86%). EfficientNet-B0 shows 29.3% reduction in test loss and 6.4% higher F1-score maintaining comparable performance on higher-resolution datasets (97.81% on Local LR). MobileNetV2 shows more computational advantages with fewer parameters and lower FLOPs in comparison to EfficientNet-B0. This makes it more suitable for edge deployments despite slightly lower accuracy (96.43%) on LFW compared to EfficientNet-B0 (96.97%). These findings provide quantitative benchmarks for model selection. Results are highlighting EfficientNet-B0's strength in feature extraction from low-quality images and reflects the efficiency benefits of MobileNetV2 which is offering practical guidance for implementing facial recognition systems in real-world scenarios where image resolution and hardware constraints vary significantly.

title: Learning to Identify RF Devices from Few Pilots via Reptile
authors: Longqi Shen, Tomotaka Kimura, Jun Cheng
abstract: We examine a neural network-based system designed to identify <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K$</tex> devices, each with device-specific I/Q imbalances in the RF modulator, as they transmit signals to an access point using time-division multiple access. Traditional methods begin training with randomly chosen initial parameters and need numerous pilot symbols, which can be impractical in scenarios such as when a unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) serves as the access point, collecting data from massive device sensor networks. In this work, we focus on adaptive learning with minimal pilot symbols to train the neural network to classify devices by their I/Q imbalances. Reptile is an efficient meta-learning algorithm designed to help models rapidly adjust to new tasks with minimal training data. By employing Reptile, we pre-train neural network model parameters offline, facilitating rapid online adaptation and fine-tuning for effective identification of new devices. Simulations indicate that Reptile surpasses conventional methods in device identification with fewer pilot symbols.

title: Multi-Temporal Deep Learning-Based Comparative Analysis for Deforestation Detection Using Landsat Imagery
authors: A.M.C. Malkanthi, B.T.G.S. Kumara, D.R. Welikanna, R.M.K.T. Rathnayaka
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Developing a robust and timely monitoring system for forest cover loss is critical to maintain the ecological balance. Large-scale forest monitoring is facilitated by the advancement in both remote sensing technologies and Deep Learning (DL). In particular, change detection methods have emerged as a promising approach for monitoring forest dynamics at both spatial and temporal scales. Thus, this study comprehensively compares diverse deep learning architectures (U-Net, U-Net++, Attention U-Net, ResU-Net, DeepLabV3+, and MobileNetV2) for monitoring and evaluating deforestation dynamics in Wilpattu National Park, Sri Lanka, over three time periods from 2015 to 2024. The models were trained using $128 \times 128$ Landsat image patches generated through bitemporal stacking following early fusion approach. The subset of two Landsat spectral bands ensures a compact and computationally efficient dataset. The model performance is evaluated using metrics such as F1-score, Precision, Recall, Accuracy, and Kappa. Experimental results indicate that UNet and ResU-Net are effective in capturing forest loss regions across all temporal intervals. However, a gradual decline in performance was observed over successive time periods, reflecting the growing spatial and spectral complexity of deforestation patterns. This underscores the need to design models that maintain consistent performance across temporal shifts, ensuring robust long-term deforestation monitoring.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Big Data Optimizing Scalable HR Analytics for Talent Acquisition and Retention
authors: Sheetal Mahesh Mane, Somadatta B. Karanjekar, Nishitha Reddy Nalla, Alka Singh Bhatt, Raman K Attri, Mohammed Quadir Mohiuddin
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Retaining and attracting the best talent is increasingly becoming a challenge to organisations in the modern fast changing business environment. A way to optimise the use of talent acquisition and retention strategies is to harness the transformative power of introducing Artificial Intelligence (AI) and big data into the Human Resource (HR) management practice. To enhance the HR analytics architecture to accommodate the employee lifecycle of decision-making, this paper proposes a scalable HR analytics architecture to utilize AI and Big Data. The structure assists business to identify high potential recruits, reduces the recruitment duration, and better predicts employee turnover through predictive analytics, machine learning, and real-time data processing. It also facilitates career and personalised employee engagement programs, which increase organisational commitment and job satisfaction. The structure has been designed in a way that it can be scaled to the needs of different organisations in terms of size and can also be flexible to adapt across industries. We show how this concept can be useful in retention rate increase and recruitment efficiency using a case-based approach. Ethical concerns and the problem of data protection are also discussed to ensure proper use of AI. Ultimately, this paper focuses on the strategic usefulness of AI-based HR analytics in developing a data-wise, resilient workforce and ensuring competitive advantage in the digital age.

title: A Deep Learning-based Wavenumber Domain Imaging Method for ISAC
authors: Lue Wen, Siyuan Zhao, Tiantian Yin, Yongxin Guo, Xudong Chen
abstract: This paper proposes a deep learning-based imaging algorithm in the wavenumber domain for integrated sensing and communication (ISAC). A forward model is constructed using orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) waveforms, indicating that the scattered field can be interpreted as the inverse Fourier transform of the scattering sources. Signal sampling in spatial domain can thus be converted to samplings in the wavenumber domain, enabling image reconstruction via fast Fourier transform (FFT). An attention U-Net is introduced to improve the imaging quality with interpretability. The proposed method is FFT-based and independent of antenna array configuration, showing potential for deployment in distributed communication networks. The effectiveness of the method is validated through simulation results.

title: Parameter Optimization Strategy for LCC-S Type Magnetic Coupling Wireless Power Transfer System
authors: Song Wu, Yinghua Zeng, Li Yu, Yanjin Xu, Baihong Wu, Sheng Huang, Jiale Hu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the mutual coupling issues among the resonant element parameters in the LCC-S type magnetic coupling wireless power transmission (MC-WPT) system (which would increase the design difficulty and reduce the transmission efficiency), this paper proposes an improved multi-objective optimization algorithm based on NSGA-II. By using strategies such as Levy flight, random walk, and adaptive weights, the algorithm's global and local search capabilities are enhanced, and the convergence speed is accelerated. This method achieves the optimal configuration of system parameters under multiple constraints. Firstly, through the topological analysis of a typical MC-WPT system, its inherent limitations are determined. Then, a LCC-type composite compensation network is proposed to construct a more efficient LCC-S topological structure. Next, the optimization objective is to maximize the transmission efficiency of the LCC-S compensation topology structure, and the parameters of the resonant frequency, mutual inductance coefficient, and load resistance of the system are set as optimization variables. The improved algorithm is simulated, and the optimal solutions of the variables and the optimal values of the transmission efficiency are obtained. A magnetic coupling resonant WPT system experimental platform is built, and experiments are conducted to study the effects of working frequency, mutual inductance coefficient, and load resistance on the transmission efficiency. The results of the algorithm optimization are basically the same, and a comprehensive analysis of the optimization results shows that the LBA algorithm is effective for optimizing the transmission efficiency parameters.

title: Particle Swarm Optimization - Artificial Neural Network Model for Predicting Rebar Corrosion in Fiber-Reinforced Concrete
authors: Bon Ryan P. Aniban, Kevin Lawrence M. De Jesus, Donna Ville L. Gante, Dante L. Silva, Jimmy G. Catanes, Sheina R. Pallega, Meriam P. Leopoldo
abstract: Chloride-induced corrosion (CIC) is a primary reason of deterioration in reinforced concrete (RC), particularly in marine structures which causes cracking, degradation, and decreased service life. Advances in the 4th Industrial Revolution have enabled utilization of machine learning techniques in different fields of civil engineering. This study develops an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) enhanced by Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to predict rebar corrosion in polypropylene fiber reinforced concrete (PFRC). Accelerated corrosion tests were performed using the impressed current method on samples with varying polypropylene fiber content, concrete cover (CC), and bar diameter (BD). Experimental results showed that the 3-7-1 network structure (NS) (3 input neurons (IN), 7 hidden neurons (HN), 1 output neuron (ON)) achieved the highest accuracy with correlation coefficient (R) of 0.98969, mean squared error (MSE) of 0.18846, and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of 7.832 %. Employing the generated connection weights (CW) from the governing model (GM), through Olden's connection weights approach, observed that the concrete cover had the most significant influence on corrosion (-43.231%), followed by bar diameter (33.717%) and fiber content (-23.052%). It highlights that increasing concrete cover and fiber content significantly reduces corrosion in PFRC, which may be used by civil engineering professionals as it offers insights for enhancing the durability of reinforced concrete structures. This approach supports SDG 9 (Sustainable Development Goal 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure) by promoting resilient, innovative construction methods and contributes to SDG 11 (Sustainable Development Goal 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities) by enhancing the longevity and sustainability of urban infrastructure.

title: An Ultra-Wideband Rectifier Based on a Novel Broadband Impedance Self-Resonant Network
authors: Haoxuan Long, Jinlin Yang, Jian Liu
abstract: In this article, an ultra-wideband (UWB) rectifier is presented for radio frequency energy harvesting (RFEH) systems. In the proposed structure, a broadband impedance self-resonant network (BISRN) is employed to reduce the diode’s impedance variation for facilitating broadband impedance matching. Then, a coupled microstrip line is utilized to tune impedance and widen the rectifier’s bandwidth further. For validation, a voltage-doubler (VB) UWB rectifier is fabricated and measured. The measured results show that the RF-DC power conversion efficiency (PCE) is higher than 50 % in a bandwidth of 158 % from 0.8 to 6.6 GHz at 16 dBm input power. The maximum measured PCE is 70.6 % at 2.4 GHz with a 18 dBm input power. The proposed rectifier achieves a compact size of 30 × 28.5 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Considering its broadband and compact features, it is very suitable for the high-efficiency RFEH systems.

title: Power Generation Performance Analysis of Tubular Permanent Magnet Linear Generators Under Different Motion Modes
authors: JiaHang Sun, Bo Zhang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: The uniform reciprocating motion of the mover in linear generators has limitations in engineering applications. To address this issue, this study plots the mover velocity-time curves in three different application fields, defining them as sinusoidal, square-wave-like (trapezoidal), and triangular wave motion modes based on their shapes. A transient field simulation model of the Tubular Permanent Magnet Linear Generator (TPMLG) is established to comparatively analyze the energy conversion efficiency of the generator under these motion modes. First, a correlation coefficient is introduced to derive the analytical expression between the back electromotive force (back-EMF) and the mover velocity. Subsequently, the amplitude and harmonic content of the back-EMF under the three motion modes are simulated and analyzed. The results indicate that the back-EMF waveform under sinusoidal motion exhibits the highest amplitude, but its total harmonic distortion (THD) is significantly higher than that under triangular and square-wave-like motions. In contrast, the back-EMF amplitude under square-wave-like motion is relatively small. Comprehensive analysis shows that the TPMLG achieves the optimal power generation efficiency when the mover operates in triangular wave motion. This research provides a theoretical reference for the selection of operating modes of linear generators in practical engineering applications.

title: Real time monitoring function using Scalable Vector Graphics in the new-generation scheduling system
authors: Gang Song, Ruijie Zhu, Haiyang Wang, Haipeng Sun
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the pressing need for flexibility and intelligent management in energy systems during the "15th FiveYear Plan" period, a framework for a new-generation dispatch technology support system is proposed. This system architecture comprises platform, data, and application layers, with a structured overview of the interaction between modules. The application layer employs Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) technology to enable real-time monitoring, providing a technical workflow for visualizing substations, transmission lines, and load elements. The system integrates functions for overload alerts, load forecasting, and price-optimized dispatch. Experimental results demonstrate that compared to bitmap technology, the solution reduces memory usage by 7.0%, decreases interaction latency by 28.9%, and improves alert identification speed by 40.0%, significantly enhancing operational efficiency in modern grid management scenarios.

title: Enhancing Cardiovascular Disease Prediction Using YOLO-Driven Deep Feature Extraction and RFGB Ensemble Learning
authors: K.Kishore Kumar, K S Ranjith, Desidi Narasimha Reddy, Swapna Siddamsetti, B.Srilakshmi, Siva Kumar Pathuri
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases constitute the major cause of worldwide mortality and morbidity and they need to be addressed through effective approaches of risk evaluation to facilitate early intervention and prevention. The classical representations might not be precise and lack flexibility, and this is the reason why powerful deep learning methods have been employed to achieve high predictive accuracy by exploiting all available medical information during analysis. This paper gives an in-depth analysis of contemporary deep learning processes in cardiovascular risk prediction. It criticizes the traditional methods and shows shortcomings of these methods then provides a predictive model which is a combination of both methods. One of the main implications of the research concerns the capability of deep learning in handling multidimensional medical information. To overcome the inefficiency and the limitations of diagnosis of the existing systems, the research proposes the implementation of a hybrid system combining both RFGB (Random Forest Gradient Boosting) and YOLO (You Only Look Once). RFGB has the power of both Random Forest as well as Gradient Boost in the features selection and classification, whereas YOLO is used to perform real-time analysis of the medical objects, which enhances their prediction ability. The model under consideration is compared with another classifier, including Decision Tree and Naive Bayes, which are used in the binary classification (YES/NO). With a best accuracy of 96%, the RFGB-YOLO hybrid clearly outreach other existing models as it provides a safe path in predicting heart attacks.

title: Rapid Model Adaptation of Code-Switching ASR in Low-Resource, High-Noise Industrial Domains
authors: Tian-Yi Chen, Chih-Chung Kuo, Yu-Siang Lan, Yuan-Fu Liao, Bo-Wei Chen, Yi Liu, Ming-Hsuan Wu
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) is a key technology for enabling hands-free, real-time logging in industrial environments. However, general-purpose ASR models perform poorly in specialized factory domains due to scarce domain-specific corpora, complex technical terminology, frequent code-switching, and high ambient noise. This paper presents a rapid adaptation framework for extremely low-resource and high-noise domains, integrating template-slot sentences generation, large language model (LLM)-based sentence refinement, high-fidelity text-to-speech (TTS) synthesis and multi-condition noisy-speech simulation. Even with minimal real text data, the approach substantially improves recognition accuracy, while noisy-speech training enhances robust-ness under severe noise. Experiments on a real factory's maintenance and shift-handover records reduce mixed error rate (MER) from 18.1% to 5.4%, and maintain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{MER} \leq 11 \%$</tex> at signal-to-noise ratios <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SNR} \geq 3 ~\text{dB}$</tex>, demonstrating the feasibility of high-accuracy ASR in challenging industrial environments.

title: Encoder-Free Style-Controllable Text-to-Speech with Voice Attribute Vectors
authors: Jaehoon Kang, Yejin Lee, Kyuhong Shim
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Natural language-based style control in text-tospeech (TTS) synthesis typically relies on large pretrained text encoders, which introduce significant computational overhead. In this paper, we propose a novel encoder-free approach that replaces heavy text encoders with precomputed prototype attribute vectors without additional training. The key idea is to construct each attribute vector by averaging the embeddings of diverse style prompts that contain the target attribute in their descriptions. Analysis of the embedding space shows that tokens representing the same attribute form tight clusters, indicating that compact prototype vectors can effectively capture their semantic meaning. Experiments show that our model achieves comparable word error rates and automatic evaluation scores to the baseline with the text encoder. These results demonstrate that lightweight attribute representations can successfully replace large text encoders in production-oriented TTS, reducing the model size by 38% without compromising perceived quality.

title: Self-Folding Modular Chain Robot for Shape-Changing Objects
authors: Sergio Mutis, Alexander Htet Kyaw, Rodrigo Gallardo, Diana Mykhaylychenko, Erik Demaine

title: Dual Variable-Radius Drum for Transmission Ratio Linearization and Stroke Enhancement in Twisted String Actuators_supp1-3665071.mp4
authors: Jee-Hwan Ryu
abstract: Twisted string actuators (TSAs) have emerged as promising actuators in robotics owing to their compliant, lightweight nature, and high transmission ratios. However, practical utilization of TSAs remains limited due to their restricted stroke length and intrinsically nonlinear transmission ratio (TR). While variable-radius pulleys (VRPs) can mitigate these issues, they exhibit poor scalability as their volume grows disproportionately with the required stroke or compensation TR range. This paper proposes the dual variable-radius drum TSA (DVRD-TSA) and mathematically proves that its architecture offers superior scalability and compactness compared to existing mechanisms as performance demands increase. For a baseline comparison to validate our model, we fabricated a prototype and compared it to a conventional TSA under constant load conditions with identical initial length. The experiment confirmed that our DVRD-TSA delivers a substantially larger linear stroke (210.3 mm, 72.5%) compared to conventional TSA (85.3 mm, 29.4%), while maintaining a comparable peak torque (25.82 Nmm vs. 24.21 Nmm), and successfully tracks its target near-constant transmission ratio (1.475 rd/mm) with low error. This work presents a compact, passive, and scalable solution that overcomes two major drawbacks of TSAs, nonlinear TR and limited stroke, thereby making them a more compelling option for robotic applications.

title: SafePR: Unified Approach for Safe Parallel Robots by Contact Detection and Reaction with Redundancy Resolution
authors: Aran Mohammad, Tim-Lukas Habich, Thomas Seel, Moritz Schappler
abstract: Fast and safe motion is crucial for the successful deployment of physically interactive robots. Parallel robots (PRs) offer the potential for higher speeds while maintaining the same energy limits due to their low moving masses. However, they require methods for contact detection and reaction while avoiding singularities and self-collisions. We address this issue and present SafePR - a unified approach for the detection and localization, including the distinction between collision and clamping to perform a reaction that is safe for humans and feasible for PRs. Our approach uses information from the encoders and motor currents to estimate forces via a generalized-momentum observer. Neural networks and particle filters classify and localize the contacts. We introduce reactions with redundancy resolution to avoid self-collisions and type-II singularities. Our approach detected and terminated 72 real-world collision and clamping contacts with end-effector speeds of up to 1.5m/s, each within 25-275ms. The forces were below the thresholds from ISO/TS 15066. By using built-in sensors, SafePR enables safe interaction with already assembled PRs without the need for new hardware components.
