title: Efficient Self-Supervised Grading of Prostate Cancer Pathology
authors: Riddhasree Bhattacharyya, Surochita Pal, Sushmita Mitra
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Prostate cancer grading, using the International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) system, for treatment decisions is highly subjective and requires considerable expertise. Despite advances in computer-aided diagnosis systems, few have handled efficient ISUP grading on whole slide images (WSIs) of prostate biopsies based only on slide labels. In this scenario, TSOR is developed, where a novel task-specific self-supervised learning (SSL) framework is used for patch-level pretraining. This is fine-tuned using ordinal regression for WSI-level ISUP grading. One of the main challenges faced by deep learning (DL) in ISUP grading, is the learning of patch-level features based on slide labels. Though using models pretrained at patch-level using SSL or other paradigms is the most obvious choice here, the diversity of training samples plays a crucial role in effective pretraining. However, pretraining on a large database of different histopathology images becomes computationally expensive. Therefore, a patch-level dataset (relatively balanced with respect to the patch-level grades) is initially created for effective SSL-based pretraining. As stain-variation across centers leads to difficulty in generalization, an additional loss term is incorporated to effectively learn the stain-agnostic patch-level features. As it is desirable that misclassification be as close as possible to the actual grade, in medical images, we fine-tune the pretrained network for WSI-level ISUP grading using an ordinal regression-based approach. Experimental results on the most extensive prostate cancer grade assessment (PANDA) challenge dataset, and the SICAPv2 dataset, demonstrate the effectiveness of TSOR compared to state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods.

title: Adaptive Supervisor Synthesis for Automated Manufacturing Systems With Multiple Unreliable Resources
authors: Nan Du, Dongnian Jiang, Hesuan Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Deadlock and blocking issues have received more and more attention in automated manufacturing systems (AMSs). This article studies an adaptive supervisory control problem for AMSs with multiple unreliable resources which may fail at any time. By using general Petri nets (PNs), each processing stage in the AMSs under consideration allows to utilize multiple types and quantities of resources. Based on a transformation technique, a general net is first converted to an ordinary net. In an ordinary net, a set of formulas is used to check the undermarked siphons, each of which is designed as a control place to prohibit it from being undermarked. By analyzing the relationship between the unreliable resources and the detected siphon, an adaptive controller is designed which can automatically adjust working modes such that the undermarked siphon caused by resource failures is marked. Finally, an adaptive supervisory controller is iteratively synthesized for AMSs with unreliable resources to ensure the controlled system can execute continuous operations even if unreliable resources malfunction. A representative example is given to illustrate the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Adaptive Neural Network-Based Fault Detection for Thermal Process of Battery Cells
authors: Yun Feng, Xingyu Zhu, Ya-Zhi Zhang, Yaonan Wang, Jun-Wei Wang, Zheng-Guang Wu, Huaicheng Yan, Han-Xiong Li
abstract: This article presents an adaptive neural network (AdNN)-based fault detection framework for the thermal processes of lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries governed by 2-D semilinear partial differential equations (PDEs) with partially known dynamics. To address the challenges of unknown nonlinear heat generation and limited sensor measurements, a two-stage approach combining reduced-order modeling with adaptive neural observation is proposed. First, a computationally tractable reduced-order model is derived through spectral approximation techniques. An adaptive neural observer is then designed to simultaneously estimate battery states and unknown nonlinear dynamics using only available surface temperature measurements. For robust fault detection, a hybrid scheme is developed that integrates model-based residual generation with data-driven threshold generation. Experimental validation on a pouch-type battery demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method in reliably detecting thermal abnormalities.

title: A Critical Review and Evaluation of LLMs for RTL Generation
authors: Arun Ravindran, Aditya Patra, Vahid Babaey, Suresh Purini
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are emerging as powerful tools for hardware design, with recent work exploring their ability to generate register-transfer level (RTL) code directly from natural-language specifications. This paper presents a critical review and empirical evaluation of LLM-based RTL generation. We examine thirty-one published efforts, classifying their use of techniques such as fine-tuning, reinforcement learning, retrieval-augmented prompting, and multi-agent orchestration across eight methodological dimensions including debugging support, post-RTL metrics, and benchmark development. Building on this synthesis, we experimentally evaluate frontier commercial and open-weight models—GPT-4.1, GPT-4.1-mini, Claude Sonnet 4, and Llama 4 Maverick —on the VerilogEvalV2 and RTLLMv2.0 benchmarks under both single-shot generation and a lightweight ReAct-style reflection loop, with compilation and simulation performed through Icarus Verilog interfaced via the Model Context Protocol (MCP). Results show that these models achieve up to 89.74% on VerilogEval and 96.08% on RTLLM, matching or exceeding prior domain-specific pipelines without specialized fine-tuning. Detailed failure analysis reveals systematic error modes, including FSM mis-sequencing, handshake drift, blocking vs. non-blocking misuse, and state-space oversimplification. Finally, we outline a forward-looking research roadmap toward natural-language-to-System-on-Chip (SoC) design, emphasizing realistic benchmarks and open flows, richer specification formalisms, AI–human collaborative design environments, and system-level feedback that spans physical design, firmware, and design space exploration. Together, this work provides both a synthesis of recent advances and a baseline evaluation of frontier LLMs, highlighting opportunities and challenges in moving toward AI-native electronic design automation.

title: Online Model Retraining, Compression, and Instance Allocation in Edge Computing Networks_supp1-3665761.pdf
authors: Qian Ma
abstract: The adoption of artificial intelligence models (e.g., DNN models) in internet of things has boosted computing demands in edge computing. Frequent model retraining, necessitated by concept drift, further increases resource usage, while model compression sacrifices model performance for computing efficiency. However, few works study computing instance allocation problem considering dynamic model retraining and compression, especially under varying workloads and model performance degradation. In this work, we model the problem as a joint online model retraining, compression, and instance allocation problem in edge computing networks considering model performance and instance cost. Solving the online problem is challenging since it is a non-linear binary programming problem with time-coupling instance switching cost. We first solve the online problem under fixed compression and propose an efficient online algorithm. Specifically, we first linearize the non-linear term, then regularize the time-coupling switching cost to decouple the problem, and finally use a randomization rounding method to derive the integral solution. We prove that our algorithm achieves a constant optimality gap. We then solve the online problem under flexible compression and propose a lightweight online algorithm. We extend the linearization method and decouple the problem into each time slot, and demonstrate our algorithm achieves an optimality gap depending on the time period. Simulations demonstrate that our algorithm can achieve a balance between instance cost and model performance in both fixed compression and flexible compression scenarios.

title: Joint Beamwidth and Power Density Allocation for ISAC-Enabled UAVs in Low-Altitude Economy
authors: Fengyi Wang, Shilian Wang, Zhu Xiao, Tong Li, Zhu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: This paper investigates integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) in low-altitude economy (LAE) networks, which is crucial for the flight safety of low-altitude unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). We derive the expected achievable rate (EAR) as a novel performance metric to evaluate the ISAC system performance under uncertain predicted direction. Both accurate beam direction prediction and beam resource allocation are essential for achieving fair EAR performance for multiple UAVs. However, the trajectories of the UAVs exhibit non-Gaussian deviations from the predefined trajectories. Moreover, the beamwidth and power density are interdependent for EAR performance. Motivated by this, we propose a transformer-based multitype weighting network (TMW-Net) to obtain accurate UAV state prediction under non-Gaussian scenarios. Building upon the state prediction results, we develop a joint beamwidth and power density allocation (JBPDA) method to maximize the minimum EAR for multiple UAVs. The proposed method searches for an auxiliary variable by establishing a power consumption-based feasibility evaluation problem, which is transformed into a simpler form through the cases of symmetric and asymmetric beam allocation. Finally, the numerical results show that the proposed TMW-Net has higher beam direction prediction accuracy. Furthermore, the designed JBPDA method can achieve a trade-off between communication and sensing in the ISAC system.

title: CaASR: A Causal Lens for Refining Temporal Action Segmentation
authors: Keqing Du, Xinyu Yang, Hang Chen
abstract: Temporal Action Segmentation (TAS) is fundamental to video understanding, aiming to recognize and segment actions within untrimmed videos. While over-segmentation errors have received considerable attention, the equally critical issue of out of-context errors stemming from the neglect of implicit causal relationships between actions remains under-explored. However, constraining these unknown causal relationships at the frame level—including identifying causal links and strengths—presents a significant challenge, leading to notable research gaps. To tackle these challenges, we define a Temporal Action Causal Model (TACM) for the TAS task as declarative guidance, which efficiently injects the causal relationship between actions into frame variables in a generated manner. To this end, we propose the Causal Action Segmentation Refiner (CaASR), a refinement framework designed to mitigate out-of-context errors in segmentation results of backbone models. By reconstructing the causal generation process of post-segmentation frame variables, CaASR constrains causal relationships between actions and ensures the reliability of generated causal relationships. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CaASR significantly enhances both segmentation performance and interpretability across various backbone models, including state-of-the-art methods.

title: Speed Ripple Suppression Based on Stability-Enhanced ADALINE for PMSM Drives
authors: Yuanming Huang, Qiwei Wang, Guoqiang Zhang, Gaolin Wang, Dawei Ding, Dianguo Xu
abstract: The existing adaptive linear neuron (ADALINE) based speed ripple suppression method is affected by the permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) control system delay and limited by the speed controller cutoff frequency, resulting in system instability. This paper proposes a speed ripple suppression based on stability-enhanced ADALINE for PMSM drives. Under unknown system delay conditions, the integral saturation characteristics in the ADALINE network are extracted to obtain system instability information. An anti-instability disturbance sliding mode tracking controller is constructed to extract the phase delay of the speed ripple suppression system and optimize the phase convergence trajectory. Besides, according to the desaturation mapping relationship of the speed ripple sine-cosine components, a phase delay adaptive selection strategy is proposed to achieve adaptive regulation for phase delay, enhancing the speed ripple suppression system stability when the ripple frequency exceeds the speed controller cutoff frequency. The stability and convergence are analyzed in detail. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified on a 2.2 kW PMSM drive platform.

title: Compliance-as-Code for AI-Driven Identity Systems: Clause-to-Control Traceability and Machine-Readable Evidence
authors: Livinus Obiora Nweke, Prosper Kandabongee Yeng
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI)-driven identity (ID) systems (document onboarding, wallet-based credential presentation, fraud/risk scoring) increasingly face regulatory obligations requiring demonstrable accountability, traceability, and technical documentation. Yet current compliance practice remains predominantly document-centric and manual, making it difficult to keep evidence synchronized with rapidly evolving systems and models.We present a compliance-as-code approach for AI-driven ID workflows that (i) maintains clause-to-control traceability under policy/configuration evolution, (ii) treats evidence completeness as an enforceable property via fixed monitoring-window semantics (silence is non-ambiguous), and (iii) exports evidence and outcomes as Open Security Controls Assessment Language (OSCAL)-native assessor packages (Component Definition, System Security Plan, Assessment Results, and automatically generated POA&M), where missing evidence is automatically materialized as structured findings and remediation items. We implement our approach using policy-as-code enforcement (OPA/Rego), CI configuration testing (Conftest), release-time provenance gates (policy bundle digests), runtime decision logging, and an evidence graph that binds events/resources to control IDs, releases, and hashes. We evaluate on two publicly reproducible ID workloads (MIDV-500 onboarding and OpenID4VP/W3C VC DM v2.0-aligned wallet verification). Across four releases, our prototype generates complete OSCAL packages with hash–linked evidence resources, automatically emits POA&M items for evidence gaps, surfaces window-level staleness as findings, and shows no material latency overhead under measured load. These results suggest that compliance-as-code can improve assessability and evidence integrity/attribution within a bounded threat model and control scope, as well as make AI-driven ID systems’ assurance more maintainable and assessor-ready.

title: A Real-time Traffic Violation Detection System On Highways Using Surveillance Cameras and Message-Oriented Middleware
authors: Ahmet Sayar, Yilmaz Dikilitas
abstract: The rapid growth in the number of vehicles has intensified traffic congestion and increased the frequency of rule violations, which remain a major contributing factor to severe accidents, particularly on highways, where high-speed collisions often result in substantial loss of life and property. Therefore, the early, accurate, and automated detection of such violations is crucial for enhancing traffic safety. This study presents a real-time violation detection system designed to identify critical highway infractions, including reversing vehicles, illegally stopped vehicles in the right lane, and unauthorized presence of pedestrians or animals on the roadway. The proposed framework employs an image processing pipeline integrated with a distributed event-driven architecture. Using a topic-based publish/subscribe messaging model built on Apache Kafka, the system efficiently disseminates detected violation events and corresponding visual evidence to authorized units in real time. The architecture is scalable and extensible, enabling the incorporation of additional violation types and analytical modules with minimal system reconfiguration. Experimental evaluations demonstrated that the system achieved reliable detection accuracy under appropriate camera placement and operational conditions, offering a practical foundation for next-generation intelligent transportation and traffic enforcement systems.

title: Frequency Domain Least-Squares Reverse Time Migration Using a Low-Rank Approximated Green’s Function Based on Tucker Decomposition
authors: Sumin Kim, Youngseo Kim, Seung-Goo Kang, Wookeen Chung
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Least-squares reverse time migration (LSRTM), a linearized inverse problem, provides high-resolution subsurface images by minimizing the misfit between observed and simulated data. LSRTM can be implemented in both time and frequency domains. Compared to time-domain LSRTM, frequency domain LSRTM (FLSRTM) offers advantages in handling multi-shot datasets. In addition, wavefield extrapolation needs to be performed only once at the initial iteration of the LSRTM process, provided that Green’s functions can be stored directly in memory. However, the memory required to store Green’s functions increases exponentially, being proportional to the dimensionalities of both model and data spaces. To address this memory issue, we propose a memory-efficient FLSRTM approach based on low-rank approximation via Tucker decomposition. In our FLSRTM method, the Green’s functions for all shot and receiver positions at a given frequency are decomposed into a core tensor and several factor matrices. Based on optimal ranks determined by an energy preservation criterion, the core tensor and factor matrices are truncated, thereby significantly reducing the dimensionality of the Green’s functions. Numerical tests on a modified Marmousi2 velocity model demonstrate the feasibility and substantial memory efficiency of our FLSRTM approach, while preserving the accuracy of migration images. Furthermore, a field data example confirms the practical applicability of our FLSRTM approach.

title: A 50–68-GHz IF Absorptive Receiver Supporting Multichannel Carrier Aggregation for 5G NR FR2-2 and SATCOM
authors: Aoran Han, Qingxian Li, Jie Zhou, Xun Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a 50–68-GHz IF absorptive receiver. The intermodulation (IM) interference caused by the IF signal reflection to the mixer is mitigated through an absorptive IF amplifier, enabling a wideband and flattened IF bandwidth. Moreover, the IF amplifier is implemented in a distortion-canceling structure to improve the linearity of the receiver. The wideband optimal noise performance and input matching of the LNA are achieved using a compact configured-coupled transformer (CCT). I/Q generation is achieved in the LO buffer chain based on a wideband transformer-based quadrature coupler. Verified in a conventional 40-nm bulk CMOS technology, the proposed receiver demonstrates a 26.2-dB conversion gain (CG) and a gain tuning range of 13dB with an 8-GHz IF bandwidth. The measurement results show a 5.6–10-dB NF and a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$- 35{-} to $</tex-math> </inline-formula>-24-dBm IP<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1dB</sub> at the high-gain mode of 26.2dB. Full-band I/Q calibration-free operation is achieved with an image rejection ratio (IRR) ranging from 28 to 60.5dB. Benefiting from the IF absorption technique, the proposed RX supports 4-Gb/s 256-QAM modulation, 9.6-Gb/s 64-QAM 16-channel, and 12-Gb/s 64-QAM 8-channel carrier aggregation (CA), which is attractive for 5G NR FR2-2 and SATCOM applications.

title: Comparison Study of Convolutional Neural Network Variants for Emotional Classification
authors: Vijayakumar P, Prakash V S, Karuppusamy S, Vishnu Raja P, Rathi K, Gokul Chandrasekaran
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Prediction of facial expressions recognizing emotions on a person's face in pictures or videos is an important field of computer vision. This technique has important ramifications for a number of applications, including as human-computer interface and surveillance tracking. A unique deep learning architecture for face expression identification is presented in this study. ResNet50v2 and VGG16 are two well-known convolutional neural network designs that are examined in our method. Both networks have been modified to efficiently extract facial features. To improve the network's capacity to record channel-wise dependencies within feature maps, we integrate squeeze-and-excitation blocks. To further encourage the model to produce condensed and informative feature representations, a self-attention regularization term is added. The CNN algorithm is used in this paper. CNNs are a class of neural networks that are mostly utilized for computer vision applications and image recognition. It is composed of multiple filter layers that come after the completely linked layer and the pooling layer. CNNs are excellent tools for tasks like image classification, object recognition, and partitioning because they are adept at learning the spatial hierarchies of data from images. The primary goals of this method are to determine the configuration that maximizes performance for the CNN-based image processing task and automate the hyperparameter tuning procedure that permits efficiency.

title: Integrated Circuit Binning Count System for Semiconductor Manufacturing
authors: Mark Angelo T. Mercado, Oliver A. Medina, Juliet O. Niega
abstract: The semiconductor industry in the Philippines accounts for nearly 60% of the country's total exports, playing a critical role in the national economy. However, many production facilities continue to depend on outdated system particularly those operating on legacy Windows NT platforms with decentralized, manual processes for Integrated Circuit (IC) binning. This study presents the design and implementation of an Integrated Circuit Binning Count System (ICBCS) that leverages microcontroller-based hardware to automate and centralize binning data acquisition. The system interfaces with legacy testing equipment to monitor IC classification pulses in real time, display local counts, and wirelessly transmit data to a centralized web-based server for storage, analysis, and reporting. The proposed solution significantly improves traceability, reduces human error, and enhances operational efficiency. Designed as a low-cost, scalable system, ICBCS supports the semiconductor industry's transition toward Industry 4.0 standards. Field testing in an actual manufacturing environment demonstrated its effectiveness, ease of integration, and adaptability to various production line configurations.

title: Optimization of Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems for Rural Electrification: A Multi-Objective and Multi-Criteria Decision-Making Approach
authors: Mohammad Reza Maghami, Jacqueline Lukose, Ka Fei Thang, Arthur Mutambara
abstract: Hybrid renewable energy systems (HRES) offer promising solutions for rural electrification, where access to reliable and affordable power remains limited. However, designing an optimal configuration involves addressing trade-offs between cost, reliability, and sustainability under variable renewable resource conditions. This study develops an integrated Multi-Objective Optimization (MOO) and Multi-Criteria Decision-Making (MCDM) framework to identify the most suitable hybrid system for a rural community in South Khorasan, Iran. Four scenarios were simulated using HOMER Pro: a baseline solar-wind-battery system, a PEM fuel cell-supported system, a diesel-backed configuration, and an MPPT-optimized system. The MOO process minimized the Total Net Present Cost (TNPC), power losses, CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emission and unmet load while the fuzzy-based MCDM analysis incorporated expert evaluation of environmental, technical, and feasibility criteria to rank system alternatives. Results show that although rural clients often prefer systems with lower initial cost and higher reliability, such as diesel-based setups, these options lead to higher operating costs and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions over time. The MPPT-based configuration (Scenario 4) achieved the highest overall MCDM score, providing 100% renewable energy utilization, zero emissions, and improved photovoltaic efficiency. While slightly more expensive initially, it offers the most sustainable and long-term cost-effective solution for off-grid rural areas. The findings demonstrate that integrating MOO and MCDM enables a more comprehensive assessment, balancing short-term affordability with long-term sustainability for rural electrification planning.

title: Traffic Speed Prediction Based on Dynamic Graph Convolution and Patch Attention Mechanism
authors: WenChao Liu, LingZhi Tian, Rui Liu, ZiYi Lv, FengPing Wang, Meng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Accurate traffic speed prediction is essential for intelligent transportation systems, yet existing approaches often struggle with capturing dynamic spatio-temporal dependencies and balancing local and global temporal patterns. To address this, we propose DGCPAT, a novel framework integrating graph convolution with a Patch-Attention mechanism. The model utilizes dynamic graph convolution to learn adaptive spatial dependencies, while Intra and Inter Patch-Attention capture short-term local variations and long-term trends respectively. Evaluations on METR-LA and PEMS-BAY show that DGCPAT achieves state-of-the-art performance across MAE, RMSE, and MAPE over multiple time horizons.

title: Novel Design of Machine Learning Based Surface Defect Detection Systems
authors: Song-Kyoo Kim, Runqi Su
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: A smart approach to surface defect detection utilizes machine learning algorithms and image processing techniques. The integration of discrete wavelet transform and the Otsu binary algorithm enhances image quality and effectively segments defects. Through extensive experimentation, a combined bivariate performance measure evaluates the effectiveness of various machine learning models, focusing on their accuracy and training efficiency. Findings highlight significant improvements in realtime defect identification, which is critical for maintaining quality control in manufacturing processes. The proposed system not only optimizes performance metrics but also promotes early defect detection, leading to enhanced production quality and reduced operational risks. This work contributes to the growing field of automated defect detection, showcasing the potential of machine learning in improving industrial practices and ensuring product safety.

title: Multi-Resolution Satellite Image Fusion Using Dual-Tree Complex Wavelet and Lifting Schemes for Enhanced Spatial-Spectral Quality
authors: Harish L, Kapinaiah Viswanath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: In remote sensing, image fusion—also known as pansharpening—refers to the integration of high-resolution panchromatic (Pan) imagery with the spectral richness of lowerresolution multispectral (MS) data to generate a single highquality image [2]. Traditional fusion methods often compromise spectral integrity, whereas recent transform-domain techniques have shown enhanced performance [4], [6]. This paper proposes a novel fusion strategy based on Dual-Tree Complex Wavelet Transform (DT-CWT) and the Lifting Scheme, aimed at improving both spatial and spectral features. The results, evaluated using visual interpretation and quantitative metrics, demonstrate the method's effectiveness over conventional approaches [1]

title: Revolving-Bloom Filter: A Bloom Filter Variant for Effective Set Reconciliation
authors: Gyubin Kim, Hyesook Lim
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: To maintain data consistency in large-scale distributed systems, it is essential to employ lightweight set summarization techniques that can rapidly detect differences without directly comparing all data. This paper addresses the accuracy limitations of the existing Ternary Bloom Filter (TBF) by re-evaluating the Counting Bloom Filter (CBF) under identical memory constraints and introducing a novel structure called the Revolving Bloom Filter (R-BF). The proposed R-BF retains the simple counter-based design of BF but incorporates a revolving mechanism in which counters reset to zero upon reaching their maximum value, thereby enabling precise representation of subset summaries. We apply both CBF and R-BF to a binary trie-based set reconciliation algorithm. Experimental results under identical memory conditions demonstrate that the proposed CBF and R-BF significantly improve the detection accuracy of distinct elements compared to the TBF-based approach. The proposed method is expected to be effectively applicable to distributed data synchronization and replica reconciliation under resource-constrained environments such as IoT and edge computing devices.

title: Impact of 5G Adjacent Band Emissions on FSS Downlink Performance
authors: Hyo-Won Lee, Ga-Yeong Park, Ji-Young Kim, Sungjun Cho, Jong-Won Yu
abstract: 5G base stations (BSs) operating in the FR1 n78 band (3.3–3.8 GHz) may cause adjacent-band interference to fixed-satellite service (FSS) downlinks in the 3.7–4.2 GHz band. This paper quantitatively analyzes adjacent-band interference from 5G BS emissions in both in-band emission (IBE) and out-of-band emission (OOBE) scenarios. To evaluate the impact on FSS downlink performance, this paper proposes a comprehensive methodology that combines simulation of 5G signal propagation with field measurements. The interference power levels obtained from both approaches are then applied to a system-level FSS receiver model using RF front-end circuit simulation to assess the potential degradation in satellite signal quality.

title: Fault Diagnosis Technology of Inter-turn Short Circuit in Dual Three-Phase High Speed Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Based on MLP Neural Network
authors: Haonan Li, Youlong Wang, Jialin Wei
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper conducts research on the inter-turn short-circuit (ITSC) fault of dual three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM). A mathematical model of the dual three-phase motor is established, and all ITSC fault states are analyzed. The corresponding fault dataset is constructed through field-circuit coupling simulation. Furthermore, a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) neural network model is built, and a strategy combining random selection and Bayesian optimization is adopted to determine the hyperparameters of the network. The model training results and 5-fold cross-validation results show that the network has high data fitting accuracy and good generalization ability. The lightweight characteristic of this model enables it to be deployed on a FPGA hardware platform, allowing it to participate in the real-time fault diagnosis and control decision-making of dual three-phase motors.

title: Ultra-Low Power Wideband Cryogenic CMOS Noise-Canceling LNAs for Quantum Computing
authors: Shawn S.H. Hsu, Mahesh Kumar Chaubey, Yin-Cheng Chang, Po-Chang Wu, Hann-Huei Tsai
abstract: This paper presents the design of cryogenic CMOS low-noise amplifiers (LNAs) using the concept of noise canceling (NC) for scalable, large-scale quantum computing applications. Various circuit topologies incorporating common-source (CS) and common-gate (CG) with the NC technique are introduced, based on our recent works in CMOS technologies. A comparative analysis of CS and CG noise-canceling techniques is presented, and different design techniques, including cascode inverter, self-body bias, input-referred noise reduction, and G<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>-boosting are discussed. The proposed cryo-CMOS LNAs using the noise canceling techniques achieve excellent noise figure, high gain, and wide bandwidth under low power consumption, demonstrating FoMs among the best. The design concepts provide directions for future LNA research for quantum computing applications.

title: Deep Adversarial Learning for Phishing and Malware Detection in Cloud Systems
authors: Thejasvi Sheshadri, Ashima Saxena, Thulasi A, Vaishnavi K H, Vijay S Manmode, Varun Dev R V
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: A model that protects cloud systems from rapidly changing phishing and malware threats by employing both traditional deep learning techniques and signature-based models in combination. Those technologies are either obfuscation-based or zero-day. Attacks fail to get through, because manipulation can't succeed -not even in adversarial cases. However, these high false positives can't generalize to anything else and are quickly faced with their own limitations. The innovation deep adversarial learning framework applies a generator-discriminator architecture based on the CNN, Bi-LSTM, and attention, with enhanced robustness and feature adaptation capabilities. These adversarial data simulate evasive behavior, so that the model can now identify previously unknown attacks while keeping accuracy. For scalability and low-latency inference, this technique uses multi-domain feature fusion and edgecloud deployment. When analyzing the results of a hybrid phishing and malware dataset, we find that it gives 98.9% (F1 = 0.985) phishing accuracy and 99.3% (F1 = 0.993) malware accuracy, with a false positive rate of 1.2%. At the same time, over dynamic cloud environments, existing deep URL and API-sequence models are outperformed by it on the aspects like adaptability, detection consistency computational efficiency across.

title: Chroma Features Based Music Genre Classification Using Machine and Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Satyabrata Lenka, Muvva Akhil Yadav, Taddi Balaram, Kupireddy Jhansi, Mayaluri Zefree Lazarus, Lucky Harichandan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This study investigates the efficacy of various machine learning and deep learning models for automated music genre classification. Utilizing the GTZAN dataset, a comprehensive collection of audio features was extracted and preprocessed, including Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), Chroma features, Spectral Centroid, Root Mean Square (RMS), and Spectral Bandwidth. The dataset, comprising 3-second audio segments, was used to train and evaluate K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Classifier (SVC), Decision Tree, Random Forest, and a custom-built Deep Neural Network (DNN). A comparative analysis of model performance, supported by accuracy metrics and confusion matrices, reveals the strengths and limitations of each approach in distinguishing between ten distinct music genres. The findings underscore the importance of robust feature engineering and appropriate model selection for accurate Music Information Retrieval (MIR) tasks, highlighting areas were acoustic similarities challenge classification algorithms.

title: Non-destructive Detection and Classification of Camel Milk Adulteration using Microwave Reflection and Machine Learning
authors: Dawiya Youssouf Hamadi, Abeer ElKhouly, Mohd Fareq Abd Malek
abstract: This study addresses the economic adulteration of high-value camel milk, a practice that diminishes its unique nutritional and therapeutic properties and can introduce health risks to consumers. A non-destructive method combining microwave reflection measurements and machine learning is proposed for rapid and effective quality control. The fundamental principle involves measuring the microwave reflection coefficient (S11) of milk samples over a frequency range of 100 MHz to 3.4 GHz. Adulterants such as water, salt, sugar, starch, or cow's milk alter the dielectric properties of the camel milk, each producing a unique "fingerprint" in the measured reflection signal. These distinct spectral signatures were then used as inputs to train machine learning models. The developed system demonstrates a robust capability to classify common adulterants and quantify them at different concentration levels, presenting a promising, field-deployable technology for ensuring the authenticity and safety of camel milk.

title: A Graph Based Attention Model and Calibrated Random Forest for Breast Cancer Classification Using Histopathology Images
authors: Dipti Deb, Ratnakar Dash, Durga Mohapatra
abstract: Artificial intelligence and computer vision advancements have revolutionized computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems, enabling more accurate breast cancer (BrCan) detection using histopathology images. This study proposes a classification framework that integrates Vision Transformers (ViT), Graph Attention Networks (GAT), and Calibrated Random Forest (CRF) to enhance diagnostic accuracy. ViT effectively captures rich visual representations and helps to form a graph-like structure, while GAT models the structural relationships within histopathology images, providing a more comprehensive understanding of tissue morphology. Extensive experiments were conducted with various model combinations, demonstrating that the ViT + GAT + CRF architecture achieved the highest performance. The experiment is carried out on the BreakHis dataset, and the model acquires an accuracy of 97.33%. These results highlight the effectiveness of incorporating both visual and structural features to improve diagnostic reliability. Our proposed framework represents a significant advancement in digital histopathology-based (BrCan) diagnosis and holds promise for broader applications in medical imaging.

title: System-Level Simulation of Long-range Wireless Power Transfer for Multi-Device in Indoor Environment
authors: Yoojung Moon, Changseok Yoon, Hyun-Seok Ahn, Young-Han Kim
abstract: The rapid increase in IoT devices deployment in indoor environment has encouraged the development of wireless power transfer (WPT) technology for a promising solution for convenient and reliable energy delivery solutions. However, the performance of WPT in indoor environments is strongly affected by spatial structure and materials of the surroundings. Moreover, WPT signal has comparatively higher power to communication signals, requiring accurate prediction of the RF propagation. In this paper, we propose a system-level simulation for multiple WPT receiver considering Tx/Rx antenna model, precise 3D propagation environment, hardware characteristics, and operating algorithms. In addition, the simulation results were further validated by measurements in real world.

title: FPA: Football Performance Analysis Using YOLO-Based Object Detection System
authors: Navaneetha M, Sahil Prashant Jadhav, Shreyas Jiddibgail, Vishal S Yalasangi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Analyzing performance in sports has become increasingly important for understanding the dynamics of the players, planning strategies for the team, and enhancing the game outcome. This research primarily explores the use of advanced deep learning techniques, specially YOLO (You Only Look Once) object detection framework, to analyze football matches. The system uses YOLO for detecting players, the ball, and strategic points of the field in real time, team differentiation using clustering, etc., using which we derive key metrics for the analysis, with complete automation.[1]. Additionally, the system maps players and the ball to a 2D field map for intuitive analysis and creating insightful visualizations like heatmaps and trajectory paths. The methodology integrates computer vision techniques and data analytics for better detection and analysis. Experiments show that the models are good enough for providing actionable insights for the coaches and the analysts with high accuracy and real-time efficiency. This research highlights how deep learning is transforming sports analytics and provide a scalable, cost-effective solution that can be applied to performance analysis across different sports.

title: Graphene-Based Bow-Tie Plasmonic Tweezers for Enhanced Optical Trapping at Terahertz Frequencies
authors: Swapnil Siddiky, Ahmed Zubair
abstract: Graphene-based plasmonic tweezers achieve strong localized field confinement by taking advantage of their low-loss properties and unique tunable conductivity. To improve near-field localization and optical trapping performance, we designed an optical nanotweezer structure in the shape of a bow-tie with a gap at the center. Using extensive parametric analysis, we explored structural dimensions, including gap size, length and width, impact electric field, trapping performance, and localized surface plasmon resonance. Our findings demonstrated that while width primarily affected near-field strength, increasing length caused a redshift in the resonant frequency. We obtained a peak optical force of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-1.57 \text{nN}/\mathrm{W}_{\mu \mathrm{m}^{-2}}$</tex> at 7.3 THz frequency on a nanoparticle by introducing an 8 nm gap between the two bow-tie triangles, which is twofold higher than that of the gapless bow-tie structure. A deep optical potential well (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>-8 \times 10^{3} \text{kb}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{T}/\mathrm{W}_{\mu \mathrm{m}^{-2}}$</tex>) was revealed close to the surface. The field and potential variation along the vertical axis further confirmed stable trapping. These findings highlight the potential of graphene plasmonic tweezers for high-precision dielectric and biological nanoparticle manipulation in lab-on-a-chip applications by demonstrating their strong geometrical tunability.

title: Constructing an Intelligent Home System Control Using Internet of Things
authors: Wen-Tsai Sung, Yan-Hua Lai, Indra Griha Tofik Isa, Sung-Jung Hsiao
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) technology has become an integral part of human life, aiming to facilitate and increase the efficiency of human operations. The intelligent home system, which adopts IoT technology, can improve security, convenience, and efficiency. In this study, the intelligent home system will be developed, which employs several physical sensing devices, an ESP32 microcontroller, ThingSpeak, and Line as notification control, and MQTT as the communication protocol. System development refers to the IoT architecture, which consists of three layers, including the physical layer, network layer, and application layer. System testing is carried out by capturing the real-time condition parameters of humidity, temperature, and smoke concentration through the ThingSpeak app, which indicates that all of the parameters can be read by the IoT system. In addition, Line Notify apps enable sending real-time message push notifications to the user regarding the status updates of smoke concentration, door lock status, and live video streaming. In conclusion, the intelligent home system developed in this study provides the enhancement of home security system, user convenience, efficient device, and low-cost system.

title: A Study on the Impact of JD.com's Ranking Competition Mechanism on Retailers' Sales Volume
authors: Jie Chen, Xiaoyue Li, Jinwu Gao
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The rapid development of e-commerce platforms in recent years has transformed the operational landscape for retailers, with product ranking mechanisms emerging as a key determinant of sales performance. While existing research predominantly focuses on ranking algorithms and consumer behavior, systematic exploration of their economic impacts remains underdeveloped. This study employs 838 data entries from the hair dryer category on JD.com, employing a multiple linear regression model to analyze how comprehensive rankings and review-based rankings influence sales outcomes. The findings provide actionable insights for retailers to optimize strategies and for platform operators to refine algorithmic frameworks.Research findings indicate: (1) Both comprehensive rankings and review rankings show significant positive correlations with sales volume, where improved rankings can drive sales growth; (2) In comprehensive rankings, the number of reviews, store ratings, and logistics ratings positively influence sales while prices negatively correlate; in review rankings, logistics ratings demonstrate particularly prominent effects; (3) Comprehensive rankings exhibit a "Matthew effect" where high-volume groups show heightened sensitivity to ranking changes, whereas review rankings demonstrate monotonically increasing effects with sales groupings.It is suggested that retailers should formulate differentiated strategies according to the characteristics of the ranking mechanism, and the platform can implement ranking compensation mechanism and dynamic weight algorithm to promote fair competition.

title: PURL-Bot: Chatbot Integrated Machine Learning Driven Phishing URL Detection
authors: Gangireddy Venkata Neelimadhavi, V.V.A.S. Lakshmi, M.Venkata Rao, K.V.Narasimha Reddy, S. Sivanageswarao, R. Sowjanya
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Phishing crimes constitute a considerable security issue on the internet and every month, about 1.4 million new phishing websites are developed exposing millions of victims to the global arena. Even though there is an improvement in the detection mechanisms, the traditional methods find it difficult to achieve high accuracy because of the limitations in detecting the feature and performance of classification methods. This paper presents the Phishing URL Classification Bot (PURL-Bot) that integrates advanced preprocessing and powerful extraction of URL features with a strong Extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) classifier to accurately classify the Phishing URLs. PURL-Bot uses the Phish Tank URL database and classifies the URLs in two categories: Normal and Phishing. Furthermore, the bot will have an intelligent chatbot system, where users can inquire about the threats of phishing, the classification details, and the performance of the system through active inquiries. The PURL-Bot performance is evaluated experimentally with an accuracy of 99.24%, precision of 99.24%, recall of 99.22% and F1-score of 99.23% that are significantly better than the available solutions. The work contributes to the development of cybersecurity by offering a powerful and easy-to-use system to prevent the threat of phishing.

title: Real-Time Design of Coal Mine Safety Monitoring with Alerting Intelligence using IoT with Logical Sensors
authors: S Veena, A Vanathi, Shaik SadikBasha, Umaie Salma, M Naveena, N Pavithra
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Coal mining continues to be one of the most hazardous industrial activities due to the prevalence of toxic gases, poor ventilation, spontaneous combustion, and risks of structural collapse. The old system of monitoring that is based on manual inspections or single sensors has not been effective enough and as a result, there are delays in the detection of hazards and the inefficiency of safety measures. In order to overcome these issues, this study suggests a real-time coal mine safety system, which integrates the Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled logical sensors, edge computing, and smart alerting systems. The methodology includes system requirement analysis, logic sensor fusion, IoT hardware implementation with NB-IoT communication, real time data acquisition, initializing Kalman filters, and predicting anomalies by using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. The results of the experiment indicate that the sensors of neither methane nor carbon monoxide gas had an average accuracy of 97.4% and the NB-IoT communication framework showed a packet delivery ratio of more than 97.5% at a distance of 500 meters with a latency of less than 205ms. The Hazard risk scoring system had accurate classification of safe, warning, hazardous, and critical conditions whereas the LSTM-based predictive analytics model gave an average performance of 95.2% when multiple hazard scenarios were considered. The tests of system reliability also showed that the system had an uptime of 98.5% even when the failure rate of sensor nodes was lower than 30% which supported fault-tolerant design and redundancy models. The results validate the fact that the combination of logical sensors and intelligent IoT systems would guarantee real-time and accurate safety monitoring, and the number of risks to miners would go down considerably. The system has the benefit of being a scalable approach that can be deployed to other high-risk industries that might need continuous monitoring of the environment and human safety.

title: Urban Heat Island and Heat Vulnerability Assessment with Ground Validation - A Case Study for Makati City
authors: Charles Andrew C. Pasion, Mark Angelo C. Purio
abstract: Urbanization, characterized by the movement of populations from rural to urban areas, is reshaping societies globally. This transformation is driven by economic, social, and environmental factors that make urban areas appealing, offering better jobs, access to healthcare and education, and improved infrastructure. However, urbanization also presents significant challenges, including the Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect, which exacerbates living conditions in densely populated cities by increasing surface and air temperatures compared to surrounding rural areas. This study addresses the UHI phenomenon and heat vulnerability by conducting an Urban Heat Island and Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) assessment, incorporating ground validation, for Makati City, Philippines. The UHI Map was developed using Landsat 8 satellite Land Surface Temperature (LST) data. The HVI Map was developed using Landsat 8 Data Product and Demographic data to identify areas at higher risk of adverse heat-related effects. Each indicator scores were normalized, scored, and aggregated to calculate an HVI score for each barangay. Ground validation was performed to verify the results from the UHI and HVI maps. A prototype device was designed, consisting of sensors for ambient temperature and relative humidity, a memory device for data storage, and a battery with a one-month operational lifespan. Three devices were deployed in barangays identified by the HVI Map: two in the most vulnerable barangays and one in the least vulnerable barangay. Over a month, the devices recorded temperature and humidity data, which were analysed to corroborate the maps' findings. The UHI and HVI maps identified areas within Makati City that are most susceptible to heat-related health impacts, offering critical insights for policymakers and urban planners. The integration of socio-economic and environmental factors ensures a holistic understanding of heat vulnerability, enabling evidence-based strategies to mitigate risks. The findings support urban planning efforts aimed at reducing heat exposure through increased vegetation, improved building designs, and the development of heat-resilient infrastructure. Additionally, this research contributes to achieving Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 11, Sustainable Cities and Communities, by promoting strategies for creating inclusive, safe, and sustainable urban environments.

title: A High-Tolerance and Thickness-Adjustable PCB-Based Microstrip-to-Waveguide Transition Design
authors: Jianhan Zhang, Xiaohe Cheng, Yuan Yao, Lei Chen, Zhibin Hu, Xiaodong Guan
abstract: This paper presents a novel transition between microstrip lines and a rectangular waveguide. A via-less choke structure is designed for suppressing the leakage of electromagnetic waves between laminates, while also enabling the transition to be compatible with arbitrary printed circuit board (PCB) thicknesses. Furthermore, to solve electromagnetic leakage and impedance mismatch caused by assembly tolerances under millimeter-wave conditions, an electromagnetic bandgap (EBG) structure is introduced at the interface between the metal waveguide and the PCB. Simulation results show that an impedance bandwidth of 9.7% from 59 GHz to 65 GHz with PCB-to-waveguide gap of up to 0.1 mm and lateral misalignments within ±0.35 mm along the X and Y directions is achieved.

title: Stress and Relaxation Detection with Enhancement Using MaskNet
authors: Rashmirekha Ram, Mihir Narayan Mohanty
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Human emotion analysis is a complex and multidisciplinary task. Researchers have explored various input modalities voice, image, brain signal to detect emotional states. Among these, voice-based analysis has become popular and practical due to its ease of data collection. It is especially useful for identifying emotional states like stress (e.g., sad, angry) or relaxation (happy). Emotion recognition from voice can provide valuable insights for psychologists and medical professionals. With the advancement of deep learning, this paper presents a novel approach for stress and relaxation detection using a MaskNet module. The proposed framework works in three stages. In the first stage, pre-processing is performed to enhance the audio signal by removing silent segments. In the second stage, features are extracted using Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) along with their first-order (Δ) and second-order (ΔΔ) derivatives to capture temporal variations. In the final stage, emotion classification is carried out using a hybrid CNN–LSTM architecture integrated with a multiplicative masking mechanism. This approach improves both the discriminative power and noise robustness of the model. Experimental results on the RAVDESS and EMO-DB datasets show a 6.3% increase in accuracy and a 4.9% improvement in F1-score compared to traditional emotion recognition architectures.

title: FusionNet-Vision: Glaucoma Detection Using Feature-Aware Segmentation and Transparent Classification Layers
authors: Chalicheema Rajani, Bhavana Valluri, Bhargavi Ravi, Deepthi Galla, Sireesha Moturi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Glaucoma is a leading cause of irreversible blindness, often progressing without noticeable symptoms. Early detection is vital but manual diagnosis from retinal fundus images is time-consuming and subjective. This paper presents a two-stage deep learning framework for automated glaucoma detection. Stage one employs an Attention U-Net with a ResNet50 encoder for accurate optic disc and cup segmentation, enabling precise computation of the cup-to-disc ratio (CDR). Stage two integrates a fine-tuned InceptionV3 classifier enhanced with a CatBoost-based ensemble to distinguish glaucomatous eyes. Grad-CAM and Grad-CAM++ provide visual explanations that highlight model attention regions, supporting clinical interpretability. Trained and validated on the REFUGE dataset, the system achieved 94% accuracy, 0.91 Dice score, and 0.97 AUC, outperforming baseline CNN models. The proposed framework demonstrates a clinically reliable and explainable approach for scalable glaucoma screening.

title: A Latent Space Intervention Method for Mitigating Hallucinations in Multimodal Large Models
authors: Hongyu Hu, Jianxiong Li, Dawei Zhao, Zhigang Wang, Xianfeng Li, Jiaxi Hong, Yanli Chen, Yan Feng, Hui Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Multimodal large models face severe challenges with hallucination, where the generated text is inconsistent with the visual input. Existing methods attempt to steer latent features but often rely on simplified intervention vectors, leading to limited correction. This paper proposes MLPS (Msign-based Latent Projection and Steering), a novel test-time intervention technique. The core mechanism of MLPS is to compute an intervention direction and then apply the matrix sign function (Msign) to extract a more robust guidance vector. This Msign vector more accurately corrects dynamic biases in the latent space, guiding the model to generate outputs faithful to visual facts. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that our method significantly reduces hallucinations, improving the overall evaluation score by up to 32.2% compared to baseline methods.

title: Deep Learning-Based Detection and Auditory Summation of the Philippine New Generation Series Peso Coins for Visually Impaired Individuals
authors: Robert G.de Luna, Jana Elyssa O. Bandong, Selwin Adam R. Garcia, Trishia L. Mirabel, Maria Carmela L. Panaligan, Jullianne Christille N. Sunga
abstract: This research is a deep learning-driven assistive device specifically engineered to support visually impaired individuals in identifying Philippine New Generation Series (NGS) peso coins. The primary goal of this study is to facilitate independent and accurate coin recognition through an accessible and user-friendly auditory feedback system. The system leverages computer vision and artificial intelligence to distinguish between various denominations based on their visual features. To train deep learning models, a custom dataset consisting of 1,419-coin images was manually collected, ensuring diversity in coin orientation, lighting conditions, and background environments to reflect real-world usage. Three deep learning architectures-Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), ResNet50, and VGG16-were selected for evaluation, given their proven efficacy in image classification tasks. These models were trained and validated on the prepared dataset, and their performance was compared in terms of accuracy. Among the three, the CNN model outperformed the others, attaining an accuracy of 99.89%, demonstrating its superior capability in recognizing coin types with high precision and minimal error. The finalized CNN model was then integrated into a functional hardware prototype which combines the trained model with a camera module and a microcontroller-based processing unit. Upon capturing an image of the coin, the system classifies its denomination and provides real-time auditory feedback, thereby enabling blind or visually impaired users to accurately identify coins without external assistance.

title: Dual-Band Multi-Gap Resonator Integrated with Spiral Inertial Microfluidics for Simultaneous Label-Free and High-Throughput Biomolecular Detection_supp1-3662841.docx
authors: Tian Qiang
abstract: Microwave resonator sensors exhibit three distinctive advantages over conventional analytical methods: real-time monitoring capacity, label-free detection mechanism, and high integration with microfluidic systems. The working principle exploits dielectric characterization through measurable resonant frequency shifts caused by dielectric constant variations in biological analytes. In this paper, an integrated microwave microfluidic sensing chip is proposed for the detection of white blood cells (WBCs, THP-1) and circulating cancer cells (CTCs, MCF-7). The proposed dual-band multi-gap coupled resonator (DMCR) is constructed on a glass substrate with copper structure gaps to generate resonance, exhibiting high sensitivity at both resonance frequency. The polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS)-based microfluidic chip employs a spiral channel architecture to achieve continuous cell separation through the synergistic effects of inertial lift forces and Dean vortices. The spiral microfluidic device achieves 74.13% separation efficiency for WBCs and 84.6% for CTCs at designated outlets, with detection sensitivities of 3.51 MHz/(10⁴ cells/mL) and 11.6 MHz/(10⁴ cells/mL) for MCF-7 and THP-1 cell lines, respectively. This label-free platform demonstrates a certain degree of specificity through the integration of microwave resonator sensors and microfluidic sorting mechanisms, showing significant potential for clinical liquid biopsy applications requiring non-invasive analysis of circulating tumor cells.

title: Generalized Regularized Evidential Deep Learning Models: Theory and Comprehensive Evaluation_supp1-3660699.pdf
authors: Deep Shankar Pandey
abstract: Evidential deep learning (EDL) models, based on Subjective Logic, introduce a principled and computationally efficient way to make deterministic neural networks uncertainty-aware. The resulting evidential models can quantify fine-grained uncertainty using learned evidence. However, the Subjective-Logic framework constrains evidence to be non-negative, requiring specific activation functions whose geometric properties can induce activation-dependent learning-freeze behavior-a regime where gradients become extremely small for samples mapped into low-evidence regions. We theoretically characterize this behavior and analyze how different evidential activations influence learning dynamics. Building on this analysis, we design a general family of activation functions and corresponding evidential regularizers that provide an alternative pathway for consistent evidence updates across activation regimes. Extensive experiments on four benchmark classification problems (MNIST, CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and Tiny-ImageNet), two few-shot classification problems, and blind face restoration problem empirically validate the developed theory and demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed generalized regularized evidential models.

title: Metaphorical Visual Question Answering: Benchmark and Knowledge-Enhanced Metaphor Understanding Method
authors: Qingbao Huang, Peihang He, Pijian Li, Xiangyu Lu, Yang Tian, Yi Cai, Qing Li
abstract: Fact and common-sense reasoning grounded in metaphorical imagery constitute a more challenging form of visual question answering (VQA). Under this form, models typically cannot obtain answers directly from images. Models first need to identify and comprehend the metaphorical components within the image, subsequently integrating prior knowledge to establish the mappings between the target and source domains depicted in the image. To evaluate this capability, we propose a VQA benchmark based on metaphorical images (METAVQA), which measures the understanding of the model of metaphorical images in the form of VQA. Experimental results indicate that interpreting metaphorical images requires robust prior knowledge and a strong ability to understand abstract components, which remains a challenge for LLMs. To improve the metaphorical understanding capability of LLMs, we propose a knowledge-enhanced method (KEMU). This method utilizes LLMs to extract image triplets, retrieve implicit metaphorical knowledge, and reason through questions step-by-step using chain of thought prompting, and pretrained classifier to match the refined reasoning output to the provided answer choices. Validated on the METAVQA dataset, KEMU outperforms LLMs in both one-hop and multi-hop questions. Our code and benchmark can be seen in https://github.com/VILAN-Lab/METAVQA.

title: A Fingertip-Size Six-Axis Force Sensor via Origami Coil Arrays for Intrinsic Tactile Sensing
authors: Yingao Xu, Houping Wu, Yunfei Xie, Jiayuan Zhang, Hongbo Wang
abstract: Force and tactile sensing play increasingly important roles in robotics hands to complete complex tasks safely and effectively, complementing the last piece of the puzzle of human-level dexterity. Despite the advances in flexible sensors and skins, tactile sensing at the fingertip of robotic hands remains an open question. Exploiting embedded six-axis force/torque (F/T) sensors for external stimuli estimation, namely, intrinsic tactile sensing, seems to be an effective solution. Here, we present OriCube, an origami-inspired, fingertip-size (14.5 × 14.5 × 12.5 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>), lightweight (4 g), fully integrated, inductive six-axis F/T sensor. It utilizes an origami coil array to achieve self-decoupled six-axis F/T measurements by detecting the displacements and rotations of a metal shell via eddy–current coupling. A modular silicone spring-based elastomer design allows fine-tuning of the stiffness and performance of each axis independently. The calibrated OriCube exhibits a high resolution of 0.01% F.S. (23 N), low crosstalk (2%), high stability (<0.2% drift in 6 h), and insensitivity to strong magnetic field changes. It is capable of detecting light touch by a feather as well as high impact force when hammered. We demonstrate real-time tactile sensing (contact position and force vector) at the curved surface of a robotic fingertip via one embedded OriCube sensor.

title: Developing Dynamic Prediction Methods for Survival Time Lost in Chronic Kidney Disease Progression under Competing Risks_supp1-3664831.pdf
authors: Zheng Chen
abstract: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) may progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) or die from other causes during long-term follow-up, making it essential to properly account for competing risks in prognostic modeling. However, most existing CKD prediction models rely on hazard-based measures, which primarily reflect relative effects, lack clinical interpretability, and cannot directly quantify survival time lost due to disease progression or death. To address this limitation, we adopted the restricted mean time lost (RMTL), an absolute and intuitive measure of survival time loss, and developed a dynamic prediction model under competing risks. Given the rich time-dependent covariate information in longitudinal CKD data and the clinical need for patients to understand their disease progression at different stages, we developed a dynamic RMTL prediction model that incorporates the landmark approach. The model captures how covariate effects evolve over time, offering insights into the dynamic impact of clinical variables, and enables individualized prediction of survival time loss over a future window from any given prediction time point. We evaluated its statistical properties through Monte Carlo simulations and demonstrated its practical utility using CKD patient data from the AASK cohort. The results showed that the proposed model yields accurate and robust estimates, captures time-varying covariate effects, and outperforms conventional static models in predictive performance. By quantifying survival time loss under competing risks, the dynamic RMTL model offers clinically interpretable and individualized risk estimates, supporting personalized risk assessment and intervention planning in chronic disease management.

title: Max–Min Robust Unsupervised Feature Selection via Sparse Subspace
authors: Sisi Wang, Feiping Nie, Zheng Wang, Rong Wang, Zhensheng Sun, Xuelong Li
abstract: Feature selection is one of the hot issues in machine learning. It reduces storage pressure by effectively screening features and has become a very practical data preprocessing method. At present, most feature selection algorithms apply <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\ell _{2,1}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-norm on the transformation matrix to calculate the scores for all features and then select appropriate features according to these scores. But their sparsity is limited, and meaningless regularization parameters increase the cost, making it prone to falling into local optimum. To solve the above difficulties, this article proposes a novel max–min robust unsupervised feature selection via sparse subspace (MMRUFS), which considers both the reconstruction term and variance term of data, so that the model can not only fully retain the original information of data, but also make the data more dispersed. Second, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\ell _{2,0}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-norm constraint is used on the transformation matrix to directly select the optimal feature subset, avoiding the fine-tuning of regularization parameters. To enhance the robustness, MMRUFS carefully designs mark weight vector to make the model treat normal samples and outliers differently and achieves the effect of anomaly detection. Finally, MMRUFS is solved by designing the surrogate matrix, and its convergence is strictly guaranteed, experimental results reveal that MMRUFS outperforms other feature selection algorithms on multiple real-world datasets.

title: Intelligent Video Analysis-based Pose Recognition and Localization for Improving Dairy Cow Welfare
authors: Roberta Avanzato, Luca Guarnera, Ludovica Beritelli, Valerio Francesco Puglisi, Francesco Beritelli, Sebastiano Battiato
abstract: Ensuring the welfare of dairy cows is essential for sustainable and ethical livestock farming. This study presents an integrated system that combines pose recognition and spatial localization to monitor cow behavior in real-time. Using a convolutional neural network (YOLOv11n) trained on a newly collected and augmented dataset, the framework accurately classifies cow postures (standing or lying) and determines their location within predefined sub-zones of the barn. The system achieved a pose detection accuracy of 91.20% and 85.12 on daytime and nighttime test sets, respectively. Validation on the external MMCows dataset confirmed its robustness and generalizability across different barn layouts (overall accuracy of 93.84%). Regarding localization accuracy, the proposed method achieved 93.28% and 95.74 on daytime and nighttime test sets, respectively. By relying solely on RGB cameras, the method ensures low cost, scalability, and ease of deployment. This vision-based approach enables continuous monitoring, early anomaly detection, and informed decision-making in precision livestock management. The dataset and pretrained models are available at the following URL (after paper acceptance).
