title: A Dual-Coil Mutual Inductive Coupling Device for Real-time Wireless Intraocular Pressure Monitoring
authors: Xin Ma, Xin Zhang, Yifan Wu, Ruihao You, Liqiang Wang, Yifei Huang, Anqi Liu
abstract: Intraocular pressure (IOP) is a key physiological parameter for maintaining ocular function, and its continuous monitoring is crucial for diagnosing glaucoma and related diseases. This work presents a real-time wireless IOP monitoring device that integrates a flexible resistive thin-film pressure sensor with a dual-coil mutual inductive coupling mechanism. The device converts pressure-induced resistance variations into voltage amplitude changes via mutual inductance, enabling wireless, low-power, and fully non-invasive detection without reliance on resonance frequency tracking. Device achieved a sensitivity of 40 mV/kPa (≈ 5.32 mV/mmHg) on an artificial-eye platform, with a resolution of ≈ 0.172 mmHg, and 5.83 mV/mL in porcine-eye experiments, showing consistent linearity and stability. The amplitude-based and wireless readout demonstrated strong immunity to frequency drift, low noise, and sub-millisecond response time (< 1 ms). These results verify the feasibility of the dual-coil mutual-inductive architecture as a promising solution for continuous, non-invasive, and clinically practical IOP monitoring.

title: A Subcarrier-Level Digital Predistortion With Undersampled Feedback for Wideband OFDM Signals
authors: Mengyao Zhang, Zixuan Long, Tong Li, Wanzhi Ma, Qiang Xu, Ying Liu, Shihai Shao, Youxi Tang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: The signal bandwidths in current 5G new radio (NR) and future 6G millimeter-wave bands reach 400 MHz or higher, posing significant challenges for digital predistortion (DPD). Two key difficulties arise: the feedback path must operate at a higher sampling rate, and accurately modeling the nonlinear distortion of wideband signals becomes increasingly difficult. Leveraging the characteristics of orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) signals, this letter proposes a subcarrier-level DPD with undersampled feedback for wideband signals. The proposed method reconstructs the frequency-domain (FD) subcarriers before aliasing from the undersampled feedback signal, enabling subcarrier-level frequency-selective predistortion. The experimental results for a 300-MHz OFDM signal demonstrate that the proposed method effectively suppresses the power amplifier’s (PAs) nonlinearity and reduces the feedback sampling requirement.

title: Design and Simulation of Four-Pole Induction Motors for Premium, Super-Premium, and Ultra-Premium Efficiency
authors: Abhishek Kishor, Natesan Chokkalingam Lenin, Sathyanarayanan Nandagopal, Arjun Seshadri, A. Bharathi Sankar Ammaiyappan, Mohamed N. Ibrahim
publish: IEEE Canadian Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering
abstract: Environmental aspects are largely affected by power generation and consumption. The Indian economy is based on the agriculture sector, where electric motors play a vital role in this application as a pump. Induction motors with the International Efficiency (IE3) standard are in use at present, which lags in efficiency. Revitalizing these motors for the next generation is a paramount importance among researchers. Super-premium and ultra-premium (IE4 and IE5, respectively) motors are the way to go in these applications for reduced power consumption. This article provides the design aspects of those three motors with in-depth electromagnetic and thermal studies. The authors believe that this will lead the researchers and the industry designers to move beyond the requirements of the energy-efficient induction motors.

title: Dual Attention-Guided U-Net with Hybrid Loss for MRI Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Zhijing Shi, Yansu Hu, Yuanzheng Wang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To solve low segmentation accuracy in MRI brain tumor images—caused by irregular lesion morphology, blurred boundaries, and intra-class intensity heterogeneity—this paper proposes an improved U-shaped Network(U-Net). It integrates the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) into U-Net’s skip connections to enhance sensitivity to small tumor features. A joint supervision strategy, combining weighted cross-entropy loss and Dice loss, is designed. It balances sample weights and mitigates class imbalance among tumor subregions (enhancing tumor (ET), edema, necrotic core). Experiments on the BraTS2019 dataset show the model achieves average Dice scores of 0.8376 (ET),0.8259 (tumor core, TC), and 0.8896 (whole tumor, WT). This outperforms the baseline U-Net by 10.4%, 14.4%, and 1.99% respectively. Ablation studies confirm CBAM boosts small tumor detection sensitivity by 9.88%. In class-imbalanced scenarios, the joint loss increases training stability by 23.5%. This method resolves boundary ambiguity and class imbalance, offering a reliable solution for medical image analysis.

title: Structural Chunking: A Semantic-Structural Integrated Method for Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Sangyong Lee, NaHun Kim, Junseok Lee
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems rely heavily on the quality of document chunking, which determines the granularity and contextual continuity of retrievable units. Existing chunking methods inevitably trade off between semantic coherence and computational efficiency. To overcome this limitation, we propose Structural Chunking, a novel paradigm that integrates semantic cohesion with structural consistency by leveraging both surface- and physical-level document features. Unlike purely semantic methods, Structural Chunking quantifies structural patterns and fuses them with semantic embeddings to compute a semantic-structural cohesion score. Chunk boundaries are then detected where this composite distance sharply increases. Experiments on five BEIR benchmark datasets demonstrate that Structural Chunking achieves the most consistent recall and average precision across domains, outperforming semantic and statistical baselines while maintaining stable chunk-size distributions. The results indicate that incorporating structural hierarchy into the RAG preprocessing pipeline substantially enhances retrieval efficiency and contextual fidelity, suggesting a new direction for structure-aware information retrieval.

title: Advancements in IoT-Enabled Cardiac Risk Detection and Emergency Response: A Wearable ECG Monitoring System
authors: Parul Dubey, Pushkar Dubey, Manjushree Nayak, Vikas Kumar, Priti Nilesh Bhagat, Krupali Dhawle
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The object here for IoT in health’s scenario translates to being observed toward the goal of health, in real time. The latter is particularly critical for heart conditions, where early notice can literally mean the difference between life and death. Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) is still one of the top killers in human premature death. It is this latter fact that demands some real solution if we are going to be monitored outside of the hospital. Standard tracking systems are out of reach for the people who need them most, often in remote areas or underresourced regions such as a country or an unprofitable inner city. In this work, an experimental dataset of wearable ECG monitors in the smart glove with sensors is utilized. It's been able to monitor heart rates around the clock outside of a hospital, and in some cases where there is no doctor present at all. The main steps in the proposed procedure would be to gather data wirelessly into ECG sensors, perform real-time risk estimation at the edge and send (e.g., as Bluetooth message) its result for cloud processing backend. The uniqueness of our system is providing a community level emergency alerting system to the health care workers at risk with positions who are alerted in case of very high risk. Meanwhile, the reliability is guaranteed by evaluating performance measures such as detection accuracy, latency and energy consumption in this work. The results indicate that the proposed system yields high accuracy for detection and immediate response, and therefore constitute an efficient heart risk management tool in everyday life.

title: Cloud Computing-Integrated Load Balancing System for Scalable Web Services
authors: Y. V. R. Naga Pawan, Prashant Ankalkoti, Vikram Kaushik, Ranjithakala Kakollu, Nidal Al Said, S.B.G. Tilak Babu
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The paper introduces a Cloud Computing Integrated Load Balancing System of Scalable Web Services that helps to address the issues of dynamic workload management, latency and scalability of distributed environment. The suggested framework incorporates the Adaptive Kalman Filter tool to be used as a preprocessor to remove noise and create smooth workload data streams, whereas mRMR (Minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance) is used as an efficient tool to select the features and improve the model accuracy and lower the computational complexity. A Graph Attention Network is used as the fundamental classifier to model smartly the node interactions and dynamically allocate loads among cloud resources. This system is deployed and tracked on the Databricks Lakehouse platform with MLflow, which allows performing the deployment and tracking the performance in a scaled way. The experimental findings show that the throughput can be significantly improved, and the latency can be reduced and the energy consumption can be decreased with better results than in the traditional methods. The suggested framework provides a basis of intelligent, flexible, and power-efficient load balancing in contemporary cloud-based web service frameworks.

title: A 120–230GHz Low Phase Imbalance Asymmetric Marchand Balun in a SiGe BiCMOS Technology
authors: Daniele Ursini, Batuhan Sutbas, Habeeb Bello, Leonardo Pantoli, Giorgio Leuzzi, Corrado Carta
abstract: In this paper, a wideband low phase imbalance balun is presented. In this balun, the even- and odd-mode phase velocities are equalized by enhancing the odd-mode capacitance using three differential coupled-lines. It is shown that this significantly improves the phase and amplitude balance. This way, a very low phase imbalance of less than 2° and an amplitude imbalance of less than 1.5dB over a wide band of 120–230GHz are achieved in simulation. The proposed balun has been fabricated in a 130nm BiCMOS technology and characterized to validate the topology. The measured minimum insertion loss is 1.4dB and the return losses are better than 10dB in the whole band of interest with a good agreement with the simulations.

title: AI-Enhanced Blended Learning for Sustainability: Gen Z Perspectives on ESG Integration in University Education
authors: Tuyen Thi Bich Tran, Luan Trong Nguyen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: This study examines how AI-enhanced blended learning and sustainability values shape Generation Z students ‘support for integrating Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) principles into higher education. Using a quantitative approach with 200 valid responses from university students, data were analyzed through Cronbach’s Alpha, KMO. EFA, CFA, and SEM. The findings show that when students perceive AI supported online learning as effective, they report stringer blended learning experiences. Additionally, students with greater interest in sustainability exhibit higher ESG awareness, which in turn significantly increases support for ESG integration in university curricula. The results indicate that digital learning innovation and sustainability awareness interact to influence Gen Z attitudes toward responsible and future-oriented education. This study offers practical implications for universities seeking to use AI technologies and blended learning models to embed ESG principles, enhance student engagement, and foster sustainable mindsets in the digital era.

title: Dehazing Algorithm Selection System with Feature Extraction for Single Image
authors: Yuto Toyoshima, Keizo Miyahara
abstract: This paper proposes a selection system of dehaze-algorithm to apply an appropriate one for an input single image by means of feature extraction. It is known that the haze is one of the most critical challenges for camera image processing. In order to cope with the negative effect, a number of dehazing algorithms have been researched. Previous studies on both dehazing algorithms and feature descriptors were examined with the aim to select the most suitable algorithm for the input image based on the explicit indices of the image itself. The examined dehaze algorithms can be categorized in two groups: Image restoration based on physical model (GMRF, Optical filtering, DCP, Bayesian net, Pre-record data set) and Image improvement with image parameters (Wavelet, Retinex, High frequency enhancement, Histogram equalizing). The implemented system was validated through a series of object detection experiments using real-world hazy images. The results of the experiments confirmed the improvement of the evaluation metric, mAP, that depicts the effectiveness of the proposed system.

title: Research on the Influence of Wind and Sand Environment on the Breakdown Voltage of Wire-Tower Gap
authors: Yu Su, Zhitong Niu, Xiuyuan Yao, Xiaojun Zhang, Wenbing Zhuang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the in-depth implementation of China's "West-to-East Power Transmission" strategy, ultra-high voltage and extra-high voltage transmission networks are extending on a large scale to the western regions. To study the effect of sand and dust environment on the insulation properties of the wire-tower air gap of transmission lines, this paper builds a wind and sand environment simulation experiment platform, takes the 0.5m wire-tower gap as the research object, conducts DC breakdown experiments under different combinations of wind speed, sand and dust concentration, particle size, and load-mass ratio, and obtains the variation law of the average breakdown voltage of the gap. The experiment results show that the wind-sand environment has a limited effect on the DC breakdown voltage of the gap, and the changes in sand concentration, particle size and charge-to-mass ratio only cause slight voltage fluctuations. Finally, the promoting and suppressing effects of dust on discharge were explored in terms of photoionization, electric field distortion and electron capture of dust particles. The results can provide experimental basis and theoretical reference for the design of external insulation of transmission lines in sand-dust areas.

title: An End-to-End Framework for Voice-Driven Image Generation using ASR, NLP, and Diffusion Models
authors: Thatikonda Mahesh, Balne Hemanth, Gatla Saiteja, Yugandhar Manchala, Nirmal Keshari Swain
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The human brain processes visual information significantly faster than text, making image-based communication a powerful tool in human-computer interaction. While voice-based systems like Siri and Alexa have advanced speech recognition, directly converting voice into meaningful images remains an emerging and underexplored area. This paper presents an intelligent, end- to-end framework for voice-to-image generation that integrates deep learning and natural language processing models. The system first converts voice input to text using an advanced automatic speech recognition (ASR) model, Wav2Vec 2.0. The transcribed text is semantically analyzed using BERT or GPT-based models to extract descriptive and contextual features. These features are then processed by a diffusion-based image generation model to produce highfidelity visuals. A CLIP-guided feedback loop further ensures semantic alignment between the input voice and the generated image. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance over existing methods, with lower Word Error Rates (WER), improved Frechet Inception Distance (FID) scores, and higher semantic alignment. This work opens promising avenues for real-time voice-driven image generation in domains such as accessibility, creative design, and virtual storytelling.

title: AI For Wildlife Monitoring
authors: Aaryan Saharan, Bhavya Sharma, Harsh Sindhal, Ruksana, Naman Malhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Conservation of biodiversity demands effective wildlife monitoring, but conventional techniques are time-consuming and imprecise. This research compares AI-based computer vision models Fast R-CNN, YOLOv7 Tiny, and VGG19 for real-time wildlife detection and species identification. YOLOv7 Tiny is the most suitable for real-time monitoring, while VGG19 achieves high accuracy in species identification but is not suitable for real-time detection due to its high computational cost and slow inference speed. Fast R-CNN struggles with detecting small objects due to limitations in region proposal generation and feature extraction. Even with YOLOv7’s strong performance, further improvements using Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) and object segmentation can enhance accuracy. AI-based solutions provide scalable and automatic wildlife conservation, helping to protect species and combat poaching.

title: A SIW-Based Shared Aperture Beam-Steerable Antenna for Multiband Wireless Communications
authors: Md Abu Sufian, Niamat Hussain, Minyoung Song
abstract: This article presents a substrate-integrated-waveguide (SIW) based shared aperture antenna module with beam steering capabilities for modern multiband wireless communications. Initially, a 4-port antenna is designed for the 5.9 GHz V2X band (5.68 – 5.98 GHz), while the SIWs are used efficiently to isolate the antenna ports. These SIW yields an electrically unaffected area at the middle of the substrate, which allows to design additional radiating elements. An additional 4-port MIMO antenna for the 5G-NR (24.12 GHz – 32.7 GHz) communication and a Ku-band antenna for the satellite communication (11.2 – 12.1 GHz) is designed at the middle part of the substrate. The antenna occupied a very compact size of 44.5 × mm 44.5 mm, and both simulated and measured results show an excellent result including bandwidth, gain, and radiation efficiency. Moreover, by controlling the port excitation at both V2X band and 5G mmWave band a full 360° beam-steering can be achieved.

title: PQSR: A Speech Corpus of Polar Questions and Spontaneous Responses in Standard Chinese with Complex Intentions Annotated
authors: Yingyi Luo, Yue Huang, Qingke Sun, Shuwen Chen
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: To advance research of how communicative intentions are conveyed in conversations and how prosody plays a role, we created PQSR, a context-specific, intention-annotated speech corpus of polar-questions and responses in Standard Chinese. It consists of two subsets: Polar Question Production (PQP) with 103 native speakers posing polar questions in given contexts for information seeking or rhetorical expression, and Spontaneous Responses (SR) with 106 speakers' natural oral reactions to these questions. Data was collected using a combination of experimental and naturalistic designs, with participants recording themselves on their smartphones. Beyond phonetic annotations, we introduced a framework for classifying communicative intentions, focusing on the respondent's concerns regarding the questioner, along with a corresponding annotation system. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{1}$</tex>

title: Comparative Analysis of Marker Based and Markerless Motion Capture Systems for Shoulder Joint Angle Prediction
authors: Deepa Sri R, S Pravin Kmar, Saranya S, Kavitha A
abstract: Marker-based motion capture system (MCS) is the gold standard for analyzing human motion. But in the real world its usage in large-scale applications is limited by its inherent inaccuracy and practical difficulties. These real-world difficulties can be addressed with a marker-less motion capture system. However, its accuracy in quantifying joint Range of Motion (ROM) has not been verified across shoulder movements. In this study, we simultaneously captured marker less and marker-based motion data on six healthy participants performing shoulder abduction and adduction movements. Based on the results we calculated the RMSE value for abduction 0.80° and for adduction 0.683° between both the systems during each movement. The findings imply that the accuracy of the markerless Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) system in ROM measurement is comparable to that of the marker-based system. However, particularly when it comes to shoulder ROM measurements, the direction and positioning of the reflective markers of the OptiTrack system have a significant impact on measurement accuracy.

title: Design and Evaluation of an Event-Detection Model With Long Short-Term Memory Network in a Secured Internet of Things Environment
authors: G Vamsee Krishna, A Shanthipriya, Abdelhalim Mohammad Jubran, B Ramya, K Srinija, M Ramya
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: To detect, forecast, and represent features in real-time from the Internet of Things (IoT) as well as edge computing scenarios, we present the Evaluation of an EDM Using LSTM in a Secure IoT Environment (EDLSSI) model. This framework amalgamates edge deep learning to achieve real-time event detection, prediction, and feature representation in environmental and IoT contexts. The system is powered by an EventDetection Model (EDM) that employs correlation analysis to identify the factors that most influence events. Using the Gramian Angular Field (GAF) method, sensor data are transformed into pictures so that deep learning can be performed at the network edge. The model makes use of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, and also an ABiLSTM which improves prediction accuracy by considering long-range context and using an attention mechanism. The Grey Wolf Optimisation (GWO) is responsible for the fine-tuning of the ABiLSTM hyperparameters, and it mimics the hunting strategies of the wolves in a pack. A Residual Group Attention Network (RGA-Net) is implemented to raise the level of feature learning while the computational load is being kept at a minimum. The performance measures show an extraordinarily high overall accuracy of 98.57 %, leading to the correct classification of 1300 out of 1407 attack instances, which corresponds to a True Positive Rate (TPR) of 98.11 %. It also accurately identified 345 normal events, achieving a TPR of 97.18 %, with 10 instances misclassified as attacks, and a high precision for both attack and normal event classifications at 99.05 % and 93.21 % respectively. During training, the model achieved a precision of 97.0 %, a recall of 97.6 %, and an F1-score of 97.2 %, while testing results improved these to 98.9 % precision, 99.2 % recall, and an F1-score of 99.0 %. The AUC scores showed improvement from 97.6% in training to 99.2 % in testing. Accuracy reached 99 % between epochs 15 and 23. EDLSSI was able to obtain its peak performance metrics, the accuracy was 99.1 %, the precision was 98.7 %, the recall was 99.0 %, and the F1score was 98.9 %.

title: Deep Learning and Machine Learning Approaches for Pneumonia Detection: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Roshni Rathour, Pavan Kumar, Ujwal Hiranwar, Ritik Bhandarkar, Rohit Kasrewar, Aayushi Patle
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Pneumonia is a serious lung disease and can become severe if not treated early. Doctors usually use chest X-rays to detect signs of pneumonia, but manual examination can be time consuming and prone to errors. To support this, AI systems can be used to identify pneumonia faster and more accurately. These systems can analyze X-ray images and recognize pneu monia patterns automatically. Advanced methods enhance the performance of these systems by leveraging knowledge from other imaging tasks or focusing on the most critical regions of the image. Additionally, there are approaches to train these systems with minimal labeled data. Some tools can also highlight the exact lung area affected by pneumonia, providing more detailed insights to doctors. This paper reviews the latest advancements in computer assisted methods for pneumonia detection, highlighting effective techniques, existing challenges, and potential future improvements.

title: A Robust and Accurate Sleep Apnea Detection Framework Based on a K-band FMCW MIMO Radar
authors: Keke Zheng, Zhiwei Zhang, Jiayu Zhang, Liling Wang, Yijing Guo, Changzhan Gu
abstract: A sleep apnea detection framework based on FMCW MIMO radar is proposed for home health monitoring. The framework is composed of two key elements. The first leverages the characteristics of the FMCW MIMO radar architecture to form a cardiopulmonary activity beamformer, incorporating distance, azimuth and zenith angles for optimal chest positioning in various sleep postures. The second analyzes the correspondence between the radar signal waveform and airflow and belt signal from polysomnography (PSG), and a novel apnea detection algorithm is introduced to assess breathing events based on radar waveforms. To validate the proposed framework, a K-band 4T8R FMCW radar was designed, fabricated, and ceiling-mounted in a home scenario. Radar data were synchronously recorded with PSG for comparison. Various abnormal breathing events, including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), hypopnea, and central sleep apnea (CSA), were accurately detected, demonstrating the framework's feasibility and robustness for long-term home health monitoring applications.

title: FDA Beampattern Optimization with Nonlinear Frequency Offsets and Non-uniform Element Spacing
authors: Abdul Hadee, Ahmad Bilal, Sohom Bhattacharjee, Yash Hemant Shah, Choon Sik Cho, Pathipati Srihari
abstract: Recent advancements in Frequency Diverse Array (FDA) radar technology address the inherent range–angle coupling present in classical FDA systems, which arises from the introduction of small frequency offsets to the carrier frequency. Modern approaches use nonlinear frequency offsets to create dot-shaped beampatterns. This paper presents an efficient genetic algorithm (GA)-based co-optimization framework for FDA radar systems, simultaneously refining nonlinear frequency offsets and non-uniform array element spacing. The proposed approach systematically minimizes sidelobes and the half power beamwidth (HPBW), achieving beampattern decoupling and interference suppression superior to the recently reported results in literature. As a result, the peak sidelobe level (PSLL) of -8.3 dB with a narrow HPBW of 4.0 km in range and 5.0° in angle is achieved.

title: Certain Investigation on Solar Prediction Model using Machine Learning Mechanisms
authors: Mudit Khater, A. Rehash Rushmi Pavitra
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The accurate prediction of solar energy is one of the key focus areas for renewable energy research since it is crucial for planning and energy management optimization. This paper investigates the use of advanced machine learning techniques,which includes Scikit-Learn and TensorFlow, to predict solar energy output. Using a dataset that contains many climatic parameters, we trained and evaluated several models, such as neural networks, random forests and regression models.The comparison research demonstrates that deep learning models, particularly those constructed with TensorFlow, outperform traditional Machine learning models in terms of prediction accuracy. Because these models have the potential to capture a range of complex,non-linear correlations in the data, these models are a perfect fit for this use case.The study highlights the importance of feature selection and data preparation in improving the efficiency of machine learning models. The findings suggest that incorporating advanced machine learning algorithms into solar energy management systems could significantly increase forecast accuracy. This would enable more efficient planning and utilization of different solar resources. The results of the study provide a strong foundation for further investigation and useful solar energy forecasting applications. Additionally, this work contributes to the growing body of research demonstrating the ability of deep learning and machine learning models to accurately estimate renewable energy. By providing a comprehensive review of various machine learning techniques, this work advances the more general goal of sustainable energy development and paves the way for more advanced and accurate predictive models in the field of solar energy.

title: Reinforcement-Learning–Based Gait Generation Inspired by Penguin Walking With Attitude Stabilization
authors: Monako Toya, Jun Ishikawa
abstract: In this paper, a walking algorithm is proposed that reproduces an efficient gait through body sway and ankle joint rotation in a penguin-inspired link mechanism. In the proposed method, a control system stabilizes the penguin's attitude on an invariant manifold (equilibrium point) to prevent the penguin robot from falling over. The state feedback control was designed separately for the penguin robot's right and left legs during each stance, when one leg remains on the ground so that the control system can switch between left and right control depending on the body's tilt. Furthermore, reinforcement learning was performed using a penguin robot equipped with these control methods. Simulation results demonstrated that a stable stepping motion could be generated by employing posture stabilization control for fall avoidance. Additionally, the learning results showed that forward motion could be acquired from the stepping motion.

title: An Improved Auction Algorithm for Multi-Robot Task Allocation
authors: Kuang Jui Lim, Shalini Darmaraju, Choon-Hian Goh
abstract: The problem of task allocation in multi-robot systems (MRTA) is critical for optimizing performance in various applications, such as warehouse automation and search and rescue operations. Current algorithms often fail to consider real-life complexities like robot dynamics and energy consumption, leading to inefficiencies. This study aims to address these gaps by proposing improved versions of the auction algorithm (A) and the enhanced auction algorithm (EA), focusing on optimizing task allocation by considering task complexity and robot capabilities. The methodology involves using auction and extended auction algorithms as the backbone, with two improved algorithms proposed to enhance fairness and efficiency. An energy handling function is also incorporated. Six scenarios were simulated, involving 10, 15, and 25 robots with 100 and 200 tasks, respectively. The mean and standard deviation of completion times were computed to evaluate performance. Results indicate that the improved auction (IA) algorithm consistently outperforms the auction (A) algorithm, while the improved enhanced auction (IEA) algorithm generally performs better than the enhanced auction (EA) algorithm. For instance, in scenarios with 25 robots and 200 tasks, the standard deviation of A, IA, EA, and IEA is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$62.7 \mathrm{s}, 51.7 \mathrm{s}, 21.3 \mathrm{s}$</tex> and 20.5 s, respectively. A lower standard deviation indicates a better distribution. Additionally, the energy handling function significantly improved task allocation efficiency. In conclusion, our improved algorithms demonstrate better performance with the added energy handling function enhancing practical applicability, reducing the standard deviation of completion time by 42.2s (comparing A with IEA). Future work should address real-life robot dynamics and communication delays to further improve the system's efficiency and effectiveness.

title: Vision Transformers-Enabled Weed Detection System for Precision Farming Efficiency
authors: D. A. Shahakar, P. Subhashini, Mohan M, Ramya. D, S. Bathrinath, Rajendiran M
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper introduces a Vision Transformers-Enabled Weed Detection System that will be used to optimize the efficiency of precision farming. It takes advantage of recent developments in deep learning methods, such as Z-Score Normalization, which is used to preprocess the data and make input data easier to work with. Recursive Feature Elimination is used to select the features well hence minimizing the size of the dataset but still preserving the most important data. The type of classifier is Gradient Boosting Machine that, together with Vision Transformers, can be used to classify weeds and crops in agricultural images with high accuracy. The system is trained on TensorFlow and made to run in real-time on edge devices, which is efficient and scalable at detecting weeds in the real-world farming scenario. Experiments show that the proposed system has an accuracy of 92, which is much better than conventional techniques of CNN and SVM. This method has a good potential of improving the management of resources, minimize the use of pesticides, and enhance the sustainability of crop yield in precision farming.

title: Virtual Reality in Higher Art Education: Evaluating the Effects of an Immersive Web-Based Platform on Students’ Performance and Motivation
authors: Yongtian He, Nurul Nadwa Zulkifli, Ahmad Fauzi Mohd Ayub
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Interdisciplinary Computer Science and Engineering (ICICSE)
abstract: This study examines how a virtual reality (VR) learning platform can influence the achievement and motivation of undergraduate art students. The researcher developed a VR website called VirtuArt for an art appreciation course to make learning more immersive and engaging. Two classes from a public university in China took part in the study. The experimental group used VirtuArt, while the control group followed traditional teaching. Students’ performance and motivation were measured through standardized tests and questionnaires, and the data were analyzed using ANCOVA and MANCOVA. The results showed that students who used VirtuArt performed better and were more motivated than those who received conventional instruction. These findings suggest that VR technology can effectively improve learning in higher art education by increasing student engagement and learning outcomes.

title: 60 Gb/s Transimpedance Amplifiers with Emitter-Follower and Folded-Cascode Interstage Configurations in 22-nm FDSOI
authors: Mesut Inac, Volkan Erturk, Arzu Minareci Ergintav, Aniello Franzese, Batuhan Sutbas, Corrado Carta
abstract: This paper compares two transimpedance amplifiers (TIAs) in 22-nm FDSOI technology, employing emitter-follower and folded-cascode interstage topologies. The designs consume 64.8mW and 61.5mW, achieving transimpedance gains of 54.5 dBΩ and 51.5 dBΩ, respectively. Both show output return losses above 10 dB up to 65 GHz and input-referred noise figures of $6.7{\text{pA}}/\sqrt {{\text{Hz}}} $ and $26.5{\text{pA}}/\sqrt {{\text{Hz}}} ,$ respectively. While both support 60 Gb/s data rates, the emitter-follower TIA demonstrates superior noise performance, gain, and bandwidth. Eye diagram measurements validate the designs against the state-of-the-art benchmarks. For future electro-optic transceivers, the emitter-follower resistive feedback topology emerges as the preference in 22-nm FDSOI, given similar design effort, thanks to its enhanced noise performance.

title: Comparative Study Integrating the Vulnerability to Forest Fire and Landslide Using GIS and Python Based Approach
authors: Vidhya Lakshmi Sivakumar, Anand Raju
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Owing to its precipitous slopes, heavy monsoon rainfall, and increasing human encroachment, the Nilgiris district situated in Tamil Nadu's Western Ghats is susceptible to frequent landslides and wildfires. Utilizing GIS and Python-based analytical methods, this preliminary investigation offers a comparative assessment of landslide and forest fire susceptibility. Datasets from MODIS fire sites, SRTM DEM, Landsat8/9, and rainfall correlation models were used to provide slope, NDVI, and elevation features. Python module based rasterio, Numpy, Scikit-learn was used to analyze and assess the normalized raster layers to provide the initial susceptibility indicators. An elevation-slope correction value of r=0.46 and a vegetation-slope correlation coefficient of r=0.68 were found by statistical analysis, suggesting that topographic and vegetation stress factors are important in the occurrence of the hazards. According to the thermal response, roughly 53.1% of the Nilgiris as per the study area is classified as having fire risk and 67.9% of the territory is classified as being in landslide susceptibility zone. The results show how Geo-AI based spatial modelling may enhance risk management and encourage sustainable land-use planning in mountainous areas, while also offering preliminary insights into multihazard interactions in the Nilgiris.

title: Low-Cost Lightweight 3D-Printed Luneburg Lenses Enabling Both Wide Angular and Long Distance Coverage for Radio Applications (Invited paper)
authors: Jun Xu, Wei Hong, Kai Chen, Yuechao Wang
abstract: The emergence of additive manufacturing technology, e.g., 3D printing, etc., has accelerated the research on Luneburg lenses, since this processing technology can offer greater design freedom and flexibility, facilitating the realization of high-performance Luneburg lenses more efficiently. In this talk, two design example concerning 3D printed Luneburg lenses will be presented, i.e., diamond-lattice-structure-inspired Luneburg lens and hybrid 2D beam scanning based on phased array and 3D-printed cylinder Luneburg lens. Both design procedures and performance validation will be indicated in this presentation. The experimental results of these two design examples confirm the feasibility and exhibit the merits as well as potential applications of this technique.

authors: Xuejing Yang, Yongsik Jeong, Kiwon Lee, WanSoo Park, SuMin Choi, DaeHyun Kim, Kyounghoon Yang
abstract: In this work, we present a 0.6 µm gate-length (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">g</inf>) AlGaN/GaN high-electron mobility transistor (HEMT) on a SiC substrate that achieves a maximum oscillation frequency (f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf>) of 80.3 GHz, corresponding to a high f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> × L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">g</inf> product of 48.2 GHz·µm at V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ds</inf> = 15 V, which is one of the highest values reported up to date for GaN HEMTs.
