The device, with a gate width of 2x50 µm and gate height of 420nm, demonstrates a peak drain current of 853.6 mA/mm and a peak transconductance of 217.5 mS/mm. Small-signal modeling yields R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">g</inf> = 0.11 Ω·mm, R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ds</inf> = 295 Ω·mm, and C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">gs</inf>/C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">gd</inf> = 22.4. The results highlight the physical mechanisms driving RF performance and provide insights into structural optimization for enhanced RF performance of GaN HEMTs for micro-/millimeter-wave applications.

title: A GNSS Positioning Enhancement Method Driven by Graph Neural Network-Based NLOS Recognition in Complex Urban Environments
authors: Qianming Wang, Kungan Zeng, Zhenni Li, Wuhui Chen, Shengli Xie, B.T.G.S. Kumara, Duminda R. Welikanna
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: In urban environments, Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) positioning is highly susceptible to Non-Line-ofSight (NLOS) errors, resulting in severe degradation of positioning accuracy. GNSS positioning accuracy depends not only on the precision of the observations but also on the spatial geometry of visible satellites, which is commonly quantified by the Position Dilution of Precision (PDOP). Satellites with higher PDOP contributions play a crucial role in improving geometric structure and overall accuracy. However, existing NLOS mitigation approaches mainly focus on removing or deweighting NLOS signals while overlooking the influence of satellite geometry. In dense urban areas, the deterioration of geometric distribution often has a greater impact on positioning accuracy than signal quality, leading to amplified errors and reduced reliability. To address these issues, this paper proposes a stochastic model optimization method driven by intelligent NLOS recognition, in which a Graph Neural Network (GNN) is employed for NLOS signal recognition to jointly enhance GNSS positioning performance. The GNN model extracts environmental and spatial features from sky-view images to achieve accurate NLOS signal recognition. Based on these recognition results, a stochastic model optimization strategy is designed to dynamically adjust the observation weights of NLOS signals according to both signal quality and geometric contribution to PDOP. The proposed framework is integrated into single-point positioning and validated using dynamic datasets collected in Guangzhou city and German cities. Experimental results demonstrate that the GNN model achieves an NLOS recognition accuracy exceeding 80%, while the optimized stochastic model surpasses traditional empirical models, improving positioning accuracy by 28.15%, $12.63 \%, 60.78 \%$, and 44.43% in the north, east, vertical, and 3D components, respectively. These results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method and provide a promising solution for robust GNSS positioning in complex urban environments.

title: A Low-Power TSPC-PRBS Generator in 12 nm FinFET Bulk CMOS
authors: Kai Scheller, Konstantin Vilyuk, Philip Hetterle, Jonas Weninger, Andre Engelmann, Robert Weigel, Albert-Marcel Schrotz, Norman Franchi
abstract: This paper presents a non-primitive pseudo-random binary sequence (PRBS) generator for sensing application, implemented using ten true single-phase clock (TSPC) flip-flops (FF) configured as a linear feedback shift register (LFSR). The feedback is applied after the tenth and ninth FF using an exclusive OR (XOR) operation, resulting in a shortened sequence length of 889. The PRBS circuit is implemented in a 12 nm FinFET bulk technology, occupying a core area of 22 µm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. It operates at a maximum data rate of 20 GBit/s with a supply voltage of 0.8 V. The total power consumption of the breakout circuit, including support circuitry is 3.52 mW. Whilst the the LFSR core power consumption is 0.72 mW. The PRBS achieves a figure of merit (FoM) of 3.67 fJ/bit based on the maximum data rate and power consumption.

title: Mutual Coupling Reduction in Dual-Band MIMO Antenna using DGS and SRR for Wi-Fi 7 Band Applications
authors: Loveta Ramyhaidar Winaryo, Catur Apriono, Fitri Yuli Zulkifli
abstract: This paper presents a mutual coupling reduction technique for a four-element dual-band MIMO microstrip antenna using a defected ground structure (DGS) and split-ring resonator (SRR). The DGS consists of a narrow slot etched along the feedline path of each antenna element. At the same time, the SRR is positioned between the antenna elements to suppress surface wave propagation and near-field coupling. The proposed structure achieves over 3 dB improvement in isolation, reducing mutual coupling from –16.53 dB to below –20 dB. This enhancement leads to improved radiation performance across the Wi-Fi 7 operating bands. The proposed antenna is fabricated and experimentally validated, making it a promising candidate for high-performance MIMO systems in next-generation wireless communications.

title: A Compact Dual-Band UWB Antenna with Coplanar Waveguide Feed
authors: Yiming Cui, Ying Qie
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel dual-band microstrip antenna fed by a coplanar waveguide (CPW), designed with integrated parasitic elements to excite multiple resonant modes effectively. The proposed configuration not only enables dual-band operation but also significantly broadens the impedance bandwidth. The antenna features a compact footprint of 36 mm × 28 mm × 1.6 mm and leverages a co-planar topology—where both the radiating patch and ground plane reside on the same substrate layer—to achieve a low profile and facilitate seamless integration into modern RF systems. Experimental results demonstrate excellent impedance matching across the 2–6 GHz spectrum, with distinct resonant frequencies at 3.5 GHz and 5.5 GHz. This design fully covers the 5 GHz WiFi band and partially accommodates the satellite C-band, positioning it as a highly promising candidate for next-generation wireless and satellite communication applications.

title: Generative Adversarial Deception Networks (GADN): Self-Evolving AI for Adaptive Cyber Defense in Cloud-Native Security Architectures
authors: Anjani kumar Polinati
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Generative Adversarial Deception Networks (GADN) introduces a new idea of adapting to different cyber defense within the cloud-native platform through the use of self-evolving artificial intelligence systems. The framework integrates the principles of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with deception-based security in order to provide a smart, self-enhancing security architecture. GADN architecture This involves two co-evolving agents, namely; red agent and blue agent: the red agent, as an adversarial agent, simulates adversarial attacks, spawns attack vectors, and the blue agent is a dynamically adapting agent that neutralizes perceptual threats through the use of deceptive countermeasures that include, but are not limited to, marking decoys, moving targets, and policy manipulations. To keep improving its defense operations, the learning loop supports the blue agent to engage in reinforcement learning (RL) and imitation learning to continuously update its defense protocols, and digital twin environment allows testing security activity with highfidelity. This self-driving, cloud native platform increases the capabilities to predict, hedge and adapt to advanced attacks, giving a proactive, adaptive and resilient security posture in the dynamic cloud environments.

title: A Study on Intelligent Question-Answering Methods Based on Power Training Knowledge Graphs
authors: Shikun Zhang, Jie Jiang, Qianyi Lei, Chang Liu, Weixian Zeng
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Against the backdrop of growing demand for intelligent question-answering in power training, this study proposes a knowledge graph-based intelligent Q&A method. By constructing a knowledge graph for the power training domain, we designed a Q&A framework encompassing question understanding, answer generation, and multi-turn dialogue management. This approach effectively addresses accuracy and interactivity challenges in specialized knowledge Q&A for power training, offering a novel technical pathway for intelligent power training.

title: Design of SIW Filters Based on Circuit Model Extraction
authors: Li Zhang, Yingjie Wang, Chunxia Zhou
abstract: This paper presents a novel method for designing substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) filters by extracting equivalent circuits model from simulated Y-parameters. Calculation formulas for the equivalent circuit parameters of second-order SIW filters are derived and subsequently extended to Nth-order configurations. This technique is successfully applied to parameter extraction in two HMSIW filter designs and a fourth-order QMSIW filter incorporating both cross-coupling and mixed coupling. For demonstration, a 25.9 GHz fourth-order QMSIW filter incorporating cross-coupling and mixed coupling is designed, fabricated, and measured. This method operates without requiring prior knowledge of center frequency (CF) or bandwidth, demonstrating its broad applicability to filters of arbitrary order and diverse topological structures.

title: Crowdsourced Geospatial Cellular Data and Fuzzy Rule-Based Inference for Optimizing Network Selection and Radio Coverage Mapping in Maritime Operating Zones
authors: Maria Gemel B. Palconit, Rau Lance Cunanan, Mary Nathaline Sevilla, Gabriel Valenzuela, Jayson C. Jueco, Jonathan Maglasang
abstract: Reliable and adaptive wireless communication is critical for Maritime Autonomous Vehicles (MAVs) operating in hybrid land-sea environments. This study proposes an intelligent framework that integrates crowdsourced cellular geodata with fuzzy logic inference to optimize mobile network selection and radio technology mapping across maritime zones. Using publicly available OpenCellID data, k-means clustering was applied to stratify cell tower distributions and determine radio-type availability in key land and offshore locations. Then a fuzzy inference system (FIS) was developed to assess the preference of the mobile network operator and predict the optimal radio technologies, GSM, UMTS, or LTE, based on signal strength, tower proximity, sample density, and location priority. Visualization techniques, including geospatial graphs, surface response maps, and signal overlays, were used to validate the FIS outputs. The results show that Smart (MNC 3) is the top choice of operators due to its strong coverage of LTE at ground stations and reliable UMTS access in maritime areas. This radio mapping is an important reference point for creating adaptable data routing strategies, which are crucial to maintaining efficient low-power communications with MAVs that can handle delays. This approach contributes to a scalable, data-driven methodology to enhance wireless communication reliability in maritime Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

title: Cavity Resonance–Enabled WPT Using Dual–Axis Orthogonal Power Receivers
authors: Ayumu Omae, Kawai Ryui, Masaya Tamura
abstract: In this study, we propose a compact dual–axis orthogonal differential receiver for higher-order modes with multi-axis electric fields. It consists of two L-shaped elements, each comprising a 20 × 20 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> FR–4 patch on a 15 mm copper pole, with the poles joined at a 90° angle and unified into one port via a T–junction for rectifier integration. Electromagnetic analysis with two-variable sweeping was used to optimize the receiver parameters for maximum efficiency. Compared with single-axis receivers, the proposed design achieved a 13.6 pt improvement in average RF–RF efficiency and a notable reduction in spatial variation. A 914.3 MHz, 1 W transmission test demonstrated power transfer efficiencies ranging from 14% to a maximum of 68.5% across 14 measurement points, showing good agreement with the analysis and confirming stable multi-axis power reception under higher-order modes. The design is well suited for IoT devices for smart factories owing to its compactness and low component count.

title: Resilient Infrastructure Design: Integrating AI for Enhanced Disaster Preparedness and Response
authors: Vinayakan, Amitava Sil, Paniteja Madala, Nandan N Shenoy, Amshith Kumar M J, Manu Vijay
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Resilient infrastructure is more important than ever as the frequency and intensity of natural and manmade disasters rise. In order to improve catastrophe preparedness, response, and recovery, this article investigates the incorporation of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into infrastructure design. Infrastructure systems can be made more flexible and sensitive to new risks by utilizing AI technologies like machine learning, predictive analytics, and real-time data processing. The paper focusses on important uses of AI, such as autonomous reaction processes, dynamic risk assessment, and early warning systems. It also looks at how AI can speed up recovery efforts both during and after disasters and enable more effective resource allocation. In order to build infrastructure that not only survives shocks but also learns and changes from each incident, a multidisciplinary strategy integrating engineering, data science, and emergency management is suggested. To illustrate the real-world advantages and difficulties of this integration, case studies of AI-enabled disaster response systems in utility networks, transportation, and urban planning are examined. The necessity of ethical considerations, openness, and strong data governance while implementing AI for catastrophe resilience is emphasized in the paper's conclusion. This study adds to the continuous endeavours to use intelligent infrastructure design to create communities that are safer, smarter, and more sustainable.

title: A Practice-Driven Framework for Transitioning Drive-by-Wire to Autonomous Driving Systems: A Case Study With a Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid Vehicle
authors: Dada Zhang, Chun-Hsing Ho, Md Ruman Islam, Pei-Chi Huang
abstract: Transitioning from a Drive-by-Wire (DBW) system to a fully autonomous driving system (ADS) involves multiple stages of development and demands robust positioning and sensing capabilities. This paper presents a practice-driven framework for facilitating the DBW-to-ADS transition using a 2022 Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid Minivan equipped with cameras, LiDAR, GNSS, and onboard computing hardware configured with the Robot Operating System (ROS) and Autoware.AI. The implementation showcases offline autonomous operations utilizing pre-recorded LiDAR and camera data, point clouds and vector maps, enabling effective localization and path planning within a structured test environment. The study addresses key challenges encountered during the transition, particularly those related to wireless-network-assisted sensing and positioning. It offers practical solutions for overcoming software incompatibility constraints, sensor synchronization issues, and limitations in real-time perception. Furthermore, the integration of sensing, data fusion, and automation is emphasized as critical factors to supporting autonomous driving systems in map generation, simulation, and training. Overall, the transition process outlined in this work aims to provide actionable strategies for researchers pursuing DBW-to-ADS conversion. It offers direction for incorporating real-time perception, GNSS-LiDAR-camera integration, and fully ADS-equipped autonomous vehicle operations, thus contributing to the advancement of robust autonomous vehicle technologies.

title: Length-of-Stay Prediction with Data Fusion and Masked Language Modeling
authors: Hieu Ngo, Chau Vo
abstract: Length of Stay (LOS) prediction plays a pivotal role in efficient healthcare resource management, optimization of care quality, and reduction of treatment costs. One of the key challenges in this domain is the complexity of processing unstructured long clinical notes containing sensitive information. Moreover, limitations persist in effectively processing long texts and integrating multiple information sources. This paper therefore proposes a method integrating two medical data sources: structured demographic and admission data, unstructured long clinical notes. Both can be then transformed into a unified text input. This data combination simultaneously leverages quantitative information from tabular data (demographic and initial admission information) and rich supplementary information from clinical notes (medical history, detailed symptoms, etc.), providing a more comprehensive picture of patient condition and improving prediction performance. Additionally, the paper proposes applying masked language modeling to enhance the ModernBERT model to create more effective general representations of entire patient texts compared to traditional approaches that rely solely on BERT. Evaluated on MIMIC-III data, our resulting Ad-ModernBERT model can yield better LOS predictions consistently in many experiments.

title: Personalising AI-Generated Jokes: an Empirical Study
authors: Ally Tze-Rou Teh, Xiao Ying Toh, Chai Xuen Seow, Tazeek bin Abdur Rakib, Lay-Ki Soon
abstract: This paper presents our investigation of the potential of generative AI in crafting personalised humour, focusing on how user-specified keywords and demographic information can guide joke generation. We introduce a two-part system: (1) a personalised joke generator built using GPT-3 that tailors humour based on keywords and user demographics (age, gender, continent), and (2) an automated joke ranking pipeline powered by fine-tuned BERT models to filter and prioritise high-quality, humorous content, trained on Reddit-sourced joke data. To evaluate the effectiveness and reception of the generated jokes, we conducted a human-centered evaluation involving 32 participants with diverse personality profiles. Evaluators rated the jokes across four humour dimensions: Funniness, Offensiveness, Surprise, and Reality Representation. Our findings reveal notable variations in humour perception across personality types based on MBTI. For instance, Sentinels responded more positively to the generated jokes, while Analysts tended to rate them lower across most categories. Additionally, a strong correlation between perceived funniness and surprise highlights the role of unexpectedness in humour appreciation. These results underscore the importance of personality-aware humour generation and suggest that current AI models require further refinement to effectively cater to diverse audiences.

title: Fuzzy PID and Sparrow Search Algorithm Integrated Control Method for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor
authors: Kexin Xu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To address the dynamic performance and robustness of permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) speed control systems under load disturbances, this paper proposes a fuzzy PID control strategy optimized by the Sparrow Search Algorithm (SSA). A simulation model of the motor control system is established, with a reference speed of 800 rad/s and a 3 N•m load disturbance applied at 0.7 s. The proposed SSA-optimized fuzzy PID controller is compared with conventional PID control in terms of three-phase current, electromagnetic torque, and speed response. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to conventional PID control, the SSA-fuzzy PID reduces startup overshoot from 25% to 15%, decreases speed fluctuation caused by load disturbance by 40%, lowers torque ripple by 52%, and shortens recovery time by 50%. The proposed method effectively suppresses current and torque ripples, significantly enhancing the system’s dynamic response and disturbance rejection capability, thereby verifying its superiority for high-performance motor control applications.

title: A 130-GHz High-Power Fundamental Oscillator in 28-nm CMOS Technology
authors: Jeongho Baek, Yeongmin Jang, Jinho Jeong
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This article presents a high power fixed-frequency oscillator operating D-band (110-170 GHz) implemented with $28-\mathrm{nm}$ CMOS technology. To achieve high output power, a fundamental-frequency oscillator topology was adopted. Based on a common-source (CS) amplifier configuration, the optimal oscillation frequency ($f_{\text {osc }}$) was determined through small-signal analysis at the gate and source terminals, while the optimum output condition was derived from large-signal load-pull simulations at the drain terminal. The overall design was carried out by combining these analyses.

title: A Systematic Literature Review of Visualization in Code Clone Detection Models
authors: Nur Fatin Syahidah Mohd Zamri, Al-Fahim Mubarak Ali, Aziman Abdullah, Siti Salwani Yaacob
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Interdisciplinary Computer Science and Engineering (ICICSE)
abstract: Code clones, which are instances of the same code segments copied in a software system, are created by developers for a variety of purposes. Code duplication is frequently brought on by programmers’ efficiency-seeking tendencies, which lead them to use copy-paste methods to speed up coding work. Numerous studies have proposed code clone visualization approaches to reduce code snippet replication and manage clone occurrences effectively. Visualization helps developers understand and avoid having duplicate code segments in software systems by giving them visual representations. Thus, in order to improve developers’ comprehension and stop the replication of code fragments, the present study provides a comprehensive evaluation of visualization approaches addressing code clone occurrences. The purpose of this study is to provide a systematic literature review of current code clone visualization approaches. The review and results of the study are presented, along with recommendations for further research projects that will enhance the current code clone visualization approaches.

title: A Beamwidth Controllable and Switchable Transmitarray Antenna
authors: Shizhe Xu, Rundong Zhang, Zhenghuan Wei, Yizhu Shen
abstract: This paper presents a transmitarray antenna (TA). It can achieve beamwidth control and switching. Beamwidth control means that the proposed TA can generate a flat-top beam with the desired beamwidth. Beamwidth switching means that by mechanically adjusting the position of the feed, the beamwidth of the electromagnetic (EM) wave radiated by the proposed TA can be altered. The proposed TA has the advantage that beamwidth control does not rely on iterative optimization process in phase compensation and beamwidth switching does not need active devices and control structure. A TA prototype is analyzed, simulated, fabricated, and measured. The proposed TA prototype can achieve 2D flat-top beam with a 3-dB beamwidth of 40°. By moving the feed closer to the TA, the beamwidth can be decreased to below 20°. Meanwhile, the operation band of the proposed TA fully covers from 24 to 28 GHz.

title: Uncovering Inter-Agent Relationships in UAV Swarms Using Trajectory Data
authors: Meixuan Jade Li, Qiting Liu, Xianqiang Zhu, Cheng Zhu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms typically consist of a large number of agents coordinated through various control paradigms, such as hierarchical, centralized, and master-slave architectures. In large-scale deployments, UAV swarms may further organize into multiple subgroups with distinct behavioral roles. In this paper, we propose inferring interaction relationships among UAVs in a swarm using trajectory data without prior knowledge of control protocols. First, we dynamically segment the trajectory sequences using the Minimum Description Length (MDL) criterion. Subsequently, we construct a cross-lagged panel network (CLPN) for each segment to model temporal dependencies and directional influences between agents, thereby identifying potential causal or leader-follower relationships. Finally, we perform community detection on the inferred networks to uncover latent group structures within the swarm. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high accuracy, effectively capturing the underlying interaction patterns and group structures within UAV swarms.

title: Latency-Aware Load Management in Cognitive VANETs via Hybrid Grey Wolf–Differential Evolution Optimization
authors: G D Vignesh, Rakesh J, A M Balamurugan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs) are the basic building blocks of the intelligent transport system as they provide real-time communication between vehicles and infrastructure. Nevertheless, in urban settings where the node density and mobility rates are growing, there are extreme latency and load balancing challenges, as well as spectrum usage. The present paper is a proposal of a Latency-Aware Load Management architecture of Cognitive VANETs implemented with a hybrid model of a metaheuristic Latency-Aware Load Manager (Grey Wolf Optimizer-Differential Evolution (GWO-DE)). The vehicles have cognitive radios that do dynamic spectrum sensing to adjust their communication strategies depending on the real time conditions of the traffic. The suggested methodology is a multi-objective optimization problem, in which the end-to-end latency is minimized, the load is distributed to roadside units (RSUs) and the packets are delivered. An ad hoc latency parameter is created involving end to end delay, queue length, and ratio of packet loss, which dictates offloading as well as channel allocation. The hybrid GWO-DE solution combines the global exploration capabilities of the Grey Wolf Optimization and the adaptive mutation abilities of Differential Evolution to give a powerful answer to dynamic network problems. The outcomes of the simulation prove that the suggested GWO-DE model is superior to the conventional approaches such as PSO, GWO, and DE. The suggested system is characterized by a mean packet delivery accuracy of 95.89% and minimal end-to-end latency by up to 30 and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$18-22 {\%}$</tex> energy saving, respectively, when using higher node densities. This shows its scalability, flexibility and energy efficiency in next-generation VANET applications. The suggested system will provide low-latency and reliable communication needed in safety critical vehicular applications within smart cities and autonomous driving ecosystems.

title: An Investigation of the Low-Power Capability of SiGe HBTs in V-Band LNA Design
authors: Xin Xu, Jens Wagner, Frank Ellinger
abstract: This paper investigates the low-power potential of SiGe HBTs in V-band low noise amplifier(LNA) designs. An LNA consisting of a single-stage cascode circuit has been designed in the IHP 130nm SiGe technology. Different biasing conditions of the transistors have been investigated to find the optimum for low-power, low-noise and high-gain operation. The current density has been chosen to achieve a proper balance between the gain and noise performance. To minimize the DC power, the supply voltage has been chosen to be the lowest required to ensure sufficient gain and noise figure. The device dimensions of the LNA have been determined to enable a low-loss broadband input matching by solely using a single series inductor. The designed LNA achieves a minimum noise figure of 2.4dB under a nominal supply voltage of 0.6V. The noise figure on average is 2.8dB from 54GHz to 67GHz. At the nominal supply voltage, the LNA consumes only 1.4mW DC power and provides a gain of around 14dB and a bandwidth of 7.3GHz.

title: Ensuring Data Deletion in the Cloud: Methods, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Shanmuga Raja B, Vivekrabinson K
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: With the exponential adoption of cloud computing, the amount of digital data stored in the cloud is estimated to surpass 200 zettabytes by 2030. The assurance provided in terms of verified and safe data deletion is the biggest challenge in terms of client privacy and the working efficiency. The work presented here provides the list of methods available for data deletion in cloud surroundings. The common methods like logical deletion, overwriting, cryptographic erasure, third policydriven deletion, the physical destruction in addition with the latest technologies including blockchain based verification are used. The major real-world issues happened in Google and Meta are the examples to suggest the risks employed in the improper deletion. The effectiveness, efficiency, advantages and the disadvantages of the current available methods are discussed and the real-world challenges in the cloud computing are analyzed with the help of blockchain based verification and life cycle automation.

title: A Novel Reflection Wave Decomposition Method Using Voltage-Controlled Voltage Source (VCVS) for Signal Integrity Analysis
authors: Seonghi Lee, Dongryul Park, Sanguk Lee, Seunghun Ryu, Hyunwoo Kim, Hyunsik Kim, Duksoo Kim, Seungyoung Ahn
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel reflection wave decomposition method using voltage-controlled voltage source (VCVS) for advanced signal integrity (SI) analysis. We exploit VCVS characteristics to actively control the termination reflection coefficient and extract specific reflection components from time-domain transmission (TDT) waveforms. Existing approaches either oversimplify R–C reflections or require long channels with well-separated phenomena. By varying channel impedance and delay, we demonstrate the proposed method’s capability to decompose complex reflection waveforms under single-loading conditions. Results confirm accurate decomposition across diverse scenarios. While multi-loading environments introduce further complexity, their investigation is reserved for future work.

title: U-Net Convolutional Networks for Real-Time Biomedical Image Segmentation and Anomaly Detection
authors: B. Murugesakumar, Aakash S, A Arunmanikandan, M Chithra, M Dhasaranjan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: A medical image analysis task, such as biomedical image segmentation, and anomaly detection, are the foundations of medical image analysis applications such as tumor localization, organ border delineation, and retinal disease screening. Our recommendation is to use a U-Net-based convolutional neural network to detect anomalies and segment biomedical images in real-time. The encoder-decoder architecture with skip links gives the possibility of highlevel feature representation and also preserving the spatial information. Robustness is enhanced by data augmentation, drop out regularization and batch normalization. The framework was trained and tested on benchmark data, such as ISBI (cell tracking), DRIVE (retinal vascular segmentation) and BraTS (brain tumor). The experimental outcomes show that the performance of the segmentation is good; Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) is 96.27, the Jaccard Index is 93.81, its Precision is 95.44 and Recall is 94.63. A side variational autoencoder with an AUC score of 0.982 and 95.68 % accuracy is employed to identify anomalies. With the example of an NVIDIA RTX 3090, it takes the model only 42 ms to operate on an image, showing almost real-time performance. The proposed U-Net has better segmentation results of 3-5 percent and reduced inference time by 18 percent against state-of-the-art and traditional CNN methods. Since DSC can be reduced by up to 7 % by removing the hybrid anomaly detection module and skip connections, ablation studies confirm their importance. These findings indicate the reliability and scalability of UNet based architectures to biological image analysis in real time. Through effective segmentation and efficient anomaly-detecting, the proposed system demonstrates high potentials in helping to make automated clinical decisions.

title: Quad-polarized Wideband Magnetoelectric Dipole Antenna with Integrated Heatsink and Transmit/Receive Module Using PlutoSDR
authors: Gong Chen, Jingxiang Wang, Yuyang Chen, Koen Mouthaan
abstract: A quad-polarized wideband active magnetoelectric dipole antenna with integrated heatsink and active transmit/receive modules is presented. The antenna, with the active transmit/receive modules integrated at its back side, acts as heatsink using metallic structures made with computer numerical control (CNC) machining technology. By integrating antenna and heatsink functionality, the increase in temperature, due to power dissipation in the transmit/receive modules, is reduced. Horizontal and vertical polarization are realized. Circular polarizations can also be attained in the digital domain by changing the amplitude and phase of the two orthogonal linear polarized channels using the ADALM-PLUTO software defined radio platform.

title: SwitchMix: Switching Dual-Level Mix Teacher for Domain Adaptive Thermal Object Detection
authors: Minsik Kim, Dinh Phat Do, Changjun Ahn, Wonjun Hwang
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Domain adaptation for object detection tasks typically focus on visible-spectrum domains. However, transferring knowledge from RGB to thermal infrared (TIR) images remains challenging due to significant domain discrepancies. To address this challenge, we propose SwitchMix, a dual-level mixedteacher framework designed to progressively narrow the crossmodality discrepancy for unsupervised thermal object detection. The proposed method integrates image-level and sample-level domain mixing to align modality specific spectral and semantic representations, while a teacher-student paradigm gradually shifts supervision from RGB to thermal domains. By periodically activating two complementary teachers, the model assimilates both local and global domain knowledge. Experiments on the FLIR and KAIST datasets demonstrate SwitchMix consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art unsupervised domain adaptation approaches in both accuracy and robustness. These results highlight the potential of SwitchMix as a generalizable domain adaptation solution for applications such as autonomous driving, defense systems, and intelligent surveillance.

title: Accent Conversion: Preserving Speaker Identity in Native English Synthesis
authors: Sabyasachi Chandra, Puja Bharati, Debolina Pramanik, Shyamal Kumar Das Mandal, Riya Sil
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: This paper introduces an advanced system for Accent Conversion (AC) that enhances the transformation of nonnative English speech to a native-accented equivalent while meticulously preserving the speaker's unique identity. Integrating a Speaker Encoder, an Accent Encoder, and a Voice Conversion model, our system enables real-time accent conversion with minimal processing delays. Unlike traditional AC methods which require native-accented input and suffer from lengthy processing times, our approach operates independently of native utterances, leveraging recent advances in speaker-independent phonetic posteriorgrams for accent conversion. Trained on an extensive dataset encompassing a diverse range of non-native and native English accents, our model proficiently captures intricate phonetic and prosodic nuances, thus facilitating highly accurate native accent synthesis. The proposed system is distinguished by its operational immediacy and reduced computational demands, rendering it a viable solution for immediate application scenarios.

title:
Synergistic Enhancement of Flame Retardancy and Mechanical Properties in Epoxy Composites with Mg(OH)
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    and Acicular Wollastonite
authors: Xin Zhou, YuShun Zhao, Ciyao Wang, Jian Zhao, Hao Shen, Yu Zhao
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Epoxy composites are widely used as insulating media in the field of electrical equipment. Excellent flame retardancy and mechanical strength are essential to ensure the normal operation of electrical equipment under extreme conditions. This study aims to synergistically enhance the flame retardancy and mechanical strength of epoxy composites. A hybrid approach incorporating magnesium hydroxide as a flame retardancy and wollastonite fibers as a reinforcing agent was employed to fabricate the epoxy composites. The results indicate that the modified epoxy composite achieved a flame retardancy rating of V-0. The optimal overall performance was observed when the wollastonite fiber content was 10 wt%, yielding a tensile strength of 44.64 MPa, a flexural strength of 66.41 MPa, and an impact strength of 9 kJ/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. These values represent increases of 24.2%, 4.7%, and 27.5%, respectively, compared to the unmodified epoxy material. Furthermore, the breakdown strength of the composite was maintained at a high level.

title: AI-Driven Multi-Source River Flow Velocity Assessment under Challenging Monitoring Scenarios
authors: Tingting Liao, Yixiang Su
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Accurate river surface velocity estimation under extreme conditions, such as low-light, ice cover, strong wind, and highly turbid floods, remains challenging for traditional contact-based and standard LSPIV methods due to sparse tracers, high noise, and complex flow structures. This study proposes a Unified Multi-source Constrained Velocity Model (UMC-Velocity), integrating multi-modal imaging (visible, infrared, and low-light enhancement), multi-scale motion extraction (LSPIV and deep optical-flow networks), and physics-constrained optimization to produce spatially continuous, physically plausible velocity fields. A confidence-adaptive fusion mechanism ensures robust cross-scene performance. Validation in representative challenging scenarios demonstrates 62–72% error reduction, improved spatial continuity (>50%), and enhanced physical consistency (40–65%) compared to conventional methods. UMC-Velocity provides a unified, all-weather framework for reliable non-contact river velocity estimation and lays a foundation for next-generation intelligent hydrological monitoring.

title: ColorEdge AI – Early Skin Disease Detection Using ResNet-50
authors: Logeshwari Dhavamani, Sathya Sri Yuvaraj. S, Rajesh. R
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The Early Skin Disease Prediction system which it utilizes the methods and technique of deep learning, for example it is using ResNet-50 convolutional neural networks along with the comprehensive image processing capabilities of MATLAB to create a precise scalable and cost-effective diagnostic tool. This system has an useful preprocessing pipeline that can effectively performs noise filtering, contrast enhancement and a tissue segmentation so that all image quality is consistent. Statistical and texture features derived from the processed images which that enhance the model's values to have a distinguish between visually similar disorders of the skin which will be very useful. With the help of large dataset, which can be considered for skin tones, types of lesions, and lighting conditions, that the model shows good generalization, aided by data augmentation and normalization to enhance robustness. A simpleMATLAB interface enables nonexperts to upload imagesand obtain real-time diagnostic findings, enhancing the accessibility in particularly in remote regionsWith the scalability and privacy in mind, the system supports deployment on the health platforms like smartphones and that adheres to have healthcare data protection standards which by securely have a processingimages without requiring prolonged storage. It has a strong accuracy and sensitivity and specificity performance which makes it suitable for real-time use and for eliminating diagnosis which delays and have a facilitating early medical intervention which will be useful for the environment. project provides a foundation for future growth such as cloud telemedicine integration, expansion to cover other skin ailments and the addition of environmental or lifestyle data for full analysis. The system is a step in using advanced AI to democratize skin care.

title: Big Data Analytics with LSTM Networks for Predictive Air Quality Monitoring in Urban Environments
authors: B. Murugesakumar, Gandhi. B.S, Gowrishankar S, Kannan. K, Keerthana. M
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Cities Air pollution in cities has become one of the burning problems of the world, which should have specific and predictable prediction models. The proposed predictive air quality monitoring big data analytics framework with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks in metropolitan areas is presented in this study. Data of different types were collected including IoT sensor, weather databases, and satellite feeds and preprocessed to feature engineering and modelling. The developed system was reported to have the highest accuracy of 96.8, with an inference time of 95 ms, and the minimum prediction error of RMSE =16.1 −1g/m 3 of PM2.5 prediction. Relative analysis to the conventional baselines and current research singles out better performance and quicker real-time adaptability. The framework shows that it can be used to maintain a smart city, where the spikes of pollution are responded to in a timely manner and the long-term environmental planning can be done. It has been found that big data pipelines coupled with LSTM-based forecasting provide high reliability, scalability, and responsiveness regarding air quality management within urban ecosystems.

title: Research on Phase Selection Closing Optimization Method Considering Grid Disturbance
authors: Xu Yang, Qi Long, Shaohua Li, Xiaofan Gao, Dexiang Li, Jiajie Huang, Changhong Zhang, Dachao Huang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In the actual operation of the power system, voltage may exhibit phenomena such as harmonic distortion, amplitude deviation, and frequency deviation, which affect the accuracy of phase selection. For Capacitive load, an optimized method for phase selection and closing based on dynamic tracking of the optimal closing phase was designed, and its effectiveness was verified. When the total harmonic distortion rate of voltage is 1.73%, the optimized phase selection and closing method can reduce the pre-breakdown voltage by 52.4%; when there is a 10% amplitude deviation of voltage, the optimized phase selection and closing method can reduce the pre-breakdown voltage by 43.9%; and when there is a -0.5Hz frequency offset interference, the optimized phase selection and closing method can reduce the pre-breakdown voltage by 63.6%; In scenarios where multiple types of interference such as voltage harmonics, voltage deviations, and frequency deviations occur simultaneously, the optimized phase selection and closing method can reduce the pre-breakdown voltage by 64.0%.

title: An Electrical Behavior Analysis Method of Esd Protection Structure in Chip Based on Spice
authors: Siyuan Shen, Xiangfen Wang, Bo Wan, Guicui Fu
abstract: With the continued scaling of integrated circuits (ICs), strong electrostatic-discharge (ESD) protection is increasingly essential for device reliability. This paper presents a method for analyzing the behavior of SCR-based protection structures using SPICE. The workflow is driven by Transmission Line Pulse (TLP) measurements, which are used to characterize the electrical behavior and to set up the simulations. Key metrics such as triggering voltage, holding voltage, and snap-back are examined through both experiments and SPICE. The SiliconControlled Rectifier (SCR) device is used as the representative protection structure, known for its reliable and efficient performance. The proposed methodology provides a practical framework for simulation and experimental verification, supporting the design and optimization of ESD protection in ICs. In particular, hybrid SPICE models are shown to capture the overall protection performance of SCR structures. The analysis also offers a systematic process for comparing and balancing alternative ESD solutions, providing a reliable basis for optimization in semiconductor device and packaging design.

title: Thermal diffusion effect by increasing gate-pitch for 4.25GHz 50W Microwave Power Source
authors: Noriyuki Tanba, Shinji Hara, Sei Mizojiri, Kazuya Yaginuma, Kohei Fujiwara, Takashi Kondo
abstract: Microwave power source up to 50 W output at 4.25 GHz is developed for microwave discharge thruster. The final stage GaN HEMT is applied to a 2nd harmonic short stub on the input side and GND stabilization design. GaN HEMT was designed with a gate pitch expanded from 31 μm to 48.5 μm to improve heat dissipation, and the heat distribution during static current operation was measured. It was found that the 48.5 µm gate-pitch had better overall heat diffusion than 31 μm. 50 W RF output is realized by three-stage amplifier configuration and impedance matching circuit between each amplifier is applied to class-F technology. Created aluminum shield case with a built-in 100 W compatible circulator and 50 Ω termination resistor (isolator). The result of RF output power and total efficiency were 42.2 W and 47.2 %.

title: Mask-Region Landmark Prediction in 3D Masked Face Point Clouds Using Non-Mask Facial Landmarks
authors: Joo Won Park, Jaehyun Pyun, Yunseong Jeong, Suk-Ju Kang, Sung In Cho
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the $8^{\text {th }}$ Korean human body measurement survey conducted by the Size Korea Center between 2020 and 2024 includes a subset of 3D scans in which subjects are wearing face masks. Such data limit the utility of the resulting 3D scans for subsequent point-cloud-based learning and analysis. This study addresses this issue by predicting facial landmarks in the mask region of 3D masked face point clouds using only facial landmarks outside the mask region. To this end, we propose a simple two-stage model that first applies positional encoding to non-mask facial landmarks and then uses an MLP regressor to estimate the missing landmarks in the mask region. The model is trained on an unmasked face dataset and qualitatively evaluated on a masked face dataset from the same survey. As a result, we observed both cases in which mask-region landmarks were accurately reconstructed and failure cases where large variations in facial shape led to unstable predictions. Based on these observations, we analyzed the limitations and underlying causes of the our setting and discussed possible directions for future research.

title: Research on Fusion Application of Power Data and Multi-industry Data for Cross-domain Collaboration
authors: Xvguang Du, Shuai Xv, Jianhao Song, Hantian Yang, Shaojun Lin, Chang Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Electricity serves as the cornerstone of modern society's operations. Power systems continuously generate massive, high-value data during operation, including generation volumes, transmission/distribution losses, user load curves, power quality monitoring, and equipment status information. These data not only characterize the operational state of power systems but also contain profound economic and social patterns, functioning as a "barometer" for socio-economic operations. Their value remains far from fully realized when considered in isolation. With the rapid development of big data and artificial intelligence technologies, the integration of power data with other industry data has demonstrated tremendous potential. This paper systematically examines the integration mechanisms between power data and transportation, industrial, construction, and emergency management sectors through authoritative case studies from the National Data Administration and Xinhua News Agency. It explores practical applications of big data technologies and AI algorithms in typical scenarios. Empirical research validates the effectiveness of integrated applications while envisioning future development trends. The study aims to provide theoretical and practical references for promoting cross-industry data integration and collaborative innovation, contributing to energy-efficient utilization and sustainable socio-economic development.

title: Ontology-Driven Customer Churn Prediction: Integrating Knowledge Graphs and Rules for Interpretable Retention Analytics
authors: Pham Thi Thu Thuy, Bui Chi Thanh
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Customer churn prediction is a vital task for telecom and banking industries, but conventional machine learning models often operate as black boxes with limited interpretability. This paper presents ChurnOnt, an ontology-driven framework that integrates domain knowledge into churn prediction pipelines. We design a churn ontology covering customer, contract, and service concepts, and populate it with real-world telecom and banking datasets to build a knowledge graph. Semantic Web Rule Language (SWRL) rules encode expert knowledge and allow a reasoner to infer high-level semantic features (e.g., HighRiskCustomer). These ontology-derived features, combined with baseline attributes, are used to train machine learning models. Our experiments show that ontology-enhanced models improve recall and F1-score for churners, providing more accurate detection of customers at risk. Beyond predictive gains, the ontology also generates human-understandable explanations for churn predictions, bridging the gap between data-driven accuracy and business interpretability. This work highlights how combining symbolic reasoning with machine learning leads to more actionable and trustworthy churn analytics.

title: A Deep Learning Based Joint Channel Access and Switch in Internet of Wban Environment for Human Activity Recognition
authors: G Suvetha, K Jaya Krishna, Bondada Ramesh, Abdelhalim Mohammad Jubran, G John Samuel Babu, R. Suganthi
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: A secure and energy-efficient Wireless Body Area Network (WBAN) for healthcare monitoring, intelligent channel management to ensure consistent patient data delivery, we introduced DJCSIW model is A Deep Learning based Joint Channel Access and Switch in Internet of WBAN Environment for Human Activity Recognition. It integrates body and environmental sensors to monitor health metrics, with data transmitted securely through clustered nodes using blockchain authentication. Optimized cluster heads (CH) are selected via the SineCosine Hunting Optimization (SHO) algorithm, while a multi-hop routing strategy using the MOORA method enhances data transmission efficiency. A three-layer NBWAN architecture facilitates responded communications with an emphasis on critical data. Patient access is managed through a Key Management Server (KMS). Using AI-driven techniques, including recurrent and deep neural networks to optimize channel selection and Modulation and Coding Schemes (MCS). The simulation parameters are used to calculate the DJCSIW model by throughput, delay, packet loss, residual energy and data success rate.

title: Beyond ASR: Achieving Privacy-Aligned Low Diarization Error Rates in Psychiatric Transcripts Using Large Language Models
authors: Rana Zeeshan, John Bogue, Mamoona Naveed Asghar
abstract: The transition to digital psychiatric records introduces distinctive challenges, due to the sensitivity of content and the conversational style of clinician-patient dialogues. Prior evaluations of Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems in psychiatry showed that while Word Error Rate (WER) remains consistently low, Diarization Error Rate (DER) is highly variable. Although synchronous speaker diarization is desirable for real-time transcription, it suffers from processing instability and limited platform availability. On the other hand, asynchronous diarization requires audio recording, introducing serious privacy risks and regulatory barriers in Mental Health Services (MHS). Both approaches also rely on voice-based separation and identification of speakers, which is less effective when speakers share similar demographic traits, such as gender or age, leading to elevated diarization error rates. These aspects position diarization as the main bottleneck in the adoption of ASR workflows in psychiatry. This study addresses these challenges by combining synchronous speech-to-text (STT) transcription with large language model (LLM) based diarization. This approach removes the reliance on voice-based speaker separation and eliminates the need to store or process raw audio, which improves privacy protection for highly sensitive clinical data. Six state-of-the-art LLMs: GPT-5, Grok-4, DeepSeek Reasoner, Perplexity Sonar Pro, Gemini 2.5 Pro, and Claude Sonnet-4 were evaluated on three psychiatric session transcripts without labels, representing female-female (FF), female-male (FM), and male-male (MM) speaker pairs. Each transcript was merged into unsegmented text, and models were tasked with assigning labels based on provided context of psychiatric treatment sessions. DER was computed using the punctuation-segmented method from prior ASR research. The results show that LLM based DER ranged between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-4 \%$</tex>, compared to ASR based diarization where DER reached up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 2. 2 \%}$</tex> in some cases. Moreover, the persistent minor errors were largely benign affirmations that did not alter the factual meaning or clinical interpretation. This demonstrates that synchronous STT combined with LLM diarization functions as Privacy Enhancing Technology (PET). This approach provides a more accurate, stable, and privacy-aligned alternative for psychiatric documentation, enhancing clinical workflow efficiency while addressing the limitations of both synchronous and asynchronous speaker diarization.

title: Prediction of unit price of labor cost for transmission line construction based on PM interval estimation algorithm
authors: Xinwei Lin
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Labor cost control is one of the important links in the construction of transmission lines. It is necessary to predict the labor cost of power transmission line construction and achieve quantitative control. This paper proposes a prediction algorithm for the unit price of labor cost in transmission line construction based on the PM interval estimation algorithm. Firstly, analyze the characteristics of the labor cost unit price in power transmission line construction, and establish an interval fluctuation model for the labor cost unit price. Secondly, a time series analysis was conducted on the interval fluctuation model of the unit price of labor costs, and a time series interval prediction model for the unit price of labor costs was established. Then, the PM interval estimation algorithm is employed to identify the parameters of the time series interval prediction model, thereby enabling the prediction of the unit price of labor costs. Finally, the accuracy of the prediction model was verified and analyzed using actual engineering data. The prediction model can effectively predict the unit price of labor cost, further supporting the control of labor costs in the transmission lines construction.

title: POI-LLM: Leveraging POI Enhanced Large Language Models for Spatial-Temporal Modeling
authors: Xinyu Shi, Wenwu Gong, Xuanzhe Xu, Lili Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Spatial-temporal modeling is foundational to urban mobility analysis, yet many graph- and attention-based architectures rely on fixed graphs or encode spatial structure only implicitly. Meanwhile, LLM-based models seldom incorporate explicit spatial semantics. We propose POI-LLM, which augments a partially frozen LLM with spatial knowledge for spatial-temporal modeling. We partition urban space into network-consistent parcels and enriches them with point-of-interest (POI) embeddings. A lightweight cross-attention module aligns parcel spatial embedding with temporal embedding to form inputs to LLM, which captures long-range spatiotemporal dependencies. Experiments on real Origin-destination(OD) flow datasets offer evidence that POI-LLM is a powerful spatial-temporal learner that outpeforms state-of-the-art models. This show that explicitly encoding spatial semantics and selectively adapting LLMs offers an efficient and effective route to spatial-temporal modeling.

title: Parallel Lightweight Hybrid Attention BiGRU Framework for Multi Resident Human Activity Recognition with Sparse Sensor Data
authors: Abisek Dahal, Kaushik Ray, Soumen Moulik
abstract: Recognizing human activity in multi-resident smart homes is complex due to sparse sensor activations and overlapping occupant actions. This paper presents a Parallel Lightweight Hybrid Attention BiGRU framework, integrating Multi-Head Attention (MHA) with Bidirectional GRUs (BiGRUs) to address these challenges effectively. The model processes global sensor relationships and local temporal dependencies in parallel, overcoming information loss typical in sequential processing. Experiments on real world smart home ARAS datasets show that the framework achieves 97.99% accuracy in Multi resident settings in House A and 99.49% accuracy in multi resident scenarios in House B. It also generalizes well across different households, demonstrating strong adaptability and robustness. By combining attention mechanisms with recurrent neural networks, the proposed architecture efficiently captures key patterns in sparse and concurrent sensor data. This work marks a significant advancement in multi resident human activity recognition, offering a scalable and reliable solution for real world smarthome applications and establishing a strong foundation for future research in pervasive computing and ambient intelligence systems.

title: Scalable Face Recognition with Multiple Deep Learning Model Integration
authors: Pawan K. Ajmera, Ramakant Soni, Anmol Mathur, Jayesh Harlalka, Vipin Saraogi
abstract: This paper presents the design of a scalable face recognition system to address real-world challenges including illumination-variation, occlusions and motion blur. This proposed method integrates multiple state-of-the-art models into a unified pipeline: YOLOv5-Face is used for preparation of the dataset, SCRFD for face detection with high accuracy and face alignment, ArcFace for discriminative feature embedding generation and BYTETracker for continuous multi-face tracking. Experimentations conducted on a locally generated dataset demonstrate strong performance by achieving the training accuracy of 90.13%, validation accuracy of 89.02%, and a ROC AUC score of 0. 9 5 9 2. The system is able to sustain real-time performance with 25-30 FPS and low latency of 33-40 ms per frame. These results make this system suitable for largescale surveillance applications. The results also highlight the effectiveness of multi-model integration in improving the accuracy and adaptability when compared to traditional approaches. This paper contributes a practical solution for deployment in the domains such as campus surveillance, access control and crowd monitoring. It also provides foundation for future work which include liveness detection, super-resolution for low resolution recognition and lightweight edge-compatible model implementation.

title: CRBP: A Benchmark Dataset of Color-Rendered 3-D-to-2.5-D Facial Projections
authors: Sahil Sharma, Ashima Sood, Vijay Kumar
abstract: The Colour-Rendered Bosphorus Projections (CRBP) Face dataset overcomes key limitations in 3-D facial analysis by offering a photometrically normalized, multiview dataset specifically tailored for 2.5-D modeling. CRBP utilizes the Bosphorus 3D Face Database, reconstructing textured 3-D meshes for each individual and producing six canonical 2-D projections. To improve model compatibility and minimize background noise, each projection is processed using YOLOv8 for face detection. This results in two organized subsets, namely, CRBP-Raw (full scene) and CRBP-YOLOv8 (face-cropped). This dual-format design facilitates thorough benchmarking of pose-invariant, occlusion-resilient, and expression-aware models within a convolutional neural network-compatible image space. Dataset statistics indicate that YOLOv8 enhances facial alignment, however, it also introduces sample selection bias, especially in extreme yaw and occlusion scenarios. CRBP facilitates applications in emotion recognition, biometric authentication, and avatar creation. The dataset is available at: https://dx.doi.org/10.21227/4qns-ys45.

title: Generation of Driving Collision Risk Scenarios Based on Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Gang Wang, Wenbo Wang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: The diversity and coverage of traffic scenarios are crucial for the training and validation of autonomous driving decision-making methods. Due to the low probability of collision risk scenarios occurring in reality and the difficulty of collecting such data on a large scale through naturalistic driving, this paper utilizes a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) based method to derive high-risk scenarios such as dangerous lane changes and emergency braking, effectively expanding specific need scenarios and accelerating the development and testing of autonomous driving systems. This paper proposes a GAN framework capable of recognizing non-uniform scenes. Initially, it introduces existing methods for generating traffic scenarios. Subsequently, a scene generation method compatible with time-series data is constructed to produce collision risk scenarios with temporal continuity and dynamic changes. Finally, through model performance analysis, the effectiveness and diversity of the generated scenes are validated.

title: Evaluating the Accuracy of Fabric Mechanical Digitization Methods_supp2-3665029.xlsx
authors: Gabriel Cirio
abstract: The apparel industry has witnessed a significant shift toward 3D virtual design, driven by advances in simulation and digitization technologies. Central to this transformation are digital twins, which allow designers to test and refine garment designs virtually, reducing reliance on physical prototyping. A critical aspect of this process is accurately capturing the drape behavior of fabrics, as it impacts both the aesthetic and functional properties of garments. Traditional fabric digitization methods involve mechanical testing of fabric samples, but they are labor-intensive, costly, and require specialized equipment. Recently, AI-based digitization techniques have emerged, offering potential advantages in terms of cost and logistics, though their accuracy remains uncertain. This study addresses the gap in knowledge regarding the accuracy of AI-based fabric digitization by utilizing the Cusick drape test—a standardized method for assessing fabric drape behavior. We introduce a reference digitization pipeline based on traditional mechanical testing and perform a comprehensive comparative study of six commercially available digitization methods, including both traditional and AI-based approaches. Using a diverse set of fabrics, we evaluate the accuracy of the digitized fabrics against real-world measurements. Our results demonstrate that AI-based methods can achieve competitive accuracy, while also highlighting areas for further improvement. We present a publicly available dataset containing real fabric properties, their digitized versions, as well as their corresponding real and digital drape metrics, which can serve as a valuable resource for further research and development in fabric digitization.

title: FreeSplat++: Generalizable 3D Gaussian Splatting for Efficient Indoor Scene Reconstruction_supp2-3665771.mp4
authors: Gim Hee Lee
abstract: Recently, the integration of the efficient feed-forward scheme into 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has been actively explored. However, most existing methods focus on sparse view reconstruction of small regions and cannot produce eligible whole-scene reconstruction results in terms of either quality or efficiency. In this paper, we propose FreeSplat++, which focuses on extending the generalizable 3DGS to become an alternative approach to large-scale indoor whole-scene reconstruction, which has the potential of significantly accelerating the reconstruction speed and improving the geometric accuracy. To facilitate whole-scene reconstruction, we initially propose the Low-cost Cross-View Aggregation framework to efficiently process extremely long input sequences. Subsequently, we introduce a carefully designed pixel-wise triplet fusion method to incrementally aggregate the overlapping 3D Gaussian primitives from multiple views, adaptively reducing their redundancy. Furthermore, given the fused 3DGS primitives with accumulated weights after the fusion step, we propose a weighted floater removal strategy that can effectively reduce floaters, which serves as an explicit depth fusion approach that is tailored for generalizable 3DGS methods and becomes crucial in whole-scene reconstruction. After the feed-forward reconstruction of 3DGS primitives, we investigate a depth-regularized per-scene fine-tuning process. Leveraging the dense, multi-view consistent depth maps obtained during the feed-forward prediction phase for an extra constraint, we refine the entire scene's 3DGS primitive to enhance rendering quality while preserving geometric accuracy. Extensive experiments confirm that our FreeSplat++ significantly outperforms existing generalizable 3DGS methods, especially in whole scene reconstructions. Compared to conventional per-scene optimized 3DGS approaches, our method with depth-regularized per-scene fine-tuning demonstrates substantial improvements in reconstruction accuracy and a notable reduction in training time.

title: Design and Control of a Compact Series Elastic Actuator Module for Robots in MRI Scanners_supp1-3658501.mp4
authors: Binghan He
abstract: Robotic assistance has broadened the capabilities of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-guided medical interventions, yet force-controlled actuators tailored for MRI environments remain limited. In this study, we present a novel MRI-compatible rotary series elastic actuator (SEA) module that employs velocity-sourced ultrasonic motors for force-controlled operation within MRI scanners. Unlike prior MRI-compatible SEA designs, our module uses a transmission force sensing SEA architecture, with four off-the-shelf compression springs placed between the gearbox and motor housings. To enable precise torque control, we develop a controller based on a disturbance observer, specifically designed for velocity-sourced motors. This controller improves torque regulation, even under varying external impedance, enhancing the actuator’s suitability for MRI-guided medical interventions. Experimental validation confirms effective torque control in both 3 Tesla MRI and non-MRI settings, achieving a 5% settling time of 0.05 s and steady-state error within 2.5% of the actuator’s maximum output torque. Notably, the controller maintains consistent performance across both low- and high-impedance conditions.

title: A Dual-System Vision-Language-Action Model for Rational Manipulation
authors: Wenxuan Song, Jiayi Chen, Wenxue Li, Xu He, Xinhu Zheng, Zhe Liu, Hesheng Wang, Haoang Li
abstract: A fundamental requirement for real-world robotic deployment is the ability to understand and respond to natural language instructions. Existing language-conditioned manipulation tasks typically assume that instructions are perfectly aligned with the environment. This assumption limits robustness and generalization in realistic scenarios where instructions may be ambiguous, irrelevant, or infeasible. To address this problem, we introduce RAtional MAnipulation (RAMA), a new benchmark that challenges models with both unseen executable instructions and defective ones that should be rejected. In RAMA, we construct a dataset with over 14 000 samples, including diverse defective instructions spanning six dimensions: visual, physical, semantic, motion, safety, and out-of-context. We further propose the rational vision-language-action model (RationalVLA). It is a dual system for robotic arms that integrates the high-level vision-language model with the low-level manipulation policy by introducing learnable latent space embeddings. This design enables RationalVLA to reason over instructions, reject infeasible commands, and execute manipulation effectively. Experiments demonstrate that RationalVLA outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on RAMA by a 14.5% higher success rate and 0.96 average task length in the CALVIN simulation environment, while maintaining competitive performance on standard manipulation tasks. Real-world trials further validate its effectiveness and robustness in practical applications.

title: Spatiotemporal Forecasting of Pine Wilt Disease in China Using a Graph Convolutional-LSTM Network_supp1-3663660.xlsx
authors: Yingying Dong
abstract: The escalating spread of Pine Wilt Disease (PWD) presents a severe threat to forest ecosystems, while predicting its complex spatiotemporal dynamics remains a major challenge. To address this, we developed a novel deep learning framework integrating a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) with a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network to deconstruct and predict the Occurrence of PWD (OPWD) in China for the period 1982–2022. Using GeoDetector, we identified 16 key factors and quantified their contributions, revealing that human-mediated factors (e.g., wood-processing factory density, road network density) are the dominant drivers of PWD spread, exhibiting strong synergistic interactions. The GCN-LSTM model demonstrated exceptional predictive performance, significantly outperforming conventional models with an overall accuracy of 0.93 and an AUC of 0.87. Crucially, the model deconstructed the spread of PWD into two distinct mechanisms: a stable, localized continuous spread governed by natural factors, and a volatile, long-distance leaping spread driven primarily by human activities. This mechanistic deconstruction provides a robust explanation for the historical patterns of the epidemic. This study provides not only a highly accurate predictive tool for large-scale PWD monitoring but also a powerful analytical paradigm for disentangling the drivers of biological invasions, underscoring the imperative for developing spatially explicit, mechanism-aware management strategies to effectively combat the global threat of PWD.

title: Real-Time Food Classification Using VGG19 with Grad-CAM Visualization for Enhanced Interpretability
authors: Karka. Nimisha Reddy, Ramu Jarubula, K. Nageswara Rao, R Maranan, S. Kaliappan, Siva Kumar Pathuri
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: As nutritional disorders led to by poor diets and plethora of different cuisines offered in the market increases, the physical and psychological wellbeing are both at stake. To solve this problem, proper food classification is necessary to track the food intake and raise awareness on nutrition. In this paper, the author suggests a food recognition model, which relies on VGG19 deep convolutional neural network, augmented with Grad-CAM (Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping), to improve the ability to interpret the information. The model has been tested on a large set of 53 international foods both vegetarian and non-vegetarian.VGG19 was chosen because it has good performance in features detection, and Grad-Cam shows the regions on the image that affect the choices made by the model, making the process of classifying images more transparent and credible. This intelligible AI system enables users/researchers to visualize and confirm classification performance. Through experimental research, it is proven that the Grad-CAM-improved version of VGG19 classifier yields a staggering 96% accuracy compared to traditional machine learning models like Naive Bayes and Decision Tree. The identified method demonstrates the high potential of real-time applications in monitoring food intake and in dietary assessment.

title: Latent Fingerprint Quality Assessment for Criminal Investigations: A Benchmark Dataset and Method
authors: Chao Huang, Jingxuan Zhang, Ye Zhang, Hao Wu, Peibei Cao, Zhihua Wang, Yang Yu, Xiaochun Cao
abstract: Fingerprint biometrics plays a crucial role in biometric identification, especially in applications such as criminal investigations. Although recent progress in recognition methodology has significantly enhanced automated fingerprint recognition, these systems still rely heavily on the quality of the input fingerprints. In criminal investigations, fingerprints are often of low quality due to their incidental deposition from natural oils and sweat, rather than being deliberately captured under controlled conditions. This degradation can significantly impact usability and identification accuracy, underscoring the need for effective Fingerprint Quality Assessment (FQA) methods. In this paper, we establish the Crime Scene Fingerprints quality assessment Dataset (CSFD-10k), the largest dataset of its kind, containing 11,500 fingerprint images from real criminal investigations. Of these, 10,000 samples are assigned Mean Opinion Scores (MOSs) for correlation testing, while the remaining 1,500 are labeled based on matching performance for generalizability testing. All labels are provided by frontline criminal police officers. Using this dataset, we propose a deep neural network-based Dual-Branch FQA (DB-FQA) framework that integrates image-level and edge-level features. The DB-FQA enhances ridge details by transforming raw grayscale fingerprints into edge maps using the Logical/Linear operator. A dual-branch network processes both the raw fingerprint and the edge map, and the Multi-scale Adaptive Cross feature Fusion (MACF) module fuses these features, guided by the edge map to highlight quality-related regions of interest. Extensive experiments demonstrate the robustness and superiority of our proposed method, offering substantial support for forensic fingerprint biometrics. The code and dataset are available at https://github.com/wzhsysu/FIQA.

title: DiffEraser: Generalized Text Erasure Based on Latent Diffusion Prior
authors: Zhihao Chen, Yongqi Chen, Changsheng Chen, Shunquan Tan, Jiwu Huang
abstract: Text removal is an important task in processing both scene and document images. However, existing scene text removal (STR) methods are primarily focus on scene text images. The STR models (trained by scene text images) perform poorly on document images with dense, complex textured backgrounds. We discover that the limitations of existing methods can be attributed to the difficuties in background features estimation in the regions to be erased, which is based on the knowledge from neighboring regions in the input images and priors learned from the training data. The background features estimation performance degrades under the cross-domain scenarios, and compromises the quality of STR results. To address these issues, we introduce DiffEraser, a novel text removal framework that leverages prior knowledge from the Latent Diffusion Model (LDM) for removing text in both scene and document images. Our DiffEraser incorporates two key innovations to fully exploit the prior knowledge of LDM. First, we replace the conventional Variational Auto-Encoders (VAE) encoder with a Diffusion-Prior (DP) encoder, aiming to integrate the heterogeneous information from the LDM prior knowledge in latent space with the multi-level encoded features of the input image. Second, we introduce a Latent-Fusion (LF) decoder that integrates the heterogeneous features from both the LDM and DP encoders to generate high-quality text-erased results. To evaluate the generalization performance of our DiffEraser, we focus on the cross-domain protocols and construct a document image dataset, NPID295, which contains 295 types of passports and identity cards. Notably, when trained on a scene text dataset, DiffEraser significantly outperforms existing STR methods in the challenging NPID295 dataset. The resources of this work will be available online upon acceptance.

title: Removing Multiple Hybrid Adverse Weather in Video via a Unified Model
authors: Ye-Cong Wan, Ming-Wen Shao, Yuan-Shuo Cheng, Jun Shu, Shui-Gen Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Videos captured under real-world adverse weather conditions typically suffer from uncertain hybrid weather efforts. However, existing algorithms can only remove one type of weather degradation at a time and deal with different weather conditions with separate models, thus may fail to handle real-world stochastic hybrid scenarios. Besides, the model training is also infeasible due to the lack of paired video data to characterize the coexistence of multiple weather. To ameliorate the aforementioned issue, we propose a novel unified model, dubbed UniWRV, to remove multiple heterogeneous video weather degradations in an all-in-one fashion. Specifically, to tackle degenerate spatial feature heterogeneity, we propose a tailored weather prior guided module that queries exclusive priors for different instances as prompts to steer spatial feature characterization.
