To tackle degenerate temporal feature heterogeneity, we propose a dynamic routing aggregation module that can automatically select optimal fusion paths for different instances to dynamically integrate temporal features. Furthermore, we propose a real-world adaptation training scheme that leverages CLIP priors to provide semantic supervision for unlabeled real-world weather-degraded videos, thereby enabling the model to better cope with the diverse and complex real-world weather conditions. Additionally, we managed to construct a new synthetic video dataset, termed HWVideo, for learning and benchmarking multiple hybrid adverse weather removal, which contains 15 hybrid weather conditions with a total of 1500 adverse-weather/clean paired video clips. Real-world hybrid weather videos are also collected to facilitate model generalizability. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that our UniWRV exhibits robust and superior adaptation capability in multiple heterogeneous degradations learning scenarios, including various generic video restoration tasks beyond weather removal.

title: A Resource Selection Model for Minimization of Disruptions in Public Fog Computing Environments_supp1-3664329.pdf
authors: Sudheer Kumar Battula
abstract: Fog computing providers have started providing services in closer proximity to the users by leasing the unused computational resources of users' devices. The leased devices are increasingly used for many time-sensitive and IoT applications. Despite the advantages of Fog, due to the highly mobile and dynamic nature of Fog devices, the resources or devices may fail at any time or may not always be available for the processing of the applications, which leads to degradation of service quality and an increase in application processing time. Hence, effective selection of the resources in the Fog computing environment by considering mobility, heterogeneity, and failure of devices is a complex task. Traditional resource selection techniques may not be applied directly in Fog computing environments due to their dynamic and unique resource characteristics. Therefore, this article proposes a Markov chain-based resource selection model to improve the quality of service by minimizing disruptions and managing device failures. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is evaluated using simulations, which take failure traces, current resource usage, and mobility as input from a dataset archive. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in terms of average disruption rates, average latency, and average overutilization. Our analysis shows significant improvements in average latency reduction of approximately 11.83%, and an average overutilization improvement by 16.17%.

title: Improved Spontaneous EEG Signal Decoding Efficiency by Function Predefined Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Boxun Fu, Fu Li, Junkai Li, Youshuo Ji, Yang Li, Yinghui Quan, Lijian Zhang, Guangming Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: A spontaneous electroencephalogram (EEG)-based brain–computer interface (BCI) is an ideal form of brain–computer interaction. The classical decoding methods can achieve classification by using meaningful manual features, but their performance is poor. The neural network (NN) methods have significantly improved the performance, but their interpretability and computational efficiency are much lower than those of the classical methods. This is because NN abandons the strong a priori knowledge of neuroscience and completely relies on training to extract EEG features. How to integrate the characteristics of neural signals into the design of the basic operator of the NNs while retaining its learning ability is the focus of this work. In this work, we proposed a function predefined convolutional NN (FPCNN) to search for the best frequency points and channel weights to decode spontaneous EEG signals. Among the FPCNN, a novel function predefined convolutional (FPC) layer adopts a learnable way to search for the key spatial–frequency parameters of spontaneous EEG, making its parameters have clear physical meanings. Furthermore, a trainable quadrature detector (TQD) based on FPC was constructed, and the quadrature characteristic was utilized to ensure the capture of complex phase change signals. The core contribution of our method lies in the proposal of a novel NN operator for decoding spontaneous EEG, and a quadrature scheme for handling the phase changes of signals. The experimental results show that the proposed FPCNN significantly improves the performance by 2.09% (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\ast } $</tex-math> </inline-formula>), 3.08% (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\ast } $</tex-math> </inline-formula>), and 3.41% (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\ast \ast }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), respectively, compared with the state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods on three spontaneous EEG datasets. Moreover, the training and testing time cost of FPCNN in a non-GPU environment only takes 67.96 and 19.36 s per epoch. Its savings in computing resources and time are very beneficial for EEG processing in diverse environments. In addition, visualization experiments demonstrated the interpretability and stability of the proposed FPCNN. The experimental results show that our method is efficient, stable, and interpretable. This work has effectively improved the decoding efficiency of spontaneous EEG signals and demonstrated the power of combining traditional signal processing methods with NNs.

title: An Improved LM-GN Iterative Optimization Algorithm and Its Application in the Vehicle-based Integrated Navigation
authors: Mingze Zhang, Aigong Xu, Zihao Jiang
abstract: To address the issue of degraded positioning accuracy in the Inertial Navigation System/Global Navigation Satellite System (INS/GNSS) integrated navigation systems caused by inaccurate measurement noise statistics and sudden abnormal measurements in complex environments, an INS/GNSS navigation method based on an improved Levenberg-Marquardt-Gauss-Newton (LM-GN) iterative optimization is proposed. This approach identifies and handles abnormal measurements using residual chi-square detection and applies an improved LM–GN iterative mechanism to correct the identified anomalies. By integrating a trust-region strategy with the LM/GN algorithm, an adaptive damping factor and iterative step selection mechanism are constructed. This design ensures numerical stability while improving iteration efficiency and reducing computational load. The corrected measurements are then fused within a Kalman filter framework, enabling adaptive adjustment of the filter gain and effectively suppressing the impact of abnormal measurements on state estimation. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared with the conventional Kalman filter and the Sage–Husa adaptive filter, the proposed method improves velocity accuracy by 58.7% and 37.6%, respectively, and position accuracy by 43.4% and 21.7%, significantly enhancing the positioning accuracy and robustness of INS/GNSS integrated navigation systems

title: Research on Secure Data Transmission of Power System Based on Chaotic Sequences
authors: Gang Qu, Erbo Shang, Haochun Jin, Ye Liang, Xin Wu, Jieyin Bai
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: With the rapid development of smart grids, distributed energy and Internet of Things technologies, modern power systems are evolving into complex systems with a deep integration of information and physical elements. Massive amounts of data, such as power generation capacity, load information, grid operation status, control instructions and user electricity consumption data, need to interact at high speed and reliably among all links of power generation, transmission, distribution and consumption. Against this backdrop, the research on the security of data transmission in power systems is of crucial and far-reaching significance. In response to the challenges faced by existing algorithms in terms of anti-attack capability, device integration, and standardization, this paper proposes a light image encryption scheme based on hybrid chaotic mapping and dynamic pixel diffusion. This scheme uses chaotic laser in the light domain for carrier masking, and implements efficient chaotic scrambling and diffusion operations in the digital signal processor in the electrical domain. The aim is to construct a multi-level and highly secure photonic-cooperative encryption system. The simulation results show that this scheme maintains a nearly linear speed encryption efficiency while demonstrating excellent robustness against chosen plaintext attacks and noise interference, and it can well accommodate the existing optical communication frame structure.

title: Adaptive Spectrum Sensing in Cognitive Radar System using SVM
authors: Veerraju Sampenga, Ramanababu Challapalli, Deekshitha Kandregula, Bhargavi Pilla, Raveendhra Muppirisetti, Raja Ratna Prasad Bandaru
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive spectrum sensing framework for cognitive radar that uses Support Vector Machines (SVM) to detect primary user signals.’ The aim is to develop a robust and efficient approach that can adapt to changing environmental conditions.The goal is to improve spectrum utilization while minimizing interference to primary users.This system employs an SVM-based classifier to analyze statistical characteristics based on main user signals, which help with reliable and effective spectrum sensing.By utilizing SVM's classification capabilities, this project demonstrates high accuracy in detecting primary user signals, making it a promising approach for cognitive radar applications and real - time applications. This work is interesting because it combines an adaptive SVM update method with statistical feature extraction (mean, variance, skewness, and kurtosis) in a lightweight manner, maintaining high detection performance at different SNRs.

title: Enhance Spam Identification in Industrial Mobile Cloud Computing Using Novel Long Short Term Memory Algorithm Compared with Support Vector Machine(SVM) Algorithm
authors: Nithishkumar Y, T.J. Nagalakshmi, Bala. S
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: To enhance the Spam Identification in Industrial Mobile Cloud Computing using a Long Short TermMemory(LSTM) Algorithm compared with Support Vector Machine(SVM) Algorithm. Methods &Materials: This work has employed two methodologies, that are Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Long Short Term Memory (LSTM). 20 is the sample size used by support vector machines (SVM) and long short-term memory. Results: Support Vector Machine (SVM) has an accuracy of 94.42%, whereas Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) has a higher accuracy of 95.11%. Based on a sample t-test with a significant value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p=0.002\ (\mathrm{p}<0.05)$</tex>, the research investigation demonstrated significance between two groups. Conclusion: Based on the data, LSTM accuracy outperformed SVM accuracy by a wide margin.

title: Domain-Specific Health Text Generation Through Low-Rank Adaptation of a Transformer Architecture
authors: Kamalesh Debnath, Shrinjoy Das, Mousum Handique, Arnab Paul, Lalzo S. Thangjom, Megha Arakeri
abstract: The growing demand for accessible and reliable health information has motivated the adaptation of domain-specific large language models (lLMs). LLMs perform well on general natural language processing (NLP) tasks but require fine-tuning for healthcare applications. In this work, Mistral-7B, a 7.3B parameter Transformer model, is fine-tuned for health text generation and noncritical symptom understanding using three parameterefficient methods-Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA), Quantized Low-Rank Adaptation (QLoRA), and Rank-Optimized Reliable Adaptation (RoRA). A synthetic dataset comprising medical question answering, symptom descriptions, and home remedies was curated from public sources. Experimental results demonstrate that RoRA achieved the highest BLEU-4 (0.52), ROUGE-L (0.65), and F1-score (0.84), outperforming baselines such as BERT, RoBERTa, and LLaMA7B while maintaining low GPU memory usage. This work supports the use of fine-tuned LLMs for safe and efficient health communication, especially in low-resource settings. It also demonstrates that lightweight adaptation using Parameter Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) can deliver high-quality outputs while minimizing computational demands.

title: Off-Grid Wind Power: Hybrid Optimization Strategy to Establish Benchmark Output Currents
authors: C. Selvamani, Sahil Shah, Pratik Dahule, U. Mehjabeen, Divya Balakrishnan, Poonam Juneja
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research examines a hybrid optimization method on off-grid wind power system with interest on defining benchmark output currents to improve the energy efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and wind system performance. Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithm (MOEA) is used to achieve multiple objectives like energy production, storage capacity and operation costs. The proposed method shows the best performance compared to the conventional optimization algorithms, such as Genetic Algorithm (GA), Simulated Annealing (SA), and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) using the MATLAB Global Optimization Toolbox. The outcome is increased efficiency of 25 percent of energy, 15 percent of the cost reduction, and a 20 percent prolongation of the battery life. The system was also 98 percent accurate in integrating to the changing environmental condition. The results suggest how MOEA can help solve the multifaceted problem of off-grid wind energy to provide a scalable and low-cost solution to sustainable energy control in distant areas. The current study will help in creating effective, streamlined off-grid renewable energy systems.

title: FedCFS: Adaptive Personalized Federated Learning Based on Conditional Feature Selection
authors: Zuqi Zhang, Changli Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Recent years have witnessed growing interest in personalized federated learning (pFL), which effectively addresses the concurrent needs for privacy protection, collaborative model training, and handling of statistical heterogeneity inherent in non-IID client data. Typical pFL approaches aim to capture both global patterns and client-specific representations from decentralized datasets to mitigate the effects of data heterogeneity. Nevertheless, the personalized features currently extracted tend to be imprecise and often contain noise, thereby limiting the effectiveness of personalization on local clients. To tackle this issue, we propose FedCFS (Federated Conditional Feature Selection). FedCFS dynamically gates raw features into global-robust features (i.e., features with limited contribution to model performance) and local-sensitive features (i.e., features with significant contributions to model performance), while filtering out noise; The two pathways are then fed into the global and personalized heads correspondingly. This sample-level operation allows FedCFS to perform feature decoupling at a more granular level compared to existing pFL approaches. Comprehensive evaluations on computer vision and natural language processing tasks demonstrate that FedCFS surpasses 11 state-of-the-art methods, exceeding the best traditional and personalized baselines by up to 28.64% and 1.07%, respectively.

title: Challenges for High-Datarate Chip-To-Chip Interconnects using Organic Interposer Materials for Heterogeneous Chiplet Systems Up to 110 GHz
authors: Jens Löffler, Manuel Koch, Sascha Breun, Robert Weigel, Norman Franchi
abstract: This paper presents an overview of key challenges that arise during the development of broadband signal lines on organic interposer substrates for heterogeneous chiplet systems. This work identifies and analyzes four critical aspects that significantly impact signal integrity at high frequencies. Conductor surface roughness, surface plating effects, manufacturing process variations and the complexity of accurate crosstalk measurement. To validate the discussed effects, simulations and benchmark measurements were performed using an advanced 110 GHz 8-port VNA setup. This enable the designer to tackle these challenges starting right at the beginning of the design flow by choosing correct modeling approaches.

title: High-Speed NRZ-DPSK Conversion Circuit Using CMOS Logic Gates with Half-Rate Architecture
authors: Hinata Tajima, Yuya Hatanaka, Daisuke Ito, Yasuhiro Takahashi, Makoto Nakamura, Toshiyuki Inoue, Keiji Kishine
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Recently, differential phase-shift keying (DPSK) modulation, which provides higher sensitivity and better noise tolerance compared to conventional modulation schemes, has attracted increasing attention in optical communication technologies. Since DPSK modulation represents data by the phase difference between adjacent bits, an NRZ-DPSK conversion circuit is required. To achieve high-speed operation, an NRZDPSK conversion circuit with a half-rate architecture employing a cross-feedback configuration is proposed. A layout design was implemented for IC chip prototyping, and postlayout simulations were conducted to compare its performance with the conventional circuit configuration. The results demonstrate that the proposed circuit configuration achieves an 80% improvement in operating speed and a 65.7% enhancement in eye-opening ratio compared to the conventional one.

title: neuroAlzheimer: Uncover Alzheimer’s Diseases a Hidden Neurological Symptoms Using DL
authors: Arunima Rout, Angom Nolini, Thiyam Susma Devi, Ujjwal Biswas
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder. It affects memory and cognitive function. Currently, it is not a curable disease with any treatment. However, a timely and accurate classification of its stages helps to manage symptoms and slow the development of the disease. This research focuses on automating the classification of brain magnetic resonance imaging using deep learning techniques to address research challenges. A predictive model consists of three major components. A predictive model comprises three key components. It starts with a basic Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which is then improved using advanced regularization and evaluation techniques. Finally, an ensemble model is constructed by integrating the custom CNN with pretrained architectures like MobileNetV2 and ResNet50. In addition, the ensemble system incorporated gradual unfreezing, data enhancement, and explainability using Grad-CAM. To make it easily accessible, realtime deployment through a Gradio interface was also implemented. These features achieved significant improvements in the user interpretability, accuracy, and robustness of the model. Its potential utility in clinical settings for the early detection of Alzheimer’s disease is highlighted.

title: An EM-Based Approach for Tracking Extended Object with Asynchronous Sensor Fusion
authors: Shun Liu, Zhongqian Jin, Ronghua Wang, Caihong Zhang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: The deployment of multiple homogeneous sensors, such as radar networks, is common for enhancing tracking robustness. However, the practical issue of asynchronous data streams, caused by differing sampling rates, is often overlooked in extended object tracking (EOT). This asynchronicity prevents the direct application of high-performance single-sensor EOT methods and introduces significant fusion errors, especially during target maneuvers where the kinematic and extension states are tightly coupled. This work bridges this gap by adapting an expectation-maximization-based EOT method for a practical dual-sensor asynchronous setup. A motion-model-based prediction strategy is utilized to align the sensor data temporally, enabling effective fusion. The entire tracking system is validated through simulations of a scenario involving a coordinated turn. Results demonstrate that the proposed integration provides an effective solution for asynchronous sensor fusion.

title: A High Aperture Efficiency Leaky Wave Antenna with a Nonlinear Elliptical Slot Distribution for High Power Microwave Applications
authors: Wonkyo Kim, Mee-Su Lee, Dong-Hoon Lee, Junyeon Kim, Donggeun Seo, Ick-Jae Yoon
abstract: A leaky wave antenna (LWA) with a nonlinear elliptical slot structure for high power microwave (HPM) applications is presented. A nonlinear elliptical slot distribution on the aperture waveguide, which controls the attenuation constant, is formed using a Taylor amplitude distribution in the leaky waveguide structure. In the proposed design, the side lobe level is improved compared to the linear elliptical slot LWA, while the gain is maintained. The elliptical slotted structure reduces the maximum E-field encountered at the slot by about 10% compared to the rectangular slotted structure, thereby enhancing the power handling capacity (PHC) of the antenna. Additionally, the proposed design includes more slotted structures per unit length than conventional slotted waveguide array antennas, resulting in increased field leakage and improved PHC. The simulated PHC of the proposed antenna is 269 MW. The proposed antenna has a length of 8.1λ, a measured gain of 17 dBi, and a side lobe level (SLL) of 10.4 dB. The proposed antenna achieves the highest aperture efficiency among the previously reported slotted waveguide antennas.

title: Infrared Monocular Depth Estimation via Parameter-Efficient Adaptation
authors: Jaehyun Pyun, Seunghun Moon, Yunseong Jeong, Suk-Ju Kang
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: Recent RGB-based monocular depth estimation achieves high accuracy but often assumes stable visible illumination. Infrared radiation (IR) imaging is practical because it remains usable in dim environments and employs invisible active illumination, which does not interfere with human vision, making it suitable for everyday deployment. However, paired IR-depth datasets are scarce, which limits both training and fair evaluation for this modality. We adapt the large pre-trained model Depth Anything v2 to the IR modality using parameter-efficient LoRA fine-tuning. To support training and evaluation, we collect an indoor dataset of $\mathbf{2 5, 7 4 3}$ paired IR-depth frames from 7 subjects. Our results show that LoRA-based adaptation transfers effectively to IR without full retraining, delivering accurate depth predictions while keeping memory and compute overhead modest. This study provides a practical pipeline for IR-based depth estimation and highlights the value of modality-aligned data and lightweight adaptation for real-world systems.

title: Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach for Efficient Spectrum Utilization in 5G and Future Cognitive Networks
authors: T. Jaya, Mohammad Omar Sabri, B. Dharani, M. Brahmam, CH Srivardhan Kumar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The sheer increase in the number of connected devices of the 5G and beyond wireless networks has compounded the pressure on smart and dynamic spectrum sharing. Conventional spectrum allocation algorithms such as static assignment, game-theoretic optimization, and single-agent reinforcement learning struggle with the high-dimensional, diverse, and time-varying characteristics of cognitive radio environments. To overcome these difficulties, the proposed study proposes a Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MADRL) framework that can be used to facilitate cooperative and decentralized spectrum management between multiple cognitive radio users. The agents set policies in a collaborative manner, and each can learn the best policies using Deep Q-Networks (DQN) with Actor-Critic system aggregation around each agent independent of the other agent, observing local environmental states, which include channel occupancy, signal-to-interference-plusnoise ratio (SINR), and transmission power levels of the agent. The suggested framework exploits the idea of interagent communication and experience sharing and reduces spectral collisions, increases throughput, and maximizes energy efficiency. The proposed MADRL-based model under dynamic traffic and user mobility conditions has a 32 % improvement in spectrum utilization efficiency, 25% decrease in interference, and 20 % energy saving as compared to conventional Q-learning and single-agent DRL frameworks. Combining multi-agent coordination and deep reinforcement learning offers scalability, adaptability and robustness needed in next-generation cognitive 6 G networks to provide intelligent, selforganizing, and sustainable spectrum management. This research is expected to result in a very adaptive spectrum allocation scheme that will allow improving the performance, reliability, and spectral fairness of a network in heterogeneous and high-density communication scenarios.

title: An Efficient LightGBM-Based Machine Learning Framework for Water Quality Assessment in Urban Environments
authors: Santhosh G, L.M.I.Leo Joseph, S. Sampath Kumar, S.T. Gopukumar, A. Aranganathan, Merlin Sheeba G, G.Sajiv, Ganesan P
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Adequate supply of safe water is a major problem in urban centers that are rapidly expanding. Conventional water quality observation strategies tend to be reactive instead of predictive, expensive in terms of resources to carry out, and time-consuming. The paper introduces an effective and scalable machine learning model with the use of Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) to evaluate water quality in an urban settings. The analysis adopts an extensive dataset that consists of twenty numerical parameters including chemical, physical, and microbial measures like aluminium, arsenic, chloramine, bacteria, and viruses. The suggested model label the water samples as safe or not safe depending on threshold values set against individual parameters. Detailed experimental comparisons show that LightGBM model is more accurate and better than several baseline classifiers such as SVM, kNN, Random Forest, AdaBoost and Gradient Boosting in terms of accuracy, F1 score, AUC and MCC. The LightGBM framework resulted in a classification accuracy of 95.1 percent, thus proving its strength and feasibility to be implemented in the real world. The current study provides an efficient approach to solve the problems of water quality monitoring in urban areas through the automation process and encouraging active measures by the population to protect their health.

title: Novel Inductively-Gated FET Diodes for Microwave Rectifiers
authors: Taisei Shimada, Shinichi Tanaka
abstract: This paper presents a novel inductively-gated FET diode (IGFD) for microwave power transmission (MPT), enabling near-zero threshold-voltage operation through inductive gate driving. The IGFD effectively addresses key limitations of conventional rectifiers in MPT systems, achieving high sensitivity in low-power operation and reduced loss in high-power scenarios. Its fundamental operation was experimentally validated using rectifiers based on either low-noise FETs or power FETs. Compared to existing rectifiers based on Schottky barrier diodes or on Gated Anode Diodes (GADs), which are also FET-based, the IGFD demonstrates superior performance across a wide input power range, clearly highlighting its strong potential for various MPT applications.

title: Design of a Modified Gysel Power Divider with Enhanced Isolation and Integrated Harmonic Rejection
authors: Hong-Yu Chen, Ching-Wen Tang
abstract: A modified Gysel power divider is proposed for applications requiring simultaneous broadband isolation and harmonic suppression. The design first focuses on enhancing isolation performance. A matching network is integrated with the conventional Gysel power divider to generate multiple isolation zeros. Furthermore, two additional isolation zeros are created by adding parallel open-circuited stepped-impedance stubs to the output ports. This configuration achieves an impressive 90% isolation fractional bandwidth while also enhancing passband selectivity. To address the harmonic responses that are inherent in the wideband design, a broadband band-stop filter is incorporated at the input port. This filter generates three transmission zeros at 7.3 GHz, 10 GHz, and 12.63 GHz, enabling a significant 20 dB suppression of the second harmonic. The proposed design successfully provides a high-performance power divider that addresses two critical limitations of conventional structures.

title: Research on Key Technologies of Computing Power Adaptation and Scheduling in Power Grid Operation State
authors: Chao Zhang, Heyi Zhang, Shuo Zhang, Yana Zhu, Jiaqi Chen, Jiarong Xie
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the growth of new power systems and large-scale renewable integration, power grid operations demand smarter and faster computing resource scheduling. This paper proposes machine learning–based technologies for computing power forecasting and adaptive scheduling. It analyzes the causes and patterns of computing demand, establishes a load–demand mapping model, and uses an LSTM network for accurate prediction. A reinforcement learning algorithm enables dynamic optimization of computing allocation. A simulation platform compares static, heuristic, and ML-based adaptive strategies. Results show that the ML-based method greatly improves task delay, resource utilization, scheduling success, and load balancing, demonstrating strong advantages in efficiency and adaptability for intelligent power grid operation.

title: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface-Aided Spatial Modulation with Signature Constellation
authors: Fanyu Zeng, Yuyang Peng, Qi Jin, Ming Yue, Runlong Ye, Liping Xiong
abstract: In recent years, a number of new technologies have emerged in the sixth generation (6G) wireless communication area. Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) technologies have been widely studied because of their strong flexibility for signal adjustment. Combined with transmit spatial modulation (TSM), the RIS-aided TSM (RIS-TSM) system can significantly boost spectral efficiency (SE) while enhancing the received signal quality. In this paper, in order to overcome the effect of correlation among transmit antennas in RIS-TSM systems, we propose an RIS-aided transmit signature constellation based spatial modulation (RIS-TSSM) scheme with a complete system model and expressions. Simulation results depict that RIS-TSSM system can achieve better performance than the RIS-TSM system in the presence of antenna correlation.

title: Domain-Adversarial Neural Networks for Cross-Dataset Pneumonia Detection in Chest X-Rays
authors: Soumya Darshan Behera, Deepankar Satpathy, Nihar Ranjan Mohapatra, Umesh Chandra Pati
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Pneumonia remains a major global health challenge, particularly in regions where radiological expertise is limited. While deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have achieved expert-level accuracy on well-curated chest X-ray datasets, their performance degrades significantly when applied across domains due to distributional discrepancies, or domain shift. In this study, we present a Domain-Adversarial Neural Network (DANN)-based framework for unsupervised cross-dataset pneumonia detection. Our approach employs a DenseNet121-based feature extractor shared between a label classifier and a domain discriminator connected via a Gradient Reversal Layer (GRL). The model is trained on the pediatric Kermany dataset and evaluated on a balanced subset of the NIH ChestX-ray14 dataset without access to target labels. To mitigate the severe class imbalance in the source domain, class-weighted binary cross-entropy loss is used. Our proposed DANN architecture achieves an area under the ROC(Receiver Operating Characteristic curve)curve (AUC) of 0.6803 and an F1-score of 0.6762 on the target domain, outperforming multiple non-adapted CNN baselines. Further validation is provided through UMAP visualizations, which illustrate improved feature alignment across domains. In addition, McNemar’s test (p < 0.001) confirms the model’s ability to learn robust, domain-invariant representations. The key contribution of this work is the development and validation of a DANN-based framework that explicitly addresses the pediatric-to-adult domain shift in pneumonia detection, validated using UMAP visualization and McNemar’s test, providing one of the first systematic demonstrations of adversarial domain adaptation for medical imaging.

title: Multi-Layer UPI Fraud Detection Using Machine Learning
authors: AmruthaPodipireddy, Rebaka Suneel Kumar, Divya Eepu, Srinu Koona, Alekya Reddy, Vasu Swayambarapu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: UPI has transformed the way consumers pay online, making the transaction faster and easier. It is now used for everyday activities such as shopping, bill payment, and money transfers. However, as more people use UPI, the frequency of fraud instances has increased. Fake QR codes, fraudulent links, and other deceptive approaches are common tricks. To address this issue, we developed a system that detects fraud using machine learning. It operates in two steps. In the first stage, we identify fraud using models such as Random Forest, XGBoost, and Logistic Regression that learn from previous transaction data. The second level focuses on unknown threats.We use techniques such as clustering and Isolation Forest to identify unique QR codes or URLs that could suggest new types of fraud. Each stage generates a fraud score, which we combine for greater accuracy. We also used Gradio to construct a simple real-time alert interface. This enables payment providers to promptly detect and prevent suspicious conduct, protecting both users and companies.

title: nextGenAgri: AI Powered Disease Prediction and Fertilizer Optimization to Avoid Economic Loss
authors: Manmohan Kumar, Ujjwal Biswas
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Agriculture is crucial for developing economies. Particularly in India, a large portion of the population depends on agriculture for their livelihood. However, there are many challenges in disease prediction and optimizing the use of fertilizer. This paper presents the novel aspects of recommending appropriate treatments for plants. We use deep learning (DL) to design system for detecting plant leaf diseases, addressing the current research challenges for fertilizer optimization. We have implemented advanced convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures: MobileNetV2, EfficientNetB0, and ResNet50 to classify plant leaf images. We used ten categories, including bacterial, fungal, and viral diseases, as well as healthy leaves. The system was trained and evaluated using a large, multimodal dataset. We observed that EfficientNetB0 achieved superior performance with a higher accuracy of 96.73% compared with both Mo-bileNetV2 and ResNet50 in effectively classifying plant leaf diseases. Our findings show that early disease diagnosis and customized treatment recommendations made possible by the suggested framework can greatly enhance agricultural decision-making.

title: Intelligent Burn Fault Detection in Low-Voltage Meter Boxes Using the TransSMOTE Framework
authors: Yanzhao Tu, Zhiwu Wu, Chunguang Wang, Hanbin Huang, Tongyao Lin, Honghui Yu, Tingting Wu, Yunru Liao
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In the current construction of smart grids, the safe operation of low-voltage meter boxes is of great significance to the stability of the power system. However, influenced by factors such as poor contact, overload, and ambient temperature rise during long-term operation, these meter boxes are prone to burn faults, which in severe cases can lead to power interruptions and fire risks. To address this issue, this paper proposes a deep learning-based method for detecting burn faults in low-voltage meter boxes. First, the SMOTE oversampling technique is introduced to augment minority-class samples, alleviating the issues of small sample size and class imbalance, thereby enhancing the model's ability to identify burn faults. Then, the Transformer model is utilized to model multi-dimensional time-series data such as voltage, current, and power factor. Based on the self-attention mechanism, this model effectively captures long-term dependencies and potential anomaly patterns. On this basis, this paper constructs the TransSMOTE-BurnAlert framework, integrating the synergistic effects of data augmentation and deep modeling. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves remarkable performance in the fault detection task, with a classification accuracy of 81.33% and a recall rate of 81.33%. This study provides robust technical support for the intelligent detection of burn faults in low-voltage meter boxes, contributing to the safe and stable operation of the distribution system.

title: Multimodal Deep Learning-Integrated Battery Management System for Electric Vehicles
authors: Ajay Tiwari, Kalyan Devappa Bamane, Abhijeet Gajanan Chimankar, Swaraj Sathish Kadam, J. Yogaraja, Rajrupa Ray Chaudhuri
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The opening of the market for electric vehicles (EV) with the latest technological developments postures the need for intelligent solutions for performance increase, longevity and safety, including battery management systems (BMS). This research is to proffer the development of Multimodal Deep Learning Integrated battery management System (MDL-BMS) and by fusing Heterogeneous data stream containing voltage, current, temperature and Electrochemical signal for accurate estimation of state of Battery. Based on a Graph Neural Network (GNN) based temporal-spatial deep learning framework, the proposed framework is able to capture the complex correlation among the several modalities as well as to take into account the temporal dynamics of the battery degradation process. Pre-processing of the data and model training is performed using PyTorch Lightning in order to provide efficient and scalable experiment features. Simulation studies on genuine life EV battery data-sets demonstrate the MDL-BMS substantially psychological the typified built construction mistake and optimistic expectations correctness for various functioning advices. The addition of multimodal learning not only improves prediction accuracy but also gives interpretability on the behaviour of the battery exploring the opportunity of pro-active maintenance and best energy management strategy for the next generation EVs.

title: Density Peak Clustering Analysis Method Based on UMAP Data Reconstruction
authors: Fan Wang, Jianqi Song
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: Density peak clustering (DPC) is a clustering algorithm based on fast search and discovery of density peak points. In recent years, DPC has gained widespread attention from researchers due to its advantages of not requiring the pre-specification of the number and shape of clusters, and being insensitive to noise and outliers. However, since the density and density peak point calculations of DPC are dependent on Euclidean distance, there are two problems: 1) it is not suitable for manifold structures, and 2) it inevitably faces the “curse of dimensionality” in complex high-dimensional data, which can lead to a decline in the algorithm's clustering performance. To address these two problems, this paper proposes the U-DPC method, which utilizes the UMAP algorithm, one of the most outstanding algorithms in manifold learning, to preprocess the data by reducing its dimensions, and then uses the DPC algorithm to complete the clustering. Experimental results show that compared with DPC, the clustering performance of U-DPC algorithm on high-dimensional data, such as single-cell sequencing and images, is improved by over 20% in terms of the ACC metric.

title: Analyzing the Impact of Daily Screen Usage on Eye Health Through the Machine Learning Models
authors: Vijayakumar P, Avanthika Vijayakumar, Kalpana T, Dharshini V, Kanaga Durga M, Karthikeyan P
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: As a result of the increased exposure to digital screens, concerns about ocular health issues such as dryness, irritation, headaches, and blurred vision have increased. This study uses supervised machine learning algorithms to estimate risk for screen exposure associated eye disorders based on screen time, lifestyle and/or co-morbidities. The Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) was used to mitigate class imbalance to conduct analyses on a dataset with 12 features. Classifiers, including Gradient Boosting, AdaBoost, and XGBoost were trained and evaluated on accuracy, ROC AUC, RMSE and classification reports. Feature importance found daily screen time, break frequency, and pre-existing eye disorders to be the most important predictors. These results support preventative health care practices, promote healthier screen use in technological societies, and help identify at risk patients at an early stage.

title: Enhanced Multi-Zonal Forest Type Classification Using YOLOv8 and EuroSAT for Scalable Environmental Monitoring
authors: Nakka Vijay Bhasker Reddy, Moturi Sirisha, Nagaram Prasad Rao, Mundlamuri Vijaya Kumarachari, Dodda Venkata Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Forests are a critical component of our world’s health, but it is still difficult today to see them properly over large distances. This research proposes a real-world and intelligent solution using satellite images and DL to detect forest stands with greater accuracy. Aiming to achieve faster and more scalable forest analysis than traditional field surveys, this study develops an automated land cover identification system using the EuroSAT dataset. The primary objective of this research was to train and compare the YOLOv8-nano model in order to analyze its performance in detecting forests and other land covers. The model was validated using 27,000 images across 10 different classes in order to provide extensive exposure to a variety of data. It showed robust performance with a peak accuracy of 97.5%. These results emphasize the high capabilities of the model for real-time forest observation and wise environmental decision making. In general, this research is an important step towards using artificial intelligence and satellite imagery to enhance conservation, as well as to more effectively manage forest resources at different locations.

title: From Clicks to Closet: A Multimodal Recommendation System for E-Commerce Fashion Using Computer Vision and Machine Learning Technologies
authors: Sreeja B.P, Dhinakar K, Jayakannan A, Pradeesh V, Sangitha Shri G
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The “Clicks to Closet” project enhances online fashion recommendations from combining text and image analysis. By utilizing BERT to analyse product descriptions and reviews and ResNet for extracting visual features, this platform generates recommendations through a hybrid model that merges these two data types. KNN is applied for identifying similar products and its effectiveness is measured using recall, precision, accuracy and F1 score. This method improves the quality of recommendations and increase customer satisfactions. This gives the significance of integrating multimodal data ine-commercefashion and the research introduced an innovative AI-based recommendation system for the ecommercefashion sector, which included a virtual try-on option for enhanced customer service. In addition to it the virtual try-on feature allows users to visualize items like clothing and accessories by combining textual and visual multimodal data to offer personalized product suggestions according to individual persons preferences. By utilizing real-time input, the system consistently improves its recommendations, ensuring accuracy and relevance for the customers. The effectiveness of the system will be assessed using metrics such as precision, latency and user satisfaction. The effort focuses on the user's e-commerce platform that align with the needs from the fashion industry and market.

title: Sustainability in the Urban Context: Evaluating Metro Manila Residents' Intention to Accept and Adopt Vertical Farming
authors: Shantelle N. Magsino, Vanessa Mae S. Malabuyoc, Ritchie Ybañez, Ma. Kathleen L. Duran, Ferly Ann R. Revilloza
abstract: Rapid urbanization in Metro Manila has intensified challenges in food security, environmental sustainability, and resource efficiency. This study investigates the intention of Metro Manila residents to accept and adopt vertical farming as a viable urban agricultural solution. Anchored on the Theory of Planned Behavior, Sustainable Development Theory, and Diffusion of Innovation Theory, the research examines how economic, societal, and environmental factors influence behavioral intention. A structured questionnaire was administered to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> residents using stratified random sampling. Data were analyzed using Partial Least Squares-Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) to identify the relationships among variables. Results revealed that economic and environmental factors significantly affect residents' adoption intention, while societal factors and attitudes toward sustainability integration showed limited influence. The study also highlights the role of perceived behavioral control and subjective norms in shaping adoption behavior. Findings suggest that enhancing public awareness, policy support, and cost-accessibility could facilitate the integration of vertical farming into urban sustainability initiatives. This research provides evidence-based insights for policymakers, urban planners, and agricultural innovators aiming to promote vertical farming in densely populated cities like Metro Manila.

title: Enhanced Performance of AlN/GaN HEMTs via Novel LPCVD-Based Sub-Gate Oxidation
authors: Zhiyong Liu, Jiejie Zhu, Lingjie Qin, Bowen Zhang, Mengdi Li, Boxuan Gao, Xiaohua Ma
abstract: This work demonstrates a novel approach featuring low-temperature 300°C 5 mins thermal oxidation of the AlN/gate metal interface performed prior to ohmic contact formation to eliminate thermal degradation of contacts. Compared to standard non-oxidized Schottky device, this optimized flow delivers an order-of-magnitude reduction in gate leakage current, alongside a 16.4% increase in peak transconductance (g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m,max</inf>) and a 7.3% enhancement in maximum drain current (I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DMAX</inf>). Comparative C-V analysis showed minimal capacitance variation but revealed a slight negative threshold voltage shift with increasing temperature. This highly effective, equipment-shared approach is promising for next-generation high-performance GaN power and RF electronics.

title: Modeling Contextual Inconsistency in Fake News Videos with MMCAN
authors: Li Zhang, Tufeng Long, Ziyang Zhang, Jinlin Guo
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: With the rapid growth of short-video platforms, fake video news has become a critical issue, characterized by its high deceptiveness and severe social consequences arising from its multi-modal nature. This paper focuses on a subtle yet insidious variant: fake news with multi-modal contextual inconsistencies. In such content, creators deliberately embed semantic contradictions across modalities and disrupt context within modalities to mislead viewers. Existing methods, however, struggle to detect these manipulations effectively, largely because they lack deep modeling of contextual relations and fail to replicate the staged, iterative attention mechanisms of human cognition. Addressing this gap, we propose a cognitive-inspired architecture named the Multi-stage Multi-modal Contextual Attention Network (MMCAN). By employing a six-stage cascaded design, MMCAN progressively fuses features from text (e.g., headlines, subtitles), visuals (e.g., frames), and audio (e.g., speech, background music) to simulate the human cognitive process of iterative verification. Empirical results on a public dataset demonstrate that our model significantly surpasses existing state-of-the-art methods. Our study highlights that incorporating cognitive principles and modeling both intra- and inter-modal dependencies are essential for advancing multi-modal fake video news detection.

title: Mapping the Research Landscape of Artificial Intelligence in Education
authors: Komgrit Rumdon, Jaturong Chitiyaphol, Kanyarat Kwiecien, Nawapon Kaewsuwan, Jirachaya Jeawkok, Thanidaphat Saengtong, Wannisa Matcha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) transforms education by enabling fast and unique content creation, generating adaptive learning, customizing teaching practices, and assisting the assessment process. However, the fast growing in number of publications introduces challenges in understanding the state of knowledge, dominant themes and identification of future direction. This study applies a bibliometric analysis to mapping the landscape of GenAI in educations. The data used in this study were retrieved from the Scopus database, resulting in 2,965 articles included based on systematic selection criteria. VOSviewer, a bibliometric analysis tool, was used for network visualization and analysis of co-authorship and keyword co-occurrence. The findings unveiled that over 90% of the included studies appeared between 2023 and 2025. The majority of the articles were retrieved from computer sciences, health professions, and social sciences. Ethical consideration is a central observation across these fields. The results provided an overview of GenAI in education and highlighted key themes in each field of study.

title: Glass-Based Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface for 6G Upper-Mid Band Applications
authors: Seokyeon Hong, Seunggoo Nam, Sehwan Choi, Youngju Kim, Byungdu Kim
abstract: This paper proposes a glass-based reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) for 6G upper-mid band applications (7.125–7.8 GHz). Unlike typical RIS designs that use patterned films laminated onto glass, our method directly forms a metal mesh grid on a transparent glass substrate and mounts electronic components such as PIN diodes or varactors using surface-mount technology (SMT). This process removes the need for a separate film layer, maintains transparency, and simplifies fabrication. The transparent and integrated structure allows the RIS to be installed on building windows or glass walls without additional support, enabling it to function as a coverage enhancement repeater. This design offers a practical and scalable way to apply RIS in future 6G communication environments. A protective cover glass may also be considered in future designs to enhance environmental durability for outdoor deployments.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Off-Road Path Planning with Dual Constraints from RF-LIO and DEM Perception
authors: Xingyu Zhou, Yutong Jiang, Zhiqi Du, Fan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In off-road autonomous navigation, both localization and perception suffer from significant uncertainty due to irregular terrain, vegetation occlusion, and sparse sensor measurements. Traditional path planning methods generally optimize efficiency, comfort, or energy consumption, but rarely account for the uncertainty of localization and environment modeling. This often leads to unreliable trajectories in challenging environments. To address this issue, we propose an uncertainty-aware path planning framework that explicitly integrates dual uncertainty constraints from both RF-LIO-based(Tightly coupled positioning) localization and DEM-based terrain perception. Specifically, localization uncertainty is quantified from the covariance of RF-LIO pose estimation, while perception uncertainty is modeled from DEM(Digital Elevation Model) cell statistics including point density, elevation variance, and missing-data ratio. These two uncertainty costs are incorporated into a unified planning cost function for both global and local planners. Experimental results in grassland, forest, gravel, and slope environments demonstrate that the proposed method improves task success rate and navigation robustness by avoiding high-uncertainty areas, while maintaining reasonable efficiency.

title: A Coupled CFD–ML Approach to Multi-Objective Optimization of Wind box Structures with Experimental Validation
authors: Shizhao Zhen, Di Zhou, Shihao Li, Huimin Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of uneven drying, dye migration and high energy consumption caused by uneven air outlet from the wind box in the knitted fabric pre-drying system, this paper proposes a multi-objective optimization method based on the integrated Bayesian agent model. The shape of the wind box and the deflector plate are parametrically modelled by the sixth-order Bézier curve. An integrated Bayesian agent model fusing Gaussian process regression (GPR), gradient boost tree (LSBoost) and neural network (NN) is constructed to achieve high-precision prediction and uncertainty quantification through Softmax adaptive weighted fusion with cross-validation error. On this basis, a ParEGO multi-objective optimization strategy based on the Bayesian optimization framework is introduced to screen the Pareto solution set by Sobol sequence sampling with non-dominated ordering. The results show that the method can effectively achieve the three-objective co-optimization under the limited sample condition. The maximum deviation is found to be no more than 12% by Fluent numerical simulation verification, which verifies the reliability of the EBSM model. The simulation results of the whole duct flow field are highly consistent with the measured data, and the air outlet is more uniform.

title: Optical Emission Spectroscopy and Neural Network Regression for Argon Flow Monitoring in PVD Processes
authors: Yu-Chieh Chen, Yi-Cheng Lin, Jin-Yu Shih, Wen-Tse Hsiao, Cheng-Tang Pan
abstract: This study presents a proof-of-concept approach for non-contact argon flow rate prediction in Physical Vapor Deposition (PVD) processes, combining Optical Emission Spectroscopy (OES) with a feedforward neural network (FNN). Conventional flowmeters cannot be integrated inside vacuum chambers, motivating OES-based machine learning as a non-invasive alternative. Three normalized Al/Ar spectral ratios (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{396} / I_{750}, I_{396} / I_{763}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{396} / I_{811}$</tex>) were used as input features. A dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> spectra under varying flow conditions was collected, with Gaussian noise added to emulate realistic fluctuations. The FNN, consisting of two hidden layers (128 and 64 neurons), was trained using the Adam optimizer with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\ell_{2}$</tex> regularization. The model achieved MAE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=5.26 \text{sccm}, \text{RMSE}=6.96 \text{sccm}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.982$</tex> on the training set, while the test set yielded MAE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=9.41$</tex> sccm, RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=22.64 \text{sccm}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.827$</tex>. Residual analysis and learning curves indicate good feasibility at moderate flows, with underestimation at higher flows due to nonlinear plasma effects and dataset limitations. These findings highlight both the promise and challenges of OES-based neural regression, providing a foundation for extending this methodology to Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) processes, where energy efficiency and carbon reduction are of greater importance. In the future, the approach may support real-time monitoring and closed-loop gas control for sustainable semiconductor thin-film manufacturing.

title: Antenna Solutions Employing Coupling-Fed Techniques for Improved Platform Noise Immunity
authors: Chung-Hao Huang, Chao-Chin Xu, Kuan-Hsueh Tseng, Chen-Kun Yang
abstract: The receiving performance of the Planar Inverted-F Antenna (PIFA) in wireless devices is significantly affected by electromagnetic interference and environmental noise, with PIFAs demonstrating weaker noise immunity compared to other antennas under similar conditions. In order to improve their interference resistance without altering existing spatial constraints, this study proposes a coupling-fed antenna design that excites backside copper foil resonances within the original clearance and substrate dimensions. Experimental results show this design achieves approximately 3 dB noise suppression across a wide frequency range and up to 5 dB improvement within the 2440–2450 MHz narrowband, effectively enhancing signal quality and communication reliability.

title: Federated Deep Learning Framework for Privacy-Preserving Cancer
authors: Mohammed Mohammud Habash, Basma Hameed Mageed Alaagam, Omar khaleel Ibrahim, Mohammed Shaker Motib, GhasaqMa'an Bakr, OzdanAkram Ghareeb
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The research suggests a Federated Deep Learning Framework to Privacy-Preserving Cancer Diagnosis which is aimed at allowing several medical institutions to engage in collaborative learning without breaching the confidentiality of patient information. It consists of the Z-Score Normalization of standardized preprocessing, Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) of the most suitable features and BiLSTM with Attention classifier, which exploits intricate temporal and spatial interactions among multi-modal cancer data. The system is implemented with TensorFlow Federated (TFF), guaranteeing decentralized training and safe aggregation of the parameters, without having to exchange raw data. It has been shown through experimental tests to have an accuracy of 95.7, large convergence rate, and communication efficiency. The hybrid privacy policy is a way of reducing leakage risk and still retaining model robustness. The study lays the groundwork toward a scalable and secure framework of distributed cancer diagnostics, the inter-institutional cooperation, the increased accuracy of early detection, and the adherence to the current healthcare data privacy standards.

title: Dual-Attention Diffusion Vision Network with Zero-Shot Adaptation for High-Fidelity Image Reconstruction
authors: G Balachandran, G C Jagan, Ranjith S, A Sajitha
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: High-fidelity image reconstruction under unknown degradation conditions is a persistent challenge in computer vision. Classical restoration methods are usually based on task related priors or guided learning of known distortions which restrict their application in natural contexts. The paper presents a new Dual-Attention Diffusion Vision Network (DADV-Net) with Zero-Shot Adaptation to be used to perform robust and perceptually accurate image reconstruction. The presented model is a U-Net-based diffusion generative backbone with two-attention modules Global Self-Attention as a semantic structure preservation and Local Cross-Attention as a texture refinement, which allows it to acquire rich contextual priors and reconstruct images even in the case of severe degradation. To boost the generalization, we add a Feature-wise Linear Modulation (FiLM) layer that is trained through meta-learning to enable the model to change dynamically to new types of degradation without requiring retraining. Assessments in ten standard and real-world degradation environments show that DADV-Net performs better than state-of-the-art baseline on both fidelity and perceptual quality. The model attains the highest PSNR of 34.3 dB, SSIM of 0.964, and the zero-shot generalization rate of 84.7 % and with steadily increasing LPIPS and inference rates. The method of Ablation establishes the personal contribution of both dual-attention and zero-shot layers. Moreover, the subjective ratings of human beings put DADV-Net in the forefront of the most aesthetically appealing image among various standards. The results indicate that the architecture proposed can be a scalable, general purpose solution to image reconstruction across domains.

title: A High-tolerance Planar Coupler Based on BGA Process for Low-cost Phased Array
authors: Chao Tang, Zongrui He, Wei Nie, Jing Ye
abstract: The burgeoning LEO (low-Earth-orbit) satellite applications necessitate cost-effective phased-array antennas for the large-scale deployment of satellite internet terminals. Conventional aperture-shared phased arrays exhibit high manufacturing costs due to complex multi-layer stacking structures. To address this problem, this paper proposes a high-tolerance planar coupler based on low-cost BGA (ball grid array) split integration. This design utilizes a split architecture, which decouples the antenna elements from the feed network. As a result, the physical integration constraints between the active circuit and the passive antenna are eliminated. This significantly reduces fabrication complexity and manufacturing costs for phased arrays. The return loss of the planar coupler from 10.7 to 14.5 GHz is greater than 13 dB. The amplitude imbalance is less than 0.7dB, and the phase difference is 90° ± 6°. Finally, the design also tolerates processing variations during BGA assembly, enabling low-cost mass production of phased arrays.

title: Research on Target Detection Algorithm in Complex Road Background
authors: Xiao Wang, Li Chen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Control and Computing (IC&amp;C)
abstract: An improved DF-YOLOv8 algorithm was proposed to solve the problem of decreasing target detection accuracy under the influence of occlusion, small target and other factors during target detection on complex road background. FIoU calculated the diagonal distance of the overlap area of the IoU of the real box and the predicted box. Compared with the center point distance of CIoU, the diagonal distance is more suitable for the calculation of the IoU Loss function of the occluded target. The CIoU in the algorithm was replaced by FIoU to improve the regression accuracy of the algorithm for the occluded target. A multi-scale convolution module DCD is proposed for small target problem. The module uses convolution of different scales to extract features of different scales, and fuses channel features of four convolution channels to exchange channel information. To obtain a more comprehensive and rich feature representation. A multi-scale convolutional network is constructed by replacing common convolution in C2f with DCD module to improve the effect of small target detection. The experimental results were compared and verified on the KITTI target detection dataset, and finally the ablation experiment was conducted and compared with the current mainstream detection algorithms, which fully proved the effectiveness of DF-YOLOv8.

title: A Novel and Simple Measurement Technique for Two-Wire Resistive Sensors in Remote Applications
authors: Elangovan K
abstract: This work presents a simplified and accurate measurement technique for two-wire resistive sensors placed in remote locations, addressing the challenge of cable resistance. The proposed circuit utilizes bipolar current excitation and diode switching to generate a square-wave output voltage, from which the sensor resistance is extracted through voltage averaging. Simulation results confirm high precision with a nonlinearity of 0.0006 % and a relative error of 0.007 %, while cable resistance dependency shows a maximum error of only 0.004 %. Experimental validation using RTD-Pt100 characteristics over a temperature range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 850° C demonstrates linear performance with nonlinearity and relative error within 0.44 % and 0.91 %, respectively. The circuit also shows limited sensitivity to cable resistance variations, maintaining output errors below 0.28 %. With its simple architecture, low component count, reduced power consumption, and cost efficiency, the proposed method offers an alternative for accurate remote measurement of resistive sensors.

title: A Framework for Evaluating Supply Chain Performance the Mediating Role of Transparency in Digital Transformation
authors: S. Aneesha Bhanu, M. Krithika
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper explores how the digital transformation of the supply chain affects t0he performance of the supply chain alongside its effects on the supply chain transparency as a possible mediator. Descriptive statistics based on the dataset of 35 valid responses ensured the completeness of the sample used and moderate variation of the demographic characteristics. The digital transformation, technology adoption and performance outcome showed that these are strong and significant were more than 0.90, which shows that they close interconnections. Findings of regression showed that combined effect of digital transformation and technology was a significant predictor of supply chain performance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{F}(2,302)=3200.445, \mathrm{p}<.001)$</tex>, with a significant proportion of variance explained. Coefficients showed that both digital transformation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\beta=0.511)$</tex> and technology <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\beta=0.489)$</tex> have significant positive effects on performance but the effect of digital transformation was much stronger. The assumption tests by the use of residual histograms showed the errors were normally distributed thus validating the regression model. The mediation analysis also showed that supply chain transparency was also a mediator but its direct impact on performance. Over all the digital transformation technology using of transparency directly impact the supply chain performance positively.

title: Experimental Verification of Null Steering Using Wi-Fi Sniffing for Coexistence of Microwave Power Transfer and Wi-Fi
authors: Ryugo Sato, Luming Feng, Zhengdong Lin, Hiroyuki Morikawa, Yoshiaki Narusue
abstract: Microwave power transfer (MPT) is a promising technology, but its high-power signals pose a significant interference challenge to co-located low-power communication systems such as Wi-Fi. To address this, we demonstrate an interference suppression scheme in which an MPT transmitter sniffs Wi-Fi frames and uses the extracted channel state information (CSI) to form a null in a Wi-Fi device. However, the accuracy of this scheme is limited by hardware-induced phase offsets. Therefore, to compensate, a two-step calibration method was employed. In a proof-of-concept experiment, this calibration reduced phase estimation error from over 20° to under 5°, which improved the null depth by up to 11.0 dB for a total interference suppression of over 20 dB. This work experimentally verifies that null-steering based on sniffed frames is a viable strategy for MPT and Wi-Fi coexistence.

title: Scalable VLSI Design for Edge AI Acceleration in Real-Time Audio-Visual Processing Systems
authors: K Bhasakara Rao, Safeyah Tawil, R Suresh Kumar, G Sridevi, Sreekanth Sura, Popuri Ramesh Babu
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The high rate of Edge AI application development requires scalable streamlined energy-effective hardware solutions, which can handle real-time audio-visual processing at the edge with little latency and consumption. Current accelerators such as GPUs and FPGAs frequently do not support multimodal data streams which is utilizing high energy, with an efficient synchronization. In a bid to avoid these constraints, the proposed Scalable VLSI Design Framework to Edge AI Acceleration in Real-Time Audio-Visual Processing Systems is a synthesis of hierarchical dataflow-based VLSI architecture, systolic array-based parallel computing, and dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) as means of optimizing performance. Swift compression-conscious interconnects and dynamic hardware division are also built in to the design in order to create the efficient synchronization of audio and visual channels. The proposed model is analysed with 7 nm CMOS technology that demonstrates the notable enhancements in throughput processing and efficiency of power along with interference latency estimation which is less than 10 ms per frame and accuracy enhancement of 13% which is better than the other existing frameworks. The obtained results are clearly depicting that the proposed framework is well suitable for real time applications such as smart surveillance, UAVs and in HMIs.

title: ActivityNet-HE: An Encryption-Enabled Deep Learning-Based Framework for Secure Human Activity Monitoring
authors: Ahsanul Islam, Sadia Akter, Tahsina Farah Sanam
abstract: An increasingly popular non-intrusive monitoring technique in smart environments is the recognition of human activities using Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI). However, the exposure of raw CSI data during processing poses significant privacy risks. This paper presents ActivityNet-HE, a deep learning framework designed to perform secure activity recognition through homomorphic encryption. The framework utilizes Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to minimize the dimensionality of the data makes it efficient to compute and extracts 29 statistical and signal-based features from time and frequency domains for each PCA stream. A lightweight neural network with polynomial activation enables encrypted inference without revealing sensitive input data. Evaluated on the CSI-HAR dataset, the model achieves 94.05% accuracy on both encrypted and plain data, demonstrating that strong privacy preservation can be achieved without sacrificing performance. While the system ensures secure inference, it incurs additional latency due to encryption overhead, which may limit its use in low-latency real-time applications. This makes the framework especially relevant for privacy-sensitive cases like monitoring the stereotypical motor movement (SMM) of autistic children in home or healthcare settings.

title: Optimization of Large-Scale Speaker Identification System Based on I-Vector with LDA, PCA, and LSH
authors: Muhammad Zaydan Athallah, Dessi Puji Lestari
publish: 2025 28th Conference of the Oriental COCOSDA International Committee for the Co-ordination and Standardisation of Speech Databases and Assessment Techniques (O-COCOSDA)
abstract: Speaker identification aims to recognize an individual's identity through unique vocal characteristics such as intonation, resonance, and articulation. However, scaling these systems to thousands or even millions of enrolled speakers introduces significant challenges in sustaining both accuracy and computational efficiency. This study presents an optimized framework that integrates dimensionality reduction with efficient retrieval techniques. Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) is applied to enhance inter-speaker discriminability, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is employed to compact feature representations while retaining key variability, and Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH) is leveraged for fast approximate search in large databases. Evaluations on a self-compiled YouTube dataset of 1,500 speakers achieved identification accuracy exceeding 98% and demonstrated up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90 \times$</tex> acceleration over brute-force search, highlighting the effectiveness of combining LDA, PCA, and LSH for large-scale speaker identification.

title: Algorithmic Aesthetics: Machine Learning for Reconstructing Poetic Imagination in English Literature
authors: B. Monika Nair, Pavithra. S, Meera Karthikeyan Nair Sathikumari, Malathy R, S. Mahadevan, R. Kanagaselvam
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This study explores the application of machine learning techniques to reconstruct poetic imagination from English literary texts, bridging computational modeling with human creativity. The structure of the corpus through which the features of the Shakespearean and Sylvia Plath pieces are encoded accommodates structural peculiarities and aesthetic elements that are hybridized based on syntax, semantics, and poetic stylization with the help of hybrid embeddings. The transformer-based model is used to deduce the latent imaginative intent of metaphor, symbolism and tone. Moreover, such generative problems as line continuation, thematic transposition, or style mimicry are carried out with fine-tuned large language models. The explainable AI methods utilizing Lisp machine interpretation are incorporated so that the features could be highlighted to drive imaginative reconstructions. The outcomes show that the model performs well with regard to several measures. The Imaginative Fidelity Score (IFS) ranged at an average of 0.89 and the averages of the affective match between the categories of emotion were at 87%. The average score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.47 / 5$</tex> based on human judgments was on imaginative authenticity and stylistic coherence. Also, thematic transpositions maintained symbolic mapping at an accuracy of more than 90.6% on more complex transitions such as the mapping of Loss to Transformation. This overlap of the fields of computational linguistics and poetic aesthetics creates opportunities in AI-assisted literary criticism, creative writing, and affective computing. The system proposed does not just analyze the poetic texts but also adds to them being a co-creator of the literary exploration. The project could be extended in the future to incorporate cross-lingual poetic re-construction, the inclusion of multimodal metaphors and modeling cultural or historical context to add additional layers to imaginative expressions. The results highlight how subtle human creativity can be represented by the aesthetic of algorithms, to which education, digital humanities, and literary AI applications are relevant.

title: Enhanced Stress Detection in Brain Tissue During Sleep Using Hybrid Ensemble Machine Learning Models
authors: Naveen Kilari, Seeniappan Kaliappan, M.D.Raj Kamal, R Maranan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Machine Learning (ML) is a fast-growing technology, which allows computers to mimic human behavior in making decisions, and is used in many fields, especially in healthcare. This paper is dedicated to identifying human stress during sleep, which is one of the important aspects of the mental and bodily well-being. Stress may be similar to eustress and stress which is distress, and chronic distress causes dire health problems because of hormonal fluctuations including a rise in cortisols and adrenaline. In this study, an ensemble ML model, which is a combination of the Random Forest (RF) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) is proposed to facilitate efficient stress management. The model uses physiological and clinical parameters in the detection of sleep-related stress. RFXGBoost ensemble demonstrated the accuracy of 96 percent, which was better than the current methods, indicating that it is useful in analyzing complex medical data. This finding shows that ensemble learning is better in analysing complex medical data. As the next step of the research, it is necessary to further develop feature engineering methods and investigate advanced ensemble approaches that can enhance diagnostic accuracy used in stress detection systems.

title: Automated Cabin System for Hygiene Compliance Monitoring with Mask, Hairnet, and Handwash Detection
authors: Francis Jann Alagon, Collien Princess Pepito, Elaine Krissmell Miral, Earl Ryan Aleluya, Cherry Mae Villame, Carl John Salaan, Jeralyn Alagon, Abu Ubaidah Shamsudin
abstract: Non-compliance with hygiene protocols-such as wearing a mask or hairnet, and performing proper handwashing-in food manufacturing facilities contributes to food contamination, thereby compromising product quality, consumer trust, and brand integrity.
