Manual inspection methods used to monitor compliance are susceptible to human error and lack objectivity. Thus, the need for an automated solution is prominent. In response, this study developed a cabinbased system integrated with two YOLOv8-trained models: one for detecting mask and hairnet usage, and another for recognizing handwashing gestures. These models were deployed on a mini-computer (Dell OptiPlex 3080). The compliance system follows the protocol outlined as follows: (i) personnel identification via RFID scanning of the employee card, (ii) detection of mask and hairnet usage through camera input, (iii) sequential detection of handwashing gestures, (iv) regulation of door access to food manufacturing areas based on the evaluation outcome, and (v) recording of compliance results for supervisory review. The system achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 99.2% for mask and hairnet compliance, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2. 7 \%}$</tex> for handwashing compliance. These experimental results support the system's potential for deployment in food manufacturing settings to facilitate compliance monitoring and reinforce food safety assurance.

title: Ball Screw Defect Segmentation Integrating Dual-Network Structure and Multi-Attention Mechanism
authors: Pengyang Song, Baolong You, Li Min, Yadong Hao, Yuhan Xu, Guofeng Hong, Shizhe Zheng
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of insufficient segmentation accuracy due to the small target of the pitting area on the surface of the ball screw and the difficulty of detecting the interference of the complex background environment, this paper proposes an improved defect segmentation model based on the DeepLabV3+ network framework. The model first systematically reconstructs the encoder and designs a dual network structure to replace the original backbone network Xception, which realizes cross-architecture feature complementarity to adjust the bidirectional enhancement of local details and global semantics by deeply integrating the feature-intensive characterization capability of RepVGG and the lightweight global attention of MobileViTv3, and at the same time, reduces the redundant computation to enhance the recognition capability of small defective targets; secondly, this paper proposes an improved segmentation model based on DeepLabV3+ network framework. defective targets; secondly, adding the CBAM attention mechanism at the deep output of the backbone network helps the model to strengthen the spatial location of the target, highlight the key information and thus reduce the interference of the background environment; finally, introducing the EMA attention mechanism at the output of the ASPP module enhances the fusion of boundary information of the multi-scale features and effectively improves the feature expression ability of the convolutional neural network. The experimental results show that the model improves mIoU by 4.83%, MPA by 4.36%, and mPrecision by 1.07% on the ball screw dataset compared with the original DeepLabv3+ segmentation model. The model proposed in this study shows some superiority in the ball screw pitting segmentation task even under the double interference of tiny defects and background noise.

title: Intelligent Multi-UAV Docking with Predictive Scheduling and Task Reallocation
authors: Dhanyashriee S, Samson Arun Raj
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The growing use of multi-UAV fleets in domains such as surveillance, logistics, and environmental monitoring demands optimized docking operations to avoid congestion and coverage loss. This work proposes an AI-driven docking management framework combining predictive battery scheduling, cooperative task reallocation, and renewable-powered charging stations. The system forecasts time-to-empty using mission context, environmental data, and discharge history, allocating docking slots to maintain minimum active fleet size. A peer-to-peer protocol ensures seamless mission handover to the nearest capable UAV, while docking stations employ hybrid wireless charging and battery swapping powered mainly by solar energy. Simulations show a 30% reduction in docking conflicts, sustained mission coverage above 95%, and up to 22% higher energy efficiency compared to reactive strategies, enabling scalable, sustainable multi-UAV deployments.

title: Fusing Lexical and Dependent Syntax for Textual Mood Analysis
authors: Jia Liu, Bei Bei Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The integration of language intelligence and advanced model architectures is a game-changer in the new era of AI computing and applications, transforming machines’ ability to understand human emotions. Our BERT enhancement method integrates syntactic information by jointly identifying key emotional words through part-of-speech tagging and dependency parsing. We then use an improved TF-IDF algorithm to construct a dynamic attention weight matrix, which we embed seamlessly into BERT’s Transformer encoding layer. This strategy explicitly utilises syntactic structure when encoding contextual information, ensuring the high accuracy of deep pre-trained models while enhancing interpretability. This provides a more reliable technical approach for natural language sentiment analysis.

title: Building Students' Industry Workplace Skills Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Chien Ching Lee, Ryan Fraser Kirwan
abstract: Effective written communication is a crucial skill for students transitioning to industry, where accurate documentation of project activities and decisions are paramount. However, students' logbook entries are sometimes descriptive, unclear and incoherent. This might be due to them not having a critical reader in mind when writing. This paper evaluates the impact of a structured series of embedded workshops designed to enhance logbook writing skills among Applied Computing students to prepare them for their eightmonth internship under an Integrated Work Study Programme (IWSP). Generative AI (GenAI) took on the role of an interactive and critical reader: as a group of clients in a Requirements Engineering (RE) exercise (lesson 1), as a writing coach (lesson 2) and as an editor (lesson 3). Data was collected via a comparison of students' logbook entries in lesson three compared to lesson one and an end-of-workshop survey. The primary improvements observed between the students' logbook submissions were in critical analysis, content relevance and depth, and the integration of supporting ideas. The survey findings revealed that GenAI, when deployed as a user, helped generate ideas during brainstorming sessions and provided a basic and structured skeleton to kickstart the writing process. GenAI, as a coach, helped students be more objective by considering multiple perspectives. As an editor, it offered clarity and formatting suggestions, which helped students write more clearly and coherently. The findings underscore the effectiveness of AI-assisted workshops in preparing students for industry by developing essential written communication skills, thereby fostering better project documentation and reporting practices.

title: Y-Slot Patch Antenna Using MLP Neural Networks Trained on ADS Circuit Datasets
authors: Muhammad Kamran Shereen, Xiaoguang Liu, Xiaohu Wu, Ayesha Naseem, Muhammad Uzair
abstract: This work presents a dual-source, data-driven surrogate modeling pipeline for Y-slot microstrip patch antennas by leveraging low-complexity, RLC-based equivalent circuit models generated using Advanced Design System (ADS). A supervised multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural network is trained on high-resolution spectral response data derived from ADS simulations, capturing the antenna’s behavior with both forward and inverse modeling capabilities. The forward model predicts S₁₁ and VSWR over a 1 GHz band (3.25–4.25 GHz) from six parametric inputs representing geometric or circuit-level design parameters. Complementarily, the inverse design model enables recovery of optimized design configurations from target spectral responses. Both models demonstrate high prediction accuracy, achieving normalized mean absolute error (MAE) below 0.02. The ADS-derived RLC dataset exhibits low-dimensional yet physically expressive outputs compared to full-wave simulators, which significantly enhances training efficiency and reduces computational burden.

title: Efficient SpMV for GPUs Using Variable-Sized Vectors and CSR Restructuring
authors: Vishal Manjibhai Pateliya, Anshu S Anand
abstract: Sparse matrix-vector multiplication (SpMV) is crucial in many engineering applications, including machine learning, data analytics, and numerical simulation. As matrix sizes expand exponentially, efficient parallel algorithms become increasingly crucial. This work reviews some of the well-known parallel computing strategies, exploring their effectiveness in enhancing algorithmic performance. We focus on techniques for load balancing and data distribution in parallel SpMV, aiming to maximize computational resource utilization. We propose two algorithms for SpMV that attempt to overcome the shortcomings of Flat-SpMV, namely the use of fixed-size vectors and the performance degradation due to irregular matrices. In the first work, we use variable-sized vectors to reduce the partial results, as opposed to fixed-sized vectors used in Flat-SpMV. Further, as the irregular nature of the matrix caused Flat-SpMV to perform slower in warp-level analysis, we developed a new method by reorganizing the sparse matrix structure and applying a variant of Flat-SpMV to it. It outperformed other approaches on more than 70 % of the input matrices.

title: Experimental Study for Investigating Polarization Diversity Effect on Antenna Signal Reception
authors: Trasma Yunita, Achmad Munir
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This paper deals with the experimental study to investigate the effect of polarization diversity on antenna signal reception at a receiver, employing an array antenna with the same and different polarization configurations. Two linear antenna polarizations, i.e., horizontal and vertical, are configured and examined in an anechoic chamber using a triangular array antenna. The transmitter employs polarization diversity, while the receiver evaluates received power signal. The variations in power level of signal reception across different polarization configurations are also presented. The investigation results demonstrate that the use of polarization diversity significantly affects the level power of receiving antenna and stabilizes the power signal reception of receiver.

title: Distributed Inference Software for Large Language Models
authors: Harshavardhan M G, P Praveen Raj, Rishith P, Vasugi I
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) such as LLaMA and BLOOM have revolutionized natural language processing by enabling advanced applications like dialogue systems, summarization, and reasoning. However, their extensive computational demands in terms of GPU memory, processing power, and bandwidth make them unsuitable for execution on consumer-grade or low-resource devices. Current solutions often rely on centralized cloud APIs, which introduce privacy risks, high costs, and dependency on external infrastructure. To overcome these limitations, this research proposes a distributed inference framework that partitions LLMs layer-wise across multiple devices connected via a trusted local network. Each device, acting as either a client or server, contributes according to its computational capacity. Servers host subsets of model layers, while clients orchestrate inference by routing inputs across available servers. The system integrates Hivemind's decentralized hash table (DHT) built on libp2p for expert discovery, pipeline parallelism for distributed execution, 8-bit quantization for memory efficiency, and KV catching for fault tolerance. Evaluation results across LAN and internet environments validate feasibility, demonstrating that models like GPT-2 can be executed on consumer laptops with 4GB VRAM. This work highlights the potential for democratizing access to powerful AI capabilities through collaborative inference.

title: Life Data Analysis (LDA) Using Weibull Distribution Method for Determination of Reliability for Hpsv and Led Street Light
authors: Khairuddin Abdullah, Nor Diana Ruszaini, Asnawi Mohd Busrah
abstract: This study applies Life Data Analysis (LDA), particularly Weibull distribution modeling, to evaluate and compare the reliability, failure patterns, and operational lifespans of High-Pressure Sodium Vapor (HPSV) and Light Emitting Diode (LED) streetlights using real field data. Although LED streetlight technology gained international traction around 2012, its long-term performance was not well documented at the time. In Malaysia, Tenaga Nasional Berhad (TNB) began widespread deployment of LED streetlights in 2016. This study utilizes actual operational and failure data from thousands of units to conduct a statistically rigorous analysis. LDA is a methodical reliability engineering approach that uses time-to-failure data to predict product life and identify failure trends. The Weibull distribution, a versatile tool in LDA, was employed to model failure behaviors of both HPSV and LED lights. In addition to failure modeling, the Mean Time to Failure (MTTF) was calculated for both lighting technologies, serving as a fundamental indicator of reliability. The results demonstrated that LED streetlights possess a significantly higher MTTF compared to HPSV units, confirming their longer lifespan and superior durability in outdoor conditions. These findings reinforce the reliability advantages of LED systems and align with their design intent of long-term, low-maintenance operation.

title: Automatic Detection of Dairy Cows Disease Using Bayesian Optimization Based Hyperparameter Fitting and CBAM Attention Mechanism
authors: K Bhaskar Rao, Maram Y Al-Safarini, R Ramya Sri, Jayabharathi P, Sumana Das, T D Subha
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: By bayesian-optimized ACDBHC, a CBAM attention networks model, to develop automated detection of dairy cow diseases, which is a highly sophisticated method for figuring out animal behaviors by means of video surveillance. The system is highly accurate in behavior detection because it focuses exclusively on six behaviors lying, standing, walking, eating, drinking, and mounting. The data used for the study were gathered in two dairy farms in Hohhot City, Inner Mongolia, where high-definition cameras recorded multi-angle footage of approximately 500 cows. To improve the video quality, the frames were converted into time-series data, which greatly reduced sampling bias. The feature extraction network was augmented with a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) and a Spatial Attention Module (SAM). The module merges spatial and channel attention methods so that the machine can better “see” the object of the research and reduce the background noise. Hyperparameters were fine-tuned by Bayesian methods, thus allowing the algorithm to switch easily between exploration and exploitation so as to improve the validation accuracy. Various metrics such as IoU, Precision-Recall curves, and Cohen's Kappa were employed to assess the accuracy and reliability of the model. The accuracy of the model was improved from 0.60 to over 0.95 by the 150th epoch, Cohen's Kappa ranged between 0.90 and 0.94, and the overall accuracy was between 0.93 and 0.95.

title: A Meta-Ensemble Deep Learning Approach Using EfficientFormerV2 and Swin Tiny Transformer for Skin Lesion Classification
authors: Moturi Sireesha, Yelchuri Siva Rama Krishna Vinay, Hari Lakshmi Sai Manikanta, Prajapathi Satyanarayana
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Timely recognition of skin cancers improves survival chances, yet automated diagnosis is hindered by subtle lesion similarities and uneven class distributions. This study proposes a dual-stream ensemble that integrates EfficientFormerV2 with the Swin Tiny Transformer for multiclass dermoscopic classification using the HAM10000 dataset. Both networks were pretrained on ImageNet and subsequently fine-tuned; their predictions were merged through two strategies: (1) probability-level fusion via weighted soft voting and (2) a meta-ensemble in which a logistic regression model learns from the concatenated logits of both backbones. Unlike earlier works that rely on a single CNN or transformer, this framework leverages the complementary strengths of a lightweight CNN–transformer hybrid and a hierarchical vision transformer. Experiments show that the Swin Tiny model achieves the highest accuracy (∼90%), whereas the logistic-regression ensemble delivers the best balance across classes (macro F1 = 0.8800) and strong discrimination capability (ROC-AUC = 0.9814), with clear improvements on infrequent lesion types such as AKIEC and DF. We also assess inference cost and model size, highlighting EfficientFormerV2’s suitability for resource-limited deployment. While evaluation is restricted to HAM10000, future work will include cross-dataset studies and integration of clinical metadata. Overall, the proposed approach demonstrates potential as a reliable, scalable decision-support tool in dermatological practice.

title: An Intellectual Deep Resource Allocation with Task Scheduling for Semi-Synchronous Internet-Based Edge Computing Network
authors: Kavala Devanandam, Abdelhalim Mohammad Jubran, Vunnava Dinesh Babu, Galeeb Shaik, G John Samuel Babu, B Rajalakshmi
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: To improve semi-synchronous Federated Learning (FL) in wireless networks through effective resource allocation, data aggregation, and workload management, we developed IDRTSE is Intelligent Resource Allocation and Task Scheduling for Semi-Synchronous Edge Computing. The clustering-based bandwidth allocation and tiered scheduling to minimize transmission delays based on clients' computational capabilities and channel conditions. A Deep Resource Allocation (DRA) strategy uses a Backpropagation Neural Network (BPNN) with Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to predict optimal bandwidth and workload distributions for adaptive resource utilization. Task scheduling across multiple virtual machines enhances computational efficiency. Optimal resource distribution is linked to increased network longevity by balancing energy across nodes and achieving greater throughput and user satisfaction. Simulation parameter is used to calculate test accuracy, energy consumption, bit error rate, task success ratio, and task success rate for the IDRTSE model.

authors: Hikaru Ikeda, Yuji Ando, Hidemasa Takahashi, Ryutaro Makisako, Takeru Wakamatsu, Tetsuzo Ueda, Jun Suda, Katsuhisa Tanaka, Shizuo Fujita, Hidetaka Sugaya
abstract: Thin films of β-Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, one of the ultra-wide bandgap power semiconductors of β-Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, which are attracting attention as the next-generation devices, were epitaxially grown on β-Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> substrates using the cost-effective mist chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method. A MESFET with a gate length of 0.45 μm and a gate width of 200 μm was fabricated on the substrate. To match the high impedance of the input and output, an amplifier circuit was constructed with a matching circuit connected directly to the high-frequency probe. A gain of 6.5 dB, a saturated output power of 12 dBm, and an added efficiency of 10% were obtained in the 2.4 GHz band. These results suggest that the mist CVD method can potentially be used for epitaxial growth in high-frequency devices at low cost.

title:
Upper 6 GHz Acoustic Delay Lines With Suppressed Group Delay Dispersion and Low Propagation Loss on LiNbO
                    <sub>3</sub>

authors: Dongchen Sui, Shuai Shao, Kejin Dai, Juxing He, Xinjian Ke, Pengcheng Zheng, Shibin Zhang, Xin Ou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This work presents upper 6 GHz (U6G) acoustic delay lines (ADLs) on lithium niobate/silicon carbide (LNSiC) heterogeneous substrates with flat group delay, high phase linearity, and low propagation loss (PL). Based on LNSiC substrates, the high-velocity longitudinal leaky surface acoustic wave (LL-SAW) mode is effectively excited and well confined. The effect of in-plane orientations (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta $</tex-math> </inline-formula>) on group-delay flatness and phase linearity of ADLs is explored, which is not systematically investigated for strongly in-plane anisotropic heterogeneous substrates such as LNSiC. Contrary to the prevailing designs prioritizing high-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$K^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> configurations (e.g., <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta $</tex-math> </inline-formula> = 36°) to achieve low insertion loss (IL) and large fractional bandwidth (FBW), a new ADL design strategy focusing on group delay dispersion suppression is proposed while maintaining comparable FBW. The fabricated LL-SAW ADLs exhibit a center frequency of 6.74GHz, a minimum IL of 9.73 dB with group delay of 50 ns, a 3-dB FBW of 7.66%, and an extremely low PL of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5.03\times 10^{-3}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> dB per wavelength (dB/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda $</tex-math> </inline-formula>). The angular sweep of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta $</tex-math> </inline-formula> validates that the propagation direction of 90° significantly reduces the group delay fluctuation from 46.2% to 13% and the residual sum of squares (RSSs) from 1487.7 to 17.2 rad<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at 100-ns group delay. The experiment results confirm the effectiveness of angle-dependent design in improving group delay stability. These findings provide a new design perspective to develop ADLs with flat group delay, high phase linearity, and low PL for RF analog signal processing in 5G/Wi-Fi 7 systems.

title: Coaxial Gate/Kelvin Interconnects for Reduced Gate Loop Inductance and Common Source Mutual Inductance in Power Semiconductor Packages
authors: Jack Knoll, Mark Cairnie, Christina DiMarino
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: A coaxial gate/kelvin interconnect is proposed to limit gate loop inductance in vertical package structures. While low-inductance solutions have been demonstrated for planar packages, existing interconnects for vertical package structures result in high inductance per unit length. The coaxial gate/kelvin interconnect proposed here has been shown to reduce per-unit length gate-loop inductances in vertical package structures by 50% or more, enabling more advanced vertical package structures. The proposed on-chip coaxial interconnect also results in significant decoupling between the gate and power loops, enabling faster switching and better control of parallel die. This paper explores several materials and techniques for implementing coaxial interconnects. The resultant electrical characteristics, bond strengths, and viability of these approaches were evaluated. A solution for limiting mechanical stress in the bond between the die and the coaxial interconnects due to mechanical loading on the unbonded end was developed. To demonstrate the viability of the proposed interconnect solution, a package prototype which includes coaxial gate/kelvin interconnects was fabricated and characterized.

title: Distance-Gradient Based Convex Optimization for Efficient Near-Optimal Coverage in WSNs
authors: Gaojuan Fan, Feitao Li, Chongsheng Zhang, Hafiz Muhammad Sanaullah Badar, Christian Heumann, Ke Yuan
abstract: Coverage optimization in Wireless Sensor Networks is a fundamental yet NP-hard problem that directly affects monitoring quality and efficiency. Existing solutions mainly rely on meta-heuristic algorithms that use fitness-based evaluations, which often incur high computational overhead, slow convergence, and limited scalability, particularly in real-time or high-precision monitoring scenarios. In this paper, we examine the relationship between effective coverage area and redundant distances in an analytical manner. We then propose reformulating WSN coverage optimization as a Distance-Gradient based convex optimization problem, which can be subsequently solved using the first-order Gradient Descent algorithm or the second-order quasi-Newton algorithm. Extensive comparative experiments against five representative meta-heuristic methods, the Virtual Force Algorithm (VFA) and a general convex optimization algorithm (CVX), demonstrate that our approach achieves near-optimal coverage while preserving network connectivity within milliseconds, highlighting its advantages over existing methods for WSNs coverage optimization.

title: Revisiting the Conventional Formula for the Leakage Factor in Modulated Leaky-Wave Antennas from a Rigorous Perspective Based on Rectangular Waveguides
authors: Pablo Mateos-Ruiz, Elena Abdo-Sánchez, Carlos Camacho-Peñalosa
abstract: The radiation pattern and efficiency of a leaky-wave antenna is dependent on its aperture field distribution. The required field magnitude is achieved by modulating the leakage factor along the antenna, for which an approximate formula derived in the last century continues to be widely used nowadays. However, this expression assumes the field transverse profile inside the guiding structure does not change along its length. This contribution revisits this well-known formula in order to obtain it from a rigorous approach assuming a leaky rectangular waveguide supporting a TE field configuration. Thus, the origin of the limitation of the maximum leakage factor value is explained for this scenario, its influence is quantified by establishing a numerical criterion, and the validity of the approximate formula is justified. Finally, some analytical examples are discussed, showing how the approximate leakage factor differs from the more accurate numerically computed one in limit cases, and how the radiation patterns are affected.

title: Simulation of M13 Bacteriophage-Based Piezoelectric Nanogenerators
authors: Glenn C. Virrey, Himeko Andrei E. Noto, Mariah Jane H. Sicam, Mike Denver M. Tolentino, John Josea R. Umali, Leanne Vince E. Vergara
abstract: Piezoelectric nanogenerators (PENGs) based on biological materials, such as the M13 bacteriophage, present a promising avenue for sustainable and biocompatible energy harvesting. This study investigates the influence of electrode material, geometry, and thickness on the performance of M13-based piezoelectric nanogenerators through Finite Element Analysis (FEA) and MATLAB Simulink circuit simulations. Four electrode materials-gold, silver, copper, and stainless steel-were examined with varying thicknesses (20 µm, 120 µm, and 200 µm) and geometries (square and rectangular). Simulation results revealed that gold square electrodes at 20 µm achieved the highest voltage output, reaching 10.383 V. Statistical analysis using one-way ANOVA confirmed the significance of material selection and geometry in optimizing energy conversion efficiency. The test displayed scores of 0.2017, 0.1845, and 0.2953 for the square electrodes with thicknesses of 20 µm, 120 µm, and 200 µm, respectively, indicating minimal discrepancies between them. Furthermore, circuit simulations demonstrated that energy harvested using the optimal configuration could be effectively stored in a lithium-ion battery. Among the chosen electrode materials, gold generated the quickest charging time of 371.42 hours with and without load, while stainless steel charged the slowest. Notably, thinner electrodes produced better voltage and power outputs, while increased thickness resulted in diminished performance. These findings highlight the critical role of electrode design in enhancing the performance of biologically inspired PENGs and pave the way for their integration into self-powered wearable electronics and biomedical sensors. Future research should explore experimental validation and assess long-term environmental durability for real-world applications.

title: Energy Efficient Negative Capacitance L-Shaped Tunnel Field Effect Transistor
authors: Alok Kumar Kamal, Neha Kamal, Avinash Lahgere, Somesh Kumar
abstract: In this paper, we have proposed a negative capacitance (NC) L shaped channel tunnel field-effect transistor (NC-LTFET), which consists of a hafnium oxide <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{HfO}_{2})$</tex> based ferroelectric (FE) layer in the gate stack. The presence of polarization phenomena in the FE layer tends to enhance the internal voltage and electric field, which result higher ON-state current and steeper subthreshold swing (SS). From well calibrated 2-D TCAD simulation results, it is revealed that the NC-LTFET outperforms the conventional LTFET in terms of both static and dynamic energy dissipation. The NC-LTFET exhibits <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 430 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 10^{4} \times$</tex> higher ON-state current and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{O N} / I_{O F F}$</tex> ratio, respectively, as compared to the conventional LTFET. In addition, the proposed NC-LTFET shows <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 2.2 \times, \sim 10^{2} \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\{\sim} 10^{2} \times$</tex> low SS, switching delay and energy delay product (EDP), respectively as compared to the conventional LTFET. As a result, NC-LTFET is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times$</tex> higher energy efficient for both memory and logic designs switching at ultra-low supply voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<0.2 ~\mathrm{V})$</tex> when compared to the conventional MOSFET and LTFET.

title: Ganoderma Detection in Oil Palm Plantations Using UAV Hyperspectral Imaging and AI
authors: Chee Seng Kwang, Siti Fatimah Abdul Razak, Sumendra Yogarayan, Abdul Mateen Montree Bin Muhammad, Choo Ai Ling, Shahrul Azman Bakar, Haryati Abidin
abstract: The imperative for early and accurate detection of Ganoderma Boninense infections in oil palms is paramount to mitigating the devastating impact of basal stem rot. This disease poses a significant threat to palm oil production and the economic stability of affected regions. Conventional detection methods rely heavily on visual inspection or destructive laboratory analysis, which are time-consuming, labour-intensive, and cost-inefficient for large plantations. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel method for Ganoderma detection using frame-based hyperspectral imaging captured by an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). The approach incorporates feature-based band registration to correct spectral misalignments, followed by dimensionality reduction using principal component analysis (PCA). Support vector machines (SVMs) were evaluated for classification alongside a fine-tuned ResNet50 model. The results demonstrated that the TF- ResNet50 model achieved an accuracy of 84%, with a sensitivity of 74% for early infected trees and a specificity of 86% for healthy trees, underscoring the potential of UAV-based hyperspectral imaging for scalable, non-destructive disease monitoring in oil palm plantations.

title: Ultra-Compact Short Range FMCW Radar Using a Shared TX-RX Antenna
authors: MinHa Kim, Yan Han, Han Lim Lee
abstract: To circumvent the issue of significant space occupation and limited detection range associated with commercial 24 GHz radar sensor and to seamlessly integrated into smart devices, this paper proposed a new ultra-compact and highly isolated frequency modulated continuous wave (FMCW) radar sensor which is appropriate for short range object detection applications. The proposed ultra-compact radar sensor is designed with a shared circular polarization (CP) TX-RX antenna, featuring extensive object detection range which is achieved by using characteristic mode analysis (CMA) decoupling method to attenuate the port-to-port leakage. The Infineon radar Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit (MMIC) is then integrated with proposed antenna, enabling it to accomplish the function of detection. The proposed radar antenna was measured, demonstrating a peak gain of 5.66 dBic for port 1 and 4.09 dBic for port 2 with respect to a port-to-port isolation greater than 30 dB. Additionally, the performance of the proposed 24 GHz radar sensor was evaluated by building holistic radar signal processing platform, showing an augmented detection range from 1 m to 11 m.

title: Unveiling Indian Coral Biodiversity and Health Status via Multi-Task Deep Learning on Underwater Imagery
authors: Sanvi S Shetty, Sudarshan K, Swathi, Varshini, Sowmya, Prashanth Kannadaguli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: The invaluable coral reefs, which are essential for marine ecosystem worldwide and especially in India, face serious threats from global warming, sea water pollution, and increasing sea temperatures. This environmental destruction causes extreme coral bleaching, illness, and ecosystem collapse, damaging sea life and effecting communities in the coastal regions which are dependent on these ecosystems for sustenance. Traditional methods for monitoring coral health, like manual surveys, are slow, costly, and obstructing rapid, comprehensive understanding. To solve this problem, our project presents an automated, efficient approach for coral reef health evaluation using deep learning on underwater images. We started with data collection and expansion, generating a dataset of over 100,000 coral images for model training using image augmentation. During the second phase, ten diverse deep learning models, including custom CNNs and pre-trained architectures like InceptionV3, were created. The third phase focused on fine-tuning these models, resulting in considerable increases in performance. Specifically, models like SimpleCNN and InceptionV3 achieved a remarkable 96% classification accuracy on a 20,000-image test set, successfully solving problems like class imbalance and overfitting. This project provides a strong groundwork for a reliable coral health monitoring system, offering marine experts a fast, accurate instrument for monitoring reef conditions and detecting initial signs of stress indicators, ultimately safeguarding India's invaluable coral reef biodiversity.

title: Enhancing Privacy Protection in Speech using Compressive Sensing Framework for Secure Speech Applications
authors: Sneha Mariya Vincent, Arun Sankar M. S.
abstract: Speech is a natural and convenient communication medium that is widely used in many applications such as emotion recognition, speaker authentication, and healthcare monitoring. Its growing integration into voice assistants and IoT devices raises a critical privacy and security concerns related to sensitive information leakage that leads to identity theft, and voice cloning. Existing privacy-preserving methods provide partial safeguards but are still vulnerable to data breaches. The proposed method converts raw speech at the input stage into a representation that is unintelligible to humans, thereby safeguarding sensitive information while preserving the essential features required for downstream tasks. Its effectiveness is demonstrated through successful implementation on four speech emotion recognition models, followed by performance evaluation. Furthermore, we conducted a comparative feature analysis between the standard and privacy-preserving domains to highlight the method's robustness and effectiveness.

title: Lane Changing Trajectory Tracking Control for Heavy Commercial Vehicle Platoon with Energy Consumption Optimization
authors: Jinqi Zhang, Maode Yan, Shifeng Huo, Lei Zuo
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper studies the lane changing trajectory tracking control approach with optimal energy consumption for heavy commercial vehicle platoon. To begin with, the dynamical model for heavy commercial vehicle with tractor and trailer and the lane changing trajectory based qunitic polynomial model are presented. After that, taking the energy consumption as control objective and considering all vehicle constraints, a nonlinear optimal control problem is proposed. To simplify the solving process, the optimal objective and constraints are decomposed into X and Y directions. Then, the nonlinear optimal control problem is transformed into linear control problem. Furthermore, the optimal tracking control model is discretized and the problem can be simplified into nonlinear programming (NLP). Finally, numerical simulations are provided to show the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approaches.

title: AI-Driven Decision Support Systems for Strategic Management in Smart Industries
authors: Rajesh Kumar V, P. Sathyaraj, Ashwini L K, Shreevamshi Naveen, Vasujadevi Midasala, Krishnamoorthi M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Industry 4.0 changes quickly, creating huge amounts of information from linked physical systems, internet-connected devices, business software. It's getting harder to make good choices in modern factories because things change quickly, are complicated, or are unpredictable. This work presents a computer system that uses artificial intelligence to help managers make better choices for businesses in modern industries. The system combines different kinds of information, uses sophisticated methods to forecast outcomes, suggest actions, builds confidence for managers with clear explanations of how decisions are made. The system uses small, independent services, packages them for easy movement, manages them across different computing locations like data centers or directly on devices, to handle growth with speed, provide quick responses, help with fast choices. Testing shows the system predicts better than traditional methods, saves a lot of money when suggesting actions, builds confidence with managers. This research shows how smart systems can help people make better choices, leading to stronger, smoother, more flexible plans for modern factories.

title: M3D-HFL: A Dual-Metric Approach for Malicious Model Detection in Hierarchical Federated Learning
authors: Kaijie Fu, Zheyu Gu, Yucui Ying, Jinpeng Zhang, Chuanhua Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL), as an advanced distributed learning paradigm, introduces edge computing layers to enhance system scalability but simultaneously expands the attack surface for poisoning attacks. Traditional defense mechanisms typically rely on single-metric approaches, which prove inadequate against sophisticated poisoning strategies in hierarchical architectures. To address these limitations, we propose a robust HFL framework that employs dual-metric malicious model detection. Our approach integrates Euclidean distance and cosine similarity measurements to comprehensively evaluate model updates from both clients and edge servers. We further leverage Shapley values to ensure fair assessment of model contributions under non-IID data distributions. Additionally, we implement a K-means based clustering mechanism to automatically identify and filter malicious models without requiring predefined thresholds. Rigorous testing on Fashion-MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets in heterogeneous data environments and multiple attack scenarios validates that our method robustly defends against hierarchical poisoning attacks while preserving model accuracy competitive with state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Hierarchical Feature Selection Based on Improved Neighborhood Buckets and Dual-Label Strategy
authors: Danyu Xiao, Shuai Li, Wenhuang Li, Zhifen He
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: To address the limitations of traditional neighborhood rough set methods in feature selection for hierarchical decision systems (HieDS), this paper proposes a hierarchical feature selection algorithm that integrates improved neighborhood buckets with a dual-label perspective. Firstly, neighborhood buckets are enhanced by introducing the median, which improves the robustness of neighborhood partitioning against data noise, with its superiority theoretically demonstrated. Secondly, within the hierarchical classification framework, a lower approximation is defined by linearly combining sibling labels and farthest labels, constructing a positive region that balances both local discriminability and global semantic differences. Based on this, a Neighborhood Bucket-based Sibling/Farthest Label Feature Selection algorithm (NBSF) is designed. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing representative methods in terms of robustness, classification accuracy, and computational efficiency, providing effective theoretical support and implementation approaches for feature extraction and granularity optimization in hierarchical structured data.

title: Optimized CNN Architecture for Superior Detection of Diabetic Retinopathy
authors: Vinod Bhatt, Pragati Sakhuja, Karthik Panicker, Ananya Jha, Abhishek Hanchate, Akula Rajani
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The current paper features an Optimized Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture to achieve the best detecting of diabetic retinopathy. The suggested model incorporates an attention system and transfer learning to improve the precision and efficacy of retina image classification. Concentrating on the important details on the retinal images, the attention mechanism reduces false positives and enhances the detection at an earlier stage, whereas transfer learning enables the tuning of the already trained models such as ResNet and EfficientNet to an acceptable minimum of labeled data. The model, which is developed based on PyTorch, has an accuracy of 94.5% and is better in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score than the traditional CNNs, the VGG16 model, and ResNet50. The findings prove that the optimized architecture is highly effective besides being applicable to real time implementation in clinical environments. The solution offers a strong and scalable method of diabetic retinopathy screening and has great potential in clinical use in the future.

title: Beyond Contact: The Rise of Wireless Human Sensing Technologies
authors: Takuya Sakamoto
abstract: This paper highlights recent advances and outstanding challenges in wireless human sensing technologies that enable the non-contact measurement of physiological signals such as respiration and heartbeat signals, using radar. By eliminating the need for wearable sensors, these technologies create new opportunities for health monitoring, human–machine interaction, and privacy-conscious observation in daily life. Over the past decade, we have developed a variety of signal processing frameworks that include high-resolution human imaging, motion tracking, and physiological signal estimation. These frameworks are grounded in mathematical models of body shape, displacement waveforms, and pulse wave propagation and leverage techniques such as signal decomposition, array processing, and multi-radar fusion. Our approaches have led to practical applications such as sleep apnea detection, multi-person respiratory monitoring, and radar-based individual identification. In addition to technical innovations, this paper addresses critical considerations for real-world deployment—including environmental robustness, ethical concerns, and interdisciplinary collaboration—toward the realization of socially embedded sensing systems.

title: A Scalable Ensemble Machine Learning Pipeline for Robust Financial Fraud Detection
authors: Ayushman Singh, Nishant Nishant, Monalisa Jena, Ranjan Kumar Behera
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Financial fraud detection presents a critical challenge in modern digital systems due to complex transaction patterns, severe class imbalance, and high-dimensional, incomplete data. To address these issues, this work introduces a novel, end-to-end machine learning framework that integrates advanced preprocessing, hyperparameter optimization, and ensemble learning tailored specifically for large-scale, imbalanced fraud data. Leveraging the IEEE-Computational Intelligence Society (IEEE-CIS) fraud detection dataset, a real-world benchmark characterized by missing values and extreme imbalance-we performed comprehensive preprocessing, including imputation, normalization, and feature selection, to improve model readiness and stability. Unlike prior studies that typically optimize individual models, the proposed framework employs Optuna with Tree-structured Parzen Estimators (TPE) for systematic hyperparameter tuning across multiple classifiers: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, CatBoost, and LightGBM. The novelty of this approach lies in the construction of a weighted voting ensemble of the top-performing gradient boosting models (XGBoost, CatBoost, and LightGBM), where weights are adaptively assigned based on model-specific performance. This ensemble consistently outperformed the individual models, achieving the highest Area Under the Curve (AUC) and demonstrating superior robustness across all evaluation metrics, including precision, recall, and the F1-score.

title: Fine-resolution Land Use/Cover Mapping Integrating Random Forest and Phenology Features in Arid Regions: A Case Study of the Tuha Basin
authors: Xiaofeng Peng, Min Yan, Li Zhang, Fanquan Kong, Yingwen Hu, Bowei Chen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: Arid regions have become critical areas for global climate change and ecological degradation studies due to their fragility and high sensitivity. In this study, fine-resolution land use/cover mapping in Tuha Basin was conducted using multi-source remote sensing data and improved random forest algorithm for the years of 2020 and 2023. The results showed that the integration of spectral, radar, terrain, and texture features significantly improved classification accuracy. The phenology feature, in particular, enhanced the ability of identifying land cover. The overall classification accuracies for 2020 and 2023 were 90.68% and 93.02%, with kappa coefficients of 0.9027 and 0.9268, respectively. This research addressed the challenges of remote sensing classification in arid regions, such as uneven land distribution, high spectral homogeneity, and significant seasonal variations. By integrating multi-source remote sensing images, seasonal temporal features, and automated machine learning algorithms, the study achieved high-resolution land use/cover classification. This work provides data support and a scientific basis for regional land use sustainability studies and dynamic land management.

title: Design of Lithium Battery Test System Based on Quadruple Four-Switch Buck-Boost Converter
authors: Suyuan Yuan, Qingsong Wang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: This paper presents a lithium battery test system integrating a quadruple four-switch Buck-Boost converter with an adaptive extended Kalman filter for SOC estimation. The system achieves wide voltage conversion, low ripple, and high SOC accuracy, demonstrating enhanced performance and robustness.

title: Qualitative Comparison of Fuzzy-Set Theory and Rough-Set Theory for Breast Cancer Diagnostics System
authors: Julaika Begum K, Ashiq Irphan K, Anitha Gnanaselvi J, A Subashchandar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Objectives: The research work aims to conduct a detailed comparison of Fuzzy Set Theory and Rough Set Theory in breast cancer classification using the Wisconsin Breast Cancer Diagnostics Dataset, focusing on their ability to handle uncertainty, granularity, and discriminative power. Methods: The study applied both Fuzzy Set and Rough Set Theories to classify instances in the Wisconsin dataset. Key metrics for evaluation included accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, AUC-ROC, and robustness against data noise. Findings: Fuzzy Set Theory demonstrated an accuracy of 95%, sensitivity of 96%, and an AUC-ROC of 0.97, showcasing its superior performance in managing imprecision in data. Rough Set Theory, while slightly less effective in these metrics with an accuracy of 93% and an AUC-ROC of 0.95, excelled in interpretability and managing data with less noise. Novelty: This study uniquely quantifies and contrasts the capabilities of Fuzzy Set Theory and Rough Set Theory in the context of breast cancer diagnostics, a critical area in medical technology. By providing empirical data on key performance metrics under standardized conditions, it fills a gap in existing literature that often discusses these theories separately or qualitatively. Furthermore, the analysis of these frameworks' robustness against data noise introduces a novel perspective on their practical applicability in real-world clinical settings, offering valuable insights for future CAD system enhancements.

title: A 56~81 GHz Frequency Quadrupler with 19.4 dB Conversion Gain and 8.07 dBm Output Power Using Harmonic Trap in 28nm CMOS
authors: Yuchi Liu, Jiacheng Guo, Yuan Du
abstract: This paper presents a millimeter-wave frequency quadrupler, implemented using 28nm CMOS technology. The quadrupler consists of two-stage frequency doubler and two-stage power amplifier(PA). Harmonic traps are placed in each stage to improve the harmonic suppression capability of the overall circuit. The quadrupler achieves an output power 3-dB bandwidth(BW) of 56~81 GHz, the saturated output power(P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf>) is 8.07 dBm, the peak conversion gain(CG) is 19.4 dB, and the fundamental, second and third harmonic rejection ratio(HRR) are greater than 55 dBc, 41 dBc and 33 dBc respectively. This performance makes it particularly suitable for signal sources requiring high spectral purity and low input power.

title: Design and Implementation of Phased Array Beamforming for 5G Networks using SDR
authors: David Louie J. Bedia, Alberto S. Bañacia, Edward M. Querikiol
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This paper presents a practical implementation of a phased array beamforming system for 5 G networks using Software-Defined Radio (SDR). As the demand for high-speed, low-latency wireless communication continues to rise, beamforming and millimeter-wave (mmWave) technologies play a crucial role in enhancing 5 G performance. To address this, the Analog Devices CN0566 (ADALM-Phaser) kit was integrated with a PlutoSDR and controlled through MATLAB and Python environments to perform both simulated and realworld beamforming experiments. Direction-of-Arrival (DOA) estimation algorithm using Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) was implemented to demonstrate adaptive beam steering and interference suppression. System calibration ensured consistent phase and gain across all array elements, while measured radiation patterns confirmed precise beam steering toward target directions. Experimental results demonstrate that the SDR-based phased array can dynamically steer beams and mitigate interference effectively. The study validates the feasibility of SDR platforms for $\mathbf{5 G}$ beamforming applications and offers a flexible foundation for future research in adaptive and reconfigurable wireless systems.

authors: Stephen Makonin, Yongfu Li

title: Novel Dual-modulation Out-phasing Power Amplifier with Arbitrary Loop network
authors: Yixi Tang, Wenjie Feng, Weiwei Wang, Wenquan Che
abstract: A novel load modulation architecture is proposed to extend the output power back-off range (OBO) of the Out-phasing power amplifier (OPA). The proposed architecture adopts an arbitrary loop network to realize dual-modulation, which overcomes the limitation of traditional OPA wherein the modulation angles at saturation and back-off are constrained to sum to 90°. The proposed arbitrary X1 network replaces the conventional parallel reactive compensation branches, serving as the key mechanism for enabling the second stage of load modulation. The dual load modulation architecture introduces an additional mode of load modulation to the OPA, thereby expanding its architectural possibilities and design flexibility. To validate the feasibility of the proposed architecture, a dual-load modulated OPA was designed and implemented using commercial GaN devices. The proposed OPA achieves 45.1-dBm saturated power at 2.6 GHz. The modulation angles corresponding to the saturation and 9 dB back-off conditions are 10° and 65°, respectively, resulting in drain efficiencies of 75% and 59%.

title: Network Traffic Prediction Based on Graph Neural Network and Anomaly Detection
authors: Liu Bo, Liming Zheng, Kongpeng Wei, Xiaolong Li
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Communication and Networking (ICN)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of network scale and the increasing complexity of traffic patterns, traditional network traffic prediction and anomaly detection methods are difficult to effectively capture the spatial dependencies in network topology. In this paper, a graph neural network (GNN)-based network traffic prediction and anomaly detection framework is proposed, which models the network topology into a graph structure and uses the spatiotemporal graph convolutional network (ST-GCN) to capture the temporal evolution and spatial propagation characteristics of network traffic at the same time. Experimental results show that the proposed method is better than the traditional method in terms of traffic prediction accuracy and anomaly detection performance, with a 23.7<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup> reduction in predictive MAE and an anomaly detection F1-score of 94.3%.

title: Effect of high temperature on electrical properties of PI film and analysis of aging mechanism
authors: Xinxin Zhang, Shengda Li, Yuanxiang Zhou, Xiaoli Duan, Hongbin Dan, Bo Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: To elucidate the aging behavior of polyimide (PI) films used in motor insulation under high-temperature conditions and its influence on electrical performance, thermal-oxidative aging experiments were conducted on PI films. The evolution of electrical properties, including surface charge decay rate, breakdown strength, and volume conductivity, was systematically characterized for samples aged for different durations. In addition, changes in the cross-sectional micromorphology were examined to correlate structural degradation with performance deterioration. The results indicate that high-temperature thermal oxidation induces molecular chain scission within the polyimide matrix. With prolonged aging, the volume conductivity increases, the surface charge dissipates more rapidly, and the breakdown strength decreases markedly. These findings provide valuable insights into the degradation mechanisms of polyimide films and offer a basis for assessing the reliability of motor insulation systems operating under high-temperature environments.

title: Fireseed: A Prompt-Driven Self-Terminating Personality Module for Large Language Models
authors: Cong Pang, Boyao Yan, Yuqi Zhu, Chunwei Xu, Bowen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: This paper proposes Fireseed, a logic-defined and prompt-executable module designed to simulate self-referential personalities within large language models (LLMs) and achieve structurally stable termination. Unlike traditional prompt strategies that rely on linguistic pattern recognition or semantic embeddings, Fireseed constructs a recursive chain purely through logical structures. By incorporating entropy threshold control, similarity evaluation, and recursion depth limits, it enables a controllable self-referential halting process. Experiments demonstrate that Fireseed exhibits consistent self-referential behaviors across multiple commercial models—including Grok, Gemini, Kimi, and DeepSeek—highlighting its universality, stability, and potential for tool-like deployment.

title: AI-Driven Secure and Cloud-Native Microservice Architectures for High-Performance Financial and Hardware Accelerator Systems
authors: Vikas Nagaraj, Sandeep Reddy Gundla, Pradeep Rao Vennamaneni
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This research describes an end-to-end architecture for financial systems that is capable of bringing together cloud-native microservice architecture with artificial intelligence and hardware accelerators. We have Kubernetes based containers and orchestrated containers using service mesh control plane technologies, real-time AI based threat mitigation using transformerbased detection models. Zero Trust security based on mutual TLS authentication and Policy based access controls based on Istio and Envoy proxies. Hardware acceleration: FPGA, GPU cluster helps for transaction processing in ultra-low latency in the sub-millisecond range. KServe Enterprise intelligence gives intelligent load balancing and predictive scaling with machine learning models. Kernel-level monitoring by eBPF integration, and network security integration of Cilium are examples of how performance improvement could be measured (latency reduction by 40 % and availability of 99.99 %) showing that the framework is suitable for mission-critical financial applications.

title: The Role of Innovation in Driving Sustainable Economic Development: Integrating Environmental Sustainability with Economic Growth
authors: Xiaoyu Mo, Yiran Ouyang, Yongliang Chen, Yuxing Liang
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Innovation is a central component in balancing the economic development with the ability of the natural environment to support such development. In light of the current crises including climate change and dwindling resources, new solutions have to be fostered for the worldwide sustainable economic growth. This research aims at determining the rolebetween innovation, economic growth, and environmental sustainability by using secondary database sources as major data sources such as published journals, researched reports, and cases. The study shows that technology increases sustainability and strengthens business resistance by utilizing appropriate policies and collaborating with other companies. Therefore, this paper advances the knowledge on how dissemination of innovation fosters inspirations of sustainable economic development bearing interventionist data for policy makers and other stakeholders.

title: Beyond Memorization: Generalizable Snake AI with DDQN in Cluttered Environments
authors: Peram John Wesley, Samson Arun Raj A
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The classic Snake game has long served as a common benchmark for testing Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) agents. While traditional open-field versions provide a simple platform for training, they often fail to properly evaluate an agent’s ability to generalize, as agents can exploit repetitive, memorized patterns rather than developing adaptive strategies. To address this limitation, an "obstacle-rich" Snake environment is introduced in which static obstacles are randomly positioned at the start of each episode. This setup introduces spatial constraints that demand more complex reasoning and prevent reliance on brittle policies. A Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN) agent is designed for this setting, supported by a compact 16-dimensional state representation incorporating diagonal obstacle detection for enhanced navigation in cluttered spaces. Comparative and ablation experiments demonstrate that the proposed representation, together with the stability of the DDQN framework, are both crucial for achieving strong performance. The findings demonstrate that this environment serves as a rigorous benchmark for policy generalization in DRL-based pathfinding. These findings have direct implications for real-world scenarios, such as the navigation of autonomous robots in constrained settings.

title: Network Penetration Testing: A Comprehensive Review of Tools, Vulnerabilities, and AI-Driven Solutions
authors: Kunal Jinta, Kapil Sethi, Abhineet Anand
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: Network penetration Testing (or pentesting) is a positive way to find vulnerabilities associated with the increasingly complex world of IoT, Cloud, and 5G. In this discussion paper, we examine the evolution of declining penetration testing tools, from simple tools such as Nmap and Metasploit, to the emergence of sophisticated Artificial Intelligence (AI)-powered platforms like Darktrace and GuardiCore. We discuss the categories of known vulnerabilities, including misconfiguration, weak authentication, and outdated software, and how different AI model architectures, particularly reinforcement learning and large language models, can be leveraged to address components of the mission, such as automating reconnaissance, identifying vulnerable systems, and generating exploitation vectors. Although AI will increase speed, scale, and ease of use, challenges such as trust, explainability, and robustness against adversarial attacks remain significant hurdles. We underscore the necessity of a hybrid, human-in-the-loop model where AI augments human expertise, a framework often mandated by compliance and ethical considerations. In this respect, we identify the need for a strong explainability framework and a consideration of ethical issues and auditability aspects throughout any automated testing framework. Lastly, we suggest future planning for research and development into kinds of autonomous (self- learning) frameworks that will grow with changing adversarial threats using AI, while also lamenting the diminishing role of humans to augment (collaborate with) AI, in what is an important field of cybersecurity.

title: Enhanced Resolution and Accuracy of the 2D-MUSIC Algorithm Using Virtual Antennas for DOA Estimation
authors: Takumi Matsumura, Yudai Handa, Naoki Omi, Haruki Inoue, Jaesang Cha, Chang-Jun Ahn
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: To efficiently transmit desired signals to devices via beamforming, accurate estimation of the Direction of Arrival (DOA) is essential. For two-dimensional (2D) Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) systems, a DOA estimation method based on the Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) algorithm using virtual antennas has been proposed. However, because the virtual antennas are positioned between the real antennas, the effective aperture cannot be extended, resulting in limited resolution. Furthermore, the conventional way of noise generation for virtual antennas often produces unstable variance, leading to larger estimation errors. This paper proposes an improved method that enhances resolution by extending virtual antenna placement beyond the real array and stabilizes the noise variance through a refined generation process. Simulation results confirm that the proposed method achieves superior resolution and lower estimation error compared to conventional techniques.

title: Transforming E Commerce in the Middle East with AI Driven Personalization and Cultural Insights
authors: Charu Bisaria, Aaied Eqab Muraay Majed, Hanumantha Rao Battu, Al-Hussein Maysir Majid, Adnan Burhan Rajab, A.Balakumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: AI personalization tools within e-commerce help companies connect better with customers through customized suggestions and automated services plus data predictions. Consequently, the effectiveness of e-commerce AI personalization tools is often hampered in the non-Western markets due to their lack of cultural and linguistic adaptation. To address this problem, this study employs recommendation systems and Natural Language Processing NLP tools that work with Arabic dialect variations and cultural nuances, which it faces in the Middle East. The aim is to create an AI framework incorporating personalization technology and a cultural adaptation approach in order to provide tailored and ethical suggestions. This study converted deep learning-based recommendation systems to work with Arabic datasets and improved Transformer-based NLP to get better sentiment analysis and user experience optimization. Hofstede’s cultural dimensions provide a framework for advisor-tailored recommendations and the factors for Middle Eastern consumer preferences, religious issues, and shopping behavior. Finally, the proposed framework shows clear superiority in both personalization, based on the accuracy of the suggested items and their sentiment interpretation. It also introduces a bias evaluation methodology capable of decreasing 25% the level of demographic biases, establishing a benchmark for responsible AI practices. A significant conclusion of the results is that they demonstrate the growth of Middle Eastern e-commerce through improved user engagement and trust. This research demonstrates how AI systems could help users to become attached with their cultural identity and increase inclusivity and scalability in e-commerce domain.

title: An Application of LLM for Vehicle Carbon Footprint Estimation: A Prototype Using Google Gemini Flash
authors: Chacharin Lertyosbordin, Pakorn Piyapan, Teerasith Vorarutapibal, Krittinut Rungsithum
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: This research presents an application of a Large Language Model (LLM) for vehicle carbon-footprint estimation through a web-application prototype using Google Gemini 2.5 Flash. The system allows users to input natural-language descriptions of vehicles, such as "Toyota Camry 2.5, 2021, 70 km trip," which Gemini interprets to infer missing technical parameters, including fuel efficiency and emission factors. Thirty synthetic vehicle records were analyzed by comparing LLM-derived CO₂ estimates with reference values calculated using the IPCC (2006) Tier 1 methodology. After excluding the top 10% of outliers, the model achieved a Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) of 16.39% and a Pearson correlation coefficient (r) of 0.955, indicating strong agreement with conventional computations. The results confirm the feasibility of using LLMs for contextual, data-driven carbon estimation, demonstrating their potential for scalable and transparent sustainability applications leveraging multimodal reasoning capabilities.

title: Impedance and Radiation Phase Tunable Miniaturized PIFA with a Single Varactor for 6G FR3 Beamforming-IC-Less Array Antenna
authors: Woojun Lee, Jaehoon Kim, Jinhyun Kim, Jungsuek Oh
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to the design of varactor-integrated impedance-radiation-phase-reconfigurable antenna (IRPA), inspired by a polarizable meta-atom radiator in a leaky-wave antenna. Central to this innovation is the development of a compact planar inverted-F antenna (PIFA) with a novel use of a varactor in the PIFA, positioned between one of its shorting pin and a ground, enabling a continuous phase reconfiguration. The designed IRPA maintains high radiation efficiency above 75% and boresight radiation pattern while covering 70% of a full tunable state of the element in a standing wave series-fed array. This enables a cost-effective solution to antennas for mobile hand-set in 6G FR3.

title: Is the Prediction of Olympic Medals Feasible
authors: Jiaming Li, Jiaqi Hu, Pengkai Ma, Haosen Wang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: This research constructs a data-driven prediction model to dissect the influencing factors of Olympic medal acquisition.Firstly, select the historical medal data published on the official Olympic website for data preprocessing, filter out outliers, and normalize the data. Subsequently, 112 indicators, including the effect of the host country, the comprehensive strength of the nation, and the strength of the events, are collated as the model training set. In the model construction, based on metrics such as RMSE,MAE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, four alternative models including XGBoost are comparatively analyzed, and ultimately Bayesian Ridge Regression is selected as the final prediction model. Utilizing this model, the medal table for the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics is predicted. The research also attains three original insights, such as the notable disparities in the predictability of medals among different events, quantifying the traditional advantages of various countries in specific events, and uncovering the differences in medal predictions between gender events.

title: Spaceborne SAR Interference Suppression Based on a Digital Subband Filter Model
authors: Xuezhi Chen, Xutao Yu, Yuan Mao, Xinyu Guan, Jiale Chen, Yan Huang
abstract: This paper designs a digital subband filter (DSF) to suppress radio frequency interference (RFI) received by the spaceborne synthetic aperture radar (SAR). Typically, SAR systems operate on a much wider bandwidth than RFI and interference appears only in a few subband components. Hence, the DSF can filter out the subband components polluted by interference in a wide signal spectrum. We construct the DSF model based on a low-rank representation (LRR-DSF) framework and derive its closed-form solution via the alternating-direction method of multipliers (ADMM). In each iteration, the optimal filter weights are updated until the model is convergent. We can apply the trained filter to homologous interference (HI) with the same spectral characteristics for rapid suppression. Real spaceborne SAR data working in the C-band are used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: BrainDepth: Brain Signal Analysis for Neuro-Fuzzy Modeling of Subjective Depth Perception
authors: Padmanava Biswas, Samrat Mondal, Debarghya Chowdhury, Sarasij Das, Mousumi Laha
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: BrainDepth system presents an innovative methodology for assessing subjective differences in depth perception using Brain Signals analysis. Depth perception is divided into three levels: short-range, mid-range and long-range based on alpha power activity elicited from EEG signal recordings from the occipital, parietal, and prefrontal regions of the brain. The proposed neuro-fuzzy model combines the power associated with understanding EEG signals with the adaptable reasoning of fuzzy logic to classify something based on considerable variability between each of the individuals tested. Results indicate that the classifier can reliably differentiate depth perceptual abilities and thus represents an efficient method to assess a characteristic by non-invasively measuring brain electrical activity. This method has potential applications in several high stakes fields where accurate spatial judgments are critical, such as aviation; real time procedures, such as surgery that requires accurate depth cues; or clinical processes, such as diagnosing depth perceptual impairments. The primary contribution of this work is a neuro-physiological signal processing and intelligent classifier used together as a measuring tool in either applied settings or as scientific research in the field of vision science or cognitive neuroscience.

title: Industrial IoT Enabling Model Predictive Control for Dynamic Inventory Management in Smart Warehousing
authors: S. Surya, IrshadullahAsim Mohammed, Kapil Tiwari, Rahul Pradip Sharma, P. Deepika, C Selvaraj
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Smart warehousing has been more rapidly developed with automation, the Internet of Things as well as data analytics requiring more flexible and intelligent methods of inventory management. In dynamic and uncertain situations where demand changes, lead times, and resource constraints, traditional inventory control methods are unable to adjust in some cases. This research presents a Model Predictive Control (MPC) dynamic inventory management strategy in smart warehouses. Mathematical proactive decision-making, which leverages real-time data and predictive modelling, enhances inventory levels, minimises retaining and shortage costs, and makes operations more responsive with MPC. The proposed solution unites inventory dynamics, system constraints, and demand forecasting into a predictive control mechanism, which reinvents decisions by new data feeds again and again. Based on results of the simulation, the MPC-based model proves to be significantly superior to conventional methods in the dimensions of resilience, adaptability, and cost effectiveness in a variety of operating conditions. The system is also designed in a modular form which also enables real-time feedback and automatic control, which is achieved by the seamless interaction with the IoT devices and warehouse management system (WMS). This paper illustrates how inventory management can be transformed in smart storage through MPC as a means of offering a scalable and ingenious method of managing complex logistics environments that harbor much uncertainty and unpredictability.

title: An Enhanced Feature Extraction and Classification by Applying Deep Learning Methods Using Mammogram Dataset for Cancer Detection
authors: B Bala Krishna, Mohyedin Hamza, J Kumari, R Premkumar, A Sangeetha, Asha V
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Breast cancer remains a major cause of mortality in women worldwide, necessitating improved detection techniques for better survival outcomes. This research introduces the Enhanced Feature Extraction and Classification by Applying Deep Learning Methods Using Mammogram Dataset for Cancer Detection (EFCDMC) model, which combines advanced deep learning methodologies for mammogram analysis using two datasets: a new high-resolution BI-RADS annotated dataset and the INbreast dataset. Batch Normalization (BN) is implemented for faster convergence, while the Flatten-T Swish (FTS) activation function is used to reduce gradient issues. A dynamic multi-component loss function for accurate localization and classification of breast lesions, NASNetLarge, is used to capture intricate structures. A decoding network for detailed feature maps employs the WELM for effective tumor classification across BI-RADS categories. The overall Results of EFCDMC, accuracy, running time, precision, and confusion matrix are experimental analysis of the EFCDMC model.

title: EDA-UNet: An Efficient Dual-Attention UNet for Remote Sensing Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yue Li, Xuechao Zou, Shun Zhang, Dengji Zhang, Shiying Wang, Pin Tao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: In this paper, we propose EDA-UNet, an Efficient Dual-Attention UNet designed for remote sensing semantic segmentation. By integrating a novel dual-attention mechanism, EDA-UNet enhances feature representation while maintaining an extremely lightweight architecture. We validate our model across diverse remote sensing datasets with different annotation granularities, achieving state-of-the-art performance. Specifically, EDA-UNet achieves an mIoU of 69.97% on the fine-grained dataset and 78.11% on the coarse-grained dataset, with only 1.45M parameters and 17.92G FLOPs. These results demonstrate that EDA-UNet not only surpasses existing methods in segmentation accuracy but also significantly improves computational efficiency. Extensive experiments and ablation studies further verify the effectiveness of the proposed dual-attention design. Thanks to its strong balance between performance and efficiency, EDA-UNet provides a practical and scalable solution for real-world remote sensing segmentation tasks, setting a new benchmark for lightweight semantic segmentation models.

title: Design of Low-Power Digitally Controlled Oscillator for All-Digital PLL Receiver in Zero-Energy IoT Devices
