authors: Jacob Anthony M. Agito, Xi Zhu, Jefferson A. Hora, Haniah Mohammad
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices in the era of sixth-generation (6G) wireless communication demands ultra-low power and high-frequency circuit solutions to support sustainable, near-zero energy operation. As IoT devices become more ubiquitous in applications such as smart environments, industrial automation, and wearable electronics, there is a growing need for compact and energy-efficient frequency generators capable of operating in the millimeter-wave spectrum. This study presents the design and analysis of a Digitally Controlled Oscillator (DCO) operating at 45 GHz, conforming to the IEEE 802.11aj standard, and implemented using GlobalFoundries 22-nm fully depleted Silicon-On-Insulator (FD-SOI) technology. The oscillator core adopts a complementary Colpitts topology, chosen for its efficiency and suitability at high frequencies. Frequency tuning is achieved through a digitally controlled switched capacitor array, implemented with lowleakage transmission gates. Operating at a low supply voltage of 0.8 V, the proposed DCO achieves a power consumption of only 5.959 mW and demonstrates excellent spectral purity, with a phase noise of −99.03 dBc/Hz at 1 MHz offset, making it ideal for ultra-low-power mmWave receivers in dense IoT networks.

title: An Integrated Framework for Robust ESS Scheduling under Load Uncertainty Using Deep Learning
authors: Taehyun Kim, Jaewoong Lee, Jangkyum Kim, Gyeong Ho Lee
publish: 2026 International Conference on Electronics, Information, and Communication (ICEIC)
abstract: This study proposes an integrated framework for day-ahead scheduling of energy storage system that jointly addresses load-forecast uncertainty, battery degradation, and costefficient operation in industrial facilities. A hybrid CNN-LSTM model is developed for load prediction, and prediction errors are analyzed across four time slots to generate realistic load scenarios using truncated normal distributions. These scenarios are incorporated into a robust optimization framework that minimizes time-of-use electricity tariffs and battery degradation costs. This approach ensures a balance between economic efficiency and operational stability. Simulation results using real industrial data from South Korea demonstrate that the proposed framework reduces total electricity cost by 12.78% compared with the case without an energy storage system, validating its practicality for robust ESS scheduling.

title: Johnson Graph Decomposition Integrated with Artificial Intelligence for Enhanced Cancer Diagnosis
authors: B. Uma, Regan Murugesan, J. Juli Amala Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advances in Next-Gen Computer Science (ICANCS)
abstract: Combining the artificial intelligence (AI) with the Johnson graph decomposition, it presents a new computational paradigm that can be used to model complex biological data structure-awarely in order to enhance the diagnostics of cancer. The hybrid framework suggested identifies relational structures of biomolecular markers using Johnson graphs which is preferred because of its combinatoric features and high capacity to describe connected subsets. These structures are then captured and categorized using the AI techniques, such as deep learning and pattern recognition models, with a level of accuracy that was not achievable before. With this method, diagnostic uncertainty on complicated oncology data sets is successfully removed and concealed connections are made apparent through translation of gene-expression profiles and mutation landscapes into Johnson-graph topologies. Therefore, the combination of AI and Johnson-graph decomposition provides an enormous jump in accuracy of structurally informed diagnosis of cancer. This paper also details the hybrid structure that uses Johnson graphs to reveal patterns of relationships of biomolecular markers whose richness is combinatorially rich and accurately represent interconnected subsets. Subsequently, AI algorithms, such as deep learning and classical pattern-recognition algorithms, are applied to these structures to obtain, so far, unsurpassed accuracy of understanding and classification capabilities. Diagnostic ambiguity in the high-dimensional oncological data is reduced by the methodology, and latent interactions are revealed by reconstruction of the gene-expression data and mutational landscapes using Johnson-graphs. It has the ability to be modified to fit a variety of cancer types and omics platforms due to its inherent flexibility thus providing it with the ability to become a revolutionary tool in precision oncology.

title: Robust Heart-Rate Monitoring Under Sleep Postural Variability Using a 24-GHz MIMO FMCW Radar
authors: Zhiwei Zhang, Keke Zheng, Jiayu Zhang, Yijing Guo, Changzhan Gu
abstract: Frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar is widely used for vital sign monitoring. However, most existing methods focus on supine posture, limiting their effectiveness in real-life scenarios where individuals may sleep in various postures. This paper proposes a robust algorithm for accurate heart rate estimation across various sleeping postures. The chest displacement is first demodulated from the MIMO radar beat signals. A hybrid filtering technique is then applied to suppress the respiratory fundamental and harmonic components. Finally, cross-correlation is used to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the separated heartbeat motion, ensuring reliable performance under posture-induced signal degradation. In the left lateral posture, the proposed algorithm effectively separates heartbeat motion and enhances its SNR, enabling accurate heart rate estimation, whereas conventional method suffers from severe interference by respiratory harmonics and noise. In continuous heart rate monitoring experiments across four sleeping postures, the proposed algorithm achieves over 90% accuracy, achieving up to 18.34% improvements over conventional method, confirming its robustness and accuracy under sleep postural variability.

title: A 2-6 GHz 10 W High-Power GaN Power Amplifier Using Extended Matching Technique
authors: Yu-Chun Lin, Chun-Wei Lin, Kun-You Lin
abstract: This paper presents a 2–6 GHz broadband high-power amplifier (HPA) with enhanced power density, implemented using the WIN 0.25-μm GaN HEMT process. An extended matching technique is adopted for the interstage and output matching networks, enabling the amplifier to deliver over 10 W of output power across a wide frequency range with a 100% fractional bandwidth. The two-stage PA exhibits a small-signal gain ranging from 13.8 to 21 dB and a saturated output power (P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf>) exceeding 40.2 dBm, while achieving a maximum power-added efficiency (PAE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf>) above 21% throughout the entire band. Moreover, the core area of the proposed PA occupies only 2.74 × 2.72 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, resulting in a power density (mW/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) that is highly competitive with prior state-of-the-art designs.

title: G-Band CRLH Substrate-Integrated Waveguide Slot Antenna in Glass-Based IPD Technology
authors: Shuping Li, Yusiang Wu, Yu-Hsiang Cheng, Chung-Tse Michael Wu
abstract: This paper presents a G-band composite right/left-handed (CRLH) substrate-integrated waveguide (SIW) slot antenna implemented using glass-based integrated passive device (IPD) technology. The antenna achieves compact size and wide bandwidth by leveraging the negative- and zeroth-order resonances of the CRLH structure. A hot via configuration is incorporated to spatially separate the feed pads and the radiating aperture to different sides of the chip, facilitating accurate on-chip radiation pattern measurements. The glass substrate also helps enhance bandwidth and gain performance, similar to a dielectric lens. A fractional bandwidth of 16.2%, ranging from 221 GHz to 260 GHz, with |S11| < -10 dB is achieved and verified by measured results. Far-Field radiation measurements exhibit good agreement with full-wave simulations, validating the antenna’s suitability for sub-THz antenna-in-package (AiP) applications.

title: Gamified Social Collaboration via Mesh CoP: Effectiveness in Enhancing Cybersecurity Awareness
authors: Maykin Warasart, Pallop Piriyasurawong, Panita Wannapiroon, Prachyanun Nilsook
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: Cybersecurity awareness is not just about knowing what threats exist—it’s about being ready to act when they appear. While technical defenses continue to evolve, human behavior remains a critical vulnerability. This study explores how a gamified Mesh Community of Practice (Mesh CoP) can enhance both cybersecurity knowledge and behavioral readiness in organizational contexts. Building on earlier conceptual and architectural work, we implemented the Mesh CoP in a real-world setting, combining peer collaboration with collaborative game mechanics designed to simulate threat scenarios and encourage proactive engagement. Participants took part in structured activities that emphasized shared learning, challenge-based interaction, and reflection. Using a pre-post experimental design, we measured changes in cybersecurity knowledge and behavioral responses, focusing on indicators such as response frequency, accuracy, and consistency. Results demonstrated statistically significant improvements in both, with stronger alignment between what participants knew and how they responded. These findings suggest that gamified social collaboration within a Mesh CoP can effectively strengthen cybersecurity awareness, foster behavioral resilience, and offer a scalable model for learning.

title: ST-QoS-A*: Spatio-Temporal QoS-Aware A* Routing on Time-Expanded Graphs for LEO Satellite Constellations
authors: Xin Lu, Zhaopeng Ning, Gang Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Large-scale Low Earth Orbit (LEO) constellations such as Starlink and OneWeb are creating highly dynamic inter-satellite networks, where rapid topology evolution poses major challenges for routing optimization. To guarantee end-to-end Quality of Service (QoS) under such spatio-temporal dynamics, this paper proposes a Spatio-Temporal QoS-A* (ST-QoS-A*) routing algorithm. Built upon the Time-Expanded Graph (TEG) model, the algorithm introduces a transmission-time-aligned cost accumulation mechanism and a physically admissible heuristic bounded by light-speed propagation delay, ensuring both temporal consistency and optimality. The algorithm is still effective under polar orbits, despite minor performance reduction due to frequent occlusions. An event-driven adaptation mechanism further enables real-time responses to congestion and link disruptions. A dynamic simulation platform integrating AGI STK 12 and MATLAB is developed to validate the proposed approach. Compared with traditional shortest-path routing, ST-QoS-A* increases the task success rate by over 100\%, reduces the average propagation delay by 10–20\%, and decreases the maximum link load by more than 60\%.The results demonstrate that ST-QoS-A* effectively balances delay, congestion, and stability while maintaining low computational complexity, providing a practical and scalable solution for QoS-aware routing in future space–ground integrated networks.

title: Preserving Cluster Identity Across Time: an Incremental Cosine Similarity Approach
authors: Adarsh Nair, K.K. Aishwariya
abstract: In many real world applications, such as customer behavior analysis, data distributions evolve gradually over time. Traditional clustering methods, which retrain models from scratch at regular intervals, often fail to preserve the fine grained dynamics within clusters as they evolve. In this paper, we propose an incremental clustering framework that maintains cluster continuity across sequential time periods. Our approach clusters new incoming data independently and then maps the resulting clusters back to existing clusters by computing cosine similarity between cluster centroids. If a sufficiently similar match is found, the cluster is continued; otherwise, a new cluster is initialized. This method enables accurate tracking of cluster evolution over time, capturing subtle shifts in cluster characteristics without abrupt reassignments. Experimental results on synthetic and real world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in preserving cluster lineage and detecting emerging behaviors. Our framework offers a simple yet powerful solution for time sensitive applications where maintaining historical cluster context is critical.

title: An 84-95 GHz CMOS Downconverter with a 22-to-35 GHz IF for Multi-band Radiometers
authors: Chien-Hao Hsiao, Rou-Yin Huang, Shih-Hao Lai, Yi-Fu Chen, Hong-Yeh Chang
abstract: This paper presents an 84-95 GHz downconverter with a 22-35 GHz IF bandwidth for multi-band radiometer applications, implemented in a 90-nm CMOS process. A six-stage common-source amplifier is employed to enhance gain and reduce the noise figure, while the mixer adopts a gate-/drain-pumped architecture with a Marchand balun to improve LO-to-RF isolation. The downconverter achieves a conversion gain of 3.3 dB and a minimum noise figure of 10 dB at 87 GHz. The proposed downconverter consumes only 15 mW of dc power and occupies a compact chip area of 1.4 × 0.84 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Optimal Variable Gain Sliding Mode Controller Using Grey Wolf Optimization for Pitch Stabilization of Twin-Rotor MIMO System
authors: Koteswara Rao Palepogu, Subhasish Mahapatra, Atanu Panda
abstract: Helicopters play a pivotal role in military and rescue operations, necessitating precise control during critical maneuvers such as hovering, take-off, and landing. Stabilizing multi-rotor systems becomes increasingly challenging in the presence of external disturbances. This work has been implemented in a twin rotor MIMO (TRMS) system that mimics a helicopter model. This study introduces an innovative method for regulating the pitch angle of a twin-rotor MIMO system through a variable-gain sliding-mode controller. The proposed controller integrates a twisting algorithm with errordependent variable gains, offering improved control efficiency compared to fixed-gain methods. In this work, the proposed controller parameters are optimized using the Grey Wolf optimization algorithm, ensuring accurate tracking and robust performance. Simulation result outcomes validate the capability of the controller to achieve precise pitch tracking under system uncertainties and actuator faults, highlighting its potential for real-world applications. Besides, the robust behaviour is analyzed under various uncertain scenarios to highlight the effectiveness of the proposed control.

title: Multi-Scale Contextual Feature Fusion Network for Robust Skin Lesion Recognition
authors: D. Jenilarani, M Soujanya, K Ganapathi, Ashraf Shaqadan, S Naveen Kumar, Selvakumar T A
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: To increase the quality of the diagnostics and reduce the mortality rates, melanoma must be identified at the initial phase of its development, yet the automated skin lesion analysis is becoming a challenging task due to irregular structure, inter-class similarity, and imaging artifacts. In this paper, the proposed multi-scale contextual feature fusion network (MCFF-Net) that has proven to be effective in the recognition of skin lesions is proposed as the solution to these problems. Compared to the more traditional multi-scale methodologies, MCFFNet is a model that contains a contextual attention mechanism that aids in the capture of the semantic dependence between lesion areas and their surroundings to ensure the further differentiation of visually similar classes. It is based on the idea of learning both finegrained textures and deep semantic details, using a hierarchical multi-scale extraction block and then adapting to combine shallow and deep features without lesion edges, an idea referred to as context-guided fusion. A refining process further cancels the background noise and sharpens the contours in order to make it robust in a wide imaging condition. It is highly tested over benchmark dermoscopic datasets, such as ISIC2018 and HAM10000. Experimental findings indicate that MCFFNet has a total accuracy of 98.3%, better sensitivity, specificity and AUC than state-of-the-art techniques. The combination of contextual feature fusion can considerably improve the boundary delineation and misclassification rates and makes MCFF-Net a promising and stable framework to be used in clinical practice to detect early-stage melanoma.

title: Identification method of DFIG control parameters based on time-domain response sensitivity weight
authors: Jifeng Cheng, Chao Wang, Qi Jia, Xinghao Wang, Xingyu Jiang, Hongbo Sun, Yuchen Wang
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: With the large-scale integration of doubly-fed wind turbines ( DFIG ), the influence of its dynamic characteristics on the transient stability and power quality of the power grid is becoming increasingly prominent. However, since the wind turbine control strategy and electromagnetic model are often provided in the form of ' black box ', the internal mechanism is opaque, which makes it difficult to accurately simulate the fault response of the unit. Therefore, the identification method of the key parameters inside the unit from the external operation data has become the core path to break through the ' black box ' limitation, which can not only construct a general high-precision ' white box ' simulation model, but also provide theoretical support for transient stability assessment and low voltage ride through (LVRT) capability optimization. In this paper, a differential evolution control parameter identification method based on time domain response sensitivity weight is proposed to solve the problem of DFIG black box modeling. Firstly, the time-domain sensitivity model of control parameters covering the whole working range is constructed. On this basis, a DE optimization algorithm with adaptive sensitivity weight is designed. By dynamically adjusting the mutation amplitude and crossover probability, the accuracy of parameter identification is improved. The typical simulation results show that the proposed method is superior to the traditional DE algorithm in terms of identification accuracy, computational efficiency and working condition adaptability.

title: Hybrid IDS System with Neural Algorithmic Reasoning and Evolutionary Feature Selection for Internet-Based Optimized Communication
authors: Sugunakar Mamidala, Ibrahim Mohammad Khrais, Sayana Kondalarao, N Sirisha, Vijilius Helena Raj, Ramya M
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: To improve security in Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) environments within Industry 4.0, we developed a HINEIO is Hybrid IDS with Neural Reasoning and Evolutionary FS for IoT Security. A multistage hybrid framework that combines optimized deep learning, evolutionary computation, and hierarchical reasoning to enhance intrusion detection accuracy. A pretrained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and transfer learning to extract features from IIoT network traffic while tuning essential hyperparameters using Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) to mitigate overfitting. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) layers capture temporal dependencies, facilitating the detection of complex cyberattacks. A Neural Algorithmic Reasoning (NAR) pipeline classifies both known and new attacks using hierarchical inference structures. To enhance detection, HINEIO distinguishes between types of zero-day attacks by analyzing reclassification patterns and employs a Genetic Algorithm (GA) for effective feature selection, minimizing redundancy and maximizing diversity. The simulation parameters were used to calculate HINEIO, training and testing average value analysis, accuracy, loss, precision, recall and computational time.

title: A Comparative Performance Analysis of Classical and Gradient Boosting Machine Learning Algorithms for Breast Cancer Prediction
authors: V. Nanammal, Balaji Vasan R J, Gopinath T, Nishanth E
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Breast cancer remains a leading cause of mortality among women globally, making early and accurate diagnosis paramount for improving survival rates. The proliferation of medical data has catalyzed the application of machine learning (ML) for developing robust diagnostic decision-support systems. This study conducts a rigorous comparative analysis of four prominent ML algorithms for the task of breast cancer prediction using the benchmark Breast Cancer Wisconsin (Diagnostic) dataset. We evaluate two classical models, Gaussian Naive Bayes and a Decision Tree Classifier, against two state-of-the-art gradient boosting ensemble methods, XGBoost and CatBoost. The models are systematically assessed using a suite of performance metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Our experimental results demonstrate the marked superiority of ensemble techniques, with the CatBoost classifier achieving the highest classification accuracy of 97.36 %. This performance surpasses that of the other tested models and is competitive with established benchmarks in the literature. Feature importance analysis derived from the CatBoost model identifies cell nucleus characteristics such as ‘mean radius’, ‘mean texture’, and ‘mean perimeter’ as the most influential predictors, aligning with established clinical pathology. This work underscores the potential of advanced boosting algorithms like CatBoost to provide reliable, data-driven predictions, thereby offering a valuable tool for healthcare professionals in the early detection of breast cancer.

title: Grey Water Management and Reuse Wetland Management Water Conservation
authors: Jayarama Pradeep, Akshaya K, Durgadevi S
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: Water scarcity is a critical global challenge, intensified by the burgeoning demand for fresh water resources. This paper presents a comprehensive solution for effective grey water management and reuse through the implementation of a vertical/horizontal Sub-Surface Flow (SSF) Constructed Wetland (CW) system. The project directly addresses the challenge posed by the Smart India Hackathon (SIH) focused on sustainable water management for educational campuses/institutional housing. The system is engineered to treat residential grey water, significantly reducing its Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD), Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD), and Total Suspended Solids (TSS) to meet reuse standards. Key innovations include integration with a low-cost, Arduino-based IoT monitoring system for real-time outflow quality and the use of locally sourced filter media. The treated water is successfully repurposed for non-potable applications like toilet flushing and landscape irrigation, demonstrating a potential 45% reduction in fresh water consumption. This study validates the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of CW technology as a decentralized, eco-friendly approach to urban water conservation.

title: Six-Port Interferometric CW Radar for Vibration Detection
authors: Kamil Staszek
abstract: In this paper, an interferometric continuous-wave radar intended to vibration detection of small amplitude is reported. It adopts recently reported topology of a six-port reflectometer exhibiting simultaneously optimum measurement uncertainty distribution and high immunity to power detectors’ impedance mismatch. Here, its performance is further enhanced for complex radar echo measurement. The developed radar operates at the frequency of 12 GHz with the aid of a single 4x4 antenna array. For an experimental verification a metal element mounted on a shaker is used. It is shown that with the use of the developed radar vibrations having amplitudes in micrometer range are detectable.

title: A Novel Multifunctional Filtering Leaky Wave Antenna in Rectangular Waveguide Technology
authors: Rushiraj Jawale, Gowrish Basavarajappa
abstract: In this paper, we have presented a novel filtering leaky wave antenna using radiative band-pass filter concept in rectangular waveguide technology. The design methodology achieves radiation by utilizing slots in each of the resonator cavities of an iris coupled band-pass filter. For proof of concept, an 8<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> order filtering leaky wave antenna is designed, fabricated, and tested at a center frequency of 9.7 GHz with a fractional bandwidth of 4.6 %. Furthermore, the radiation pattern of the filtering leaky wave antenna exhibits beam scanning 30 degrees in the entire operating band with a peak realized gain of 13.3 dBi. The beam scanning rate of the proposed filtering antenna is 6.5 degree per fractional bandwidth. The proposed methodology is scalable to realize high gain leaky wave antennas with higher order filtering response. Furthermore, it offers multifunctionality within the same size of the waveguide band-pass filter, thereby contributing to the overall system miniaturization.

title: Graph Neural Networks-Guided Code Optimization System for Software Performance Enhancement
authors: Ramachandiran R, B. Harichandana, Vikram Kaushik, Vijaylaxmi Inamdar, S. Prathi, Vikas Raheja
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The rapid nature of software system development necessitates new approaches to guarantee that there is optimization of code to achieve improved performance. The paper presents a Graph Neural Networks (GNN)-based Code Optimization System, which takes the form of graphs and represents the programs to identify performance bottlenecks and offer performance optimization guidelines. The system is founded on the applications of Graph Convolutional Network (GCNs) as its core method and realized with the assistance of the PyTorch Geometric system that can be discussed as effective in the capture of syntactic and semantic dependencies within the code. Experimental results of running benchmark software projects have revealed that there have been tremendous gains in the execution time, use of memory and computation efficiency compared to the conventional code optimization tools. The developed solution offers the software developers with a scaled and automated solution, reducing human intervention and reducing the high-performance software development cycles.

title: An FPGA Based Accelerated Perception Sub-System
authors: Sreehari N, Naghulram S P, Sahil Ahamed S, Shreyas Srinivas A, Yamuna B, Karthi Balasubramanian
abstract: This paper outlines an FPGA-accelerated perception sub-system for real-time object detection employing the You Only Look Once (YOLO) v5 model. The system uses the Deep Learning Processing Unit (DPU) B4096 implemented on the Xilinx Kria KV260 platform for efficient deep learning inference. The implementation shows a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.5 \times$</tex> speedup over traditional CPU solutions, achieving up to 59.94 Frames Per Second (FPS) for the YOLOv5 Nano model and 17.4 FPS for the YOLOv5 Large model. The system further shows high detection accuracy with a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.76 and an average Intersection over Union (IoU) of 0.72 for the intelligent traffic perception system. The implementation incorporates optimized data pipelines, quantized models, and high-throughput inference methodologies within the Kria Docker environment, utilizing OpenCV, Xilinx Runtime(XRT), and Vitis AI Runtime (VART). The results highlight that an effective hardware-software co-design approach, combining high throughput, optimal resource utilization, and reliable inference accuracy, significantly enhances the performance of FPGA-based AI (Artificial intelligence) workloads in applications such as surveillance, industrial automation, and production line safety.

title: A Compact 40 dBm GaN/SiC MMIC Doherty Power Amplifier at FR3 Band for 6G Applications
authors: Hossein Zaheri, Gregor Lasser
abstract: In this paper a Doherty power amplifier (DPA) on a 120 nm GaN on SiC monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) process is presented. The measurement results show a peak power added efficiency (PAE) of 27-43% and 6 dB backoff PAE of 19-37% with a peak delivered output power of 37-41 dBm across the operational band of 13-16 GHz. This performance is achieved in a compact active area of 2.6 × 1.7 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, which makes it an efficient and scalable solution for the high power and bandwidth requirements of 6G networks.

title: Automated Firmware Extraction and Vulnerability Analysis in Embedded IoT Devices: A Replicable Cybersecurity Infrastructure Framework
authors: Lucas O'Mahony, Toyosi Oyinloye, Jakir Hossain, Lee Speakman
abstract: Embedded IoT devices continue to exhibit firmware-level weaknesses caused by unsafe memory operations, legacy libraries and inconsistent validation. These issues are difficult to study due to proprietary firmware, diverse hardware interfaces and the lack of reproducible extraction workflows. This work presents a lightweight, repeatable framework for firmware acquisition and analysis using low-cost hardware and open-source tools. The framework integrates UART, SPI and chip-off extraction with an automated pipeline using magnify.py for ELF triage and flawedfunctions.db, a database of 224 unsafe <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C$</tex> functions. Experiments on four devices show that chip-off extraction provides complete and reliable firmware acquisition, while UART and SPI offer partial access depending on hardware design. Automated scanning revealed recurring high-severity memorysafety issues, with Ghidra confirming insecure calls such as strcpy and sprintf. These early results demonstrate the feasibility of accessible, reproducible firmware extraction and static analysis. Future work focuses on scripted Ghidra analysis, broader device testing and enhanced risk scoring.

title: CenterMamba-SAM: Center-Prioritized Scanning and Temporal Prototypes for Brain Lesion Segmentation
authors: Yu Tian, Zhongheng Yang, Chenshi Liu, Yiyun Su, Ziwei Hong, Zexi Gong, Jingyuan Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Brain lesion segmentation remains challenging due to small, low-contrast lesions, anisotropic sampling, and cross-slice discontinuities. We propose CenterMamba-SAM, an end-to-end framework that freezes a pretrained backbone and trains only lightweight adapters for efficient fine-tuning. At its core is the CenterMamba encoder, which employs a novel 3×3 corner→axis→center short-sequence scanning strategy to enable center-prioritized, axis-reinforced, and diagonally compensated information aggregation. This design enhances sensitivity to weak boundaries and tiny foci while maintaining sparse yet effective feature representation. A memory-driven structural prompt generator maintains a prototype bank across neighboring slices, enabling automatic synthesis of reliable prompts without user interaction, thereby improving inter-slice coherence. The memory-augmented multi-scale decoder integrates memory attention modules at multiple levels, combining deep supervision with progressive refinement to restore fine details while preserving global consistency. Extensive experiments on public benchmarks demonstrate that CenterMamba-SAM achieves state-of-the-art performance in brain lesion segmentation.

title: EIF: An Ensemble Interpretability Framework for Transparent and Accurate Machine Learning Predictions
authors: K. Pavithra, M. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: In machine learning, the trade-off between predictive accuracy and model interpretability presents a fundamental challenge-particularly in domains where trust and transparency are critical. We propose a generalpurpose solution, the Ensemble Interpretability Framework (EIF), which integrates diverse base learners using ensemble techniques such as voting and stacking. A novel Performance-Interpretability (PI) value is introduced to quantify and constrain the trade-off between model performance and explainability. EIF is designed to be model- and domain-agnostic, adaptable to various classification or prediction problems. To demonstrate its effectiveness, we apply EIF to the Adult Income dataset, showing that it maintains interpretability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PI} \leq 0.05$</tex>) without compromising accuracy. Evaluation through confusion matrices, ROC curves, and feature importance confirms its practical applicability. This research offers a reusable, interpretable ensemble modeling framework applicable across domains including finance, healthcare, and social science.

title: AI-Optimized Blockchain Architecture for Enhancing Digital Financial Service Efficiency in Indian Banks
authors: Shilpa Sachdeva, Shravani M, Lisha A, Manoj S, Dhanushree R M, Suhas C
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The development of digital financial services in India has expedited the need to have secure, transparent, and high-performance systems of transactions. The traditional blockchain models in banks are limited to latency, high computational, and scale restrictions with a large number of transactions. To overcome these challenges, an AI-optimized blockchain architecture is presented, which is an adaptive selection of consensus, predictable node management, and fraud detection. It uses a federated trust evaluation model based on deep learning optimization and executed on TensorFlow and Hyperledger Fabric. Experimental testing shows that there is a 36.2% increase in transaction throughput, a 27.5% decrease in the latency, a 33.3% reduction in the consensus time, and a 7.6% enhancement in the accuracy of detecting fraud when compared to the PBFT conventional systems. Also, the total energy demand was reduced by 18.9 %, which is a confirmation of sustainability. The proposed framework would greatly improve the efficiency of digital financial services in Indian banks with secure, transparent, and adaptive financial services that are appropriate in real-time transaction ecosystems.

title: Design and Evaluation of a VR-Based Interactive Property Tour System for Real Estate Applications
authors: Utpal Saikhedkar, Girish Mude
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: This paper introduces the design and assessment of a VR-Based Interactive Property Tour System as a means of improving the visualization of real estate and interaction with customers. It combines Z-Score Normalization to preprocess data, consistency of data to all metrics of user interaction, and Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) to determine the most powerful behavioral and environmental variables that can influence the user experience. Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM) is a classifier that was built with the help of the TensorFlow software to predict the user engagement and their intentions to buy the product with a high accuracy. The experimental analysis shows that the accuracy of the system, spatial perception and the quality of interaction are considerably enhanced in comparison with the old models of virtual tours. The findings suggest the increased user satisfaction and lesser navigation latency, confirming the efficiency of the machine learning-immersive virtual reality combination. The presented research adds to the scalable, AI-powered intelligent property visualization, which is a more realistic, data-driven, and interactive solution to the modern real estate applications.

title: Computational Intelligence Decision Support for Renewable Energy Source Selection Using Extended TOPSIS
authors: Sumathi M, Rathi K, Gayathri K, Jayalakshmi P, Kalaiselvi S, Vinodhini D
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (ICONSTEM)
abstract: The growing demand for sustainable energy, combined with the need for rapid action to address climate change, has highlighted the necessity of selecting the best renewable energy sources. The process of choosing the best renewable energy source is challenging and involves evaluating numerous conflicting factors, including cost, efficiency, resource availability, and environmental impact. This study proposes a novel decision-making framework that incorporates the Fuzzy Harmonic Mean Aggregation operator for Heptagonal fuzzy numbers (FHM_HFN) operator and the Techniques for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method into the multi-criteria decision making (MCDM) Approach. The FHM_HFN operator effectively aggregates expert opinions by capturing the interrelationships between criteria and dealing with data uncertainties. The results of the real-time example show how well the proposed fuzzy decision-making approach works to offer a systematic and transparent approach to evaluating and selecting the renewable energy. The proposed fuzzy harmonic mean operator for the HFN is used to integrate the outcomes of the fuzzy evaluation. This method providesa decision-making tool to the energy planners and decision makers aiming to promote sustainable energy development.

title: A Cooperative Adaptive Low-Frequency Load Shedding Strategy for Regional Power Grids Based on Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Gulizhati Hailati, Da Xie, Jiading Jiang, Tian Wang, Mierzati Dilimulati, Xiaojing Zhang, Qiang Li
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: The integration of high-penetration renewable energy has led to a reduction in the equivalent inertia of power systems, making frequency stability a critical issue. This poses severe challenges to the speed, adaptability, and coordination of traditional Under-Frequency Load Shedding schemes. To address this, this paper proposes a cooperative adaptive load shedding strategy based on Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning. Firstly, the regional power grid is partitioned into multiple agent regions based on electrical coupling, establishing a centralized training with decentralized execution control architecture. Secondly, a novel reward function integrating global frequency stability and local economic objectives is designed to guide the agents to cooperatively learn the optimal load-shedding policy. Then, the Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient algorithm is employed to train the agents, enabling each of them to make fast, distributed decisions relying solely on local observations. Simulation results demonstrate that in low-inertia scenarios caused by high-penetration renewable, the proposed strategy, compared to traditional methods, can effectively raise the frequency nadir by over 0.3 Hz, reduce the total shed load by 10%, and shorten the frequency recovery time. Furthermore, the strategy providing a novel solution for frequency stability in new-type power systems.

title: How Critical Thinking Shapes Student Engagement with AI Tools to Foster Self-Directed Learning
authors: Ratima Singhachotsukpat, Koravick Thiangtham, Cattareya Wilepana, Nanthawan Yaemsawat, Parichart Sisaeng, Noawanit Songkram, Jintavee Khlaisang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Educational Communications and Technology (ICTAECT)
abstract: This study investigates the role of CT in shaping students’ AI literacy and its subsequent influence on autonomous learning (AU) within Thai higher education. Adopting a mixed-methods design, the quantitative phase surveyed 512 undergraduate students from over 20 universities, while the qualitative phase engaged five students based on their CT scores using convenience sampling. Structural Equation Modeling confirmed that CT significantly predicts AI literacy, and AI literacy, in turn, strongly predicts AU, establishing its mediating role between CT and AU. Complementary qualitative findings revealed clear behavioral distinctions: students with high CT skills consistently used AI as a supportive tool for brainstorming, verification, and reflection, whereas students with low CT skills tended toward passive reliance on AI outputs with limited evaluation or concern for long-term implications. The findings underscore CT as a foundational competency for effective AI use and autonomous learning. Pedagogical implications highlight the value of embedding structured reflection activities to encourage students to critically evaluate AI outputs and strengthen their reasoning. In addition, the study emphasizes the importance of clear institutional guidelines and regulations on AI use. Together, these measures ensure that AI serves as a scaffold for learning rather than a replacement for independent effort, preparing students to become autonomous, critical, and responsible learners in an AI-driven society.

title: Design and Analysis of Bipolar Cubic Magnetic Coupler for Multidirectional Wireless Power Transfer to Cluster AUVs
authors: Anqi Hu, Xiangrui He, Yingqin Zeng, Minghai Liu
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: In this paper, a novel bipolar cubic magnetic coupler (BC-MC) for multidirectional WPT system is proposed for charging cluster AUVs. Specifically, the presented BC-MC transmitting coil is composed of four L-shaped coils connected in series, which can supply power to multiple bipolar arc-shaped receiving coils positioned around it. A multi-objective genetic algorithm is employed to optimize the coil parameters, aiming to achieve enhanced coupling and reduced volume. In addition, an LCC-S compensation topology is adopted to stabilize the current in Tx coil under dynamic load variations. An experimental WPT prototype is built and the effectiveness of the proposed BC-MC was verified by the measurement results. While satisfying optimal load, the system can achieve 92.45% efficiency at a power level of 200 W for four AUVs.

title: Post-Quantum Cryptography for FANETs: Evaluation and Comparative Analysis of Key Encapsulation Mechanisms
authors: Marnie McHugh, Bahareh Pahlevanzadeh
abstract: In February of this year, Microsoft released their Majorana 1, a quantum computing unit using topological qubits. Quantum computing is threatening to undermine traditional encryption techniques, and UAV technologies are promising to improve farming, city management, and search and rescue. It is therefore important for us to assess the impact of post-quantum encryption on FANETs as a matter of urgency. This research is the first known to the authors to address KEMs within a FANET setting. This research uses UB-ANC, a NS3-based UAV network simulation technology, and liboqs, a quantum security library, to evaluate the preparedness of FANETs for encryption in this new paradigm. Each of these KEMs are assessed on 3 points: number of successful key exchanges, throughput, and time to complete the key exchange. Beginning by completing a number of exchanges on FANETs of 4, 10 and 20 static UAVs to establish potential candidates, then run 30 minute survey missions on each of those candidates at each network size. These algorithms are evaluated both as KEMs intended to be used in hybrid encryption, and as public key encryption schemes. Evidence is found that Kyber and ML-KEM are both feasible solutions, at all security levels within applications, which require a less than 32 bytes to be transmitted within a single exchange. Evidence that BIKE, at lower security levels, or within smaller UAV networks, is a functional solution is also found. Ultimately, it is our belief that there is promise within hybrid encryption for FANETs, but the use of KEMs as public key encryption is not yet feasible.

title: PID Controller Parameter Optimization for the Ball and Beam System Based on the Gazelle Optimization Algorithm
authors: Feiyu Huang, Hong Fan, Zilei Guan, Yunan Yao
publish: 2025 12th International Forum on Electrical Engineering and Automation (IFEEA)
abstract: Conventional PID controllers face a major drawback in that their parameters cannot be adjusted automatically, while the Gazelle Optimization Algorithm (GOA) is often limited by slow convergence and a tendency to fall into local optima. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes an improved algorithm, GOA-MDES, which combines Mean Differential Evolution and the Simplex Method. The ball-and-beam system, a nonlinear and open-loop unstable benchmark, is employed as the validation platform. The improved algorithm is first evaluated using standard benchmark functions and then applied to PID parameter tuning. Experimental results demonstrate that the GOA-MDES-tuned controller achieves superior performance in terms of steady-state error, settling time, and overshoot when compared with GOA, GWO, and PSO. Moreover, the proposed algorithm shows clear advantages in both convergence speed and accuracy. These findings verify the effectiveness of GOA-MDES and highlight its potential as a general-purpose method for PID parameter tuning in nonlinear control systems.

title: Dual-band counter-CP antenna with wide AR based on metamaterials
authors: Pei-Min Huang, Qing-Xin Chu, Zheng-Hua Rong, Pei-Lin Yu
abstract: This paper studies a dual-band counter circularly polarized (CP) antenna consisting of two square loop antennas. The outer loop antenna consists of multiple segments of capacitive and inductive elements, while the inner loop antenna is a simple square loop antenna, and both antennas have a feed point. When the loop is wound counterclockwise, left-handed circularly polarized (LHCP) waves are obtained below the balance frequency (3GHz), and right-handed circularly polarized (RHCP) waves are obtained above the balance frequency (when wound clockwise, the opposite is true). The antenna has an extremely wide axial ratio bandwidth, with a 3dB axial ratio (AR) relative bandwidth of 25.4% (2.20GHz~2.84GHz) in the lower frequency band and 17.1% (3.27GHz~3.88GHz) in the higher frequency band. At the same time, the radiation patterns of LHCP and RHCP are compared, and the paper also reveals the gain bandwidth and matching characteristics - the impedance bandwidth in the S band (2~4GHz) is very wide.

title: Research on Multi-Granularity Guided Small Object Detection on Water Surfaces
authors: Runze Wei, Guoyin Wang, Qun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Conference on Computer, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (ICCBD+AI)
abstract: Detecting small objects on water surfaces is challenging due to tiny target size, wave and reflection interference, and limited annotations. Traditional methods struggle with accuracy–efficiency trade-offs, especially for densely distributed vessels. We propose MG-Det (Multi-Granularity Guided Detection), a framework tailored for water-surface small object detection. MG-Det adopts a coarse-to-fine inference: a global model ensures high-recall candidate regions, while a lightweight model refines detection within selected windows. A region filtering module reduces redundant inference for efficiency. To further enhance robustness, targeted augmentations—compression, color perturbation, and light-shadow adjustment—improve small object representation. Experiments on a private vessel dataset and the WSODD benchmark show that MG-Det achieves superior accuracy (AP) and efficiency (FLOPs, FPS) compared to mainstream methods. With strong deployability, MG-Det suits edge scenarios such as unmanned surface vehicles, water monitoring, and maritime search and rescue.

title: A Multilingual Intelligent Document Processing System
authors: Ravi Kishore Kodali, Varsha Sanga, Sai Veerendra Prasad Kuruguti, Lakshmi Boppana
abstract: In today's digital world, processing multilingual documents is critical for business, legal tasks, and information retrieval. This study describes a Multilingual Document Processing System that uses Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to extract, query and summarize text in multiple languages. The system employs advanced OCR models to correctly recognize text from scanned documents, images, and handwriting in various scripts. By incorporating RAG, it improves comprehension and response generation, allowing users to retrieve and summarize information in English even when the original language is different. This approach takes advantage of recent advances in natural language processing, large language models (LLM), and multimodal AI to address challenges in multilingual data accessibility, knowledge synthesis, and real-time communication. The system provides a scalable AI-driven solution to improve document processing, eliminate language barriers, and increase global user engagement. AWS services support scalable document processing but cold starts in AWS Lambda hinder real time tasks.

title: ALERA: An Entropy-Based LLM Multi-Agent Framework for Dynamic Risk Quantification in Quantitative Investing
authors: Senmiao Wang, Zhenyu Li, Guanlin Wu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Big Data and Information Analytics (BigDIA)
abstract: The financial services industry increasingly relies on data-driven quantitative investing, with large language models (LLMs) advancing decision-making through improved financial semantic understanding, news-driven forecasting, and trading signal generation. However, traditional risk metrics like volatility, Value-at-Risk, and Maximum Drawdown often fail to capture the dynamic complexity of markets, leading to undetected risks or excessive trading. We propose ALERA, an LLM-based multi-agent framework that uses entropy to quantify decision-making uncertainty and assess risk across four dimensions: expert disagreements, historical experience, market volatility, and stock correlations. ALERA mitigates long-term information forgetting with a memory pool and incorporates stock interactions for robust risk assessment. Our contributions include pioneering entropy-based risk quantification, a unified framework for dynamic trading strategies, and extensive empirical validation showing superior performance in return and Sharpe ratio compared to baseline methods. Specifically, ALERA achieves an annualized return of 26.32% and a Sharpe Ratio of 1.71 for AAPL, with a cumulative return of 6.31% and a maximum drawdown of 3.63% over a three-month period from August to November 2024, outperforming baselines like MACD, KDJ+RSI, ZMR, and SMA.

title: Design of AI Algorithms for Predicting Epidemic Outbreaks
authors: Sharmishtha K. Garud, Monali Gulhane, Kalpana Malpe, Pawan Verma, Shubham Kaldate, Nitin Rakesh
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Symposium on Sustainable Energy, Signal Processing and Cybersecurity
abstract: The speed with which deadly diseases are spreading around the world has made it even more important to have good models that can identify when epidemics will happen. Most of the time, traditional ways of predicting epidemics are based on data from the past and the knowledge of experts. These methods may not be able to handle the complexity of new diseases well. This essay looks at how to create and use advanced AI systems that can predict when an epidemic will happen. These studies use many types of machine learning methods, like decision trees, support vector machines (SVMs), and recurrent neural networks (RNNs), to look for trends in data about early disease spread or guided learning. We suggest a unified method that uses real-time data from social media sites, public health sources, and weather data to make the model better at making predictions. The study also utilizes reinforcement learning techniques to continuously enhance forecasts based on new data received, and the researchers test those algorithms using a variety of data to see how well they work. This includes information about past outbreaks, maps and health reports from various regions. The results demonstrate that the AI-powered method makes high-quality predictions, is timely and offers a substantial flexibility benefit compared to off-the-shelf methods. Combining AI algorithms and real-time monitoring systems can also be used by health organizations and states to inform resourcing, plan actions and mitigations against the spread of outbreaks. The results highlight the potential that AI could have for shaping global health policy and making disease control more nimble and effective.

title: Improved Stability Criteria for Delayed Neural Networks: Further Utilization of Information on Time-Varying Delays and Activation Functions
authors: Yu-Long Fan, Chuan-Ke Zhang, Li Jin, Yong He, Leimin Wang
abstract: This article focuses on the low-conservative stability criteria of delayed neural networks (DNNs). To achieve this goal, new techniques are developed to effectively utilize more system-related information. To use the time-varying delay information, some delay-product terms are introduced into the Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional (LKF), and an extended matrix-injection-based transformation method, which introduces delay-derivative-dependent slack matrices while obtaining the negative definite condition, is proposed. With respect totheuse of activation function information, the terms related to the activation function are fully augmented in the LKF. In particular, by considering the sector-constraint information of the activation function, a new nonlinear-function-dependent functional term is established, and a sector-constraint-dependent matrix-separation-based inequality is developed. By applying the above techniques, several improved stability criteria are derived, and two typical examples are provided to illustrate the advantages of the proposed methods.
